comment: Went here for lunch and it was great. It started with the preserved duck egg which I would actually recommend (just don't ask for a full description until after you eat it!). For the entree we had chicken rice which was awesome. I definitely recommend this for a local meal. We also had the green dragon vegetables (delicious!) and a tofu soup that was awesome. The overall restaurant was very nice and clean and clearly it's a place that locals frequent. I would definitely recommend for a sit down meal and good local flavors.

A classic icon of Singapore's chicken rice scene. This ranks as #3 for me after Tian Tian chicken rice at Maxwell, Toa Payoh Lor 4, aWee Name Kee (the now defunct Novena)Boon Tong Kee also serves Chee Cheong fun instead of rice which is nice. Besides the chicken, we always order the fried bean curd, bean sprouts

A specialty place with good price. Must have: signature chicken + 鸡油饭/literally 'chicken oil rice' (this bowl of rice is heaven on earthnot oily!! flavorful savory chicken aroma mixed with bits of ginger)

What started as a small chicken rice stall in Chinatown has now established its recognition as well as multiple restaurant locations all over Singapore. Boon Tong Kee is often regarded as one of local favorite spots where families and friends gather for good times over delicious Cantonese home-style food. Many regulars come to Boon Tong Kee primarily for their Signature Boiled Chicken or Famous Chicken Rice, also known for its silky white sauce chicken rice. Although chicken is the signature dish here, there is a wide selection of irresistible creations you wouldn't want to miss out. Some of the notable mentions such as Fried Bean Sprouts with Salted Fish, Fried Assorted Vegetables (Kang Kong) with Sambal, Poached Chinese Spinach with Assorted Eggs and Crispy Deep Fried Chicken are quite popular. The options are simply too many to list... if you have the appetite and the belly, I'd say explore and try as much as you can indulge.

Arrived at 9pm on a weekday, expecting a wonderful tender chicken rice dinner I've heard so much about, however I was greeted by an unsmiling waiter. Went thru the menu but It took a full 8 mins before our order was taken. The restaurant was not that full. A couple who came after us was served before us. My wife wanted to walk out, but as good people, we waited. Finally the chicken dish arrived and we tucked in to succulent meal. Meat was tender and the rice fragrant, my rating is based on the service rended.My take: PR Dept of Boon Tong Kee, please arrange some training for your front line staff as they are the ambassadors of your business. The atmosphere killed the enjoyment of having dinner here.

Of course their speciality is the Hainanese chicken rice. We also ordered deep fried prawn balls, 1 whole chicken, and pork ribs. With 5 rice, 5 drinks, peanuts and towelettes, 10% service charge and GST, we paid $90.Place is just a hole in the wall establishment, no fancy decor and average Asian service (no small talk, no refill, no smile).Although the food was pretty good, I don't see how they stay in business charging this kind of prices for food-court quality food.

Boon Tong Kee's chicken rice is classic. The other stuff they try to push on you is passable but just stick with the chicken rice and all will be well. Came here on the second day of CNY and the line was insane with over an hour wait. We had heard the claypot rice here was quite popular and thus we ordered ahead while waiting for our table so the timing synced up. Alas, the claypot rice is alright but very forgettable. But the dependable staples didn't disappoint. Love the fragrant savory rice here. I can eat bowls of it! Paired with the silken white skin and moist chicken, it just works. Another staple, that fried tofu. Impeccable delicate and soft on the inside with a light crispy exterior. I don't know how it holds its texture but when dipped in the salad dressing, so yummy! Oh and that char siew that's already on your table when you're seated... it's just sublime. Being CNY, we also ordered lo hei for some festive cheer and our server was really personable in preparing it. But for everyday classics that won't disappoint, the chicken rice, fried tofu, and char siew are winners for sure. Also this location is open late which is a plus for supper cravings.

First stop after arriving in Singapore, because our hotel was less than 1km away, so we wanted to grab something to eat quickly. I have to say, every dish We've ordered tonight was very very delicious. I have to say each dish had its exact original ingredient flavors and tasted goood.... I often find it hard to taste the ingredients in its very original flavor and still have all the delicious details in sauce without over powering the ingredients... I hope I make sense. :) and it was a plus that the restaurant opens late!

When I think back to my childhood, hainanese chicken rice is one of its highlights. That boneless white tender chicken served on a bed of broth boiled rice took my mother AGES to make from scratch in the UK and was an absolute treat... however, when in Singapore HCR is available on every corner you turn around. #yeay We have been to Boon Tong Kee a number of times, and stumbled across the one on Balister Road after our temple visits. The restaurant is clean and the staff have the usual stiff upper lip until you warm them up with some "xie xie's" and attempting to banter with them. We of course ordered a plate of HC which come with individual bowls of rice (hells yeh). The chicken never fails, especially when you top it off with ginger, sweet soy and chilli. We also ordered a range of dishes from fried tofu (hells yes), baby spinach with salted and century egg, a Cantonese fave, broccoli and mushrooms, "gourmet" fried spring rolls and the seafood horfun. Special shout outs to the tofu which was light with the perfect amount of salty coating and the horfun. Sweet baby J, the horfun was to die for. The sheets themselves were the fattest I've seen. The seafood fresh. The sauce, solid. I was so full but kept going back for more. Downside: A LOT of MSG. MSG is killing my food vibe in Singapore. Please pass me my water bottle, please and thank you.

I've never had chicken rice in a NICE restaurant. I didn't know something like this was possible until I came to Boon Tong Kee. We tried several dishes, including the infamous chicken rice. We also had the preserved egg and char siu appetizers, vegetables with egg and pork with preserved vegetables.Everything was sooooo delicious. This may be the most expensive chicken rice experience I've ever had, but it was definitely the most delicious and satisfying. Although the wait can be long, and the servers not the most friendly in the world, the food is irresistible and there is a parking lot around the back!

Good  restaurant in Ballister area. Definitely one of the popular one for it gets pack and people have to wait when it happens. Came here to try the infamous Chicken rice but I went with my instinct ti try a seafood dish called fish head in black beam sauce. Fish head was good not overdone. Flaky , moist and just seasoned right. The sauce didnt overpower and just the right amount. It was delish. It a little pricey $24 SGD but it was a good portion.I m not sure if this is common to charge customer for towellete and the peanut for what I taught it was a complimentary when the server brought it to us from the beginning. Therefore the 3 stars.
Great atmosphere. Authentic. Hainan chicken rice was fantastic. Cereal prawns were amazing. For greens, had the chili spinach. Highly recommend this local treasure.

This place was close to my hotel and was told it has Singapore's famous 'chicken rice' dish.  I decided to give it a try and it was good.  I have an open mind to food and will try almost anything once.  I didn't like how the chicken looked but it was good.

Ah, the famous Singaporean chicken and rice.  In NYC, chicken and rice is something you get off the street from the Halal dudes.  Here, it's Hainanese chicken.  Weary from a 9 hour flight with layover from Tokyo, I was eager to finally get some grub into my system, so my coworkers who so graciously picked me up from the airport, drove me to Book Tong Kee.One of the (funny) reasons we chose this restaurant was because there was air conditioning, which seems to be a rare thing in Singapore.  Upon sitting down, we were offered (more like advertised) some roast pork.  My boss obliged, so we had some cold roast pork.  Not sure if was supposed to be cold, but it was cold.  Tasted okay... nothing special.We also ordered a tofu dish, chicken and rice, and water spinach (cong xin cai, morning glory, etc).  The tofu was unlike anything I've had before in the States - perfectly battered (?) crispy outer and hot and soft inside.  Chicken and rice was pretty standard - flavorful and tender.  Water spinach - I'm really biased because it's my favorite vegetable, but here, they make it spicy and it's an excellent combination.Not sure how the prices were, but service was okay and the restaurant is fairly clean and pretty nice, actually.

yet another kee and a pretty famous one at that!kee = 記 = to record, mark, note/ to keep in mind, remember/ record, chronicle.and you bet boon tong deserves a kee added to their name.if any rice can be so good you can even eat it on it's own, their chicken rice is it.it is addictive like carbo should be.every grain soaked through with the all important stock used to delicately poach the chicken.every grain stays individually separate yet works collectively to provide a uniquely unctuous mouth feel that is nothing short of delicioussimo.you will probably forget your name as you slip ever so subtly into a food coma.and that is just their chicken rice alone.but what makes this shop special?how about it being their very first restaurant?how about the plentiful parking located just behind?how about the experienced and ever so friendly staff that make appropriate recommendations and always warn me when i try to order too much?how about the bell you can ring for immediate service when they get super busy?how about the extensive zi char menu that goes beyond just their chicken rice?how about it being affordable and yet in air-conditioned comfort?how about just being able to eat chicken rice at 5am in the morning?!your honour, i rest my case.P.S. the bus load of tourists may be a daunting sight.but their specially created takeaway containers make it a swift no brainer option on those occasion(s) you can't get in.

No review is truly fair unless proper shout-outs are made to other Yelpers who have contributed to the success of a "foodie" experience. Although Boon Tong Kee (especially this branch) has been on my bucket list for some time, I never got around to trying it...and when the Yelp King of Singapore found out about it as I was preparing to make my exit out of this little amazing RED dot, he just made it happen.So thank you Sir Nik T. for this wonderful experience and introducing me to what is now my second favorite chicken rice spot in Singapore.Chicken...immaculate.Sauce...just about right.Rice...near perfect, crumbly yet moist. Yeah, near perfection.Yep, first runner up in the chicken rice race and trailing quite closely behind the almighty Tian Tian.Yelp 100: 52/100/My-last-3-weeks-in-SG
When chicken is dry on the inside , is not so tasty Vegetables comes as shown in pocWith end going bad The old flame is gone Prefer loy kee ,

I took my dad here to introduce him to Singapore's famous Chicken Rice. I really wanted to take him to Tian Tian at Maxwell, but I was afraid the heat would be unbearable for him. Being the loving daughter that I am, I opted to celebrate this momentous occasion in an air conditioned environment. :) I normally do take away here, so dining in was a new experience.Unfortunately, our server could barely speak English, yet she still tried to upsell us by suggesting I order the more expensive, not boiled chicken. After declining, I asked for iced water and instead got some weird coconut drink. If you can't even understand the word "water" that's definitely a problem. She did manage to get the rest of our order correct, probably because I pointed on the menu.Despite this, my dad truly enjoyed it, and our bill was under $20. (Then again, we weren't hungry so we didn't order a lot of food.) Takeaway is still a pleasant experience, as the line moves quickly and the food remains tasty by the time I get home. Because of this, I maintain my 4 star rating.

Just getting seated will set you back $5+ from the obligatory boiled peanuts, pickles, and wet towelettes. Came for dinner and found a queue waiting to get in but later found many were picking up their takeaways. We sat on the 2nd floor dining room and the service was very good however, the food arrived at our table sporadically making the dinner awkward as we waited in between dishes, especially the last dish which came  as we were about finished. Ordered steamed eggs (3 different kinds of eggs), side pork with mui choy, stuffed tofu, and famous steamed chicken. The stuffed tofu never made it out to us. Was later told that it was not available ... okkkkkay. We didn't originally ordered the chicken but the waitress was shocked that we didn't and convinced us into adding it, and was glad she did - juicy, flavorful and good portions. Menu was easy to read and catergorized. Will be back to try the many other dishes.

The chicken is tender and tasty, the rice is fragrant and the chilli sauce is good enough to accompany them. Being a well-established brand, it is safe to bring your overseas visitors to Boon Tong Kee for their first taste of our famous Singapore chicken rice.But i feel that the standard has dropped since they decided to expand their branches, and the few that still has standard are their River Valley and Balestier road branchesSide dishes to order when eating there are their bean sprouts and oyster vegetables. A must have to complement the tasty chicken rice.

Went to the restaurant last night as recommended by the Days Hotel staff...they are famous for their chicken rice and honestly it was the best chicken rice I have ever had!! Normally I would have put a 5 stars however,  I was not happy for the fact that their was only a wet naps per persom on the table,  no napkins to either wipe your hands or mouth. We  obviously used the wet naps as it was the only thing on the table to wipe our hands and when the bill came.... SURPRISE!!! There was a 0.30$ charge for each wet nap!! Seriously the waitress should have told us! Anyways,  I would go back only for the chicken rice but for the rest, not that impressed!
This place may be was good before it was run down by tourists. Verse of glutamate salt and sugar in all dishes -- avoid

I came here in hopes of a spirit-lifting meal, but was left disappointed. After being so highly recommended, even by one of my closest friends I found this spot right next to the Shaw Plaza on Balestier road. The service was excellent, quickly showing me to my table and getting my order, it was chicken rice of course. The chicken rice was quickly served, but the first error was spotted when a dirty fork was given to me, I cringe at the very thought... disgusting. I had it replaced and started on the meal. It was utterly a disappointment! The rice was dry and so was the chicken, very difficult to swallow and generally just a complete disappointment! Totalling a 9 dollar something bill I honestly believe and with full conviction say that the average $2.50 chicken rice you find at standard kopitiams are like a million times better! Stay away!This is my first 1-star review, it was truly a let down!

This is the famous one that my mother used to say 'CHOW XIN CHI always come here eat when he comes to Singapore!' Chow Xin Chi is the famous Hong Kong actor/director Stephen Chow. Boon Tong Kee is undoubtedly part of the Singapore chicken rice fame and this Balestier outlet is the first and original branch in Singapore. Over the years it has attracted many tourists and locals alike to try what was hailed as the best chicken rice in Singapore.I remember the best part of the meal was the rice. It was glistening smooth, moist and savoury. One could finish the rice easily without mixing it with the ingredients. The chicken was a hit-or-miss, depending on which day you visit the outlet - meaning it isn't always excellent. That said, it's still a pretty decent meal, though pricier than most chicken rice stalls out there.Oh, and they open till the wee hours.

I have not been in this restaurant for 15 years after I had frankly lousy sweet chicken rice and paid through my nose. Now having tried it again today,  I'm won over. The rice is fragrant and perfectly cooked. The  chicken is very good. We had fish and vegetables too. All good and tasty. You still pay through your nose, but now its worth it.

An Oldie but GoodieI've been a fan of Loy Kee for years now. Unfortunately, it's a little far for me to constantly visit them but they are still one of my favorite chicken rice restaurants to visit when I have the craving. With all the chicken rice stalls and restaurants popping up, with one receiving a Bib Gourmand from Singapore's Michelin guide, what differentiates Loy Kee from the rest of the pack?Why it is still my Go To place for chicken rice. Firstly, the rice. Unlike most places that tend to offer healthier options these days, Loy Kee doesn't. Is it sinful? YES! But it's also bursting with flavour and nothing makes me happier than having oily lips with every mouthful of rice (best time to kiss a loved one). The Chicken. What's popular now is boneless chicken rice, where they skillfully remove all the bones, either from the breast or thighs and serve it beautifully presented on a plate. I, on the other hand, love picking meat of the bones as that's where all the flavours are. Despite being a huge boiled chicken fan, I really love the roasted chicken here. The skin is nice and tasty yet the meat remains juicy and tender. We also get more consistency with the roasted chicken as we tend to realize that the boiled chicken is a bit of a hit and miss, with it sometimes being juicy and tender and other times overcooked and dry. The SoupsAnother trademark of Loy Kee is their soups, with watercress soup being the most popular. The soups are not MSG ladened and my favourite has to be their watercress soup. Served as an individual double boiled bowl or in a traditional soup pot if you order for 2 or more (those old traditional ones our grandmother's used to cook over charcoal), the umami-ness of the pork and the sweetness of the watercress are infused wonderfully into a delightful soup, making it the perfect companion to the chicken rice. The Condiments A chicken rice is only as good as the condiments it comes with and nothing is more important than the holy trinity, Chicken Rice Chilli, Minced ginger and Dark Soy Sauce.While I find the chilli and dark soy sauce here pretty average, the ginger is very nice and adds an even deeper dimension when eaten with the rice. Overview. Again, it's up to personal preference but we really love the rice here and the chicken is good too. Paired along with a soup and the condiment and it makes for one of the best chicken rice in Singapore.

Came here for the chicken rice and here's my take on Loy Kee Best Chicken Rice -The name on the sign is impressive claiming to be the best. Was it? They need to rename the restaurant.Chicken was nice (definitely not "the best") but the portions were too small.  Rice was nice and shiny but lacking any moisture, like it's been sitting around for awhile. The accompanying soup was a notch better than most chicken rice joints. It contained bits of green onions, tomato, and tofu. Unlike some places where it just seems to be a bowl of water from boiling the chicken. Like the option of indoor or outdoor seating. Nice clean shop. Old school decor. Solid seats and tables. The weirdest part about the whole dining experience at Loy Kee was the wait service. We sat down, the waitress handed us the menus, then just stood there waiting to take our order. Usually I'd asked for a few minutes, but this time I decided not to say anything. A couple of minutes passed and I could hear her sighing. That's when I decided to start reading from the menu again ... from the beginning. Thanks for making your customers feel they chose the right place to eat tonight. Staff needs some training on customer service :-)

A taste of old school Singapore!Since my husband was working late and there aren't turkeys readily available on this island, we decided to spend our first Thanksgiving abroad together at Loy Kee. I mean, Hainanese chicken is a perfect substitute for turkey, right?!We were not disappointed. We each ordered their original boneless chicken with all the fixin's and it was absolutely delicious. The portion size was perfect for me; however, for the American appetite it's definitely on the smaller side.I love when my husband introduces me to gems like these on Balastier Road, because it gives me a sense of what Singapore used to be like. Hooray for enduring the test of time!
The restaurant has air conditioning,  I ordered the famous chicken and rice set, but disappointed. I had better ones before. The congee was OK. Would not come for the chicken again.

Since chicken rice is almost like Singapore's national food, I believe I have to try this place out. RIce is good, not exceptional. It is of a smaller shorter grain. The roasted chicken is better than the steamed chicken, which is quite dry in my opinion. The sauces were given on those small trays and it is very hard to get the attention of the servers to give me more sauce. I asked once and was not given the extra sauces that I asked for. I did not try other dishes. Hence, my review is purely based on the chicken rice & the service only, I will not come back to Balestier just for Loy Kee chicken rice because about 100 metres away, there is Boon Tong Kee, which is way better than this.
Well I thought the service was bad in New York but here I am in Singapore. Really opened my eyes! The worst service ever! I won't be back for sure! The food was not that good.

I am going to start this new thing where places I eat at really often gets five stars, even if it is partially out of convenience. I have eaten here probably 15-20 times over the past 6 months. The quality is consistently great and for a restaurant where they serve you, it is frankly underpriced, probably because they are making a dish that is so abundantly available at hawker centers.In and of itself, this place is awesome. The roasted chicken rice is tender and juicy. The bok choy has a lot of those crispy onions on it. They must cook the rice in coconut oil or something for it to taste that good. The only mild downside is that I often want more of the condiments than they give on the tray, especially the thick black vinegar.

Started off with lemonade, holy sweet and sour goodness, got the thirst out of the body quick.The chicken, rice, veggies, soup and the additional pan fried egg, does exactly what they are suppose to-make me happy, and fill up my tummy!

Spicy fried chicken is thumbs up.I am an Arnold's Chicken fan, but Jollibee is good enough for my sudden fried chicken cravings. Little Q, lots of couple seats, smiling crews, and moist fried chicken.Only Pepsi here, so loses a star. I would prefer coke zero to balance out the indulgence.

Jollibee is a well known fast food restaurant from Philippines. When the first outlet was opened in Singapore, it was then known for its super long queue. But now it has since expanded to Changi and now Novena, the queues are not as bad as it used to be.I happened to walk past the outlet at Novena. The queues only had about 6 customers in front. Maybe because it already 9pm, right the peak dinner time. The queue moved quite fast and the staff at the counter was friendly.I decided on the 3 pieces Chicken Joy meal which costs $9.50. It came with a drink and a side. For side there choices of plain rice, french fries, mashed potato and buttered corn. For drink, there was various choices such as Pepsi, 7-up, Mug and mountain dew.The chicken pieces were available in 2 flavours : original and spicy. I had selected the original. The chicken pieces were quite chunky and meaty.The fried chicken went quite well with the brown gravy sauce.
Tender juicy spicy chickenjoy coated with yummy brown sauce, plus very decent spaghetti. Coupled with a refreshing cup of orange juice, I had a rather enjoyable late dinner past 9pm at Jollibee!

This was a must visit since I love Jollibee from the states. I brought along a friend since it was his first time and they did not disappoint at all. The food was outstanding like always and the employees were very friendly.

Great chicken. Not many outlets in singapore so hard to find one. automated ordering cuts he queue. Can do better with fully integrated payment rather than going to counter to queue up again. Very crowded on a weekday night!

If you compare to the very 1st outlet this store have lesser seat, they have more seats for 2 than a bigger group. So you might need to take a longer time to get a bigger seats area if you come in groups during peak hours.  The fired chicken are tender and juicy so is a must try, but again this outlet don't have the full menu, so chicken will kinda your only option for the protein. Go for the original if you can't take spicy food, because the spicy version can but a bit too spicy for my taste.Stuff are friendly even during peak hours so a big thumbs up to them.

Love the spicy chicken joy, enough kick with the Chili and the meat is tender succulent and tasty! Top up to a fragrant juicy savoury taste with the brown sauce and Chilli sauce. Incredible sides too with the rice or mashed potato with brown sauce, particularly love the mashed potato with its buttery taste which goes perfectly with the brown sauce. Perfect mix with a pineapple juice to refresh the taste palate to continually enjoy the wholesome flavors, satisfied!
Love this place! The cocktails are amazing! The staff are super passionate about the drinks and will tailor a cocktail to your taste. Thank you for a great night!

I truly enjoyed my experience here. The bartenders really know how to find you the perfect drink. They start you off with an espresso shot and give you salami bites throughout your visit. Best  if you can get reservations, but we got there really early and they were able to accommodate my group of three. My favorite drink of the night was Peachy Keen. Super sweet and tasty.

Awesome nondescript water hole inside the hotel. One of top 50 bars in Asia. Make sure to try "Cure for all ills." On the 2nd visit, i had the reversed gin and tonic which the bartender torched  the oak to give the drink an oak fragrance to it.

A concept bar that is well executed serving amazing cocktails. You'd never even know it was here but it's fun to see a "secret" speak easy type of place at the hotel you're staying at yet never even know it was there! The cocktails are very mild So you can easily enjoy two or four ;) but unique concoctions with beautiful presentation and balanced flavors.  It's rsvp only and men must wear pants or you can't get in. The spot is smaller inside but with comfortable couches and a small food appetizers style menu.

Very cosy speakeasy that plays lovely prohibition era style music behind an unmarked door at a hotel lobby.Drinks are somewhat smallish but rather tasty. The complimentary slider (before 8:30pm) a welcome gift.Excellent service from staffs.

One of the more convenient speakeasies in Singapore! I love that it's so cozy, though it can be a little loud when it gets crowded. Would definitely recommend you make a reservation (no matter the day). Fairly wide variety in drinks (on the menu) which were potent and tasty; would recommend their take on the gin and tonic. I like their little customization on the ice; I think it was a good touch. I would like to see more of what they could do off the menu the next time I'm back!Food is good; oysters were fresh, and I loved the steak sauce.Servers were attentive and friendly. Special shout out to Kai for being a rockstar!

Our last stop on on our fancy cocktail bar crawl, and probably the best of the lot.  I never would've guessed this hidden, speakeasy like bar would be located right off the lobby of the Marriott on Orchard.  What an awesome surprise!  Cocktails were mostly good, atmosphere was excellent and the place was packed at 4AM.  Despite not having reservations (that seems like a must here), we were able to get seating very quickly.  Only two slight negatives:  my reversed gin and tonic was so smoky that it completely overpowered the entire drink. The smoke was a cool gimmick, but the cocktail needs to still be drinkable and in this case it wasn't. And the quote objectifying women on the mirrored wall was a bit of a turnoff ("Men:  No clothes, no drinks; Ladies" No clothes, free champagne"), especially for a bar going for such a classy, hipster vibe.  Not super cool.  Still, liked the place and will probably come back on my next visit to Sg.

The Other Room is a very cool newish bar in an unexpected place - off the lobby of a hotel and the Marriott Hotel at that.  But they are doing some amazing work here with both infused liquors as well as barrel aged Cocktails, so it's definitely worth seeking out.  Plus, if you ever needed a break from shopping on Orchard Road, this would be a great place although it is open only in the evenings.  Anyway, upon arrival, I received a welcome espresso martini which was served in an eye drop bottle!  Very cool although I opted not to use the tincture and went straight for the bottle .  I tried one of their bottle aged cocktails - Boulvardier - which was really good, as the barrel aging helps smooth out the Campari just a bit.  It was also served with a beer back, which made it doubly enjoyable.  I also tried one of my usual drinks - a Vieux Carre, which was also executed very well.  Overall, I loved the drinks, the concept and the excellent service here.  And it's also great to see a new cocktail bar that isn't on Hong Kong or Amoy Street.  There is a small food menu as well, which I didn't have a chance to try.  But there will be a next time, and definitely looking forward to it.
Great speakeasy. The staff is great and helpful. I don't want to write too much about this place, because I can't do justice. Just visit.
Definitely my new favorite bar in the area. Ambiance is just perfect for a nightcap and pre or post dinner date. Order the reverse gin & tonic!

One of my absolute favorite stops in Singapore. Service is great, drinks are great, and the atmosphere is incredibly fun. Only downside would be price - be prepared to spend $20-25 a drink. Oh, and the few food offerings they have are pretty awesome too.

This place is a hidden gem! Located behind a black door in the Marriott at Tang Plaza is this awesome little bar. The drinks were phenomenal! You are create with a coffee martini as a welcome drink. I had a raspberry sour type drink and then a delicious New York sour with smoke blown into it and a cute marshmallow garnish. I was hungry and got the sirloin as a snack. The entire staff was highly attentive as I also kept finishing my bowl of crackers and it was instantly refilled. I can't wait to come back!
Amazing decor, amazing staff, great menu. Music is a little too loud for a speakeasy, it's a speak-kinda-easy.
Stylish throwback. Great service, fun atmosphere. Even finding it and getting in are part of the experience ;)

Was very close to my hotel which was GrandHyatt Singapore. It's really a good court in a shopping mall. Many different places to eat. I haven't been to a hawker Centre yet but seemed a bit too sterile. Food was very good and price good.
We never thought a food court could be so good and such good value!Tried 3 locations, numerous vendors. All were delicious!You can't go wrong coming to this food court anywhere in Singapore!

Found this place when I had an extreme craving for Xiao Long Bao (XLB) and went to Din Tai Fung.  Prior to arriving I found myself immersed by plenty of aroma that made me question if I were in Foodie Heaven.  How jealous I am that a food court like this does not exist in California.If I could copy and paste this paradigm to where I live, I would become a millionaire because there will be an interminable demand for food like this from where I come from.Also, in the center of this chaos of amazing food, there's a woman quietly selling these amazing tutu coconut or peanut steamed cakes.  I bought 5 for 3.50Sing$.OMG they were sooooo good!I'm coming back here tomorrow and the next day before I go home and cry because I won't be able to walk to this place.
Lots of good options. But overwhelming, but just follow the crowd and you'll end up with something tasty. The hainanese chicken shop here is really good!

With a recent revamp, Food Republic did a good job at changing the mix at the Wisma Atria location. The company also runs Food Opera at ION Orchard, and the food court at Isetan. They complement one another well, and local workers can navigate among the three without feeling bored. Don't know why the sushi and teppanyaki counters are there, since Japan Food Town is literally next door and so much better (also pricier).

Food Republic at Wisma Atria has renovated and it is even better now.I will say skip the other ethnic food and stick to local food. The safer way to tell which stall is good will be by how long the line is.I only tried the food twice since the renovation. But based on what I had, I liked the Yu Kee Yong Tau Foo very much. I have always like this brand and only had it at Bishan outlet and the old food court at Orchard Emerald. So I am very happy it is available here.The items are standard, different from the other yong tau foo stalls, with 5 pieces of tofu and fish ball/fish cake and the noodles are topped with minced meat. I like the set which includes a side of kang kong drizzled with fermented bean curd. So yummy. The soup is also very sweet and tasty.The mee pok stall is also different with fish maw in it. It is not the best bak chor mee but it is decent. Good choice for Orchard Road. The or luak (oyster omelette) was also nice, especially the chili. Skip the Korean ginseng chicken soup which was very bland.Currently there is a 10% discount if you show your passion card.

A good place to visit when you can't really decided what you want to eat, just because this food court give you a variety from la-mian, fish soup to BBQ Chicken Wings Love the chicken/pork cutlet noodles here. You should always go for double cutlet upsize because only additional $0.50 more.
Ordered Japanese food at Goen. Black udon & W-Katsu Curry Rice. Ok taste. But when you are hungry, that's another story.
Very good variety of Singapore food reminiscent of hawkers, but in air conditioned mall.  All tasty and quite reasonably proced.

Say you want cheap but you're a little too intimidated for a full immersion experience at the hawker centers? Start at Food Republic. It's a food court with stalls representing food from all over Asia. We tried several stalls and the Hainanese chicken rice, the Indian stand, and the avocado ice were all really, really good. The options are seemingly endless and everything is clean, with lots of corners for finding a seat. The decor is of course not legit, but it's still super cute.  Only caveat - there are no napkins.

A good place to visit when you can't really decided what you want to eat, just because this food court give you a variety from la-mian, fish soup to BBQ Chicken Wings Love the chicken/pork cutlet noodles here. You should always go for double cutlet upsize because only additional $0.50 more.

If you find yourself shopping in Wisma Atria and you felt the need to grab something to eat, then head off to the Food Republic at the 4th level. You will be welcomed by a variety of cuisines and sometimes an overwhelming crowd. I try to come here for lunch around 11am to beat the usual lunch crowd. Queue's are shorter, and more seats to choose from. My favorite is the fish stall where they serve a variety of ways of cooking fish-deep fried and soup. I tried the deep fried dory twice and it was just ok but when I had the soup dish, it's the constant thing that I order every time I'm here. Also, when it comes to beverages, I don't need to come up to the drinks kiosk, I can just wait for auntie to pass by with her cart of refreshing drinks. One time when I was trying to veer away from the usual lime juice that I order, auntie was really helpful in suggesting other drinks and I opted for the lychee-just to try something new.When you come here, and it happens to be crowded, remember to look for more seats through those corridors and not just settle on the seats you see. Chances are, you might end up a window seat with a great view of Orchard road.

The newly renovated food court at Wisma Atria Level 4 is finally open to public about a month ago! The folks from the Breadtalk Group really know how to make a difference with their food courts - which gives them such an edge above the rest. Each food court has a theme - though most of it relates to our Singaporean heritage, there are some subtle differences. For the most famous Food Republic (and probably with the most expensive rent) it is all back to basics of our Singaporean food roots with the revamp this time round and they have decorated it with all types of vintage items from our past which gives it a really nostalgic flavour and makes it distinctly Singaporean, even if some of the stalls in there hail from different countries and serve other cuisines. It is after all our heritage to have a mishmash of everything. There is a total of 23 stalls, 3 mini restaurants and 1 kiosk. How's that for spoilt for choice? I need to eat at this food court whenever I am in town next time and not bother thinking about restaurants.I would recommend that you make a beeline for their Odeon Beef Noodles - where my favorite is the dry noodles that comes with soup that packs a punch. Otherwise there is always the safe choice of Thye Hong Hokkien noodles which made this branch famous in the first place when it first opened. People are still queuing to this date, which is good. Their Indonesian Padang stall also has rather hefty meals that is sure to fill up a hungry person or 10.

Best food court eveR!!If you're a tourist like me, you'll pass this court on your way towards the Sentosa Express. The place is always bustling and filled with all types of food from many different countries i.e. japanese, indian, taiwanese, vietnamese, indonesian, korean, etc, etc. For example my varied lunch that day consisted of dim sum, indonesian bbq chicken and rice and nasi lemak. Wtf?? The food options can make you quite dizzy if you don't know exactly what you want. Anyways everything I had was really good but I constantly remember how amazing that Indo BBQ chicken was *drool* Also, the place is kept exceptionally clean for how busy it gets. I might just be an easily amused tourist but if I ever visit Singapore again, I'm definitely coming back here.
Lots of good options. But overwhelming, but just follow the crowd and you'll end up with something tasty. The hainanese chicken shop here is really good!

This place is pretty, the food is okay, but the extra dollars we're forking out for the slightly fancier packaging just affects the foundations of 'hawker food'. I would steer clear of the nasi padang and 'economic' rice if I were you - you could pay up to $6.50 for a $3.50 meal you could usually get at your hawker centre!The only stall (if they are allowed to be called that) that I patronise often is the Rojak Vendor, which serves up a great Rojak! The ingredients are fresh, a little cold, but it enhances the experience (Cold Rojak... now that's an idea!). Besides that, I'd recommend a train ride to Tanjong Pagar or Tiong Bahru for a more wholesome experience.

Great selection and great value for the price. I wouldn't call this a relaxing dining experience but if you're looking for a place to satisfy your hunger at a good price then this is a good choice.It's noisy, chaotic and sometimes very crowded but the food is very good.Make sure to bring your own napkins - no one provides or sells any.

It's got everything for everyone. It's priced right especially for being right next to the ion high end shopping malls. I ate at salt and pepper and had a hot dish with salmon and chicken and egg for 10 bills.  It was great. Old ladies walk around and sell u drinks off the carts from water to fruit drinks.

Definitely one of the best food courts on Orchard. Would definitely recommend the Vietnamese (awesome Pho and Bun Thit) and Indian stalls. What makes this food court good is the variety of stalls, nice atmosphere, lots of available tables and the option to go to the sushi, teppaniyaki or Din Tai Fung restaurants which are on the same floor for something a bit fancier !

A very nice food court located on the fourth floor of the Wisma Atria mall on Orchard.  Easily accessible from many of the nearby hotels via the underpasses.  We ate here most of the time for lunch in our recent 4-day trip to Singapore.  Although the food is slightly more expensive and perhaps less authethic that the various hawker centers throughout the city, I think Food Republic has several convenient features for tourists like us: (1) its extremely clean with lots of staff picking up plates, (2) air conditioning, (3) plenty of seating, and (4) it even has a sink in the center of the court for hand washing.  Like other food centers, there's a good variety of cuisine too: Taiwan, Indian, Indonesian, Korea, Thai, Peranakan, Japanese, etc.  If a sit-down restaurant is more to your liking, they also have Din Tai Fung (specialize in dumplings), a sushi restaurant, Teppanyaki Grill, and a Toast Box (excellent breakfast chain with amazing Kaya toast, coffee, and a decent Laksa too).Our favorite stalls at Food Republic are:1. The Taiwanese one - Forgot the name, but their claim to fame is beef noodle soups using thick noodles cut by hand.  Supposedly the method of cutting imparts superior texture to give a nice, chewy noodle.  We ordered both the beef dumplings and steamed pork dumplings from this place and they were both fresh and tasty.2. There was one stall that made Laksa (traditional noodle in soup) and Laksa Goreng (noodles only). I liked how they offered you the choice of noodle to use.  Laksa had the usual thin fish slices, shrimp, and some sort of shellfish (cockles perhaps?).  Flavors were bold and intense at the same time.3. Soup Guru(?) - My wife liked this one and went here a few times for traditional Chinese soups.  I liked how they described each soup in English and the traditional health benefits of each.4. They had an Indian restaurant (specializing in Biryani) next to an Indonesian restaurant (with their own special chicken set).  I tried the Chicken Biryani this time and its quite good. They gave a whole small bird with skin and all and a good side of rice and some pickled veggies, all plated on a banana leaf. The "Biryani sauce" was given as a side.  Overall it was good - a little different than Biryani I've had here in the USA, but still good.5. Sergeant Chicken - they offered both steam and roasted Hainanese Chicken Rice here for just $4 SGD. I opted for the steamed version and was glad I did.  I never knew that such as a simple dish could have so much flavor.  The rice itself was seasoned with broth and you can always add more with the side of soup they gave you.  The chicken can be eaten with the minced ginger or with the spicy chili oil.6. The fruit juice place is pretty decent too.  They charge slightly more if you decline ice in the drinks.  Coconut juice is actually a whole baby coconut with a good amount of juice and coconut meat to chew on.  The mango and guava(?) are also good with the right amout of tart to help sooth a spicy meal.  I think one of the ladies working here also preloads a bunch of the drinks onto a cart and sells them by bringing the drinks throughout the court - which is really efficient.Our least favorite stall is probably the Fish Porridge one on the corner.  My wife expected a nice smooth congee but instead got this clear soup with cooked rice and fish meat mixed in.

Clean (but what isn't in this island nation), central to many places, lots of broths, food under 10 bucks,  and it's a food court? Best damned food court I've seen. Puts many places around the Bay Area to shame. If you're on the run, this is a good place to put something quick in your tummy.  I'll B baaaack.

You can do much better than this place if you explore Singapore.  The stalls are boring from my perspective, after seeing the rest of Singapore.  It is on the expensive side as well.  If you enjoy bland, safe, and food the locals leave to the tourists, then this is your zone.
Very good variety of Singapore food reminiscent of hawkers, but in air conditioned mall.  All tasty and quite reasonably proced.
Food Republic is a big food court along Orchard Road. It's more expensive than the hawker centers in Singapore. The food is pretty good though.

I only ever come here for the shiok maki at the Japanese stall. For the uninitiated, that's an unagi and avocado roll wrapped in seared salmon and topped with roe and creamy mayo sauce. Normally I hate mayo but this one doesn't taste gross. Expensive and your arteries will likely protest but they can stand to shut up once in a while.

let's say you want to be inside, (full AC), experience the fancy mall-like food court rather than outdoor older hawker centre, don't mind successful franchises, then a food republic food court will feel safe and easy.  sure more expensive, but singaporeans take food seriously -- where else will you find food courts upstairs and downstairs in the same mall?  and even separate kopitiams.  therefore with more discriminating eaters, even the chains are better.  I say try both here and the hawker centres.

The price, atmosphere and food was better than average, with the customer service being rather dismal.I picked the smoked duck pasta, which was really creamy and went down well with a beer. The decor contrasted from the street outside, and felt like a low-key hip place to be. The beer price works out better when shared amongst a small group.Although customers have to order at the counter, it's manageable with the amount of seating available. It was no rush, and we were given menus quickly and seated.The only bummer was the server being rather slow, checking his phone in the open and taking a long time to bring the final beer.Overall, it's a pretty leisurely place to go and enjoy in the early evening.

Starting with humble beginnings with 49 Seats (this is how they got their name) at Kreta Ayer Road in 2012 and now they have move to a bigger shop space in Orchard, Centrepoint. 49 Seats are known for their Western Fusion Asian dishes at affrodable pricing.Interior was casual with a good similar industrial chic look that contains bright hanging lights, metal chair. What caught my attention was the items that was sprayed coated in silver that sticked onto the wall. Totally Creative! Initially I thought they were just the usual props made especially for decorations but as I touched it, I realized they were all recycled items. How interesting with plastic cups, spoons, forks, plates, egg trags and even egg trays.Tom Yum Seafood pasta is rated as A spicy lover must try. Looks like this dish is highly raved because of its uniqueness. The Tom Yum was served cream base with seafood like mussels and prawns. It packed a good punch of sweetness, sourness and spiciness in every mouthful of spaghetti. This is in fact semi spicy and the bestseller here.Tom Yum Seafood - $14.90Another recommendation on its menu will be their Seafood Marinara and a good alternative if you are not keen in spicy Tom Yum. Pasta is pretty tasty with mussels and prawns paired with tomato sauce.Seafood Marinara - $13.90Adding $4.90 to my pasta for set of additional soup of the day and 1 soft drinks. I had the Cream of Brocoli with garlic bread by the side of the double layer bowl. The soup was not quite hot, however still able to warm up the tummy.The environment did leave a good impression. As we were only there for pasta, we have not tried out the other western food dishes. It will be good to be back again.

It's actually a pretty nice spot to chill out with your friends. Reasonable price with all the yummy food. Recommend their chicken chop, the tom yum pasta it's alright..maybe because I don't really like creamy. But taste not bad.

The food is pretty good and prices are decent ($16+ per pax inclusive of soup of the day and a soft drink/ice lemon tea at $4.90) with no GST and Service chargeHad mushroom soup and it was rather watered down. Nothing impressive. Ar least it isn't canned Campbell's soup. It also comes with a piece of garlic bread. I would pass on the Beef bolognese, flavour was way too herby, not in a good way, like as though they tried too hard to make it unique. Do try the Classic Carbonara. it comes with a generous serving of pork bacon, like really really generous. cream sauce is also fresh and tastes great with just the right amount of salt. Thw service however, needs to be brushed up. The waiter/server seem to have this air about him that just gave me and my girlfriend bad vibes when he was explaining the set meal options to us. hey we are customers, not your kids or juniors. Also insist in sitting inside even if they tell you they are fully booked and you have to sit outside. was told the reservation would be in an hour but my Gf and I finished our meal in 20mins. yet when a party of 6 walked in just like us, they managed to get seats inside on the "reserved"  tables. disappointed that they are so inconsistent on thisWould come back again as it's one of the better options in the Tanjong Pagar/Outram Park food places.

First time finding this new restaurant at Chinatown , was really hard, I've to find by iPhone map device. But finally managed to found it ! The ambience is good but is a no when it's crowded , it would be super noisy and it'll not be romantic anymore. I saw many good reviews about the seafood marinara so I wanted to try it out , I thought it would be normal to the others but wow , when I tried , one word ; AWESOME ! I just love the flavor of the rich tomato base . And is worth it cuz they give the portion just nice for you . And the pasta is just too QQ and soft . The prawns is cooked perfectly . But I don't quite like the ice lemon tea , cuz when I tasted , is like its comes from the normal can . I thought it would be homemade . But overall 10/10 ! I would love to takeaway the pasta if possible !

Named for the number of seats available in this whitewashed, industrial style pub/diner hybrid, 49 Seats is more known for its happy hour that runs daily from 4pm - 9pm than its food.Meeting up a couple of friends there for the first time, the place was mostly filled with people who were enjoying a quick pre-dinner drink or just getting started to get sloshed with alcohol. For me, it was the food on offer that captured my attention. I had the Sirloin Al Scampi ($19.90) which was done according to the done-ness I wanted and tasted wonderful. And the prices are pretty affordable as well. It's a pity really that more people don't discover the food they have and go for the simple pub grub to go along with their drinks.

Overall a place that looks better than how its food taste. It takes good skills to do good Asian fusion and unfortunately 49 Seats does not cut it. After hearing good reviews about  the Tom Yam pasta, I decided to give it a shot and big mistake, Tom Yam is better as Tom Yam soup. The pasty base just did not blend well with the pasta at all. I can't even remember the ingredients in it as well. I was pretty put off but thankfully it was happy hour and the cheap drinks made up for it and I guess best of all I didn't have to pay so yea for all that it was a two star experience but if I had gone there solely for a meal, it might have been one stat or below. The place looks inviting with its dim lighting but more emphasis should be placed on the food.
I had the fried oysters but it didn't taste right.

Took a gamble and this turned out to be awesome. I was stuffed and they kept bringing out more great tasting food that I didn't know was included when ordering. Highly recommend!!!! Inexpensive for all that you get...

address: 5 Koek Rd 01-10 Cuppage Plaza Singapore 228796 Singapore
comment: Gyoza no Ohsho @ Cuppage Plaza is a place which offers Japanese Ramen and Fried Rice. The variety to Ramen caters to people who go flavor, richness, spiciness, non-spiciness and good Gyoza. The Gyoza here are cooked in the Authentic Japanese Style of cooking, the Gyozas are a must try. The Ramen are very rich in flavor and the noodles are cooked nicely, not too soft, not too hard. Foodies will find themselves craving for more soup as it is really good to the last drop. The Menma (Bamboo Shoots) in the Ramen does not have the turn-off taste unlike what they serve in Ajisen Ramen. They are also very crunchy and nice. Although One bowl of noodle might be a bit pricey, but it is worth the Value.

address: 5 Koek Rd 01-10 Cuppage Plaza Singapore 228796 Singapore
comment: This is one of several Japanese places in the slightly run down (and to me a bit shady looking) Cuppage Plaza just off Orchard Road. This place specializes in Gyoza and ramen but also offer other Japanese dishes. I have tried several of the dishes and have in general been rather pleased, especially considering the fair prices here.The least favorite has actually the Gyoza been, they have been a bit soggy and the seasoning of the meat inside has not been that good. The fried rice was however very good as well as the kara age and the ramen has also been very good. The place does not really have much charm but is fine for a quick bite but ai actually do prefer to take the food with me and for take out they also have some rather nice set meals with several dishes for 9-10 SGD.

address: 5 Koek Rd 01-10 Cuppage Plaza Singapore 228796 Singapore
comment: Sorry guys really not sure what the rave is about here.  All 3 kinds of stock was ok seriously nothing that is remotely close to Yokohama standard - at lease this is what i think they ate trying to do.  Now Gyoza was supposedly their signature dish i got to say was pretty disappointing.  You will not get checks of meat but rather like a paste.  Portions was very generous and price cheap seriously save your money and go across to Santouka.  Now i got to head for a nice Alfero Gelato @ orchard gateway with Waffles to wash the salty feeling out of my mouth - ok that was an excuse.

address: 5 Koek Rd 01-10 Cuppage Plaza Singapore 228796 Singapore
comment: Best gyoza. Their lunch sets are cheap and filling. Different day have different lunch sets for you to choose. Food are delicious. Water is free flow. Their service is good too. One of my favourite place to have my lunch. Favourite gyoza place of mine.

address: 5 Koek Rd 01-10 Cuppage Plaza Singapore 228796 Singapore
comment: Good gyoza. Cheap and dependable-looking place like you might find in Japan. Feels like very authentic Japanese fast food type ramen place that also has gyoza.

Tool almost all their signature tapas and they were all good.  Only issue was that the food came out all at once so we had to rush to eat so it won't be cold.  Only the coffee was not great could tell it was a standard auto machine made. Otherwise service was efficient.

The food here was SO bad and SO expensive. I came here with a big group, and absolutely no one liked it. They went to McDonald's afterwards because they were still hungry. I will say, though, it was very pretty inside. One of the nicest looking restaurants I've ever been in.
Food very average. My chicken was hard and dry and pretty tasteless. The croquettes were not bad. The view and ambience nice if not too Spanish. No need to return.

3 stars but I will try it again. The place was full and very busy for dinner. Service was excellent. Kitchen was quick to deliver. What gives three stars is that some of the food was good, some OK, some bad. The jamon croquets: avoid the jamon, the croquets themselves were fine. The small amount of jamon served with this dish seemed spoiled - glad we did not order the larger more expensive portion of jamon.Grilled vegetables were very good.Garlic prawns had good flavor but were a bit soft - not very fresh.Eggplant chips with honey was like a desert - the honey was too sweet and seemed out of place. Still it was edible.Padrino peppers were very good. Its hard to mess these up though.The creme brulee with sorbet was not so good. The (raspberry?)sorbet was not a good match with creme brulee, and the creme brulee was bland and a bit grainy - it is supposed to be smooth and creamy. The burned sugar was a bit over burned.We will give it one more shot and avoid the dishes we didn't like, maybe try some new ones.

New to the restaurant scene, Tapas Club is one of the best Spanish eateries I've tried in Singapore. We ordered a cold cut platter, mushroom croquette (highly recommended!), grilled garlic prawns, grilled sea bass (recommended, again), a steak, vegetable paella, and some wonderful churros! Tapas portions were great. The only issue we faced for the night was that our vegetable paella came out slightly burned with quite a pungent taste. Our waiter and the restaurant supervisor handled the situation very professionally by changing the paella to the seafood style immediately and putting the churros on the house! Great service, fantastic food, and good draft beers!
Outstanding food. Caters to vegetarians too. We had the spinach croquettes that were tender and delicious; the batatas and paella were super.

On picturesque Cuppage Terrace underneath one of the beautiful shophouse fronts. Get the Malabar Fish curry here, but i'm sure most of the other dishes are delicious too!---- SET LUNCH ----Pappadum: 4.5 starsCrispy, light and addictive, and the three sauces all taste fresh and delightful.Tomato Coriander Soup: 4 starsHeavily spiced with coriander, parsley and perhaps pepper too but tastes light and slightly sweet, pleasant.Malabar Fish Curry: 5 starsThis is amazing. Might be the best curry I've had in my life, and I grew up in Singapore. Delicately tender fish fillet, I hate when people overcook fish in curries but this was perfection especially with the fresh grated coconut in the tangy santan curry. This is apparently a Kerala-style dish. Cannot recommend this highly enough!Okra: 4 starsSlightly bland spicy but they give you so many ingredients... tomato, cherry tomato, onion, ginger and the okra! Tastes very fresh and healthy.Yellow Dal: 4.5 starsGarlic Naan: 3.5 starsSuper fragrant, quite greasy and crispy but slightly bland tasting. I've had better naan, but even average naan is yummy!Set lunch is such a great deal, it was S$17 for all of the above! If you order a la carte the Malabar Fish alone would be $20 (for a bigger portion of course).

Great outdoor seating. I tried the mushroom pakodas was quite good. The naan and main course was delicious as well. The staff is friendly and courteous, but easy to me missed out in rush hours, when you sometime feel you are being ignored. But overall food 3.5 and atmosphere is about 4.
Great food with a friendly outdoor and covered dining area. We come here every time we go to Singapore. Dont miss it.

Our favourite curry house in Singapore. Amazing variety and the flavours are exactly as the descriptions show. Even the spicy Curry's still have the flavours rather than just the intense chilli taste.We love this place and look forward to going back every time.Try the lamb chop starter and the Chicken Tikka Masala, beautiful!!

One of better Indian restaurants in Orchard Road area. The décor is more rustic, and the food is not as refined as at the 'celebrity' Indians (like Rang Mahal, Song of India, Punjab Grill, Yantra) but it is much more satisfying - like a good old traditional French dish at a top bistrot vs. a beautifully-plated and highly-technical one with emulsion at a Michelin-starred restaurant. The vindaloo is one of the best you can have! I like extremely spicy food, but did well to follow the advice of owner Sandeep Sachar and ordered it with 6 chillis (on a scale of 1 to 10), otherwise I wouldn't have been able to savour the different subtle flavours in the curry. Fragrant biryani and excellent garlic naan. Warm and attentive service staff, who share Mr. Sachar's passion.

This joint brings you higher end (and higher price) Indian food than what you'd normally get.The lamb samosa was a large Punjabi style one, chock-full of minced meat. It was crispy and quite flaky.The chicken mulligatawny soup was both sour and salty. I'm not sure how to describe it but it had a pleasant taste. Then was Bharwan aatish khumbh - tandoori Mushrooms with nuts and cheese. It had a wonderful mix of flavours and a rich nutty taste. It was a bit sweet - which the manager had informed us about when we ordered. So it's not for everyone.We also had the murgh korma - chicken in a slightly sweet, mild rose cashew sauce. I was surprised by how mild it was. It seemingly had no chilli, and just a bit of pepper. I could even taste the rose. It was very pleasant and more subtle than Indian food usually is (though it'll probably be derided by purists). One thing to note is that a good cut of chicken was used, whereas lower end Indian places use cheaper cuts. This isn't necessarily a good thing, since the meat loses some moistness and flavour.To accompany our dishes we had butter roti and lachhna paratha (layered paratha). They were pretty good but they were not hot and the former did not have any palpable liquefied butter. In short, they were a bit old. I told the manager who claimed all the food was made only upon ordering. Well...We also had mango lassi which was excellent with a very intense mango taste.The service was not so good unfortunately. I asked for water and the server forgot. Only when I told the manager did it come. The mushrooms also only came upon my reminding the staff. Also the restaurant was a little bit warm.Overall this place is alright, but not very good value.

Curry Culture is one of the better Indian restaurants in Singapore. The venue is part of the al fresco dining complex on Cuppage road. Staff are friendly and attentive.There is always some cheesy Bollywood movie or music video playing on the drop down screen in back, but it somehow adds a whimsical charm to the place.While we haven't really been blown away by the vegetarian offerings, like channa masala and dal lentils, the meat offerings are well cooked and nicely spiced. I highly recommend the lamb chops masala. Dishes are served with rich, velvety sauces. I suspect a lot of ghee goes into these offerings. As a result, the wife and I usually choose to walk home from Curry Culture to battle the inevitable food coma.
I was in Singapore for work, a friend of a friend took me to lunch here. He is originally from India, and said this is the most authentic Indian cuisine he's had outside of home. Delicious.
Amazing, delicious and taste buds are happy.  A must to go to when in Orchard City Center in Singapore! The device was fab. Really caring people.

Totally unreliable delivery. Ordered food for whole family as they were all tired after brutal 24 hr flight and delivery never showed up. Called three times (both locations) and they keep bouncing me back and forth between locations. All the reviews on this page may look good and food may be great but, no, you are not getting my business anymore. Thanks for starving us to sleep!

It was my first Indian food experience in Singapore. I've had better Indian food before. The portions seem so small while the prices are very high but somehow you don't walk out hungry. The veggie Aloo bowl was tasty but the chicken tandoori was very salty and not well done. Great service from the owner and the other servers. The place wasn't exactly clean and there was a distinct smell that we couldn't figure out and it messed up our experience. The mango drink was very fresh but again, the glasses were not clean. Overall, the food is ok, the service is great and the prices are VERY high!

We are here last night and it was on the whole a gray experience.  Waiting staffwereSo friendly and attentive. Hubby likes a hot curry and has been disappointed in SG as they're afraid it'll be too hot including the vindaloo!! Here the Waiter bent over backwards to accommodate hubby and we throughly enjoyed the curries!! Desert we ordered Kulfi ice cream, this should be melt in your mouth creaminess but it lacked essential flavor and had a gritty texture? But if it's curry your interested it's a nice spot off Orchard Rd amongst bright traditional shop houses were you can take in the atmosphere and relax

One of my buddies told me this was the best curry he had ad anywhere in the world.  so good that he ate here 3 times in 5 days.  MAN was he right!  The vindaloo at level 8 is hot but the flavor was amazing!  the owner is very nice guy and the staff was attentive.  This will be one of my regular spots when in singapore!

Great spot found on tripadvisor. Terrific curry--and I'm from Waltham's Moody Street. We tried the Vindaloo and lamb curry dishes at a spicy heat level of 2, 4, and 5. Perfectly good but we did sample the level 10, which is nice and vinegary with a slightly sweet nutty taste. Worth it for the flavor. Chili heads might be disappointed, but there is an off-the-menu level 14 that you might want to try and review!

This place is incredible. The curry is so good- I had two veggie curries that were the perfect spice level and creamy but not over the top. This is a great bet if you're looking for traditional Indian. What really makes this place so great is the service. Everyone was so nice, and attentive. Will definitely come back next time I'm in Singapore and highly recommend.

I was visiting Singapore on a conference trip and had craving for some Indian food. After reading lots of great reviews about this place, we decided to dine here on a Friday night. Getting reservation was easy as we were here an hour before it's closing time. We were seated promptly outside and the server was quick enough to take our orders. We had samosa and papdi chaat as our appetizers. The papdi chaat was better of the two.. very tasty with right amount of tanginess, spices and chilly! The samosa was also good but I enjoyed the chaat more. I often judge an Indian restaurant by the kind of chaats they make. I was in the mood of having some cocktail which will be spicy yet having the good liquor .. the waiter knew perfectly my want and served me the India summer- cocktail with whiskey and spices.. it was the perfect drink I needed on a Friday night. A must try drink if you enjoy some spices! The main course- aloo paratha, Channa masala, tandoori roti and aloo gobi was spot on.. very tasty, flavorful and true to its kind. Definitely fabulous dining experience. The service was excellent and a perfect ambience to have dinner with friends. Next time will love to try non- veg dishes as they seem to be excellent!
Amazing food and amazing staff. We were uncertain on our order and level of heat. We left it to them to decide and we were thoroughly impressed! Will return every time we are in Singapore.
We had a chicken biryani which was fine. The ambiance is good with seating indoors and outdoors as well. The staff was pretty friendly and helpful.
Great service, the food followed suit. Make sure you stop here for a bite, you won't be disappointed with their authentic cuisine

The owner/manager set us up with some very tasty dishes that were spot on delicious. We had amazing appetizers and main dishes that all had the right combination of flavor and spice. The service included interesting history and traditions. My whole family recommends it highly. Don't be distracted by the other restaurants, just go straight here.
Excellent curries! Each one we tried was distinct and flavorful. Nicely hot, too. Friendly service as well.

The staff at this restaurant were warm and friendly, providing one with a level of unparalleled service. However at best, the food was mediocre with primarily a non-indigenous clientele. The appetizers were heavily spiced yet still left a lot to be desired. The main courses were likewise bland. But the kicker was the bill that came with the mediocre food. I have no issues paying premium prices for good food. Alas, this was not.
I loved this place!  Very friendly staff and food that was tasty and perfectly spiced. I had a chicken masala with dome saffron rice and a plain nan. Would definitely eat here again.

Great location, great beer, great food. Great, all-around. I am no Japanese beer connoisseur but they had quite a selection (and a great HH price for Asahi for beer newbies like me!).They have an extensive beer menu and while its not the cheapest, you can find all kinds of interesting niche craft beers. They also have quite a large food menu. They say they're known for their yakitori, which I didn't have a chance to try. We ordered off of the lunch menu, which is in the $15 range and includes a full set of soup with a salad. I had their curry rice with karaage chicken and it was the best curry rice I've had in the city so far.As far as I could tell, they only had outdoor seating so it might not be the best place when it is pouring outside or if you need to cool off from the heat. Still, its nice and breezy and it allows you to do a good bit of people-watching. It is located right outside of the western entrance to the Somerset313 building, next to the German restaurant.

JiBiru Craft Beer & Yakitori Bar maybe one of my favourite place on earth!More than 40 Japanese beers from microbreweries available in drafts or bottles! Selection of beers that I can only dream of back home. And paired with yakitori from Saitama region north of Tokyo with sauces directly imported from Hibiki yakitori restaurants of Higashi-Matsuyama. I know what I want to order... I want one of those Hitachino Draft serves in Weizenbier glass with that cute owl logo! I Unfortunately they were out of Red Rice Ale or the Amber Ale. Hitachino Nest Dai Dai IPA ended up being the drink of the evening!We also ordered Edamame and Yakitori which were both really good. So many beers I want to try. Just wish they have 3 oz samplers options or I should get more people to come drinking with me next time! Come before 6 pm for the best deal $10 VS $15 after 8 pm!! I should have started drinking much much early! You know who can resist specials?I am dreaming of a taste of Hitachino Nest XH (8%) A robust Belgian style Brown Ale made with extra malt and hops and matured in Shochu casks for over 6 months. I wonder how this will taste like!or Kinshachi Matcha Draft (Green Tea Beer)or....Until next time!

Offering people watching up the wazoo, JiBiru is a top notch spot to sample some cracking Japanese craft beers, sit under the Big Ass Fans™, and just watch the world go by.Located behind the busy Orchard Road shopping area, and within earshot of the MRT entrance makes this thoroughfare busy as a bee.Grab a bucket or two, or a craft draft, and settle in for a gawk and a talk!

This spot does a *lot* with their limited space, so they get credit for that.  The tap lines are limited but seem to rotate frequently.  They have a partnership with Hitachino which in the craft beer world is mediocre; and worse they've had some outright bad British craft beers.  On the other hand they had a recent line takeover by Shiga Kogen (a solid craft line out of Japan), so you never know.All of that being said, the venue is outside (but well covered from rain), and the izakaya-influenced menu is surprisingly varied and tasty.   As a veggie I am partial to the rather filling tofu salad and the seasonal corn inari, but my carnivorous companions enjoyed the various seafood and meat dishes.

This something as unusual as a place specializing in mainly Japanese craft beer and the selection is pretty great. I have explored some of these beers while in Japan but the craft beer trend was jot as strong when I was there so many of the ones on offer here were new to me. They are also thoroughly described in the beer list and the staff are knowledgeable so really impressed by that. Prices are perhaps a bit on the steep side but the happy hour is pretty good (at least if before 6pm).They also have some Japanese whiskey and sake as well as some beer from other countries and some ciders so most people should be able to find something to drink here. Of course they also serve food and it is good and simple Japanese food. I sampled several of the dishes and it is good solid Japanese food, my favorite was the curry but I would not come for the food but rather the beer selection and I may or may not have some food. The locations is central, right by Somerset tube in the mall 313@Somerset.

Amazing selection of Japanese beer that I didn't even see in Japan! Well described too - some of the more strange ones are pretty expensive though it makes sense.The collection of Hitachino Nest beers are a good enough reason to stop by.Oh and the lunch specials where well priced and tasted good as well :)

As a travelling beer snob I was super pumped to find a place like this on vacation.  If you want to get your hands on some awesome Japanese microbrews look no further.It was pretty packed on a Friday night but I was able to find a corner of a table, and I was surprised by the selection of beers.  The beers were all great, lots of varieties, styles and microbrews.  Most beers are bottled so if you are a fan of draught beer than you will be disappointed.My two issues are: 1) the beer menu was organized loosely by brewery and not by style, they are not cross-referenced anywhere so you have to flip through a lot of pages to narrow down decisions, beer snobs like to see styles of beers grouped together. 2) Food was not at the level of the beers, beers were 5 stars, food was 3 stars, sorry but I am use to yakitori style foods that make you want to stay, eat and drink moore.If you down with beer, this is the place.  Bring your wallet though, this is in one the pricey areas of Singapore.

My fav to grab a beer place in town currently. I like their Japanese craft beer and Jap fried chicken. Minus one as it can get rather humid sitting out there.You may call them in advance to ask whether their tv is showing the sports channel you would like to watch as well. :)

Those who have met me know my love towards craft beers and most of the places that serve them. I'm usually an instant fan and seeing a review of such places below 4 stars usually means I've finally become annoyed enough to provide feedback via a review.It's definitely not my first time here but my previous experiences did not have service issues because I happened to be there during off-peak "happy hour" before the main crowd comes in. While it was far from packed tonight, the lapse in service became quite evident.I stopped by with Gold Elite Nik T. and Sweet Elite Linda L. for a beer and a good conversation after our dinner with Cindy L. and Ning.*******10 minutes to get our order in.5 minutes for Linda L. to receive her order.15 minutes of chatting without anything else arriving.5 minutes before we got someone's attention and to find out that they RAN OUT of our orders...and we were never informed about it.Nik T. looked at his watch and decided to downsize from 500 ml to 300 ml. We both ordered something else that they said was available.15 minutes of chatting without anything else arriving.5 minutes before we got someone's attention again and NOW found out that they CAN'T serve the new draft due to fizzy issues with the keg...and offered a ton of apologies.Nik T. downsized all the way and decided to go dry while I finally settled for the same drink as Linda L. It arrived in less than 5 minutes.Linda L.'s drink became warm while she waited for ours to arrive. Nik T. ended up leaving with just a sip of hers. I ended up having one instead of going dry like Nik T. so that Linda L. didn't end up having a brew herself.BUT WAIT...if that wasn't enough to end the night, our bill...was wrong. We were billed for our initial order. Gold Elite couldn't take it anymore...and gave immediate feedback. I just smiled...said it was okay...and got ready to review this place.*******Thankfully, I waited a bit...and managed to justify in my mind that they deserved 3 stars at least for their product. But seriously, their staff needs some training yeah? This isn't a Kopitiam...and even then, Kopitiams don't pull this kind of crap.Yelp 100: 20/100

I would move to Singapore for JiBiru.  Well, I would move there anyway, but I digress.  What a fantastic concept to specialize in the growing craft beer offerings from Japan.  The presence of a place like this speaks volumes to the growing craft beer culture emerging in Singapore, which has improved dramatically in the 2 years since my last visit.Prior to my visit to JiBiru, my knowledge of Japanese craft beer was limited to Hitachino.  While they do have a lengthy list of options from that brewery (both on tap and in bottles), they also have pages and pages from 7-8 other Japanese producers.  In addition just to round things out, they carry a few European and Australian beers as well.  My colleague and I were only able to sample a fraction of what was offered, requiring a few returns to try out the rest of the list.Although we only got a couple of small plates (pan fried gyoza and chicken wings), the food was quite delicious and pairs well with the beer.Service was just OK.  More often than not, we had to flag down our waiter to order more beer, even though the place was less than half full.People watching is quite excellent, as JiBiru is situated near one of the entrances to the 313@Somerset mall.

JiBiru specializes in Japanese beers, and they have the most extensive selection I have seen outside of Japan.  Actually, even i Japan I'm not sure if there are many places that carry 60 Japanese craft beers in bottles plus 5 on draft.  Anyway, they have a sampler of 4 beers on draft (all from Hitachino) which is the way to go if you would like to try a few.  I'm not the biggest fan of HItachino though (except for their espresso stout), so for me it was just ok.  Their selection by the bottle was better though.   I tried an Imperial IPA from Minoh, which was a great example of the style - strong, bitter, and full of flavor with an ABV of 9%.
