The portion was pretty decent and I have to say, I was pretty impressed by the chicken. Because of the way it's cooked, the skin remains beautiful smooth and gelatinous, Yet, giving that little crunch (or bounce?) when biting into it. The flavor is fairly light (good for someone like me who can only have very minimal salt now) but the taste of the pure chicken really shines through. It's so good that I could have done without the sauce they drizzled over. Again, do take note that I've been on a no salt / minimal salt (like 120mg max) for the last 2.5 months so my tastebuds do tend to differ from someone who regularly eats out everyday. The rice was pretty decent too, a little like Loy Kee's but less oily. Soup was, well a chicken soup, but I could taste a bit of herbal-ness in the soup, which was a nice touch. The ginger was interesting, being a little sweeter than usual and the chilli. Oh the chilli was good. It was a little sweet when you first taste it, before the sour suddenly kicks in and than the spice. Ipoh Kway Teow Soup ($7.90)This was pretty good too. The soup is light, yet very tasty and the thin Ipoh Kway Teow was cooked to perfection. The flavors were very balanced and the chilli it came with gave a real kick. A good pairing with the portion of white chicken. Chicken Sushi ($4.90)Now this was interesting. I expected the rice to be the same as the one served with chicken rice, but it wasn't! It was chicken rice + more. The addition of fries garlic and shallots, along with the oil, not only help bind the rice into sushi form, but it packed a lot of extra flavor and aroma into the rice.Topped with a very very tender piece of chicken (although I wised it was bigger), drizzled with their sauce and topped with shredded, stringy, fried ginger (that was a nice touch), the chicken sushi might sound gimmicky but it was so so so good. On a whole, I do think the chicken rice here is pretty good. It definitely ranks higher than Tian Tian in my books, and it's a good way to experience chicken rice in a comfortable, air conditioned environment, without paying a chatterbox prices. Considering that they're the new kid on the block, I really hope they survive.

Located in orchard road but in the sleepy and quiet TripleOne somerset is Kaiware Japanese Restaurant. Helmed by the Japanese food veteran Peter Loo, set your expectations high and they will be met! The menu seems to offer a bit of everything, raw, cooked, fried, even a kids meal. There's something for everyone here. My friend who brought me here wouldn't stop raving about the quality of the sashimi here. Even though I do love sashimi, I decided to go with an oyako don as I hadn't had a good bowl of oyako don since my last japanese trip!1. Oyako Don $10++For $10++, I was surprised to see such a huge serving. The japanese rice was definitely quality japanese rice. You could taste the fragrance of the rice. The rice also quickly absorbed all the sauces from the omelette and the chicken making it extremely flavourful. I could totally eat a whole bowl of this rice on its own!They were extremely generous with the numerous cubs of juicy and tender chicken meat that was doused in the sweet teriyaki mixture. Served together with the don, is a miso soup which a tad too salty for my liking, but I happily fished out and ate the seaweed. Alongside, you will also get some watermelon slices.2. Ikura Chawanmushi $8++I decided to treat myself with an Ikura Chawanmushi. I love ikura and I love this even more as the Ikura was super fresh and almost melts in your mouth. The chawanmushi was steamed to perfection. It was almost like eating a pudding, a baby with no teeth would have no problem eating this. The steamed egg had a mousse-like textuyre yet withholding the characteristic notes of the egg, prawn and mushroom flavours.I'm definitely ordering this again!Overall : great quality japanese food in a cosy setting. I do hope they settle smoothly in their new location in Tanjogn Pagar and I cannot wait for my next dining experience in Kaiware.Take note : Kaiware is moving to 22 Cross Street #01-50/53 China Square Central Singapore 048423 on July 2016. Reservation contact number 6735 2345 will remain the same.

Hidden gem inside an office building, which is a shame. What isn't a shame is that it's my office building. Really good quality AND good value Japanese food. Super (crazy!) thick sashimi slices here, and generous portions of soba noodles. Try the excellent value lunch set, which at ~17++ is great - you get fruits, appetiser, miso, chawanmushi, rice and a choice of "main" dish.

This restaurant was only opened a month ago and I dined in because of the word of mouth from my friends.  3 of us dined in last night and we had Sashimi Teishoku, Sukiyaki and Haru Chirashi Sushi.  I found the thickest sashimi to be served in this restaurant.  For the price I paid for Sukiyaki ($28), the quantity and quality are much better than those I get at Marine Parade and Orchard.So, for Sashimi lovers, you've got to be there to enjoy an excellent dining experience.  Remember to ask for privilege card so that you are entitled to a 10% discount on a la carte menu.
I regularly come here for lunch and you really get a lot for your money, and of good quality. I'm not too crazy about the interior design but that is secondary. Good professional service.

address: 277 Orchard Rd #03-17, Orchard Gateway Singapore 556083 Singapore
comment: Just recently found this korean BBQ place, i love the place and the food. Beefs selections are vast and love the side dishes.Should try sweet potatoes and kimchi fried rice

address: 277 Orchard Rd #03-17, Orchard Gateway Singapore 556083 Singapore
comment: Popped by on the second day of Chinese New Year, and we were looking for a Korean barbecue to go to, and we were surprised to find this place open!Reasonably priced, about $30+ per person, for a buffet spread of different meats to grill, and a limited selection of veggies and Banchan. Kimchi here is fresh and tastes quite okay. The quality of the meat here is not amazing, but good enough for the price, and free flow. Service here is pretty attentive and good. The ventilation must be quite good here because I didn't smell terrible after the meal. Yum!

address: 277 Orchard Rd #03-17, Orchard Gateway Singapore 556083 Singapore
comment: Great food. Liked the meat collection. Even better is that soft drinks and ice cream included too!!

Didn't think I would like the Roast meat here since I just came from Hong Kong and had tons of Roast Pork. Boy was I wrong, can't believe I like this so much better than Hing Kong. Their meats were crunchy and the sauces were amazing, I don't normally eat roast pig but I would eat it there. We got bunch of stuff to try, sated egg York wings, two way Chinese broccoli (half is steam and the other half was fried minced broccoli leaf...OMG, must have) and black pepper shrimp which was ok. You can get either noodles or rice with the meats. We all got noodles and the sauces/chili comes with it is pretty good. I love that you can order using the tablet on each table, no waiter/waitress needed. Also, the pickled jalapeños goes really well with the noodle and the meats to balance out the fatty skin taste
Excellent char siew; roast pork not bad; roast duck so-so. Meepok must try. Peak hours advisable to make reservation.

I came here because I watched a video by The Muttons introducing this place owned by them. The char siew is good. Chunky and all for the good ones. It's just that for my bowl, there were quite a few pieces with just fat and no lean meat in it. Mind you, I am not even talking about the siew-yok(roasted prok) here. I like that the bowl had some pickled cucumbers as a nice touch to warrant $9.90 but the char siew parts that I got were too fatty.Yes fat is taste but too much fat, especially in chinese cooking, equals oily equals un-stomach-able. My appetite is gone.People order char siew more for lean meat dare I might say. The fatty part could be there minimally. Dare I also might say, that fat cannot be glorified in char siew as if in a chu-toro or o-toro because those weren't as oily as char siew. So stop marketing it that way! The char siew needs to be more refined. I have tasted better in hawker centres.Talk about the roast pork, there is crispiness in it yes. But the crackle wasn't that crispy also. Dark sweet sauce could be provided for pairing. The mee pok noodles were cooked al dente, no complaints. The salted egg chicken wings got cold very quickly. The wings weren't as crispy and fresh as expected, the sauce becomes gooey quickly. A better way needs be come up with to present it other than this usual style.Thought of ordering the platter but the price of rice is $1.50! Also actually, I prefer white rice over chicken-flavoured rice for my char siew rice. That may be why I find it too oily.This place does hold so much potential. It could be a like a fook kin club of roasted delights. The sauce of the char siew is really good, but there needs to be added twist to warrant the price and make the dish more palatable.Long story short this place has got good vibes and respectable food, but it might not have enough to lure me back a second time.

I suppose as the new place to be seen, it does have a nice interior with neon lights and a suggestive name. After the multiple media reviews I had high hopes for this place. Alas! My hopes were dashed. While the food here isn't awful, it wasn't great either.We had the cold tofu starter and deep fried baby squid to start with. The tofu was strange with chopped century egg, some salted egg (sic?) and some ikura on top. I felt that it didn't go well altogether. The baby squid was fried to crispness and no complaints about that. This place's staple is the roast platter, and both char siew and roast pork were lacking in fat, making them a little dry. I suppose the fat proportion of a cut is highly subjective, and dependent on luck, but we didn't think highly of it. The noodles were not bad; springy. It did lack some seasoning which were easily remedied with some garlic chilli. However, it could have done with some pork lard (they should have it on all the tables). Would I return? I'm not sure.

‍service‍We were seated very quickly and offered water and menus. Our orders were taken quickly, and the server gladly brought a refill of the salad. After the delicious katsu the ice cream was also quickly brought.  ambiance Simple ambience but very clean, and it didn't feel too cramped even though it was the dinner hour. Brightly lit so not the best place for a romantic meal but rather a quick simple tasty experience. foodHere is where Saboten shines. The quality of the food was excellent from the delicious dressing for the salad to the fresh pickled radish to the absolutely amazing pork katsu. Grinding the seeds and making your own sauce was such a fun unique experience. The meat was amazingly tender and the breading fluffy. Yes it is fried food, but it doesn't leave you with that unpleasant post fried food feeling you get after a greasy meal. I can't say enough about how tender the meat was. Even the included ice cream was light and delicious and a great way to end the meal. mojoOverall great mojo at Saboten. A comfortable place to enjoy this absolutely amazing katsu which is really unequaled elsewhere. Friendly staff and plenty of food.

It feels very different to dine at Saboten restaurants in Singapore because they are well-furnished with spacious seatings and bright lightings, unlike the usual no-frills takeaway Saboten outlets that I come across in Tokyo. But of course, this world's largest Tonkatsu chain do have restaurants in Tokyo, mostly in major shopping malls or department stores. To celebrate the opening of its new outlet in  313@Somerset, Saboten introduces the Iberico Loin Katsu and Fried Jumbo Prawn that are exclusive to this outlet.Iberico pork, which is famed for its refine marbling and tender texture, was not an easier cutlet to handle than the original katsu. Not as rich or oozing juices as you may find elsewhere, the trimmings were rather leathery, and some effort was required to disintegrate the protein. This in particular, is what polarizes opinions.The Fried Prawn Jumbo Set ($28.80) featuring a wild-catch Tiger prawn, crab croquette and original loin cutlet, is more likely to appease the finicky palates with a mixture of seafood and pork. The coating of breadcrumbs for this set of ingredients was also more consistently golden, light and not cloyingly oily. It would be a pity not to try the deep-fried scallops (2 for $12), especially when they are at their freshest and best condition this time of the year. The Hotate Feast is a new seasonal promotion that runs till end Oct.Good to know: there are also Grilled Chicken Set ($18) and Grilled Salmon Set ($21) for those who prefer non-fried food. Yuzu and Goma dressing are imported from Japan. The Tonkatsu Sauce is developed in-house with more than 10 types of ingredients.All the sets are complete with chawanmushi, pickles and yuzu sorbet, not forgetting the free refills of crunchy cabbage, Japan-imported rice, miso soup, that complete the teishoku experience. As usual, you proceed with the old but obligatory ritual of grinding the sesame before adding the Tonkatsu sauce. But what surprises me is that there is also radish and even curry sauces, which I view as privileges that one can't get in Japan--it is usually katsu with one and only one type of dressing. This may not be the place for the impeccable classic tonkatsu but you can still discover some reliable deep-fried gems, if you pick the right ones
Very tasty and well-prepared food. My personal favorite was the pork sandwich, which was perhaps the most flavorful one I've ever had (the key was the yummy pickle-and-something relish on it).
Excellent set!  Good price for the set!  Salad is great!

I've visited Saboten branches in Hong Kong and Singapore and this one is good. Good quality fried pork cutlets with unlimited rice and cabbage Very nice curry sauce for the rice and pork and sesame dressing for the cabbage.

This restaurant is located upstairs, in the back of the mall.  If you're ever in Singapore, you have to to try the thin crust pizza. They have the best.  I haven't found a thin crust pizza that compares to the one I had here, with the fried egg in the middle.  Nevertheless, the menu is pretty expansive, and they offer a variety of other dishes, including bowl dishes. The place is decorated nicely, as well as the view out of the windows.  You forget for a second you're dining in a mall. One night I was dining there, they had a live performer. Not certain if it's every night.

A nice find in orchard.. this cafe serves up Italian favorites plus has a crazy good deal on oysters during happy hour. The around the world brunch menu helps satisfy your wanderlust and palate since travel is not feasible these days. Nice atmosphere and a good place to spend a few hours meeting up with friends over drinks and food.

This is currently my favorite restaurant in Singapore. What they offer is an interesting combination of Asian Fusion, pizzas, Western  dishes, and a very nice selection of craft beers. Along with some other things, as well. All of their food is prepared with an interesting presentation and it is all very good.This restaurant is not exceedingly large. But, the tables are well space and it has a very artistic interior. My suggestion is, if you are only dining with one other person, be sure to ask for a full table because they do have smaller tables along the wall. But, those tables are packed in there pretty tight. From this, you won't really be able to enjoy your conversation and your meal as you may very well have somebody you don't know sitting right next to you. And, I mean right next to you. This restaurant also offers live acoustic music on various nights of the week. The performers all seem to be pretty good and what they provide is covers of some well-known tunes. Watching these performers is not an absolute necessity but it does add to the overall atmosphere of the restaurant.The staff here is very nice and they do their job fairly well, though during peak hours they can get a little forgetful and your meal may arrive a little bit cold. This is not a criticism, this is simply a fact. Just keep that in mind.Overall, fun place to eat.

To start off the official opening hours is from 6:30pm on a Friday but nice to accommodate us at 5:40pm.   Got an outside sitting but did get a trainee waiter which we helped train.   He did say that it was his second day so we were equally accommodating though he can't really get his order right until the 3rd time.   Food wise, nothing really outstanding.  If i may say a little confused with the Asian stuff.

The absolute worst service I've ever experienced. First you need to actually interrupt the waitresses to get any kind of service. They would rather huddle up with their backs to customers than give some service. Then a fly landed in my beer. So when I asked for a new beer because a fly had landed in it they brought me a partially poorer beer that was missing the orange. So I asked if I could get another orange slice like my last beer. Unfortunately this restaurant has a fly problem cause another fly landed in my second beer. They brought me a new beer and this time they told me this would be the last beer. To that I said yes please and remove this beer as it's not my problem you have flys in your restaurant. To this they said it wasn't their problem either? This seems odd to me as I'm used to if restaurants have a bug or rodent problem they actually do need to take some kind of action to correct it. You'll never guess next they explain that they had sat us at a six person table and because a party of six has shown up they would like to move us to the hall way seating. Oddly we haven't even finished our large pizza our loaded fries or my beer yet. Certainly will not be coming back and it's hard to imagine why anyone would be interested in eating at this establishment. Unless your interested to be treated very poorly as part of your dinner plans. Sadistic

Oh, honey. This is one of those situations where you think, "I get what you're trying to do, but how do I say this nicely? No."I get that this is a trendy place; their dark and sexy interior communicates this well. We arrived on a weekday evening, and most of the tables inside were already reserved. We ended up sitting outside, which wasn't bad as they still made efforts to decorate this area and create an ambiance. The food sounded promising, and there was a lot to choose from. I almost want to say that they're a little confused, as their signboard mentions modern Italian/pizzeria even though there is page after page of Asian inspired tapas and dishes.We ordered a Caprese salad and their Morning After Pizza, which includes a fried egg in the middle. The Caprese salad was amazing. All the ingredients were fresh, and I still remember the beautiful texture and saltiness of the proscuitto. Unfortunately, the Morning After Pizza fell very flat. We couldn't taste anything, which was surprising considering all the toppings that were on there- the roasted mushrooms, the egg, the minced parsley, the melted cheese. Maybe it was the tomato sauce- perhaps it needed more salt? For a place that has "pizzeria" on their signboard, this concerns me greatly. I leave my review at 3 stars because they have the ambiance down, and it seems like a great spot for tea or some snacks. I wouldn't say I'd avoid this place completely, but for pizza in this type of setting and for those prices, you'll find me at Extra Virgin instead.

Keeping this short and simple - pretty decent food with pretty decent price tags! Wouldn't go out of the way for it but will definitely choose this as my go-to place for dinner if I'm in the area! Be sure to make a reservation as the queue can get reaaaaally long, especially during dinner time!!

Supply & Demand is kind of like this... You meet this great girl and she's got it goin on. You know... Great legs, pretty face, etc. You ask her out on a date and on that date you come to the hard realization that's all she really is... A pretty face. No substance, no umpty-ump.Back to the review, on the surface, Supply & Demand has really got it going on. Beautiful interior, great atmosphere, good looking people, modern ambience. We started off with the Caprese Salad and it was sublime. The tomato, Caprese and rocket, I mean arugula... doused with olive oil is a must have.  Our second dish was the Morning After Pizza. A tomato based mushroom, bacon pizza topped with soft egg. It tasted like Card Board. Ok that's harsh, but really with all those toppings lumped together, how could it be that bad... We may have gotten a bad batch, but it's as if the pizza was pre-cooked, refrigerated, heated and then served. The soft egg was not even center, so the lucky person who got that slice was the only one who had a chance to taste it.In short, Supply & Demand is my Adriana Lima. You look at her, she's beautiful, a Victoria Secret model, no less, but as soon as she opens her mouth, your first reaction is to cover your ears. :D

I may have had a more positive experience here than other reviewers based on the lack of vegetarian food I experienced while in Singapore. Of course there was plenty of vegetarian fare to be found in Little India.. but if I wanted Indian food all week I would have just gone to India.That being said, there was not a huge selection of vegetarian items at Supply and Demand but the kitchen was very accommodating towards our needs and modified pastas and pizzas on the menu accordingly. We really appreciated that the kitchen was willing to add in extra veggies as needed instead of subtracting the meat yet still charging $22 for some tomato sauce and mozz.I LOVED the decor at Supply and Demand! The space imbues an industrial aesthetic in the form of concrete floors, reclaimed wood tables, and exposed ceiling beams and pipes. The dim lighting completed the urban feel of this trendy eatery. It seems to be a pretty popular place as we had to wait about an hour to be seated (at 8 pm) and as we dined there seemed to be an endless flow of patrons. The crowd was predominantly people in their late 20s-30s sans children; I'd assume this means the late night scene at the rooftop bar is pretty fun.Overall, a very pleasant experience and I definitely recommend Supply and Demand to any vegetarians seeking a meal with Western hemisphere flavors!

Not a bad place for decent Italian. I would stick to the pizzas though. Gets super packed during meal times so book or be prepared to wait. Service is pretty sketchy too - the staff do try their best but could do with a bit more training and experience (half of them look like they're 16 years old).

I like this place but..its a pain in the (  Y  ).  Even when we came early and it literally almost empty, the lady said there is only two tables open. I guess most are reserved. Actually when we left there were empty tables with reservation signs with a huge line. So GET A RESERVATION A DAY AHEAD!! actually I called on the same day to make a reservation and no one answered. The staff is what I'm finding typical singapore, hard working understaffed. The pasta is average imo. Just compared to other similarly priced Italian places, they don't do it as well. The basics is al dente pasta. The pizza is not bad but you have to like a crispy crust. I generally like this place.

Greyhound Cafe ParagonSingaporeMy favourite cafe!A queue at 12 noon on Saturday. Chicken wings not as good as those in Bangkok.Tom yam koong with large prawn which is better than river prawn at Ping's in Bangkok. Shame on you Ping's!Fried rice with crab - very nice.Thai iced milk tea - good, not overly sweet like in Bangkok.Overall good but I think it costs a lot more than in Bangkok.

I went there with 2 other friends and shared the mushroom pad thai and vegetarian tom yum noodles. Total was $32 including gst. Prices are kind of high for regular thai food, but if you consider the location, and you see yourself surrounded by high-end luxury brand stores, I guess it's still reasonable orchard rd standard.The pad thai is good, but the tom yum soup is a little too sour, too much lime added I assume. Overall, I'm still very happy they have a vegetarian section in their menu! If you want to know why I didn't give them another star, it's because they don't provide tap water T.T (even though I told them I really don't mind). So remember to bring your own water or get ready to pay $3 for a bottle of water.
Nice ambiance and seating, but no cold water is served. Only mineral or sparkling water.
Food wasn't up to expectations. Service wasn't up to standard as well. They forgotten our pomelo salad despite reminding them that it wasnt served yet twice.

address: 260 Orchard Road, Robinsons Orchard The Heeren, B1-02A Singapore 238855 Singapore
comment: I was craving gyoza and had been wanting to try this place for a while. The gyoza was really tasty! Thin skin, pan fried to perfection with juicy fillings. The gyoza sauce was a bit on the salty side. I also ordered the black truffle ramen. The portion was small but it came with juicy pork belly, perfectly soft boiled egg, and tons of black truffle! I was pleasantly surprised and would totally reorder this entire meal.

address: 260 Orchard Road, Robinsons Orchard The Heeren, B1-02A Singapore 238855 Singapore
comment: Amazing gyoza place hidden at the corner of Basement 1 of Robinsons Orchard (formerly known as The Heeren).  One of the many things I like about this place is how quiet this place is everytime I visit. Don't get me wrong. It is not entirely quiet (as in no customer) kinda quiet but it's the certain "zen" that it exudes the minute I stepped in to this restaurant. First off -  no queue. And second - price is reasonable. And third - good food. Go straight to the superstar when you order - Pork Gyoza either panfried or boil, depending what you fancy. If you want something other than pork, the Prawn gyoza is a good choice too. Besides gyoza, the waitress would recommend you an in house special called jia jia men, a noodle dish which is pretty similiar with the taiwanese version (jia xiang mien). I dont like it as i felt it lacked of taste but found myself ordering my last two recent visits. (i have no hope, i know). Upon serving you jiajia men, the waitress will tell you to mix everything in the bowl and once you're done eating half portion of the noodle, she will then add in "hot soup" to it and a half boiled egg into the soup. So for the price of one, you get to enjoy the dry version and then the soup version. Selling at $6.50 per portion, I thought it's a pretty good deal. If you;re still not full, the garlic fried rice and the Nikujyaga (braised beef in stock, i think) are pretty decent. I would def come back from time to time.

address: 260 Orchard Road, Robinsons Orchard The Heeren, B1-02A Singapore 238855 Singapore
comment: The gyoza is one of the best I have ever eaten. I am usually not a fan of gyoza as it is usually sticky, mushy or has a thick layer of dough.I am pretty much blown away with the gyoza here. The dumpling is nicely crisped on one side. The skin is very thin so you do have to deal with chewing through to reach the filling. I had the pork gyoza so the meat was moist and very juicy. Dip it into the sauce and topped with ginger and you have a winner. There are 3 types of fillings now - pork, vegetables and prawns.I also tried the jyajya  men. I was curious about it as there was an instruction sheet on each table on how to enjoy it to its maximum. It was basically chewy noodles with miso paste, minced meat and green onions. Add vinegar and chili oil (or chili flakes) to taste. I found that to be a bit on the bland side, maybe I did not add enough  seasoning. Halfway through the noodles, you could add the soft boiled egg (the server would bring it over when you tell them you wish to have the egg), more miso paste and a bit of the noodle water to have a soupy eggy noodle. This was much better as the additional miso paste did give more taste to the noodle. The highlight is still the gyoza. Order a plate or three. It is that good. The pan-fried version that is.

address: 260 Orchard Road, Robinsons Orchard The Heeren, B1-02A Singapore 238855 Singapore
comment: I love love love gyozas and this is THE best place in singapore for gyozasThe skin is thin, the filling fresh and tasty and the little bundles of goodness fried to perfection -- With just the right amount of crisp on one side. My two favourites are the pork and the veggie gyozas. The prawn gyoza is ok but i didnt like the crab at all. Every now and then, theyll come up with some funky flavors like curry chicken (so-so) but i know better now and stick with my usuals.Also recommended: the garlic fried fried rice, chicken karage, whitebait, chicken cartilege.Surprisingly, the mixed sashimi platter is pretty fresh and affordable at $28. Theres a special for a bucket of kirins ($25+) but sake is on the pricey side. I wasnt impressed with the salad, edamame (tasted like the frozen ones from ntuc) or the jya jya mienWould give it 5 stars if the other dishes were as good as the gyozas.

address: 260 Orchard Road, Robinsons Orchard The Heeren, B1-02A Singapore 238855 Singapore
comment: This is Gyoza heaven!After reading the positive reviews on Yelp I decided to stop here during a shopping trip at Orchard so expectations were high but I am happy to report that this place did not disappoint.I must agree with precious reviewers though: stick to the Gyoza, I had the basic fried pork kind and these were super delicious! The skin was thin and crispy and the filling tasty and balanced. I also had the boiled crab gyoza and while they were really nice, I still preferred the fried pork ones but this might just be personal preference.A nice plus is their condiments: they have a range of condiments (including sliced ginger - my fave)  on the table so you can mix your own dipping sauce (in my case: heaps and heaps of ginger with black vinegar and a dash of chili oil). Additionally I also had the clam dish (I believe it was called LaLa soup) which was very average, nothing too special to it.Would I go back? YES, I would definitely make a detour for this to fix my dumpling craving!

address: 260 Orchard Road, Robinsons Orchard The Heeren, B1-02A Singapore 238855 Singapore
comment: Gyoza, usually a side dish at Izakaya or ramen-ya, becomes the leading star at Gyoza-ya. Having opened at the old Heeren since last year, it has introduced new items to meet the ever-changing consumers' tastebuds. One of my favourites picks was the all-new Crab Gyoza $7.80, an interesting and flavourful twist to the traditional meat filling. Made with fresh crab instead of frozen crab meat, each dumpling is wrapped with the exact same amount of filling, churned and measured to perfection by the machine.The other new dish is the Tonkatsu Udon ($6.80). The creamy broth tasted like Ban Mian Soup--light but no less oily than a Tonkotsu ramen. The "udon" belongs to the flatter Kishimen Udon that is popular in Iwate prefecture. It resembles Ban Mian, but softer in texture.Pan fried food tends to win over steamed or boiled ones because they have the extra fragrant burnt aroma. But hey, the Boiled Pork Gyozas($4.80) are not too bad either. Succulent and well-seasoned, the skin is just slightly thicker thus chewier than Xiao Long Bao. I thought the chefs were pretty clever to drizzle them in sweet miso sauce. Too much meat? There is always the Vegetable Pan Fried Gyozas($4.80), just as freshly made like their gyoza siblings.  If you like unfiltered sake, this is one of the places in Singapore that actually imports this premium brew from Japan.Gyoza-ya also prides itself as being the first to serve this Jya Jya Men($6.50) in Singapore. Not to be confused with the typical Chinese or Korean bean paste noodles, Jya Jya Men is an Iwate prefecture delicacy that ranks together with Wanko Soba and Rei Men (Cold Noodles) as Morioka's Top three Noodles.What's the difference? The noodles and the way of eating. Either Kishimen aka flat udon (same as the Tonkatsu Udon) or the usual thick udon, are topped with Minced Meat Miso & Cucumber and eaten with chilli oil and vinegar. After emptying the noodles, the staff will add a soft-boiled egg, more miso minced meat and some boiling water that was used to cooked the udon. Stir everything and you'll get this greyish broth. Doesn't taste as rich as it looks but neither is it as slurpy as ramen broth. I loved the Yaki Azuki Gyoza out of all and felt that it needn't be eaten as desserts towards the end of the meal. Sweet red bean mash encased in thin, crisp shell that reminded me of my all-time love, the Croissant Taiyaki. Never mind if there isn't any butter since they're probably healthier. Matcha, Sesame and Yuzu Ice Cream ($6 each) imported from Hokkaido are also wonderful sweet endings, though the red beans were undercooked. The biggest draw factor is the price. With the gyozas at an average $4.80 for 5 pieces and other food not exceeding $7, it's possibly one of the best deals for Japanese food in Orchard.

address: 260 Orchard Road, Robinsons Orchard The Heeren, B1-02A Singapore 238855 Singapore
comment: Gyoza-ya, under the care of Akashi Group has made the headline again among foodies since its opening in 2014. I tried to make myself available but every time I'm ready, something caught up. It's kinda sad when I am away from home most of the time with very brief period each time when I return from abroad. But I know I can't find excuse not to visit this time in Jan when I schedule my unplanned return to SG. I have been eating dumplings in Australia and they were mostly made by the mainland Chinese who flock the country of late. But I wasn't expecting the same at Gyoza-Ya, simply that I have read reviews from reputable accolades and I know they are one of my trusted source. I reached the humble outlet prior the dinner crowd: the time reads 6.15pm. There's ample tables to go around for 4s but 2s were almost taken up. The wait staff was polite and obliging to give me a table near the corner of the restaurant when I turned down his offer on the small table next to the entrance, neither a bar counter seat is welcoming, I told myself. I was given a small slip of order list that spells what the restaurant offers. Quite extensive given the size of the humble eating place. The service was very prompt and attentive. My Yuzu Cha arrived quickly and order was taken attentively. I was such a glutton that I ticked so many dishes that they seems to battle for table space when they arrived.  The soup udon was so flavorful that I can't bear to let them drained any unconsumed broth into the sink! The thick slab of char siew was equally good!! Tender and very well marinated, a good layer of lean plus fats goes so well. The JyaJya Men on the contrary didn't fare that well, perhaps the miso wasn't as robust. On average, the udon has a good chewy texture but still, I prefer the round udon to flat udon, the latter has a tougher bite. Gyoza-Ya serves only flat udon. Red king crab dumplings are a must eat. At $7.50, I got 5 plump gyoza filled with juicy minced crab meat, it's a premium dish in affordable price I must say. I like my dumplings boiled every time I had gyoza, even when I had them abroad. The pan fried pork dumplings were excellent too! Not greasy and there's a faint sweetness from the chopped cabbage mixed in the minced pork. The fried soft bone chicken chunks was crisp and addictive. I like the fried batter coating, it taste like the prized crunchy batter bits from long john silver fast food chain! Salty but a delightful way! It's a hate it or love it dish if u don't mind eating soft cartilage. What I least like was the tofu topped with minced beef, the seasoning in the beef just taste weird which I find no words in describing. I'm sorry. But the tofu has a silky texture. I'm glad to have made the trip tonight. Now, I can strike one restaurant out of my to-eat list that goes on and on whenever I leave my home base. Gyoza-Ya, indeed an inexpensive dumpling house that every foodies should at least try once. YUM!!

address: 260 Orchard Road, Robinsons Orchard The Heeren, B1-02A Singapore 238855 Singapore
comment: Read good reviews of this place and decided to check things out for myself. Garlic Rice - both the versions with or without seafood are really tasty! It's a small portion but the price is not high too lah. Tori Karaage - very deep fried but a tad tasteless leh. Rather disappointing...Ramen - they only have one type of ramen. The texture of the ramen is quite QQ so not bad actually. The broth is also the thick pork-based one. My girl actually wanted a whole bowl by herself. Of course we had Gyoza too and yes yes, the Gyozas were very nice. Crispy base and soft steamed dumplings tops and flavourful fillings!! Not sure if I'll return again for a full meal but yes, the Gyozas are worth checking out at least as a snack.

address: 260 Orchard Road, Robinsons Orchard The Heeren, B1-02A Singapore 238855 Singapore
comment: Good: they have vegetarian Gyozas. Not so good: the vegetarian stuffing is really boringBad: located in the basement of the shopping center in the midst of the home appliance section, you can hardly call it "atmospheric"

address: 260 Orchard Road, Robinsons Orchard The Heeren, B1-02A Singapore 238855 Singapore
comment: Definitely a fan!The noodles to be eaten two ways is absolutely brilliant! I am only torn as to how much noodles to leave behind for the soup version. Plus, I am easily influenced when dishes comes with runny egg.The gyozas are great too. I prefer the fried version to the boiled version but I like both the pork and vegetables version. The veggies are chopped just coarsely enough to retain the bite and crunch.The rest of the side dishes are all good and decent. Karage chicken perfectly seasoned, garlic fried rice is a nice dish to share, they also have seasonal karage soft bone. Yummy place.

address: 260 Orchard Road, Robinsons Orchard The Heeren, B1-02A Singapore 238855 Singapore
comment: We began with two small seasonal appetisers (some thin rice noodle with goma [sweet sesame] sauce) and shredded teriyaki chicken. The noodles were smooth and delicate but slightly bland even with the goma sauce. I suppose the point was to appreciate the texture of the noodles. Meanwhile the teriyaki chicken was a little too sweet and sour, and didn't really taste like teriyaki at all. Indeed it was kind of like shredded jerky.Gyoza is what this place specialises in. The gyoza were bigger than at other places and the skin was smooth and not overly-thick like at some places. However the gyoza were not sealed so the meatballs inside fell out sometimes. Also the taste of the pork inside was a little odd. The gyoza sauce here seems to be a mix of, among other things, soy sauce, vinegar, oil and sugar. This compares to vinegar at many other places.We also had 2 types of noodles: jyajya men and tonkotsu udon. Jyajya men is like the Japanese version of Chinese zhajiang mian - noodles with a black meat sauce on top. Unfortunately these noodles were rather bland - more sauce was needed, and the sauce wasn't all that fragrant in the first place. It got even worse when, as recommended, I cracked in a soft boiled egg, added some sauce and hot water - it was even more bland. The tonkotsu udon was much better, being served in a rich meat broth.We also had seafood fried rice since the portions were quite small. It wasn't bad as far as Japanese fried rice goes (I think because they fry it on a grill instead of a wok it doesn't have much wok hei [smokiness of the wok] that Chinese fried rice has), but there was hardly any seafood inside. And yes, the portion was small to.The individual dishes are cheap but they add up to more than you'd expect! With two cups of green tea it added up to $40.60.

address: 260 Orchard Road, Robinsons Orchard The Heeren, B1-02A Singapore 238855 Singapore
comment: Seriously good gyoza! Loved the menu. Great place for the guys to go out for dinner after a hard day. Prices are excellent. Dumplings are made fresh (you can watch them!). Plaza Singapura location was crowded and service was very busy. Heerens location is by far the best one. It is hidden in the basement level next to housewares. Plus it has the cheesy gyoza!

address: 260 Orchard Road, Robinsons Orchard The Heeren, B1-02A Singapore 238855 Singapore
comment: I don't know whats the fuss about this place, food is so so. Food presentation can be improve tremendously. But the place is great, good for hanging out and catching up with friends. And its near marks and spencer so you can do some shopping after.

address: 260 Orchard Road, Robinsons Orchard The Heeren, B1-02A Singapore 238855 Singapore
comment: Yummy gyoza. They've got quite a few varieties of 'em, including curry chicken (!!). Our family liked the vegetable and the pork (classics), and the mentaiko (cod roe) gyoza.The other dishes aren't particularly outstanding though. The garlic fried rice was A-OK. The spicy ramen was way too hot! I'll have to try the regular pork bone broth ramen another time.This is a very affordable place - we spent about $22 per person.

address: 260 Orchard Road, Robinsons Orchard The Heeren, B1-02A Singapore 238855 Singapore
comment: TL;DR - GO FOR THE PAN-FRIED PORK GYOZA AND DONT BOTHER WITH OTHER STUFF!! unless you realllllly want to, then maybe get the garlic fried rice.Ladies and gents, today is the day I learned about the existence of this amazing gyoza... while deciding what to order from deliveroo.And... OMG, Gyoza-ya, where have thou been all my life?The Yaki Buta Gyoza, aka the pan-fried pork Gyoza, is a MUST must must order. I already had high expectation from all the rave reviews on yelp, but I was not disappointed. The thinness of the gyoza skin, the perfect sear, the delicious minced pork that went so well with the vinegar sauce - just blew my mind. It's the absolute star of this restaurant. In fact, next time I wouldn't bother ordering anything else and just order multiple servings of this.It's 5 pieces per serving by the way. I think i can easy eat 20 of these by myself.However since I had to meet the $25 delivery order limit, I ordered other stuff too. Namely:Sui Buta Gyoza (boiled pork dumpling) - meh. Maybe bc it was delivered, i find that the thinness of the gyoza skin, which is what made the pan fried version so amazing, does not transfer over to the boiled version. Also not a fan of the sweet sauce that they douse all over it. I may have liked it more without the sauce.The garlic egg fried rice - this was much talked about on yelp so I gave it a try. And... I mean, it's good, but just like garlic fried rice in other japanese places.Broccoli aburi - meh. This was a weird deep fried(?) broccoli with bonito(?) flakes on top. Not really a fan.Ramen egg - i only needed another $2 to get to $25 so I threw this in. It was a good ramen egg, but it's what you should expect in other japanese places as well.

address: 260 Orchard Road, Robinsons Orchard The Heeren, B1-02A Singapore 238855 Singapore
comment: Practically the best gyoza outside Japan! I loved their boiled gyoza with prawn fillings. The fried tofu with minced beef is very nice as well. I did not order other things, because from what I heard, only the gyoza is worth ordering. If you are not a big eater like me, this place is just FERFECT! It's nice for in-between lunch and dinner timing, the environment pretty quiet on weekdays, it has spacious area with cute Japanese interior. Pricing is ultra reasonable! I will be back. :DHowever, only 1 thing got me turned off, they don't refill your green tea, I mean how difficult it is to do that?!!! And it's not like their green tea is free or tastes super good or something. I just thought it's a mandatory thing to provide free refill in a Japanese restaurant. Sigh.PS: THE GYOZA SAUCE IS BOMB and there is one on every table. Loving the free-flow ginger too! Is it just me or every dumpling tastes better with bunch of ginger, soy sauce, chilli oil and sesame oil! :p

address: 260 Orchard Road, Robinsons Orchard The Heeren, B1-02A Singapore 238855 Singapore
comment: The MOTHER of all Gyozas in Singapore is found in the basement of Robinsons Orchard. I know, i know... you're all thinking, how can you make a restaurant out of a side dish?!?!? Well.., if the skin is crisp and thin and the pork is tasty, then yes it can be done! I'm a simple man. I ordered three servings of the Pan-Fried Dumpling w/ Pork. Yes, you heard me! Three Servings! One for me, myself and I. Please note that the restaurant offers a version with Prawn or Vegetable, take your pick! To round up the meal I ordered two servings of Ninniku Yaki Meshi, more aptly known as Japanese GARLIC Fried Rice. As an avid rice lover, this rice dish just hit the spot, hence the needs for the extra serving.I'm sure some of you have been in the situation where the food was so good that any form of communication between you and your significant cease to exist. Well, it happened on my first and definitely not my last visit to Gyoza-Ya. :D

address: 260 Orchard Road, Robinsons Orchard The Heeren, B1-02A Singapore 238855 Singapore
comment: Consistently good across the 2 outlets on Orchard. The gyoza pan frying is down to a precise science! New small plates I'm discovering also are outstanding. Shirasu Age is a whitebait fish lightly battered. Nikujyaga is a stewed vegetable and beef small plate. Both I recommend ordering on top of everything else. And I'm happy they've stuck to a limited menu offering so what they do, they do well.

address: 260 Orchard Road, Robinsons Orchard The Heeren, B1-02A Singapore 238855 Singapore
comment: Love their gyoza. The yaki cheese gyoza was especially wonderful, definitely recommended for cheese lovers. Ramen was not bad for a small serving too, though the meat did not look appetizing. The pricing and small servings allow one to order a variety of dishes - which is good for those who want to try different things.

address: 260 Orchard Road, Robinsons Orchard The Heeren, B1-02A Singapore 238855 Singapore
comment: Poor service and incredibly slow. Dishes not authentic. Very greasy.

Came here on a Sunday evening, for two, place was rather empty, so just order, grab a seat, and they will bring the food to you. There are no freshly made drinks except lime cordial, so I guess it was between lime cordial and teh botol.We got rice and a few things to share: Assam fish, beef rendang, sweet potato leaves, fried tempeh, and deep fried hard boiled eggs. Man, the food here is SALTY! I would rate everything here as average, and the sweet potato leaves were quite old, and also dripping with salt. Tempeh was over fried and slightly burnt, and the Assam fish was nice and spicy, but was let down because they used poor quality catfish that was inherently salty, which brought down the dish despite its great sauce. The saltiness of everything here was quite evident to us on our extra order of rice, given both of us aren't huge rice eaters. The cost came up to about 30 for two of us. I don't think I'd come back, my hunt for great and inexpensive Indonesian food will probably continue...

I second what Yelper Lyna Y. wrote - everything I ordered was on the salty side. I do like the food as it has a hint of the homestyle smokiness or rempah in the dishes. Unfortunately the saltiness just marred the whole meal as I needed to eat plenty of rice just to tone it down. The chicken rendang is definitely one of the better ones around as the chicken is still moist and not hard and dry. I do like the decor with its posters of Marilyn Monroe and other famous stars of the yesteryear. Then you get a bit of museum feel with old Peranakan style tiles motifs on chairs and around the restaurant. Packets of crackers hanging from the ceiling to be sold. An old ice kacang machine sitting on top of a shelf. Pretty nostalgic.

I've eaten at this cozy place on Killiney Road so many times that I'm surprised I haven't written a review yet. The food is delicious, especially the rendang chicken. It's spicy, but not enough to scare me away. Following the Paleo lifestyle  doesn't allow me to use rice to help with the heat, so I'm always sure to grab a lime juice and a water. They've got many different kinds of chicken to choose from, and also have a rendang beef that I still need to try. They've also got a variety of cooked vegetables, gravy and fried eggs to round out your meal. I found this place a bit intimidating when we first moved because I was going to have to order at the counter and try to pronounce some of the names of these dishes, but have no fear--pointing seems to work just fine for me!

Decent malay food but overall rather salty-tasting. Heard reviews that it serves very good rendang. Now, good rendang is hard to come by in Singapore and I must say I was quite disappointed. The rendang sauce was salty and lack spiciness. The cut of beef was too lean and dry. Hajah Maimunah at Jln Pisang is a much better deal.
Definitely the best Nasi Padang in Singapore! Today I had my usual chicken tauchu with green chilli, fish Assam pedas, kuah lodeh and some rendang!

I didn't know what beef rendang was before stumbling upon this place.  Now, I"m mildly addicted, and whenever I need my fix, I come here.  I don't eat the other stuff behind the glass, but when I've waited in line, people have told me that the other dishes (you can choose a variety, all for the same price) are good.  I don't know if it's that beef rendang is simply pricey or that this place is pricey - but whenever we walk along Killiney and everyone picks their favorite dinner, my beef rendang ends up being the same price as everyone else's combined!

Parking is hell but place is nice and clean with paintings on the wall for sale.There is a place to sit inside with fans to keep you cool while eating the spicy faire.The food is pretty good. I had the rendang, cucumber pickle, spiced fried chicken and rice family style. Apparently the rendang is a must have.

Despite topping the CNN's 'World's 50 Most Delicious Foods' list, Rendang might not yield much promise with its bleh ordinary appearance ( i.e., chunks of meat in a thick gravy) but if you head down to Killiney Rd and find yourself flaring your nostrils at the delicious smell in the air, Warung M Nasir is the culprit. The ingredients (shallots, chilli peppers, lemon grass, turmeric, coconut, and galangal and meat) are simmered for up to four hours for the meat to soak up the goodness of the spices, and the result? Tender chunks of beef (or chicken, goat, or lamb!) that are just unforgettably oh-so-yummy.

This little gem of a eatery is tucked away along the line of shops of Killiney Road. The place is distinctively balinese in decor, painted in warm inviting hues of dark tangerine and has various paintings hanging off the wall that you can purchase. But the food is really what is so stellar about this place. The minute you step in, you are greeted by an array of dishes tucked into a two-level glass cabinet - tangy assam fish, rich sayur lodeh, pan-fried brinjal strips with sambal. Absolutely spoilt for choice and so far, none of the dishes have ever disappointed me. Wash down this rich and comforting meal with a cup of iced teh botol, a sweet and fragrant jasmine tea popular in Indonesia and you will feel all set for a nap.

Opened by and named after Malaysian singer M. Nasir, Warong M Nasir is a cozy little eatery that is worth raving about. The high ceiling, wooden furniture and well-lit setting create a warm and welcoming ambience. With a wide display of kuehs and other dishes, I decided to go with the one that looked the most appealing - the Nasi Padang. One cannot help being drawn to the spread of nasi padang dishes. What I remember to be the most outstanding is the beef rendang, with a perfect balance of spices forming an amazingly fragrant dish. Other recommended dishes include sayur lodeh, tauhu telor, and tapioca plant. For the brave-hearted, you can try the ox tongue, which has an acquired taste and texture and definitely does not appeal to everyone. Those with a low tolerance for hot and fiery fare will be up for a challenge, seeing that they are that generous with their spices. However, just eat the dishes with the generous portion of steam rice served and there should not be a problem.

I didn't know what beef rendang was before stumbling upon this place.  Now, I"m mildly addicted, and whenever I need my fix, I come here.  I don't eat the other stuff behind the glass, but when I've waited in line, people have told me that the other dishes (you can choose a variety, all for the same price) are good.  I don't know if it's that beef rendang is simply pricey or that this place is pricey - but whenever we walk along Killiney and everyone picks their favorite dinner, my beef rendang ends up being the same price as everyone else's combined!

address: 150 Orchard Rd #02-25, Orchard Plaza Singapore 238841 Singapore
comment: Located at one corner of Orchard Plaza. Very crowded during lunch. Great food and value for lunch set. Bara Chirashi $14. Comes with Prawn Miso Soup. Prawn broth in Miso Soup makes it tasty. Generous pieces of sashimi and not over-serving of rice, makes the set even more worth it. Highly recommend to get the lunch set. Look forward to try other menu.

address: 150 Orchard Rd #02-25, Orchard Plaza Singapore 238841 Singapore
comment: Good value omakase and excellent culinary skills at this small & cozy Jap-French restaurant.

address: 150 Orchard Rd #02-25, Orchard Plaza Singapore 238841 Singapore
comment: Every dish was satisfying. Not one disappointed. Devoured the jamon, then the tuna tartar. Beef was so tasty and with great texture. Curry was rich in flavour, great comfort food! Homemade gyoza on the spot. This was foodie heaven! And absolutely loved the friendly, cozy atmosphere. Really felt like a guest at Chef's home. It's all about the food and feeling good with the company.

address: 181 Orchard Rd #07-01, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: This was such good KBBQ in Somerset for a very reasonable price. The side dishes in the buffet were surprisingly really good, and there were so many meat selections marinated in different sauces. Seating was outdoors but not too hot with the fans blowing. The fans were so strong that my hair kept blowing into my face. The staff were very attentive and changed out our paper many times.
One of the Nicest Buffet in Orchard. They do have credit card promotion time to time on 1 for 1. I love the wide range of foods available for dinner.

Sadly I am rating Triple Three less than many fellow yelpers here. There is only one thing I liked here, ie service. One word summed up the whole experience: meh!FOOD 3/5Despite the layout to give an impression the range of food was extremely extensive, the food was mediocre at best. Nothing really stood up, nothing to rave about. It was disturbingly mediocre for the price and venue of this lunch buffet. To me, they are just lousy calories I was consuming. AMBIENCE 2/5The tables and chairs were arranged so close to each other. It was like a dining hall in a college but those tables and chairs in my college were not even that close. It was a pain to walk between chairs at different tables. And mind you I am not even that broad. I had to be careful not to bump onto any chairs on both my sides. Also, I find some of the patrons Triple Three attracted were .. how should I put it nicely? Hmmm.. ok there is no way but to be blatantly honest here, the word is "selfish". I witnessed some patrons would took all the pan fried salmon after the chef cooked a batch of them and placed in the tray.  Clearly there was a line behind. These people were those who would go to any buffet and displayed their lack of etiquette and wanted to make sure their consumption was worth every penny they spent. SERVICE 5/5The staff who took care of our table was really friendly and attentive. She would clear our plates promptly and refilled our water. Moving forward, I would not even eat here for free. Even a top notch service would not move me. It is such a pity. Sorry, but not really.Triple Three = 3 3 3 = 9/3 = 3 Stars :PA little update: My brother just told me what was the cost per pax for lunch buffet at Triple 3, almost S$100 including tax per person!! That was one way overpriced and mediocre lunch I ever eaten for a while :(

We came here for lunch last weekend. The food was okay, but it was hard to get food. Instead of laying things out, Triple 3 prefers to have their staff serve you, so that creates lines all over the place. For instance, they cut your sashimi to order, so that takes a little longer. Or the snake of people in line for naan, which blocks off most of the indian food area. The pasta station only had one burner, so it was also a wait for pasta. There was also a line at the tempura station, and the tepanyaki station. I have never been to a buffet that required so much waiting in line. I think this is a big issue, and I won't be back because of it. The lines die down towards the second half of the meal service, but that means I have less time to eat.In terms of quality of food, the salmon sashimi was okay, but the swordfish was very watery. The tempura was well done, light and crispy. The pasta was okay. The meats were not very flavorful. Despite being offered a variety of food, I found my plate constantly filled with the same items, usually items that don't require me standing in line. There was a one-for-one special if you use a POSB/DBS card, so we took that offer. They actually didn't bother to verify that we had the card before giving us the bill. I think the buffet was meant to be cheaper...please don't ever pay the full price for this. For $78++, you can do a lot better.
Lots of food options. Definitely one of the best buffet I have ever tried. Like the Indian corner. The dessert choices were good. Definitely will be back for it.

Great American Buffet!!!!! Good quality American food, although it's buffet style, some items are made to order with nice plating! $108++ for dinner is worth it! They have air flown corn fed sirloin and of course all you can eat and cooked the way you want on the spot!

A weekday spread here is as scrumptious and indulgent as a weekend buffet spread that I have had at most of the other buffet places in Singapore. With many live stations, the sushi station and the grill are hot favourites with perennial queues. My favourite, however, is the outstanding tempura live station where the batter is as good as it gets. I hardly finished sampling the entire spread given over 8 counters to choose from, every culinary station hardly disappointed. the roast and indian are highlights done rather well at a buffet where I would have expected less given the quantity. But here there's no compromise on quality too. If you love seafood like I do, the crab legs and succulent prawns, are juicy and sweet with a fresh ocean savouriness rather than a stale fishy taste that I've had at other buffets.Kudos to a great buffet spot,  but it's always packed, so do book early!
Good spread with sashimi and cold seafood. The warm food included roast beef and a good combo of indian food. Attentive staff makes for pleasant lunch.

If you're craving for tonkatsu after a whole day of shopping, there's only one place you should / must head to - Tonkatsu Ma Maison. Located on the 2nd floor of Mandarin Gallery. I ordered the Oysters and Rosu katsu set and it was delicious. Crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside. The oysters are a bit too rich but it comes together in a set so that's fine. The rice, cabbage, and soup are free-flow, so eat to your heart's content.  I would gladly pay $35++ for a meal here for it's warm, attentive service and delicious katsu!

We randomly stopped in here for lunch while wandering around Orchard Road. My husband and I ordered the Rosu and Hire sets. The tonkatsu came out perfectly, was a deliciously crisp piece of meat with all of the traditional items that come with tonkatsu: rice, shredded lettuce, spicy mustard, and soup. I think we cleaned off our plates fairly quickly :) The only small complaint I have was that it seemed like the restaurant was severely understaffed. There was one server who waited on all the tables on the main side of the restaurant as well as the opposite side. Sitting down at a table was quick, but waiting to submit our order took much longer.

For a weekday night, the place packed fairly quickly. The menu consisted of deep fried meat and seafood. Most of items in the menu was in set, which served with rice (choice of white or jyukkokumai (multi grain rice)), tonjiru soup ( miso soup with pork), cabbage and pickles and all were refillable. Each meal was accompanied with roasted barley tea, started with a small dish of grated radish and ended the meal with a bowl of plain looking jelly.There was goma (sesame) dressing and soyu on the table to add to the shredded cabbage. For the deep fried items, there was sweet and spicy Tonkatsu sauces to dip with. Want add kick, add some freshly grated sesame seeds.Mille Feuille Truffle Katsu (S$33.80++)Truffle chips, Top quality truffle salt, Special truffle pasteOne could smell the truffle when it was served. As the meat were thinly sliced and layered on top of each other, the patty was tender and soft.Cheese Mille-feuille KATSU Set ($26.80++)Deep-fried Multi Layered Sliced Pork Cutlet with CheeseSimilar to the truffle version, the meat was tender and soft. The melted cheese really stretched and very long too.IBERICO PORK Rosu (Pork Loin) Set ($34.80++)The most disappointing dish out of the 4 ordered items. The meat was quite tough and dry. One could not if there was any different from the usual pork loin. A waste of money for this dish.Katsu Don ($21.80++)Deep fried pork loin topped with egg and special soy sauce Although it was the cheapest among the 4 dishes which we ordered, it tasted not bad.As the place was packed, one had to wait for the bill. There was some error with the bill but it was swiftly corrected.

This is definitely the best tonkatsu shop in Singapore. In addition to more variety (eg. Kurobota, prawn, fish, Nagoya style, etc) , the tonkatsu here is just extraordinary - moist inside and crispy batter outside. My fav is the jumbo pork loin. Side dishes are sometimes questionable; for example, the grilled mentaiko is too The mixed grain rice, soup and cabbage (all with free refills) are also superior. On weekends, ne prepared to queue. Votre maison est ma maison when it comes to tonkatsu!!!
Food nothing special, prices very high and very stingy - for example, we asked for a bit more shredded cabbage and were refused.I think there are plenty of better ways to spend your money.

Regretted ordering the oyakodon with pork katsu the moment it arrived. Covered by both egg and sauce, the crisp outer layer quickly became disappointingly soggy. The meat within was nothing special either and wasn't as tender as expected. The dry one that came with rice on the side fared much better. The crispy katsu tasted pleasantly mild, without the all-too-familiar stench of reused oil. However, it's definitely not worth the price at ~$25-35 per set. Service was impeccable. The waiter checked in on us regularly, ensuring that we had no shortage of rice and cabbage. Also, I quite like the DIY aspect of it all where sauce is poured at our discretion onto the little platter with demarcated wells.

Ma Ma Mia!Tonkatsu by Ma Maison has been one our favourite, if not favourite restaurant for Tonkatsu. Naturally, the star of a Tonkatsu restaurant should be.... Well the Tonkatsu but as important and glorious as that piece of beautifully fried pork should be, I personally feel that the side dishes that comes with it plays a very big part too. There's no use having a great piece of protein, only for it to be ruined by a lousy bowl of rice or a soggy salad. Thankfully, that's the part Tonkatsu by Ma Maison gets perfectly right.There are a few option of meat to chose from here but after trying a few, I would highly recommend getting the Rosu (Pork Loin).Jumbo Rosu Katsu Set ($29.80)This is for the ultimate meat eater. 250g on perfectly fried, juicy pork loin served with rice, soup and free flow salad. First, the loin. A perfect balance of fat, ensuring that every night is a good one. Mix it the perfect crispiness of the breading and the Rosu Katsu in the fantastic Tonkatsu. It's seasoned beautifully, perfectly fried and juicy with every bite. Perfect! The salad that comes with it is perfect as well. It may only be cabbage, but the freshness, crispness and sweetness of the cabbage helps cut down the oil in the Tonkatsu, making it easier to finish. The soup that comes with it is perfect as well. These aren't simple bowls of pre-mixed miso soup as well. Made with carrots, Radish (daikon) and pieces of pork, these little bowl of soups are stars of their own, helping ensure the sweetness of the cabbage and its sesame sauce, doesn't over power the pork loin, allowing its umami-ness to shine through. To ensure that we don't over eat or overload ourselves, we tend to order a Jumbo Ruso set with an additional rice set ($4.00) to share, which is more than enough for us. Overall, we really love the restaurant and really can't find any fault with it. Simply love the Tonkatsu here and still our go to place whenever we have the craving for it!

Tried this place for the second time, when I come to Singapore for business trips I normally stop nearby so it's within walking distance. The place is nice, good sevice and quite similar to a Tonkatsu-ya in Japan, food is not exactly cheap.I loved the miso, tsukemono, brown rice choice and all the sauces. Shame for the main thing, which is the tonkatsu, it wasn't all that great, quite dry despite me ordering the Kurobuta Hire which is meant to be the best pork that they have on offer.ALl in all I have had better, but it's a decent option if you are in the area and really want to eat Tonkatsu.

One of the most expensive pieces of fried meat I've eaten. Can't say I'd eat here often or even come back again, but I felt pretty satisfied after polishing off my set meal. The restaurant was half empty(full) when we walked in around at almost 9pm on a Friday evening. They had a "MisoKatsu Fair" special at the time: sizzling negi miso rosu katsu set (pork loin with negi miso sauce and egg) for ~S$24++. Pork fillet went for a dollar more. FYI pork fillet is also known as tenderloin and is the leanest of all cuts, so it's a healthier choice. My friend got the pork fillet, and it was less flavorful in my opinion. The chefs cook the meat in a open kitchen right in front of the bar, so you can see the marbling of the meat before they fry it up. To be honest, I expected the pork to be cooked with a bit more skill or technique. Although the meat was very high quality, the end result was just like another fried piece of meat. The sizzling platter was a nice touch as it kept the food warm, but it wasn't a testament to the cooking. The side dishes were nice, but nothing spectacular or unique.After adding on a chocolate cake dessert (just for good measure), the damage came up to about S$35. Glad I tried it, but not willing to pay this much again for some fried pork cutlet.

2 stars - this place isn't the best for tonkatsu, but if you're at the mandarin gallery and are craving it, then don't hesitate. They give you a scoop of rice, japanese cabbage salad both with unlimited serving and a small bowl of miso soup. I get that they serve many types of pork but the quality just isn't there. I have had much better tonkatsu elsewhere. I was really disappointed with my dish. Since you can't go wrong with rice and cabbage, my grief is with the other items on the plate. I had the mangalica rosu katsu and guess what, the meat was stale, not crispy, not tasty, and jerky. Other people who think this place has the best tonkatsu either they haven't had real good ones or I was just unlucky to be facing a gruesome experience here. It's really a nightmare for me. The cashier was nice though. On the side note, you may want to put the sauce on the side, because your tonkatsu might get soggy by the end.
Good food, great service. Totally worth a visit.We were here for lunch and try out the set meal.The portion is a lot but tasty, the taste get better with the sauce added.Thoroughly enjoy the meal

This tonkatsu is to die for!!! I loved it. Well, I also haven't been to Tonkichi in a really long time and that used to be my go-to place for gd tonkatsu, but my bro said this place won over Tonkichi when he went on a tonkatsu hunt with his gf. Anyway, I don't like very fatty cuts of meat, so I went for hire-katsu and it was deliciously juicy! As other reviewers have mentioned, the tonkatsu tasted really light and not soaked in oil as is typical of not-so-good places. It was amazing and made me very happy. I got the 120g portion, which actually didn't look like very much but was pretty filling. $22.80++The tonjiru soup, pickles, and cabbage are all free flow. Soup was delicious! And had a ton of ingredients.. Very comforting and brothy and hearty. Cabbage dressing was also very good, went well with cabbage. OH, big plus for being able to get brown rice! I LOVE brown rice. and at no extra charge. Makes me even happier :)Only thing is that I like Tonkichi's actual sesame seed grinder (sort of like mortar and pestle) as opposed to Ma Maison's plastic container thing that effectively does the same thing. Oh! But Ma Maison had both spicy and sweet tonkatsu sauce, never had the spicy one before. Pretty interesting. Liked both of them!Orange jelly that came after the meal was really strange and artificial tasting though, skip that.. Service was okay, took a while to get anyone's attention, I suppose things were getting busy on a Thursday night. It took a while for them to give us warm water and I had to keep asking for more though.

This has always been one of my staple Tonkatsu restaurants despite its higher than average price tag. The quality is decent for the katsu itself but recently when I returned its tonjiru that's always served in the teishoku was weak and flavorless. The tea jelly dessert too was pretty awful. I'd return just for the katsu and the delicious rice!

I came here because Ippudo had a que but I did hear that this place has some of the best tonkatsu in Singapore and I would have to fully agree. Ok, take this as you will, I'm from nyc and obviously not from Japan, so my opinion might be a bit skewed, but still very much honest. I have had tonkatsu many times in nyc/nj but at ma maison, it was the best I've ever had. The service was great, super friendly and very helpful. It's hard to find good service like that here so it was really refreshing to see that again since I left America. The miso beer and sweet potato sochu...awesome! My boyfriend ordered the black pig tonkatsu and he wasn't impressed. The meat was tough, and I'm not sure if its because it might have been a little overlooked or maybe that's just how the texture is naturally. I actually enjoyed his dish. Yes, it was a bit tough and chewy, but it was still juicy and flavorful. I had the tonkatsu fillet and, again, the bomb! That dark sauce is salty and flavorful, plus the nice shredded PILE of cabbage. The sticky brown rice was also fantastic. It was nutty and hearty, just awesome. I want to find out how to make that, because I can get used to that kind of brown rice! Not cheap though. 2 drinks and 2 meals was $100. Thank god the food was good.

A long time ago, I had a really good dinner here with a friend and remembered it for a year and a half whilst away from Singapore. When my craving for katsudon hit me last week, I made the rare special trip to orchard on a weekday to have some katsudon and was sorely disappointed. I'll cut to the chase. The service was appalling. I understand being rushed and busy. I was perfectly happy to wait. However, I do not appreciate being shooed out of the restaurant and made to feel like it was my fault while the manager, I think, scolded the waitress for almost sitting us before another couple that we (and apparently the waitress) hadn't realised was waiting. Embarrassed, we walked out and endured the glares from that couple although all we had done was said 'table for two?' When we were seated, the appetiser came in a very rushed rambling of the description as though he didn't have time for us or this at all. We then proceeded to wait eons for the food until, after realising we kept looking over, the manager finally came over and said 'There's some quality issues with the white rice. We are cooking a new batch now. I think you should change to the brown rice.' When told that 'no, we would prefer to wait for the white rice, thanks', he kept trying to convince us to change our minds before, defeated, he went to the kitchen to check how long it would take. Incredibly, two seconds later, we were told that they weren't sure the second batch wouldn't have the same quality issue (in the white rice? Really?) and we should take the brown rice. 'Should' was being used in a 'you should take it or you have no rice' sort of way. At this, we had no choice but to agree to the brown rice. At this point, I'd like to say that I have nothing against brown rice, but my partner really did not want brown rice and was willing to wait for the white rice anyway.The katsudon did arrive with very little rice drowned in the sauce. It definitely wasn't a good katsudon sauce either and the lack of rice made for a too salty too sweet katsudon. Perhaps they were running out of brown rice, seeing as there isn't any white rice apparently. There wasn't an apology though he did appear at the end of the meal and asked 'did you like the food'. We just smiled, as we didn't want to deal with him anymore, but it was an awfully disappointing experience. In fact, I was still thinking about that satisfying katsudon I never had the next day, and went to Ginza bairin for dinner promptly. I wouldn't recommend people not to go for the tonkatsu, but just a word of caution about the service. Also, I've heard the service at the Bugis branch is much better anyway. For that price and quality though, I'd just go for the cheaper Ginza Bairin's chicken katsudon set. It's much much more gratifying.

This place serves pork cutlets that are crispy on the outside yet very juicy on the inside. I never hesitate to pay a little more to get the Hungary Mangalica Rosu Katsu set at $31.80. The meat is more tender than the other options which are sometimes too dry due to the lean cut.I love the free-flow cabbage as I can gluttonly feast on my favourite sesame dressing that they provide on every table. It also helps me to feel less guilty to eat more vege to balance out my sinful meat.They also serve tea-jelly at the end of your meal. I always enjoy this humble looking jelly as it washes your pallete after the feast.Tonkatsu is a very popular dinner spot. Be prepared to queue at least 45 minutes if you are going at 7pm.

So we were there for an early dinner, and it was a toss up between Tonkatsu and Ippudo. Having never patronised T before, it was a clear winner on the freshness list, and we were warmly greeted by chirpy servers. We were quickly served balls of chilled, grated radish and a detailed look through the menu saw us ordering up Mameton, their self proclaimed bestseller, an Iberico pork set, and an Ebikatsu set. All orders come with a side of rice (plain or multi grain), pickles and soup.Taste wise: wow. It's a clear difference between pedestrian pork, dished out in the Mameton set, and Iberican pork. The breaded crust (panko?) was delightful to bite into, and not cloyingly oily as katsus are wont to be. The Iberico was well marbled, I.e. fatty, which provided a juicy burst or meaty goodness with each bite. It's not to say that the regular version was shoddy, but it just paled so much in comparison when side by side with the Spanish cut. The ebikatsu wasn't too bad, though strangely I adored the side of finely shredded cabbage. Icy cold, the servers would come around offering extra servings of fibre, which went very well when liberally doused with the accompanying sesame dressing. In addition, the meals come with roasted tea and a small cube of jelly as dessert. The flavours seem to vary daily, and ours was peach - cold, clean tasting, and not overly sweet. Price wise, three sets came up to shy of $100, though it also has to do with going for the premium pork. I do enjoy the service though, we're hard pressed to find sincere and friendly waitstaff around here. And the fact that it consists of cute Japanese blokes makes it so much more of a rarity!

The good:  Unlimited rice, cabbage and oh man the condiments.  By the end of the meal my food companion had to stop me from dipping my finger into the sweet, sweet sauce.  I guess my table manners go out the door when it comes to succulent sauce.  Next time I'm bringing a zip lock bag and bringing some home, no joke.  Also worth noting is the breading; light, fluffy and full or flavor.      The bad:  Lots of inconsistencies all around.  The temperature rivaled Antarctica and as a result we shifted not once, not twice but three times until we finally found a spot where we could feel our toes and fingers.  Service was spotty, sometimes we got what we asked and sometimes not.  I'm guessing they were as confused as their logo which is (and I'm not making this up) a pig serving pork.  Speaking of pork, I ordered the one from Hungary and although it's supposed to be fattier than the rest,  it was 40% fat.  I lost almost half of my meal to chewy, inedible swine bits.The ugly:  Given the options, price and location, this is probably as good as it gets in Singapore.  I feel with a little quality control and management direction this spot could skyrocket to the real deal, but it probably wont.  Why?  It doesn't need to, it's the best in Singapore...for now.

My favorite katsu place in Singapore. Although on the pricey side, their pork katsu are always juicy and tasty. Warning though, I brought some senior citizens here once and they complained of too much 'chewing' lol. Their pork katsu are always perfect to me though. I especially love their giant prawn katsu, it's the size of an adult's arm but the meat is still sweet and tender! I also love their miso soup which comes full of yummy veggies and fried tofu skin.

I dream of crispy panko fried porky goodness!One would never guessed that you can open a restaurant with a menu based on Katsu pork. These guys offer fillet and loin cuts from you basic pork, black pork (more fatty tasty), and pork from Hungary (even more fatty goodness). Sized from 180g to 250g. Go with friends and try the different cuts.Comes with free refills of brown or white rice, Soup, and cabbage.

Sometimes when I go to a place like this I am afraid that I want to give them five stars only to justify how much I spent, so I don't feel like a sucker. This meal was excellent, probably the best tonkatsu I have had in Singapore. I am not sure if it was worth $80 for two people with no drinks. The condiments are amazing and the service is great. I am just not sure it is worth spending 2.5 times more than Romankan Yokohama to go here. The black pork tenderloin is really big and satisfying.
