What else can i ask for?! Run by 3 sisters, they stationed themselves in the small area & doesnt seem to chat much. I've been coming here since we moved to north east. ALOT of patience is required to get this noodle. Typically, we q for 30 to 45 mins on a wkend.We love everything about this plate of noodles. Introduced this to a msian fren but she didnt like it. But her opinion is not stopping me from giving 4 shiny stars!

address: #01-64, Kovan 209 Market & Food Centre Hougang Street 21 Singapore 530209 Singapore
comment: I grew up having noodles from this stall. It used to be at #01-51 on the upper level of the food center hence the number 51. But it has since moved down to the lower level facing the back. I love the shredded chicken mushroom noodles and always looked forward to Sunday when I would get to have this for breakfast. The highlight was the sauce. The mixture of the dark sauce with chili coating every strand of the egg noodles (Hong Kong style with a QQ bouncy bite) was simply delicious. After many years of not having the chicken noodles, I re-discovered it again several years ago and fell in love with its special noodles. It has everything! The special noodles comes with wanton, char siew, prawns, braised mushroom and shredded chicken. The wanton is small but is extremely tasty with its soft skin and small bit of minced meat. The prices have increased over the years though. It is also closed for 2 days during the week. Do go early as the noodles get sold out by lunch time, around 1+ pm, latest 2pm. There can be a long line at times where the wait can be 40 minutes or more.

address: #01-64, Kovan 209 Market & Food Centre Hougang Street 21 Singapore 530209 Singapore
comment: I was wandering in Kovan, refusing to bow down to the air-conditioned MEH eateries in Heartland Mall and got myself into the hawker. It was lunch time and the crowds were aggressive. There was a queue outside Ming Fa Wanton Egg Noodle stall, but it wasn't ridiculously long, just a few aunties and uncles in front. Shortly after I joined the queue, thinking of what to eat, the woman behind me talked to her son; they were deciding which wanton mee stall was better. Almost immediately, this auntie in front of me sprang to life: 'This is the nicest stall! You don't buy now they will get out-of-stock.'True enough, when it came to my turn, everything else was sold out except for wanton mee. Even my request for extra char siew was ignored - to save it for full orders? The noodles were firm and chewy with a faint hint of egg flavours; the sauce was a good mix of savoury dips.

address: 33 Seng Kang West Ave #02-K1/K2/K3, The Seletar Mall Singapore 797650 Singapore
comment: Located side by side Sushi express Shukudo is not bad at all considering its location in a neighborhood mall. Fusion menu has wide variety from Japanese style pasta, pizza to more traditional rice dishes. We had a Teriyaki Chicken bowl complete with egg and a hot plate beef steak which was surprisingly tender with wasabi-like sauce that was not spicy but had great flavor! This one is a keeper for sure!
Is a decent place to have good seafood at reasonable price. Love their crab braised beehoon, tasty and fresh.Is always our family go to seafood place for years.

rest_name: Sin Chie Toke Huan Scissor Cut Curry Rice
comment: Tried the scissors curry rice. Must say that it pales in comparison to the beach rd one. But it's the best one can get in the area. The color and taste are comparatively subdued. I had mine to go and they considerately placed a plastic cover inside the brown paper to contain the juices. The curry chicken was okay - I find the curry quite plain as I like my curry spicy. The pork chops ala Katsu could have been crispier and it was just passable. Teh also just so-soIt was quite cheap and really much more reasonable than the rip-off Teochew porridge just down the road.They also sell porridge in the same stall too though.

rest_name: Sin Chie Toke Huan Scissor Cut Curry Rice
comment: This place is known for its Hainanese Scissor Cut Curry Rice. There's always a long queue out the front, so despite the inconvenience of getting there, I made a trip down to check it out.The curry chicken wing was tender but somewhat bland, so I didn't really like that. The pork chops were a little dry, but it was pretty tasty. I liked the cabbage, and stewed fatty pork. They were both perfectly cooked till there was a nice balance between the tenderness and chewiness. The minced pork ball was probably the best item I ordered. It's firm and springy as you bite into it, and very juicy. Full marks for flavours and texture, none for presentation though! There are also a lot of other things to choose from, but that's all I ordered. It's open from 6pm till 5am in the morning. There's a queue even at midnight! But don't worry, they are really fast and efficient. The queue moves quickly.It's located in its own kopitiam space, so lots of space for seating. Parking in that area isn't too bad later at night, but if you're going earlier, you may have to park further away and walk over.

Tucked away in the basement of My Village in Serangoon Gardens I had a lovely quick lunch here. I tried the hot soy chicken and it was delicious! Freshly cooked and not too greasy it was sweet and hot. The chips come with a bit of mayo which is always a plus in my book. Had a refreshing cup of brown rice green tea to wash it down with. First time for that and it was really nice and now I apparently won't get cancer! I highly recommend this little restaurant if you need a quick and tasty lunch. Almost forgot to mention how helpful and pleasant the owner was as well!

This restaurant is located behind a Chinese temple at one end of punggol, which has a golf course and also a florist around that area. It is quite a walk from the lrt about a 10 minute walk and if you don't know the way to walk in you can easily get lost.I decided to dine there one night as i thought the restaurant looked quite classy and it seemed like the food would taste delicious and fresh. I had ordered a tempura soba and i was really disappointed when i saw 2 miserable looking prawns staring at me. The wasabi that came with the sushi was also pretty tasteless and not as 'spicy' as it is supposed to taste like.My friends had actually ordered other dishes like their chawamushi and bento sets but all were of average standards and we were actually paying for restaurant standards, really not worth any cent of it. I should have trusted the reviews online and went for other places to eat.

address: 1 Pasir Ris Cl E hub Downtown East Singapore 519599 Singapore
comment: I've been quite impressed with the food from pastamania lately. The pasta's are well cooked and the sauces are tasty, if not tastier. This time round, I also ordered the calamari rings from their (new) menu. I was pleasantly surprised to find out that the calamari rings were really good! The squid was fresh and the batter was light and crispy. A great dish to order and share.

address: 6 Tebing Lane #01-05 Sports Hub Punggol Singapore 828835 Singapore
comment: This cafe is located at the sports hub in Punggol which is behind the temple and florist at one end of Punggol. It is a convenient place to dine as it has an indoor soccer field and also crabbing, fishing and prawning just beside it. There are other restaurants too and also a nice view as there is the punggol park river that flows along there.I had tried their fish and chips and i loved the batter that they had perfected to the right consistency. The fish was still juicy and it tasted really fresh as well although it had been deep fried.  I loved their fries too, crispy yet good to eat on its own. They were really generous with the food portions too and i felt that they were sincere in wanting to make customers eat valued for money dishes.Service was really awesome as well, and i noticed that they had a wheelchair ramp for easy access for the physically disabled. This would make it wheelchair friendly and add another place to dine for the physically disabled.

Service was very bad for me. Waited to be seated at the entrance and no staff noticed us. The restaurant wasn't full. We were served by a slightly plump lady with dark red hair. She had a very bad attitude and zero experience about the menu. We wrote down our order and she stayed by our table to flip through the menu in front of us and looked at what our written orders are. Benefit of doubt given as she may be new. However, when she served us the food, she slam it on the table and walked away.Very very bad service at this outlet.

So.. I've always been a huge fan of conveyor belt, 100jpy/$1 sushi.. and today was the opening promotion for the Seletar Mall sushi express. Located on the second floor, behind the escalator, the restaurant has a strange layout, in which they fully maximize the shop space with every seat facing the conveyor belt. It might look a bit claustrophobic, as I had initially thought it was.. but after awhile, you are so consumed by the sushi going around you, that you completely forget that the shoulder of the next person beside you is literally inches away from you.Nonetheless, the sushi was fresh! Thick salmon sashimi slices, ikura gunkan, jellyfish, you name it! To be honest, I haven't really had a lot of experience with high end sushi, but hey,.. if the sashimi melts in your mouth like it did when I was in Japan, it works for me too! I really liked the sweet shishamo fish, can't tell if it came out of a can or not, but hey.. 3 pieces of pregnant fish for $1++ works for me :D it's kinda sweet, so hot green tea came in handy!Green tea is free, unlike nihon mura .. so.. wash down all that omega 3, protein fish with hot green tea, the hot water dispenser is available every 2 or 3 seats, so you're never more than an arms' length away from getting hot water. Desserts, there's a variety of desserts, like pudding, cheesecake, cream puffs, chocolate cakes, mochi.. and even collagen jelly packet drinks! I didn't have stomach space to try their desserts, but definitely wanted to try their pudding in the cup, which had what looked like blueberry jam on top of the pudding.. or maybe it was yogurt? I don't know, it was readily available,  I watched it circle the conveyor belt once, and it was never replenished, but I was also too distracted looking at salmon slices floating around too..

As a soup lover, this is my favorite restaurant which I can eat healthily without feeling guilty. Their popular dish Samsui Ginger Chicken is a must have. It is a traditional Samsui dish consumed by the Samsui women in Chinatown who only consumed once a year due to their low income. The chicken was steamed without much seasoning. You can dip the tender meat in ginger sauce.The sauce adds fragrance and tasty compliment to the chicken. A plate of lettuce come together with the Chicken and you may wrap the chicken in lettuce. For me, I prefer to eat the chicken separately.And my favourite soup there is double boiled dried scallop with black chicken soup which according to them invigorates blood circulation & relieve stress which I feel I need it.Oh. There is this An po and ah gong fried tapioca which when I see the menu first time, I was wondering what is it. The difference is only on the spicy. Ah po version is spicier than An gong.

This restaurant is located at the third level of compass point at one corner just beside some optical shop. Most of the time it is quite crowded especially during evening times and you might have to wait pretty long to get a seat.When i first sat down i thought that the menu looked pretty healthy and everything had herbs in them, which i was not used to eating. When the dishes came however, they were pretty tasty and even the ginseng soup that tasted really bitter at first tasted much better as i continued to drink it spoon by spoon.My favourite dish would have to be the ginger chicken with cabbage, as the chicken is really tender and the ginger is a must have to compliment the chicken. I don't normally eat ginger too as it can be quite pungent but this ginger sauce was not pungent at all and was pretty tasty to my liking.

rest_name: Good Luck BBQ Chicken Wings and Satay
address: 20 Kensington Park Road #01-29 Chomp Chomp Food Centre Singapore 557269 Singapore
comment: I was recommended to enjoy this stall's chicken wings and was not disappointed at all. My first few bites of it got me hooked into it almost immediately. When my last few bites came, I wanted to order more and that was how good it was. So if you come by this stall at Chomp Chomp Hawker Centre, you have to give this a try. I have tried the satay on my previous visit before this and I was not disappointed. Its certainly one of the better stalls at the food centre. So put aside your weighing machine, you can worry about that later! More importantly is enjoy the good food especially with your loved ones.

rest_name: Good Luck BBQ Chicken Wings and Satay
address: 20 Kensington Park Road #01-29 Chomp Chomp Food Centre Singapore 557269 Singapore
comment: Good place to spend a bit but too expensive to warrant a large nealThis hawker stall offers various satay and chicken wing. The chicken wings are decent and the satay's flavors are tasty, but at $0.70 per satay the quality doesn't justify the price. If you have a small appetite it might be fine, but if you're like me and going for rounds and rounds of food this place is not worth

rest_name: Good Luck BBQ Chicken Wings and Satay
address: 20 Kensington Park Road #01-29 Chomp Chomp Food Centre Singapore 557269 Singapore
comment: There are a couple of barbecue chicken wing stalls at Chomp Chomp food centre. Good luck BBQ chicken wings has by far been the tastiest there and probably one of the better ones I've tried in Singapore. The wings are barbecued just right, leaving the outer skin crispy while the inner meat, tender and juicy. The overall light burnt taste and secret marinade sauce used makes it super refreshing and addictive. Available at $1.20 per wing, expect yourself to chomp on more than one! Besides BBQ chicken wings, the stall also sells satay (pork, chicken and mutton) at 50 cents per stick. After trying out rated excellent by Makansutra 2011. The stall owner and helpers are pretty friendly, making the ordering process a good one.

address: 1 Pasir Ris Close #02-119 E!Hub Downtown East Singapore 519599 Singapore
comment: Owner was friendly to us patrons and it was such a great atmosphere tbh. The Cheesy Chicken Bruschetta I ordered was a tad bit dry but I took the gravy from the Bangers & Rosti and honestly such a great combo???? I'm not sure what the sausage is made of but it was decent and I thoroughly enjoyed my meal  It looks like a great place to study and an even better place to eat in big groups (the guy was accommodating in terms of seating)

address: 1 Pasir Ris Close #02-119 E!Hub Downtown East Singapore 519599 Singapore
comment: Ribeye Steak, Cheesy Bruschetta Chicken and the Mushroom Chorizo Pasta is good. Quite impressed with the food presentation for all dishes as it really enhances the aesthetic appeal.Mushroom soup flavourful and consistency just right, However the bread was charred and left a bad taste. Did not mention a thing but staff was alert and offered another serving with diluted mushroom soup.Charred Grill Rib Eye came last with the same unbearable 'burnt' smell from the grill. The grill grates were just not scraped well enough.Joe

address: 1 Pasir Ris Central St 3 #03-21 White Sand Shopping Centre Singapore 518457 Singapore
comment: Before my Singaporean friend fly back to Colorado, we met here for a late Thursday Dinner.  Time was about 20:50hrs ish.  Initially we wanted to try another establishment, but in terms of the Food Menu option at that establishment, nothing stood out, hence to Penang Culture we went.Another establishment in town located in a Mall which is located along some random passage way aka, to maximize space of the Mall.  This Penang Culture is located inside White Sands Shopping Centre at the 3rd Level.  They have a separate Kitchen space along one of the corridor that I have passed thru several times in order to find the Washroom for the Ladies at the White Sands.Penang Culture is under the GD Group Restaurants, which have several locations in Singapore.  Is it truly a PENANG food experience?  I bet to differ.  I think its better to go to Malaysia and head up NORTH to PENANG as one of the State in Malaysia to truly experience PENANG food.  *SIGH*Yet another establishment that DO NOT have a brick and mortar location etc.  From the conversations I had with my friend, though she prefers the Changi Airport location better, the White Sands Penang Culture is more convenient for us to meet that Thursday evening.From the Menu we shared the Bronze BBQ Platter ($18.95) and Penang Oyster Eggs ($9.95).  EVERYTHING was SEMI-OK.  Nothing stood out.  At least the Oysters in the "Egg Omelette" is plum and juicy BUT NOT fishy.  The Bronze BBQ Platter comes with Shrimp, Squid, and Satay.  Apparently, the Satay sauce is being poured over the Satay while the Squid is cooked in a different kind of Spicy Sauce.  The pictures featured in their Menu were somewhat deceiving, coz the Satay Sauce from the Menu of 201 - aka Bronze BBQ Platter was in a separate small container.In terms of our Dinner, I feel since it is located inside a Mall and its Air-Conditioned area, portion of the food is tiny.  The pricing was higher compared to similar items of food found at a nearby Hawker Centre.  in terms of flavor it was ok... NOT mind-blowing or mouthwatering.My friend ordered a Plum beverage of some kind aka Ampla Juice ($4.95) while I opt for a Root Beer beverage that evening.  Thankfully Penang Culture is Halal Certified by the MUIS.I may return to another location of Penang Culture and perhaps order some other items in their Menu in which I want to try.  Perhaps from there, my review might differ.Yet another establishment that DO NOT ALLOW separate checks when time to settle the payment.  *DOUBLE SIGH*Penang Culture at White Sands is opened DAILY from 11:00 - 22:00hrs.Penang Culture @ White Sands Pasir Ris1 Pasir Ris Central Street 3,#03-21, White Sands Shopping MallSingapore 518457Tel: 6585 4877gdgroup.com.sg/penang-cu…

rest_name: S B Fish Head Steamboat Seafood Restaurant
comment: I generally don't eat fish head but this place was recommended to me by my husband and his family so i decided to try, ended up just drinking the soup though but it was good enough to go along with some white rice. There tends to be a queue on weekend evenings or even some weekday evenings so do go early to get a seat. I love the soup as it is infused with a lot of flavours and not the typical fishy soup with the smell. There is also a lot of ingredients like tomato, ginger, spring onions etc so it really is good enough to go along with white rice.The service there is not bad too as the staff try to be attentive to customers who need their help be it for ordering or follow up service. A good place to have good rich soup even if you don't eat fish head.

address: 1 Pasir Ris Central St 3 #B1-20/21 White Sands Singapore 518457 Singapore
comment: We are one of the regular customers who love to patronise yakun esp at whitesand outlet.It carries a family ground based friendly ambience with staff who friendly helpful n down to earth   n we cant find such closeknitted relational attitude  at other outlets. The staff here are cheerful n friendly serving with their hearts i believe.Particularly staff Yuding who is always cheerful n friendly. Our grandson baby Luke is very fond of her n her radiant smile have build a rapport n chemistry with our grandson Luke.When she was assigned to work at Sengkang outlet we missed her presence. Now we heard that she will be permanently transfer to Sengkang. We definitely will miss her dearly.We like to commend that we really appreciate her service n cheerful smile n greetings that always made our day shine.we wish her the best in her future endeavours.

address: 1 Pasir Ris Central St 3 #B1-20/21 White Sands Singapore 518457 Singapore
comment: The food is good for breakfast but the service is very slow. The cashier leaves the counter unattended to go pick a broom and sweep while the queue is so long. No proper planning and organizing among the staff

address: 1 Pasir Ris Central St 3 #B1-20/21 White Sands Singapore 518457 Singapore
comment: Have I expressed my love for cheezy French toast before? If I did, please allow me to do it again!Popped by recently for afternoon tea at White Sands and once again ordered the cheezy French toast. I like that the bread is soft and the melted cheese inside taste so well with the kaya dip! I tried to replicate it at home, but I failed terribly. Not because I don't have good culinary skills okay. It's just... I can't outdo Ya Kun! I do like that Ya Kun is constantly introducing new items onto their menu, be it food or drinks. Recently, they have a whole new series of ice blended drinks, which is more modern than the traditional ones served. But they charge for whipped cream, which I thought was unnecessary.

My family and I go to Sakura for all occasions, like family gatherings and birthdays. I'd say the food is very good for value. There is always something different whenever we go, and recently (Mother's Day), there was durian balls among the fried items and a wonderful strawberry mousse cake for dessert. And my favorite yam paste was back! Along with bubur pulut hitam too. 2 years ago, for Christmas buffet, there was roast turkey with cranberry sauce. So good.Despite what my friends say, I find the food delicious. I'm happy to say Sakura is one of my fav places to eat, and I recommend it for those who want to try different cuisines from Japanese (there's sashimi and a whole array of sushi) to Peranakan (ayam buah keluak and kuih pie tee) costing under $30 for an adult. Thumbs-up from me! ;D

Not sure if I am just blind or what, but I keep trying to find places on Yelp and the addresses lead me to someone's house. This restaurant was no different. I ended up at Pasir Ris Close and found it.

By far one of my favourite places to go to for pizzas or delivery, Domino's Pizza runs an awful lot of weekly discounts and giveaways. The pizza is easily one of the best I've had, in terms of the kind you can get delivered. They don't stinge on the toppings nor on the cheese and the sauces they use are pretty darn good. What's more, its really affordable as well. The sides they offer are pretty decent as well, but be careful to not over order, as I have a tendency to do so. 2 large pizzas are really filling and can easily be shared by a group of 4 or more. Delivery times are pretty accurate and precise as well, so if they tell you that it'll take 45minutes, you can be sure they'll be there before the time is up.

address: 93 Pasir Ris Drive 3 #01-02, Pasir Ris Elias Community Centre Singapore 519498 Singapore
comment: Opened 24 hrs. It is a ideal place for friends and family to gather. Indoor's air-conditioned while there is a outdoor area to sit as well. Located just right behind of the bus stop. Food - I'm lovin it.

address: 1 Pasir Ris Close #01-35/36, Downtown East Singapore 519599 Singapore
comment: Undoubtedly, Popeyes is known for their crispy and flavorful chicken! I love their chicken tenders, which are juicy and really 'tender' (sometimes chicken tenders taste pretty tough and dry because they are made from chicken breast). There's nothing to complain about the batter for the chicken as well! The Popeye's recipe is foolproof! The sides go well with the chicken too! I love their mashed potato and Cajun fries in particular. They are more spiced and flavored as compared to those sold at other fast food chains that either taste too salty or too pepperish. A variety of burgers are also available here if you do not fancy chicken.One thing that I do need to point out is that there are several schools around Downtown East, so it tends to get crowded with schooling people on weekdays.

address: 49A Serangoon Garden Way Stall 44 Singapore 555945 Singapore
comment: I read through a compilation of Great duck rice in Singapore and found myself here.At $3.50, -a bowl of rice with gravy-a bowl of fragrant soup-a plate of seemingly endless sliced duck meatMuch value for money and extremely gratifying during a rainy afternoon. This stall spoil market by giving ALOT of meat, though thinly sliced, but easy to eat.Definitely coming backNote that this is not the Cantonese style whereby the duck skin is crispy, this is more of a braised finish with sauce

address: 49A Serangoon Garden Way Stall 44 Singapore 555945 Singapore
comment: Dad insists that he took me here ages ago, but of course I don't remember these things... only his elephantine (and selective) memory keeps track of my childhood food adventures, but I'm glad we had a chance to re-visit this place.Ah Seng (yes, the guy's really called Ah Seng) is an functional as you would expect, dishing out his simple, tasty fare to any and all who come by.Dad orders, and what appears with our rice is this plate of artistry - smooth, braised duck meat, coated in a rich, savoury brown nectar of the gods. Can I use savoury and nectar to describe this? Because that's what it is. Add to that Dad's surprise order of beancurd skin (tau kee), and its the awesomest duck rice meal you can imagine. Unless it's Cheok Kee... that's a tough fight lah.This meal is as much good for your wallet as it is for your love for nostalgia - and in this time of old hawker legends retiring from their woks, and some from this earth (big love to Bedok Corner chng tng's Mr Lim), you owe it to yourself to check this one out.

address: 1 Sengkang Square #04-14/19, Compass One Singapore 545078 Singapore
comment: The Kopitiam at Compass point is pretty big, but seats are always scarce unless you come early in the morning.Speaking of mornings, coming here for a late breakfast is actually not a bad idea. The drinks stall has the standard boiled eggs, toast, and coffee or tea set meals, and even a small selection of dim sum set meals.The rest of the fare is nothing special, but taste decent nonetheless. I usually default to the few choices when I'm looking for a fuss-free meal. If you're a local or have spent a long enough period of time here, you know what I mean: chicken rice, ban mian, those mini wok stuff, etc.

As a north-easterner for the past two decades, I have always passed by this place but did not visit it until a dinner invite yesterday. We order 6 dishes for 7 people - longevity noodles, "fish maw" soup, yam ring, "fish", "satay" and tofu with mushroom and dou miao. Everything was pretty light tasting which suited my palate except for the "fish", which had both seaweed and an overly salty gravy. The chef could have a lighter hand with the seasoning.On the contrary to the previous review, we received good service from the waitresses at this vegetarian restaurant. They were really nice with our birthday cake that we brought over. The waitresses also let on that they brew their chrysanthemum tea with pandan leaves to impart its aromatics and enhance the taste of the drink.The meal was on a slightly expensive side, costing about $140.

This stall is along upper serangoon road and i think it has been around for many years. Decided to try it one day as although i don't take vegetarian food, it seemed like something different from what i have been always eating.When i went in i noticed that the staff were not really attentive to my table and others too and they did not serve customers very willingly, not sure if this was due to their 'popularity' they thought they had. We ordered some dishes like their oyster vegetables, sze chuan dish, mock gong bao chicken and they all tasted pretty good.The only thing i didn't like was the service and i think it was the whole restaurant that didn't seem to like their service too. The price is also slightly on the high end so i don't think it is worth it to dine there with that kind of service.

New business in the area! Replacing Cedele (moved to punggol waterway) in the same spot opposite My Village shopping centre. I've not eaten the claypot rice at geylang before so am not able to make a comparison. You have to pre-order the claypot rice before you reach the place so that you can skip the 30 mins wait of preparation. hmmmm thats kinda troublesome to me. Teh! The claypot rice comes in 2 sizes. Small $18, good for 2  & large $28 good for 4. The server will ask if you would like to mix the salted fish and dark soy sauce while he mix the rice. Traditionally, salted fish is added in for a smoked fragrant. It might look intimidating to some because it looks like a piece of stale meat. The claypot rice is really good! The chicken & chinese sausage portion is generous, in comparison, the few strands of choy sim on top of it looks pathetic. Anyway i think its for plating purpose. If you would like to add more vegs, they have many choices on their menu. We had nai bai with fried enoki, tofu with prawn & salted veg duck soup. The veg & tofu are ok.. I didnt like the salted veg duck soup. Its too salty for me & doesnt go well with the rice. It should go well with plain rice. There isnt a crowd during lunch. The servers are attentive to the extent that whenever someone dropped their chopsticks, they rushed to us. The shape of the bowls that they are using should be changed! It doesnt hold the chopsticks well and it rolls off our table. But they look chic for ... claypot rice. I will return for lunch as its air conditioned & water is served. Not too bad to hide from the heat. Hmm yes, gst + service charge. Total bill: $97.60 for 6 of us.

address: 1 Pasir Ris Central Street 3 #02-01/04 White Sands Singapore 518457 Singapore
comment: Mad Jack is where you can find Halal western food, with a local twist! The food served here is quite decent, and has a great variety for you to choose from: appetizers, finger food, salads, pastas, burgers and even desserts. What's more, the prices are pretty reasonable and friendly to the pocket. If you love chocolate and like it sweet, you'd love their brownie with ice cream and M.A.D & Rich cake. Personally, it tastes a little too sweet.If you're too lazy to get out of the house, you can also call for delivery. Overall, satisfactory food that is value for money.

address: 1 Pasir Ris Central Street 3 #02-01/04 White Sands Singapore 518457 Singapore
comment: Their desserts are rich and sinful, although prices are a little steep. I don't like their fries- I find them a tad too greasy. I like Mad Jack, but I'm not a fan. I'd say there are other places I'd be for the same price.

Came by for lunch the other day and it was a world class experience. Made a reservation direct via the Shangri-La's website and received an e-mail confirmation. Shang Palace is a Michelin 1 star for 2021.Shang Palace isn't near any MRT stations A taxi or rideshare would be helpful. Shang Palace is located on the right hand side after entering the lobby.Tables were placed pretty far apart and front of the house staff wore vinyl gloves. Masks, uniforms, and name tags were all worn by the staff.Service was available, although perhaps not quite up to Michelin standards. Staff were pretty busy presenting dishes to customers.Started off with the shrimp dumpling and it was world class. The skin was translucent and the shrimp were very fresh and fragrant.Moved on to the BBQ rice noodle roll and it was also stunning. Rice noodles were translucent and the BBQ pork was very fragrant and fatty. The soy sauce was perfect too, super light.Their fried dace balls with the clam sauce was also excellent. Perfectly fried fish balls!The egg tarts were baked to order and tasted best fresh!The highlight dessert was their mango pomelo sago which was excellent. Super fragrant mango with pomelo made this a refreshing end for lunch.~$63/head after 10% service and 7% GST

The food was absolutely delicious and fresh but way over priced for dim sum or what I'm used to paying for dim sum. The restaurant was very nice and elegant and very clean. Normal dim sum portion. all the dishes were about $8-$15 for maybe 3-4 pieces. Not your typical place with carts being pushed around. All made to order.

this place is definitely high end. needs reservations and service is impeccable. Food is outstanding.. lives up to the name. You could tell that its a different skill level of the chef to create those delicate dishes.  What got me impressed with the place is also a very diverse diner base. It has cross the cultural divide that even the indians and foreigners were fans of the chinese restuarant.

Since Chef Mok Kit Keung (of 2 Mich star Shang in HK) revamped the cooking and menu, this has become one of the best Chinese restaurants in Singapore. Many classic dishes are superbly executed. Take the deep-fried boneless chicken stuffed with glutinous rice on a bed of crispy rice and mock seaweed (made with deep-fried kai lan); the chicken skin is deliciously crispy, and the glutinous rice is so addictive with yummy mushrooms, dried scallops and prawns. Or the crunchy pork rolls with sautéed fresh milk, egg white and crab meat, or the deboned quail stuffed with bird's nest in a fabulous broth. Innovative touches with the use of ingredients not often used in Chinese cooking, like pigeon, quail, foie gras, frog, truffle paste, etc. Attentive and pro-active service. The menu is quite long, and the overall experience is so pleasant that we would go back often if it were not so pricey. Chef Mok Kit Keung is the King Kong of Kantonese kooking!
This is a great place for dim sum right on the hotel. Premium in every way. Service is good.Recommend.

Mesmerizing Chinese cuisine, you breathe it in while you eat it. Some spicy szechuan or wok fried meat and seafood but delicately so, also steamed fish or stewed duck, roasted chicken or wagyu beef or braised pork or, baked lambshank, crispy noodles or vermicelli noodles, dumplings, and lots of claypot items. The staff serves you new Jasmine tea anytime you're less than half-full on your cup -- they are serious about keeping you replenished. Sophisticated families eat here, and I imagine all appreciate it. Bill quickly goes upwards -- do it anyway, you will recover financially later. #inside-shangri-la-hotel
shangri-la fancy dining. business dinner with delicate dishes, enjoyed the vermicelli claypot with seafood and crunch.

address: 1 Claymore Drive #01-06, Orchard Towers Singapore 229594 Singapore
comment: My Tacometer reads five out of five tacos. Señor Taco does the finest work of capturing the flavor and gritty experience of the best cantinas in Yucatán and Baja. Wise men say the best Mexican food is found in the dirtiest places, so why not put up a taqueria in Orchard Towers?! And I enjoy the taco/cervaza specials. Bang on, mi amigos!

address: 1 Claymore Drive #01-06, Orchard Towers Singapore 229594 Singapore
comment: This place ain't too bad on the tacos, a little greasy, but the food isn't really the problem since there are important factors to consider before a customer is able to receive their food . It's the way this place is mismanaged that matters. If you are the only customer ordering food at a place it should be in the establishment's advantage to be able to meet all request of that single customer. Though this was not the case. I happened to be the 1 customer ordering food and the order was forgotten, literally. All the classic signs of stifling micromanagement of employees, poor service on top of poor service. Though the responsibility lies with the leader, in this case A Filipino woman with no respect for the customer. Photo added.

address: 1 Claymore Drive #01-06, Orchard Towers Singapore 229594 Singapore
comment: One of the Best Mexican food spots your going to get in Singapore let alone most of Asia, coming from someone who is Mexican and has been to many Asian countries, if your looking for artisan gluten free hipster food this place ain't for you.

address: 1 Claymore Drive #01-06, Orchard Towers Singapore 229594 Singapore
comment: Only open at night. Tiny kitchenette turning out quesadillas and tacos soooo greasy as if to help slow down the impact of booze, of which there are lots. The Entertainer offer includes two BOTTLES of tequila for the price of one - not the place for a quiet evening or a fun night with the kids. Their orange-colour salsa is numbing.

address: 1 Claymore Drive #01-06, Orchard Towers Singapore 229594 Singapore
comment: Orchard Towers is known for the "nightlife" (and that's putting it mildly), and now it's known for tacos I guess.This Señor Taco branch is buried behind Orchard Road, in the second block of Orchard Towers along Claymore Drive. It's more like a taco stand, with a couple of tables and chairs, and a limited menu compared to the Clarke Quay location. They sell a selection of Mexican beers such as Negra Modelo and Corona.The tacos are the same, a similar greasy quality to a random mexican place selling tacos on a street corner in the United States. It's not very good, but it's not very bad either. At $8 a taco, you limit what you eat.The staff were helpful and obliging, and it was a weird atmosphere where they blasted karaoke sing-a-long hits for their slightly intoxicated customers and their lady "friends". Let it be clear, I was here to pick up a couple of tacos, not for anything else.

address: 1 Claymore Drive #01-06, Orchard Towers Singapore 229594 Singapore
comment: Love this place! Perfect for a nice drink and great food. Can't wait to come back when I visit Singapore again. The staff is amazing at making you feel at home!

address: 1 Claymore Drive #01-06, Orchard Towers Singapore 229594 Singapore
comment: We went to Señor Taco on a Saturday night with some friends. I really do like the vibe of Señor Taco. It's al fresco dining with a laid back feel and a great location to people watch. The owner is extremely friendly. Our friends eat there often and he went out of his way to make us all feel at home. We took advantage of the happy hour. I tried a mojito. It did not look like any mojito that I have ever tried, but it was refreshing and actually tasted really good.  For our second round of cocktails we all had margaritas. They are good and strong!! As far as the food goes, it is OK. I had an al pastor taco and a carnitas taco. They were too greasy for me and I would not order them again. We also tried the guacamole. Once again, it is OK, not great. I feel like it is almost unfair to try to review Mexican food in Singapore. It is not going to be great. I sound like a pessimist, but honestly, I am just being a realist. If I do go back to Señor Taco it will probably just be for margaritas, not tacos.

address: 428 River Valley Rd Singapore Singapore 248327 Singapore
comment: I've been here several times and while prices have gone up a few dollars each, it still is reasonably priced. Food here is hearty, the atmosphere is casual. The beers are cheap and good! Italian of course. I really enjoy the taste of the pizza crust. It's not the biscuit thin type but it's good a nice soft chew with a bit of a crunch to the crust outside. Toppings are quite generous. Sometimes I like to order some cold cuts and a few of the antipasti. Surprisingly the anchovies are pretty good, and the stuffed peppers always popular for my family. Generous with the clams. On its own or with pasta. And cheaper than other restaurants. Often there are interesting daily specials. I also order takeaway puccia. It's their inhouse made bread stuffed with cold cuts, tomatoes, tuna and chilli. I don't usually go for canned tuna but this combination just works, helps that it's served hot and crops. In fact we often order this to share and have there with other mains as it comes cut into 4 full pieces. Small selection of deserts but the tarts are always good. Only one negative. Sometimes it can be hot but they improved it with some fans. They also are a grocery store selling cheeses and ham by weight and various bottles Italian sauces and condiments. In the freezer at the back are frozen free pasta. Lots of stuffed ones.

address: 428 River Valley Rd Singapore Singapore 248327 Singapore
comment: Cibo was a new entry in "The Loft" when I lived around the corner in Nathan Road. That it has survived is a testament to its success.River valley is a blackhole for restaurants and bars alike. Ernies came and went, as did Brez'n, Starker, Great Thai and even Toni's Pizza.Cibo has avoided the churn by offering authentic bites and booze in an understated chilled corner of The Loft that during the week buzzes with activity.The staff are attentive (and perhaps this is the key), they refill water regularly which is a must in this part of steamy Singapore and they are fast also.I've eaten the bolognese here (great); the charcuterie & cheese board with balsamic glaze (good); and did 2 take-away pizzas (poor) when I had friends over in March 2016.The pizzas, sadly, were a miss. Singapore has very good Italian pizza stores outside of the standard fast food fare and Cibo really should have excelled here. It's a shame because pizza should be their hero dish, and it sours an otherwise good experience.

address: 428 River Valley Rd Singapore Singapore 248327 Singapore
comment: A nice little Italian restaurant and market. They have a great selection of antipasti, pastas and pizzas. A small selection of Italian wines by the glass and beers, as well as a good wine list. Only stopped by for a drink and a quick snack. Looking forward to going back and trying some of the pizzas.The staff and the owners are very friendly and nice. The places is quite small with only a couple of tables outside and inside. Nice rustic decor combined with modern. Enjoyable space.The place isn't just a restaurant but rather also like a mini store. They sell a number of house made pastas, pasta sauces, other premium Italian foodstuffs and the likeWould recommend. Will come back.

address: 428 River Valley Rd Singapore Singapore 248327 Singapore
comment: Went here for dinner and sat inside. Service and decor is good. I ordered the special pasta and it was delicious!! My husband got the lasagna and it wasn't hot enough in the middle, I think they didn't heat it up enough so the outside was really hot but the inside was cold. This and the fact that they served water in plastic glasses is what made me drop 2 stars. Other than that the seem to have a good happy hour deal so I might be back for that.

address: 428 River Valley Rd Singapore Singapore 248327 Singapore
comment: No complaints here! Delicious wine by the glass ($8.50+) is what first caught my attention. I decided to stay for the food and was not disappointed! The pizza with tuna is definitely worth mentioning. It's a combination that I had never tried but I can't wait to have it again. Also a fan of their truffle fries (with big slices of truffles) and the pasta. Can't go wrong here!

address: 428 River Valley Rd Singapore Singapore 248327 Singapore
comment: Tasty and very authentic Italian. Thin crust pizzas. Good range delicatessen too. Friendly Italian hosts

address: 1 Cluny Rd Botanic Gardens Visitor Centre Singapore 259569 Singapore
comment: Mui Kee 妹記生滾粥品, which was from Hong Kong, was having a 6 months pop up at this cafe from 30 June to 31th December 2017, Tue - Sun : 7.30am - 3pm. Beware of insects and other bugs around while dining. Make sure you not eating one of them. Make sure they are not crawling on you. Felt so tourist brunching here, surrounded by doggies around.Thought a table was empty. Turned out someone tied the dog to the table to chope the table. Asked the next table who couldn't answer. Waited about an hour for the food to arrive, as porridge just ran out when I placed order. Else it would be about 30 minutes.Fish Belly Porridge (S$14.50)Served with a side of dough fritters & century eggOne could taste that the fish belly had gone through stir fried with rice wine before adding to the porridge. There's a distinct soya bean milk aftertaste in the porridge. Homemade Pork Meatballs Porridge (S$12.50)Served with a side of dough fritters & century eggThe meatball porridge was pretty bland, comparing to the fish belly porridge. Drunken Chicken (S$10)The chicken was tender but surprisingly sweet in taste and lacking of the alcoholic taste which associated with the dish. Pig's  Innards (S$9)Not sure why but the dish was served with porridge like grain. The pig's liver was a tab too rare and quite veiny too, making it quite an effort to chew. The intestine had lingering bitter taste.

address: 1 Cluny Rd Botanic Gardens Visitor Centre Singapore 259569 Singapore
comment: The food here is okay there's nothing too special about and a little on the pricey side.  The place is nice since it's in the Singapore botanical garden.

address: 1 Cluny Rd Botanic Gardens Visitor Centre Singapore 259569 Singapore
comment: 3 stars considering the tourist location, the food is decent and prices are a tad more expensive. There's additional caprese sandwich served with chips and kale salad and a house special pizza rolled up like a spring roll. Both are good, pizza was especially filling because of all the cheese. It's a self service restaurant but the staff was very helpful seeing I'm with 2 kids.

address: 1 Cluny Rd Botanic Gardens Visitor Centre Singapore 259569 Singapore
comment: We stopped here for a bite before roaming around the gardens. They had a variety of items - sandwiches, noodles, burger, salads. I had a craving for a cheeseburger, and was not disappointed. There is seating area outside where you can see the chefs cutting the veggies and making the pizza. Once you order, the cashier gives you an electronic disc, which you are to place on the table, it informs the staff where you are seated to bring your meal to you. Note, that i think it said place the disc on the green circle...but on our table there was no green mark. But, you can see a slightly different gloss painted area (or just look under the table to see where the sensor is). Food was good and prompt. Just note that at the end, the birds in the area may stop by for a visit to steal any left overs there may be....

address: 1 Cluny Rd Botanic Gardens Visitor Centre Singapore 259569 Singapore
comment: I'm so surprised this place is always so crowded. Expensive mediocre food with little to no service (self-service, mostly). I gotta say some of the staff are extremely nice and friendly but some don't seem to care at all. I wonder why there's such a huge disparity in service quality. You don't get seated by the staff but instead look for your own table. Some of the staffs were really nice to help me look for extra chairs for my table. Go early on a weekend (if you really want to visit...), it was extremely crowded by 11AM on Sunday!If possible, choose a table outside because it's extremely hot and stuffy inside. Pets are allowed! We saw some fur babies sitting outside with their owners. You order at the counter, take the drinks with you and they serve the food to your table. Food and drinks were overpriced and really meh. We tried a variety of things, from their porridge, to chili crab pasta, spam fries, big breakfast etc. Nothing spectacular. For an iced coffee that costs $6, it came in a plastic takeout cup. For such a high price point, I would've expected hand poured lattes but they came out of the machine.Unless you're already at Botanic Gardens and don't have much food options, this place is not worth a visit.

address: 1 Cluny Rd Botanic Gardens Visitor Centre Singapore 259569 Singapore
comment: Extremely over priced with no service (self service) and underwhelming food even if you ignore the price tag.

address: 1 Cluny Rd Botanic Gardens Visitor Centre Singapore 259569 Singapore
comment: A great place for brunch, followed up by some walking around the Botanic Gardens, I keep asking myself why I haven't been doing this more often. The food here is excellent, no complaints from me, and prices aren't as steep as what most people would assume. Its a very common sight to see expat couples, both caucasian and Japanese, having breakfast here or with their pets, sipping on tea. Casa Verde is nicely sheltered, so seating outside is really okay as well. There are no smoking tables here, and it being the Botanic Gardens, you can't just anyhow smoke. So smokers have to take note.

address: 1 Cluny Rd Botanic Gardens Visitor Centre Singapore 259569 Singapore
comment: I enjoy the breakfast here so much that I was had an accident while parking my car because I was still half-asleep, in my rush to get here!It was definitely worth the repair cost ($350 for hitting the wall) as I got to savour my favourite breakfast item - the cinnamon French toasts with strawberries and maple syrup are absolutely divine. The outdoor sitting is not too humid and is nicely shaded. You'll usually see expats walking their dogs around dining and enjoying the food as well as the brisk morning air. Once you're stuffed, you can always take a leisurely stroll through the Botanic Gardens to shed some weight, something you'll never see me doing!

address: 1 Cluny Rd Botanic Gardens Visitor Centre Singapore 259569 Singapore
comment: Had a nice pizza and salad. All cooked and prepared well.  One reviewer already commented that the pricing seemed a bit high for the dishes, and particularly since you're placing the order directly at the counter ... seating is also casual and non-AC.  Just wish that the service was friendly and knew when to say "thank you".  As a customer, I probably overstate my appreciation to service providers ,,. but when consistently not reciprocated, then no matter how good the food is, it really isn't worth dining there. So four stars for the chef ... and two stars or less for the less than friendly service.

address: 1 Cluny Rd Botanic Gardens Visitor Centre Singapore 259569 Singapore
comment: We come here at night, usually as most of the throngs of people have begun to retreat through the gates and just a few tables dwindle into the evening. It's quiet, usually cool enough out that you almost need a sweater (ok almost) and they thankfully play old jazz standards. The manager and server FIfi are a service team of a calibre we haven't seen anywhere else in Singapore in our two years of eating our way around the red dot. The rest of the staff however are not very useful so if you pick a night when the manager is off duty it will not be the same. The food quality is good. It's casual Italian bistro food with good pizza options, pastas and salads. They do fresh juice juice and they do have a wine list though it could use a little help from someone who knows their wine. The day time scene is very different, they convert the restaurant into a cafeteria style place where you line up and dishes arrive at tables at random. The food quality is pretty decent but it's a bit frenetic and you might be waiting a very long time for everyone at your table to be able to start eating.

address: 1 Cluny Rd Botanic Gardens Visitor Centre Singapore 259569 Singapore
comment: A great place for brunch, followed up by some walking around the Botanic Gardens, I keep asking myself why I haven't been doing this more often. The food here is excellent, no complaints from me, and prices aren't as steep as what most people would assume. Its a very common sight to see expat couples, both caucasian and Japanese, having breakfast here or with their pets, sipping on tea. Casa Verde is nicely sheltered, so seating outside is really okay as well. There are no smoking tables here, and it being the Botanic Gardens, you can't just anyhow smoke. So smokers have to take note.

address: 1 Cluny Rd Botanic Gardens Visitor Centre Singapore 259569 Singapore
comment: I enjoy the breakfast here so much that I was had an accident while parking my car because I was still half-asleep, in my rush to get here!It was definitely worth the repair cost ($350 for hitting the wall) as I got to savour my favourite breakfast item - the cinnamon French toasts with strawberries and maple syrup are absolutely divine. The outdoor sitting is not too humid and is nicely shaded. You'll usually see expats walking their dogs around dining and enjoying the food as well as the brisk morning air. Once you're stuffed, you can always take a leisurely stroll through the Botanic Gardens to shed some weight, something you'll never see me doing!

address: 1 Kim Seng Promenade #01-106 GREAT WORLD Singapore 237994 Singapore
comment: This is the new casual outlet of the Blue Ginger. Shorter menu (unfortunately, they don't have one of my Nonya favs, Nasi Ulam) and less traditional, homey décor. Prices also seem lower, although am not sure. The food is good, but if you really wish to savour the best of Peranakan, there are better places. Like Violet Oon at National Gallery, Candlenut st Dempsey, the Peranakan at Claymore Connect, or even the original Blue Ginger itself.

One of SG's most famous chicken rice restaurant. They have multiple branches across the city - my personal favorites are the classic Balestier and River Valley outlets. Although pricier than your typical hawker fare chicken rice, the chicken rice here are really good / worthy of its name. Chicken meat is juicy, rice has a fragrant smell, sauces a good complement. We also like their fried tofu appetizer and three egg spinach. Definitely a place to bring out-of-town visitors to try the city-state's famous dish

The chicken and rice was good. I also enjoyed the thick crab soup. Everything was very reasonable and the food was served fast. Could've gone without all the constant stares  from the cooks and cashier; it was really uncomfortable.

Quick service during lunch time with comfortable seating and air conditioning!My friend and I ordered the half hainanese chicken with two plates of rice. Returned the appetizers. The entire experience was fuss free. The food was decent. Nothing to rave about, but it wasnt bad either. I'd say it was sufficient to satisfy my chicken rice craving for someone who hasnt been home for a year!

Don't know what the fuss is about, this place is perennially crowded. Went there for lunch and ordered their famous chicken rice. Rice was cold, chicken was barely warm either. Very little sauce as well. Prices are cheap, but you get much better Chicken rice even in Portland!! Many many more options in SP so give this one a miss.

I have always liked BTK for its juicy & fatty white chicken for some years. Today, lunch, was far below the usual standard. BTK quality has deteriorated.Chicken was, on the contrary, dry and tough. I'm disappointed.This meal, equally disappointing was the KuLuRou; it was all batter with just about no pork. Possibly my last. Would have given "0" star for today's food/meal experience.

This restaurant is not an honest establishment. It seems to belong to the same Boon Tong Kee group of restaurants but per Ah Leong (the Manager), it serves "higher class" food made from "premium" ingredients compared to the Ang Mo Kio branch, which is supposed to be the "lower class" version.I ordered some take away via phone and was attended to by Ah Leong. He took my order of Salad Prawns (which price was indicated as SGD15.00 on their online website).When I picked up my order of prawns, the restaurant charged me SGD42.80 (not including GST yet) for 1 order of Salad Prawns. I was flabbergasted as it was thrice the price that was listed online! When I questioned Ah Leong, he claimed that the price indicated online was meant for the Ang Mo Kio branch and that the prawns used at River Valley was far superior than that used in AMK, thus costing thrice the price.He was very aggressive and said that if I could not afford it, I could request for a refund and was extremely vocal about it, attracting attention from other customers. I was embarrassed, paid and left in a huff.I was surprised yet again when I returned home and opened my box of prawns because there were only 5 pieces of prawns, each no more the length of my little finger, coated with layers of flour. That means that each prawn costs about SGD9.00. By the way, the prawns were tasteless and in no way considered "premium".It is unbelievable how such unethical establishments still last in Singapore. Definitely not recommended as you will definitely feel cheated after dining there.
I went there for the chicken rice..taste good!! Good place for family to eat dinner togetherCONCLUSION = RECOMMENDED!!

First time to have this white chicken in Singapore. SGD13 for half a chicken with out the rice. The rice is separate.This place has no napkins. They set out wet towels that is not free. They charge you $2.00 per wet towel. Take note that the appetizers they give you is not complimentary. They charge for that too.Over all the experience was blah.Chicken was just ok.

There are many popular places in Singapore that are famous for their Hainanese chicken and Boon Tong Kee is one of them.Hainanese chicken comes in two version (roasted/boiled) and Boon Tong Kee serves both. We had half roasted and half boiled Hainanese chicken. Both was nice with moist succulent chicken meat, but the roasted had a slight crispy skin. But if I was to choose a favourite then it has to be the boiled version.Although Boon Tong Kee is popular for their Hainanese chicken, I found there are many other dishes that are also nice. One of these dish is the crispy cereal prawns and one I do recommend to order. The prawns were massive and were definitely jumbo prawn. It was messy to eat but it was delicious. I actually thought this was the highlight of my our meal.

Delicious hainanese chicken! First tip, make sure you refuse the peanuts and pickled veggies when you sit down if you don't want them. That way, you won't see a surprise charge on your bill. The napkin is .30, but you might need that at the end of the meal.The chicken here is more expensive than what you would find at a hawker centre, but it's so worth it! Locals recommended this place to me and my bf, and I am so glad they did. The chicken is so soft and silky, each piece just melted in my mouth. Be sure to order a side of the amazing rice!

The rice was good, but I can't recommend anything else. The chicken was just OK, and If I hadn't spent $10 on it, I wouldn't have eaten as much as I did. If you are thinking of going, you should know that they charge for anything they can. The peanuts we didn't order, and thought were complementary, they were on the bill. The Preserved Veggies that we didn't eat, they were on the bill. Guess what else was on the bill? The napkin. The napkin. They charged us 30 cents for the [explicative]ing napkin. (I have a picture, it's listed as towel)We ate food as good or better for $10 total, and they didn't charge us for a napkin.

Visited this place for late lunch on a Wednesday and had the half chicken with chicken rice. It was very delicious! One of the best chicken rice I have eaten during my visit. The chicken was steamed nicely, soft and succulent and the rice was fragrant and tasty.

This place is open late, and who doesn't like a place that is open late, sure they might not have the best chicken rice but they are open to the whee hours of the night.  Fighting jetlag, and you are hungry, this place is open.  It is pricier than most places, but when it is 130am and you want some chicken and rice, this place is open.

This is just another overrated chain that is too commercialized and had lost its flavor. There was no soup. Service staff impatient. Honestly this is just a place to scalp tourists. (If you are reading this before coming to Singapore, you can find better chicken rice in Clementi and Chinatown) 2 bucks for wet towels and a little more for appetizers, which is just Chinese braised nuts.Chicken Rice has almost attained a cult status in local context. Please improve service and food quality I'll promise to go back and try it.

I used to go to the Boon Tong Kee on River Valley Road and get take-out chicken rice late at night because they operate till 4 am and I lived just down River Valley Road when I first moved to Singapore.  In terms of chicken rice, there are cheaper options of the same quality (if not better) such as Five Star (next door) or Tian Tian but I find that their chicken rice is pretty good and the quality is consistent.  I also like the chilli sauce and their take-out packaging is very nice and neat.So last week, when I picked up my family from Changi and we were looking for a lunch place, I decided to go to Boon Tong Kee.  It's close to my apartment, is air conditioned and serves good local dish.  I did think about taking them to Tian Tian but with all the luggage and stuff I don't think it's a good idea to line up in the hawker center.  This was the first time I dined in the shop.  The aunties there are very friendly but they are extremely good at up-selling.  We were not sure about what else to order apart from chicken rice and the auntie suggested cereal prawn which is their specialty and so I said ok.When the cereal prawn arrived they looked humongous (like the size of my hand) and I quickly checked the price on the menu, WOW it's SGD42 (the most expensive cereal prawn I ever had).  To be fair, the prawns are of good quality and the four of us had 2 prawns each so it wasn't that bad and we were ok with the higher price.  The prawn dish ended up being the most expensive item of our meal, more than all our chicken rice and vegetable added together.  We were also really stuffed as we probably over-ordered. So, do be careful when you order and check the prices so you know what you are getting yourself into!  That said, my everyone was very happy about the chicken rice.

What sort of chicken rice place doesn't serve soup with the chicken rice? Why don't they give ginger unless you ask? Is it deliberate that they make you ask for more chili instead of having it on the table so you can help yourself? And their chili isn't even that good. Quite simply put, this branch of Boon Tong Kee seems to be more for the tourists. It's great that the staff speak English because my mother doesn't speak Mandarin and we're quite sick of how people assume that everyone speaks Mandarin. No they don't. That all being said, the breast meat is dry, there isn't that delicious layer of congealed chicken oil beneath the skin, and they don't serve soup. I have no idea why I ever liked coming here for chicken rice, but trust me, from now on, I'm going next door to Five Star.If you do end up here for whatever reason though, order the crispy tofu. That stuff IS THE SHIZZ.

4 stars for the food, but I would say it is really expensive here.$20 for 6 pieces of fried pork? Crazy. Hainanese chicken was tasty and pretty good. Worth it if you want to try it at a place that makes it well.

I feel that Boon Tong Kee has been unfairly slighted by 'foodie hippies' that criticize this place just because it has been commercially successful. Despite opening up branches here & there, and having that super-LOL TV advertisement (not sure if it's really aired or just viewable in their own TV inside their restaurant), I feel that Boon Tong Kee has not sacrificed its quality.I've been frequenting this River Valley branch for a decade now and the quality has always remained consistent. It is, admittedly, not the best chicken rice in Singapore but it's close to my house and opens up till late, which is certainly a huge plus point.Aside from the chicken rice, I love to order the deep fried boneless chicken feet. Served with some sweet Thai chilli sauce, it perfectly complements the rice.A small tip: They don't serve the ginger/garlic mix if you don't ask for it.
If you are a tourist then you should absolutely be aware of this restaurant's trick to get you to buy something you don't want. I got trick into buying a crappy dish for $60. What trash

Choice of eating indoor (air conditioning) or outdoor.  Very good white or brown (roasted) chicken.  Small amount of light sweet soy sauce sprinkled over the chicken dish.  Broader menu variety than average chicken rice eateries in Singapore.

A wandering sage once said, "I'm crazy for chicken rice!"since those wise words were spoken, I've lived my life striving for the ideals represented by that quote. and it is in that spirit that now I must deliver this heavy message: Boon Tong Kee is only ok.since emotions are sure to fly high at this declaration of mediocrity against this populist favorite, let me break this down as objectively and deliberately as possible:chicken (dark meat) - the dark meat was delicious, but then again it's dark meat, which is always delicious. one thing that sets Boon Tong Kee apart is that the meat has been deboned, excepting the leg. that's a huge plus for this lazy ABC.chicken (white meat) - drier than expected, this was a bit of a let down as it looks perfect, but is clearly not as tender as my front runner for chicken rice and baseline for comparisons, Tian Tianchicken (skin) - not gelatinous enough, this was also a disappointment. whereas the skin on tian tian is good enough to eat on it's own and gets even better when eaten with the meat, the skin here definitely adds to the meat flavor and texture but can not stand on its own. chicken rice - very aromatic and flarvorful without being oily, and they even serve it in a pyramid. I was quite happy with the quality of the rice here, but i would have to give a slight edge to Tian Tian, who's rice is slightly more fragrant and has better texture as well.other factors - no chicken innards is a "no good" from me. the place is air conditioned which is a huge plus relative to typical hawker center fare.
Yummy chicken rice, salted egg squid (funky and yummy), fried ribs with zhen jiang sauce (so tender), and Kong Kang (morning glory) so gooooood.

I love the chicken rice here because they prepare the chicken rice well, it's not busy, the servers are friendly and the spicy sauce is great! I really like boon tong kee because of it's ambiance and because the chicken rice is sooo good. I really don't have a complaint about this restaurant and i think boon tong kee is really good!

Perhaps Oscar Wilde is right and the only thing worse than being talked about is not being talked about. In which case, Boon Tong Kee must be pretty damn pleased. I think it's safe to say by now that this chicken rice is nothing if not controversial. There are people out there who swear by it and contend that it is the best in Singapore. There are also people out there who will scream until they're blue in the face that it's terrible and best avoided.Such is the perennial issue of chicken rice in Singapore.I'm going to tread the middle path. I think the chicken rice here is pretty good. It's not the best chicken rice I've had in Singapore, but nor is it the worst. Would I eat here repeatedly? Sure. It's accessible and open late. Service is slightly transactional but works fine. But if you're on a chicken rice tour in Singapore and have the luxury of time allowing you to hit up multiple places - then give BTK a shot. Maybe it isn't the best but the name and the fame would indicate you should at least try it once. Right?

Wanted to eat really good hainanese chicken rice and after our first place was closed for remodeling. Asked the taxi drive for another place and Boon Tong Kee is the place. The hainanese chicken rice was really good and the rice I really liked. They cook the rice in the water to cook the chicken so you get the chicken broth and flavor. The black pepper crab wasn't that good compare to other places. But we came here at least three to four times in our trip to Singapore.

Boon Tong Kee is a perennial. And a perennial near-delight. Their staple chicken rice dish is tasty, the sauces just about right. The poached chicken is typically juicy, though if like me you don't fancy a super strong chicken flavor, the chicken breast is better - ask for only that. BTK's rice is great, full of flavor and with a hint of pandan that makes it quite special. The real gem are the sauces - BTK's trademark red chili sauce and the sweeter brown (Hoisin?) as also the fresh ginger paste make for the magical Singapore chicken rice taste - each on its own, or in any combination with the chicken and the rice! Yes, freely mix n match what is on your plate - for an equally delightful result do what you may!It is the average service, erratic stocking of even chicken, and a mediocre set of alternatives that take away a star from this rating. And 5-star Hainanese next door has slipped in this count too, so you're left with a choice between two quite good but no longer superlative eateries if you want chicken rice. Still, a reliable, enjoyable outlet with atypically long hours for a good plate of chicken rice, night or day.

It is not the best chicken rice I have ever had, but it is convenient when I do want some chicken rice in a more comfortable air-conditioned seating area. The white chicken tastes good, with their potent chilies. What a pity that this restaurant does not serve chicken rice soup, which is complementary in other chicken rice stalls & restaurants. You would have known that their mini fried tofu that comes with wasabi sauce is great like a snack or side dish. Another dish that I like over here is the spinach with 3 different types of eggs. I would say they have a not too bad rendition of this dish that I really like. Apart from the queueing at times and sharing of tables, I wouldn't mind coming here more for my dinner fix. ;)

Definitely the best chicken rice in Singapore -- sometimes referred to as steamed chicken or white chicken.  Tender, juicy and flavorful --- they serve it with the sweet dark soy sauce and chili sauce but I ask for the ginger sauce which gives it another layer of flavor.  For the perfect bite, you should have on your fork the rice, chicken dipped into the three sauces and a small piece of cilantro.  They don't take reservations so try to arrive when they open at 12nn.The other dish which is a must try is the "Raw Fish" --- its their version of ceviche but the fish is not marinated in vinegar only but a mixture of sesame oil, vinegar, soy, and cilantro.  Aromatic and flavorful.Other dishes that are good are the fried bean curd, cereal prawn, green bean in XO sauce (warning this is spicy!), and if you want to be adventurous -- the battered boneless chicken feet.

A friend brought me to Boon Tong Kee here in Singapore and I must say, this was definitely the best Hainanese Chicken Rice I've ever had.I've tried the dish in Toronto, and at various food courts and hawker centers in Singapore - but this restaurant had the smoothest, tastiest steamed chicken I've ever had the pleasure of trying.Between the 4 of us, we ordered a half chicken order, with rice and an additional dish of Fried French Beans and Scallops with Spicy XO Sauce. Each dish, from the chicken, to the flavourful rice to the crisp and delicious beans / scallops, was enjoyable.I've since introduced it to coworkers who have shared their appreciation for Boon Tong Kee. Highly Recommended!

Used to be one of the best chicken rice place but the standaard has lowered during my last 2 trips back to Singapore. No matter what, Chicken Rice is still one of the best food in my list. Boon Tong Kee needs to maintain the high expectation and keep the fragance flows .....
This was very yummy! The chicken is very moist. The crispy bean curd was delightful. And the spicy veggies (not sure what kind of veggie it was) were fantastic! Open very late too so convenient!

Maybe once, a very long time ago, Boon Tong Kee had acceptable chicken rice. But I no longer remember those days.To be fair, the chicken rice itself is okay. The rice is nice but oily. The chicken is okay but really oily. It's just that everything else about the BTK experience is so expensive, and so meh. Other than the chicken rice, everything is meh and not that great. The chicken rice itself is quite expensive comparatively and also okay only lah.So... for a late night post-clubbing chicken rice fix, I much prefer Five Star chicken rice next door, which is cheaper and tastier.

Most chicken rice lovers know of Boon Tong Kee - but, not because it is the best. Standards have dropped quite a fair bit since I first ate here when I was 17. The last time I had it for supper, the chicken was practically swimming in oil and no longer as tender I remembered it to be. The rice was fragrant and well done, I have no fuss about that. Chilli and ginger dips deserve a mention for giving a good kick to the meal.The best thing about the River Valley branch is that it opens till late, like post-clubbing late - fantastic for odd cravings at night.
Expensive but the quality of their food is fantastic. Succulent chicken meat. Fragrant and tasty rice. Please do try the fried tofu!

BTK at RV does a pretty decent steamed chicken but the roast chicken errs on the dry side. The rice is OK but have had better elsewhere. The fried tofu is pretty good but the sweet and sour pork is quite disappointing .. one of our orders came a tad under cooked! The good thing is that they're open till pretty late but you definitely pay a lot extra for that!

I would have given BTK 5 stars in the past. BTK has always been one of our favorites so needless to say we must eat it on this trip. Thing is, they posted the opening time as 11.30 but it wasn't open when we got there. We did a little shopping at Great World City and the place was already pretty filled when we came back. We ordered the chicken rice for two, deep fried tofu, prawn roll and kang kong belacan. I sometimes forget how the food in Asia is right sized. The chicken portion looked pretty small to me. Still tastes just as good, nevertheless. The kangkong belacan is pretty good. Husband pointed out that they don't give soup? We still enjoyed the food but the bill was pretty hefty for the amount of food we got, with the drinks and extra rice etc, we paid like a little over $50. Sorry BTK, love the food but can't afford to eat like this every time. We went to get some at the hawker centre the next time we wanted chicken rice.

This place was heavily recommended by a friend so expectations where high coming in.  The famous Chicken and Rice was good... but the overall experience left a bad after taste.  They charge you for every little thing.BYON (Bring your own napkins).  They charge for the napkins and towellettes they leave on the table for you.Also be aware, the snacks they leave on the table for you are NOT free and you have to tell them you don't want them at the time of sitting down otherwise you will get charged. Food is not that great to tolerate such a bad overall experience.

Great food and a fun place to eat. Nothing special about the decor but as a visitor in Singapore it was nice to eat with mostly locals instead of tourists or high end foodies. The rice pyramid is a nice start. Sauces are tasty and the house special boiled chicken is really interesting.

Been living in this area for nearly five years now. Come here for supper at least two to three times a week. High quality of food is very very consistent. There was never a bad day in this place. I leave this place happy and fully satisfied Everytime and have NEVER been disappointed even once. This restaurant is a well-oiled and superbly managed and executed business. If they are selling stocks, I will definitely buy. Favorite dish is roasted chicken which gets sold out very fast. Must come in afternoon or reserve.

Boon Tong Kee (or more affectionately known as boons) is one of the more famous chicken rice shops in Singapore. Chicken is velvety and the rice is fragrant without being too oily. Drizzle copious amounts of black sauce, wallop a large amount of chili on the side, and you have heaven staring at you on a plate. The best thing about this outlet of Boon Tong Kee is its location. Sitting right on busy River Valley Road, the outlet is the perfect post clubbing spot - especially because it opens till pretty late too. I think I have stumbled into the restaurant at 4 am before, and they were still willing to serve me (I might be wrong though; everything was pretty much a haze). Yummy, comforting food at 4 in the morning - what more can you expect from a restaurant?

rest_name: No. 18 Zion Road Char Kway Teow
address: 70 Zion Rd #01-17, Zion Road Riverside Food Centre Singapore 247792 Singapore
comment: The Char Kway Teow served in this stall was outstanding. The noodles had this really lovely charred texture and tasted pretty sweet. The dish was full of the usual ingredients: cockles, chinese sausage, crispy pork lards, and they all blended really elegantly to form a really bold, flavoursome plate of noodles.Worth the calories!

rest_name: No. 18 Zion Road Char Kway Teow
address: 70 Zion Rd #01-17, Zion Road Riverside Food Centre Singapore 247792 Singapore
comment: Noticed No 18 Fried Kway Teow at chinatown with a lot of published accolades and a line. It appears this is the stall's temporary home while its original location in Zion is undergoing renovation. The $4 non-cockle plate I ordered is of decent portion size and contained a good amount of ingredients (fish cakes, chinese sausage, beansprouts, vegetable) in between the noodles. However, the noodles were quite dry and mouthfeel and overall taste average when compared to others which are typically smoother and more slippery. I guess this is akin to a dry version which may appeal to some who like less-greasy food but i actually prefer the wetter version from Food Street in the same hawker centre (if the husband is frying).

rest_name: No. 18 Zion Road Char Kway Teow
address: 70 Zion Rd #01-17, Zion Road Riverside Food Centre Singapore 247792 Singapore
comment: This is one of the most famous Char Kway Teows in Singapore.  They do have a lot of cockels and other goodies in there, and the portion is huge.  However, the flavor and the "wok hay" isn't always there.  They have a long line, that is backed up, and they're trying to rush out some food.  A local who ordered after me told them to cook it longer for more "char" in their char kway teow.  Maybe if I had done what they had done, I would be more impressed.  Bottom line: if there wasn't a wait, it'd be worth it.  With the wait, it's just above average Char Kway Teow (big portions, lots of goodies) for at least a 45 minute wait.

rest_name: No. 18 Zion Road Char Kway Teow
address: 70 Zion Rd #01-17, Zion Road Riverside Food Centre Singapore 247792 Singapore
comment: I have a confession to make - I'm scared of wooden spoons. How scared?- Like being in a demonic nightmare you can't awake from- Like jumping out of a plane only to realise you forgot to take the parachute- Like being chased by a hungry cheetah and you're wearing thongs(In Oz we call this being sh!t scared! OR wearing the brown underpants!)Why am I scared? It all stems from my youth, when as a horrible child I got up to all sorts of mischief, which resulted in being disciplined (on the knuckles initially), by my mother - using a long wooden spoon. My naughty nature was such that she got so adept at using the thing she could hit me with it from another room, around walls, and over her shoulder without looking.So why bring all this up? Well... back in the day my mother lived in Singapore, and one of the dishes she brought back to Australia was char kway teow. It remains one of her favourite dishes to this day.
