I LIKE this place.Peperoni is comfortable, unpretentious and welcoming.  Its location in the old walkup apartments across Great World City is convenient whilst retaining a more charming and private vibe than the shopping centre eateries.Naturally, Peperoni is best known for their pizzas, which are very good.  Thin crust with the right amount of bite, and generous toppings.  They've got the classic types of pizza covered, as well as some more unusual varieties.  The XXL pizza is always visually impressive and a fun challenge for larger groups.Though I might actually like the pastas better...  Like the pizzas, they're cooked precisely, done al dente.  Sauces are flavourful and portions generous.  Fantastic comfort food.Prices pretty reasonable too (20ish for pasta. sub-30 for meat-based mains) particularly when you consider that it's part of the Les Amis group.Definitely recommended.

I've only lived in SG a year and a half, but to date, this is easily the best pizza I've found on this island. I've tried a number of their pizzas, and they never fail to hit the spot. All they need to do now is open a location closer to me.

A friend of mine recommended this place to me brought me over to try it out. Firstly is the ambience, this place has a nice and homy with a nice touch of italian design which I do enjoy a lot. Secondly which is the most important is the food, I had their carbonara and my main course which was a good but the sauce was too thick for me (might be just me) but it taste great. I love this one dish which I could not remember, it is a large fried mushroom with chicken on top which was excellent and am craving for again up to this point. Highly recommended from couples, family and groups of friends.
very good pizza and calamari.delivered fast. and take credit card on the phone for delivery.will go back

Awesome pizza that's for sure! It's a family friendly place and going there with friends was just the thing. Fresh ingredients, generous too! Had pepperoni one of course and oh the beers to choose from. That's the kicker for me!Loved the German beers, we all had a go at different favourites. The staff was friendly and the place was lively. Awesome place for group outings!
We've been here twice so far and we love the pizza! We really like the thin crust. The Nutella and banana dessert is great too.

As fans of the original restaurant on Greenwood Ave, it seemed only right to visit the newest kid, if only to see if it was going to be any good.Thank goodness it was. My motley crew of uni friends demolished a "family-size" pizza, as per our usual habits, and we are proud to report that they've kept standards high here. Birthday Boy Gus even got a dessert on the house, so happy faces (and bellies) all around.

I really love their pizza as the crust is super thin and crispy with good variety of toppings.I hate pizza with thick crust which made me feel that am eating a lot of flour. Their pizza is also well known for their XXL size Pizzas which is perfect to share with friends. Well, it is also a nice place to chill in with friends which I usually did.The staffs there are very friendly and pay attention to our requests even when the place is crowded.And while waiting for the food, they also placed a cup of crayons for you to doodle on their paper laid table. I will recommend for the salmon pizza which is really good and served in large portion. A must have when I'm having my meal there is the tiramisu. Well. There's only one thing I don't like which is the location as it is not easy to find and not bus-friendly.
I enjoyed the pizza, however I like a more robustly flavored sauce, good service. I would go again.

Pharma ham lacks aroma, so does the Arugula leaves; the mildly spicy sensation in your mouth is nearly non-existent! Feeling very cheated and disappointed. Definitely nowhere close to what I get from Mozza in MBS. Furthermore, the cheese used in thePepperoni pizza tasted like powdered Parmesan cheese melted at high temperature to cover the surface of the pizza. You definitely get what you pay for at this kind of pretending-to-be Italian restaurant in Singapore. Guess the reviews on Yelp should be taken with a pinch of salt sometimes.......
Near one of my past favorite hotels on Robertson Quay, Peperoni Pizzeria has been one of my favorite places to go whenever I'm in Singapore.   I can't wait to go back again in May.
Honestly I feel that the food here pretty much taste the same. I ordered 3 different types of pasta and they taste similar, just salty. Wouldn't come back if you ask me.

I didn't come here for skinny pizza. That's a different restaurant. This place used to have great pizza. What happened guys? You seem to be cutting corners, thinning the pizza base similar to slice of paper, adding little cheese, and burning the pie. On a positive note, this is the catalyst to get me to try new pizza places around the corner. Peperoni, I wish you well in your future endeavors... good luck...

address: Great World City, #02-05A/6 1 Kim Seng Promenade Singapore 239404 Singapore
comment: First time visiting Great World City after its major revamp to find that much has changed! Decided to have dim sum and there were a few to choose from. Imperial Treasure has always been good so we walked in just at the last order for lunch. The manager and waiting staff were attentive without hovering and we had a booth which was pretty private. Food was excellent and the beef cubes were superbly done. I was surprised to find duck tongue on the menu and just had to order it. Well braised and the accompanying tofu was soft and tasty. Even my daughter who tried it for the first time liked it.

address: Great World City, #02-05A/6 1 Kim Seng Promenade Singapore 239404 Singapore
comment: This was my second time at Imperial treasure. As usual it is just as good as the first time. This time I tried new dishes, there was dried oyster congee which was very flavorful. Would definitely order it again if I went back.Best for the roasted pork, it was very good but the portions were very much smaller. I am comparing it to East Ocean's serving.We had a lot of dim sum, I like them all. The staff was friendly and attentive.

address: Great World City, #02-05A/6 1 Kim Seng Promenade Singapore 239404 Singapore
comment: If you are looking for fabulous and consistent dim sum, this is the place to visit.We managed to get a reservation at 10.30 am on Sunday for 4 people. We ordered our favorites: roasted pork, Siew Mai, har Kao, and Chee chong fun. Basically, everything there is nice. But if I need to just choose one dish- it's the roast pork. Sinful yet heavenly.

address: Great World City, #02-05A/6 1 Kim Seng Promenade Singapore 239404 Singapore
comment: This is a dimsum review, not for dinner as I've never eaten dinner here. I came here with a friend on a Sunday morning at 11am, without a booking. They said they could accommodate us, but we had to finish eating by 1145. Sure, whatever right?We sat down, ticked a bunch of things, which may seem a lot for two people, but I'm a big NOM monster, so who cares?This place does the basic items well and while there isn't anything very OUTSTANDING, the quality of everything is general is very good, which is why I give it 4 stars. 1 less star for expecting me to eat everything in 45 minutes. Especially for serving me my last item at 1137am. We ordered radish cake (yum), char siew noodles (good char siew), har gow (okay), siew mai (okay), steamed yam cake (okay), egg tarts (YUM), char siew polo (okay), chicken feet (YUM), salted egg yolk custard bun (YUM, and flows like a river), fried wantons (delish, remember to ask for salad sauce to go with it, the default sauce is something not memorable). Most dimsum places have a few good items, and the rest is soso. I really love this place's consistency in quality across the board. When I say an item is okay, it does not mean that it is passable. It means that I would eat it. Do I eat a lot of things? Not really. The cost was reasonable, about $70 for two people, which is a lot less than eating dimsum at a hotel on a Sunday. Would I come back? Yes.Come here for dimsum, but call before coming, or face a long wait, or a very rushed brunch.

address: Great World City, #02-05A/6 1 Kim Seng Promenade Singapore 239404 Singapore
comment: Was here (late) for a dimsum brunch on a saturday. We ventured bravely into the restaurant, without stopping to ask the lady at reception where our friends were, and promptly got lost in the maze of rooms in this huge complex. The restaurant is mainly made up of private rooms, great if you're dining with a large group of people.Food was great, I had the Century Egg Congee (about $9 and came in a huge bowl), char siew bao, char siew sou (like a pastry), polo bun (HK-style pineapple buns), fried pig's intestines, liushabaos, egg tarts. Didn't try the usual dimsum orders with prawns as I'm allergic to them.Everything I tried was good, certainly one of the better dimsum places I've been too. But special commendation must go to that dish of gold-on-a-plate, FRIED PIG INTESTINES. Ok, it's mainly an acquired taste, only 5 out of 10 in our group actually liked it, but I'm a huge fan and... this was amazing. Crispy and flavourful and the intestines had none of that pungent odour. (Sometimes with the lower-quality ones it becomes exceptionally smelly) Gosh I'm salivating just thinking about it T_T

address: Great World City, #02-05A/6 1 Kim Seng Promenade Singapore 239404 Singapore
comment: This is one of my favorite places for dim sum. I'm certainly not the only one who feels this way about this outlet (or some of their other ones for that matter), going by how difficult it is to get a table from 11.30am-2pm on weekends if you don't reserve in advance. The simple things are done very very well and my picks have more to do with personal preference. For my pork fixes, I love the char siew soh (shared 9 pieces with someone before), char siew noodles and pork belly/siew yoke combination. There is a baked coconut pastry that is all kinds of delicious in the same vein as AG's custard polo bao. I think the siew mai is ok but the giant fried wantons shouldn't be refused (now if only we could have Pontian mee chain's wantons in this size my life would be perfect). The chefs also fry vegetables (you cai) really well . If you're a stickler for cooking, you'll realize the simplest things are the hardest to do and besides the way one of the chefs at Hup Choon does his irresistible broccoli with garlic , Imperial's team is the only other one I like that peels the stems meticulously and blanches/fries the vegetables to a perfect 'al dente'. It's like they make these familiar home style dishes to subtly say "now THIS is what a chef can do with your humble kailan". Finally the soups here are pretty good but I don't order them often for lunch and if you have a craving for XO mee pok, I think Summer Pavilion's version has a slight edge.I think I just wrote myself into a dim sum craving. Darn it!

address: Great World City, #02-05A/6 1 Kim Seng Promenade Singapore 239404 Singapore
comment: Was craving Chinese for the longest time and we decided to try out Imperial at Great World City. We had quite a pleasant evening except for one service person who felt maybe we were an inconvenience to her..but besides that very small issue the food was excellent, the black pepper beef was really good..the tiger groupa with chilli was amazingly good. We also had the roast duck, Kai Lan and Singapore noodles which were all good. Only disappointment was the Beef Hor Fun which was very ordinary. Will definitely return..and maybe that service staff was having a bad day. We all do have those days.

address: Great World City, #02-05A/6 1 Kim Seng Promenade Singapore 239404 Singapore
comment: Extremely lousy service. We ordered various dishes and kindly requested for our rice dish to come first so that our kids could start eating but not only did the manager not attend to our request, he gave us an irritated look and said dishes will just come out together as they are supposed to. Indeed, the rice dish was still amongst the last dish to come out and the kids had to wait till then before they could eat. Horrendous attitude, nothing like the other imperial treasures that we have been to.

address: Great World City, #02-05A/6 1 Kim Seng Promenade Singapore 239404 Singapore
comment: You can always count on Imperial Treasure for good food and great service - auntie waitress power! We had a dinner gathering here, and pulled some strings to get a private room. Peking duck is highly recommended, and when rolled with thin popiah skin, cucumber slivers and sweet sauce... woah. And like all good places, bits of the carcass becomes an addition to fried rice or noodles. Everything adds up, of course so you'd best leave this place for special occasions.

Kuriya is one of my favorite Sushi destinations in Singapore. The place is elegant, the service impeccable, and the fish was recently swimming. Very fresh! My husband said his Uni was probably the best he's ever had. For me, the way the Chawanmushi was prepared and served was an absolutely joy. We ordered several dishes, for fear of missing out, and everything was delicious. Can't wait to go back!

Fantastic fresh fish!  Visiting from my current abode in a land of dubious food preparation, fresh seafood was definitely high on my list when visiting Singapore.Simple high-quality sushi and sashimi.  That's what I wanted, and that's what I got.  Sake, Hamachi, Hotate, Madai, Unagi--all very tasty.  I did play with the rolls a little bit, trying a Dragon Roll in one visit (enormous) and a Foie Gras roll in another (interesting) though the basic fish is the star.The atmosphere is brightly lit, vibrant, and open.  They open early for lunch and fill up by about noon--it seems a popular place.  They did have the sushi conveyer belt and while I sat at one for a few moments, I felt the stuff going by wasn't the best of their offerings, so I just ordered off the menu.

On the pricey side but the atmosphere is pleasant and the food is high quality. The service could have been better. We were a table of four and one person's lunch set arrived 20 minutes before the others. Agree that Kuriya is one of the better sushi restaurants in Singapore.

Suitable for business lunches and corporate events. Reserved a place for business lunch and the service was excellent. Very easy access as you can walk in directly from the drop off point at the Office tower location.

I love Kuriya Dining! It's my default dining destination if I happen to be at Great World CIty and have some time to spare. A meal at Kuriya is to be enjoyed at leisure, to rush through it would do neither you nor the chef justice. We got the edamame (really fresh and plump), selection of sushi (very fresh) and some yakitori items (grilled prawn, scallop and wagyu beef), king crab (sweet but a bit difficult to extract) with plum sauce, uni egg rice in claypot (seasonal item), dobinmushi (really tasty) and chawanmushi (really smooth) Everything was absolutely delicious, though I prefer the king crab at Hide Yamamoto.Service was really good and our server even offered to scrap the burnt parts of the uni egg rice for us if we liked. They also called to remind us of our reservation and the last order time, and were very lovely about it when we apologised for running late. Will definitely return!

Definitely one of the better Japanese restaurants I have had in Singapore, but it comes with a big pricetag. The sashimi is very fresh and their beef based items were really tasty. I particularly enjoyed the wagyu uni donburri and the wagyu curry udon.  I would go back for these most definitely.

This is possibly one of the most consistent Japanese restaurants I have eaten at over the years and all the raw fish is always fresh and delicious. The service here is also impeccable and much better than many other Japanese places I've been to. Only thing is that it's not cheap, but it's worth the premium.

Very very fresh sashimi and delicious bento as well! I would say this is my daily to go jap restaurant, if not for its sky high prices! However, it is still worth going for special occasion to indulge in some splurging and pampering on your belly.

Easily one of the best Japanese restaurants in Singapore. Although a little on the pricey side, Kuriya knows how to serve up authentic and seasonal Japanese cuisine. Sashimi here is cut to perfection both in length and width ensuring adequate taste and portion. Wasabi here is grated fresh from the root and if you're lucky enough you just might get the end of the root to grate on your own when you request for more wasabi. A long time favorite on the menu and a personal favorite of mine would be the Miso Wagyu Beef which is served over a mini wooden Japanese stove. The beef grills atop a special kind of leaf which further enhances the flavor and visual experience. If you are lucky enough, do try the Matcha or green tea creme brulee  which is out of this world tasty! It is a rare treat indeed, sometimes only with seasonal menus but it doesn't hurt to check with your server!

For the price, I would say that it's not one of the very best Japanese places around, but the experience here was very good and the food itself was quite satisfying. The feature here I think is the beef, which we had in a variety of settings, from donburi to grilled to shabu shabu style. The quality of the Wagyu was just amazing, which was extremely tender and had the right beef flavor. The raw fish items were fresh and pretty good quality, but I've had better and paid a lot less. The service was top notch however, and the server was extremely friendly and had a nice conversation with us.

Authentic food, good service, unreasonably priced!  And the price is my only reason for the three starts.  $200 per person for a tasting lunch menu, with just green tea.  That cuts into celebrity Japanese chef (like Nobu or Morimoto) price range!

My favourite fine dining restaurant for Japanese food. Everything is top notch here from the food, ambiance right down to service. I particularly like the sashimis here as it is super fresh. Pricey but worth it!

Having spied someone having these ridiculously minute coin pratas, we too decided to have a go. It was truly a leap of faith since I haven't had a single good prata here for years. Perhaps the size made the crust easily crunchy and the insides soft and fluffy. The chicken curry was flavourful and tender.Teh tariks here are always milky & sweet, just the way i like them2xTeh Tarik + plate of coin pratas = $9.20, overpriced imo but they're the best :D
Love this little gem on River Valley! They have many different types of Roti to satisfy a savory or sweet craving.

Absolute farce. Service so bad it's almost comic. Staff stood in front of restaurant and approached me saying Sir, very good Indian food.  Come come. And that's the last I see of him. Come in as single. 25% dine in crowd but overrun with dispatch riders picking up to go orders.  Sat down at 8:40 pm Get menu. Order lassi, naan and vindaloo.  8:55 lassi arrives.  Watch maybe 20 to go orders getting picked up.  The 10 or so  diners in the place all had their food when I arrived.  Staff are all huddled in the back talking, not serving anyone except handing bags of to go orders.  9:10 no food. A few diners leave so the MIA staff comes up front to cash register.  I ask where my food is and he says "on the way sir".  9:20 a couple comes inn, sits down and orders.  9:25 couple gets served food.  That's it.  40 minutes for naan and vindaloo?  Get up to leave, cancel order and pay for lassi.  Prompts staff to come up and say just 2 more minutes sir.  Tell him I would not enjoy my meal there and leave late and hungry.Maybe the food is good there but the staff are clueless. They clearly put to go orders first.  If I had called food it would have been served faster.  Singapore has great Indian restaurants that provide quality food and service and pay attention to their diners.  This one rates near the bottom....I notice that other reviewers have commented on the Long wait for food.  Others rave about the quality.  Since my patience ran out at 40 minutes I admittedly cannot attest to the quality.  But taking so Long to serve with servers huddling in the back, chatting and handing to go orders and then someone who arrived 30 minutes after I arrived get  served really ruined my appetite.

Decent fluffy prata served w good fish gravy. To be fair, I almost always buy to take it back home so it's lost some crispiness by then. It's served with a really yummy tasty, just right amount of tanginess fish gravy.Tried their prata bomb once but nothing special. Much prefer the one at Fadhiya.They also have a pretty nice selection of rice and dishes, I ordered the mutton on the bone before and that was really tender and softly gnawy. Soup kambing here is not bad but I ordered it with mutton bones coz their usual is with cubes.The teh tarik is super sweet so definitely ask for less sugar. Even my friend with a sweet tooth finds it too sweet.Sometimes they have putu mayam, it's just bought from somewhere but what a great dessert after the spicy savoury dishes.Staff are all nice and cheery and the prata man always has a chat or laugh with me. I usually call ahead and they prepare it for me to do a quick pickup since parking is difficult. Outside is the dreaded jagged yellow line so you gotta be quick!24 hours opening yay but the rice dishes get cooked around 10 or 11 as a few times I came around 11am and the veg was not ready. In this area, I definitely rate this about Spize which super greasy.

Great place. Have been coming here for years. Like the staff and service, the food is consistently good though over 3 years there have been a bit of ups and down but nothing significant. One point to note: They charge for water, it's 30 cents a glassBrought plenty of friends and family from other countries here to try experience Singapore's local fare. Everyone had very positive reviews. I myself absolutely love this place since it's open 24 hours, 364 days a year. Good food, awesome convenience, friendly staff.
Love that chicken! We ate here our first night in town. Second night, after lots of drinking, I got a bunch of chicken to graze on for the next day.

address: 1 Kim Seng Promenade #01-107/108 Great World Singapore 237994 Singapore
comment: All these years I skipped this restaurant because I enjoy going Anzu, their neighbor. On 24th Feb 2022, I tried their Salmon set and Pork Belly Set; Salmon was alright. The looks of the food are plain, but that pork belly is delicious! Love their homemade tofu beancurd and that brown thingy. Last weekend, had dinner and tried others. (Too famished that I skipped pictures)1) Taco spring roll - made me miss Mexican food now2) Humberg steak - yummy!3) Stir fried noodle (Worcester sauce) - hard texture and taste is okay4) Pork Belly - of course you must had it5) Brown sugar pancake - interesting to have it here.Love the food and ambience but not attentive service. Table is somewhat sticky.

address: 1 Kim Seng Promenade #01-107/108 Great World Singapore 237994 Singapore
comment: Okinawan Diner Nirai-Kanai has recently relocated to Great World City from Liang Court. One of the rare places serving fully authentic Okinawan cuisine in Singapore!Okinawan cuisine are said to be good for health and beauty and NIRAI-KANAI means the god's world in the distance of the sea.Soup Noodle with Simmered Pork Belly (S$7.60++/small)..It is also known as Okinawa Soki Soba. Although it is called "soba", it is not made from buckwheat but eggs, like your usual ramen noodle. It reminded one of the Chinese style rickshaw noodles.Simmered Pork Belly (S$9.80++/ 2 pieces)It is known as Rafute (Okinawan Braised Pork Belly). Classic Okinawan Braised Pork Belly, slow-cooked in three Okinawan favourite seasoning - Awamori (Okinawa distilled liquor), Okinawan brown sugar, and soy sauce! The braised pork looked very fatty but it was very tender with the fat melt in the mouth.Green Caviar-Seaweed with Ponzu Sauce (S$14++)The seaweed is actually Umibudo, better known as Sea Grapes. Love  the feel of the popping texture, bringing the taste of the sea to your mouth.Ended the meal with Okinawan Brown Sugar Pancake with Whipped Cream (S$9.80++) which was also known as Chinbin. Chinbin is a Okinawan traditional sweets which is given for kids on May 4th or 5th of the Lunar Calendar. Slightly chewy in texture. Serves with cream to bring out the fragrance of Okinawa brown sugar! Dip the rolled up crepe in the light whipped sweet cream for extra kick.Accompanied with Sanpin-cha (Jasmine Tea) (S$4++)Fresh flower scent tea, a good match with Okinawan cuisines, and is recommended for hot summer days.Not only does it aids in digestion, the scent of flowers gives relaxation effects, and is very good for fatigue recovery.

address: 1 Kim Seng Promenade #01-66/77 Great World City Singapore 237994 Singapore
comment: Wow, how can I describe my experience? I am a total steak lover, quite possibly because I'm an Ang Moh and meat is large part of our diet. Finding a good steak in Singapore is not generally easy, and when I have found a new steakhouse here, they're either poor quality or so expensive that I can scarcely afford to pay for the bill! Here's my verdict: Pepper is surely the best steakhouse I have eaten at in Singapore.  Let me say that again: this is the best steakhouse I've eaten at in Singapore! First, the menu has a ton of choices to pick from (perhaps too many), and so I was pleasantly surprised to be so spoilt for choice. After about 10 min of deliberation with my guest, I made a decision to go with the New Zealand grass fed Black Angus beef. I then chose the ribeye cut for just over $60. I'm exceptionally health conscious, but I also enjoy red meat, so it is vital for me to order something that is lean, grass fed, with no artificial things added...so no problem there.The food came out quickly...within fifteen min, which is just right, and as we were taking pleasure in our meals, the manager came over to check on the food, as did the waiter. We were both all smiles. The steak was absolutely delicious, and I enjoyed the french fries too...though I could have taken advantage of a free-flow of steak fries, I was too full to finish my first order...in fact, the meal was so filling that I didn't eat dinner that night! I also didn't get a chance to try their beer this time (it was lunch time and I was working), but I hear positive things about their microbrewery, so that is on my short-list as well. My partner had a seafood pasta with loads of prawns and a pleasant alfredo sauce (I tried a bite, just to be sure!). I'm not sure what restaurant the other reviewer was at, because this was definitely in the top 3 joints I've visited since relocating here Two years ago...and I eat out a LOT! :-)  I've travelled and eaten around the world...so I'd like to think I know what I'm talking about here.  Do yourself a favour, and give Pepper a try.

address: 1 Kim Seng Promenade #01-66/77 Great World City Singapore 237994 Singapore
comment: The food is good, but the service is painfully slow. Don't blame the staff though, this is a management issue. The two waitstaff were literally running from table to table to try to keep up. But they were overwhelmed as was the kitchen. Such a long wait. The management of this restaurant needs to decide if they want repeat customers or really don't care if people come back. I imagine the staff will turn over too, as they a stuck dealing with the fallout.

address: 1 Kim Seng Promenade #01-66/77 Great World City Singapore 237994 Singapore
comment: I've heard middling reviews of Pepper Steakhouse & Bistro, and it's not hard to see why.My own visit was a mix of inconsistencies, with highs, lows, and very lows. Having made reservations via Chope, when we arrived we were seated at the non-booth tables at the end of the restaurant. Nothing wrong with that... except that my family all run a little on the short side, with the tallest of us being still under 1.65m. The seats at Pepper Steakhouse, for some odd reason, are rather low relative to the tables, meaning that when we sat down, the table was at chest height. That's not very comfortable when dining. We asked to change to a booth seat, which from our estimation, looked more comfortable in terms of height (ironic, I know). The manager/supervisor told us he didn't have any available tables at that moment, but he'd change us once a table became available, definitely before our mains. Satisfied with that compromise, we ordered. For starters we have the beef tongue (decent, a bit greasy as it's braised, then fried) and the beef carpaccio (also decent, unspectacular). Those came and went... and then eventually our mains arrived. No word of a table change, no sign of anything. Mildly put off, we continued eating.We had three steaks in total, and the New Zealand 'Wakanui' 500g Chateaubriand was excellent. At $78 ++, it was excellent value, and actually one of the best steaks I've had in a long time. Both my dining companions didn't feel their steaks were anything to rave about (one had the 'Savannah' entrecote, and the other the 'Harvey' ribeye), but they did feel tat my steak was much better than theirs. Perhaps the Wakanui is just a better grade of beef. Regardless, this steak was cooked as requested, I asked for it rare and it came beautifully red all the way through, succulent and in no way dry. The outside was seared well, and salted to bring out the flavour of the meat. My brother felt it was a touch too salty, but both my mother and I felt that it was within the 'delicious' range of saltiness.Signature steaks also come with free flow fries, however the thick cut fries were nothing to write home about. Lukewarm, a little bit soggy, they tasted tired and we didn't even finish the portions served, let alone ask for more. We had all asked for Bernaise sauce with our steaks (the sauce is complimentary, which is refreshing since many places charge nowadays), and the Bernaise was competently executed. The flavours were balanced, it wasn't too tart, and went well with the steak. I just felt it important to mention that because I've had some incredibly sour Bernaise sauces in Singapore where the chefs have clearly been a bit too enthused with the tarragon vinegar.One final point of note is that Pepper Steakhouse and Bistro is run by the Pumproom group, meaning that you have access to all of the Pumproom's microbrewery ales and beers. Steak and beer. You can't go wrong.So we never did get that table change that was promised, not all our steaks were that memorable, the fries were unimpressive to say the least, and one of our party who had been seated next to their wine cooler was interrupted throughout his meal every time then needed to pull a bottle of wine out of the chiller. But if you're hankering for an affordable steak and happen to be in the area, the Pepper Steakhouse is worth considering. I'd go back. Maybe.

address: 1 Kim Seng Promenade #01-66/77 Great World City Singapore 237994 Singapore
comment: I like this place , really pump room, but we order from here quiet frequently, mainly the lite menu or bar snacks.  Not bad and very convenient.  And great staff or at least the ones that take care of my group of friends

Very good Indian food. They have a variety of dishes and a great vegetarian selection. Upon request, they made my food very spicy. Which made me very happy. Friendly staff, and reasonable prices. Highly recommend.

Had vada Pav and samosa at Kurry Korner Suntec. The Vada pav had giant chunks of potatoes, poor preparation of the filling. Microwaved to reheat so the coating was not crispy. The pav was a sweet plain burger bun. The chutney was not balanced and just garlic all the way. Any Indian street side vendor can make better vada pav For 4$ you are better off having popiah from Qiji or vada Sambar at Saravana Bhavan The samosa was also similar.

Year after year I enjoy coming here all December.  Curries are flavorful and  rich.  Leaves that nice after taste n mild tang.   Roti is always consistent and crisp.  Even better with egg.  Friendly staff.

Need a detox from all that hawker center food?Little Farms has got you covered. Ingredients are wholesome, nutritious and as much as possible, organic. Brunch is served until 3pm, but lunch goes on until 5pm. I love the colorful salads (from S$18 and up) here on display right in front of you, just pick and choose. You'd have to pick a seat, grab the number at your table and then place your order at the counter. I got the vegetable stack (S$24) which had beautifully roasted squash, tomatoes, eggplant, cauliflower, zucchini, olives and topped with a simple EVOO and balsamic glaze plus sprinkling of sea salt. You can really taste the freshness and high quality ingredients they use here. Cookies are not their strong point as the sea salt chocolate cookie I had was dry and hard :( I'm not sure if there's a scarcity of brunch places in the River Valley area, but Little Farms was PACKED even on an off hour of 2pm on a weekday. Also seems to be a favorite among expats and their kids. All I gotta say is, I'm going to be back since HOM Yoga is right next door.

Great quality (organic) food, clean interior decor, LOTS of tables, and busy at all times - what's not to like?The prices. C'mon. Charging S$9 for a tiny glass of milk shake or S$25 for a small breakfast plate is outright ridiculous and robbery.Apparently I'm the only one thinking so as this place is, as I mentioned, packed at all times.Great food, don't get me wrong, but ridic prices.

address: 1 Kim Seng Promenade #01-22 Great World City Singapore Singapore
comment: The good thing about Ramen Champion is that there is ramen galore to choose from, the bad thing about it is that there is too many choices. I know, I have first world problems.As I have no idea who to order my ramen from, I tried to order one from each stall to taste and see. It helped that I have my family along to con them into eating ramen from the different stalls.King Ramen from Butaou - hubby ate this and he liked it enough. The rich soup is tasty and full bodied. I tried it and it was nice...just not sure if it's my best tasting.Spicy Ramen from Tonkotsu Itto - I like spicy anything so this ramen already win a few more point by being spicy. The soup is rich and tasty too. Ramen from Tonkotsu Itto - daughter ate this and she really liked it. I tasted and can understand why. Same rich and tasty soup goodness here.Garlicky Spicy Ramen from Miyamoto - after tasting all the ramens ordered, I decided I liked this the most as I like garlic, and spice and the generous dose of bean sprouts they throw inside with the ramen. I realised that I needed the bean sprouts to compliment the taste of the ramen, so that it won't be too ger-lat too soon.Nice place to grab a pre-movie meal, easy and fuss-free and tasty. You probably need to come with a group and order 1 ramen from each stall to eat at the same time to figure out what is your favourite ramen!! Good luck!

address: 1 Kim Seng Promenade #01-22 Great World City Singapore Singapore
comment: Well, Wednesday after work dinner with my friend and decided that it will be good to check out their new ultra spicy Magma Ramen that's only exclusive to this branch. Was the drive over worth it? Neh. Broth- its super thick gravy like and just layered with chili oil. I love the spicyness but that's about it. There's no flavor profile to it. Just none. Noodles- thick fat noodles that tasted like cheap noodles from the supermarket. Whatever happened to handmade ramen? Eggs- the yolk seems overdone Would i come back? For their grilled cheese ramen maybe!

address: 1 Kim Seng Promenade #01-22 Great World City Singapore Singapore
comment: This is my second time to Ramen Champion but first time to this outlet which is new at Great World City. Previously I went to the Bugis outlet which seemed to have more stalls.Based on my non-scientific survey, I saw 4 stalls and 1 drink stall.Itto - We ordered the tonkotsu special. The difference between this and the classic seems to be 4 slices of thin char siu instead of 1 and an egg instead of none. The price was around $16.50 instead of $11.50. They served in black bowls. It had the thin kind of noodles which I believe is Hakata style (?). I enjoyed the noodles and it reminded me a bit of Ippudo. The soup was richer and saltier than Ippudo..which is fine with me coz I like my ramen soup salty. My favourite shop is Miharu which some complain is too salty (obviously they are not regulars and do not know that to drink it you can ask for a pot of broth to lighten it and make it go further ;). The char siu was very tender. The egg did not look like the seasoning had permeated at all but the texture and doneness was good. Probably not worth the special price unless you have a particular craving.Sukiyaki Ramen - They serve in red bowls. This had quite a special taste to it, being a cross between sukiyaki broth (thicker than it) and ramen. Again we had the special and it had char siu as well as sukiyaki beef slices. The beef slices were quite fatty and were very tender. The char siu was also quite good but I think I slightly prefer Itto's as they were a bit more meat than fat. We really liked the flavour of this soup and ended up using noodles from the white bowl stall (see below) to dip in it.There was a white bowl ramen stall (I forget the name) but I think true ramen lovers should skip this one as it was very light tasting and nothing special. In fact it had a strong taste of beansprouts from the copious amount of beansprouts. The noodles were flat and wider like mee pok. It was a bit doughy for my taste.Bishamon Zero - We ordered a cold tofu and gyoza from here. The gyoza was ok. The cold tofu was topped with fried onions and sitting in what I thought was sauce but turned out to be a sea of chilli oil..it was just too much as I was hoping for something fresher and cold tasting as a foil to all the rich soups.It's nice that some stalls had some side dishes so that it's not ALL ramen but some of the dishes were sold out.Make sure you get the loyalty card chopped for each bowl of ramen. Some of the stalls don't tell you or give it to you.

address: 1 Kim Seng Promenade #01-22 Great World City Singapore Singapore
comment: i wish i had more hands so i could give it 4 thumbs down.i normally like to review ramen-yas by breaking down into the components of broth, noodle, and toppings, rounded out with a holistic summary. staying true to that format, here goes:i ordered the special tonkotsu ramen from Tonkotsu Ikkyu, as tonkotsu broth is my favorite, and the description of the ramen seemed the most authentic.broth - i feel like singaporeans like a lighter broth. despite Tonkotsu Ikkyu sounding like an authentic creamy tonkotsu (as opposued to Buta God who described their tonkotsu as lighter), it tasted very watery and was not creamy in the slightest.toppings - i was most excited to try Tonkotsu Ikkyu's advertised sous-vide chashu. but calling this chashu sous-vide is like calling a steak medium rare after you've burned it to a dry, tough crisp, then putting it in a dehydrator, then burying the resulting black carbon mess in the ground for 10 billion years until it becomes a diamond.noodles - the men were the correct thin straight ones you typically find in tonkotsu ramen.holistic summary - ramen in singapore is terrible. to end on a positive note, the asahi i ordered along with the ramen made me feel better about wasting $30 and stomach space on this meal.

address: 4 Jln Bukit Ho Swee #01-164 Singapore 162004 Singapore
comment: We chanced upon a banner upon our recent trips to Tiong Bahru Plaza the week before, advertising this noodle bar. It is just a 10 min walk from Tiong Bahru Plaza along Jalan Bukit Ho Swee, but in the scorching sun, it can seem longer!Verdict:- Beef Brisket Noodles (Clear Broth) (2 combo meaning more slices of beef) : Love, love, love the beef! It was tender and had negligible fats on it. The noodle portion was just nice for me and was done al dente. But it might be small for big-eaters. The clear broth was soothing for me but it will taste much better with the braised broth; kinda like the Chinese Braised Beef La Mian.- Lu Rou La Mian (Braised Broth) - The broth was fantastic and the meat very tender.- Spicy Chilli Wantons - This was a side dish to share and they've manage to achieve the perfect balance of spiciness and sourness.- Fried Chicken cubes with Sweet Sauce - The owners were trying out a new menu creation and gave us a sample plate to try. Love the crispy outer layer combined with the chewy inner chicken meat. Considering the hot weather now, we would go back again another time when the weather is cooler, comes highly recommended!

address: 1 Kim Seng Promenade Great World City #B1-07 Singapore 237994 Singapore
comment: The food tastes really nice! And the set menus look very appealing, though they all seemed to have at least one item that I'm not a fan of. Had two dinners here, one with a party of three and one by myself. This review covers both. When we arrived as a party of three there was a short queue. After a little wait we were moved to the intermediate waiting area where they have magazines and menus to explore. Good way to make a longer waiting time seem shorter. Service was very quick and precise. Orders are noted on a piece of paper (or pieces of paper in case of separate checks), checked if the order is correct and later on checked if all the ordered items have been delivered. I normally judge a sushi place by the crispiness of the nori, but the only item I had with nori (really) were hand rolls and those are somehow usually always crispy even though other nori items may not. Only one of us had a set menu. It looked really nice, but I can't judge about the taste. I really liked the texture of the salmon and the fact that the tamago wasn't too sweet. The ebi tempura was also very nice. The shrimp meat perfectly cooked. When I revisited this restaurant by myself. I choose to be seated at the bar as that would obviously go faster. The advantage of sitting at the bar is that the food goes straight from the chef's hand to you and you can watch the chefs prepare all the food. Disadvantage is that the conveyer belt keeps moving tempting dishes by at about exactly the right height and distance to grab some more (-;I have had a look at the 'fish market' where they sell all sorts of ready made sushi and fish to be prepared at home. The ready made sushi looked so much better that those of the supermarket on the same floor. Price indication (1 person):1 tamago (2 pcs)1 maguro (2 pcs)2 salmon nigiri (4 pcs)1 salmon hand roll7 pcs salmon sashimi1 diet coke SGD $31,50

address: 1 Kim Seng Promenade Great World City #B1-07 Singapore 237994 Singapore
comment: Sigh. I think I set my expectation too high because my Japanese friend recommended this place. I got the Kurobuta Goma Shabu Udon, and while the pork was good, the whole thing was just... too sesame-y. You know how they sometimes serve you sesame dipping sauce at a Chinese hotpot place? It's almost exactly like that, except in this case the udon was drenched in very thick and creamy sesame dressing. It was nice at first but too much after the 4th bite. The place was spacious and comfortable, though. My friends and I ended up staying for almost 3 hours just hanging out. They also have a pretty extensive menu, will probably give it a second chance and try their sushi/bento box.

address: 1 Kim Seng Promenade Great World City #B1-07 Singapore 237994 Singapore
comment: Prolly the worst service I've ever experienced. Waving these people down for order is met with eye contact and then flat out ignored. Left after 10 mins, such an arrogant bunch. Came here twice and both times were the same.

address: 1 Kim Seng Promenade Great World City #B1-07 Singapore 237994 Singapore
comment: Simply love this restaurant and the sushi options and its sake, if I could I go everyday to take away or eat in. It's a shame that it is inside of a shopping mall and the fidelity card is also very confusing system, I did not get my free aka and cashier took my card after first prize but there were three more to go.The combo was really good and enough of food for two.

address: 1 Kim Seng Promenade Great World City #B1-07 Singapore 237994 Singapore
comment: Ichiban Boshi used to serve up very decent Japanese fare. Not any more. I've patronised Ichiban from day one, when they were first located at Novena, and originally positioned as a mid priced offshoot of Kuriya. I dare say the quality (and quantity) of food and service has gone down the drain. Sashimi is barely fresh. Portions have gotten smaller. And quality of ingredients has become mediocre. Barely value for money as it were. Service is harried at best, occasionally surly. And the kitchen misses orders with a regularity that is - frankly - quite embarrassing. This place is a shadow of its former glory. Its mediocre Japanese cuisine at best, and a bright shining example of all that's wrong with over-expansion and mass market mentality. Only eat here if you've no choice. Still better than other mediocre chain outlets like Sakae Sushi or Sushi Tei. But only by a bit.

address: 1 Kim Seng Promenade Great World City #B1-07 Singapore 237994 Singapore
comment: I've had countless meals here and only reviewing now. My fav includes:1) Ichiban Jyu - this is my hubby's fav as he digs the fresh salmon slices and the spicy chilli padi 2) Salad with Jap Sauce - I forgot the menu name of this salad dish but I simple love love love the thick salmon and tuna slices and that Japanese sauce that I cannot find outside!! I have always enjoyed my dining experiences here.

address: 1 Kim Seng Promenade Great World City #B1-07 Singapore 237994 Singapore
comment: This is a pretty average sushi place, but my colleagues and I come here for lunch anyway because it's a short bus ride from the office and the prices are fair, considering the quality of the food and the atmosphere.The weekday lunch queue can look a bit intimidating, but exercise a little patience and you'll be seated within 20 minutes. I'm also surprised at how efficient the service is, as we usually go in a group of 6 and everyone usually gets their food around the same time.Their bento sets are pretty good; my only complaint is that the amount of food you get can be a bit too much for someone who's not very hungry. My favorite is their aburi sushi; it comes with around 7 pieces and you get a clear soup with it.If you're not one to wait for a mass-market sushi meal, check out their Kuriya takeaway area. (Note: I'm not sure if this is something that I should separately review, as Kuriya and Ichiban share the same space and cash register, but have different names.) They have an amazing variety of rolls, bowls, nigiri, aburi... basically, a lot of what you can order off the menu at Ichiban, and a lot better than what I see at Fairprice and Cold Storage. I've bought a few things from them before and really enjoyed them!Overall, nothing to go out of your way for, but a decent choice if you're in Great World City.

address: 1 Kim Seng Promenade Great World City #B1-07 Singapore 237994 Singapore
comment: Came here for lunch with a few friends - no wait at 12.30pm. They have many set meals as options - curry, soba, udon, tempura, rice bowls etc and some hot dishes and of course ala carte sushi. No special lunch deals so pretty pricey for what you get. I didn't try the sushi so not sure that's good/value for money.. But the set menus are overpriced imo (average $20 and you don't get too full; maybe we just eat like pigs?!). Won't be back given so many other Japanese places to check out and with lunch specials.

address: 1 Kim Seng Promenade Great World City #B1-07 Singapore 237994 Singapore
comment: The Great World City has a rather nice setting and fair conveyor belt sushi with decent service. No one thing is extraordinary - but decent + decent + decent has to be much more thank decent, right? So in summary has a few things consistently right. The set menus look appealing though impatience takes hold and I have yet to try them. The agedashi tofu, most handrolls and Hokkaido cheesecake are worth a try.

This review is for a visit in 2014, so the accuracy may be in question.We popped by here for dinner in late 2014, and this place has an exterior that is completely opaque, and we had to roll open the doors and ask if they were open for dinner. There are heaps of Japanese salarymen having dinner here, even on a weeknight (probably a Thursday?). It was either this or a walk to Great World City, so this was it.We sat down and got a bottle of sake (decent sake list here), and many many many skewers to share. Prices are slightly pricey, I think the bill was about $200 for two. I would revisit, but it's a little out of the way.
Not as good as it used to be (see my previous review). The food is quite over-flavored on my last visit.And the tsukune are definitely much smaller now.

If you have no reservation, make sure you speak Japanese. They don't want to serve you even there are tables open!!! Oh... more they spent time on cleaning the table but not for non-Japanese speaker..,, but they will make you wait for 10 minutes without taking to you before kicking you out!

We have been to Ichigo a few times, last time the service, the quality of the food, and the prices were remarkably disappointing. The service was officious, cordial and borderline rude (for Japanese standards, you would have to live there to know). The staff seem more concerned about their rigid reservation system and getting customers in and out quickly than the dining experience, and this took away from the positive vibe the dinner should have been. Also some staff can't speak English or Japanese!Note that we have lived in Japan for many years. Be wary of the Chicken Saute on the osusume menu - it is actually fried chicken, not sauteed, and is mostly koromo, skin and gristle, very little meat.  The Horenso Salad has over-garlicky salad dressing, it smothered the salad - it is overpriced and they don't mention that there is pork in it (though this is standard in Japan). The tskune is really good but ridiculously small for the prices. There was another item we ordered but it didn't taste right, and had to send it back.Great Japanese does not have to cost this much.  There are better alternatives, leave this one for those Japanese who rotely treat this as their enclave.

I live at the river valley condo. I want to eat Japanese food. So, i find shops near my home. I started order foods. And, it have been a long time. The food never come there. So, I ask shop owners "Where is my food?" The Japanese lady answered badly. I think they don't understand English well. Prices are really higher than others shop.  NEVER EAT THIS SHOP!! YOU WILL REGRET IT!!

you'll be lucky to get a reservation at this exclusive japanese joint. run by a japanese couple, they serve up some of the most amazing, authentic and artful japanese food that i've had in singapore.I recommend the tsukune variety platter ($14 for 5 sticks), which is their in house specialty. They do cooked/grilled dishes (mostly chicken based), so no sashimi or sushi here. Their sake menu is extensive and reasonably priced, as evidenced by the many japanese regulars enjoying a bottle of sake. Tip: get a big bottle, and finish it up over several visits! they'll keep your sake for a month.

TL;DR: clear cooking skills, fantastic location, but questionable wine.We walked past this restaurant for years. I love the location, but thought it would cultivate a tourist trap. Turns out the chef knows what he is doing. This is one of maybe a handful of times in years that lobster was soft under the fork, perfectly cooked instead of the usual rubbery texture I've come to expect from Singaporean chefs. The snapper was, again, spot on. They made the most of the medium steak with even texture showing perfect control. The chef also knows how to balance salt and seasonings, again something less common here and it took me straight back to the Mediterranean of my youth. Pasta was al dente with a well seasoned and balanced bolognese ragu which I managed to get through despite being full before starting it. Every other table was having pizza so I guess that's what we're trying next.I would have 5 starred it but the Primitivo had very clear volatile acidity (when bacteria trapped in the wine produces acetic acid, leaving a stench of vinegar). This is not an unknown problem with Italian wines and it was still early enough that I could drink it by holding my nose (Primitivo has enough fruit to offset the acidity). But at $12 a glass, in a restaurant where the staff clearly has a trained palate, this is a real shame. It means I won't risk wine at further visits and they will lose the profit I was happy to give them. A bottle of decent Primitivo from 2016 is probably $20-30 to import, hardly a huge hit on the bottom line. I'm sad because it is hard to find a place that cooks meat and especially fish so well, and I was looking forward to pairing it in the future. Tables are relatively close together and the popularity of the restaurant (despite its rating here) meant that it got pretty loud. By 9pm we could not hear each other across the table. I measured an average of 55dB with my phone with peaks at 65dB, about the same as someone drilling through the other side of a wall. Outdoors was better for that reason, despite the excellent presentation of the white tablecloths and fountain behind the dining room.

We booked for dinner on Sunday night. Food came with the same wonderful flavors & quantities that we loved from our first visit a few months ago. Pizza, Ravioli & Calzone were wonderful and we couldn't have enough of their desserts ! Pro-tip : Make sure you try their Burrata & definitely save some appetite for their desserts. There was though a snag that made this a 4* instead of 5*. I suspect they were overbooked given this was the last day before dining restrictions kicked in. After a wait, we were accommodated into the private room where we were the only ones - much like being back at home on our dining table. Fortunately, a table became available in the main restaurant, though 30 mins from the point we had arrived. The staff were wonderful through this time & more than made up with prompt service despite this being clearly a very busy night. Will surely be back and look forward to a wonderful dining experience again :)

Don't waste your time with this bush-league operation. My delivery order from them was suddenly cancelled after more than one hour after placing an order. You're better off trying another restaurant during the COVID-19 lockdown and afterwards. I can see why their service was deservedly panned on Yelp.

Very nice atmosphere. Family friendly and relaxed. The bread was light and crisp. The fettuccini was homemade and very well done. I recommend this as a spot to relax, enjoy dinner and watch the world around you.

Limoncello is located at the end of Robertson Quay. I've been here twice, once with a big group of 16 for a birthday party. Bad experience. Understandably, we went on a Friday night, and things were pretty hectic, but service was pretty bad. It's in the range of La Villa, but the service is way below that of La Villa.We were seated at a long table toward the back of the restaurant and throughout the dinner a large majority of my group complained of the insufferable heat. I was fine actually, but for some of them it got so bad that they went outside, and only re-entered the restaurants when the dishes arrived. Which brings me to the point of the food. We had to wait pretty long for our dishes, and finally, when they did arrive our orders were messed up.  They accidentally gave us two portions of the Bolognese, so I tried some of it - very standard fare. We also ordered two Spaghetti Al Cartoccio which is spaghetti with mixed seafood wrapped in baking paper in light tomato sauce. Unfortunately, only one of this arrived and we kept waiting and explaining to them that we were expecting a second one - it never came and we eventually cancelled it. Anyway, apart from the mess-up my friend who did get the dish raved that this was really quite delicious, and there was generous portions of seafood. As for me, I got the Spaghetti Carbonara, which was standard quality - nothing to write home about. I suppose I wasn't expecting much anyway, ... so I'd suggest ordering the Al Cartoccio if you do come here. In total I spent about $30, so that's quite reasonable for standard Italian fare. It's kind of a nice restaurant with some potential, and a nice ambience for a date, but perhaps not the best for a group dinner.

Limoncello is alright. I've been here more than five times just because it's convenient, has decent food and predictable.I like the truffle pizza and the parma ham pizza. Also enjoyed the usual margherita pizza.It's nicer to sit outside when the weather permits - then you get a view of the river and can people watch if you so desireBasically, i come here when i feel tired and can't be bothered to be creative about where i want to go eat.

The pasta dishes are OK now, and the pizzas are still good, but they have reduced the size of the pizzas! You pay $50 for 2 small pizzas and that is just ridiculous. The smaller size is obvious because 1) you are still hungry after eating a pizza and 2) if you take away, the box which they have been using for years has a lot of space now since the pizza size has been reduced.I say reduce the pricing for each pizza then or increase the pizza size again so customers feel they are not ripped off.

6th visit. This place is a regular favorite amongst my Italian friends. Honest and reliable pizza. Nice and tranquil main dining room with a trickling waterfall in the back. I've sat outside as well as the bar area before and think the main dining area is the most comfortable. Antipasti platter was v nice - Parma ham,Burrata, tomatoes, rocket, roasted peppers. I had the barramundi today - fresh product was nicely roasted. I would order this again.

positively surprised!I had a candlelight dinner (with my Brother ;-)) on a nice Thursday evening there and both of us had a Pizza. I was positively surprised about the good quality of Pizza, the size of it, the flexibility of the waiters and they even served Perroni beer (felt almost like at home :-)).

The service is the best! This is my honest review.. I would like to thank the wait staff named Dipo, he really smiles when serving me with wine and pasta. I feel so comfortable eating my dinner, the food and everything. Ofcourse in coming back here for some more! Well i advise u and ur family to dine in here. U will really enjoy the food!

Limoncello is located at the end of Robertson Quay. I've been here twice, once with a big group of 16 for a birthday party. Bad experience. Understandably, we went on a Friday night, and things were pretty hectic, but service was pretty bad. It's in the range of La Villa, but the service is way below that of La Villa.We were seated at a long table toward the back of the restaurant and throughout the dinner a large majority of my group complained of the insufferable heat. I was fine actually, but for some of them it got so bad that they went outside, and only re-entered the restaurants when the dishes arrived. Which brings me to the point of the food. We had to wait pretty long for our dishes, and finally, when they did arrive our orders were messed up.  They accidentally gave us two portions of the Bolognese, so I tried some of it - very standard fare. We also ordered two Spaghetti Al Cartoccio which is spaghetti with mixed seafood wrapped in baking paper in light tomato sauce. Unfortunately, only one of this arrived and we kept waiting and explaining to them that we were expecting a second one - it never came and we eventually cancelled it. Anyway, apart from the mess-up my friend who did get the dish raved that this was really quite delicious, and there was generous portions of seafood. As for me, I got the Spaghetti Carbonara, which was standard quality - nothing to write home about. I suppose I wasn't expecting much anyway, ... so I'd suggest ordering the Al Cartoccio if you do come here. In total I spent about $30, so that's quite reasonable for standard Italian fare. It's kind of a nice restaurant with some potential, and a nice ambience for a date, but perhaps not the best for a group dinner.

Grand Shanghai will take you back to the olden days of fine dining in Shanghai with a live entertainment. Theresa Teng songs covers. Romantic dimmed chandeliers. Fancy bathroom. OK service. We ordered quite a lot of dishes! It was our last meal in Singapore so our relatives wanted to go all out! Here is what we got:jellyfish appetizer Peking duck Roasted crispy chickenSalted egg fried prawns Sweet and sour pork Shredded chicken with beancurd Shark fin soup Winter melon soup Crab fried noodle Mango pudding Mango sago with pomeloIt honestly felt like a Chinese wedding dinner. Minus the lobster, fish, and abalone. I was seriously considering having my wedding here haha. Anyway, food was pretty good. Typical Chinese food. My favorite was the Peking duck and the salted egg fried prawns. Mmmmm. Yummm!! I would come here again for special occasions. Service was good too! There were a lot of ladies taking good care of us.

Dinner at the Grand Shanghai is like taking a trip back in time. Chinese songstress crooning old Chinese classics accompanied by a soulful saxophonist, the crystal chandeliers, old fashioned table lamps and ceiling fans...five stars for the ambience. We had Crispy Eel, Xiao Long Bao and Guo Tie, which were good, but I've had better.  The Peking duck is good but not the best I've had. The meat was succulent and tasty. The soufflé dessert is good. All in, the food is decent but not a stand-out. If you come to Grand Shanghai, it's mostly for the ambience. A great place to entertain some Gwai Lo, or to get that retro or vintage feel.

My family's favourite Chinese restaurantAmbiance - old town Shanghai, modern retro with Chinese/Taiwanese singers singing old Chinese songs. The older generation would probably love this. My grandparents certainly do. The main attraction for my family though is the food. Been here more than 10 times and almost everything we have ordered has been really good.Tonight we had the following dishes:Black fungus in vinegar (cold appetizer) - mainstay for our family. Simple dish but oh so delicious and refreshing. 10/10Cold bitter gourd (cold appetizer) - refreshing and very bitter. I don't personally like this as I don't like bitter gourd, but it's one of my father's favourites. 9/10Sea cucumber w fish maw & abalone - I'm not a fan of this dish as I don't like abalone but the majority of the table liked it alot. Abalone and fish maw was tender, sea cucumber was juicy and plump. This is an individual portion dish. Came with a lot of veg, so you don't need to order a separate veg dish if you don't want to. 7.5/10Salt & pepper spare ribs - my brother loved this dish. Pretty good, Tender, juicy, not oily. 7/10Garlic dou Miao - very sweet 8/10Dan Dan mian - not a fan of this usually, but ordered one portion as someone wanted to try. Wasn't half bad, sauce was rather tasteful.  7/10Deep fried cod with garlic - lovely. Not at all dry like the usual fried fish in Chinese restaurants, very soft and flaky, almost melt in your mouth. Closer to jap gindara teriyaki type of cod texture then the fried Chinese type of fish. Awesome dish.  8.5-9/10Shark cartilage/bones soup  -  Don't eat shark's fin soup, and definitely prefer this instead. Warm, rich and full bodied. Very satisfying. 8/10Cold aloe Vera jelly dessert - refreshing, great end to dinner. Possibly my favorite Chinese dessert. 10/10Total cost was about $700 for 6 pax for tonight's dishes

The resto itself is nice... Feels like in shanghai a little bit and they sing old fashion songs - depend for people since some people cant stand to hear old songs. I was having a good time there on my birthday treat, the singer sang dual language happy birthday.. Feels goodFood - their food is considered mediocre with price that bot cheap i bet, i would better go to long beach to have that chinese food with better taste and pretty much same price i guess??

Above average shanghainese food. All the dishes were generally good. I especially like their crispy eel appetizer, it's like a good interpretation of our local baby squid style.The nicest part is the decor and the entertainment. If you go with old folks, they will particularly enjoy the shanghai singers. They also accept song dedications and you get to hear lots of Chinese oldies.

I came here for a wedding reception so the review is strictly for catered food + experience. Food was good; portion sizes were generous. What i enjoyed most was the Shanghainese Jazz singers who performed a couple of sets during the reception- very entertaining.
Food was fine. Was wedding fare, so would want to return to see their usual offerings.

Toby's came to Singapore by way of Australia and I'm loving the vibe here. The modern warehouse look with its cool cement walls and warm wooden tables is hipsterness magnified. From the outside, I thought this is just a casual cafe, but going in, its actually a full service restaurant.I already had a light lunch, so I just ordered their croissant and an iced chai. Prices are higher due to the dreamy location by the Singapore River. My order came quickly and I tore into a supremely flaky croissant that's warm and nicely paired with (even more) butter and strawberry jam. Their iced chai is frothy and amazing. It's so amazing, that on a repeat visit, I ordered the same thing. Before you leave, browse their single origin coffee selection and coffee accessories. The coffee freak in you will surely be pleased.

Toby's Estate is a great spot to relax with some good coffee and have a chat with friends. There is some counter space along the front window where you can work at your computer and the view of Robertson Quay. With the free WiFi and ample table seating, it makes a great coffee shop.The prices are fairly high, so be aware, but the food quality is as well. Also, there are no bathrooms inside the place, but rather, around the corner of the building, so plan accordingly.

A comfortable, quiet cafe with the best coffee you can get! Ordered the flat white ($5.50 before gst) and was not let down by the smooth coffee which was not acidic and pleasant to the taste buds. Other special drinks include the mocha chai and their cold brew.No service charge but excellent service.

This is one of many place along the water at Robertson Quay and I know what you are thinking - yet another place that is just over-priced and does not really deliver nearly what one would expect. I can really understand that view as many of the places around here cater to people with more money than sense and taste but I do not believe that Toby's Estate is one of them. The coffee here is actually really good, they serve excellent filter coffee and the ice coffee is also one of the better ones I have had in Singapore. Espresso based beverages also do not disappoint but I seldom order them since the other coffees are so good and in my view a good filter always is preferable over an equally good espresso based beverage.The food is not bad but a tad bit on the pricey side so I do only eat here when my hunger coincides with an intense need for coffee. Service has always been very friendly here and I can see that as a regular you tend to get certain benefits as I have noticed that when I have been here a lot during periods (when I stayed close by) they always manage to find a seat and also sometimes give some free tasters of some coffee.I can agree with Michelle M that the bathroom set-up is a bit strange but that seems to be the same for several places around there but I never had any issues with it being overly dirty or messy - maybe it is for once the ladies room that looks worse than the men's room :-)
The ladies working were very sweet.  Food was delicious.  Overall good vibe.  Free wi-fi.

Meh, not impressed by this place. There's no waiting area. It was a Sunday afternoon and seats are all taken. So my group of 4 awkwardly waited at the space near the entrance. When we finally got a table, it was by the window. It wouldn't be so bad if the sun didn't shine through and heating up our area. On the bright side, my friend(nearest to the window)'s coffee remained warm throughout.I ordered scrambled eggs on toasted brioche, $10, with Harrisa sausage, +$4.50. The eggs were tad overdone to my liking instead of runny and creamy. For a moment, I thought I was at McD for Big Breakfast. Very plain and ordinary.Not going back anytime soon since its just another cafe serving plain pricey eggs. But hey, at least they have free wifi. ;)
Coffee much better than I remembered to be the last time I was there. Very, very comforting and enjoyable cuppa. Have not tried the food though! Would most likely go back to try the food soon :)

Coffee is great, and I don't say that lightly. Definitely on par with the better 3rd wave places, especially a very "common" place nearby. Food is decent, though a touch pricey. That said, not much affordable fare in the Robertson Quay area to begin with. Very importantly... Free wifi! Great place to sit down and hammer out a bit of work over a nice V60 brew.

The first thing that I wanted when I woke up that first morning in Singapore was to find some place to have some breakfast. Fortunately Yelp came to the rescue and recommended this place that was just across the river from my hotel. I must admit that I am not really used to the cafe culture here in Singapore, namely because they pretty much all have table service (normally I simply go to the counter, order my coffee, and then find a place to sit). This place wasn't all that bad, and the Brooklyn Style that I had was pretty nice. They also made a decent coffee (not that I am a real coffee connoisseur, but I decided that since I was overseas I would try out the coffee in as many places as possible). The service was pretty good, though not the quickest (but I found that that was the case in most places in Singapore anyway - maybe it is not as hustle and bustle as I am used to in Melbourne). It's also a pretty quite part of the city as well, and the riverside view makes it great for the experience.

My new favorite joint for brunch even though it isn't very accessible (my definition: near an mrt). I hate driving into town area because I am pretty bad at directions and one wrong turn can cause me to loop around a couple ERPs. Not cool. The nearest mrt station is clark quay but it's still quite a far walk. Despite the long "hike", I managed to reach this place, hungry. All that walking really works up an appetite. The food1. Soya milk latte- Loved it. It had the perfect nutty taste. 2. Croissant with scrambled eggs & honey bacon- Cindy Q was spot on in her review of the its croissants. It has to be the best croissants I've tasted!!! How on earth did they make it so flaky and crispy??? Magic. The scramble eggs were pretty good but then again how wrong can one go with them. Child's play. The honey bacon on the other hand had an interesting smokey flavor laced with a sweetness that reminded me of candy bacon (Epic Meal Time). It was ok I guess but I think I prefer my bacon savory rather than sweet. Lovely ambiance It's like walking into a cafe in Australia - Chilled, laid back and with a big coffee roaster.  I would love to bring a good book here one day, read it while sipping on my latte and nibbling on those magically croissants! Overall great experience. Perfect for a lazy weekend brunch. Best thing is that they serve brunch till 5pm so for all ya sleepy heads out there who cannot get up in time for a MacD's breakfast, this is perfect.
Very good food, nice setting. Had the Wolly with poached eggs on a bread. The bread is excellent, soft and full of taste. The coffee drinkers advised that the coffee is good too.

I just tried to eat here and there were several open tables when I arrived. However, I was turned away because they "only allow dogs at one table," and that table was occupied. But I have been here many, many times before with my dog and have never been told this. In the past, there have been multiple dogs present at different tables. So, I'm not sure why I was turned away if not for a fake "one dog at one particular table" policy. Regardless, I only used to eat here because they are one of a handful of restaurants that allowed dogs on their patio, but the food really isn't spectacular. If you don't have limitations, try any other of the places in Robertson - there are many more that are far better.

Ok, bees there a few more times... The service is still slow, depending on the time. And it's still overpriced. However, after more than 5 yrs in Singapore, I have to adjust the score to other similar places--1 star was too harsh considering the competition! :-)

This place is a regular coffee joint for me. 1) The coffee..always reliable. I have never had a bad or off one here.2) Try the Gilbraltar for a bit more intensity than a latte and a bit more volume than a piccolo3) They have lovely shattery-crust croissants here!4) Love the decor and chill vibe5) Fluffy scrambled eggs6) A bag of Rodyk blend beans..costs $12.50. That's cheaper than many of the roasters in town and this blend really works with milk-based drinks. Chocolatey, well rounded, not too much acidity and therefore a crowd pleaser.7) It's always a plus looking over the river enjoying your drink. Makes you feel you have all the time in the world and you're really out of the "city"8) They serve a brioche here with great texture and lightness..so much so that I quite often order scrambled eggs on brioche to share..on the side of a croissant of course. Tip: Ask for jam, it's free!8) Consistency (see 1, 5 and 8)

Overpriced and poor quality food. Horrible service.  Ordered the pulled pork sandwich for $22. Small amount of pork and lukewarm fries.  After I finished the sandwich and about 25 min later they then decide to bring my wife's chicken salad. Very low quality chicken and the pieces were practically cold. They charge $18 for this "dish". I suggest to visit one of the other small restaurants near by.

Had Saturday lunch here with a couple of friends. I had a beef burgers with rainbow fries. The fries were fantastic. The beef was hard and undercooked in some parts Service was ok. They seemed understaffed.  Aircon was terrible. It felt hot in the middle of the indoor eating area. It was noisy too.
Good food and ambience. Pretty busy during weekend. Didn't have the green juice on the menu.

Finally had the opportunity to try the coffee at Toby's Estate last Sunday and its coffee gets my vote of approval. The cafe mocha I tried was pure cocoa and coffee goodness. My friend had a latte and she enjoyed it immensely too. Having studied in Australia, I can say that it compares well with the coffee in Melbourne.Will certainly be back to try the food!

Their coffee as usual were spot on. But serving size was smaller. Seating area was kinda limited. The food menu was okay, I was hoping that it would be better than Manila outlet, apparently not. Manila still have the best food to offer.

Toby's is just a stone's throw away from Kith Cafe which is also very popular with the residents in the area. Shall try that some time soon. Love the old warehouse feel to the area. Very grunge but they have since refurbished and repainted the exterior. We have noted this place some time ago before Toby moved in. Something we noticed about the recent development in the cafe scene is that they all kinda have the same decor. Brick walls juxtaposed with a black, white and wood theme. A little raw, a little unfinished. I'm not complaining because i like it this way. The flooring of my future home would be cement or i would have a cement wall feature.Nice airy space to chill at but my main complain is that there are not enough seats in the house! The concept of communal dining is cool but it's not very comfortable squeezing between different groups of people early in the morning just to get my caffeine fix. The space could be better utilized i feel.The coffee is easy on the palate. I usually don't take coffee without sugar but after having Papa Pahleta's, i concluded that good coffee doesn't require any additional sweetening. I would put this in the same category. Can't say too much about the coffee as my throat was crying for help from the soreness and i think coffee made it worse. :(Ham and Cheese Croissant was really good. The pastry is very light and airy and extremely crispy! I would love for the centre texture to have more pull though. The pastries are outsourced. S said something about it coming from Bread Project. I should just go straight to the source to get my croissant. S had the poached egg with salmon on brioche. My first impression is that it looks a lot like WH's but the brioche is not toasted and this is more buttery and very fluffy. Shall try the brioche with jam next time to get a more accurate feel to the texture. Nicely done eggs but i wouldn't say that this dish is spectacular? Not something i would definitely come back for.W showed up at Toby's after we were about done with our breakfast. He had the Toby's Breakfast- a composition of scrambled eggs, back bacon, roasted tomatoes and peppers and sautéed mushrooms. The eggs sure look runny enough. Shall try this when i feel better. Anyway, it's breakfast till 3pm daily so more incentives to come down. Downside to this place is also the really slow service. They really need to work on getting the coffee and food out faster.

With no bathroom indoors and pour overs made with beans that were roasted a months ago, Toby's will not be my number one place to go if I'm looking for a coffee joint. Multiple service errors also made the experience less enjoyable than it should have been. Sorry to say, but I've had better experiences at a neighborhood kopi joint.

Toby's Estate, is a pretty renowned coffee chain in Australia. Originally in Toby's Mum garage in Sydney now expanded to Sydney, Melbourne, Perth, Brisbane, Singapore, and even Brooklyn. They were also in the Union Square Holiday Markets in NYC. I kinda like the Robertson Quay area as its usually not too crowded and there's plenty of dining areas. There's also a couple of coffee places where you can sip your coffee by the river. Of course when the weather permits.. Sat by the river for a bit and it started pouring.. Coffee on a weekday afternoon was awesome nevertheless. *Thumbs up*

As the coffee culture is starting to blossom in Singapore, Toby's Estate might just be the perfect addition to the local cafe scene. They have been roasting and serving cups of caffeinated (or de-caf, depending on your preference) goodness since 1998.Stepping into the cafe, you're immediately greeted by a gorgeous handpainted mural on the main wall, as you see above, which depicts the point of harvest to the end product. This is representative of Toby's mantra towards coffee appreciation, "for us, it is all about the journey of the bean.
