We take pride that we do our business sustainably and when it comes to the process of creating that perfect cup, we also take it very seriously."Serious is Toby's Estate about its coffee as you see the sheer varieties of ways you can get your cup done - espresso machine, chemex, clover, woodneck, V60, siphon... and before you get your heads in a mess with the sheer amount of geeky coffee terms, rest assured that the baristas will be more than happy to explain to you the various ways to preparing the drink. We love the idea of "man" versus "machine" as a way for coffee lovers to explore how the different preparation methods creates different coffees.We had a cup of espresso and cappucino each to taste the blend on its own and with the addition of milk. Needless to say, we were suitably impressed as it has a bold body, definitely will work for those who love their shots!Good news to those who love to work outside, Toby's Estate is wireless equipped so you can drop by for your appointments and meetings.

Coffee - one of the best you'll find in Singapore. Diamond in the rough.Brunch/Breakfast - I don't know why some initial blogs and reviews had it as just "OK" but the scrambled eggs are done superbly, the Moroccan variety is hearty and deserve praise and the makeup of the peasant eggs dish is well done. All round applause.In summary, one of our favourite places for brunch, weekdays or weekends.Edit: We just tried their muesli. Divine.Update 25 Feb 2014: We noticed the strong truffle flavours overpowering the mushrooms and have provided feedback directly in the past. The mushrooms are still too heavy on the truffle side - can we please have an option to reduce the truffle or eliminate it altogether? Sometimes, we just like the mushrooms sauteed lightly with salt.Update May 2014: Fly discovered in breakfast half way through the meal. Staff did not offer to replace or strike off the cost of the dish. That's not the way to run a business in Singapore's competitive F&B scene. Seems like attitude and service mentality is dropping. Didn't have a chance to see if they have taken input about the mushrooms as there were no mushrooms on the day.

This place is a little gem in Singapore. Most places are buzzing, giving you the impression life is going crazy fast.However by luck I found this cafe, along the river on Richardson Quay. Imagine a nice cafe, high ceiling, modern / industrial / simple decor.A nice terrace, and inside a few tables, a bar along the windows to sit on high chairs and enjoy coffee, and a communal table in the middle. That's were I enjoyed 2 hours of my time, drinking coffee, having a nice lunch, reading etc. Food is good, but not amazing, so go here for  simple food and a coffee, not for michelin star food ;-)This is simply my kind of cafes, where time slows down, people are friendly, the coffee is good and I can easily relax.They also burn their own coffee beans inside the cafe itself.

Toby's serves awesome coffee at a pretty chill location. The coffee they serve is yummy, and ranks as one of the best in Singapore. Creamy, strong, smooth. It's hard to find better coffee, even with the recent rise in number of specialty coffee joints in Singapore. Toby's is located right along the river, which makes it a perfect place to people watch and catch up with friends. It's also a pretty ideal spot to do work at, what with free wi-fi and power outlets. It's interior is dark and inviting, and it's hard to leave the place without feeling satisfied and happy.

A super heavyweight to descend on the shores of our indie coffee cafes, this Third Wave coffee invasion experienced some serious rocking of the boat when Toby's opened up last year. Hailing from Australia, this franchise was a sign that our coffee scene is now big enough to sustain an overseas franchise since the Second Wave coffees. What it brought along was a huge space along the Robertson Quay area. It has very high ceilings and a very casual friendly atmosphere. What I really liked was the fact that they are really serious about the coffees. You can tell with the bean bags and apparatuses lying around. They bring in their own beans and there are sampler sets for you to try.The baristas are also very friendly and will speak to you about the coffee if you asked. When we went they have already ran out of food. Generally, try to avoid cafes on Sunday late afternoons if you want food!
The best Flat White (kind of like a latte in the US) I have had in a long time.  The Brekkie of Champions was amazing, everything very fresh and lots of it.  Highly recommended if you are hungry.

Very solid!  If you're looking for a good hearty breakfast and coffee to match this is a great option. It's not claiming to be gourmet food and café. Just a cool spot to walk by the water and get some tasty food in a community setting.

Really trendy coffee shop in Robertson Quay. You can tell that most of the patrons here live around the corner, because they all look nice and put together. There were not enough people that looked like a frikken HOT MESS because they miscalculated how far it is from Clarke Quay and walked a good 20 minutes under the brutal sun right after lunch time. (I may or may not be talking about myself....) If it's your first time visiting and you cab it, note that Rodyk St kind of dead ends and looks pretty residential. Keep walking towards Robertson Quay, hang a right and you're there! The first time I stopped by, I ordered a cappuccino and a pastry. I admired the excellent latte art; the pastry was nothing to Yelp about. The second time I visited, I ordered the iced chai latte, and that was an epic fail whale. I kid you not, it was 10% chai at the bottom, 90% milk, and a tall cup full of ice, all for the lovely price of $6. Blech.I also find it strange how they don't have a bathroom inside the shop. You have to go outside around the corner. I actually went to this bathroom, and it explicitly says it's not a public bathroom but only for the residents of the building. Weird. Despite the warning signs, I used it anyways and unfortunately discovered that it needs some maintenance. There were only 2 stalls, and neither of them locked correctly. Overall, decent place to check out if you need to get out of your bubble. Just beware of the bathrooms.

Mmmmmm...  yes please. Coffees of different origin, blend, style, and brew? yes please.Food made with whole, fresh, and simple ingredients, with breakfast all day? yes please.Service with a smile, suggestions, and explanations? yes please.Free wifi and quirky upmarket-slash-hipster-slash-trendy ambience with funky lighting? yes please. Scenic patio with good people-watching perches? yes please.Ample seating during peak hours? uhhhh. Nope? Dang. Well, all of the above will do. I will wait for a table, then.
Had the coffee here and it's amazing. A little pricey but great! Definitely better than starbucks! Haha the flatwhites are awesome!
Nothing to say about the food, I came for coffee, I needed it after days of awful hotel coffee. They delivered on the coffee, it was everything I had imagined it to be. Thank you, you saved my life.

One of the top places in Singapore for coffee alone, maybe not so much for brunch. But for coffee, this is firmly in the top echelon of coffee places in Singapore. They have introduced consistency into their coffees, such that the espressos are flavourful and well made; and the milk-based espressos are also tasty. If there's a slight grouse, it would be the use of the Greenfields milk - I'm not really a fan of that as it's rather thin and not so creamy. What I like is the variety in the beans that they use. Toby's brings in beans from all over the world, and so you have very interesting variants in the hopper ranging from a sweet Ethiopian Yirgacheffe peaberry, to full bodied Mexico, to jammy Costa Rican - and if you are in luck to visit when they have COEs on offer (certificate of excellence coffee) - by all means, try that. you'd be pleasantly surprised. The food - it's alright, not stellar. The eggs could be much more runny and use cream; although the mushrooms and bacon are alright, you can't go wrong with them. The ambience is lovely - a high ceiling, by the river - very Australian. Reminiscent of Seven Seeds in Melbourne, or St Ali.

Great coffee and fantastic scrambled eggs! Staff are very friendly and fairly efficient (by Singapore standards!). Having said that the place is completely packed every day.Great place for a relaxing weekend brunch and highly recommended.

Coffee is excellent, ambiance is great, pastries top-notch.Came here last week for a laid-back breakfast.  Had a latte and a pour-over coffee with a chocolate croissant.  We sat outside on their patio, which is very nicely sectioned off from the common sidewalk, with a little waterfall and some plants.  You're right on the river.  The inside space is great too, loft-feeling, and if it wasn't so nice outside I would have happily enjoyed sitting indoors!The prices were high for an American standard, but for a Singapore standard, they were reasonable and the food/drinks were a higher quality than you'd get at many nearby cafes for a similar price.

Australian breakfast food arrived in Singapore. Great coffee with poached eggs (just look at the trays of eggs by the wall !!!!). Fantastic house blend (Rodyk blend) the day I visited. Great location too, fronting the Singapore River

As a coffee lover, I rejoiced when I saw that the Sydney-based Toby's was expanding to Robertson Quay.  Coffee-wise, I was not disappointed, loving the quality of the coffee beans and of course the baristas.Only tried a couple of food items which were not great, but certainly decent.Great wooden, slightly dark interiors facing the river as well.  Lovely place to unwind with pals on the weekend.
Toby's Estate is located in a fun part of town- Robertson Quay. The cafe has a contemporary-rustic-shared-table feel. The coffee itself was OK; i prefer the coffee at Oriole Roasters

Am not a coffee drinker and came here for a meeting. The overall environment is great for small and big groups. Servers are great and pleasant, very attentive too. Can't comment much on the menu as I only had Peppermint tea but would come back here again just to chill or work for a change.

As a coffee lover, I rejoiced when I saw that the Sydney-based Toby's was expanding to Robertson Quay.  Coffee-wise, I was not disappointed, loving the quality of the coffee beans and of course the baristas.Only tried a couple of food items which were not great, but certainly decent.Great wooden, slightly dark interiors facing the river as well.  Lovely place to unwind with pals on the weekend.

Toby's Estate, is a pretty renowned coffee chain in Australia. Originally in Toby's Mum garage in Sydney now expanded to Sydney, Melbourne, Perth, Brisbane, Singapore, and even Brooklyn. They were also in the Union Square Holiday Markets in NYC. I kinda like the Robertson Quay area as its usually not too crowded and there's plenty of dining areas. There's also a couple of coffee places where you can sip your coffee by the river. Of course when the weather permits.. Sat by the river for a bit and it started pouring.. Coffee on a weekday afternoon was awesome nevertheless. *Thumbs up*

One of the top places in Singapore for coffee alone, maybe not so much for brunch. But for coffee, this is firmly in the top echelon of coffee places in Singapore. They have introduced consistency into their coffees, such that the espressos are flavourful and well made; and the milk-based espressos are also tasty. If there's a slight grouse, it would be the use of the Greenfields milk - I'm not really a fan of that as it's rather thin and not so creamy. What I like is the variety in the beans that they use. Toby's brings in beans from all over the world, and so you have very interesting variants in the hopper ranging from a sweet Ethiopian Yirgacheffe peaberry, to full bodied Mexico, to jammy Costa Rican - and if you are in luck to visit when they have COEs on offer (certificate of excellence coffee) - by all means, try that. you'd be pleasantly surprised. The food - it's alright, not stellar. The eggs could be much more runny and use cream; although the mushrooms and bacon are alright, you can't go wrong with them. The ambience is lovely - a high ceiling, by the river - very Australian. Reminiscent of Seven Seeds in Melbourne, or St Ali.

Really enjoy the coffee and food at Toby's. They serve breakfast, lunch and dinner. Located along the Singapore River, you can sit outside or inside. The staff is friendly and courteous. I usually order a cappuccino or drip coffee, but they have several different methods and roasts you can choose from. You can also buy freshly roasted beans and coffee-making supplies here. Free wifi!

Love the space. High ceilings, big long table, right by Singapore River.Coffee great. I had the regular latte. Rich, smooth, thick and fragrant, just the way I like it. Kind of remind me of Abraco in NYC.

Good spot for coffee while in Robertson quay. I like both the indoor and outdoor seating spaces. Ordered the Mac n cheese and thought it was ok, I would have preferred it to be creamier. For some reason though I prefer kith and some of the other Robertson quay coffee places

Really smooth, strong and aromatic coffee, nice location by the river, and very tranquil and pleasing atmosphere. There's some nice outdoor seating if you feel like it. Or you could sit at the long communal table that occupies most of the inside of the cafe. The communal table, high ceiling and floor-to-ceiling glass shop front makes the space feel a lot more open.There are food options like quiches, sandwiches and breakfast/brunch items. A different menu is offered for brunch, lunch and dinner. There's also wifi and ample and strategically placed power outlets so you can pull out your laptop to work. Toby's takes its coffee really seriously (you know, Third Wave and all) so there's a clear focus on coffee appreciation. You can buy coffee making apparatus, books (including one written by the owner) and other assorted coffee paraphernalia.

Toby's is just a stone's throw away from Kith Cafe which is also very popular with the residents in the area. Shall try that some time soon. Love the old warehouse feel to the area. Very grunge but they have since refurbished and repainted the exterior. We have noted this place some time ago before Toby moved in. Something we noticed about the recent development in the cafe scene is that they all kinda have the same decor. Brick walls juxtaposed with a black, white and wood theme. A little raw, a little unfinished. I'm not complaining because i like it this way. The flooring of my future home would be cement or i would have a cement wall feature.Nice airy space to chill at but my main complain is that there are not enough seats in the house! The concept of communal dining is cool but it's not very comfortable squeezing between different groups of people early in the morning just to get my caffeine fix. The space could be better utilized i feel.The coffee is easy on the palate. I usually don't take coffee without sugar but after having Papa Pahleta's, i concluded that good coffee doesn't require any additional sweetening. I would put this in the same category. Can't say too much about the coffee as my throat was crying for help from the soreness and i think coffee made it worse. :(Ham and Cheese Croissant was really good. The pastry is very light and airy and extremely crispy! I would love for the centre texture to have more pull though. The pastries are outsourced. S said something about it coming from Bread Project. I should just go straight to the source to get my croissant. S had the poached egg with salmon on brioche. My first impression is that it looks a lot like WH's but the brioche is not toasted and this is more buttery and very fluffy. Shall try the brioche with jam next time to get a more accurate feel to the texture. Nicely done eggs but i wouldn't say that this dish is spectacular? Not something i would definitely come back for.W showed up at Toby's after we were about done with our breakfast. He had the Toby's Breakfast- a composition of scrambled eggs, back bacon, roasted tomatoes and peppers and sautéed mushrooms. The eggs sure look runny enough. Shall try this when i feel better. Anyway, it's breakfast till 3pm daily so more incentives to come down. Downside to this place is also the really slow service. They really need to work on getting the coffee and food out faster.

Toby's serves awesome coffee at a pretty chill location. The coffee they serve is yummy, and ranks as one of the best in Singapore. Creamy, strong, smooth. It's hard to find better coffee, even with the recent rise in number of specialty coffee joints in Singapore. Toby's is located right along the river, which makes it a perfect place to people watch and catch up with friends. It's also a pretty ideal spot to do work at, what with free wi-fi and power outlets. It's interior is dark and inviting, and it's hard to leave the place without feeling satisfied and happy.

A super heavyweight to descend on the shores of our indie coffee cafes, this Third Wave coffee invasion experienced some serious rocking of the boat when Toby's opened up last year. Hailing from Australia, this franchise was a sign that our coffee scene is now big enough to sustain an overseas franchise since the Second Wave coffees. What it brought along was a huge space along the Robertson Quay area. It has very high ceilings and a very casual friendly atmosphere. What I really liked was the fact that they are really serious about the coffees. You can tell with the bean bags and apparatuses lying around. They bring in their own beans and there are sampler sets for you to try.The baristas are also very friendly and will speak to you about the coffee if you asked. When we went they have already ran out of food. Generally, try to avoid cafes on Sunday late afternoons if you want food!
Service is horrible!  My food order was forgotten which came with the usual blank stare from the staff.  A shame for this brand to not be able to uphold it's strong Australian values.

Really enjoy the coffee and food at Toby's. They serve breakfast, lunch and dinner. Located along the Singapore River, you can sit outside or inside. The staff is friendly and courteous. I usually order a cappuccino or drip coffee, but they have several different methods and roasts you can choose from. You can also buy freshly roasted beans and coffee-making supplies here. Free wifi!

dinner at violet oon, ion last night. i actually quite like the food here, it's the cheaper version of candlenut.  good peranakan food in a nice, comfortable setting. the portion's generous too. we ordered beef rendang, ayam buah keluak, chap chye and ngo hiang. all eaten with jasmine  . satisfying meal.

If all of a sudden you're having a Peranakan attack while shopping at ION, you might come here. The food is not bad. Otherwise, for a really satisfying experience, go to the Violet Oon at the National Gallery, or the Peranakan at nearby Claymore Connect, or Candlenut at Dempsey for a modern twist. They also serve non-Nonya dishes like shepherds pie. Ambiance and service are more casual Café style than restaurant.

Take away is.... would i return... YES!  Rendang... nice.  kelauh a tad sour but like the way they smooth out and stuff it back it.  Lodeh pretty good.  Keuh D D unfortunately was served a little cold inside.  Tasted ok but the texture of the wrapping too smooth.  Perhaps a new rendition?

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-15 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Feeling homesick travelling thru Asia? Drop by this iconic Aussie place right on the river in Singapore and you will feel at home. Great music, Aussie beers at reasonable prices and good tucker.Some great traditional food -chicken parma - and some new ones with an Aussie twist.Not a fan of Roo but that is here to and made well according to the guys I was with.Enjoy!

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-15 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Classic (Aussie) bar food favorites. Stopped by on the way back to my nearby hotel. Ordered the grilled chicken with bacon sandwich (added avocado) and a Caesar salad. The chicken was a bit overcooked and tough, while the Caesar dressing was a bit dull. They have all the comfort foods and a great spot outside, but keep your level of expectations at bar food and drinks.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-15 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: I agree with most on here.  Food is nothing to write home about but prices on buckets of beer is decent. It Has a nice view of the river and outdoor seating. We would come back to share a pizza and beers. Pizza also decent. Just come knowing it's a meh but decent.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-15 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Went for lunch brunch with my family and it was a pleasant experience. Food was simple, no frills but fresh, tasty and good value for money. The coffee was also decent. Service staff was friendly and this place is very child friendly. Love it!

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-15 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: One of my favorite places in Singapore around Robertson Quay area.  Lots of seatings, tons of TV to watch rugby (go All Blacks!), fans (all seats are outdoor or open air) and lots of friendly people everywhere.  Why only 3 stars?  Their food needs little more improvements!

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-15 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Good steak. The portion is just nice to go with a vegetable side dish. We ordered a plater of grilled sausages, prawn and lamb. It was ok, nothing amazing. The price is slighly on a higher end I must say.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-15 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Breakfast was great. Try their pancakes as well. Service was also good. I would recommend if you are in the area.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-15 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Convivial enough establishment, but doesn't warrant the high prices (even in the Lion City).Chicken club was pretty good, but the fries were tired. After Meggetigans and Murphys, I was astounded to see that the beer selection didn't compare, but the pints still came out highest. $14 (Singapore dollars) is crazy without a stout, much less an IPA, on tap.You can still choose to ignore all that, and come for the gentle breeze on the canal.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-15 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: I've given this restaurant a few shots and left feeling the same each time. The food is either bland, greasy, or the flavor and food combinations are just disagreeable.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-15 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Boomarang (why they insist on spelling it incorrectly, I don't know) is one of my favorite places to come for a nice, relaxing evening. The food is good, the service is friendly, and they have happy hour. The food is a little pricey, but pretty standard for the area. But the food is very good. The Wagyu burger is pretty great, and comes with beets in it. You can add a fried egg and bacon for a bit extra. I was happy to find that the fries that came with the burger were good also. For lunch, they have a lunch special for $12. It involves a sandwich and soup which is really good. The sandwich menu changes weekly depending on what's in season and what the chef feels like making, so there's always something new to try.  Happy hour is weekdays 5pm - 8pm and weekends 2pm - 8pm. They also have some weekly events. Tuesday is trivia night. Wednesdays is beer and burger night where their great wagyu burgers + a beer is $25 and also pint night ($10 for a pint).

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-15 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: The menu looked great, but the result was disappointing. Bruschetta on soggy flat bread instead of golden toasted bread just doesn't cut it. And the "Aussie Steak Sandwich" had everything in it as promised on the menu, but one sad piece of lettuce, the steak and some soft onion was a real disappointment.Thank goodness the piece of steak was tender and cooked well. Apart from that saving grace the result would be one star. Such a shame as it felt like the food was rushed and no care taken. We have eaten there before and enjoyed it much more.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-15 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Planned to go to Boomerang (grrr, Boomarang??)on a Friday evening. Made online reservationists just in case. Heard nothing, so made a follow up phone call and confirmed our reservations. We do not live anywhere near Robertson Quay so getting here was quite a trek. Hindsight, believe or not, should have driven.Finally get to Robertson Quay and we are dodging gobs of free range dogs and kids roaming about the area. Gobs! Clearly this is a very family friendly part of town. Show up to the restaurant on time. There is no record of our reservation. Kind of bugs me, but only kind of. The place is about half full so no big deal. We are seated. There is indoor outdoor seating, a nice sized well stocked bar area and tons of TVs playing a variety of sports. Another plus is the restaurant sits alongside the waterway and you can watch the tourist boats gliding by. Aside from the reservation snafu, service was really top notch. We ordered our food and it was out within ten minutes. The waitress was really great. She was very attentive.Our starters were the kangaroo sliders. And a side order of garlic bread. Sliders were very good. We ordered rare and they were rare. After the sliders, the rest of our dinner was okay to not good.. I ordered the fish and chips. It included a little salad. The dish was good. The fish was nicely  fried. But the plate that was used was too small so fries were constantly falling onto the table. My companion ordered the lamb. He got a much larger plate, weird, since his portion was smaller. Lamb was very tough and flavorless. We decided to pass on dessert.All in all our experience was okay. I now realize It might have been a better experience for my partner and I if we approached Boomerang as a pub and not a restaurant. So on our next visit (via cab) maybe do a Tuesday trivia, stick with the bar menu, and let loose! Hopefully darting children will be safely tucked into bed as I stumble home.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-15 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: I pass by this place often but until recently have avoided this magnet for boisterous salmon-tinted overfeds reeking of beer.I finally went and was pleasantly surprised.  My husband and I went on a date and put our well-behaved kids at a table on the other side of the restaurant.  It's a good venue for decent Westernized food.  If I had endless resources and extremely high metabolism, I'd come here more often, because the atmosphere right by the river watching the Australian Football League and people watching can be fun, and the food is tasty.  However, I don't, and the food here is pricey.  It's typical bar fare priced at about $40-$50/head.  My small tumbler-sized margarita was $20.  The service is not impolite but just indifferent.Note that the kids meals are only appropriate if your children don't really eat.  They are tiny.  It's like one of those "Where's the beef?" commercials.  Hamburgers are sliders.  Each of my kids needed to get a whole 'nother meal after their kids meals.  Six people - I only had a salad, 4 kids meals, 2 pork cutlets, a margarita and 2 beers, 3 lava cakes = $200+ with kids leaving saying: "We're still starving!"

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-15 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: A friend of mine wanted to hit this place up because she wanted to bring her dog out to spend the day with us. I liked how it was an out door kind of place with a good view of the Quay. It wasn't quite western so it was in line with my pact to not eat anything I can find in the US. So, when I saw that there was a Kangaroo meat pizza it was a bit intriguing. Why not? I had never had it before and the rest of the menu seemed run of the mill American esque.  It was the most disappointing thing I ate the entire trip. It was small slivers of meat on each slice. The only good thing was the buttery flakey dough. My chai latte had way too much milk. I wish the service was nicer or at least a bit more cheerful. Rather they acted like the customers were an inconvenience. Should have picked a better profession if this were the case! Eh, at least the company and conversation made the day good.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-15 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Boomerang featured prominently in a list of top kid-friendly brunch spots in Singapore...Perhaps after being featured among such august company, the restaurant decided not to bother anymore, because the effort was seriously lacking at brunch one sunny, Singaporean Sunday...The harassed wait staff managed to weave around shimmying, speedy scamps while completely ignoring our requests for condiments and unapologetically refusing to replace an incorrectly entered entree.  (Frankly, I'm not sure how you justify this when you have two open face melts with the same name)...Our vegetarian friend was left staring aghast at an open face turkey melt...The only saving graces were the wonderful company and the lovely, riverfront setting...and at least my eggs were served over medium as ordered...PARTING THOUGHT: For an Australian restaurant, there weren't many Aussie options on the menu...

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-15 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: My 'go to' place in Singapore when you do not want to miss out on any sport from back home.  Multitude of screens for watching all Australian sports live.  When not watching sport location and view over Robertsaon Quay is excellent.Food is generally good.  Last time I was there the ribs were supurb.  Only suggestion would be to introduce a better choice of boutique beers like a nice IPA!

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-15 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Decent morning brunch menu, with multiple options. Chose the vegetarian omelette with long black coffee and was not disappointed.  Nice ambience along the river and staff was reasonably efficient. A little hard to find for visitors, but overall a nice experience.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-15 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Very good coffee. Great atmosphere for brunch and dinner. Food generally high quality. Can be very busy but I find the staff very attentive and helpful. Nice range of dishes. Perfect spot for watching sports with some friends. Right on the river so nice ambience. I go here all the time and quality is consistent. Only reason I didn't give 5 stars is it is very very expensive. 10 bucks for a mug of coffee is nuts even for Singapore. But it is superb coffee..

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-15 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: The food here was way below my expectations.  We had the pancakes which were too thick and dry and the french toast which was way too sweet for me.  The fresh squeezed orange juice was good, hence why the review is 2 stars and not one.  I would avoid this restaurant for breakfast .

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-15 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: An australian pub directly at the Singapore river. Happy hour from 7 to 10. And on Wednesday one of my favorites: Burger and beer, for 22 dollar. Last time I tried the Kangaroo burger. The meat is a little bit dry dispite medium doneness, but with the served topping it is really delicous. So you can sit here in nice atmosphere, watching some rugby other other sports stuff on the flatscreens and simply have a good time.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-15 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Boomerang featured prominently in a list of top kid-friendly brunch spots in Singapore...Perhaps after being featured among such august company, the restaurant decided not to bother anymore, because the effort was seriously lacking at brunch one sunny, Singaporean Sunday...The harassed wait staff managed to weave around shimmying, speedy scamps while completely ignoring our requests for condiments and unapologetically refusing to replace an incorrectly entered entree.  (Frankly, I'm not sure how you justify this when you have two open face melts with the same name)...Our vegetarian friend was left staring aghast at an open face turkey melt...The only saving graces were the wonderful company and the lovely, riverfront setting...and at least my eggs were served over medium as ordered...PARTING THOUGHT: For an Australian restaurant, there weren't many Aussie options on the menu...

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-15 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: One of my favorite places in Singapore around Robertson Quay area.  Lots of seatings, tons of TV to watch rugby (go All Blacks!), fans (all seats are outdoor or open air) and lots of friendly people everywhere.  Why only 3 stars?  Their food needs little more improvements!

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-15 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Boomarang (why they insist on spelling it incorrectly, I don't know) is one of my favorite places to come for a nice, relaxing evening. The food is good, the service is friendly, and they have happy hour. The food is a little pricey, but pretty standard for the area. But the food is very good. The Wagyu burger is pretty great, and comes with beets in it. You can add a fried egg and bacon for a bit extra. I was happy to find that the fries that came with the burger were good also. For lunch, they have a lunch special for $12. It involves a sandwich and soup which is really good. The sandwich menu changes weekly depending on what's in season and what the chef feels like making, so there's always something new to try.  Happy hour is weekdays 5pm - 8pm and weekends 2pm - 8pm. They also have some weekly events. Tuesday is trivia night. Wednesdays is beer and burger night where their great wagyu burgers + a beer is $25 and also pint night ($10 for a pint).

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-15 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: I ate here for dinner one night and it was pretty decent. Not a place I would come back to though, as there are better places around the River Valley area in my opinion. I had the calamari and the mezze platter which was good enough but nothing fantastic. A bit overpriced actually I thought, for the quality of the food. The crowd is mainly expats, lots of Aussies and people who live around the area. Its a nice enough ambience, overlooking the river.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-15 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: This was an unexpectedly pleasant place for a lazy sunday brunch. Along a stretch of Robertson Quay that's better known for coming to life at night.My fiance and I have a standard brunch habit - we almost always order salmon poached eggs and pancakes. They didn't have salmon and poached eggs in their menu but I requested that the eggs benedict be replaced with a salmon and they accommodated it just fine, no need to pay extra, etc. Just for kicks, we also ordered the huevos rancheros - that's what mexicans have for brunch and its made of scrambled eggs, refried beans, salsa, avocado and crispy tortillas. The avocados needed abit of salt but otherwise I really enjoyed this dish! Just dump everything on the crispy tortilla and enjoy the mini mexican party in your mouth. The poached eggs and salmon were scrumptious and satisfying. The pancakes were generous but we've had better. Overall, we left as happy campers and all set for the rest of the lazy sunday...Final verdict: Just like a boomerang, I'll definitely be back.

After walking around the ION dining hall, I found Ya Kun Cafe and wanted to share a combo meal with my parents.I ordered the kaya butter toast set which came with the perfectly crisp toast slathered in generous amounts of butter and kaya jam, soft boiled eggs, and kopi range. I also added two more cups of a la carte coffee for my parents.I was glad to only order one value set to share between three people. It was just the right amount for a perfect afternoon snack. The kaya toast was absolutely delicious; super aromatic, buttery, and sweet. Super addictive and definitely not health conscious. Kopi was a little sweet with some condensed or evaporated milk but it was strong enough to help tone down the sweetness of the toast. Soft boiled eggs were pretty bland so there's white pepper and light soy sauce on the side. Overall, I was really glad to have tried Ya Kun Cafe and some of the most well-known Singaporean staples. Highly recommend!

To be honest, I am initially quite skeptical of the place. I always thought hawker centre / coffee shop chicken rice would be the best and most authentic. So when I know there is a restaurant selling chicken rice, I'm like meh... Just another overpriced chicken rice store to cheat the ang-mohs money...However, I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of the food. For the chicken rice, the rice itself is actually tasty and flavourful, not too oily. The chicken is fresh, sweet and tender.It is also nice that they serve a variety of other foods. Thos that I have tried include the Tofu, Pork Ribs, Kang Kong, Fried Egg. All of which are of pretty above average standard. So, honestly, if I am around town and want some good chinese food, this is where I will go!  :)

Jew Kit is relatively new to Killiney Road and I added it to Yelp last night during our visit. We thought we'd grab something after watching a movie in the theatre because it was late and neither one of us wanted to cook. The service was prompt, but they did not understand a lot of the questions we were asking. For example, what is the difference between the large and small sweet and sour pork. The food was good, but it was definitely a paleo cheat. We probably won't head back because there is not a lot on the menu that works for our diet, but I do recommend the Jew Kit for others looking for decent Chinese in the Somerset area.

New kid on the block. Very nice addition to Killiney Road. Many choices here but this one is special because of the charming atmosphere, exceeded expectations and great service. Each time we come by we are pleasantly surprised trying something new. The chicken rice comes in 7 variations, but there are other choices and they are all good. For those who don't read chinese, menus are also in English. In the day it's somewhat dimly lit, but always just right. Being further down the street than Kopitiam and the other busy shops, the street is quieter.

When basic meals averaged 20+ Sing dollars (16.00 USD), it was refreshing to find a daily go to meal for a very affordable 5 Sing dollars. The basic staple known as "Chicken Rice" in Singapore, (Hainanese Chicken, everywhere else) Jew Kit offered the best quality for your money.  The portions are ample, the soup broth is flavorful, and the Kai lan in oyster sauce with fried garlic garnish were all simply fantastic!This place would have received 5 stars if it weren't for one event near closing time we were served subpar chicken.  It was caked and coated with a clear gelatin.  Perhaps they refrigerated the day's left over roasts and served it with the chicken stock morphing into a gelatinous goo from being chilled?All in all, it was our "go to" stall for Chicken Rice when we lived near Killiney Road.

This is a really cute and cheap place to grab some Chinese food on Killiney road. I've visited a couple times, once by myself and once with my partner. The first time I visited, we ordered a large sweet and sour pork, the thai style chicken, and sweet potato with plum powder. The sweet and sour pork was about average and tasty enough- it was a little over fried and the sauce was good but nothing new or exciting. The large portion is good for sharing or for one person who is particularly hungry. My partner ate mostly the thai style chicken and in my opinion, it was tastier and better value than the sweet and sour pork. I ordered the sweet potatoes out of curiosity and by the time it came out (it came out after our entrees) both of us were pretty full. It tasted like extra-sweet and tangy sweet potato fries. A good starter if you enjoy sweet potatoes. I've also had one of their chicken rice sets and it was delightful. The chicken was tender and flavorful, and the rice was absolutely delicious but not too oily. I'm not overly familiar with chicken rice so I can't say how it stacks up to other places in the city, though. I ordered an iced coffee to go with it and it was a little on the small side, but up to snuff with other local kopi places. It was a substantial and very thrifty lunch. Service was meager but polite and quite unobtrusive. The interior of the restaurant is very cozy and retro- great for a quick meal alone or with friends! Definitely worth checking out if you're in the area.

Average food in taste. Not bad, not excellent. I think thai style chicken chop rice is nice. The black hor fun noodle is too basic so I don't recommend at all. The venue is cute with old novelty decoration spread around.
My regular stop for chicken rice! Quick, tasty, fresh food and beverages. Easy to get a table and service. The Lovely set is a good deal.

I probably eat their chicken rice too often. It's not the best chicken rice ever, but it is decent and under $5. If you're in the neighborhood and would like to grab something quick, cheap, and yummy, I would suggest the chicken rice from this place. I felt adventurous once and ordered the beef hor fun and it was disgusting. Back to the chicken rice!

address: 8 Grange Rd #01-03,Cathay Cineleisure Orchard Singapore 239695 Singapore
comment: Ramen Keisuke is a well known ramen chain by Chef Keisuke Takeda in Singapore and origins from Japan. It starts with an outlet in Millenia Walk. Currently there are 11 outlets in Singapore with Ramen Keisuke Kani King which opened in March 2016 being the latest. Every outlet is different and has its own signature ramen dish. The new 40-seater restaurant specialises in Mr. Keisuke Takeda's new creation, Crab Broth Ramen. In Ramen Keisuke Kani King, instead of using pork base which is commonly used, Mr Takeda uses specially imported swimming crabs and chicken bones to create the creamy base for Crab Broth Ramen with Rich Soup whereas for Crab Broth Ramen with Clear Soup, it will be a mixture of crabs, special blended herbs and vegetables and subsequently simmered down for hours to retain the distinct seafood flavour in the soup base.The restaurant was decorated in a colorful and bright way.On the table, besides the menu, there was an order list and a bowl of sesame seeds to ground. One could select the strength of the soup base, the texture of the noodle and optional items in the ramen dish.One used the grounded sesame seeds to add flavour to the ramen dish.It was thoughtful of the restaurant to provide baskets to put the bags in.There is various condiments such as vinegar, table salt, soyu, chilli oil and mayonnaise on the table to help yourself to.Remember to help yourself to the free flow of marinated bean sprouts and Niru cabbage garlic which were avaiable on the table. The cabbage was bland but crunchy in texture.Don't forget to help yourself to the flow free of hard boiled eggs too.KANI TAMA Ramen ($13.90++)Crab Broth with Mixed Fried OmeletThe omelette was filled with crabstick, sliced mushroom and spring onions. The soup base was rich and creamy with full of crab flavours, although it was a bit too salty towards the bottom. I did not miss the cha siew or the flavoured egg which were commonly found in ramen dishes.Overall the food was good and very filling, with so much free flow side dishes to fill up oneself. Service was fast and smooth. By the way there was also free wifi available at this outlet.

address: 8 Grange Rd #01-03,Cathay Cineleisure Orchard Singapore 239695 Singapore
comment: I love ramen. And Mr. Takeda's ramen places stood out pretty much above the rest. I'm always a fan of his amazingly creative ideas for ramen! I love his rich broth ramen that's really really good to me but for some people it could be quite overwhelming. However, Keisuke Kani King  offers a totally new concept of ramen (apart from the other new and unique keisuke lobster king at Clarke Quay) which is very refreshing as the tonkotsu ramen trend is slowly dying and that's what makes it different from other tonkotsu-based ramen restaurants. This place is such a haven for seafood lovers like me, crabs in particular! But! Don't expect a whole crab on your ramen because the only main thing that's really really crabby is the broth. I am a souphead and obviously I went crazy with the super rich and tantalizing crab broth! We ordered two types of ramen (there are 4 styles):Crab broth ramen with rich soup ($15.9)So creamy and delicious as expected! It's like a mixture of pork, crab and chicken base altogether.Spicy crab broth ramen ($14.9)The rich soup one is delicious but this is the BOMB! I usually avoid spicy/hot food but THIS has got to be the only one that I'd eat! Just looking at the soup color is enough to make you salivate real bad! It's soooo rich, tasty, and the hotness is just right. I'll be back to try the Crab Tsukemen a.k.a dipping noodles (I used to love Menya Musashi's tsukemen in black soup when the quality was still good).Note: they provide free flow delicious nira cabbage garlic in addition to beansprout and eggs here. Also, they close at 2 AM, fyi.

address: 8 Grange Rd #01-03,Cathay Cineleisure Orchard Singapore 239695 Singapore
comment: Pro: - nice texture of noodle- decent price - basket to put bags and belongings- brothCon:- no other side dishes other than gyoza
Good food and nice staff. We had kuftah kebab with saffron rice, delicious and good size portion. We also had hummus on the house which was a nice touch.

What do u think about a restaurant you spend 1 hour walking and transportation to reach it and then they say to you.. sorry we don't have the capacity to serve you please wait 40 minutes Looked inside and saw a couple of tables only...What??

Located on the less lively, but more charming stretch of Robertson Quay, across the river from Warehouse Hotel. As in the stereotype, sun-loving western customers dine outside, with a pleasant view of the river. Heat-fearing Asians prefer the comfort of aircon, although the dining room is soulless. One might question the logic of combining Indian and Lebanese food: The chef is Indian, but lived in the Middle East for 20+ years. He must be overworked, for the food takes a long time to come out, and also in random fashion: bread was served a full 10 minutes after the hummus; our two neighbours both had steak frites, but one order came out 5 minutes after the other. An order of pappadum never showed up. When the food does appear though, it does taste good and authentic - delicious pita bread, scrumptious hummus, well-marinated kebab and lamb chops. The Indian dishes served at another table look appetising. Polite albeit not terribly pro-active wait staff.
Didn't have food but wanted a cold beer, price was good @ 2 beers for S$14.  Nice and cold and on the river!

Artisan Boulangerie Co. is a fun cafe style restaurant that offers an interesting blend of drinks and/or quick meals. For those of you who know Killiney Road you know that there are a number of coffee houses and cafes in this area. Many of them are outdoor or open air cafes. That's great if you wish to embrace the elements but if you want to sit in air conditioned comfort this is the place for you. The food here is as you would expect. They offer numerous bakery items and quick meals like various egg-based dishes for breakfast and salads and sandwiches for later in the day. Of course, they do a great job on their lattes and various other coffee-based drinks.The seating is nice here. The staff is friendly and helpful. Overall, it is a great place to grab a quick meal or sit back with some coffee, cruise the internet, or talk with friends.

I'm not sure why I didn't wander into this restaurant sooner since it's so close. Paleo? They sure make it easy to follow the lifestyle. Their menu features salads and meats with veggie sides in addition to the typical bakery delights. Good luck avoiding the breads and pasteries...they look delicious! So far, I've had the beetroot, pumpkin and feta salad (skip the feta for the Paleo folks), and it was awesome. Very fresh. I've also sampled their omelet with peppers, mushrooms and ham, which was also good. My favorite so far is their peri peri chicken ($22) because it couldn't be more Paleo with seasoned, grilled chicken breasts and veggies. Don't love too much spice? They put most of the sauce on the side. In the Killiney Road area and looking for something healthy? This would be my first recommendation. I'd go here daily if it was a bit less expensive!

Ok. I think this bread is a little overkill for a sandwich like this. I can see why this place is popular with the selection of foods. Even the venue feels more comfortable to the neighboring Real Food. Espresso is average and drinkable but lower than I would like. They have my favorite drink. Abc juice. I like this place although I'll probably walk the extra 5 min for the better espresso.Update. The espresso was good today. Hmm maybe the previous was a fluke. I have to try again

I live down the street from here, so I cant believe this place has been open for over a month and i didn't notice... Until yesterday, when i happened to walk down this way after coming back from town. Anyway, i came here for lunch so i didn't try the pastries (next time!).I had their roasted chicken sandwich, which was more like a baguette since that's what they used instead of soft bread. This was simple and really good! I don't normally finish the bread part of sandwiches in my feeble attempt to save some carbs, but i definitely gobbled up every last crumbs of this sandwich. The baguette is actually what makes it delicious, it's laced with different types of nuts and seeds which gives it that nice crunchy texture and savory flavor. I do feel the price is steep for just a simple baguette though. It was $11.80, I think i would have been more ok if it was $8-9.I got a long black and, like other reviewers, was disappointed. I expected such place to serve quality coffee, but it tasted like the coffee brewed in my office pantry and costed $4.80. I'll go somewhere else for my caffeine kick next time.They also have a brunch menu from 8am - 2pm!

My husband and I tried this for breakfast one morning. It's different than restaurants in the US because you order at the counter, pay, then they bring it to you. My husband had a ham, sausage, and pepper omelet and an iced mocha and I had the Eggs Benedict with ham. The food was all delicious and the service was fantastic.

Decent place for breakfast if you live in the area. Food is consistently good although on the pricier side (compared to the other breakfast joints on this street). They have lunch/dinner menu as well.

I cherry picked my pastries based on visual-appeal. I swept sweet bakes like Vanilla & Raisin Swirl $3.50 & Orange Brioche off the shelve, and the former wins slightly but with low marks. The Danish presented in burnt rims, has a notable buttery flavor but not rich enough to remember. The sweet glaze blend gently with the flaky pastry partnering some scattered candies raisins. I wasn't really impressed with the taste, just mediocre.The Orange Brioche $5.00, was weaker in taste. It didn't sing any buttery tune like other artisanal brioche, no signs of flakiness and rather dry in its texture. There was a small helping of citrus scented custard piped in the middle of the dough, mildly sweet. The orange fruit slice hindered my chewing - simply aesthetically pleasing on the the sweet bread.The Madeleine $2.00/pc, was a decent piece. Not exceedingly sweet with a soft interior. I'd prefer it to be served warm like db Moderne Bistro so that I could taste the rich buttery structure in its comforting warmth. This one was left in the open, atop the pastry glass cabinet, side-by-side the Financiers. Obviously, it has been overpriced.The Kumara & Bleu Tart $6.00/pc, champ the fleet in my whole selection when its rivals failed to compete well. The soft and crumbly tart shell adapted quite well to the sweet orange-pigmented kumara cubes gelled together in a pool of coagulated cheese - buttery rich and very delightful. Noticeable flavor is seen coming from the flaky tart, less from the filling.The battle field continues to be less interesting when the limping Roast Chicken Sandwich $11.50, hit the ground. The fillet slices were dry and fibrous, no traces of flavor until my taste buds met up with the sweet onion chutney above the fresh lettuce. The hard-like-rock baguette made things worst, it was a total shame!When I thought nothing will be praised, I was charmed by the healthier fare, $8.50 - Quinoa & Lentil Salads. The power grains are executed in perfection along with a mixture of soft lentil which is often undercooked. Carefully seasoned with the right amount of tang lending from the balsamic reduction and some sweet hints from the fresh apple slices, the rehydrated dried cranberry fruits, the heap of rocket greens woke my taste buds with a striking saltiness from the accompanying shaven Parmesan. Just as the episode starts to climax, I felt a cold gush of water came splashing down - the 2 sesame rolls that served alongside was rockier & rubbery than the earlier baguette! What's happening to the breads here? I let out a heavy sigh!

Saw a friend check in on Facebook and it sounded interesting, so I dragged my companion for the day on Sunday to give this place a try.The decor's real fancy, and the entrance felt more like I was entering a bank than a bakery. The theme continues, with a lot of glitzy and posh throughout the place.We had a pain au chocolat (mediocre, good but not better than the other famous places like Maison Kayser or Tiong Bahru Bakery) and a raspberry tart (my companion like this but I was unimpressed).The coffee was decent, but nothing to go back for. I'd really like to try their sandwiches the next time I'm there, the breads and pretzels looked quite enticing.Overall I'm excited at this new place. It's just a ho-hum first impression taste wise, but that counter was stocked with other things I'd love to go back and try.

Finally got to try out abc and totally love the pastries, bread and coffee. The pain au chocolat or chocolate croissant is crispy on the outside, soft & light on the inside. Coffee tends to be on the nutty side (not sour and acidic like at other cafes) which is my personal preference. And the plus!! Service is good - staff smile and greet customers to start their mornings and there's a great chirpy vibe here.  I'll recommend abc!!

Value for money, taste and ambience have this place a two.  Artisan for the croissant and pastries I would agree.  Other items was either an ok or below par.  Scramble eggs was for some reason looked like they added too much milk.  So it came out a little light instead of bright yellow where it should be.  Bacon was also a disappointment.  They got good bacon but ruined by the person cooking it.  Coffee I agree with the previous reviews Luke warm.  No copy comfy hit for this Mother's Day.  Time to head back to bed!! :)

I came here to buy a loaf of bread for breakfast the next morning the evening before. Service was absolutely amazing. The staff seemed more than willing to accommodate my numerous requests and there were even bread samples! (Who says no to samples??)So i went home with a loaf of walnut sourdough. This loaf was off the hook. Each slice was filled with so many walnuts. So much that I wasn't sure if that was the case for every loaf, or if the baker had accidentally spilled a whole bag in. Anyhow, this place makes bread buying as easy as ABC. I wouldn't hesitate coming here again.

Have been here a few times. My usual is either the croissant or pain au chocolat. In my opinion based on visiting Parisian bakeries & eating thru many of NYC's best croissants, I'd have to say that ABC's croissant is better than Maison K & Tiong Bahru B. ABC's croissant is crisp on the outside and has a sound when you tap the exterior, while the inside has visible layers with a soft interior. Today I tried the eclair which I thought was one of their signature items. It was a bit disappointing bc did not taste authentic at all. Tasted like something I'd buy from the supermarket and not up to ABC's high standards. I've also had lattes a few times and noticed that the temperature was bordering warm to lukewarm. C'mon ABC, I know you can do better! :)

Fab decor and ambience but pastries are a bit meh. Came in on a Saturday for brunch and place was buzzing. The staff are all quite young, perhaps that's why they're all bustling very busily to little effect. Tried the boeuf bourguignon pie - dug in and found peas and potato. Perfectly ok but that's not boeuf bourguignon so they should just label it a beef pie lah. Have to say they're very generous with the beef and the chunks were tender, not chewy. Good quality balsamic on the accompanying salad.  The portobello sandwich had generous stuffing of well seasoned portobello, but it was cold. Would be much better warm. The chocolate croissant wasn't buttery enough although it was ok. Chocolate eclair wasn't too sweet but again ok, no great shakes. Best thing was a lemon curd tart with a bracingly tangy curd - but then again I can make lemon curd, so um not blown away. Long black coffee tasted a little sour like it'd been percolating a while so I'd advise coffee aficionados to go for the lattes and mochas which have to be made fresh.

The ambience, decor and gorgeous display of baked goods and pastries was what attracted me to ABC @ Somerset when I first stumbled across it. I had the latte and it was good. Subsequent visits to the Somerset and Asia Square outlets were really disappointing. I really wanted to like this place but the bread and pastries here are not worth the effort. On one visit I bought a loaf of bread after asking the staff to recommend one that was soft & fluffy in texture, instead it turned out to be dry and crumbly. On other visits, we have tried the pear tart, chocolate eclair (twice!), chocolate lava cake. The tart and lava cake were average, nothing to shout about. The eclair pastry was surprisingly dry and hard. I would rather pay a few more dollars to have a delicious Paul bakery eclair than waste my calories here. If you are looking for a chill out cafe to have a coffee and a chat with friends, this would be the ideal place.. But i wouldn't go out of my way to eat here again unless the quality of the food improves.

im back to try more stuff! as usual it's pretty easy to get a seat, it's not too crowded. guess this lil place has yet to be found by e masses. *shhh*1. hot chocolate : if u like milky type, this is e one for u. personally I like those which are thicker. 2. chocolate banana croissant :  I like this better than e plain croissant just cause I like the choc nana combi. 3. ABC special : came w a basket of roll which is really yummy with e butter and jam spread. it's addictive and we finished e whole basket of it. forget carbs diet! Everything else on e main plate was just OK. Sunny side up + bacon + salad + shrooms. Next time ill just stick to their pastries!yes its as easy as ABC. like it? come again!
Their bread is tasty, but pastries and drinks a bit too sweet. When it's crowded service quite slow. Also somewhat overpriced.

I frequent the new-ish one on Killiney but know of the others.  It's pricey, but the breads, pastries and venue are awesome!  We get a few loaves  of bread a week and sometimes I treat us to a pastry here and there.  It's like pure joy in a little package.

Bakery cafes - are relatively "new"' in the sg brunch scene. The delicious smell of freshly baked goodies and hand-crafted coffee filled the tastefully furnished cafe. I tried the almond croissant, chocolate banana croissant and blueberry tart. All were really yummy. Fantastic for breakfast / brunch and tea!

When everything else in Great World City is overcrowded and it's a 20-minute wait for a table, Al Dente Pronto is the perfect place to go if you want good, reliable food and a great choice of seats and tables!The Chicken Carbonara was the main that I got - portion size? Check. Taste? Double-check. Served in a nice porcelain (not sure about that) dish were big chicken chunks and al dente (aha!) pasta with a lovely cream sauce... but they left the peas out. Hmm.That aside, the hazelnut gelato ($4) was to die for. Probably not made with Nutella (the easy way out for most ice creameries), each scoop was chock-full with nutty goodness, and there were about 8 whole hazelnuts - wow!Definitely worth a return trip if I'm back in the area and need some dessert. They also had a rather impressive breakfast menu ($7 for Eggs Benedict)! But they stop serving at 11.30 am. Might give that a shot as well.

Overall a pretty decent Indian restaurant in Rob quay. We started off with the tandoori platter which has chicken malai tikka, prawn tandoori, fish tikka and lamb seekh. Was great value for money and the kebabs were on point mostly.For mains we had the butter chicken and saag paneer. By Singapore standards they were both pretty good. Their cocktails are interesting takes on modern cocktails with an Indian twist.The ambience reminds us of many Mumbai places and the service is great. Overall would recommend!

The energetic and charming Michelle is no longer there, but the good is still excellent. Moist murgh tandoori and great curries are deeply satisfying. Be prepared to sweat, especially as there is no aircon.

I've been here 2 times, and both times I've had a great experience with excellent food and good service. The staff is friendly and attentive and happy to make menu suggestions. The atmosphere is great for dates, groups, and families. The food is so good! The veggie platter is a favorite, along with the saag paneer and samosas with veggies and the Tamarind Rita. Will definitely be coming back!
Good food. Nice ambience. Great music. Dabba Gohst to die for. Unique is Baileys Kulfi.

Tasty food served by friendly staff!  We ordered chicken tikka masala, tandoori chicken, smoked eggplant, mixed salad, cheese naan and roti.  All the dishes were properly spiced, chicken dishes were moist and flavorful, and atmosphere was welcoming.  Ginger lassi complimented the meal perfectly and was a nice change from the usual mango.  Looking forward to going back.

address: 11 Unity St #02-14, Robertson walk Singapore Singapore
comment: This gem is hidden in a slightly out of sight area of robertson quay on the second floor. I had intended to come here for sake on a sunday afternoon but I soon realised that every Japanese izakaya is closed in the afternoon on sundays as i walked about.I had a beer else where and decided to make my way back after 6pm when it was opened for a quick and small bite to eat and ordered a bottle of sake. I noticed that all the service staff are really japanese and asked to recommend me a sake which is on the sweeter side, as thats what I prefer in my sake. I pointed to something else but he pointed out an alternative (for the same price, didn't try to up sell and THAT is important to me) which he thought that I might like. He was right! I took a sip and he looked at me hoping he was right. lol quite hilarious. I said, "Yes tastes great!" He put on a sigh of relief and smiled.I ordered a wooden plate of uni, chutoro and grilled hotate to compliment my Sake. All of it were so good and fresh and didn't break the bank!I got a little bit greedy after awhile and ordered a sashimi set for another $19 (because it also comes with Uni and i wanted more uni!). No complaints except that the rice was plain japanese rice and could have been vinegared sushi rice. 3 things stood out for me. The quality and prices of the chutoro, the sake and the uni. I will definitely be back for these 3 things!

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: The Book Cafe20 Martin RoadThere is a diversified range of reading materials available- several hundred local and foreign books, magazines and newspapers are available.Several couches indoors. Quite a lot of outdoor seats.There is wireless Internet access and also electrical power-points. Easy street-side parking right in front of the café.All-day breakfast.Egg RoyaleToasted English muffin + maple bacon (none today so replaced with usual bacon) + grilled tomatoes + baby spinach + poached eggs + hollandaise sauce + rotating potato - goodClassic Cheese BurgerGrilled beef patty + cheese + tomato slices + lettuce + caramelised onions on a toasted burger bun + fries - nice & juicyCalamansi Ice coffee

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: Book cafe is a wonderful place if you are looking for a pressure free place to read or get some work done. There is free WiFi, good coffee and desserts, as well as substantial food items  (though I personally haven't tried them).I had the iced latte and lemon pie both of which were sizeable and tasty. There is plenty of seating both indoor and outdoor  (with fans) for customers to stay however long.I will be back to try the food!

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: Moseyed on into this cafe by chance from walking around the Quay. First impression stepping inside was the quietness of the place for a Sunday evening. One can get some serious work, reading or chill time accomplished in here. Sofa seating seemed cozy and inviting. Did I mention reading? As the cafe's name eludes to, there is a very large inventory of reading material for one's perusal. Free and fast WiFi (perhaps I visited when patrons weren't streaming). Order cheese cake slices and a flat white. Cheese cakes had a gummy texture to the surface layer, so maybe it wasn't as fresh as I expected. The flat white was very good. Double shot from some nice dark roasted beans and some milk ... nice cup of Joe to my liking! Average cafe with an extra star for stacks of reading material, less a star for mediocre cheese cakes.

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: I visited for brunch on a Saturday morning. The place wasn't full which was great, if you're looking for a place where you can have a conversation without shouting. At one side of the restaurant, there are couches that were perfect for relaxing with a good book. And books there were aplenty for you to browse with. The service staff were friendly and eager to please. Unfortunately, the food though decent, isn't good enough for me to specially return for it. I had the eggs blackstone (English muffin, spinach, tomatoes, eggs, rosti) and a flat white. The coffee was better than I expected - low in acidity. I was excited about the apple pie based on previous reviews, but it didn't live up to the hype. I prefer a harder crust; the filling had just the right hint of tartness and sweetness. My friend really enjoyed his chicken sandwich which he ordered based on the recommendation of another reviewer. It's a nice place to hang out with friends but if you're a picky eater, it may not live up to your expectations. Free wifi available. Toilet is very clean and orderly.

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: This isn't a cafe you come to specially for their food, but to read your book/surf net/work on your computer.There are heaps of reading materials in the interior, but we chose to sit outside. There are power outlets but you may have to fight other users for them. We got a pot of tea, coffee, pumpkin soup, and a slice of Oreo cheesecake to while the afternoon away. Wifi was a bit slow because it was crowded and it was a public holiday. On a normal day, it would probably be okay.Our food was okay, nothing special, but if you have the munchies while reading, they will be quelled.Service was prompt and our water glasses were rarely empty.

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: This place is spacious, with both tables and sofas to chill out at, whether you're working or lounging. The walls are stacked with rows of books and there are global newspapers up front. The food and drink are okay, but the ambiance is great to relax. The service is quick and snappy as well. Definite recommend.

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: Unlike those new kids on the block, The Book Cafe situated on the corner of Martin Road is a well-known, well-loved hideout for many book lovers, myself included. Throw in free fast-speed Wi-Fi, more than 10 socket plugs peppered around the place and dozens of foreign/local magazines for your reading pleasure and you have a café that is perpetually teeming with diners/readers every day of the week.Take your pick between square tables or lounge sofa seats, put up your feeds and chill-out for a few hours reading, gossiping, sipping a cuppa or whiling the time away people-watching.My fourth visit to the café saw me ordering their Traditional Apple Pie which did not disappoint at all; think soft, chewy, sweet apple bits hidden expertly within a thin, crispy, sugary crust with streaks of chocolate sauce on the side. I didn't order drinks this time as I came on a full stomach but on my previous visits, their Flat White left quite a good impression on me too.Packed with weekenders in casual wear during weekends and with businessmen on weekdays, The Book Café comes highly recommended if you're in the Havelock Road area and looking for a good place to recharge (self and electronics alike).

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: A really nice coworking spot. There's plenty of tables inside and out, and a living room with couches if you're feeling more in Kindle mode.The coffee is good, but unremarkable given the high quality of Singapore coffee options, including Toby's Estate nearby.The food is pretty fantastic though; the Eggs Blackstone has a wonderful hollandaise and... maple bacon.

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: Just like any reviewed place, it depends on the time that one makes their visit. I've come to The Book Cafe several times before and most of the times in the past, it has been relatively crowded.  However, tonight, on a Wednesday evening at about 6:45pm, it is relatively quiet.  In fact, a lot of the sofas are still unoccupied. But that's probably about to change as some people come here for dinner, dessert, or drinks. This is the kind of cafe to come, relax and chill for awhile.  Half of the cafe space is simply an enclave of comfy sofas and shelves of magazines and books.  This is the kind of place you expect to spend at least an hour or two, or three...The prices are mid-range but that is to be expected, given the location.  It's walking distance from Robertson Quay, with its fancy restaurants and bars.  The Book Cafe offers a nice ambience for personal time; and even if you come with someone, you are able to each do your own thing while sitting comfortably side-by-side. This is on the short list of "must-visit" cafes in Singapore.

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: Cute, cozy bookstore located in Robertson Quay. I always walk past this cafe on the way to Orangetheory Fitness, with people constantly being seen inside. I was able to try this cafe after seeing it a multitude of times, and the cozy exterior indeed is reflected inside. The cafe offers different types of cafe food like sandwiches, all-day breakfast options, and pasta/asian foods after 11am. I ordered the Emmentaler omelet, which came with eggs, lean bacon, tomatoes, avocado and sour cream, and toast. I got the whole grain toast, and it was a very generous serving with butter and jam. The omelet was very thick and the stronger taste of the cheese accompanied the bacon very nicely. It was a good portion for brunch. The prices were typical of the area, my omelet was $20 SGD and most of the brunch dishes were similarly priced. The desserts and drinks looked really good as well, and I hope to come back to try their pasta. Most of all, the ambience is what makes it really worth coming here, and many people come here to study/read creating a fusion of restaurant/coffeeshop vibes. It gets really busy in the weekend mornings, with people tending to hang out it can be frustrating to get a seat.

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: I must spend way to much time looking at Google Maps because when I discovered this place I knew that I had to check it out (especially being such a book nerd). All I can say is that it's reputation certainly lives up to its name with large bookshelves inside covered in books, as well as a number of covers of Lolita on one of the walls. I came here for breakfast (I simply wasn't interested in breakfast at my hotel, even though it was probably included in the price) and I must admit that it was pretty good, and the coffee wasn't all that bad either. This is one of those places that I could easily spend a few hours in every morning with a hot cup of tea and a nice book. The also have an outdoor section, though a part of that is a smoking area, though why would one want to sit outside when you can sit inside with all the marvellous books.

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: This place has a major fruit fly issue. Flies on my food, in my drink, just buzzing around everywhere. Had to go up to the counter to get served even though I was sat at a table with a menu. My avocado sandwich contained no avocado. Found a needle??? In the sofa. I was looking for a comfortable, chill place to study, unfortunately this wasn't it.

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: I'll admit I'm biased because I love anything book related.Let me try to be objective though.Came in on a Sunday for brunch (today, actually)Had smoked salmon set sans the salmon, because vegetarian. Flat white. Long black. My friend had the smoked salmon set and vouched for the edibility of the salmon, hot cocoa, and we shared a French toast set. Food was great, waiting time was Long, even though the place was not crowded. Worth the wait though. Price is average for cafes. Decent portion size.Music is old fashioned jazz-ish music. Not loud enough for me, but then again, to each their own. Service was great. Attentive, friendly, non-judgy even though my half-asleep brain asked weird questions about the menu. Bright enough for study/work/reading. They also have a great selection of books to read. If you're so inclined, it's a great place to transition from coffee to wine/beer. All in all, an experience I wouldn't mind repeating the next time I have an itch to be outside on a Sunday.

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: My favorite local spot in Singapore. On a few occasions I spent about 4 continuous hours here working and studying. The staff is wonderful. I am always greeted with a friendly smile. The lemon pine nut pie (available only on fridays and weekends) is to die for. The flavors compliment each other so well and the presentation is beautiful. The eggs Royale and eggs Blackstone are also solid dishes to try here. The dragonfruit and pear juice is my personal favorite drink here. The iced Carmel latte also delicious on a hot day (which is literally every day in Singapore). Very unpretentious. I definitely recommend this spot.

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: BREAKFAST/LUNCH:- eggs w/ bratwurst (~$15)- turkey, avocado, & egg white sandwich (~$15)FOOD: Simple. Consistent. Tasty. There's no mystery behind the menu here. They serve breakfast, salads, sandwiches, and entrees catered to the cafe crowd. They also have a lengthy tea and coffee selection. I came here for breakfast 3 days straight, and it's very satisfying. Food is well-seasoned and portions are appropriate. AMBIANCE: I like it because they don't try to hard. The place embodies the calming neighborhood vibe. There's a section with couches if you want to wind down for you drink/eat, and an outdoor seating area as well. I stayed for a couple hours on Sunday to work, and they were very accommodating. PRICE: Very reasonable all things considered. You can get a proper breakfast/meal + coffee for right around $20. OVERALL: Highly recommend this place to anyone living in the Robertson Quay area. Singapore in general could use a few more of these neighborhood joints. PS: +0.5 stars for doing takeaway

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: I feel like its name suits this place, as it's rather fortuitously decked out as a sanctuary to catch up on those eponymous founts of knowledge - or let's be honest, random laptopping - with the food incidental to the experience.not that the food is bad, but I just don't feel like that's the raison d'etre of this place. to be fair - it's all pretty decent. my pancakes were just about fluffy enough, with a dash of powdered sugar and sliced fruit; eggs benedict as you'd expect, with flowy yolks and a rather cute addition of a latke; and an unphotographed order of cereal was a rather out-the-box execution of muesli, generic sweetened vanilla yogurt and milk.so it's all edible, but not exactly travel-worthy.the calm of the place is more than worth it though. it's hidden away in the outskirts of robertson quay (as though our red dot is large enough to quantify for this term), and almost completely rid of any hipsters - money can't buy that second part these days. it's not cool so much as cozy, with a smart layout of sofas at the back and traditional table-and-chairs in front, as well as the books and magazines all propped up on shelves everywhere.get a coffee, and some food - support these people please - and while away your afternoon. it's like being home, without actually being home.

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: Nice place. You will feel very relax in here. You can take time to read many books and magazines. The food is normal, not bad. If you want to find a cafe where give you relax feeling and long chart with you love and friends. Here will be your choice...

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: The Book Cafe, just another one of the lovely neighborhood cafes I will be frequenting in the Robertson quay area. The ambience of this place is very relaxing. They play some nice 50-60's old swing Motown blues, real soothing and conducive to the relaxing atmosphere.You could sit outside or inside, where I bet it's perfect to post up and do some work from home stuff. They a little living room library set up just next to the main dining area.Off the shelves are tons of magazines and periodicals for you to peruse during your stay.
