They even have my favorite, Monocle!As for food, I could only comment on breakfast as that's all I've had here the past two times. A set will set you back S$14 and that's your standard two eggs, some toast, hash browns and a meat of choice. Add in a coffee and you are looking at a little under S$20 all in.The service is very good at this place, real friendly and and attentive, but not overly.This place makes me want to come back and do some work. I may do that so i could test out the lunch specials.This will be one of my frequent neighborhood haunts!

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: It's hard to find a place in Singapore that allows you to sit and do some work. This is a very nice cafe and very friendly staff. Good WiFi until it got a bit crowded, then it slowed down a bit. Lots of power outlets. Really great eggs benedict - simple with no frills but very well made hollandaise sauce.  Had a flat white (2 actually!) that did not disappoint!

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: really well priced. service staff were cheerful and friendly. food was really good, had the scrambled eggs and whole meal toast. very cozy vibe. definitely gonna go back!

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: I sort of like this place. It's very cozy. Tons of magazines/books to peruse. Espresso is ok. That other one nearby is much better. On the dessert, I would stick to the pies which are "baked fresh daily". The others looked dropped off by some supermarket. Also another perk is the ample patio street space which is very shaded. Overall nice place.

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: 'Let's go to Book Cafe today! Awww yeah I missed that place!" It's such a cozy hang out, perfect to chill on the couch and catch up on some emails, maybe even do a little bit of work. During the weekends it can be quite packed, but nobody seems to mind sharing a couch. You gotta accept a bit of PDA though, the crowd is a combination of couple's snuggling up to each other and having brunch or a coffee together, and the other half is couples composed of a person dating a laptop.Easy going vibes with Jack Johson and Enya are playing on the background and dim  lights. The services matches the music and is slow as well. Menu is quiet extensive and there's always something that can satisfy your needs. 15 dollar for a salad and 8 dollars for a iced mocha is a bit much though, but you are paying for the ambiance and for one of limited spots on the couches.

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: This cafe was located across the street from our hotel so the location was perfect. They have an extensive menu so you can find something for everyone and a ton of books and games to keep you occupied.  The environment is very relaxed the service was great.  A good place for breakfast or a light meal.

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: I was finding a place in between 2 appointments and had no laptop or books with me. The place is unexpectedly crowded with people hitting my chairs all the time. Nonetheless the traditional lemon cake is really good. I had it with Hot Honey Lemon. Perfect combination.

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: Probably some of the warmest service I've encountered in Singapore. Maybe it's because I'm almost a regular but I swear there are a few folks who work here who make me ok with paying the Bougieville prices. The cafe is very cute on the inside and has a much more homey, approachable feel than the usual pretentiousness that frequently comes when S'pore establishments try Western fare. The food is pretty solid also making this a definite go to place to get some work done, or just hang out with a cup of coffee and a good book!

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: Pretty awesome and the vibe is real chill. Not a book fan but they got kickass sofas and it's just nice.

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: Great place to hang out and complete assignments.The coffee is all right but I came here for the ambience,and this place is perfect for lounging during the afternoon with a book to read.

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: Long-standing, well-loved cafe. Great place to read, chill, catch up plus free wifi. Decent coffee n food!

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: Just a tiny bit out of the way, but worth it.  This is a great place for breakfast when staying in the area.

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: A great place to get away from the fast pace of working life. Located near to robertson quay , this restaurant is pretty well hidden and offers customers a serene ambience to laze the afternoon.This would be an ideal place for you to chill and read a book, there's indoor and outdoor and there is a couch area indoor where you can read and dine. The shop also offers a great variety of books and magazines.I would recommend to have a set of egg benedict at the couch section, with a book to read through the afternoon, it would simply be sensational and mind refreshing.

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: I give it 2 stars for the free wifi and ambience but the service and food terrible. Took nearly an hour to get my brunch, staff running through the place as so busy. Very understaffed. My "extras" were a joke eg tomato was a single thin slice of uncooked tomato. Poached eggs overlooked and coffee good flavour but served cold, probably because they are too busy again. Use it for the wifi but avoid for anything else.expect a LONG wait.

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: Full marks for ambience, passing marks for menu, and brownie points for cheap wine. Spent quite a bit of time here one evening, and depending on the CD on repeat of the day, you can get crazies singing to Lady Gaga. Over and over again. Tres annoying. There are the studious types hunched over their laptops on the sofa, and the serious dinner crowd that prefers to sit at the proper tables. I was rather pleased with their $40 bottle of house white that was surprisingly drinkable. Would return just for this. Forget everything else edible. It's just that - forgettable. You'd be better off throwing a rock anywhere along Robertson Quay and scoring better food.

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: Book Cafe has always been one of my favorite places to hunker down with a book or a magazine with a cuppa, away from the madding crowd. I love that they are also one of the few places which serve breakfast all day.Food : Have been for brunch, dinner as well as late night coffee on different occasions, and have never once been disappointed. Have tried the pancakes and the fry up which consisted of hash brown, sausages, bacon, toast and eggs for brunch, cod and sandwiches for dinner, and last but not least, hot cocoa with marshmallows, mango smoothies and a variety of desserts i.e, apple pie, lemon and rosemary cake with Greek yogurt as well as pine nut pie (available only on weekends). Comfort cafe fare ... love it all.Service : Friendly and pleasant.Ambience : Laidback and cosy. Relaxing music. Love the sofas.Remains one of my favorite haunts.

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: Had a nice salad here & glass of wine. Very chill, free wi-fi, and friendly staff. What's not to like?

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: Hey. Lost in Singapore and looking for something a little bit "western " but not too much. The best grilled chicken sandwich I've had in years!!  Great ambiance and great wi-fi connection. Life is good. This place is great!!

address: 20 Martin Road #01-02 Seng Kee Building Singapore 239070 Singapore
comment: Another great standby - consistently great service, personable atmosphere, great food and a place to read or chill out.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-04A The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Quite a nice location near the riverside area of Robertson Quay. Saw that it was close toMy hotel and decided for a nice lunch. The service was fast and on point. The food was fresh and had a good selection of appetizers and main courses.I ordered the mozzarella ball, quite tasty. And little hard to cut with a knife. Easier to eat with your hands.I ordered the 4 cheese pizza, Quattro formagi .Was good tasting but I wish they put more gorgonzola cheese on it. I made a comment to the waiter and he would relay to the chef. Also ordered the Sicilian Cannoli for desert. Everything was well presented and had a great taste. I will defiantly visit here again on my next trip.Having to add that I keep coming back every time I am in Singapore. The food is always amazing and the atmosphere is wonderful. I have become good friends with the chefs and the owner. And their service goes above and beyond with service and great food!!!!

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-04A The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Finally a new Italian place in Robertson Quay!Amazing appetizers, of course mozzarella based, as the name stays. Got a pasta, sciagliatelli with cacio ...tasty. Good service (well, it's the first day they are open, hopefully they keep it up), slightly on the pricey side. Will be back for more mozzarella!

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-04A The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: The Robertson Quay area is full of fun spots to eat. Mozzarella Bar is a great choice especially if you like a little cheese in your diet. The outdoor seating is nice and even in humid Singapore, it was comfortable on a warm sunny day. I ate appetizers for lunch and the selection and prices were excellent. I love the Singapore Hawker Markets but when you're ready for a more standard style of food this place works great.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-04A The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: My friend and I visited DOP MB for dinner this evening, as it is close by my hotel and overlooks the quay.  Each of us ordered and ate a side salad, and we shared a Neapolitan Pizza that included anchovies.  Service was very good, with attentive and friendly staff.  Salads (I had Rocket and friend ordered Spinach) were very good and healthy serving size, which helps to explain the higher than expected price.  The pizza was another story.  Crust was golden brown at the end, but undercooked in the center.  Pizza was so salty that is was not so appetizing.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-04A The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Interesting Italian place. Servings were rather small, or else I was just very hungry. Recommend the Suppli (arancini balls). Also the linguini, any of them.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-04A The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: No kind of restaurant is more full of clichés and claims of authenticity than an Italian restaurant. Even full-on franchise Italian-American restaurants boast about their "authentic Italian origin". Unfortunately, on my experience, the more they declare their authenticity, the more tasteless the food turns out to be. The more they boast about their "ricetta de la nonna" (grandma's recipe, the cliché of clichés), the more pedestrian the recipe is.D.O.P. Mozzarella Bar is all about claiming authenticity, starting with the name. The menu itself has an introduction stating the owner's true Italian origin and how we would find "traditional", "authentic", and "pure" Italian food. When we got there (several weeks ago, I'm such a slacker with my reviews) the maitre d' immediately told us they were having some trouble with their oven so our dishes would take longer than usual to be ready. We stayed nonetheless (wine makes time fly).Our dishes came out quite promptly, in fact. We went the easy way and had risotto and ravioli. The food was really flavourful, well cooked and carefully crafted. The environment is modern and elegant, but welcoming. It has no squarely-patterned tablecloths, faded pictures of smiling people on Sicilian villages or most of the visual stereotypes Italian restaurants commonly abuse, which is highly appreciated. They even ditch the ricetta de la nonna, but substitute it for "Mama Teresa's recipe". Prices are in line with most of the Robertson Quay area (pricey, that is), but the food is truly appetising. The key, as usual, is to focus on the food and go easy on the wine. They sell high-quality cheeses and carefully selected Italian ingredients, that is a plus.D.O.P. Mozzarella doesn't need to claim and assert its Italian purity on every paragraph. The food is delightful, and that makes any appeal to tradition or righteousness irrelevant. I have no doubt the place will be a success.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-04A The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Excellent food! Starting with the complimentary bread with olive oil which is great. Then appetizers are the best (try the smoked cheese or parmigiana egg plant). I've tried a few main courses and they were really good too. Very friendly staff! Enjoy!

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-04A The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: An Italian restaurant owned by an Italian? Yeah. Why not. If you love your cheeses, your pasta, your anti-pestos, this is definitely the place to check out. They've got a selection of wines to pair with some of the finest cold cuts and cheeses. The staff is very attentive and well trained.

Good view.Food comes out quick, Drinks come out quick.Service was fine.I did not like the drinks and food was just ok.I don't like to be rushed to leave the table and it was hard to get a table and just for less than an hour.It was annoying walk for registration and check in all around the place.So I couldn't get why everyone are crazy about the place.But the view is amazing and crowd was nice too.

Walked in no reservation.  Food was good, but it felt like the servers forget about you.  One came to our table just to take a knife off our table to give to another. It was weird. It doesn't take away from the taste of the food and drinks. We ate the ceviche, guacamole, chicken tostadas, and sea bass. The food and drinks were pretty good.

Well I saw that this place was located close to my hotel. It was a great location but the place had no WiFi to check into Yelp with.I had a desire to grab some tacos for the night. Looked at the menu and ordered two beef and two Chicken.Plus ordered a side of chips and guacamole dip.Well normal Mexican food restaurants don't usually charge separate for a small helping of chips, and charge for salsa. But this place does. Since the salsa and Guacamole were the same price I went for the Guacamole $5 Singapore dollars and $5 Singapore dollars for the small bowl of chips.I also ordered a margarita.Well I got the bland chips and the blandest guacamole ever. Was really expecting more flavor. My tacos were then brought to me and there was not a shred of cheese on them. But the instead put red cabbage. Well I tried the beef. It was a bland, watery mess. I was so disappointed. So then I asked again for my drink. It was brought out and to my surprise was just a nasty looking lemon slice on a glass of margarita on the rocks. Tasted it and was again disappointed. Well moved to the chicken taco, and Wow, disappointment number 4!!! Tastes like eating a paper taco with cabbage. No cilantro in sight. No spices, or hot sauces to add. Just a lot of money and a disappointed stomach. Asked for my check and left after paying S$10 for on beef taco and S$8 for the chicken. S$16 for the margarita, and S$10 for the chips and guacamole.The Resturant at least took off the two tacos I didn't eat. I highly discourage anyone eating here, unless you like high priced bland food...

Went for lunch on a Saturday. Most of the food offered was "brunch" like breakfast burritos and avocado toast. I had a decent salad but the dressing that came on it was quite spicy. I could tolerate it but could have been toned down. Overall decent atmosphere. Food is priced similar to the rest of Singapore.

Ambience was decent; has a very chill vibe, and it helps that it's next to the river so the whole setting was quite casual. Perhaps taking note of the previous feedback, the service we we experienced was extremely fast, and their staff were friendly. Food was pretty good! My favorite dish by far was the blue crab tostaditas! Price point is definitely on the higher end, probably because of the location as well. With that said, I think a lot of people on yelp are complaining because they're not used to paying for a single taco (I've been to a few restaurants that charge by per taco overseas). The only disappointing thing, for me, was dessert. Their churros were a little bit overdone, and my husband didn't really like the rice icecream.

I obviously was not expecting authentic Mexican food in Singapore but was hoping for something decent. I loved the decor, the music, the ambiance. Service was great throughout. The concept of the place is great, but I'm sorry the food did not live up to the price they are asking for for each dish.The beginning of the meal was not too bad with the tostaditas - wishing they just made tostadas, that were regular sized instead of the topping too heavy for the tostadita.The tacos were not bad. The poblano taco needing a lot of help in the seasoning department. The lamb al pastor and the lengua tacos were not bad. The baja was quite flavourful.The churros to end our meal was a disappointment. It was more like a crispy biscuit. Yes they were crispy throughout. Was it overcooked? Overfried? Not sure but it was not doughy or chewy on the inside and we felt let down.I feel like this place is worth 2 stars only but I'll only take 2 stars off for food and value. I'm sorry that I can't recommend a place that charges 5 times more than what it's actually worth.

Ok that was my favourite from the whole meal! Rather small portions of the rest though. There's a vegetarian option for all categories, the reason we picked it in the first place. In this part of town, you mostly pay for ambiance and location and not for the food, so the meal was quite pricey.
Great Mexican food in Robertson Quay! My server An was really attentive and helpful, and the food was excellent. The house margarita was a little small, but really tasty!

If you're a fan of Lucha Loco, you ought to know she's got a hot new sister at Robertson Quay that everyone's checking out.I met her over the weekend, and I must say she's got a colourful personality. I admire her taste in furniture and her keen eye for decor. Her taste in music is top notch, as she bobs her head to club-like Tanjong Beach Club-esque tunes. And my, can she cook up a storm. For starters, her salsa is pretty good but her guac isn't as good as mine. (And I'm not saying that 'cause I'm jealous. I make a meaaaaan guac!) Her elotes (which is roasted corn smothered in sauce and sprinkled with cheese and chives) are probably one of the best snacks I've had in a while. I also loved one of her tuna appetizers, though I forgot what it's called. Although I'm an only child, I do understand that people hate it when you compare them to their sibling. But I gotta say that Senorita Super is just like her sister in the sense that she charges outrageous prices for a single taco.* However, I couldn't help but see if it was worth it at all. I ordered the one with chorizo, but was disappointed that it was more shredded meat than ground chorizo itself. So overall, I'm giving her a 3.5. Don't get me wrong, she's a cool friend and I'm thinking all my other friends will like hanging out with her, but she's just really high maintenance considering she enjoys the finer things in life. Maybe we'll just hang out once in a while over margaritas and elotes. --*That did not sound right but whatever leave me alone.

The day before I visited Super Loco I was told that it was currently the hottest thing in town. Digging around on the internet I found out it was run by a couple of Aussies who consulted chef Jason Jones (of Mamasita fame) on the menu. Being from Melbourne and having lined up at Mamasita on a number of occasions to eat tacos like every other hipster in town, I figured it was worth checking out.We arrived early (6pm) on a Saturday night and got a table right away. In the hour that followed the restaurant filled up with all sorts of groups - families out the front, dates on the the smaller tables and groups of friends gearing up for a big night on the larger high-topped tables at the back. The Margaritas were good, the salsa and chips were excellent though I baulked when I saw the meagre portion of guacamole that was served with them. We then ordered the famous Elotes, a Mamasita staple, which I declared would be the test for how well they had interpreted Jason Jones' menu. Flavour wise they were spot on - sweet, spicy, sour and salty but for some reason they were cold when we ate them as if they'd sat for far too long after being grilled. Perhaps this is an interpretation suited to the Singapore climate but I'm not sure it's for the better.The tuna things* were great, the chunks of fish generous and the dressing really well balanced. I'm sad they whisked the plate away before we could scoop up the slaw that they came sitting on. They would have been a nice addition to the top of them. *I can't remember what these were called!The Mexican truffle quesadilla were also terrific. Hot, melty with cheese and stuffed full of mushrooms. Compared with the tacos (ranging in price from $8 to $12!) they felt like one of the better value items. I tried the snapper taco. It was okay though at $8 I was kind of expecting the flavours to blow my mind. They didn't. While certainly not a cheep night out, a visit to Super Loco is a fun one.  Choose your menu items wisely and consider the cocktail jugs as a way to maximise your cash.

Good view.Food comes out quick, Drinks come out quick.Service was fine.I did not like the drinks and food was just ok.I don't like to be rushed to leave the table and it was hard to get a table and just for less than an hour.It was annoying walk for registration and check in all around the place.So I couldn't get why everyone are crazy about the place.But the view is amazing and crowd was nice too.

Walked in no reservation.  Food was good, but it felt like the servers forget about you.  One came to our table just to take a knife off our table to give to another. It was weird. It doesn't take away from the taste of the food and drinks. We ate the ceviche, guacamole, chicken tostadas, and sea bass. The food and drinks were pretty good.

Well I saw that this place was located close to my hotel. It was a great location but the place had no WiFi to check into Yelp with.I had a desire to grab some tacos for the night. Looked at the menu and ordered two beef and two Chicken.Plus ordered a side of chips and guacamole dip.Well normal Mexican food restaurants don't usually charge separate for a small helping of chips, and charge for salsa. But this place does. Since the salsa and Guacamole were the same price I went for the Guacamole $5 Singapore dollars and $5 Singapore dollars for the small bowl of chips.I also ordered a margarita.Well I got the bland chips and the blandest guacamole ever. Was really expecting more flavor. My tacos were then brought to me and there was not a shred of cheese on them. But the instead put red cabbage. Well I tried the beef. It was a bland, watery mess. I was so disappointed. So then I asked again for my drink. It was brought out and to my surprise was just a nasty looking lemon slice on a glass of margarita on the rocks. Tasted it and was again disappointed. Well moved to the chicken taco, and Wow, disappointment number 4!!! Tastes like eating a paper taco with cabbage. No cilantro in sight. No spices, or hot sauces to add. Just a lot of money and a disappointed stomach. Asked for my check and left after paying S$10 for on beef taco and S$8 for the chicken. S$16 for the margarita, and S$10 for the chips and guacamole.The Resturant at least took off the two tacos I didn't eat. I highly discourage anyone eating here, unless you like high priced bland food...

Went for lunch on a Saturday. Most of the food offered was "brunch" like breakfast burritos and avocado toast. I had a decent salad but the dressing that came on it was quite spicy. I could tolerate it but could have been toned down. Overall decent atmosphere. Food is priced similar to the rest of Singapore.

Ambience was decent; has a very chill vibe, and it helps that it's next to the river so the whole setting was quite casual. Perhaps taking note of the previous feedback, the service we we experienced was extremely fast, and their staff were friendly. Food was pretty good! My favorite dish by far was the blue crab tostaditas! Price point is definitely on the higher end, probably because of the location as well. With that said, I think a lot of people on yelp are complaining because they're not used to paying for a single taco (I've been to a few restaurants that charge by per taco overseas). The only disappointing thing, for me, was dessert. Their churros were a little bit overdone, and my husband didn't really like the rice icecream.

I obviously was not expecting authentic Mexican food in Singapore but was hoping for something decent. I loved the decor, the music, the ambiance. Service was great throughout. The concept of the place is great, but I'm sorry the food did not live up to the price they are asking for for each dish.The beginning of the meal was not too bad with the tostaditas - wishing they just made tostadas, that were regular sized instead of the topping too heavy for the tostadita.The tacos were not bad. The poblano taco needing a lot of help in the seasoning department. The lamb al pastor and the lengua tacos were not bad. The baja was quite flavourful.The churros to end our meal was a disappointment. It was more like a crispy biscuit. Yes they were crispy throughout. Was it overcooked? Overfried? Not sure but it was not doughy or chewy on the inside and we felt let down.I feel like this place is worth 2 stars only but I'll only take 2 stars off for food and value. I'm sorry that I can't recommend a place that charges 5 times more than what it's actually worth.

Ok that was my favourite from the whole meal! Rather small portions of the rest though. There's a vegetarian option for all categories, the reason we picked it in the first place. In this part of town, you mostly pay for ambiance and location and not for the food, so the meal was quite pricey.
Great Mexican food in Robertson Quay! My server An was really attentive and helpful, and the food was excellent. The house margarita was a little small, but really tasty!

If you're a fan of Lucha Loco, you ought to know she's got a hot new sister at Robertson Quay that everyone's checking out.I met her over the weekend, and I must say she's got a colourful personality. I admire her taste in furniture and her keen eye for decor. Her taste in music is top notch, as she bobs her head to club-like Tanjong Beach Club-esque tunes. And my, can she cook up a storm. For starters, her salsa is pretty good but her guac isn't as good as mine. (And I'm not saying that 'cause I'm jealous. I make a meaaaaan guac!) Her elotes (which is roasted corn smothered in sauce and sprinkled with cheese and chives) are probably one of the best snacks I've had in a while. I also loved one of her tuna appetizers, though I forgot what it's called. Although I'm an only child, I do understand that people hate it when you compare them to their sibling. But I gotta say that Senorita Super is just like her sister in the sense that she charges outrageous prices for a single taco.* However, I couldn't help but see if it was worth it at all. I ordered the one with chorizo, but was disappointed that it was more shredded meat than ground chorizo itself. So overall, I'm giving her a 3.5. Don't get me wrong, she's a cool friend and I'm thinking all my other friends will like hanging out with her, but she's just really high maintenance considering she enjoys the finer things in life. Maybe we'll just hang out once in a while over margaritas and elotes. --*That did not sound right but whatever leave me alone.

The day before I visited Super Loco I was told that it was currently the hottest thing in town. Digging around on the internet I found out it was run by a couple of Aussies who consulted chef Jason Jones (of Mamasita fame) on the menu. Being from Melbourne and having lined up at Mamasita on a number of occasions to eat tacos like every other hipster in town, I figured it was worth checking out.We arrived early (6pm) on a Saturday night and got a table right away. In the hour that followed the restaurant filled up with all sorts of groups - families out the front, dates on the the smaller tables and groups of friends gearing up for a big night on the larger high-topped tables at the back. The Margaritas were good, the salsa and chips were excellent though I baulked when I saw the meagre portion of guacamole that was served with them. We then ordered the famous Elotes, a Mamasita staple, which I declared would be the test for how well they had interpreted Jason Jones' menu. Flavour wise they were spot on - sweet, spicy, sour and salty but for some reason they were cold when we ate them as if they'd sat for far too long after being grilled. Perhaps this is an interpretation suited to the Singapore climate but I'm not sure it's for the better.The tuna things* were great, the chunks of fish generous and the dressing really well balanced. I'm sad they whisked the plate away before we could scoop up the slaw that they came sitting on. They would have been a nice addition to the top of them. *I can't remember what these were called!The Mexican truffle quesadilla were also terrific. Hot, melty with cheese and stuffed full of mushrooms. Compared with the tacos (ranging in price from $8 to $12!) they felt like one of the better value items. I tried the snapper taco. It was okay though at $8 I was kind of expecting the flavours to blow my mind. They didn't. While certainly not a cheep night out, a visit to Super Loco is a fun one.  Choose your menu items wisely and consider the cocktail jugs as a way to maximise your cash.

As the new kid on the block of robertson quay, Super Loco sure has stirred up a lot of buzz among my group of friends. Frustrated for not being able to get a reservation here for friday or saturday night at a good time for the past two weeks (calling on a wednesday on the same week is not early enough), i finally headed down on a sunday night. Even at 6:30pm the place was already packed.Overall I think their food was tasty. i enjoyed my meal, and this place has got their ambience correct for that trendy place with dim dim light (the older couple next to our table made me smile when they used their iphone light to look at the menu) but what ultimately made me knock off one star is the price to portion ratio. It baffles me that $11-13 per taco is just for ONE single 6" taco. The flautas were $18 for two regular sized rolls, and the quesadilla was also $18 for tiny pieces. Churros were $12 for 5 pieces. The elotes was as tasty as everyone gushed, but it's $8 for half a cob of corn.I think if the prices were 20% less, it would have made more sense. But then again, in a country where $22-28 cocktail has become a norm, i guess this is the price to pay for glam-ed up street food?The drinks on the other hand, is pretty averagely priced at $15-18. The margaritas were pretty tasty!

This is a very very strong one star. The tacos here are amazing, there is no doubt about it. Not sure what the other menu items offer, but the kitchen staff know their craft so I'd expect stellar Results. What I don't understand is their service. Bad service when they're completely packed is understandable. I get it. But their wait staff were far more interested in closing up for the night (hours away) then serving the few customers that were remaining. This is INTENTIONALLY bad service, especially when you have an army of staff. This was a planned practice.

This might be the biggest disappointment in all of Singapore. Pretty unbelievable how much hype this place got and how poorly it delivered. I guess they know their audience well, since people keep packing the place in. Perhaps it's tourists or nearby residents who want tacos but can't be bothered to venture farther than 10 minutes to get decent kormex at Vatos. Save your time and money and go someplace else. Nothing on their menu tasted well, and I'm not even going to complain about the price. The food is bland and even the tortillas don't want to be there since they fall apart before even getting picked up off the plate. Sad. They have beer and creative cocktails, so that and the river location save them from a one star ranking.
I ordered a burrito via Grab Food and it was great. Went there to eat with a friend and it took 20 minutes for someone to ask us what we wanted to eat after we ordered drinks.

I am very wary of Mexican restaurants outside México, since I've had so many dreadful experiences with horrible food labelled as "Mexican". My general rule is: if a restaurant has neon signs, cacti, sombreros, skulls, and a stereotypical name including words such as "tequila", "amigo", "fiesta", "loco", "señor" or "latino", that is definitely a place to avoid. So, anyone could understand why I was reluctant to visit a place called "Super Loco".Reading the menu quickly dispelled my fears: no burritos, no nachos, no chimichangas, no fajitas, no chilli con carne, no "taco meat" (whatever that is). Instead, they have proper corn flour tortillas and also several welcome surprises with ingredients such as axiote, huitlacoche and pibil pulled pork. There is fairly good variety of tequila and mezcal, some very good brands included, and even explain the difference between tequila and mezcal. When it came to taste, Super Loco delivered. I had a huitlacoche quesadilla, with more mushrooms than huitlacoche but was still good. I also tried a red snapper taco which had a very nice touch of axiote, and a very nice mango ceviche. I was glad to have some of those nearly tasteless but fresh Mexican beers we like so much, rather overpriced. The only thing I did not like was the habanero sauce since it was, in fact, mayonnaise and that ruined the habanero taste. Overall, it was a good meal. It was also overpriced, though.The obvious question is if the place is "truly" Mexican, whatever that means. I could tell the owners are not Mexican, some slight misspellings on the menu gave them away. However, it is clear they have done their homework properly. The menu states they travelled to Mexico City and the Pacific Coast to do research on street food, and that explains Super Loco's good taste. It is a very good take on Mexican street food. It's true, maybe it's not exactly as it is in México (purists sure will say that), but it has the proper essence. The fact that they don't stick lime wedges on your beer makes them more Mexican than many other joints I've visited elsewhere.

Love the food but be wary of the prices. I'm a big fan of Mexican food. Super Loco delivers HOWEVER beware, prices are steep. A single taco could equal a meal elsewhere. A single Elote is enough to burn pockets. So order with caution! Prices aside, food was incredible. Flavours were spot on and service was great. Ambience was fun and vibrant. I'm a big fan of ceviche and man do I love their combinations. Their tortilla chips are super addictive and the hot sauces are so flavourful you hardly notice the spice. Elote was simply awesome and tacos were delicious. However the portions leave a lot to be desired. Remember to leave space for cocktails as they have a pretty extensive list. I understand that Super Loco is situated in an expat area and prices are suited to the clients there but I feel that for the amount of food they serve, the prices are unreasonable. Not for every dish but for most. I'd love to return as much as I can but the prices are simply far too high. Amazing food. High prices. Worth a try for a true Mexican food lover.

Not the cheapest place in town but I find Singapore can be expensive anyway for eating out.Came here as it caters to gluten free. They do corn tortillas and there is lots of choice for what you can have which was a big plus.So, fab chips and guacamole. Salsa was ok but not as good as the guac. This was a decent portion that two of us shared.Tortillas good (portions of two) but small so you need another couple to fill the gap. We ordered pork tortillas then little small (4) portion mini crab things which were tasty. Mexican was normally always a cheap meal but not so much here so be warned. Desserts again offer gf options - not wow but ok enough. Great margaritas.Service was so-so. Solid 3*.

Super Loco is a Mexican place (same owners as Lucha Loco) located alongside Robertson Quay. It has a very colorful look and design and it does look as if it is a fun place to hang out at. In a sense it is also as they serve some pretty decent Mexican food. We sampled several different tacos and they were all good but everything does however feel slightly like a rip off as prices are too high for what they are serving.I was also (like some other reviewers) asking for some changes to the dish but that was not possible which also seems to suggest they are perhaps not making the food (or that they are just unwilling to do much for their customers). Service was very disinterested as well, one of these places where the staff are more interested in talking to each other, checking their phones or fixing nails and/or make-up. We had to waive at people several times to be able to place an order and when finished it was the same thing trying to pay (and the place was not even half-full)So food was decent but over-priced and we did not really feel that welcome so will not return any time soon.

Super loco is super delicious! Super bummed that they arent open for breakfast/bunch on week days as their breakfast options are absolutely delicious; flavourful and fresh. The atmosphere and decore is so funky - it's truly a stand out along Robertson Quay.  I highly recommend this place to anyone looking for a delicious mexican bite whilst staying in Singapore!

Is it time for brunch?If so, this is one of my new favorite places for brunch.  It's by the water, but not too hot, and has such fab options for a casual meal.  Reservations for groups can easily be made over email (gotta love it when you don't need to call!) Also, who doesn't like Mexican food right?The FoodThere's a nice variety of bites for the kiddos and adults.  We started with the esquites - grilled corn with a healthy dose of spice and lime mayo.  It packed a nice kick and was a great, semi-healthy side/starter.  The Mexico Grande was a great variety of options including avocado toast, bacon, eggs, and baked beans.  Everything was seasoned well with an ode to savory Mexican flavors. The sweetcorn fritters were nice and crispy with a little sweetness and paired well with the salty smoked salmon. My little one LOVED her berry smoothie and I felt pretty great letting her go wild with the smoothie because it was full of almond milk, coconut water, and agave nectar.  It's great when restaurants present sugar-free, healthy options.  But when you want the sugar, look no further than the crispy, sweet churros.  Fried dough and chocolate sauce - does it get better than this?The verdict?I'd definitely return.  The ambiance is chill and it's a nice, family friendly option.  This is more of a Californian Mexican style type of restaurant, but in a good way.  I'm just thinking of my next smoothie there...

Decent Mexican food. Tacos are really good. I'm from San Diego and I know what a good taco is.However , food is super expensive and nothing special to justify the price. Might as well walk over to Clark quay and get your Mexican food there.Additionally I just came here for breakfast and wanted to order the breakfast burrito... I asked to have the black beans on the side....not the most egregious of requests....but they could not do it. The server (very nice by the way) explained that it was already in the burrito and could not be taken out. Which made me question...am I ordering a pre made burrito??? For $19? What am I paying for? I should just go to 7 eleven. It's was the strangest thing .
Great fresh food, we were early as were going to the zoo. They prepared our food very quickly. Good service

I agree with previous reviews, the portions are so small and expensive. A single taco is $11. Nothing about the taco justifies that price. It's small (six inches) and basic. The garnishing is simply shredded cabbage and some sauce, the cheapest fixings possible. There's no sight of any kind of onion or tomatoes.That said, the grilled corn sprinkled with cheese is really good. I don't remember the price of that item, but that's probably why I liked it so much.The margarita jug is a rip off. It's not a jug, it's a slim carafe. $59 for six short glasses. Yes, that's cheaper than if you ordered six separate margaritas, but barely.The servers are nice. Okay, you get one point there.

DINNER: - tacos al pastor ($13)- quesadilla de Pollo ($16)- gingerale ($7)FOOD: The food is a deserving 3/5, as both dishes were very well seasoned. The tacos are served on single tortillas with a small portion of al pastor, couple pieces of grilled pinapple, and salsa Verde. Each taco is a couple bites. The only issue with the dish was the overcooked meat, which tells me they don't prepare the al pastor on a revolving spicket as its traditionally done. It had ok flavor, but was dry and tough. Quesadilla was average at best, and lacked cheese. No stringy, oozey, goodness here. Food is better here than at their sister restaurant, Lucha Loco.AMBIANCE: Decoration is well done. Comfortable, relatable, but elevated enough to host a date or set group dinner. It has the markings of a Baja taqueria without actually putting you there. I only wish it were a bit brighter. I sat inside, and found it hard to see what I was eating. Probably not an issue if seated outside. PRICE: It's expensive for dinner, because the portions are so small. My bill for one totaled $37.50 and I could've eaten a couple more tacos ($11-$16 each). OVERALL: Come for drinks + late night eats. It's not a bad place to visit, and could be very fun. Stop by with a group later in the evening to grab drinks and share a few small dishes.

The pricey and high maintenance sibling of Lucha Loco. (As Michelle M aptly put it)This is the new up and coming spot on Robertson Quay, decked in blinking neon, blaring music and similar lucha libre decor. The line is long even on a weekday. The menu is very close to the one at Lucha Loco, and so are the exorbitant prices. For the premium pricing, I was underwhelmed by the food. I went for the elotes (mexican grilled corn), a couple of tacos, a chile relleno and the huitlacoche quesadilla. The chile relleno tasted rather tired and bland. The huitlacoche quesadilla didn't contain any huitlacoche, they substituted with a couple of mushrooms and corn. Maybe Singaporeans aren't ready for the real thing. (Huitlacoche, plainly speaking, is mouldy fungus infected corn, i.e. an acquired taste) Their tacos were a little better, but not particularly authentic. Also, $8 for half a ear of corn?! You have gotta be kidding me. Again, it's Mexican street food! Tacos cost between US$2-4, S$8-12 is daylight robbery at around 4-5 times the cost. I've eaten at many a food truck and hole-in-the-wall type places south of the border, I know what I'm talking about.Adios, better Mexican food and pricing can be found elsewhere in Singapore.

INSANELY expensive. $11/taco. Small portions, watered down house margarita (the 'jug' was a ripoff). Service leaves a lot to be desired, confused wait staff. Head elsewhere! Many better options in Robinson Quay.

I didn't go into this place expecting super authentic Mexican I mean after all it's called super loco and it's in a super touristy area in Singapore. So perhaps adjusting expectations before going helps the experience. We went during happy hour for $9 frozen margaritas and these were strong enough. I prefer margaritas on the rocks but not available for happy hour. Advised that the dishes were meant for sharing family style so for 8 of us we got 4 dishes and chips and salsa. In America each dish woulda been a portion for one but that is bc we are fat Americans. It was plenty of food and it actually tasted really good. Had the chicken enchiladas and the steak both of which were flavorful. The salsa that came with the chips isn't really my favorite kind - more smoky rather than fresh but went nicely with the drinks. The setting is fun and it didn't rain and their fans are powerful enough to feel like a cooling night breeze. Overall attentive service and a fun night to hang with other friends who had to leave for the airport early. I certainly wouldn't have chosen to go here just bc the name but my friends did and I'm glad we did. I think the dishes were expensive - like high 20s to low 30s but I'm getting used to these types of prices. I suppose it's about the same for tourists that end up hanging around Times Square. I mean what else do u expect but jacked up prices and mediocre food? So when I get pretty decent food like I did here I'll just be happy and not sweat the high prices.

Literally the worst restaurant I have been to in Singapore!!!!Portions are TINY and the prices are outrageous! The food tasted mediocre and the margarita was piss poor and what they call a "Jug" of margarita for $59 is a Carafe that barely gives 4 people a drink.If you have a night out in Singapore and happen to end up in Robertson Quay, go anywhere but SUPER LOCO. 7/11 would be better!!!!!!!!

Decent Mexican, love the pineapple in my salsa.If you've read my 200+ reviews on Yelp, I've eaten at some fancy expensive restaurants and nevertheless have found the food to be of value. Either on the quality per dollar or quantity per dollar ratio or both.Super loco is unbelievably expensive.There is a dearth of Mexican options in Singapore and they are milking the expat pocket for what it's worth. I especially disliked how the "tequila cart" came round and the servers "didn't know how much each shot costs" yet pressured my whole table into buying them. It sounds silly but you'll understand when you're there. It was $16 each, which is Pangaea type pricing while drinking said shot next to a kid watching Aladdin on his iPad. The food portions, as with lucha loco, are pathetically small. You could eat better and be full at other super atas street food joints like Ippudo down the road. Unless you are craving tacos epicly like I was craving chwee kuay in the middle of Virginia, or your boss paid you a really good bonus and Hermes ran out of Birkins for you to buy, skip Super Loco.
Super cute but pricey! The drinks are strong and the menu sounds very tasty. I will come back for snacks one day. It looks really nice for a chill out sunday with friends. Nothing pretentious.

Probebly the furthest thing from Mexican food you will find. You cannot substitute seasoning for expensive exotic vegetables, this is supposed to be Mexico,  the land of spice. If I wanted a 30 dollar tortilla chip with garbanzo beans and anise slathered on it, I would have gone to a 5 star restaurant. We wanted to shake salt over out entire table's orders for lack of flavor. The drink... 2 sips of the 17$ Margarita and it was gone. Great if you are a sugar ant.

Great atmosphere, but the food is pricey and not really that Mexican.  The tree enchiladas with no other extras like beans, rice, etc. was SGD 26, about twice what it should be.  It was also extremely spicey, not very Mexican.  Interestly, no burritos and only one enchilada choice.  Might be better with the tacos that looked good. Probably wouldn't return, although I did have a brunch here before and decided to try again.

If you like overpriced, inauthentic Mexican food served by disinterested staff, this is the place for you. Some of the worst 'Mexican' food I've had in Asia. Clearly, the owners don't know the food. Will definitely not be back.I think they call it Super Loco because you would be  Super Crazy to come back and eat here.
Well, don't sit at the bar, service is pretty poor as you have a team waiting on you..... Nobody in charge and nobody to blame.Food was ok, but 4 of the 5 drinks they advertised, they didn't have.
The food was bad and the service was horrible. I do not recommend wasting your money at Super Loco. I am sure any other Mexican restaurant in Singapore is better than this place.

Have been here twice and really want to like it. The service is so bad that we won't be back. We had poor service on our first go (huge wait times between every step of the meal from taking our order to bringing our check), but decided to go back for another attempt. We waited so long for someone to come greet us and take our drink order, we ended up walking out.

I went back and fourth between 3 and 4 stars on this one.  The service here was abismal, we could not get someone to take our order or attend to us, but as I'm new to Singapore it seems like maybe I'm asking for more service that is to be expected.  In any case, the food was great!  The masa huarache is a must try, great flavor, as was the tostadita de garbanzo.  These really tasted good.  The tacos were good, but expected.  My boyfriend and I also ordered quesadilla which never came, so they offered us a tequila shot instead since we were full and ready to head out anyways.  This was a nice touch.  Speaking of drinks, the margarita did not impress.    I will definitely come back for the Huarache and stick to a corona and it will be a nice dinner :)

Each bite delivers explosive bursts of flavor....tantalizing your tastebuds with hints of sweet, spicy, and tangy...hitting you with one after the other.,.and the harmonious flow of textures and freshness in each dish! Pure genius (the main reason I love Mexican cuisine). The crab appetizer, taco's, chicken quesadilla, sirloin, and let's not forget the drinks...all are top notch! Go now before it's too late and this place like so many others starts lacking in the "umph" that made it great.
This place is pretty nice I think. 3.5 star. The food is not pricey imo, especially in this location. We tried several ceviches and many of the tacos and all were nice.

the tacos are great!  I can't get over the experience we had there.  the service was some of the worst i have ever had in Singapore.  we could not get a drink from our server despite being next to the bar, so i would just go to the bartender and get them since he was quicker.  somehow they messed up our order (I rec'd the wrong quesadilla) and then forgot a dish. our friends sent back their salad  2 times and the people next to them sent back their quesadilla 3 times since it was the wrong one.I would take this as a bad night and they're still working out the kinks as it's a new place.going forward i might stop in for a taco and a beer, but I am not going to stay long, especially if the service doesn't get any better.

Ok all please forgive me, I am writing this for Americans that are accustomed to Mexican food.  While the favors are ok, the quantities are un acceptable, the menu is small,  the price for taste, quantity is something to be ashamed of.  I have actually thought about going to confession after this meal as I feel guilty for going.  That being said if you not used to good Mexican food and are used to over priced fare, you just might enjoy it, just know that even a run down Taco Bell provides better value.

I really don't understand the low rating for this place, I know it's expensive, but so is everywhere else. Fish tacos and chorizo tacos are delicious, the drinks are strong, and the churros are damn good. Had 2 tacos, a margarita, and churros and that was plenty to fill me up. I'm a hardcore taco fan and would definitely recommend this place. Food, drinks, atmosphere, all great. I'll give 4 stars because yes, it's expensive.

Its a cool place, nice the vibe and ambience setting by the river. Really tasty food, we had  tuna ceviche, pulled pork tacos, chicken quesadilla and mexican rice. Couple of the dishes were a bit spicier than expected but I like spice ,my friend not so much. Cant remember what the bill was but couldn't have been that bad as would go again. just a good place to go with a group of friends for a casual fun dinner.

This is a quick review:Positives + good food+ good locationConsiderations- forgetful service- rude maitre d (hostesses)- devilishly small portions (those labelled large might be good for almost one person)
It's just bad, food is bad, service is bad and price is bad.  All up bad.  Had the chef even eaten a real Mexican food? Ugh, never would I ever come here again.

If youve been to lucha loco then you know what youre getting yourself into.  This is the younger drunk sister to lucha loco.  Its set in the robertson quay area near the gallery hotel.  If you like lucha loco you'll like it here. If you hate the expensive food at lucha loco you'll hate it here.  The menu is almost exactly the same which was a disappointment.  I love the food but I thought they would try something new.  They added a couple new menu items but its pretty much the same, as is the drink menu.  Its fine because I love the food anyways. This is more of a casual bar atmosphere than lucha loco. More of a casual drinking atmosphere to grab some small bites.  I gave it 4 stars because in spite of the prices I really like the food and atmosphere.  It was successful for a reason.  The service was on par for singapore which means not stellar but it can be worse for sure.  Our server was available but not overly attentive.  Expect to pay what you'd pay at lucha loco.  The drinks arent cheap but until the powers that be realize that taxing the crap out of alcohol doesnt actually work in making people drink less, the drinks will still be expensive here.

Prior to moving to Singapore I have been living in the US and have been spoiled with Mexican food from my frequent trips to Cali and Mexico. Therefore when I heard a new Mexican place was opened in town, I was excited to try it out. My experience at Super Loco was a big disappointment. While the place is nice and trendy, the food is really what I cared about. The moment we sat down, my friend and I proceeded to order some drinks and chips and guac. She ordered a horchata and it just tasted someone dumped a whole bunch of cinnamon powder into the glass. My friend sent it back (after explaining how to make it) and they ended up adding a bunch of milk and when we commented it was not right- the waitress came back and told us the bartender said he didn't know how to make it and will make another drink instead. Really?? The chips and guac came- the chips were stale and the guac was a liquid mess. We ordered enchiladas and it came out soggy and was tasteless. None of the taste blended in together and nothing was flavorful. We also ordered a taco but even now as I'm writing this review, I cant even remember what kind of taco we ordered. The entire meal was unsatisfying and unmemorable. To top of it off, when we got the bill they decided to charge us 3x for the drinks. While we were arguing the bill (and managed to get them to change it) we noticed other tables complaining to the staff as well, especially one guy who was complaining loudly to the manager about the service.

this place is a cozy little eatery down along mohammed sultan road: narrow, tiny, and earnest. the food was surprisingly enjoyable, with a large (for this place) menu to choose from and dishes that hovered above the average mark.we started with a salmon salad, which was a tall mound of thinly-mandolined cabbage, halved cherry tomatoes and salmon sashimi. served with a creamy sesame dressing (THIS SAUCE CAN GO NO WRONG). the sashimi moriwase, or mixed platter, was also fresh slices of fish and tentacle served beautifully on a flower-shaped bowl. such effort!the spider roll had crispy and not-too-oily soft shell crab rolled loose-ish in rice. it's a good time to mention that I LOVE tobiko (and ikura and mentaiko) and they are generous with it here. the cooked food here is decent too, with standard things like saba (horse mackerel) and unagi going down quickly. the fried rice also maintained grain integrity with some smokiness from cooking and a good dose of garlic, if a little oilier than we'd have liked.but the beef that came last on a hot pan was quite surprisingly good - cubes cooked at medium (though a little over that by the time I finished shooting) that had a good browning. it was properly seasoned and topped with grated radish that brought a fresh vegetal counterpoint.worth a visit, and more than a couple more after that - and good for time-to-relax mealtimes.
Really good Japanese!Came here with family and ordered the Unagi Bento Box. Well priced and everything that came with it was delicious. Overall a great time

Came here for a quick lunch but was so disappointed with the food.  The lunch set Zaru Soba for 11sgd felt like a small portion of 7-11 soba and no o-yu.  The udon special set has soggy prawn in it ... in general - won't come again

The ten-dons are deeeeelicious. They have a mix-and-match set with things like tempura-don or katsu-don with udon or soba for under $20.  The bentos are super value-for-money - slices of sashimi (tuna and salmon mostly), a selection from the oden pot (a prawn, fishcake and konnyaku are mainstays),a dollop of potato salad (amazing), and a protein of your choice (the hambagu is pretty awesome), and all the bentos are $20 or under. That hambagu bento is $14 dollars. This food comes fast, and fuss-free. and it isn't expensive. Why aren't you eating there now?

This is one of the first few japanese restaurants that mushroomed up in Mohd Sultan back in 2007 when mohd sultan faced a dynamic shift to family friendly restaurants from clubbing scene.At Sugisawa,  the al carte are rather pricey but the bento sets are big, good and decently priced. There bento boxes ranges from $15 - $22 depending on the selection. There is a wide range of selection from fried items to terriyaki to sashimi. We realised that they have a sizeable amount of japanese patrons and this bring up our confident in getting some edible japanese eats in town. Till this day, I still love to dine here when I am in search for some nice bentos.

I was a bit skeptical going in this restaurant because it didn't look so nice from the outside, but the minute we entered and saw the place full of Japanese, then it should be  a good Japanese restaurant.I ordered the grilled black cod and and I have to say that it was grilled to perfection and seasoned well.  It was tender and juicy and not at all dry.  I also ordered the avocado salad which was just ok.The service was very good.  When I ordered the sauteed mixed vegetable, the server informed that there is pork in that dish so I was able to change it to a non-pork vegetable dish.  They were attentive and would refill your water or tea.  Lastly, it was reasonably priced!
I really like the ramen soups here.  But the service is awful... Slow and rude! :-s

This is hands down my favourite and best kept secret that I selectively share by bringing my close friends there for meals. Whether it's lunch or dinner, nothing at sugisawa, at least not their bento and set meals disappoints your hungry bellies. So here, you can expect a full meal, authentic japanese with 20 ingredients and still expect change with a $20 note. Yes, the bentos here average at about $16 and they'll give you fresh sashimi, some cold appetizer dishes, your main protein choice and fluffy japanese rice. My favourite is their sakana bento. Everything is well prepared and consistent. For small eaters, share with the set meals with a friend! They have smaller bowls of udon and rice or soba and sushi etc. where you will probably pay $10-$12 only. There is practically nothing to pick about sugisawa, taking into account the value, the quality and the ambience if you dine al fresco. Find this little restaurant along the rows of eating options along robertson quay.

address: 80 Mohamed Sultan Road #01-01/02 The Pier at Robertson Singapore 239013 Singapore
comment: Came in and got seated right away. We ordered  several drinks and a prawn cheese toast. I got the apple peach tea.The server came out with a wrong drink and wrong food (we got mushroom tartes instead). He fixed our drink, and gave us two desserts on the house which was really nice of him. Mushroom tartes- so yummy! It was hot and flaky and there was the perfect amount of mushroom.Apple peach tea- the top was foamy with apple bits inside. Not too sweet and I really liked it. Azuki red bean matcha cake- it was okay. I'm not a big fan of red bean so I can't say much... My friend really liked it though.Chocolate cake- tastes exactly what it's supposed to. It was good.Overall nice place to have tea and coffee while chilling and catching up with friends. Yum!

address: 80 Mohamed Sultan Road #01-01/02 The Pier at Robertson Singapore 239013 Singapore
comment: After visiting the Singapore Tyler Print Museum or watching a show at The Singapore Repertory Theatre, I like to pop by this TCC outlet with my friends for a cup of coffee or tea and some desserts. The atmosphere here is usually tranquil and peaceful (cept when a few party goers drop by in the evenings). I particularly love the hanging chairs although they might not be as comfortable to lounge in as the sofas around. Food wise, they do sell main meals although there is nothing much to shout. The drinks are reliably good and there are a few innovative tastes you can choose from. For me, I always stick to hazelnut latte. For those who are avoiding caffeine, there is also a range of sodas, blends, yoghurt drinks and milk shakes to choose from.

address: 80 Mohamed Sultan Road #01-01/02 The Pier at Robertson Singapore 239013 Singapore
comment: There are plenty of TCCs but i really like the one at river valley because of the alternate seating outside inside this gallery of art and with air conditioning still. It is usually quiet in the afternoon and the menu often has tea time specials. The service crew there are very accomodating of my requests for say honey instead of sugar. It's a great spot to unwind or have alone time, and if the weather's good, the comfortable chair outdoors is my default choice.

address: 80 Mohamed Sultan Road #01-01/02 The Pier at Robertson Singapore 239013 Singapore
comment: TCC is one of the higher end chain of cafes that seem to be present everywhere on the island. While I think the food and drinks are just about average with some rather inventive but odd-tasting drinks like Lychee Jazz, I am rather fond of the decor and comfort at this particular TCC outlet. Located at Robertson Quay with many plush and expensive restaurants around, this bright but warmly lit cafe stands out in the day as an ideal environment for tea. The chairs are comfortable and large enough to sink into. We spent numerous lazy hours there with a few snacks and drinks until it was almost sunset. There were few people going in and out, and most were large groups of friends or families. It was quiet enough for talking to friends but also had just enough people so that it doesn't feel empty. Granted, I did not enjoy my drink but the light snacks like spicy wings, mozza stick or shrooms bite were good accompaniments along with their selection of desserts. There is also usually a tea set with small savoury and sweet snacks that makes choosing a lot easier.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-03 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: I love this place! I come here every trip to Singapore and the food is always consistent and the meats high quality. Robertson Quay is a relaxing neighborhood and a great place to get out of downtown or avoid the crazy in Clark Quay.I like to order the meat and vegetable tray to get a sample of multiple meats and some veggies. Gif you want a great meal and a chill vibe. This place is for you!PS: cooking over the hot coals is a fun experience for people who haven't been before!

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-03 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Surprised that it took me so long to visit this place. Claiming to be the tallest bar in Singapore, the open roof top floor is surprisingly a nice place, even if it seems a little touristy. Weekdays are the time to go, Wednesdays is ladies night so they get 50% off on certain drinks. But this place is for the views, alcohol is just on the side. 360 degree views of Singapore from 70+ storeys tall. Wow, just wow.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-03 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Aburiya has two locations, one in Robertson Quay and the other in Boat Quay. This is a review for the Boat Quay branch. We had reservations so didn't have any problems getting seated. The waiting staff came to take our order shortly after we were seated but never asked us if we wanted water or tea (not sure if it's because we ordered a bottle of sake.) We had a toddler but they also never asked if we needed kid utensils or bowls. When the server brought us our meat, she also didn't explain which body part or type of meat it was. The food itself was good and the environment was nice. But the service was definitely not what you would expect for a Japanese joint.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-03 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Tried this restaurant for the very first time. Although the ambience and location is good, the food is so so. The tongue was great. Kimchi was far from being a kimchi - more like achar. The biggest disappointment: even though wagyu marbling was great, the meat was frozen - straight from freezer. Leaves much room for improvement.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-03 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: This is my Favourite yakiniku restaurant in Singapore. The meat is of a very high quality and there is a good selection of cuts. The staff are attentive and friendly. The atmosphere is relaxed.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-03 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: So we were out hunting for this elusive and yet fantabulous Japanese BBQ place by the name of Aburiya. A little further down from where I usually stray, this joint is located closer to the Tyler Print Institute than the main Robertson hive. First up, a friend tried to get us a table without reservation but was turned away. Full, they said, despite there being several empty tables. A second friend wouldn't take no for an answer and sat at one nonchalantly. And that's how our party of five got in. Score!It's a BBQ joint so you get to choose from the set or a la carte menus, and grill your meats over a mass of charcoal. We opted for Set E, that at $75, seemed only sufficient for two. Rice, tamago soup, kimchi, tiger prawns, chicken, beef, beef and potato stew, and a side of salad. We added on two more plates of wagyu beef, one sliced and one in cubes just for good measure. The stars of the show was undoubtedly the wagyu slices and the beef and spud stew. Well marbled cuts of meat, these babies were delicious and flavorful. They barely needed a minute on each side on the grill and were wonderfully tender. You're able to savor the meat with a drizzle of lemon, a dash of salt, or simply au natural. The stew, too was great. With gravy a little on the thinnish side, the cuts of meat were fork tender and went very well with the rice provided. Everything else was rather plebeian, and with it's obvious popularity, it was exceedingly difficult to get service. However, to their credit, the staff were unfailingly polite and provided extra lemons, plates, and water with no hesitation.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-03 The Quayside Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Definitely one of my favorite eats while in Singapore. The BBQ was fantastic. It had a pretty cosy feel about it, as there were about 10-15 indoor tables and the place was packed! We were told that it would be a 30 minute wait at least, which is quite surprising for a weekday evening, but that's how good the food was. The menu was pretty extensive, I remember loving the beef short ribs the best, as they were so yummy and tasty when grilled on the BBQ. You get to cook your own food, which is part of the experience, and we tried a variety of other meats but nothing came even close to the beef short ribs (we didn't try the wagyu beef as it was pricey). Dinner was a little pricey, but all said, completely enjoyable. Service was pretty excellent for a busy night, and it was a lot of fun taking the time to cook our own meats and relaxing over a beer while looking out the window and people watching as the restaurant is located near a small river canal. The lights in the area get pretty nice too at night, as it's beside a residential condominium, which adds to the vibe of a nice, upscale restaurant in a local neighborhood. I would love to go back again!

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-05 Riverside Village Residences Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: It's summertime and that means unagi is the perfect way to get some energy back! After looking at my options, I figured I'd check Ichinoji out since Man Man and U-ya are incredibly popular and may have long lines at lunch.Ichinoji is in a little alleyway in Robertson Quay and when you turn the corner, you can already smell that great charcoal they use on the unagi. While there are no sets specific to lunch available, there is an unagi fair happening right now and we ordered one Unagi Omelette, one Unajyu and one Large Hitsumabushi (from the regular menu).Unagi Omelette - like a dashimaki with unagi in the middle. The dashimaki was delicious, not too firm, had a lot of flavor from the dashi and encased some delicious unagi!Unajyu - very generous portion, about 2 full pieces of unagi on top of rice, accompanied by chawanmushi, grilled unagi bones, soup, pickles, and dessert (warabi mochi & kanten). Everything was delicious. The unagi was nice and soft, while still having a great smoky flavor from the grill. The chawanmushi was nicely done and I also liked the dessert which wasn't too heavy.Hitsumabushi - I ordered the large because the medium one looked tiny, and that was the right amount for me. It's always fun eating hitsumabushi since you get to enjoy it in multiple ways. The set came with the usual bucket of rice topped with unagi which was grilled to perfection, condiments (leeks, fresh wasabi, seaweed) and dashi to make ochazuke.I took one star off for the location because while it's great, I don't see myself going out of the way just to go there. Service was passable but nothing to write home about. Otherwise, this place was reasonably priced for the portions, wasn't too crowded which was perfect, and was a nice place for a quiet lunch!

Congratulations to Chef Kenjiro "Hatch" Hashida on reopening his restaurant!Always the innovator his meals are fresh with a surprise mixture of traditional Japanese and other famed cuisine techniques. The meals are prepared in the traditional Japanese way but in every corner there is a hint of other methods that help to enhance the underlying flavor.Unfortunately it was still preopening and the staff was still struggling a bit getting back into the flow after a long break, the taste is just as I've remembered with more refined techniques perfecting his mastery.Cannot wait to go back after its official open in October 5, 2018!

This is the best sushi in Singapore and compares favorably to Masa in NYC.  Hashida-san and his team provided impeccable service.  The food was outstanding and show an incredible attention to detail.  I just cannot recommend it enough.

address: 11 Unity St #01-19/20 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: My friend's brother and wife lives out in Singapore and they exclaimed this was definitely one place we had to go to for our double date (plus the toddler...). After eating a lifetime's worth of hawker market foods, I found myself really craving a different type of pasta. Started off with a cheese and meat appetizer and it had a great little selection of stuff. We all went at it and it started the meal off right. We got a variety of dishes and everyone seemed to really enjoy it. It took me a really long time to narrow down what I wanted. I ended up getting a pasta dish w/ alfredo style sauce and pancetta or bacon. It was rich and creamy! Also tried the tuna encrusted w/ sesame seeds and liked it a lot as well. Service was good. Food was good, Decor was beautiful. Prices were very fair. Pretty solid!

address: 11 Unity St #01-19/20 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: Once again in a week we went to wine connection for our late dinner. The food was great so was the hospitality. There signature stakes was wonderful and more in portion than expected.Hopefully I will be there again soon for a late night out.Taj

address: 11 Unity St #01-19/20 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: Lively bar with excellent wine choices. Staff are friendly and accommodating. Had the Cuvée Raphael with a cheese platter. Delicious. Great prices and ambience. This will become a regular place for me!!

address: 11 Unity St #01-19/20 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: This place has really gone down hill. Food used to be good. Now it's tired and off. For the prices they charge service was terrible. When i mention to asst manager. His comeback was "didn't they bring the food to the table " staff is clueless as to what service is , not through their fault, management hasn't trained them properly. And given the response of asst manager I can see why. I will not be returning there again. Judging by how the place has gone downhill I wouldn't be surprised if they were out of business soon . So hurry down if you want substandard food and service. They may not be around much longer. The location is the only positive thing I can say. It's a real shame I always looked forward to eating there.

address: 11 Unity St #01-19/20 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: Best value for money for a drinks and a food place in Singapore. Ambience is great as well. And the crowd is trendy.Love the tapas options at $5 each and the house wine options too. Huge restaurant but still difficult to get a place on a weekend. Shows the popularity.I think we need more options like these in Singapore.

address: 11 Unity St #01-19/20 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: I met a dear Friend who recently moved to Singapore for a glass of wine at Wine Connection. If I have said it once, I have said it 1,000 times, "Alcohol is expensive in Singapore!" We all know this and unfortunately I feel like I am becoming slightly numb to it (that is actually scary by the way!). Wine Connection is a breath of fresh air. They have an extensive list of house pours, none of which break the bank. My favourite type of wine is a nice, robust Red Zinfandel. I have found that Red Zins are difficult to find in Asia. Typically if you do find one it is only by the bottle and ridiculously expensive. Wind Connection offers a glass of 7 Deadly Zins at $11 SGD a glass! For that reason alone they are FIVE stars in my book! In addition to a great menu the service was excellent. The atmosphere is also great! Needless to say, I will be back!

address: 11 Unity St #01-19/20 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: I've eaten here maybe 10 times, I am very familiar with the service, the place, the menu ect. This review is probably one of those that people will read as "well it's an outlier, you always get those when you own a restaurant". Well my response would be that a restaurant is only tested through their handing of issues, and their interaction with their customers, not when someone rates 5 starts for ordering a glass of wine, which requires no thought, I don't feel this is representational of the restaurants ability to serve, and thus earn their 5 star rating. Let me explain what happened and you can judge for yourself.Typical night out to dinner and drinks, a few bottles of cheap wine and some apps and mains. My wife orders spaghetti, and it was too spicy for her taste. Easy enough, right? We asked the waiter if we could order something else, we told him that the dish was too spicy, he said ok and we ordered something else. Like any normal restaurant, with any normal level of service, you would expect the spaghetti removed from the bill, replaced with the new item, right? Wrong.I thought they forgot, so I reminded them. This is where their true colors came out. "Sir, as stated on the menu, we only allow a switch if there is exactly one bite, but your wife had more then one bit." Well I guess I can't say that I am surprised as in Singapore if there is a rule, there is no exception. After explaining that the spaghetti probably cost them under $1, and that any normal restaurant would remove the $12 item from a $300 bill, they insisted that a $300 bill is their normal check value and my wife "ordered incorrectly" as it states spicy on the menu. So after refusing to remove the item, spending 5 minutes explaining their one bite policy, and accusing my wife of ordering incorrectly, I admittedly lost it.  I could not comprehend what was going on, it turned into a scene and ruined our night. I'll add that finally they removed the item, as I think they knew by that time I was not going to back down.You, as a restaurant, are not selling me $12 spaghetti, you are selling me the experience of a nice night out, you are selling me your customer experience and in turn I am spending my night, filling your seat. Well here is the ultimate lesson for you, if, by me writing this review, it is preventing at least 1 person from spending $12 at your restaurant, then your one bite policy, and your disrespect for the customer has lost you money, and I have succeeded.

address: #01-12, Robertson Walk, 11 Unity Street Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: Always on the lookout for quality Mediterranean offerings, I had the chance to try out Cappadocia at the recommendation of a scholar working on Mediterranean history. I was most impressed by the appetisers (hummus, leaf-wrapped finger foods). They were done with finesse and presented impeccably. I wasn't too enthused about the kebab mains that I had: it was not particularly memorable, although the portion was generous and the chicken was juicy and tender inside. A decent entree.The meatball with spaghetti can be an utter mess once you get into it, although the flavour of the meat cannot be faulted. The spaghetti was so-so, with the tomato sauce needing a little more seasoning. I would recommend you come for the appetiser platters: try as many as you can, and bring a lot of friends along! The prices are reasonable for such nice ambience and food.
