address: UE Square 207 River Valley Road #01-75 Singapore 238275 Singapore
comment: Excellent AYCE sushi dinner buffet! Like most AYCE places, the sushi is not top tier but good enough. Buffet includes crab hot pot, sirloin steak, meat skewers, whole squid, maki, good sides and decent desserts. The value really cannot be beaten and the service was also excellent, even during the weekend rush when the kitchen was overloaded.$52pp on Fri/Sat. Slightly cheaper during the week.

address: UE Square 207 River Valley Road #01-75 Singapore 238275 Singapore
comment: My friend and I were hungry and looking for a place...pronto!walked upon this place in the Robertson Quay with all its specials and deals on a banner.Restaurant was clean and had a business-like restaurant appeal.Server gave us the lunch special menu and as we looked over the menu things seemed pretty expensive for what you got, but we were hungry....so it didn't matter. Once the server came over, I asked about their "All you can eat Shabu deal"....then he comes out with 3 other menus with all the other deals/specials...that were much better. WTF right???Long story short, we got the "All you can eat shabu/japanese small dishes" dealWe devoured:- A plate of pork and beef shabu- Tuna handroll- Chicken karage- Miso soup- Butter asparagus- Fried prawns- Thai beef salad- Pork cutlet- Chicken gizzard- green tea ice cream(Much much more on the menu too)All this was $42 per person. Sounds expensive? When you compare it with their other entrees and "combos"....you're only $10 away from getting all of this endlessly.Overall, service was friendly...but should've given us all the specials/deals menu in the get-go. Clean and and would recommend if you are really hungry.

address: UE Square 207 River Valley Road #01-75 Singapore 238275 Singapore
comment: 4 adults and 1 11-year-old kid, but all were charged for adult all-can-eat on a Monday night for $56 each.The shabu shabu beef here was more tender than all the wagyu beefs I've ever tried in my entire life - no matter how we cooked it, it's still very tender :PAll other food we ordered was good in quality and portion size for many, but not so much if your party is too small to try most thing in their extensive menu.Service was slow and not easy to flag one down even though we sat near the servers.4 very bad things here are:- 5 people sharing one small pot for shabu shabu X(- not price friendly :/- sashimi was cut too small and too thin to eat heartily :(- the sink in the restroom would wet you.  Really bad design.

address: UE Square 207 River Valley Road #01-75 Singapore 238275 Singapore
comment: This is a review of a Thursday evening dinner date at Z'en Japanese Cuisine.The room is a combination of Japanese aesthetic and modern classic design.  The space  includes several nice design elements but the ceiling is probably the accent that stands out the most.  tinyurl.com/bp85nj2While not full, the restaurant was busy.  There appears to be three sitting areas, outdoors, lower level indoors (our seating area), and upper level indoors.Z'en has an extensive menu and it took us quite awhile to determine what we were going to order.The service was relatively good.  For the most part, the staff was attentive.   There were some gaps where they were not really checking in.  The staff was professional and polite but not extremely friendly.  The most significant negative was the pacing of the meal.   We were two people sitting at a four top.  There should have been plenty of room for food.  However, almost all of the food arrived within the same short time period.  We ordered quite a bit of food.  It was overwhelming.  There wasn't enough space.  Plus, along with the other dishes, we were managing shabu shabu.  The staff was not overly proactive in quickly clearing the plates we had finished.   There should have been some thought put into how the dishes were timed.  The food ranged from good to extremely good.   The presentation for their dishes was quite appetizing.Sushi - We ordered a wide range of sashimi and nigiri.  It was all very good.  The seafood was fresh.  The sushi was well-prepared.  My favorite was the swordfish. The flavour was extremely delicate.Mekajiki (Swordfish) Sashimi tinyurl.com/cehd94oMaguro (Tuna) & Avocadotinyurl.com/cwleltsMixed Plate (we selected) - Ebi (Shrimp), Saba (Mackerel), Uni (Sea Urchin), Blue Fin (for her - I choose not to eat Blue Fin tuna)tinyurl.com/d7cl9t2Wafu Sakoro Beef - I really enjoyed this dish.  I can think of no better way to describe than a Japanese version of country friend steak with mashed potatoes.  There were nuggets of breaded steak placed on top of mashed potatoes.  The seasoning was amazing.  The meat was tender with the slight crunch of the breading.  I could eat this everyday.tinyurl.com/d2y6e6jTempura Mori - This was a mixed tempura.  It was actually very good.  I also enjoyed the sauce provided for this.  When served, the tempura was hot and crisp.  I particularly enjoyed the mushrooms.Unfortunately, it was served during the full flurry of dishes. It was pushed to a far corner of the table making it difficult for either of us to try it.  We did manage to work around and eat most of it.  But, with everything else, by the time we ate it, much of the tempura had cooled.tinyurl.com/cwaostmShabu Shabu - First, since this was brought overlapping everything else, it was very difficult to manage the cooking process.  It was quite good but because of timing we kept slightly overcooking the meat.  Their version of the standard shabu shabu dip was divine.tinyurl.com/cujb3tltinyurl.com/d94sgg7Salmon Kama (jawbone) - They were out of the hamachi kama.  We decided on the salmon.  This was my first time having salmon kama.  I must admit this was probably the one dish too far.  We had ordered a lot of food.  I did try it and it was extremely good.  The fish was so tender and flaky.  We did not come close to finishing this dish.tinyurl.com/cl2x95cAlong the way, I pretty much lost my bottle of sake.  While keeping up with all of the food, I just didn't have time to keep pouring.  I think I drank less than half of it.Receipt ($272.20)tinyurl.com/d6qhplhDuring this review, I have commented numerous times on the timing of the meal.  However, it was egregious.  This should have been an enjoyable relaxed dining experience where we could truly savor their very delicious food.  However, it was not.  It was a race to try the dishes and complete them while they were still at their peak.Overall - The food was very good.  With the exception of the pacing and some lapses in attentiveness, the service was good.  The room is quite comfortable with a warm and inviting feel and impressive modern design elements.  This could have been a four or five star experience.  In the end though, it fell short.

address: UE Square 207 River Valley Road #01-75 Singapore 238275 Singapore
comment: My favorite Japanese restaurant when it comes to shabu shabu, Zen Japanese offers high quality ingredients at reasonable prices. While I come mainly for the shabu shabu steamboat, I recommended getting the baked oyster and soft shell crab maki as notable additions from the menu as they taste really good. Both service and the overall ambience is very good. Have been here many times and will continue to go as it is very good value for the beautiful and tender beef!

address: UE Square 207 River Valley Road #01-75 Singapore 238275 Singapore
comment: Came here when we were searching for a good sushi place by Robertson Walk / Quay so that there would be good ambience and people watching.  Saturday night, the food was pretty good (we were eating sashimi and lighter fare), both indoor and outdoor seating.  When we arrived around 9pm, it was as if they were short a waitron or two.  Had to ask for water, then ice, then more water, then soy sauce, etc.  After the first few minutes, I thought we were going to be waiting for our food til midnight, but much to my surprise, the rest of the meal was appropriately paced.  They forgot one dish.  I didn't pick up the tab so don't know how much it was, but I got the sense from the menu that it was over $200 for 4 of us with two of us not eating that much.Still looking for that clutch sushi joint by Robertson Quay...

address: UE Square 207 River Valley Road #01-75 Singapore 238275 Singapore
comment: We all know that the Clarke Quay, River Valley and Robertson areas are big on Japanese food. But little did i know i've been missing out on the biggest in-plain-sight gem, Z'en Japanese Cuisine, for so long. I've walked past (and even through) this restaurant at UE Square too many times and i can't believe i never considered going in. Z'en (a sister outlet of En Japanese Dining Bar) is run by executive chef, Masashi Yasui from Kyoto. You'll be dizzy with choices just looking at the a la carte buffet menu (64 items in total) and there are a lot more in the main one. I would highly recommend the buffet for the quality items and reasonable price. Buffet prices are listed at the end of the post and it's cheaper to go on weekends (i don't know why but i'm not complaining). I was looking forward to lots of Shabu shabu after a recent authentic meal. Z'en serves both the beef and chicken shabu shabu. Needless to say, we went for the Australian Wagyu beef (200g for $39). The meat isn't sliced very thin and that took a while to cook on the portable stove but it was quite delicious with the ponzu sauce. Remember to ask for the peanut one too! We had at least 10 plates of this. Very nice and not too bad marbling.Other than shabu shabu, other items include some sushi and salmon sashimi. The pieces of sashimi are very small (1/4 the regular size). It's easier to order a few more sets at a go. I wasn't expecting very high quality sashimi anyway so it met my expectations. The Aburi salmon sushi was nice too with small amounts of rice and the salmon was nicely torched. We gave the rest of the sushi a miss to save our stomach space. Of course the rice and noodles section was left unordered. If you must, try the Zuwai Chahan with gravy (Crab Fried Rice, mui fan style, S$23).From the Grilled Dishes, you mustn't miss the Sirloin Steak with ponzu sauce (200g for S$32). This was perfectly grilled to a tender pink and when it was served, we simply ignored the shabu shabu. This is THE DISH to eat. The fried garlic at the side were irresistible and went well with the meat. For moo moo lovers, do order the Stir Fried Tenderloin Beef cubes with mashed potatoes as well (we forgot about it)The boys loved the Grilled Squid (S$13) and Baked Oysters as well. Not too rubbery, nicely grilled and rather fresh. There are some skewers and grilled fish on the menu but we gave that a miss.From the fried section, i adored the Cream Crab Croquette (4pcs for S$10), Ebi Tempura (3pcs for S$13) and Age Gyoza (5pcs for S$10). The Agedashi Tofu (S$10) wasn't too bad either as it cleanses the palette with its light broth.Desserts weren't that fantastic but i ate some anyway. You need a sweet end to every meal. Skip the chocolate and vanilla ice cream. The green tea one is a little too milky as well. The Tofu cheesecake and Creme Brulee were adequate in taste and texture. There were many dishes that we didn't try but we were very happy with most of the items which we had. The boys were quite happy with my restaurant choice, even the picky W. I will probably be back when my Shabu craving kicks in again. Service was a little slow and they have the tendency to forget your orders so place more in advance. Wastage is charged though so don't over-order!Now for the buffet prices: Weekday Lunch (S$38++)Weekday and Eve of PH Dinner: S$52++Weekend and PH Dinner: S$48++Make a reservation! It's very popular. Pictures and more reviews available on my blog. Check it out.

address: UE Square 207 River Valley Road #01-75 Singapore 238275 Singapore
comment: Great value for a meal in singapore. Loved all the small plates. Good quality and unlimited!   Sirloin beef, salmon sashimi, agadashi tofu were all excellent.  Great for a group meal. I will definitely return.

address: UE Square 207 River Valley Road #01-75 Singapore 238275 Singapore
comment: Love the buffet. At almost $60 per person, I consider good value with high quality beef served up for shabu shabu and yummy desserts. Particularly the tofu cheesecake and coconut creme brûlée. With unlimited servings, it's a dream!

When you're craving for some American style Chinese comfort food and a flight to Australia for the next best thing is not in the cards, get your fix at Chop Suey, but prepare to pay up what the food you remember from back home in the US.High end service, well executed food and prices to match.Our favorite dish was the Crispy Orange Beef featuring tender strips of beef fried nicely and coated with orange flavored glaze.The Wok Breath Rice Noodle was nice as well as the sticky crunchy baby squid.Cocktails were tasty with appealing Asian accents, especially the Hot Lychee Margarita.PARTING THOUGHT: sooner or later we'll save enough room to finally try the desserts!

I attended the July UYE at Chop Suey Cafe today at 38 Martin Road and meet yelppers like lawrence, peter & gloria from USA as well as the local yelppers like Nik, Sonya, Ping etcThanks Sonya for arranging this brunch. The food is fantastic and great ambience ... oh my it's so relaxing. I had a great time today brunch-ing with all the lovely people.This cafe serve American Chinese cuisine, i ordered a smoke duck with herb omelette and the portion serve is big and it's really tasty. I expect the smoke duck to be placed on top the omelette but it caught my surprise. The smoke duck is wrap within the omelette and it's placed above the toast with alittle veg & marmalade garnish on top of it and the sides dish is 2 roasted tomatoes and mushroom.Oh my ..... I never regret ordering this ..... It's simply delicious and I'm really full.  BLURP! I envy those people who stay around here .... They have nice cafe around the vicinity and you people are so lucky.Tumbs up ...... I will recommend my friends to visit ......

Chopsuey is an Asian-American fusion restaurant that also serve brunch. They have an elaborate menu so everyone can have their pick. I got their duck omelet from their brunch menu and it was a generous amount with juicy sides - tomato and mushroom infused with delicious herby sauce. The duck was very well cooked and flavorful. The bread that came with the omelet was the downside of the meal - it was dry and did not serve a purpose at all. In fact, it absorbed a large portion of the moisture from the omelet. I also got to try their French bean in Szechuan sauce - this is like your regular si ji dou - except cooked with lots of flavor. Highly recommended to fulfill your vege of the day! Besides their food, their service was very friendly and food served in a timely manner. I would give this place a visit again, maybe to try their main dishes next time.
WE HAD AN AWESOME TIME.good food, nice people, and a beautiful space - what else could you ask for!

We're having an old friends get together at this restaurant. The food to say the least is "unusual" in that it's a fusion of Chinese and western. Whatever! But the bottom line is that it's interesting and the food is very flavorful. Definitely worth a visit especially if you've become jaded on the regular stuff. Arguably it is a little unhealthy in that we tried most of the fried stuff. But what can you say. Anything fried always tastes better. Sigh! Looks like a diet over the weekend. Anyhow I enjoyed the meal and company and will probably come again, this time with the family. Parking though is challenging so take a cab or plan well.

address: 81 Clemenceau Ave #01-15/16/17, UE Square Shopping Mall Singapore 239917 Singapore
comment: Super happy with their service staff; booked their private room for my overseas guests. They were really helpful and accommodating (my guests had a very strict diet). At the end of the dinner, my guests were raving about their food (they had steak) - they said it was the best steak they had in Singapore so far, and were really pleased with the quality of service they received!I will definitely be back here soon (especially since they have the cheese wheel pasta now), and would definitely recommend it to people!Just note that their private room may be a tad bit cosy if you have more than 10 guests in the room.

address: 81 Clemenceau Ave #01-15/16/17, UE Square Shopping Mall Singapore 239917 Singapore
comment: Went there on a Sunday for brunch with a group of friends. Liked that they are very accommodating to large groups. Plus there's a bouncy castle for children on sundays too. The prices are acceptable but options are boring tbh. Put together my own plate of "sides" - smoked salmon, sautéed mushrooms and sautéed garlicky spinach (a tad enthusiastic with oil but otherwise perfectly done)

address: 81 Clemenceau Ave #01-15/16/17, UE Square Shopping Mall Singapore 239917 Singapore
comment: Extremely quiet place on a Monday, just what we are looking for a girlfriends meetup. We made a reservation via chope for 2. Food portion is huge & taste good. They have a happy hour promotion for some drinks on a Monday at $6 each. We had 2 glasses of luis felipe cabernet sauvignon to go with hoegaarden battered fish & chips & goose confit. Both dishes are good in our opinion & bill comes up to $69.  Location of this restaurant is approximately 10 mins walk from clarke quay mrt. They serve brunch in daytime & heard that they welcome kids!

address: 81 Clemenceau Ave #01-15/16/17, UE Square Shopping Mall Singapore 239917 Singapore
comment: Nah lets move on all they serve is beer for Friday nights biggest profit margin in Singapore

address: 81 Clemenceau Ave #01-15/16/17, UE Square Shopping Mall Singapore 239917 Singapore
comment: If you frequent the Robertson area, you would probably have seen or heard about District 10 at UE Square. My impression was that it is a cool bar that does drinks and the usual bar grub and hence it piqued my curiosity when i was invited to brunch by the nice folks at District 10.When i stepped into the restaurant, i noticed that the decor has changed. The place is now bigger, brighter and certainly classier. We had the District 10 Eggs Benedict ($16). I was a little confused because they turned out to be Eggs Florentine. Anyhow, lovely poached eggs on fluffy toasted muffins with a nice crisp on the outside. I found that the hollandaise sauce was well balanced with the flavors from the sautéed spinach and smoked salmon.We had the interesting Pandan Coconut Pancake with Gula Melaka Syrup ($9) which tasted like the traditional Malay kuehs. The pancakes are on the dense and chewy end with crispy shredded coconut on top (the browned parts). I couldn't stop soaking the pancakes into the brown sugar syrup. Lovely. But only if you like kueh.Next, we moved on to the heavier items. The Hoegarden Battered Fish & Chips with mint mushy peas and tartare sauce ($22). The fish was satisfactory crisp but had its limelight stolen by the amazing natural cut fries. Hell they can be a main on their own. Love the salty batter! The District 10 Brunch Beef Burger ($20) comes paired with the fries too. Hooray! Charcoal-grilled Black Angus patties topped with fried egg, crispy back bacon, cheddar cheese on a sesame bun. You can never go wrong with the egg bacon cheese combination but i thought the patty was a little dry. Well, at least you know they don't use unknown cow bits in this one. Do not miss the thin crust pizzas by Italian Chef Luca Pezzera. Love the crust that crackles with each bite. The Portobello Mushrooms pizza ($26) with Portobello mushrooms and a generous serving of truffle oil on top was earthy and delicious.For something with a local twist, there's the Wagyu Beef Cheek Rendang pizza ($29). The meat was flavorful but somehow it was very gelatinous. The sauce however was pretty spot on for an Italian creating a local favorite. Thumbs up to Chef Luca but could we have more toppings please.

address: 81 Clemenceau Ave #01-15/16/17, UE Square Shopping Mall Singapore 239917 Singapore
comment: I have visited this restaurant twice and had two very different experiences.  The first was a couple months ago with a group of ladies eating appetizers and drinking cheap wine.  I really enjoyed the pizza and other food my friends ordered.  We got away with a cheap fun meal in a great atmosphere.  More recently I went for lunch and ordered a simple burger as did my other two companions.  One of the burgers came really underdone, with cheese, and was generally inedible.  Thus began four rounds of 'back to the kitchen' eventually ending in a take away box with a decent burger. Meanwhile my friend and I had finished our brugers which were good, not excellent.So lesson learned, visit this place in the evening.  Their day time game is not up to snuff.

address: 81 Clemenceau Ave #01-15/16/17, UE Square Shopping Mall Singapore 239917 Singapore
comment: I'm an American man visiting for work reasons.  First time was in April 2015. Was right across street from my hotel. Margarita pizza was fairly inexpensive and delicious. Expert preparation and cooking. Have been coming back ever since. Everything I have gotten so far has been nearly perfect and outstanding. I've had the calamari appetizer, ravioli, and lava cake most recently.  That 3 combo is the perfect dinner out for me. Don't forget to ask for some water with lemon when you eat here. They have a big bottle they will bring out to your table that is free. Environment is very pleasing with music playing, not too loud. Clean, modern, and inviting.  Half outdoors half indoors.  Staff are nice and polite.

address: Studio M Hotel No. 3 Nanson Road Singapore 238910 Singapore
comment: I decided to have breakfast here when I stayed at the hotel. It was served at the seating area - it functions as a breakfast area from 6:30am to 10:30am, normal cafe from then to the evening - and the bar starts functioning from 6pm to 1am. So, it is quite a good deal actually. I tried the breakfast, which was pretty okay. There's a general spread - cereal, noodles, fruits, salad, meat and cheese platter, soups, omelet station, etc.What I Love: It's got nice decor, and the omelet station was good. Food was nice. I had grilled vegetables and the omelet. The bacon was pretty yummy too (I kinda helped myself to quite a few servings of that). The coffee station was good - you could make your own - which I don't mind - as then, I can make it my own way. The vegetables were fresh - there were quite a few options and at least there were healthy options.What I Don't Love: The noodles looked like they were dipped and coated in oil. Ewwww. I shrugged it off. The Cafe is also pretty tiny. When you have quite a full hotel - you gotta have enough seats. So, I took my breakfast to the poolside to get privacy. There could be more options.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-05, The QuaySide Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Let's be real here people-- if you're looking for traditional Italian or New York style pizza. THIS IS NOT IT. That being said... this PIZZA IS BOMB AF!!!!!!I've been looking for great pizza since I moved to Singapore and this has definitely made my list. The sourdough crust is thin, has a great crunch on the outside but still doughy on the inside. The tomato sauce has an awesome taste and they don't skimp on the toppings, not even a little bit (I got the hangover pizza, no onions).Also, got the garlic bread and the homemade iced lemon tea FTW! I went to the Robertson Quay location and honestly, the only thing that could have made my experience better would be: more comfortable seating. The chairs are fine but a booth would be better haha :)

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-05, The QuaySide Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Whenever I travel to Singapore, I always make sure to stay away from the "American" foods like pizza. But sometimes you just that craving, well I do at least. Heard a lot about this place from my co-workers, and they usually recommend pretty good places to eat.With pizza selections like "The Hangover", "Truffle Shuffle", and "Hipster", you know you're in for something a little different. Trying to make myself feel like I was being a little healthier I started with the Baby Spinach Salad, which was really good. A great vinaigrette with very fresh tasting ingredients. This was probably large enough to be a meal in itself, but being the glutton and truffle head that I am, I decided to also order the Truffle Shuffle.The pizza is a thin crust and about the size of a medium domino's pizza. The Truffle Shuffle's roasted mushrooms, onions, and truffle oil were the stars of the pizza. If it wasn't for the salad, I would have easily polished off the whole pizza.Definitely a must try if you are craving some pizza. I will be back again to try the other pizzas!

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-05, The QuaySide Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Nice little pizza outlet in a mall with open seating. Pizzas were great. Garlic bread was delicious. Service was quick and friendly. Couldn't ask for more!

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-05, The QuaySide Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: It had been A G E S since I last had pizza. My husband and I were in the Suntec area and decided to give this place a try. Food - We had the "old school" pizza (handmade NY-style cheese & basil) with cheddar fries. I was surprised to find bits of tomatoes in my fries. It was ok, couldn't say it was mind-blowing. My husband really enjoyed the pizza; he finished the entire thing by himself. I, on the other hand, wasn't much of a fan. It felt dry and wasn't cheesy/greasy enough for my liking. Service - You have to indicate your order on a checklist, which was useful. The staff were friendly, no complaints.Atmosphere - it wasn't as busy as I'd expected considering it was a Saturday. BUT $6 for bottled water, really?

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-05, The QuaySide Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: They have a buy 1 get 1 free pizza at this location. Dine in only. Pizza is ok. With that deal it's good for the price.I think this place is good for families.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-05, The QuaySide Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Dropped by after going to SPRMKT for dinner because I was violently unfulfilled by the salad I had there.Service was nothing to shout about but the PIZZA OMG THE PIZZAAAAAAA. Also, Super fast baking time for the pizza. So - Yes, I say most definitely yes. I don't care for their drinks but the pizza is gooooooood. Period.

address: 60 Robertson Quay #01-05, The QuaySide Singapore 238252 Singapore
comment: Always been a huge fan of Alt Pizza, having first tried it at their Suntec Branch. It's a bit of a copy cat of Extra Virgin Pizza, but nevertheless it's really good gourmet pizza joint.My favorite Pizzas are the (i) truffle shuffle, (ii) crabby ninja - reminds me of my times in Maryland, given the use of Old Bay Seasoning and (iii) the Hangover - a crowd favorite!The Robertson Quay branch is perfectly located in the middle of Expat friendly neighborhood of River Valley. Pizza's range between $15-$19. It is much larger location than both the Suntec and Katong branches and is perfect lunch spot for those living in the area and doing some people watching.It is of note that the One-for-One Pizza deal is available to all Alt Pizza locations, but is for a limited time only. I wouldn't be surprised if the promotion has already ended. All in all, a fantastic place to get pizza, if you are willing to spend approx, $20 per person. I would say the food quality/taste of the pizzas at Robertson Quay branch is as good as than one in Suntec and better than the Katong branch. :-)

Meh. Add the price plus service and I land at meh. Bacon appetizer was reheated and not fresh cooked, temp was not hot. If your going to charge 12$ a slice for bacon it should be fresh cooked. My salad order was wrong and had to go back to the kitchen. Steak was good (not great)Creamed spinach was warm not hot. I expected allot more from Wolfgang. He usually delivers (at other locations ) the goods but not today.

Ambience: not much, just a big room with lots of tables, not much privacy. Very different compared to other steak houses, more like a bistro than an upmarket steak house.Food: not spectacular, had better steaks at competitor.Service: needs more polishing, though one or two waiters were very good.

The food at both restaurants is very good. The differences are mainly in terms of style, and you see that in décor AND service: (Although it is located in a shopping mall) Cut is more formal, while Wolfgang (located in a '5-star-minus' hotel) is friendlier and more relaxed. Normally, I find the 'standard' piece of beef and two sides the maximum food I can gulp down in a meal. Unlike Cut, Wolfgang is open for lunch, so you have the option of having the same cuts of steak but in smaller sizes, and thus able to enjoy more of the restaurant's offerings; in this regard , the set lunch (comprising 3 appetisers, a salad or soup, a steak, 2 sides, dessert, and coffee/tea) is extremely good value. The accompaniments are good but not exceptional; the steaks are the real thing. Our party ordered and shared the Cajun rib eye, tenderloin and petit filet mignon. They're all very succulent and irreproachably satisfying. The wine list caters to various tastes and purses. So, Both Wolfgangs are to be commended - Mozart at two different stages of life. Unless you want a very high-end dining experience (but then, why steaks?), Wolfgang seems to be the better (and more economic) choice.

when one utters the name wolfgang, a swift and somewhat automatic chime in will most likely come in the form of puck?enter the other wolfgang......................zwiener!a man who brings with him 4 decades worth of experience from honing his skills at peter luger's.a distinguished gentleman i had the honour of indulging in a wefie with. i am just so glad he has injected much needed competition into the stale steakhouse scene and now this is a cut above the rest in all but it's prices.i like how bright and airy this traditional and classic setting is.i was swarmed by wait staff during dinner service and maybe half strength at lunch, in any case you will not find attention lacking.it coud be more polished but i'm sure they will in due time.the top 2% usda quality beef coupled with their humidity controlled in house dry ageing process means elation to your palate.their specialty is the porterhouse cut which i had at dinner.i left wanting to try their ribeye as that is my measure of a good steakhouse.try i did at lunch but i have yet to reach a conclusive verdict and will reserve final judgement for when i finally try their dinner ribeye cut.nevertheless they still secure top spot thus far.just like in the states, the doneness is mostly under.so a medium is akin to a medium rare especially for the bone in cuts.lobster bisque can be apportioned and shared, making for double the happiness.their namesake salad is what i would also recommend, a good combination of flavours from smokey thick cut bacon, warm grilled shrimp, caramelized peppers, sharp onions, beefy tomatoes, crunchy long beans and leafy lettuce.the crab cake does not look the part but this is where the old adage, do not judge a book by it's cover, comes in.not overly crumbed, not overly minced but chunky sweet crab meat that will please the fussy.cream spinach is just another one of those must have. no cream is used but the oh so smooth texture of that spinach, slurp it like baby food!the wine cellar and bar area looks impressive enough for sealing any million dollar business deals.i'll come back for a tipple or two, just with you!for now, remember the name wolfgang................zwienerthere is a new steak sheriff in town!

They don't have the best burger in the world, But they had the best burger i have never had in Singapore(actually better than some of the place in the US).I've been to both locations many times: The Foundry(now closed) and PigsFly.Yea, sounds confusing, they are not a restaurant, they are more like a mini food court with 4-5 different kitchen.I loved their burger even fries were good!! The burger just so tasty and juicy, cooked just right when you bite, it just melt in mouth:PHighly re-commanded for those who crave a good burger in Singapore!

Went to the location at Changi Business Park Crescent. They seasoned the fries and burger nicely, but the patty was under cooked, the meat you could tell was too moist when it was on the fire or prepped causing it to be mushy, and the excess moisture that was held in the patty squeezed out as you ate it making it a slippery mess. If it wasn't for the seasoning, I would give it one star.

the best new japanese restaurant in my books!outdoing yet another japanese restaurant in the robertson quay area that i have been wanting to but have yet to review.this restaurant will get a star, there, i hope i don't jinx them!but in all seriousness, looking at the way michelin dishes them out, esora ticks all the boxes.it's one of those places that you just can't wait to write a yelp review for!:)a holistic approach that delivers an experience, being same but different. attention to details, no sauce, garnish too insignificant. where the inclusion or exclusion of which changes, enhances or detracts.the perfect balance that doesn't overwhelm nor leave your keen senses feeling deprive.service, ah yes, a crucial component of that experience.a friendly, well informed and cross trained team that works in sync, flowing as one, the strength of each making the sum of parts stronger.exquisite but not just a pretty face.from the pieces of cutlery and dining ware, to the presentation and plating.you think you have seen it all but then they deliver more.yes, the food will speak for itself.flavours exploding via umami bombs!techniques, if you ask, will be gladly shared verbally.showcasing the best produce they can procure in the regions where they thrive.no dish will taste the same, as each has a complex twist.the "what is that, in a good way" smells fill the room and lifts the anticipation to the next level, whilst your palate waits.pacing is even as the machinery grinds into full gear when all lucky reserved guests showed up.wow, i expected nothing less and they delivered plenty more, a wonderful and complete experience that made for a perfect anniversary celebration!thank you, next........am so glad summer is coming when menu will be changing and esora will be blowing me away, again!

Our last late dinner in Singapore and it was an average Chinese restaurant at that. We had a late  dinner so we were starving. We were seated and asked us what we wanted already. We asked to give us a few minutes. Once the lady server heard us speak English, she left right away and the owner came inside as he spoke our language a little.There were a few locals inside only. We asked to give us another few minutes as we were not sure what to order yet.We ordered:Kangkong large $20 - good Sweet  & sour pork large $20 - good but was heavily breadedLala medium $18 - this was ok and more like baked clams in sauce than a supposed soupBbq pork ribs $20 - ok but it was fatty and a few bones. Sauce was overpowering. This seems more like a sautéed pork than a bbq.Rice was good and cheap for a dollar each.We ordered Chinese tea to share. It was ok.For Chinese food, this was pretty expensive and average taste. I've had  better in other  areas of Singapore. We finished our food but we didn't want to go somewhere far and we were starving. Minus a star on food quantity, there was no service and being very expensive. They didn't provide napkins and didn't seem to want to provide it. I didn't want to ask as they might charge us like another restaurant.  Sorry but I would go somewhere else to eat good Chinese good somewhere else like the hawker centers. [39/100]

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-12/13, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: Hot tea no refill, and not notify until ask for more tea. Food is worse than foodcourt standard. Staff very unfriendly as if I own them 100million. Will never come again and encourage no one to come ever.

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-12/13, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: I used Yelp to reserve but was told when I arrived at the restaurant that they do not use Yelp to take reservation. Only after showing some displeasure did they squeeze 4 of us a table for 1hr. Wanted to order the 3 meat buffet but like the other reviewer was complaining, they did not offer. However, the top grade wagyu was available for add-on order. I wonder if this is just a gimmick to attract customers. Service was slow as one of the Japanese staff said three of the staff did not turn up due to sickness. It turned out that three of the Japanese staff were on the floor taking orders. Not easy to understand but I suppose they have mostly Japanese customers so only the non-Japanese customers are having some communication problems. Would I be keen to go back again? Probably not.

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-12/13, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: What a disappointment and a shame to this restaurant. First of all they do not serve the three meats shabu shabu, who knows why, despite the fact it is on the menu!!!!! But the service was the worst I ever experienced. After all they do charge you 10% service charge!!!! A restaurant to forget...

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-12/13, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: Best Shabu Shabu I've ever had. 45 SGD per person for the buffet the food deserves 5*. However it was very hard to get the servers attention to order anything. I can totally recommend the sukiyaki base for Shabu Shabu. The Japanese curry at the buffet was also delicious.

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-12/13, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: A little meh. We bought the deal.com.sg coupon with free flow of Wagyu and Spanish pork for around SGD50+ (after adding service charge and GST). Turns out that the coupon was not much cheaper than for walk-in customers. The default soup stock is that very light Japanese style "watery broth", but you get to switch to chicken stock, sukiyaki, etc. for just $3. I thought the beef was a letdown. Kinda dry. The pork was much better. All in all, unless you are a big eater, I don't think the buffet was a great deal. I've definitely had better beef...

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-12/13, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: Went there for dinner over the weekend. Had their pork shabu shabu set which came with thin slices of pork meat and bacon, and a large plate of veges, mushrooms, and noodles (bought my food voucher from Groupon at $12 for 2 pax. Had to say this is a very good deal). Nice ambient with the option of sitting indoor or outdoor. I went there on a Sunday evening and the service was slow though. Other than that, everything was excellent. Fresh and tasty food. Would definitely go there again.

With the promise of delicious steaks and free-flow fries ahead, I could barely hide my excitement when taking a seat amongst Les Bouchons' auburn honey dining room. Although the setting is white linen tablecloths and classically French, there were no glares from fellow patrons or staff as three old friends gathered and joked nearly as much as they ate. The Os A Moelle/Bone Marrow with Toast is the must order Entree ($18) - definitely some of the best bone marrow I've ever had! Make sure you order an extra serve of thin, crisp toast too - the warm and springy rolls from the bread basket just don't do this dish justice! As far as Steaks go, I thoroughly enjoyed the Grilled Rib Eye with Vigneron Butter ($38.80) and Grilled Sirloin with Herbs ($38.80) - it was very classic and kept simple to highlight the steaks, which were both cooked to a perfect medium rare. The house made fries are so crisp and moreish, but ironically enough - we were so full that we gave the endless supply a miss. The only disappointment was the Créme Caramel Maison ($12) which was all booze and no caramel crackle - which, in my opinion, is the best part of a créme caramel! Be prepared to spend a little over $60/pp for three courses but I'd definitely pop by again for just the steaks alone.I highly recommend enjoying the sights and sounds of the scenic walk back into Clarke Quay after a hearty meal at Les Bouchons - there's no better way to work off those juicy calories, then to enjoy good company in the cool evening breeze!

When it comes to Entrecote-style steak places I tend to do in with very low expectations... so with that in mind, I wasn't exactly 'disappointed' with Les Bouchons Rive Gauche.Let's talk about the good first. The steaks are generally excellent value. The amount of meat you're getting for the price you pay? Plus free flow fries? And deliciously crisp and fluffy fries at that? It's a great place for the hungry meat eater.The desserts are HUGE. We had... something. It was a sundae of chocolate and vanilla and it was delicious chocolate sauce (the real stuff, not chocolate-flavoured nonsense), ice cream, and basically it fed four already very full people quite comfortably.Why just two stars after that though?Our steaks were all underdone. We ordered one rare, two medium rare, and one medium, and I think I can safely say that they were all roughly one step under-cooked. My rare was closer to blue, but that's splitting hairs really and overall I was happy with it. The medium rares and mediums though, those were noticeably undercooked. When a medium steak still has slightly translucent glossy bits of meat, that's definitely underdone. The beurre cafe de Paris was absent, and while some other (not very tasty) butter was provided instead, they was definitely a little stingy with it.Beyond the steak, the terrine was possibly one of the worst, worst worst terrines I've had in my life. Yes, including the ones you buy from a supermarket, or the ones you find in an international buffet. This one was barely edible, and I'd highly recommend you give it a miss.So after all that, would I still recommend Les Bouchons? Sure.Great value steak, great fries, and wonderful desserts. Recipe for a good evening here: skip the starters, order your steak slightly overcooked because it'll turn up undercooked (net result = just right) and then use the remaining space to have one of their gigantic desserts to yourself.I might go back... except none of the people that i went with want to.
Just booked a table for tomorrow. No clue why some report the location as closed. Yelp please correct. Thanks

This was the first French restaurant i went to and was a good exposure for my taste buds, quite tantalising food. I normally like to eat steak and it was one of the better medium priced steaks I had eaten in Singapore. They serve free flow of fries along with the meals and the bread there is excellent as well, a good way to stop you from eating more fries.Ambience was quite good because it was facing the river and you could eat and chit chat and chill out facing the water. One of the things that turned me off was the service and it was really bad. The restaurant opens on the dot and even if you were early the manager and waitresses would just stare at you until it is time for opening.The service rendered was terrible and the staffs were very arrogant and had no idea what customer service is. I would go back to the place probably after awhile but definitely not too often.

The outdoor seating by the river is a great experience in itself. In addition the food is pretty good! But best of all is the wine selection. The pesec leognan wine was a perfect combination with the salmon. The salad and the fries were very good as well. The waiter knew the wine and the food pairing and made a great suggestion! I am definitely coming back again!

Came down for a company dinner based on recommendation from a colleague. If you are need a good amount of meat, maybe with some sides, maybe with some wine, but meat, more importantly - this is the place for you.There was a number of us so we got various cuts along with a grilled meat platter. We ended passing our different cuts of meats around - not quite the best of dining habits but 'twas good to be able to try the different cuts for starters. I liked the slight charred taste to their steaks, which adds a nice kick to the bite. My lamb was unfortunately just that bit too rare for my liking but otherwise, the beef is good. You may get tempted by fanciful sounding other names on the menu (like I did) but just get your favourite cut and you can't go wrong. Test it out with the different sauces - mustard, honeygrain mustard, etc.Now that we got the meat part aside, you get to start your meal with unlimited buns. You also get unlimited salads and frites to go with your steaks. They were good, but the steaks stole the show. We didn't go for refills in the end. Expect to fork out around $60/pax. Quite alright if you're looking to indulge. I've read a couple of compaints about the service. Though the staff was quite alright, just wish they didn't make it like it was a bad thing not to wine with the steak. I mean, all I wanted was just meat.

I should have followed my first instinct when there was no answer at Les Bouchons when I called at 5pm to reserve a table inside....We arrived on a balmy, but clear skied Tuesday night around 7pm and found the outside tables very nice. When asked if we had a reservation I said we had tried but there was no answer......before I could finish speaking...the Chinese Singaporean Maitre'd said that was ok, there were plenty of tables outside. We said wonderful we would take a table outside and I mentioned I would like to see the inside just for my curiosity.  I was body blocked at the doorway and told we had to "go outside, go outside, go outside.....no tables inside"....The wait staff looked sheepish and so we began our dining experience at Les Bouchons Rive Gauche....The menu is as other reviewers have described. Beef steaks of various cuts and sizes. A marinated lamb dish is also available. We passed on desserts based on previous reviews. All reasonably priced. The wine list of 10 whites and 10 reds is adequate but as expected, weighted to European names. We ordered 2 Ribeyes, a caprese salad, accompanied by a 3rd Cru Pomerol Bordeaux listed as a 2010 vintage. The waitress brought the wine, showed me the label from about 6 feet away. I asked if she could bring it closer and immediately saw it was a 2002. 12 years in the bottle would have only detracted from this wine and I asked if she had the the 2010 as listed. More puzzled looks, more explanations, another offer to pour this vintage "at the same price" .. More discussion on why I didn't want the 2002 and after determining they did not have a 2010, I asked if she could please bring the wine list back. We eventually had a wonderfully similar 2012 St Emillion. The steaks and frites were fine. This establishment could be between a 3 and 4 stars based on its food, improvements in its wine list, its location and the fit out. But from my experiences with many Singaporean restaurants with heavy tourist traffic, the evening is ruined by poorly trained front staff and a constant push to turn over the tables quickly while playing Russian roulette with what wine is poured.

The steaks here are good and value for money. The sirloin and ribeye that I tried were done to the right doneness and came with a heap of yummy fries.Pleasant ambience and service. Definitely worth a try if you are craving some steak!

Came here with high expectations because of the good reviews but was quite disappointed. I had the rib eye steak which was quite good but the fries are burnt. My partner had the Normandy steak but there was nothing special about it other than the portion was huge. I would actually recommend just getting the rib eye. We had creme brûlée  for dessert and was not impressed at all. The sugar on top was too thin and not burnt enough to have that crackling sound and taste and the custard was too soft. Comparing it with another french restaurant with the same theme, I prefer the other place more

Les Bouchon has become a tradition for my visits to Singapore. The food is great, probably the best place to get steak and fries in Singapore. Thanks to Sam who manages the place, the service has always been awesome!

Come here for the steak, and only the steak. Our ribeye medium rare was grilled to perfection. Some medium rares end up difficult to chew but Les Bouchons' was nothing but tender. Sadly, everything else is subpar. Avoid the escargot, which clearly wasn't fresh, and the cold hard bread.

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-02A, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: Went to Mondo Mio for the second time today because I believe in second chances and although the food was great, the staff and service were terrible. The first time we came after lunch they were one hr from closing and they were NOT happy to serve us but we decided to stay anyways, I am not a terrible person so we ordered quickly and ate super fast but they kept giving us mean looks and they practically took the plate away while I had food on my fork! I felt super rushed and we left within 45 mins. Today I went for dinner, was not greeted well and they CLEARLY stated they have pasta and pizza specials which is buy one and get one. I asked the waitress and she confirmed it and showed me on the menu, another waiter a male came and I confirmed again and we ordered pastas and drinks. They ignored us the rest of the time and when the bill came it was for the full amount with no special, I tried to call the waiter and he ignored me 3 times, finally he came and I showed him the bill he took it from my hand, did not let me finish my sentence and went to correct it which tells me he knew it was wrong the entire time. He was rude and I will certainly not go back.

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-02A, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: Took a detour to Singapore while travelling in Southeast Asia. Needed some nice pasta and meat!Were not disappointed. Had a cheese and ham platter - it might have been enough with that, but we also had a great rib eye and risotto.  No room for desert though. The restaurant is in a very romantic neighborhood - a stroll along the canal is perfect before and after.

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-02A, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: Fantastic food. And the staff very attentive which can sometimes be a challenge in Singapore eateries. Had seared scallops and fettuccine dam good. Maximo brings the Real Italian element. I will definitely make this place a staple on my list for Italian food in Singapore. Prices also commensurate with quality and service.

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-02A, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: Ughhh I am so conflicted writing this review. To be honest, everything BUT the food was good when we ate there this past weekend. We really liked the ambience, the service, and the crowd dining there, but the food was unfortunately underwhelming. The prices for wine by the glass are very reasonable. My prosecco cost less than $10 and you know how many places you have pay more than $12 for beer? I had the fettuccine with bacon and sundried tomato, my fiancé had this fusilli with pesto sauce and salmon. My sauce was way too salty and it was overall a very confusing flavor. My fiancé's dish came with maybe five measly small bites of salmon. The taste wasn't that much better than the presentation. If you just want to get couple glasses of wine and grab some light fare, maybe give it a shot. But don't expect too much of the food.

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-02A, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: This restaurant really took care of us, the food was great, the company equally as good, great atmosphere, the staff did a great job at containing the 12 of us in our supper club and never missed a beat with the wine.  Definitely a do over.

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-02A, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: I have been in Singapore for almost 10 days and this was the best meal, ambiance, and service combination! The attention from the staff was on point, the food was excellent well executed Italian, and the music actually fit to the cuisine of the restaurant. They were extremely friendly and made recommendations and the owner/manager specifically showed such love and care for his place. Will definitely recommend this place to others and will return when I make another visit! My tummy is so happy!!

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-02A, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: Very good Italian food.  I highly recommend the ravioli.  Great atmosphere and a great hang out to enjoy your glass of wine.Be sure to ask for a full glass or you will get only 1/6 th of a glass.  Great place to have dinner.

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-02A, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: Hate to do this but our meal at Mondo Mia was rather perfunctory. It's a rather drab looking joint but I'm willing to over look that since the likes of Da Luca have seen better days too. It strikes me as a neighborhood joint where you can pick up a pizza/pasta to go or dine in with a book if you felt like it. We sat facing the kitchen and there were no Italians in sight, which may or may not have been a warning bell because we've eaten at Indian-run Italian joints and they turn out decent pizzas. If you're a stickler for Italian-ness, there was some smarmy Italian music playing so there you go. We popped in here for a pre-theatre meal on Saturday.After we were shown to our table, we sat down and the waiter laid our table and placed a bottle of olive oil in the center. We expected some bread to appear since other tables had some but I guess our table fell though the cracks. We started our meal with one of the day's specials - burratina  with parma ham, salami and rocket leaves. This was the highlight of our meal as  the cheese was fresh (though a little sloppy even for a home made one) and went very well with the salty cold cuts and bitter leaves. My only gripe is that it cost more than our mains, but not a big deal. For mains, I had a crabmeat spaghetti with vodka sauce while the dude had an aglio olio. Both dishes were terribly bland, which is not something you'd expect with a vodka sauce or pasta tossed in spices. The aglio olio looked strikingly similar to a vongole as it had *some* garlic, no peperoncino or parsley, let alone some pecorino to top it off. You can imagine how much fun that was to consume.We paid about $70 for these 3 dishes and no wine, so I would definitely say that I've had better.

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-02A, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: Good quality cheese pizza. Feels like a good NY pizza pie as opposed to the standard fare. Others were enjoying their food too.

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-02A, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: A decent Italian restaurant compared to Prego and others.  But given that it's located in Robertson Quay, it offers lots of post-dinner activities as well as clean and not-so-crowded outdoor seats.Worth trying it but not the place I would recommend for the best Italian food

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-02A, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: Good quality cheese pizza. Feels like a good NY pizza pie as opposed to the standard fare. Others were enjoying their food too.

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: This is a nice location, right by the river. It has a relaxed atmosphere and friendly staff. The breakfast we had was a little expensive - $17 SGD each, but the portions are "Westernized" - they're a lot larger than other places.I like the coffee - my cappuccino was good. My girlfriend really liked her Earl Grey Lavender & Orange tea.This is a nice place to hang out and relax.

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: Right along the river...walking difference from severalHotels..we were at four points and found it handy..prices are pretty reasonable by Singapore standards...latte was really good...I had a bacon egg and cheese toast sandwich and it was only $6 and it was really good...wish they were open earlier for us jet lagged folks.

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: Excited to try the place. Woke early on a Sunday morning and looking for spot nearby to "break" my fast. I was happy to see that this cafe opened early and served simple breakfast that I'm looking for. Initial impressions are that the spot gets a lot of recurring business which is always a good sign.I ordered a pretty standard breakfast that I would fix at home in the states. Eggs, bacon and some wheat toast. They also had fresh juice, I had the watermelon. For lack of a better word, it was homey. Just what I was looking for. It wasn't anything extraordinary but the cafe gave me enough to want to come back and try out the specials. It looks like people were very keen on the Kith Coffee, so I need to come back and get that. I love the neighborhoody feel and the friendly service. I'll definitely come back and will be making this part of my breakfast go to places.

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: I was looking for a simple place to grab a quick bite of breakfast before I continued my exploration of Singapore, and I had walked past here the day before so I decided to check it out. I must say that it wasn't really the best place that I had visited here in Singapore, but then again you can't always expect to strike it lucky when exploring a new city. Okay, I do have to say that the staff were pretty good, but when I looked at the menu there really wasn't anything all that appealing. The place was pretty small, so all of the seats were outside, and while their coffee was okay, it wasn't the best. Mind you, the locals seem to quite like the place since there were always people gathering around here (usually mums with their strollers). However if I am ever back this way I'd probably give this place a miss.

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: Nice small breakfast restaurant visited mostly by foreigners due to their western style menu. Everything just tastes very good so this is definitely a 5 star rating. And the coffee tastes how coffee is supposed to taste. Not like the watery Starbucks coffee but very good quality coffee. You sit outside in the shade. There are newspapers to read and children can play.

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: I feel this cafe has good food potential and was certainly recommend. Coffee is quite strong which I do enjoy. My chocolate crossaint was great and partners mango smoothly delicious. However the bacon, egg, tomato toastie I felt was a little lack luster. What really let this place down was the speed of service. It took us 30mins to get the toastie and crossaint, which we needed to ask for as a reminder. Also be prepared to sit outdoor or take away. As there is no indoor seating.

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: Kith is definitely my favorite brunch spot at Robertson Quay. It's cozy, the coffee's good and food is great - especially for the price.It's right down the street from where I live. So when I need some down-time to myself on the weekend, i'd head down here with a good book for a cup of latte and sandwiches. If the weather is nice you can people-watch by the river while enjoying your meal too! Love!On to the food - I usually get one of their sandwiches. It's easy no frills sandwich and cheap for what it is - they're priced at $8,$10 and $15. My favorite is the smoked salmon one for $10.I've had their big breakfast too and it's relatively cheap for about $15-16. It's a proper breakfast. Their mini toasties are good for if you don't feel like having any of the above but still want something to nibble on.Coffee is excellent.The only down side is, seating is mostly outdoors and there are no A/C, which can be downright unbearable when it's especially hot in Singapore

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: I stopped by here when wandering from Clarke Quay towards Robertson Quay when the hunger and heat got the better of me and I just had to stop somewhere. I saw Kith and recalled that I had been at their other location by Dhoby Ghaut and did not find it horrible so I was up for giving it a shot (and to be honest at this point I would probably even have given McDonalds a chance). Kith has a pretty relaxed setting at a corner of a house with some shade but it does not really have any seats inside so even if it is shaded it is still fairly warm.I had some pretty decent pasta with a pretty good flat white while S went for a toastie and a freshly pressed juice. Neither of these were anything special but more what one can expect and prices are a bit higher than I would like to pay but then it is Robertson Quay after all so perhaps to be expected. I have since been a few more times and they are in a sense reliable, there has so far never been anything amazing nor anything really disappointing. It can tend to get a bit too noisy around as many families with children appear to like to come here and at least when I have been there it has been the type of people who do not feel like telling their kids to behave and take it easy so if that disturbs you it may not be the best place.

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: Who love Mondays? Well I do 'cos I'm having lunch at kith's cafe. A little Monday pick-me-up lunch of Spaghetti Meatballs and Flat White makes my Monday that much sweeter. My first time here, I was abit disappointed that the place was a bit small (no seating inside) but managed to get a seat outside, facing the river. However, since it was a Monday, there wasn't much crowd save for the odd Caucasian couple with kids, Caucasian yuppies and a few passer-bys getting some takeaway coffee. The view was good - luckily the sky was overcast and the weather was cool; I can't imagine what it would be like if it is a hot sunny day!  Food was ok but coffee gets my nod of approval! I drank one cup and got another one to take back to the office. Will definitely drop by again - but not on weekends!

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: This is always a stop for us along our walk. Great place to see friendly and smiling people. Breakfast is our favorite time here. However, lunch is delicious as well. Great coffee, and all at reasonable prices. Favorite stopping point for me on my frequent walks/jogs

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: I've been coming here for so long..sometimes you forget to highlight a place because it's always there. What I like about Kith is that it's kinda cute and quirky, it's always sincere and honest..and that reflects in the coffee, food and service.It operates out of a tiny space but they expand quite a bit outside. The tables and chairs are built for small people (luckily I'm one) but many tall expatriates seem to squeeze in comfortably (kid in tow). I personally think the old location was prettier inside..more seating but the new location is less food-fumey and has more shade so I think overall it's better.The food is simple and straightforward but there are little touches of brilliance. Love their white bread in the big brek always nicely toasted and love the homely strawberry jam - it really looks like someone spent all day cooking it on the hearth.Free wifi - always a nice bonus.Prices for the big brek and coffee are attractive. I've had the toastie several times for a lighter bite and it's very simple but it's served nice and hot with a tart apple salad on the side.The coffee is not the best but it's usually a nice to good cup..at $3.80 it's worth it. If you get a cup that's over-extracted and bitter, give your feedback to the staff. I think they will hasten to replace it.

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: Given that I had low expectations for this place, I was pretty impressed with the food and service. We were a group of four and though it was just, we were seated in a matter of a few minutes. I ordered a cheese pizza and pineapple ginger juice and my husband ordered some roast beef wrap thing. Both were pretty good (not to-die-for but not bad) and the juice was quite refreshing.

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: Loved this place, I thought the coffee was strong and tasty, toasted sandwiches were nice and crisp and they had some great cookies, this place was a welcome break from the sun.

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: Friendly service, good food, reasonable prices (for Singapore) and litle unexpected added touches like apples with the toastie that turn this suburban corner cafe from ordinary to extraordinary¡!! Highly recommended but you'll need to beat off the joggers and mums with bubs to find a seat on a sunny day...

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: A good advantage of staying relative near town is the accessibility to all these little cafes that are sprucing up in town. Kith Cafe has become one of my usual brunch places on the weekends to grab a quick bite with "free" parking. My typical brunch there would be their hotdog and a glass of  lychee watermelon iced blended. Kith Cafe is very popular with expat families and increasingly popular with the locals too.  Great place for informal group gathering and even playdates for the kids. It can be quite chaos  on weekends with kids and pets around.  Well, its one of the very few cafes that is both kids and pets friendly. Recently, my husband and I brought my 8 months old baby girl along to have brunch. She loves to sit and watch the older kids play. I think she must be wishing that she is old enough to join in the fun. Great place to people watch by the river too!

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: In all honesty, i can't see why theres so much hype about this place? probably cos of its indie concept and the fact that it appeared on Monocle.The tables and chairs were pathetic and tiny. The view... well by the canal (wouldn't really call it a river tho it connects to the Singapore River)Coffee was decent, but the toastie I had was terrible. I ordered a egg and ham toastie. it was very homemade style, which wasn't quite what i was looking for. Worst part of the toastie was that the scrambled eggs inside was definitely cooked eons ago and was too dry. more like a scrambled egg bits.Kitchen looked make-shift, small and dirty.

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: Another addition to the brunch places popping up all over the city, Kith café is located along Robertson Quay and provides expats, families and yuppies with good coffee and sandwiches. On weekends, Kith is generally crowded unless you come a little later in the afternoon. I usually order an unsweetened iced coffee and a cheese and bacon toastie (I love the little apple slices they provide on the side to temper the savouriness of the toastie with crunchy sweetness). Sitting outside along the sidewalk with a newspaper and coffee at hand is a great way to spend a peaceful Sunday.

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: I thought the coffee here was excellent. I also had the toast with Jam for breakfast. The bread wasn't great, but the jam appeared to be homemade and was quite good although they don't really give you enough of it to cover the giant pieces of bread. On this weekend, the place looked like an expat daycare center because of all the toddlers running around--that could be a positive or negative depending on your point of view but just be aware. Plenty of seating outside though and a nice place to have a cup of joe.

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: We walked with our dog close to three miles from Tangling Mall along Orchard road, through Ft. Canning park, down to Clarke Quay and finally Robertson Quay. Having the dog with us limited the places we could eat at but then we found Kith. They were happy to let us sit outside with him, even providing water for him. We ordered the smoked salmon sandwich and the steak sandwich. We also ordered the pineapple and ginger drinks. The service was prompt and friendly. The drinks were cold and refreshing, never having tasted pineapple and ginger before. The sandwiches were very tasty, the steak getting the slight edge over the smoked salmon. The side order of bacon for the dog was tasty enough that a couple of pieces did not make it to the intended customer. All in all it was a good experience, we will be back.

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: Kith is a cute, cozy place on the quieter side of Robertson Quay .  It's one of those places I'd been meaning to try for years, literally, and I finally got round to it about about 2 months ago - this tells you I've got quite a backlog of reviews!Kith offers a decent selection of food (ranging from biccies to small bites to traditional full breakfasts and to sandwiches) at reasonable price points, e.g. $10 for a sandwich.  Our table only tried several simple food items like the smoked salmon sandwich, brioche with yogurt and strawberries, and a tuna + green apple toastie.  Even simple dishes can sometimes go awry, but I'm happy to report that all these items were well executed and presented.Where I felt a bit let down was in the coffee department.  I'd heard a lot about Kith's coffee and had been tremendously looking forward to trying it.  However, the coffee was disappointingly average.  I'd certainly put places like Toby's Estate and Smitten above Kith in the coffee stakes.Still, Kith is a pleasant place that's hard to dislike.  It's a comfortable place which is family-friendly, pet-friendly and offers ample people watching opportunities.  If I lived in RQ, I'd be happy to call it my local.

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: If you like your food home-made style, then you should check this place out. A good time to go would be during breakfast so you can try out the toast and homed strawberry jam that is quite good actually. Coffee on the other hand, was just average and nothing to shout about. The place is quite stuffy so don't come overdressed or you'll be perspiring throughout your meal, which is never good.

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: The interior is very small- a couple of bar seats, and a long bench for a large group. Furnishing is pretty spartan, the legs of the bar and chairs reminds me of book stacks. Feels pretty much like an old classroom with the blackboard as well. The 'alfresco dining' is in fact a couple of tables and chairs/stools scattered along the corridor. Fits very much into the home and patio concept. I can see how the residents are drawn to this little spot.Breakfast food is a must have (if i have my way that is). I would also insist on all day breakfast too. We were there for tea so we didn't try the food.Kith's scone looks pretty but tastes crappy and it got worse as the temperature dropped. The texture is almost cardboard-ish and dry. It was only a little better with the.. wait for it... WHIPPED cream (oh how i hate it when they serve whipped instead of clotted). The jam was kinda weird with the watery texture. It looks like it was curdled and then defrosted. Anyway, just avoid the scone at all cost.Drinks are good though.

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: In all honesty, i can't see why theres so much hype about this place? probably cos of its indie concept and the fact that it appeared on Monocle.The tables and chairs were pathetic and tiny. The view... well by the canal (wouldn't really call it a river tho it connects to the Singapore River)Coffee was decent, but the toastie I had was terrible. I ordered a egg and ham toastie. it was very homemade style, which wasn't quite what i was looking for. Worst part of the toastie was that the scrambled eggs inside was definitely cooked eons ago and was too dry. more like a scrambled egg bits.Kitchen looked make-shift, small and dirty.

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: Kith Café is an awesome hole in the wall along the Singapore River. It actually recently just expanded but before was literally a tiny little space frequented by the River Valley neighborhood. Staff is super friendly and the food is simple but very satisfying. Go for their breakfast which is served with the best toast in Singapore and home-made strawberry jam. Their coffee is pretty great too. Try the Kith macchiato, which is espresso, chocolate, topped with a marshmallow. They recently expanded to a bigger space, in the same location. Have lunch outdoors facing the Singapore River. They also just opened a new branch in Park Mall, serving dinner as well.

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: Paired with the glistening surface of the Singapore River and the occasional bumbleboat whizzing by, a sip of ice-cold liquefied Nutella blended with nuttily fragrant hazelnut ice cream over at Kith Café is the rest-stop for winners after a day-long poach at flea markets at Clarke Quay. Drink it before it melts - it is good to the very last drop!

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: A good advantage of staying relative near town is the accessibility to all these little cafes that are sprucing up in town. Kith Cafe has become one of my usual brunch places on the weekends to grab a quick bite with "free" parking. My typical brunch there would be their hotdog and a glass of  lychee watermelon iced blended. Kith Cafe is very popular with expat families and increasingly popular with the locals too.  Great place for informal group gathering and even playdates for the kids. It can be quite chaos  on weekends with kids and pets around.  Well, its one of the very few cafes that is both kids and pets friendly. Recently, my husband and I brought my 8 months old baby girl along to have brunch. She loves to sit and watch the older kids play. I think she must be wishing that she is old enough to join in the fun. Great place to people watch by the river too!

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: Another addition to the brunch places popping up all over the city, Kith café is located along Robertson Quay and provides expats, families and yuppies with good coffee and sandwiches. On weekends, Kith is generally crowded unless you come a little later in the afternoon. I usually order an unsweetened iced coffee and a cheese and bacon toastie (I love the little apple slices they provide on the side to temper the savouriness of the toastie with crunchy sweetness). Sitting outside along the sidewalk with a newspaper and coffee at hand is a great way to spend a peaceful Sunday.

address: 7 Rodyk Street #01-33 Robertson Quay Singapore 238215 Singapore
comment: Quirky little cafe by the river (canal?). I like how it's hidden from everything else, like a little sanctuary.Brunch sets and coffee here are average but the laid back atmosphere makes up for it. Salads and juices are great, the first time I visited Kith, I wanted something more than what was offer on the blackboard so I asked if I could request for a specific salad. I was in luck because the person who would soon say yes was none other than lady boss Jane herself.So I had a ginger grilled chicken salad with baby spinach, wild rocket, japanese cucumber and cherry tomatoes, and have had it again every time I return. It tastes awesome.Perfect for a lazy weekend.

6-course Lunch at Ichigo IchieIntercontinental Hotel @ Robertson QuayChef Akane EnoThey also have an 8-course lunch but 6-course was just nice for me.Bamboo shoot in soupy chawanmushi with a dollop of ume plum paste3-in-1 box (scallop/baby squid with a really nice jelly sauce, grilled fish & sushi fish)Cold prawn somen with Japanese tiger prawn in prawn stock - Superb! Love it!Fish dumpling with crab meatBeef White coffee pudding & pumpkin (?)/red bean pancake - pudding is not my thing but this is super good & silky smooth.  Hey! I'm missing the photo of the rice dish.Overall a good meal. Dinner menu attached. Lunch is cheaper.

address: 30 Merchant Road #01-07 Riverside Point Singapore 058282 Singapore
comment: The outlet served Chengdu style of hotpot, and was opened last September. It was part of a chain which started in Shanghai in 2009 and currently having about 30 outlets in China. For the hotpot soup bases, there was choices such as Mala, Kampong Chicken Nutritious Chestnut Soup, Fresh Mushroom Soup, Pork Trotter Soup, Tomato Soup and Pickled vegetables Fish Soup. For the types of pot, there was the single soup base pot, pot with nine grid-like compartments, where ingredients can be cooked separately, Double circle or "son and mother" pot, which has a smaller circular compartment in the middle that is usually used for non-spicy stock,and the usual yuan yang pot that holds two types of soup bases.Kampong Chicken Nutritious Chestnut Yuan Yang Soup Pot 甘榜鸡板栗养生鸳鸯汤锅 ($27)It came with a quarter chicken and assorted vegetables in the chicken soup base. The soup was very rich and creamy, while the vegetables were very soft.One could add beef butter or chilli to increase the spiciness in the mala soup base, although it was already quite spicy.There were various sauces and condiments available which was chargeable at $4 per person. We had the following items with the hotpot :Fresh Pork Aorta 鲜猪黄喉 ($12[Normal], $7[Small]) It was my first time having this and the texture was quite chewy. The staff told us that it needed 10 seconds to cook. Spicy House Tripe 辣府毛肚 ($12[Normal], $7[Small]) Similar to the above item, it needed 10 seconds to cook. We were told it was beef tripe. The texture was slightly less chewy compared to the pork aorta.Beef Slices 特级肥牛 ($14)The meat was very tender and silky smooth.Beef Cube 牛仔粒 ($32 [Normal], $18 [Small])Although it looked quite frozen when served, the meat was quite tender and soft.Spicy Fresh Fish Slices 麻辣鲜鱼片 ($16 [Normal], $9 [Small]) Although it was spicy, I felt that the saltiness had overwhelmed all the taste. Maybe with beer it would tone down the taste a tab.Mashed Prawn Meat 鲜虾滑 ($15)Served in a cute heart shape, the staff helped us to scoop into balls into the soup. The meat was juicy and bouncy.Spicy House Home Made Juicy Mashed Beef Balls 辣府手工撒尿牛肉丸 ($16 [Normal], $6 [5 pieces]) Beware of this meatball when eating, especially the centre part, where it was filled with flavourful soup. Bouncy, chewy and juicy.Bamboo Shoot 竹筍 ($12[Normal]) The staff told us that it was flown in a couple of days ago from China. It was served thin sliced into thin sheets.
