The texture was silky smooth, unlike the usual bamboo shoot we had locally. A must order!Bamboo Fungus竹荪 ($12[Normal], $6.50[Small]) Another item flown in from China, in dried version. The texture was very good, with crunchy feel.Mushroom Platter 鲜菇拼盘 ($20)Tofu 老豆腐 ($5)Fried Prawn Rice 虾仁炒饭 ($10)Surprisingly the dish was made with short grain rice, not with the usual long grain rice commonly found in Singapore. Although it was short grain, the rice was not sticky. The cubes of vegetable was soft and flavourful.As for dessert, we hadRaw Sugar Rice Cake Stick 黄糖糍粑 ($7 [8 pieces], $4 [4pieces])It was made of glutinous rice, and topped with red sugar syrup. The syrup's colour was quite similar to chilli oil, that we almost thought that we were having another spicy dish. The simple looking rice stick was chewy inside like mochi, while encased with a thin, light crispy crust. Very nice on its own even without the syrup.Overall the food was not bad. The place was relatively quiet which allowed one to enjoy the meal in peace. Maybe could be due to the reason the place was located at the far end of Clarke Quay and most people still did not know about it. By the way the restaurant is currently having a promotion during its supper hours :32% off for Supper Steamboat at 辣府火锅 Spicy House Restaurant- Valid on 19 Dec 2016 - 31 Dec 2017- Valid only on Friday, Saturday and Sunday from 10:00pm to 02:00am- For orders made after 10pm on valid days- Not inclusive for the soup base, sauce and drinks

address: 60 Eu Tong Sen St Singapore 059804 Singapore
comment: Came here for a company's lunch buffet and it was pretty good!Dishes I like:* salmon sashimi (fresh and thick slices)* fresh prawns* mee siam * durian penyet * yam ice cream* bread butter pudding* wafflesIt's an affordable and nice dining experience, which I would come back to.

I was in Singapore on business, staying nearby to Robertson Quay. Ventured out Sunday evening for a late solo bite. Verre wasn't crowded, but I sat at the bar anyway. Probably should have grabbed a table, as the bar seating was a little cramped for food.I had two glasses of lovely French burgundy, and the pate trio. It was really fabulous - three distinct textures and flavors, which went well with the wine The bread was nicely toasted and stood up well to the pates.Definitely a nice experience. Several other inviting choices on the menu as well, including escargot and steak tartare ... I wish I'd been hungrier!

It's hard to believe that I'm the first to review Verre, as it's in a very popular hood and it is a fantastic wine bar.  The room is beautiful and spacious and very roomy.  Definitely a lot quieter and more intimate than some of the larger places like Wine Connection.  It's also a bit different as it offers some formal main courses, but first let's talk about the wine.While their by the glass choices are decent, around 6-8 whites and same for reds, their deep by the bottle offerings are the real star of the show.  In particular, they had a solid offering of French, both Bordeaux and Burgundies, and many are quite reasonably priced.  By biggest pet peeve however is that our Bordeaux arrived cold!  OK, it wasn't ice cold, but still colder than ideal and with some condensation, so that was annoying.  The by the glass selections did not have such an issue.As for the food, don't miss out on the tarte flambe.  These are basically flatbreads, but much better.  Loved the savory toppings, and we ordered a swecond one as a starter too.  The entrees are interesting.  The beef bourguignon was very good - super tender morsels of beef in a super rich stew.  But why are the mashed potatoes so gummy?  The duck and steak frites looked delicious, while the salmon looked good but a bit small.Overall, Verre has a lot going for it. I would definitely go back for some wine and tarte flambes.  There are a few miscues, such as bottles being refrigerated too much and the gooey mess of a mashed potato.  But I applaud them for their ambitious menu, and with a few tweaks, they could be even better.

Farther off Robertson Quay is Rodyk Street, which was for a bit, a hipster spot (thanks to Toby's Estate). Even though i used to frequent this spot, i've not noticed Verre, formerly a wine bar hidden behind dark and heavy drapes. Thankfully, after a relaunch, Verre Modern Bistro and Wine Bar has lost all that darkness and brought light, and great food to its mix. The new direction cannot be a better choice really. With their expertise in wine (they have over 750 labels of fine wine mainly from Bordeaux and Burgundy), Verre is able to provide great pairings with their Modern French dishes created by Chef Consultant Masashi Horiuchi (who also manages Shelter in the Woods). We had an extensive night of food and wine pairings, something easily done since one could have over 30 wines by the glass with your food choice.A good start to a meal at Verre would be the creamy Chicken Liver Parfait ($24) paired with a reduction of port wine, madeira wine shallot, balanced with a tangy mandarin orange jelly and a dehydrated honeycomb-like mandarin orange. This was paired with a dry lemon lime Paringa Estate Riesling 2012 ($19.50). The Half Lobster Salad ($38) features a sweet Maine lobster cooked in court bouillon, with a creamy guacamole and a refreshing calamansi and honey dressing. I would order this dish for the sweet and tangy dressing! The wine pairing was the Stick Chardonnay 2013 ($18) with flavors of grapefruit, white peach, citrus and oak spice.I loved the Black Garlic Soup ($19), which was made with a white wine chicken stock and black garlic. That clove of roasted black garlic was icing on the cake and gave the soup a slightly tangy sweet preserved plum flavor. We had the dark fruity Massalino Dolcette D Alba 2013 ($18) to go with this.The Pan-seared Scallops with Sweet Corn ($38) was an absolute stunner. The corn flavor was immensely intense and the pickled konbu gave the dish an umami lift.Onto the bigger dishes. I'm not a fan of the Seafood Papillote ($30) of oven baked seafood. It was a little too bland for my liking though that toasted dill bread with gruyere was perfect for mopping up the stock. Do not go away without having some of that gorgeous Suckling Pig ($42) done 2 ways. One part slow roasted for 4 - 5h and braised with spices; and another slow braised for 12h with a tangy Asian marinade of orange, honey, and spice. Give me a bun and make me a slider out of this pulled pork mix with Iberico ham and pickled onions already!I was extremely pleased with the meat selection at Verre. The Fillet of Wagyu Beef ($62) can have my body and soul. Just look at that pink flesh (best enjoyed slightly rare)! And hand over that umami American potato truffle fries, seasoned with truffle shavings and truffle oil. I'm sure there's some soy sauce in there somehow. No bottled ketchup here by the way. We'll go with the homemade mushroom ketchup made with madeira wine and pickled mushrooms. Have this with the classic full bodied Massolino Barolo 2010 ($32) and you'd be in cow heaven. After that heavy meal, I was grateful for the light refreshing desserts. I enjoyed the deconstructed Apple Mille-Feuille ($16) A LOT. We had apple in all forms- macerated apple with lemon juice, sorbet, compote, and caramelized, with layers of caramalised filo pastry and vanilla custard cream flavored with Calvados. That cream THAT CREAM!! The dessert wine award goes to the Caprilli Moscadello ($15), a silky and refreshing drink which was sweet but light enough.Other hits include the Saint-Honore ($10) filled with the mind blowing vanilla pastry cream and chantilly! The Canele ($4) was pretty good too but could be more crisp. Certainly one of the better ones because I

Since my last review, I must have been here 30 more times. This is my second home from 6-7pm most days :-)The staff is amazing, the wine selection is great (especially if you go for the fancy cellar), and the location is perfect--right on the river. And the happy hour prices are unbeatable!

Singapore does have many wine bars but not really an abundance of wine bars with good selection of wines at decent prices. Verre does in that sense fill a gap, and a bit surprisingly (perhaps not in having a good wine selection but decent prices seldom goes hand in hand with this area) it is in a rather touristy and expat heavy area.This bar/restaurant is located along Robertson Quay and has both nice outdoor seating area as well as a fairly large dining room. It has never been very busy when I have been here so have always been able to get a seat without reservations. Service has always been friendly and fast so a big plus for that.The wine selection is pretty good, I counted 8 reds and 8 whites by the glass and 1 sparkling. Very decent prices and for their happy hour it is really good (from 4-7 pm on weekdays and 4-6pm on weekends) with buy 1 get 1 free offer on the wines by the glass and some beers. Their champagne by the glass is for example the excellent Guy Charlemagne Brut (for a review of thier 2008 check out thewinecurious.wordpress…) and at 18 SGD for 2 glasses it is excellent value for money.The selection of wines by the bottle is also good, a lot from France but also from other parts of the world. Prices are pretty good as well so really a pleasant experience.They do also have a full food menu. I have had the food and it is not bad but also not something very special. I mainly come here for the fine but occassionally also eat here and have never been really disappointed but also never really escited about it either. Expect pastas and other European dishes on the me u.Overall this is one of my favorite places for wine in Singapore.
Superb great service! Good job Manager! Keep it up.Great wine selection though the prices are slightly on the high.
Terrible service. Lots of people working. It took me less time to eat then it too get my check and pay.

Solid spot.  Headed over to have dinner with a friend on Friday night, and it def. did not disappoint.  Solid service, nice atmosphere, and good food.  We had a bottle of SB, which was decent (I'm not a SB fan, but I didn't want to hurt my dining partners feelings) and started with the asparagus and melon app, both were excellent.  The asparagus came with salmon which was different, but very tasty.  I had the scallop dish which was excellent.  He had some kind of meat dish that just looked okay.  All in all, a solid dining experience, good date night, or just quick drink.

I was eager to try this wine bar due to the other reviews I had read. I was sorely disappointed. I went on a Friday night. As a single diner, I love sitting at the bar. However, I was told I couldn't sit at the bar because they were using it to put things on there and to clean. Really? And, I saw it was covered with things and stuff. That should have been my first sign. I decided to sit inside anyways in front of the lovely wine cellar. I asked the waiter what was good on the menu and felt he didn't know the menu too well as he stumbled for explanations. I ordered a glass of Pinot (it needed to open up greatly) and one of the savory tarts flambé. I patiently waited for this as I listened to the children (!) from a few tables over scream and run back and forth to the door. That wasn't the relaxing dining experience I was looking for after having a 14-hr work day. My tart finally came and it was dry and lacked the savoriness I expected. I ate it and paid the check. For $42 SG, it was not worth the food nor the experience. Hence, I went to another place to have a proper dinner as I left hungry.

Ever stuck in a forsaken place where the nearest bus stop is a winding 3 streets down? Lemme introduce Moru Korean Foods! Is it so awesome that you will dream of it!?No. Does it serve authentic korean food? It says the chef is korean so i will just believe it to he so Will it crave your sudden need for korean food? I hope so! Its basic korean..in a coffee shop.. One plus point is their side dishes change so yes, you will get the rudimentary extra kim chi salad dish but you may not get the sweetened anchovies.. Today i believe its a starch cake! They do hotpots and korean bbqs. Sadly, my lunch is only an hour and in tropical singapore, having a bbq at 1.30pm is redunkulous. But i will go to them if i ever... Hopefully never, work overtime and wee into the night!

address: 177 River Valley Rd #B1-50, Liang Court Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: $19 for the rice with breaded katsu, ebi and sliced beef just wasn't worth the quality. This reminded me why I hardly eat Japanese food in Singapore. I'd derive far more satisfaction from a burrito or a good bowl of yong tau foo or bak chor mee that would cost me less than half this.

address: 177 River Valley Rd #B1-50, Liang Court Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: Teishoku restaurant. Translates to set menu with a main, several small sides, rice and miso soup. I upgraded the miso soup to kaijiru (clear, clam soup) which was yummy! I ordered the hire katsu and it was decent. Good value is the word that comes to mind. You can fill with rice to your hearts content. Ordering is done via touch screen, service is efficient and a large selection to choose from. There's a hustle and bustle all around you but that's to be expected with a large number of families who dine here. Enjoyed the curry katsu in the past but strangely there's a large 'not available' sticker across the menu. Hopefully, not for long. Again good value, fast; would recommend for a no fuss meal.

address: 177 River Valley Rd #B1-50, Liang Court Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: This restaurant never fails to satisfy my appetite. The Hire Katsu is so moist and perfectly fried, the Chicken & Ebo Fry is also authentically Japanese. Whatever you order, get the set menu for small sides including miso soup. It's our go-to place :)

address: 177 River Valley Rd #B1-50, Liang Court Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: Yummy in my tummy! I love the chicken nanban here (fried chicken cutlet topped with a tangy sauce and tartare sauce), I love he iPad self order system. Food always comes pretty quickly and piping hot. I just wish they had a bit more variety on their menu.

address: 177 River Valley Rd #B1-50, Liang Court Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: Had their signature set of Nasu Miso and Hokke Set (usual: $15.90++) which I have always wanted to try and I was eager to make that my first stop.If you are new to Yayoiken, there is no doubt you should make this set your first choice.The Set contains eggplant and pork stir-fried with miso paste and sesame seeds, grilled Atka mackerel, tofu, FREE-FLOW Japanese rice as well as a regular miso soup which I traded up for their absolutely delicious Kaijiru (miso soup with clams) +$1.90.One winning point about Yayoiken is the fact that they serve a delicious Japanese rice which they offer free-flow to customers. This is an extremely important fact as their protein portions are usually large and delicious that it calls for an extra portion of carbs to prolong the umami enjoyed.The Nasu was nicely caramelized with miso and tender to the bite, although the pork tasted a little too sweet, requiring some of the Japanese rice and savoury kaijiru to wash down.The highlight of the meal had to be the grilled mackerel that Yayoiken prides itself on. With a charred crispy skin on the underside and juicy, fatty meat on the inside, this is enough to make non-fish fans rethink their opinion. Some might be put off by the presence of bones on the fish, but these can be easily removed in a swift pry from the center, leaving one with just the fleshy insides to enjoy. Having gotten used to the large whole fish one gets in the Shima Hokke Set ($13.90) however, this was a little lacking in portion size and I think I will revert to my usual order of the Shima Hokke when I return for a generous portion of the tender, delicious mackerel.Kaijiru is a must-order with a mere top-up of just $1.90 for plump clams and umami-enhanced miso soup.For pictures and the full review visit voraciousappetite.wordpr…Thanks!

address: Furama City Centre Hotel 60 Eu Tong Seng Street, #03-01/02 Singapore 059804 Singapore
comment: Wo Peng is located in the fairly old hotel, Furama. However, the restaurant isn't too shabby. In fact, it gives me a familiar Cantonese resto vibe, which I enjoy actually. Staff are suitably friendly, and dishes are by and large authentic & yummy. More hits than misses. Now on to the food!!1) yusheng / lohei - this was a delight. The mock salmon looked positively real. Whilst tasty enough, the slightly hypochondriac me was wondering if it was made out of many chemicals. Hahahaha. One lovely bit was the crispy fish skin!!! I don't think I've ever had yusheng with crispy fish skin which provided a lovely crunchy texture to this age-old dish. 2) double-boiled superior soup with almonds - oh, this i LURVED!!!! Wow! Just so ambrosial and heavenly. Soup lovers would be over the moon with this one. Guaranteed. Seriously. 3) poon Choy - Award-winning Chef Julian Tam supposedly was the first to introduce this Cantonese dish to Singapore. And his version is authentic and doesn't disappoint. Chockful of expensive delicacies like abalone, dried scallops, fish maw, sea cucumber, shrimp, meats and veggies go into that claypot. The sauce is phenomenal and warrants a bowl of white rice. Yes, the rice is a MUST. 4) sautéed "peach resin" with egg white - ok, this dish didn't look too appetizing but the flavors were tremendously delicious. The egg whites and some century eggs (I could be mistaken with the latter) and veggies.... They all went together like nutella and toast. Very awesome. 5) wild cod fish - it looked like art, like a calligraphic painting. Very interesting way of cooking it - if you notice, the filleted fish is fried but the fish slices are steamed and placed by the side. How perfectly contrasting! Me likey!!! Mucho!!!6) roasted duck - while yummy, it didn't strike me as fantastic. Nothing out of the ordinary. But yummy nonetheless. 7) glutinous rice with Chinese sausages - yes yes yes yes yes yes yes!!!!!!!!!!!! What a way to end with this staple! I don't know why, but I enjoyed this laap mei faan very much. The Chinese sausages went terrifically well with the sticky rice. A true winner. 8) custard buns - honestly, this was a let down and the worst dish of the night. The skin (bun) was tough, and the custard was watery. A pity, cos it looked so yummy! All in all, I really really enjoyed my meal. Chef Julian came out to say hi to us and he is friendliest, most humble and humorous chef. CNY Set Menu for Take Out$298 for 5 pax or $528 for 10 pax includes four dishes:Wo Peng Poon Choy Braised Australian Abalone w/ Dried Assorted Seafood in CasseroleProsperity Crispy Fish Skin, Vegetarian Salmon Yu ShengWok-Fried Glutinous Rice w/ Assorted Chinese Sausages Deep-Fried Red Bean Pan Cake Poon Choy for Take Out (FREE STAINLESS STEEL TREASURE POT!)$228 for 5 pax (Usual Price $298) OR$428 for 10 pax (Usual Price $568)

address: 177 River Valley Rd #01-23/24, Liang Court Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: Not many may know that Tampopo has launched their FIRST Kyoto fair featuring the award-winning KYOTO BEEF only until 11th FEBRUARY!!  Kyoto Beef? How good can it be when it's not even one of the Top 3 Wagyu Beef in Japan? Yes, I had those questions in mind too but when I had a bite of the Kyoto Beef, I nearly wanted to flip the tables. (Just kidding) Trust me, this breed of cow is just as elite as the vegetables and tofu produce from Kyoto.Wagyu purists might disagree but I do not care. This is definitely my ideal cattle because of the regular marbling of fats make this a balanced cut that is tender yet not too fatty. Kobe beef felt like swallowing a whole chunk of butter and I couldn't proceed after one. But not for this. The one-week Kyoto fair is run by Okamoto san, an experienced chef with a restaurant in Kyoto. ALL ingredients, from the pickles in the appetizers to the strawberries in dessert are all imported from Kyoto. There is ala carte menu but the lunch/dinner course is much more highly recommended for the full quality experience. The price ranges from $28 to $100, which is jaw-droppingly reasonable for the excellent standards of the meal. But that's not the end. The dessert brought the Kyoto meal to another climax. Matcha Fondue. Yes, dark green liquid served WARM with Kyoto Strawberries, Warabi Mochi, Matcha Cake and Shiratama Dango. This was so ridiculously good that I licked my fondue cup clean. Blissful. The beef, the tofu, the matcha. Every ingredient played their respective role in he course. Looks like this meal has set a high standard for 2015 and honestly speaking, it's difficult to find another place in Singapore that can beat this in terms of value and quality.

address: 177 River Valley Rd #01-23/24, Liang Court Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: The restaurant appeared upscale and the photos of the dishes in the menu were inviting.The food portion was large but quality was lacking.The sashimi came in slices thicker than our liking.We liked the quality of the shima aji and hamachi. However, the otoro was a disappointment. It looked more like akami! For such upscale restaurant, it was another disappointment to be served "toothpaste" wasabi!The salmon roll that we ordered was overly salty and for this dish, we wished the salmon slices were as thick and large as were in the sashimi.We ordered the black pig tonkatsu but the pork did not taste nor look like black pig! Actually, there is no way to ascertain what kind of pork you are getting. Furthermore, there was too little sauce in the rice. Overall quality of the black pig tonkatsu was below average.The only dish that we liked was the potato salad. The potato salad had bits of cucumber, onions, carrots in it. It was both soft and crunchy at the same time. It would be difficult to convince ourselves to make a revisit considering the many alternatives restaurants available at similar price point.

address: 177 River Valley Rd #01-23/24, Liang Court Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: Was in the area on Thursday for lunch. A quiet restaurant to lunch at. Pleasant environment and not crowded. She ordered the all-salmon sushi plate which looked absolutely delicious. There were salmon nigiri, salmon maki, salmon belly sashimi. And I had the 11 kinds of sashimi don. The toppings change according to season. It was absolutely fresh and every piece was sweet and oh-so-yummy. Really good. Even if it's a bit pricy $35.80.

address: 177 River Valley Rd #01-23/24, Liang Court Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: Very bad food.  Nothing we ordered was nice. Tonkatsu,  don, noodle & quality of rice are disappointment.  Won't be back again, not worth the tummy space.

address: 177 River Valley Rd #01-23/24, Liang Court Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: Best known for the black pig shabu ramen which is okayyy.I had the Salmon roll salad (vietnamese rice roll with vegetable and a thin slice of salmon). Salad dressing was a sweet chilli sauce. It was unique, but I felt that for $12.80, the was barely any fish.They take reservations for large groups so if you have a large party, it might be a good place for a gathering. But dont expect too much from the food!

address: 177 River Valley Rd #01-23/24, Liang Court Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: The hype about black pork brings me here. The hype it is all about. The service is alright. The location is good. The good is so-so. There are better ramen out there for my liking. The pork is indeed tender and juicy, the egg is perfect but there is nothing to shout about for the noodle and the broth itself. Not really a place that I will seek to go back to for my meal.

address: 177 River Valley Rd #01-23/24, Liang Court Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: The service is friendly.The broth isn't hot enough and it tasted bland.There were way too much noodles in the broth and the noodles were soggy. Super prime cutlet is chewy and tasteless. The vegetable on the plate wasn't fresh. The cucumber were dried out.

address: 177 River Valley Rd #01-23/24, Liang Court Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: This is my first time to Tampopo at Clarke Quay. From my very basic knowledge of Tampopo, they are supposed to be famous for their black pork fried cutlet and that has always been a staple in my usual order.This time round, my friend Cheryl L made me try the Wafu Steak and Fried Pork Rib Ramen, which she swears are awesome.Unfortunately, the Wafu Steak wasnt that great. It was slightly tough and a little too salty for my liking. Cheryl L agreed and was pretty upset cos it's usually very tender and the meat actually melts in your mouth. So much for our first dish.When the Ramen came, I was a little apprehensive. But the broth did not disappoint! Though it's stated that it's spicy (1 chilli), it's not spicy at all. For someone who cant take food that's too spicy, this was perfect for me (but for lovers of chilli, you might need to get them to increase the dosage!). The Fried Pork Ribs were great too. However, I'm not used to very salty food, I couldnt continue after about 4 pieces. Cheryl L happily consumed the rest. Heh.

address: 177 River Valley Rd #01-23/24, Liang Court Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: I love Japanese food. in Fact, it is my favorite, but hard to come by in Berlin (at least if you want good quality).I was in Singapore for 2 days before flying back home. Luckily, a friend had just made the big move and took me to Tampopo. Granted, if you're from SF or NYC, the food is nothing special. But, we ordered the chicken katsu, ebi bento box and a salad, and everything was delivered fast, was fresh and tasted great. Their are probably better places in Singapore, but all in all this is a great place to go to. They do get busy, so expect to wait for 20 minutes or so, and when coming with a bigger group, definitely make a reservation beforehand. The menu is big, the prices alright for Singapore, the service friendly.

address: 177 River Valley Rd #01-23/24, Liang Court Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: We had just arrived in Singapore and were looking for easy and quick food. We ended up here just by walking around the hotel.It's an easy choice, nicely located next to Clark quays.For the food, expect something Japanese, with a big choice on the menu.However it stays simple and the food is average. Nothing special, nothing bad, but they are plenty of other options here in Singapore.

address: 177 River Valley Rd #01-23/24, Liang Court Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: Was in the Clarke/Robertson Quay area with a buddy from San Fran and he craved for Japanese - so here we were!Ordered the sashimi platter (can't recall which one it was), but I do recall that the one we got offered a wider selection of choice cuts and thicker (though, less) slithers of raw fish. Was really impressed with the presentation, and the service was impeccable, even though the staff couldn't really enunciate or speak understandable English, they were super attentive and the green tea we had was always hot and filled to the brim. Will definitely be back to try their ramen (apparently, that's their specialty), and I simply love their name. So cute!

address: 177 River Valley Rd #01-23/24, Liang Court Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: The first time i try tampopo is when my mum takeway unagi sushi for me. It simply tasted awesome. I immediately asked her where she bought it from and that was the time when i first introduced to Tampopo.So one day, i decided to head down to the restaurant with my colleagues. I told them it's a must to order the unagi sushi. It tasted even better than the takeaway version. Warm unagi at the top of the sushi. Next, i tried chicken teriyaki raman. Love how the chicken is grilled perfectly. One negative part will be the sauce is abit too sweet to my liking. It's a must to add in tasty egg to your bowl of ramen.  .

address: 177 River Valley Rd #01-23/24, Liang Court Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: Great food and service. I always go there if I have a ramen craving. The bp rich pork bone ramen and the Hakodate ramen are my favourites

address: 177 River Valley Rd #01-23/24, Liang Court Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: We have been to tampopo twice for lunch. Tried 2 types of ramen, sashimi, maki rolls,  gyoza and cakes. Both times the service was prompt, with servers ready to help with selection. Food was tasty and fresh. Would definitely go here again when I crave Japanese food.

address: 177 River Valley Rd #01-23/24, Liang Court Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: The food is quite good but pricey. However the staff attitude is shocking. We entered at 9pm, ordered and were served about 20 minutes later. About 5 minutes while we were still eating later we were handed the cheque and staff hovered about waiting for us to pay. Even though the restaurant didn't close until 10 pm tables were being cleared and chairs put up around us, giving us the impression we were expected to get out. For a restaurant of Japanese heritage this is just shocking. Even management didn't seem interested in customer care. We certainly were not able to enjoy the food because of this atmosphere.

address: 177 River Valley Rd #01-23/24, Liang Court Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: Tampopo is one of the first ramen shops I went to in Singapore. The first time I went, I'd just been back from Kyushuu and was craving Tonkotsu Ramen. The soup base at Tampopo is rich and fragrant, and the ramen serving is big. By the time I'd finished, I was too full for dessert. With all the new ramen shops that have opened up in Singapore, Tampopo is no longer the first place I go to for ramen, but if I'm around the area and craving Japanese food, I would definitely go there and drop by the deli downstairs for some dessert to take home.

address: 177 River Valley Rd #01-23/24, Liang Court Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: As compared to basketball ramen, the food served is definitely better and richer. The menu selection is wide and if you are looking for ramen, they serve quality ramen. Do try their spicy ramen soup if you are a fan of hot spicy soup.Besides ramen, the sushi is definitely fresh and delicious. Remember to try the unagi sushi. The unagi served is thick and juciy which one will not expect. However the pricing for sushi is on the high side, which explains the freshness of the sushi.One dish for take away is the tam po po cream puff. In fact they do have a separate bakery store at the basement of liang court. However you can ask the staff at the restaurant on the availability of the cream puff. It is just plain awesome. Try it!

address: 177 River Valley Rd #01-23/24, Liang Court Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: Went to Tampopo with the family and we ordered the works! In short, everything tasted fresh and yummy. It's value for money (not overpriced) and definitely worth repeat visits to try more of their extensive menu! Since they're famous for the ramen, we tried the Deluxe black pig shabu ramen. The broth was really flavorful - I was told they actually make their own bone soup as the broth base, not some chemical concoction. There are lotsa add-ons too like the flavored egg and spicy mentaiko. Their tonkatsu was really good... we ordered the premium loin black pig tonkatsu. I don't think I've had better tonkatsu - the meat was super juicy and tender yet the batter was extremely crunchy. Waaay better than what I've had at Tonkichi. I really liked their desserts too. We ordered the milk pudding, matcha warabi mocha and matcha parfait. I think they're all winners, though my fave was the milk pudding - silky soft and full of milky goodness!

address: 177 River Valley Rd #01-23/24, Liang Court Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: It took me some time before I eventually stepped into Tampopo to give it a try. Reason being my reluctance at what I assumed was another company jumping on to the Ramen bandwagon. I must say I am pleasantly surprised as Tampopo offers not only ramen but a wide variety of Japanese dishes that range from sushi to bento sets. My first experience was to try their signature black pig shabu ramen and I must say I was very satisfied with what I had. It was authentic and very similar to the ramen I had when I was in Japan and the paper thin black pig pork belly slices simply melts in my mouth. I gave the sushis and bentos a go when I returned for my subsequent visits and realized that for the price you're paying, which isn't a lot, you get to enjoy decently authentic Japanese food, and that's why I will keep going back for more.

address: 177 River Valley Rd #01-23/24, Liang Court Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: Forget all those pretentious, "It" Japanese restaurants that over charge just for customers to be "scene" with a bowl of designer ramen. Although during lunch and dinner times, the restaurant is rather packed and noisy, I must say this place serves up a bowl of delicious ramen. They're most known for their pork bone soup ramen, and my family and I have been there enough times to say for sure that you do not need to be seen at a stuffy and uptight Japanese restaurant to eat good ramen. If it's anything that describes the ramen at this place, is that it is both cheap and flavourful. You can really taste the richness of flavour in soup stock ; one spoon full of the ramen soup really packs a punch. All this at an affordable price of $14-16 a bowl. Not to mention the lovely Japanese sponge cheesecake that I love to end my heavy lunch with. It's the perfect balance of sweet and light. This place has never failed me whenever I needed a quick ramen fix and I always crave it whenever I go back to the UK to continue my studies.

Buffets are often for the heavyweight eaters but not so much so for the taiwanese porridge buffet.  Once in a while, I will be in the mood for some relative light eats.Crystal Cafe has been serving porridge buffet for a long time now and its value for money. The spread is not extensive but mainly comfort food. They have the typical braised items, chye poh omelette and much more.  Great for cold weathers too.They attract a huge office crowds on weekdays and family crowd on weekends. Booking is highly recommended.

Extremely bad service rendered by the old overweight male manager whom greeted all the regular customers with his sad and unhappy face. The cafe owner should grant his wish by allowing him to retire early since he is obviously not showing interest in welcoming & retaining customers. He is not mindful to care for customers unlike his subordinates, shame on him for hogging onto a managerial role which he is clearly incapable of doing so.

Located on the ground floor of Orchard Grand Court along Killiney Road, Crystal Café is a decade-old Asian International restaurant that is known for its affordable Taiwan porridge buffet. The restaurant has a nostalgic feel to it, with a casual ambience where it is easy to feel at home. This buffet is available daily, costing $11.80++ on weekdays and $13.80++ on weekends, and features a selection of traditional Teochew dishes. To complement its sweet potato porridge, are a dozen braised dishes and vegetables. Making it more worth the money, the buffet spread is inclusive of desserts, with a small range of cakes, jelly and assorted fruits. If Taiwanese porridge is not your cup of tea, Crystal Café serves western and local cuisine as well. This place offers a well-rounded meal, and is perfect for family lunches or dinners.

After looking at the wine connection (next door) disappointing selection and pricing of sparkling wine by the glass we stumbled across this tapas/Spanish restaurant next door. My expectations were fairly low but as they had two Cavas at 7 SGD per glass I was convinced to give it a try.We also ordered some different tapas for the table to share. The patatas bravas were acceptable,, the croquettes pretty good while the cheese and cold cuts can rather be skipped and the same goes for the padron peppers. In general the food is nothing to get excited about but as a snack when having a drink they are perfectly fine.The cavas were not the best I had but for this price it was a bargain. Nice outdoor setting and friendly service will encourage me to come back.

Came here after a very long day at work and I loved the food. Had the paella (can't remember the name and can't seem to find anything similar on their online menu, but it was the only one with no seafood in it) which was really good, well-cooked and satisfying (or maybe it's just because I was super hungry LOL). One of the best ones I've had in Singapore, on par (or perhaps even better) than the version in Serenity. Way cheaper too! Came in a large pan which was more than enough for 3. We also had the Catalunya pizza ($13)- really simple with only a topping of anchovies and vegetables but well-excecuted. The crust was thin yet flavourful, and very cripsy. And it was big for its price! Dessert was the Crema Catalana ($10) - essentially Creme Brulee. Nice but not sensational, but big enough for 3!. Still, it was a very good meal and worth it for the prices. 3 dishes filled the 3 of us up quite well- a feat considering that we'd been starving for 9 hours before that!Found it quite difficult to get the attention of waiters but they were helpful and polite when they finally came to our table.

This review will probably be of little use to most of you, given the circumstances of my visit to Barraka. The time is 2.15am on a Saturday night and we have just been ejected from The Chamber nearby where we were watching a big football match. They decided to close at half-time, those bastards. We walk around for a while in the Robertson Walk area looking for an alternative and Barraka pops up. The screens are a bit on the small side but there's space, they're open and willing to serve us booze. Moreover, the manager invites us in without malice, despite us being supporters of the team currently beating his 1-0.But the best part? The bill. Four whiskies = $28. That is just simply amazing in Robertson Walk. I have no idea if they had a deal or a happy hour or something, I didn't ask, I just stared at my bill in stupefied amazement.Well I lie actually, the true best part was when my team (Arsenal) won 2-0. But that's some thing the poor, Liverpool-loving Barraka manager had little control over.

Second time here and very pleased with the food, drinks, service and ambience. They have a good variety on the menu that I'm sure will please most tastes. We stick to a Paleo diet and the Polo (grilled chicken breast and vegetables) hits the spot. The prawns and mushroom tapas dish was awesome as well. The entire menu is very Paleo-friendly. The drinks are the cheapest we've found in town - and they're good. I really enjoyed the traditional sangria. The food is also very reasonably priced. Our service tonight has been awesome. This has easily become a large player in my roster of go-to restaurants.

I didn't try any of the food so I cannot comment on that. But Barraka is a nice casual hangout that serves a good selection of beer at fairly reasonable prices considering its central location. So how can you not like that? You do, however, have quite a lot of choices at robertson quay. So Barraka is not a bad choice but not exactly a standout choice with all the other restaurants and bars around.
Sucks! The staff manager of the place attitude!!! Yell at client and still say client yell at him. Please don't waste effort going.

Meh.  We ate tapas which tasted generic. Some of the more expensive ($20+) meat dishes were tasty but overcooked and dry. The drink was cheaper than average.  The bill took 30 mins to process (typical singapore only allowing one person to work the register) so we left feeling our time was wasted. The manager Sam was disinterested, some would say rude. Will probably stick to wine connection next door some time. For good tapas I would recommend the place on Emerald hill and for excellent tapas I would recommend Catalunya on the waterfront by fullerton bay hotel.

Terrible food. The seafood paella was flavorless, over cooked, and (worst of all) full of sand. The service was mostly bad: when we ordered, the waiter offered some useful information, but was otherwise entirely inattentive.

The buffet restaurant was well known for its Penang buffet since the 1970s. For a weekday night, the place was packed with customers. Besides the penang fare, one could also find cold seafood such as crayfish, cooked prawns and mussels on ice.Can't help noticing that everyone just went straight for Tow Kwa Pok. The moment one opened the cover, it smelt so mouth watering. Stuffed with minced pork and vegetables, topped with brown sauce and chilli sauce, it was so delicious.We were lucky to get a plate of freshly fried Char Kway Teow which one could taste the wok hei in it. Remember to help yourself the crispy pork lards. Accompanied the meal with Teh Tarik which tasted not bad at first but felt watered down after having the heavy stuffs. The manager said said that the restaurant used to served Teh Halia (Ginger Tea) but replaced it with Teh Tarik after feedback from customers. There was a number of live stations for Hokkien Mee Thng, Penang Laksa, Kway Teow Thng, Ark Thui Mee Sua Thng, Kueh Pie Tee, Popiah, and Ban Chang Kueh. The broth for the Hokkien Mee Thng was quite rich and flavourful. The Penang Laksa was not bad but the broth was not spicy and sour enough for local Penang taste. The Ban Chang Kueh was light and crispy even after left on the table for quite sometimes. It was made freshly by an old auntie who looked old enough to be my grandma.There was also rare local dishes such as Char Moey and Nasi Ulam which were rare to find these days, but the porridge was lacking of wok hei taste, while the other latter was kind of bland. The Pig Stomach Soup was full bodied and peppery without offending smell or taste from the meat.For dessert, the freshly scooped Tau Huay with Gula Melaka was smooth with kind of an old school feel. The Apom Bokwa was soft and went quite well with the banana sauce. The assorted kuehs such as Kueh Dadar, Kueh Bengkah, Pulut Tai Tai (served with Kaya), Kueh Talam, Abuk-Abuk, Kueh Lapis, Ang Ku Kueh (Tau Sa), and Rice Bengkah  were cut into small pieces. Soft and yummy.

Princess Terrace bills itself as Singapore's Best Loved Penang Buffet. I don't know about that, but it might just be Singapore's Most Expensive Penang Buffet. For almost $50++ per person for weekday lunch while having neither fresh seafood besides prawns and mussels nor a carving station, nor a particularly large spread, this is certainly a pricey buffet to go to.This being a buffet, it is impractical for me to review everything I ate, so I shall make general observations and talk more about a few specific dishes. In general, most of the savory dishes ranged from okay to pretty good.The char kway teow, perhaps the highlight of any Penang buffet, used to be the best my family had found in Singapore. Sadly, the standard has dropped and now it is rather pedestrian, without much wok hei (wok smokey flavour) or flavour not much.On the other hand, the kueh pie ti was good, being both crunchy and savory. The soups too were excellent - the salted vegetable and duck soup fully extracted the flavours of its components, and the pig stomach soup was both tasty and featured stomach that was very smooth (i.e. clean).The Penang Curry Chicken was excellent, being really well spiced, and rich without being overwhelmingly so. The Nasi Ulam (spiced rice) was interesting - I haven't tried it before and it was a delightful culinary experience with the refreshing mixture of flavours in my mouth.The Herbal Duck Mee Sua had a rich soup but was too herbal for my taste. The Penang Laksa taste alright but was quite thin.What really stood out here, I must say, were the desserts.The beancurd dessert was sublime - it was so smooth and slippery, it was like biting into a cloud (though the gula melaka syrup didn't exactly complement it).There was also a large selection of nonya kuehs (cakes). They were cut into small pieces, making it easy for one to try many of them. All of them were very good, with smooth, rich tastes.The ban chang kueh (crispy peanut pancake) was not quite as good crispy but it was rather dry and there was no chewiness to balance the crispiness out. It was quite peanuty but was a touch under sweetened.In short, if you find a good credit card deal, or you really like Penang food it might be worth coming here once in a while. Otherwise you should only come once in a long while since it's really pricey. Or you could always go to Penang instead.

I've been here a few times with my family. I'm not really sure why they like this place so much, but we continue to go here. $50 for lunch buffet seems rather steep, but I'm never the one paying lol. When I was younger, I liked that you could make your own ice kachang, but now that I'm a little older, I like the prawns the most I think. There is a cold section of the buffet and a hot section, on the side, you can order a variety of noodle soups and down a few stairs is the dessert station. It's not that large, but I think there is something for everyone. I liked the steamed Chong fun, the curry, the steamed fish paste thing, and the soups. The duck and noodles and pork I could pass on. I ate maybe 15 boiled prawns, but they were soooo delicious!! Definitely my favorite! Being from the US, where the fruit is terrible, I still end my meal with a few slices of watermelon. I also still make my own ice kachang lol. I don't really like any of the cakes, but there is a good selection of them. Oh, the tofu dessert was also good:) Also, try the ginger tea near the desserts! Service was ok. They are mostly Indian, and they don't speak Chinese, so English is the way to go... but they were friendly and refilled our waters regularly.

Say the words, "I ate at a hotel buffet when I was in Asia" to Anthony Bourdain, and what is he apt to do?  Punch you in the face (though to be fair, it's possible anything you say to Anthony Bourdain risks eliciting the same reaction).Yep, I did the unforgivable by eating at a hotel buffet in Singapore.   Damn proud of it, too.  Now, the buffet at Princess Terrace is not just any old buffet.  It's the only buffet I know of that serves up Penang-style dishes.  I'm sure some Nonya is turning in her grave right now at the mere thought of dishes she spent a lifetime perfecting being served up in chafing dishes.  But for someone who doesn't know jack-squat about Penang cuisine, a buffet offering up the "greatest hits," so to speak, and cooked up by 2 chefs who are actually from Penang, is a terrific way in my opinion to experience Penang foods first hand.  I loved the variety of the foods on offer.  Highlights for me included the kueh pie tee, which were filled to order, the assam laksa, which had a very flavorful fish stock, and the do-it-yourself rojak station, with green mango, guava, pineapple, radish and cucumbers. The otak otak (fish mousse wrapped in banana leaf) and the kerabu bee hoon (rice vermicelli salad) were also good.  The pig's stomach soup and duck meat herbal soup (ark thui mee sua thg) were very flavorful and warming, but light at the same time.  Best of all were the desserts, with 6 or 7 different kinds of homemade kueh (Malaysian sweets) to choose from, and even a ban chang kueh station serving up the peanut pancakes to order!  There's also a banana caramel sauce that I could (and did) just eat by the spoonful, by itself (though it's supposed to go on apom balik pancakes).Not everything was great.  The ayam goreng was overcooked and dry, and the fried fish fillets tasted like the generic dish you would find in any Westernized Chinese restaurant.  But the best part is, you can leave anything you dislike on the plate! The restaurant staff were really helpful in explaining what each dish was and the ingredients in them.  They actively encouraged me to try every dish, even though this admonition inevitably led to a bit of waste, as I had no choice but to take little bites while leaving the rest of the food on the plate.  They were very good about clearing away the dirty plates, too.  +1 star for pretty great service.Overall, unless you actually have a go-to Nonya for all your favorite Penang dishes, the buffet at Princess Terrace is a great way to try out generally quite good renditions of many different dishes, some quite hard to find in Singapore.  P.S. - I used a Citibank card and got an 18% discount off the bill.  This deal lasts at least through December 31, 2012.

Unpretentious and unassuming but very comforting Italian restaurant. You are greeted by the owner, Steven, who welcomes you like he is inviting guests into his home. He's been here for 14 years and has developed quite a loyal following of regulars, families, Japanese businessmen and the couples all can be spotted. If you are looking for uber hip or so cool it hurts, you need to look elsewhere but if you want authentic Italian dishes with hand made pasta, then take a seat and enjoy the food. Nat, Celine and some Luciano will play occasionally for background music. Cloth napkins and tablecloth add a nice touch.We order:Calamari Fritti con Salsa alla Diavola (golden fried crispy squid ring, served with spicy tomato sauce) After the first piece we realized we had overlooked the word 'spicy' and asked if we could replace it with a non-spicy version. No problem and they also asked if we wanted another accompaniment like mayonnaise instead. Helpful service! Even better the lemon wedge came with a little stainless steel lemon slice squeezer so you don't have to use your fingers. Another thoughtful little touch. The dish was fine. I find squid is squid. If it is not rubbery, I'm good.The owner asks how is your food. I don't hear this asked often enough on this little island. He engages in some conversation but short enough to not be intrusive. He wants you to dine before the dish gets cold. It is these little things that make the dining experience.Gli Gnocchi alla Fiorentina (dumpling potato pasta sautéed with minced beef and mushroom in a pink sauce)I'm a sucker for potato anything and this dish was calling my name. It had the right potato to flour proportion and I ate it up. The meat sauce was very enjoyable and Steven, seeing how I was really likely my dish, suggested their 6 cheese sauce gnocchi next time. Can't wait!Pappardelle con Gamberoni in Salsa di Zafferano (handmade flat pasta sautéed with king prawns and sundried tomatoes in a saffron sauce)The pasta noodles were surprisingly light and delicate considering their long, almost sheet-like shape. A hint of saffron made this dish very rewarding to tuck into. Alas I only got one mouthful as it was devoured by my better half.We were in a rush, so moved out without dessert. I would also note to readers that they also have a pizza oven to serve take out pizza or you can dine in. I asked how long typically a pizza takes and thankfully he didn't say 45 minute to an hour!These small, owner-run restaurants where you see the owner taking pride in what he does and making sure patrons are well taken care of are the hidden gems worth discovering. I would highly recommend you try them out.

This is a service review - not a food review. Visited Spizzico Westgate at noon on a Sunday and was [initially] surprised to see no other customers. They seem to have some interesting beers on draft but I couldn't decide which to order. When I asked for a taste of one to help me decide, both the waiter and what seemed to be the manager rudely and flatly refused without explanation. They further didn't offer any recommendation. So, we decided to visit Spageddies instead and had another great meal with pleasant and attentive staff. No customers at noon on a rainy Sunday in a prime location doesn't seem that surprising after all.

One of our dining companions also mentioned Spizzico when the topic of good Italian food came up, which is why the vouchers were purchased.The place is tucked away at the very quiet UE square and the restaurant was not very crowded when we were there. It has a very homestyle feel to the place, like an Italian home.A strange incident happened when we tried to order with the head waiter, who could not really answer our questions properly regarding how the food was prepared, and had a bit of a trouble hearing as well. He wasn't really helpful.First up the Caprese salad ($20). It was very refreshing, and the buffalo mozzarella was solid and quite tasty.We also tried the Parmigiana with eggplant ($14). Rather average, now to think of it.We also had for mains, the Italiana pizza ($22). It is white pizza with parma ham. It was not much of the thin-crust variety and lacked a bit in terms of the texture or 'exciting taste' department. It was a very.. safe pizza. Meh.The seafood risotto with saffron ($24) was quite good though. There were bits of prawns and scallops inside mixed with parmesan cheese coating. They made the whole risotto less 'gelak' and lent it a very rich tone.Then we also had the soft shell crab spaghetti ($22). Also quite good because it was slightly spicy and the pasta was not soggy.Lastly, panna cotta ($12). I actually really like panna cotta and this place does it quite well. Very classic type of dessert. We were too full for tiramisu.Other than the rather odd waiter, the food itself here is pretty good, since I can still remember how they taste after so many months. I wouldn't pay full price for Spizzico though - try to go only if there's another group deal voucher going on!

I was quite surprised by its extensive selection of food and it even has an alfresco dining area for those who prefer outdoors. The menu stays close to a traditional Italian style, from soup, salad, cold appetizer, hot appetizers... to risottos, pastas, seafood, carne (meat) and of course desserts.   But we could not wait and jumped right into the hot appetizer section. Nothing could go severely wrong when fresh squid is used to make this Golden Calamari rings ($18) instead of rubbery frozen kinds. These lightly-battered sotongs are better off on its own instead of being dipped into the Diabolo sauce, which may overpower the original taste the meat.Not sure if the flat pasta was undercooked as it was rather tough and not anywhere near "char kway teow" nor "hor fun" like the owner humorously quipped. However, the saffron sauce with sundried tomato was not too cheesy along with some fresh, bouncy scallops & prawns.For my main course of seafood, I tend to avoid cod fish but this was not overwhelming rich with nicely browned edges. The Cream Wasabi Sauce was slightly too sweet and would prefer it to be sharper. From the Meat, the highly anticipated beef tenderloin was too thick and thus there was not much taste from the meat or the little sauce. At $42, the quality was not convincing and thus I would still recommend their thin crust pizzas.We were surprised when the Smoked Salmon Pizza ($20) looked like it had just travelled out from the forest with the lush canopy of wild rocket. It was not spicy as I expected, but the bright flavors of capers and onions complemented the smoked salmon very well.Not everyone might be fond of the wobbly Pannacotta ($12) but I do. It was not sweet at all and the dark golden brown caramel sauce was bitter, just the way it should be.On the hindsight, the Cassata($12), a traditional Italian dessert of semifreddo, dried fruits and chocolate sponge was nothing very special. Think ice cream parfait with harder texture.After coming across many mediocre tiramisu at restaurants, Spizzico's version ($12) was a pleasant surprise with moist sponges and traceable amounts of coffee liquor. A simple yet delightful end-of-meal desserts to have.Overall, the food here is relatively sound and I would stick to the pizza, pastas and desserts instead of the seafood/meat course. But what is heartening to know is that the ingredients used at Spizzico are fresh and the sauces are made from scratch. While this place gives me a prim and proper feel with neatly ironed table sheets and heavy utensils, I can imagine it to be a suitable location for families and couples to enjoy quality fare away from the crowds.

address: 80 Mohamed sultan Rd #01-12 The Pier Singapore 239013 Singapore
comment: Singapore - Located on the Riverwalk along the Singapore River, the setting is very nice, as was the service. I sat outside, with great views of the river and people meandering by. Menu appeared to be largely a Thai-Malaysian cuisine. Ordered Satay and a fish curry dish. Food was okay but did not match the setting. Was hoping/expecting recognizable flavors (e.g., aromatic ginger, chilli, kapi, fish paste, mint, etc) but it was not to be. The curry was bland, with no depth or interest. Pretty disappointed.

Our group was looking for a place to eat and still enjoy the hustle and bustle of Clarke Quay, so we settled on this place. As far as location, this place was great. The main restaurant was in the corner while they had covered outdoor seating right on the river walk. The sangrias were okay. I ordered the calamari, a spicy tuna roll, and the scallops, of which were nothing to write home about. But the wait. There were a few times where we were just waiting. And waiting. And waiting. "For what?" you may ask. To take our order, for our food, etc. Which came as a surprise since the place didn't look very busy.Note to self: stick to asian food when in Asia.

Crap food and mediocre service.  The namesake octopus was strangely fishy tasting (which it definitely should not be) and now after leaving I'm left wondering if I will wake up at 4 am praying to the porcelain god in my hotel bathroom. Nothing we had was noteworthy and frankly, while it was edible, I was embarrassed to have brought a business colleague with me for dinner. Never again.

A definite place to avoid in Singapore, we should have read the yelp before coming here. We had some of the worst service of our life and we were the only ones in the restaurant. The waitress sat on her phone at the bar and forgot to make our drinks the whole time we were there and never removed them from the bill. Food was also mediocre at best.

Visiting from the USA and decided to try this place. My party has had lots of Spanish tapas over the years ... this was the worst ever. Food was not good.. no one could eat it. Drinks were weak too. Service was ok not good... and they did forget my drink. Was an expensive meal we couldn't eat.

Horrible service we came for happy hour 1 for 1 drinks and when the bill came the server changed the tab around and we had to complain to get the promo. The serve didn't want to give us the promo and was rude I will never come back to this location again. There are so many choices of bars to go to what ever you do not go to this bar go some where else you will get better service

We were legitimately the only people here for lunch and the service was terrible. Half of our food and our happy hour drinks were not brought out and the server made us feel that we were unwanted here. Also none of the food was enjoyable

I was extremely excited to try a Spanish Tapas Bar in Singapore to reminisce on my amazing experience in Barcelona, Spain. Obviously I knew that the experience and food wouldn't be the same or as authentic, and probably a bit overpriced because Octapas is located in the tourist central of Clarke Quay. First off, we made a reservation for a Wednesday night dinner for our friend's birthday. They accidentally gave away our table inside where the live music played (which was not good music anyways) and shifted us outside. At least it was shaded and not too hot outside. We ordered a few tapas and a paella that supposedly fed 4 people. Throughout the course of our dining experience with Octapas, our party progressively became more and more dissatisfied.My extremely small plate of S$12 Champinones al Ajilo (Mushrooms with Garlic) was drenched in oil and salt. I had to chug my entire cup of water while eating it. And, when I asked for more water - it took forever to get the waiter's attention and we had to ask repeatedly (3 times) to get my refill. And, our bland Valenciana (Meat & Seafood) Paella was $60 and finally came after about 45-50 minutes. This dish is supposed to serve 4 people, but it was extremely small, overcooked, and had an awful cardboard taste. There wasn't much meat (chorizos) or seafood either!  Also, our $15 Caipirinha cocktails were extremely sweet and barely had any alcohol in it.  Save your time and money by going somewhere else! I would've rather eaten snacks or a Bao at 7-Eleven.

All up it was $96 for 3 plates of very average tapas and 2 cocktails. After traditional spanish tapas? This is not the place.At first glance the ambience was nice, however we we're greeted by blank faced staff as we looked for a table. Upon seating ourselves we we're told that the table we sat at was being used by someone else and if we could move to another table...a reasonable request to which we happily obliged. First up was the drinks, having a quick glance at the slightly pricey cocktail menu I opted for a margherita and was asked if I wanted lime, raspberry or something else that sounded a bit candy store..This would usually be a red flag for me but being extremely hot I wasnt in the mood for scanning the menu again so I just went with the lime. It wasn't the worst but certainly not the best, incredibly sweet and tasted like a premix. For tapas we opted for cheese croquetes, a bruschetta style plate & some lamb cutlets. The croquetes themselves we're OK. But they came with a cinnamon style jam which when used together gave the sensation of eating a cheese donut.... Weird. The bruschetta was a doughy, white bread roll cut in half and spread with a tomato, garlic ish paste. In my opinion inedible. I love lamb cutlets, possibly one of my top 10 favourite meals. These we're OK but extremely fatty, I've never seen cutlets with that much fat around the entire cut (close to half an inch).
Love the live band they bring the life to the party... we were dancing and enjoying our time with them. A must visit in he popular area of Clarke quay. Come early because they do get packed.
I should've checked Yelp before going here! The name is pretty cool, but the spinach was dirty, the lamb was chewy, and the drinks were week. I would avoid this place.

Octapas is a cleverly named tapas bar on the bank of the historical Singapore River, along Clarke Quay. Right next to the Read Bridge (pre-party central), Octapas offers indoor as well as outdoor seating to its patrons. Most nights, live music can be found at this quaint yet vibrant joint, and you can sip an ice cold beverage of your choice as you watch tourist-laden bumboats float by. The menu offers simple Spanish fare, some items more traditional than others, but all of it tasty and satisfying. They also have a happy hour, for those who want to eat out on the cheap - always a bonus in my book! Service can be hit or miss, which is unfortunate, but not uncommon in such touristy areas. Though in my opinion, the food is well worth the occasional frosty waitress. Try the garlic bread, chorizo, meatballs, bacon wrapped prawns, chicken in cream sauce, and croquettes.Buen provecho!

This review is for the happy hour only. The happy here is pretty decent. The patio is right on the river, so it creates a nice scene/back drop. The drinks are 50% on wine and beer until 8pm for happy hour. They have a delicious wine list that I had to take a picture of in order to remember what I was drinking so I could find it later. I thought the service was good. We might have eaten there, but neither of us thought the menu looked good. I'll go back for the wine, but that's about it. For 2 glasses of wine, I paid S$15.5 after the happy hour discount.

I wish I had read Yelp before I came. The location of this place is beautiful but the service was just so bad it's not worth coming here. We were the only table and our waitress forgot to bring our drinks and one of the dishes and when the food did come she brought out the wrong dish. The food was very mediocre. When the bill came it had the drinks on them. All in all poor experience.

Worse meal ever in Singapore. Clearly meant fot yourist as no local would ever go back to this place.Terrible microwaved food for an exorbitant price. We paid 110$ for good that was not worth that price. Meatballs we dry and hard, clearly microwaved. The worse was the asparagus wrapped in ham. Burnt, dried and shrivelled - completely disgraceful. Can't imagine a chef who would be proud to serve that to his patrons. Clearly unqualified.What made matter even worse was when we called the serve over she had the audacity to tell us we were asking too much and asparagus at the restaurant has aleays been prepared that way. Throughout our meal she as rude ans giving us quite an attitude.Don't waste your money. Stay away. Spend it on somewhere else that is worth your hard earned money.

Absolutely horrible. I ordered the Sea Bass with Verde Salsa. I kid you not, it was seriously overcooked fish, butter, salt and some peas. Disgusting and they charge $17 for it. Also the dish is incredibly small. On top of all of this they charge $5 for a bread basket. And the bread is incredibly subpar, and the butter is cheap and of very poor quality.Also the food took an incredibly long time to come and when my friends (who ordered the Paella) got their food, it looked like it sat in a fridge for a couple days before they microwaved it and put it on our table. I don't understand how it could have taken 45 minutes to microwave a dish.Anyways me and my party didn't even eat our food after trying it. We refused to eat it and told the waiter that we refused to pay for their pathetic excuse for food. It certainly doesn't help that their service was just horrendous. So incredibly slow.Also our reservation was not honored and only after standing our ground with the staff did we get a table outside.

Honestly, there are much better options in Clark Quay other than this one.I went with my friend to have a girl's night out. We ordered Paella to share and we were told that we have to wait for 30 mins so the waitress recommended that we order tapas as well. As we are already starving, we ordered beef and calamares. Lo and behold, paella came like 10 mins later. While we were eating, the waitress came over and told us that they need to send back the paella as this was for the other table (good for 4) and not for 2.Ok, so they take back the paella to the kitchen to do what again? Add more and serve to another table? And then she came back and said its okay like we owe her. I wanted to call the manager and talk to them about this unacceptable quality of service but was there to catch up and spend quality time with a friend so I didn't bother anymore.We ended up paying $120 for a mediocre food and utterly lousy service.Really not worth it!

Every time I go running along the marina, I see Octapas.  It's cute sign, clever name, and location are all so alluring that we decided to check it out.  First disappointment, the menu.  It is not tapas.  None of our favorite spanish tapas: bacon wrapped dates, cheese stuffed peppers, etc. were on the menu.  We should have left at this point, but we didn't.Second disappointment, the disco ball that started up immediately after we placed our order.  We were in the mood for something casual and low key, and did not anticipate the disco ball which felt so NOT Spanish (albeit fitting for Clark Quay).Third disappointment, the food.  It was just not good.Lastly, everyone else mentioned, service is terrible.I was literally angry by the time we left.  Poor food, poor ambiance, poor service.  Why waste your money?

Incredibly nice location and some very good food options and choices for the vegetarians too!! Service is decent and a seat by the water front just does it!! I will surely go back here again sometime with friends

Service was awesome. We came for just drinks but ended up trying some tapas. Price was okie for the location. Food was excellent. Highly recommended. The seating by the river is an added bonus. But the band after 930pm was not bad. Overall, an excellent place to spend an otherwise boring Tuesday night. Thumbs up guys! Keep up the good work!

We came here during happy hour to refresh ourselves from the outside swelter. Half off Sangrias were tasty and affordable.We got the shrimp tapas which were amazing and came in a metal dish of olive oil and garlic. Tasted great but is also twice what you would pay for comparable tapas in the states and seemed an expensive food option compared to other area foods. Although I give the food and drinks top marks I found it overpriced.

Here I am back in Singapore for another business trip and decided to take my coworker out for dinner before he needed to leave Singapore. I told him that I liked Octapas from my previous trip.I was looking forward to having Paella Valencia again as it is their signature dish. We ordered our drinks from yet another cheery waitress as noticed on my previous visit. When the waitress came back I placed out food order for the Paella as I knew it would take a bit longer to cook. We were into our second cocktail when the kitchen brought out the pan of Paella and took the foil covering off at the table. I can't describe well enough how excellent the dish was enjoyed by the both of us as this was a most delicious meal. I was so glad that my decision to return to this establisment as a treat to my coworker. Our culinary experience was only topped such an attentive staff as well as Manager that personally asked how our meal was being enjoyed.Once again I not only recommend Octapas, but state that I will be back for at least one more dinner here before my business trip concludes. Kudos to the hard working staff that consistently makes this place a favorite of mine in Singapore!

We came here during happy hour to refresh ourselves from the outside swelter. Half off Sangrias were tasty and affordable.We got the shrimp tapas which were amazing and came in a metal dish of olive oil and garlic. Tasted great but is also twice what you would pay for comparable tapas in the states and seemed an expensive food option compared to other area foods. Although I give the food and drinks top marks I found it overpriced.

We refused to eat it and told the waiter that we refused to pay for their pathetic excuse for food. It certainly doesn't help that their service was just horrendous. So incredibly slow.Also our reservation was not honored and only after standing our ground with the staff did we get a table outside.

This place is dreadful.  Gave our are reservation and got irritated when we complained to the manager for a table.  Service was awful and the food is overpriced. 3 out 6 of us sent back our food because it was so bad. Fish was practically just salt and butter.  Drinks were also 95% juice.  Avoid!

Honestly, there are much better options in Clark Quay other than this one.I went with my friend to have a girl's night out. We ordered Paella to share and we were told that we have to wait for 30 mins so the waitress recommended that we order tapas as well. As we are already starving, we ordered beef and calamares. Lo and behold, paella came like 10 mins later. While we were eating, the waitress came over and told us that they need to send back the paella as this was for the other table (good for 4) and not for 2.Ok, so they take back the paella to the kitchen to do what again? Add more and serve to another table? And then she came back and said its okay like we owe her. I wanted to call the manager and talk to them about this unacceptable quality of service but was there to catch up and spend quality time with a friend so I didn't bother anymore.We ended up paying $120 for a mediocre food and utterly lousy service.Really not worth it!

Great paella, mediocre tapas, abysmal service. The waitress would disappear for a half hour at a time. It was an hour from the time we ordered the paella until it was delivered. 40 minutes to receive an order of churros. 20 minutes to pay the check that we have to beg to get out of the place. The carne paella was delicious though the chicken was overcooked. The bacon wrapped shrimp was tasty but the rest of the tapas were just mediocre. All in all not worth the aggravation to have a tuna half hour meal. Can't recommend it.

Octapas is a cleverly named tapas bar on the bank of the historical Singapore River, along Clarke Quay. Right next to the Read Bridge (pre-party central), Octapas offers indoor as well as outdoor seating to its patrons. Most nights, live music can be found at this quaint yet vibrant joint, and you can sip an ice cold beverage of your choice as you watch tourist-laden bumboats float by. The menu offers simple Spanish fare, some items more traditional than others, but all of it tasty and satisfying. They also have a happy hour, for those who want to eat out on the cheap - always a bonus in my book! Service can be hit or miss, which is unfortunate, but not uncommon in such touristy areas. Though in my opinion, the food is well worth the occasional frosty waitress. Try the garlic bread, chorizo, meatballs, bacon wrapped prawns, chicken in cream sauce, and croquettes.Buen provecho!

One of my favorite unique Chinese restaurant in Singapore!  They use Chinese herbs in their dishes to create a healthy Chinese food experience.  So it's yummy and medicinally good for you!  They use high quality simple ingredients with delicacies such as abalone and sea cucumber.  Some of the dishes I don't agree with like shark fin but I understand it's on the menu because it's culturally accepted (and I'm Chinese!...but from California).  I had the $88 special for lunch, which they recommended and I'm glad I had that one. I definitely want to go back for more!!!  Best to go with more people to explore more on the menu.

Lousy service, visited a few times, consistently did not bring orders on the table.No apology for oversight, on the contrary, "that's why we didn't charge you for the food we forgot to bring out since you cancel it."

An old, homey European restaurant. Reminds me of this place in Los Angeles called Anna's near west side pavilion that closed down already, but my grandparents and his friends used to take me all the time as a kid. Anna's is an Italian restaurant and Tavern is more like an Austrian, German, other types of European food. Their cheese is delicious, their Parma ham is sprinkled with Parmesan so it's nice and salty, they have Australian and Japanese Wagyu. We opted for Japanese medium rare 260g, did not disappoint. Other people had the chateaubriand also delicious. And cod. Paired everything with a red bottle of pomerol. Ended the dessert with crepe Suzette. Nice homey Christmas meal.

Have been to this restaurant a number of times over the last decade or so. The dinning experience I would ranked as above average but it wasn't so in my last encounter. The Foie Gras which have been so call the signature dish has remained the same -- right, the same, as everybody else have innovated and improved. Main was the Japanese wagyu and US prime (don't think it's USDA certified as the waiter doesn't even know what I was saying.) Wanted the steaks to be medium well and indeed it was -- but they tasted so similar to the hainanese style steak we used to have from many other places. The steaks looked grilled but the taste is almost like pan-fried. This is really a big disappointment and one that you don't expect from an rather established old joint. Got only myself to blame for not trying out the newer joints in town.
I love the Tavern.  Amazing quality of meats and sides, the Tavern is my favorite little hole in the wall.

address: The Foot Hills 70 River Valley Road #01-15 Singapore 179037 Singapore
comment: Very nice ambience . Suitable for family and children as there's a place where children can run around . Had Cajun grilled cheese sandwich . It was nice , crunch on the outside , soft n fluffy inside , well marinated chicken. Not greasy at all . Ice mocha just nice , not too sweet . A very pleasant experience indeed .

address: The Foot Hills 70 River Valley Road #01-15 Singapore 179037 Singapore
comment: I went here on Easter Sunday with a couple friends and enjoyed the food and atmosphere quite a bit. It's set in a park, so it was exactly the kind of place that you'd want to go for a cute brunch. We got pancakes (I got the plain and my friends got chocolate chip) and they were delicious and fluffy. I got scrambled eggs on the side and felt that they could have had a bit more flavor (nothing a little extra salt can't fix), but my friend got eggs Benedict and really liked those. I would recommend going here because it was a really cute place and wasn't too expensive, with pretty good food for both breakfast and lunch.

address: The Foot Hills 70 River Valley Road #01-15 Singapore 179037 Singapore
comment: Good cake selection, they have a nice carrot cake (voted best by Daniel's food diary). Coffee is alright. Food is halal but the French toast was more like a churro... the cooked food and lunch items are average

address: The Foot Hills 70 River Valley Road #01-15 Singapore 179037 Singapore
comment: Nice little restaurant with an extensive cake selection where you can eat yourself silly. The red velvet cake is very popular. Only downside is accessibility. For those who drive, you will have to park opposite at Liang Court mall & take the overhead bridge on the 2nd floor of Liang Court. It's about a 200m uncovered walk from the bridge to the cafe so it's a bit of a hassle especially when it rains. Staff are friendly. Space can get a bit crowded during busy periods as the tables are quite close to each other. There is a nice selection of mains to suit most taste buds.

address: The Foot Hills 70 River Valley Road #01-15 Singapore 179037 Singapore
comment: Unimpressed. A great place to eat if you get hungry walking around Fort Canning but a less than charming vibe, employees that look miserable and a incessant electronic voice that speaks every time the door is opened, welcoming you to the place which I found tedious. Definitely not what we were looking for for brunch.

address: The Foot Hills 70 River Valley Road #01-15 Singapore 179037 Singapore
comment: Valrhona chocolate cake ($9.01 on Honestbee) - 4.5 starsGood cake! They're right it's best served at room temperature.Fish and chips - 3 starsToo salty! But I ate this a couple hours after so maybe it would've tasted less salty had I eaten it fresh...?I got this via Honestbee delivery (honestbee.sg/r/NICOLAL53… for $10 off) and have to go down to the store to try their other cakes and food!

address: The Foot Hills 70 River Valley Road #01-15 Singapore 179037 Singapore
comment: Interesting location near fort canning park opposite from Liang court. It's in a busy location, but is slightly in the park, which makes it quite peaceful. I ordered the spicy fried chicken and waffles. They told me it would take 15 minutes...its been more like 25. I had to personally ask the waitress to take my order...that was a bit ridiculous. Also, they had the audacity to give me the bill at a sit down restaurant before I even got my food. However, the food was very delicious!
