No mixed feelings on the translucent-looking vermicelli (aged rice milled by hand). I vouched for its refreshing taste and the to-die-for claims by many others who have tried. The texture of vermicelli was extremely chewy (not rubbery), unlike others who soiled the noodles, making it soggy & brittle. The rice noodle was thread-thin yet chewing has been made possible on each strands amazingly. You could taste the sweet broth (using pork, chicken bones) in the vermicelli, though it was fried dry. The seafood heightened the flavour of the dish. The clams, prawns, scallops enhanced the taste, making it more refreshing while the roasted peanuts, fried shallots (with garlic bits), crispy seaweeds contributed to the crunch. I have no doubt in my choice.To end the lunch, I asked for the dessert menu. Pumpkin cream with ice-cream & Sweet potato balls were picked among the 8 choices (by now, you should be aware that I am a big fan of pumpkin and sweet potato). The pumpkin paste was smooth and silky. It tasted fresh and home-made, definitely not a canned puree. Moderately sweetened by the accompanying scoop of coconut ice-cream, making it creamier. The pulut hitam (pudding-like black glutinous rice) was barely noticeable except for the grated peanuts. But the pumpkin would still taste pleasantly good without these. The sweet potato balls however, tasted inferior. More of a mochi treat. Previously it tasted real with sweet potato mash but now, the deep fried balls were coupled with more starch in the mash. I didn't like the chewy texture, I'd wanted a creamy & wholesome sweet potato mash balls instead. Not making it better, there was a greasy sick taste (soaked up too much oil), causing greater disappointment. Still, the pumpkin cream managed to salvage my almost-ruined sweet indulgence.

really good heng hwa food at this crowded outlet at the nex mall in serangoon. I really rather like the putien chain - the flavours are light but intense, and while service can get rather hectic when full-house, it's efficient and earnest when you do get it. highly reliable, consistently delicious, and a large enough menu to return frequently (though we do have our favourites, of course).we started with jellyfish - decent, though I've had better. they do it here with XO sauce, which brings a mild bite. the better starter was their fried century egg: wedges fried up in a crispy batter and tossed in a sweet-sour sauce; this was delicious. it always makes me laugh when americans use these delicious things as fear-factor type challenges.the salt and pepper clams are addictive, and the beancurd with kailan are a must order. the beancurd sheets are wrapped to a satisfying thickness - so they bite al-dente and the flavour of the soya bean comes through.but my favourite really is their squirrel fish. essentially a filleted fish fried to a golden-brown and topped with a sweet and sour sauce. it's completely, and utterly delicious - the fish is fresh and moist, the batter stands up fantastically to the sauce, which is enlivened by the tiny bits of vegetables strewn atop. I have massive cravings for this fish.the meat dishes are pretty good home-cooking too. we finished the meal with a fruit platter and syruped loquats - I'm not one for syrupy things but the latter were very interesting.if you've skipped that long spew, then I really like this restaurant. honest cooking, good prices, decent portions and highly consistent standards even across outlets - and I have a soft spot for regional chinese cooking (much of what we have locally is more generally cantonese than anything else).p.s. other dishes I also like: their seaweed appetiser, three-egg spinach, braised beancurd with meat sauce (how vague is that description), fried egg plant with pork floss, steamed prawns with garlic, braised beancurd with cabbage, and their noodle dishes.p.p.s. what I really mean to say is: we haven't had a thing on this menu we didn't liked.

I had Pu Tien in some of their other outlets. But when I went to this one, for some reasons none of the dishes were good. Something is missing or the dishes are just not tasty. We had all their typical signature dishes but they just didn't work for me that day.Not sure if it is the chef's off day or this outlet is just not as good.

Pu tien's not your typical Chinese restaurant. I'm saying this in reference to the type of food being served. If you haven't tried Xing hua (a Han ethnic group from Pu tian) food, I highly recommend you to go visit at least once. The restaurant is pretty big and spacious. I like it that it is lit up pretty brightly and fresh look unlike most Chinese restaurants that usually go for a dimly-lit, warm and cosy feel. A very good place for a family meal or tea time with friends. Food prices are pretty affordable given the great quality of food and nice ambience. Must tries: Pu tien lor mee, homemade beancurd, stir-fried yam. Their chilli is amazing and goes well with almost any of their dishes, especially staples like noodles.- I usually end up with getting 2 or 3 helpings.

I found my favorite stall here - Ayam Penyet.It is the same Ayam Penyet stall found in Raffles City food court. The ayam penyet and bakar bawal are excellent. The soup is tasty though it can be a tad too salty. The chili is power - super spicy. The kecap manis is readily available. The other stalls which I used to patronize are the fish soup and beef noodle. They are pretty decent. The roast meat stall is so-so, you can save your calories, likewise for coffee@work the fried beehoon. Really not worth the calories.

The Ayam Penyet stall (bugis junction food court,food junction)charged me $9.80 for one packet of ayam penyet with an extra serving of a few pieces of sliced sausages. I could have stomached it if they had told me abt the $3 surcharge earlier before i bought it ,but they didnt and just smiled when i asked them why it was so expensive. Their answer was "It is boss decision". Maybe i looked like an easy target.The rice was clumpy and cooked very badly..no fragance nor texture to it at all.I felt like I was eating a riceball with no grains. The chilli was just overwhelmingly spicy,with no layers to it as you would expect from the dish. And the $3 chicken sausage slices was run-of-the-mill and mediocre at best..i stopped eating the whole packet after a few mouthfuls cos of the awful taste it left in my mouth.Honestly, if you feel like being a carrot-head awaiting the vegetable knife and chopping board, you are welcomed to give it a try.p.s.if i could give it a NO-STAR rating, i would. But the system doesnt allow that. So 1-star it is.

You don't often get a mall with two different food courts in Singapore, and Nex is one of those: both Food Republic and Food Junction has taken up space there. But my favourite by far is Food Junction, even though the former is supposed to be more fancy and better tasting. I'm not entirely sure, but I also think Food Junction has more stalls.The choice here is excellent, with a variety of Chinese, Malay and western food to choose from. The food court also has several cordoned off areas pretending to be full-fledged restaurants, and I've never felt the urge to try those.Some of my go-to's for good and non-fussy meals include Pepper Lunch Express, the Chinese noodles stall, and the fried hokkien noodles/char kway teow stall (I'll devote another review entirely to that).

address: 127 Lor 1 Toa Payoh # 02-25 Toa Payoh West Market and Food Centre Singapore 310127 Singapore
comment: This is really good prawn noodle soup. What makes it good? The broth.It has a prawny robust taste that you will not really be able to tell it is a halal stall. It is popular with many customers during lunch time. I like that you have other seafood options. I ordered the clams prawn bee hoon soup and it was full of la-la. I definitely had clam coma after that and it satisfied my craving. They were fresh and sweet. There were also crayfish and a huge seafood platter option. I saw most people ordering this clam prawn noodle soup though.

address: 127 Lor 1 Toa Payoh # 02-25 Toa Payoh West Market and Food Centre Singapore 310127 Singapore
comment: The stall was located at the second floor of the hawker centre, on top of the market. I was pretty surprised that there was no queue when I reached the stall, as the surrounding stalls were lined with queues even for the drink stall. There was no notice about its promotion which was reported online on instagram. I checked with the owner that the promotion was available. Maybe because there was no notice and no one knew that there was a promotion going on. The stall offered the chinese style prawn noodles soup, with 3 different kinds of noodles (yellow noodle, kuay teow, bee hoon)  to select from. From the basic prawn noodle soup at $3.50 to the atas lobster prawn noodle soup at $28.50.But to celebrate its first month since opening, Lobster prawn noodle soup will be $26.50 instead of $28.50, $10 for big prawn and crayfish.Prawn Noodles with Clams (usual S$6.50)Today it was going at $6 per bowl.There was lots of clams which I had counted 18 pieces. All the clams were packed with juicy sweet meats, and no empty ones. The broth was flavourful and slightly peppery. Best there was no "Kee" taste in the yellow noodles. Although usually prawn noodle soup came with slice pork and crispy pork lard, but as this stall was ran by a Muslim couple, there was none of these items in the dish. But the dish could still hold itself very well.

Stumbled to this area and read that the reviews of this Zichar is pretty good. Tried a few dishes here and agreed with the good reviews:1) Fish Head Steamboat - something about soup cooked over high heat (read wok-Hei) just rocks my world. The fish chunks are generous in amount and the flavour is just awesome. Plus the soup comes with free refill, that totally wins Liao!2) Salted Egg Squid - deep fried sotong rings with salted egg batter. Win already. Mum complained cannot see the sotong but I just like the batter. Haha3) Herbal Wrapped-Chicken - nice and tender. Hubby likes the sauce with accompanied with rice. I find the rest of their dishes also very good, like their Broccoli with Garlic and Chye Boh Omelette. We are so in love with this Zichar place now.
Love the food great price n the service is very professional. I was treated like family

Yi Jia seafood is a "zi char" stall that has been featured in several newspapers in Singapore. Their most notable dish is their prawns in rockmelon, strawberry sauce chicken and marmite pork.My friends and I went down to Yi Jia seafood for a gathering last week and it was a disappointing trip. We ordered 2 of the 3 recommended dishes, the strawberry chicken and marmite pork. Together with hot plate tofu and oyster sauce vegetables, the whole course tasted average at best.I beg to differ from the reviews of Yi Jia found on the papers regarding the dishes as the dishes seemed like a try-hard at innovation. The marmite pork was overcooked and did not have a marmite taste. The strawberry sauce chicken tasted like fried chicken with strawberry from a box of "yan yan" biscuit dips. Finally, the service was exceptionally slow. From the time of ordering to the time the first dish was served, we had waited for an hour. Secondly, the dishes were slow to come out of the kitchen, as we nearly finished our rice before even the 2nd dish arrived. I do not recommend this stall to anyone with high expectations and one who has after-dinner plans as the slow service destroyed the pace of the meal.

Fast and efficient service. Around 10 other customers here at 3pm having lunch.Piping hot beef Pho arrived in 4 minutes.Noodles had good bite to them. The soup is borderline not watery and the flavours are subdued. The beef brisket is good. The bowl feels light on vegetables but perhaps I've been spoilt by "little Vietnam" in geylang.Black Vietnamese coffee smooth and sweet. How else?After reading a few reviews it seems that hair in soup seems a common happening. Naturally a hair appeared in my bowl of noodles. The waitress whipped it away and replaced it with a new one.I'm quite a hairy guy yet I don't often find my own hair in my soup... so what am I doing wrong?

okay-for-weekday vietnamese food at the ever-crowded nex mall in serangoon. this is an okay choice for dinner - it's something different from the local food you'd usually have on a weekday night for not much more money, and the flavors are adequate. not quite a destination restaurant, however.to be fair, this is rather like the vietnamese version of thai express - it's fast (sort of, though we had rather a wait seeing as how it got pretty busy at the 1930h mark), it's rather cheap - you don't come here for gourmet.mango salad is decent if veering on the sweet side with a almost-too-syrupy dressing, summer rolls are a roll-up of thick vermicelli noodles, lettuce and chicken (more than the sum of its parts really, especially with a dip into sauce), and the prawn balls on sugarcane were bouncy without being greasy.the mains I thought were rather better - and decent enough to return for. they took a little longer than the appetisers to arrive (and they also forgot one of our orders) - but a plate of stir-fried beef vermicelli was full of that smoky wok flavor and a pleasing mix of veg (rather like japchae), and the grilled chicken that came with broken rice and a sunny-side-up was certainly properly cooked.we finished with a dessert that seemed like a melange of chendol, sago (white tapioca balls), coconut cream and mango - it did ok as a something sweet.I'm certainly all for middling establishments and chains - but this one is closer to thai express than sushi tei - so I'll still be recommending the latter (there seems no bound to the number of times I can eat at that establishment).

address: 23 Serangoon Central #B1-05/06 NEX Mall Singapore 556083 Singapore
comment: My hubby and I love one of their steamboat broth at Xian De Lai, especially their duck soup base since the days we been eating at their liang seah street branch. At the nex branch, the hot pot comes in individual pots. These means that everyone can have a soup base of their choice. The branch at nex allows you to have two options either set meal or buffet. Hmm, we usually think that the buffet would be a value for money and often we will opt of that. They have a self service sauce station for you to mix  your own dipping sauce for your meal. The items for the steamboat are rather fresh and I like the homemade noodles that are beef, pork and chicken and their dumplings too.  They also have a list of cooked food for you to choose from and they are delicious too.

Located within 5 minutes walk of Exit C of Potong Pasir MRT station is Mellben Legend Seafood, one of the Mellben that is NETT priced!! The ang mo kio outlet charges GST and Service charge!On a monday evening, the business was quite slow, we were one of the 3 groups of patrons at the restaurant. Even though it is a coffee shop style, it was still reasonably airy, it wasn't too stuffy. They have huge ceiling fans to circulate air around the shop.Mellben is famed for not using any MSG in their crabs. I have eaten at Mellben 4 times before and each time, I am always happy to go home, without feeling overly thirsty, but yet the food is still very tasty!1. Butter Crab 1.1kg $66At $60/kg, the price has gone up by $2 since the last time I visited in december 2014 and the freshness is still there. My friends who visited from JB said this was one of the hugest crabs they have seen, and they liked that the meat was easy to pick off the shell and that the meat had a harder texture, wasn't mushy. This signaled that the meat was fresh.The buttery sauce was addictive, I loved it. There was enough meat to feed 3 adults in this crab.They also enjoyed the buttery sauce, which went well with the fried mantous.2. Fried Mantous 5 for $3Even though we had the mantous sitting for a while, they were still crispy on the outside. Alot better than the ones I had at AMK, whereby the mantous were obviously fried a long time ago, but since the business at that outlet is always so busy, the staff just quickly grab a plate and serve. These mantous were served to us, about 5 minutes after they had served us our crabs. Probably because they had to cook it after they cooked the crab!3. Fried Prawn Paste Chicken $12These chicken pieces were very plump and well seasoned. The fresh aroma of the prawn paste was addictive. I definitely enjoyed this plate of fried chicken. The skin was also very crispy, and not too fatty.4. Fried Hong Kong Noodles $5I loved how wet this plate of noodles was. The prawns in the dish were also crunchy and fresh. They wasn't alot of wok hei fragrance to the dish, but you can still tasted the charred bits of the noodles.It was very easy to make a reservation, although the lady whom I've made a reservation with 4 times before is a PRC lady, so knowing mandarin would be a plus. Do note they will charge you $2 per box to da bao anything. It is a ridiculous price, but whatever. Bring your box I guess?The service is okay, not the worst, not the best, but the 2 PRC ladies were friendly throughout our meal. Not sure if this is a bad sales tactic, but they told me the smallest crab they had was 900g-1.2kg, nothing smaller. Hence always expect to pay at least $60 for a taste of crabs at Mellben.Also, we were using a groupon and drinks are not included, and you have to pay for them seperately, we were not told of this, and it was not written in the Groupon T&C, but now we know

Nando's is a chain of fast-food chicken restaurants that has been growing steadily over the last 10 years in Singapore. Did you know that Nando's is African? Nando's was founder in 1987 and originated from South Africa. Nando's prides itself over their peri peri sauces which comes in garlic, mild and spicy!To me, as a non-spicy food eater, all were spicy! As such, I went with herb and lemon and got a little toothpick flag that said "Not so brave" on my chicken! I guess it's meant to jokingly make fun of me for choosing a non-spicy option.As I was browsing the menu, the friendly manager walked by to introduce their latest items to me, including the pita which I ended up having. He also spent time to introduce their latest Nando's Periviledge loyalty program which was a mobile app. Spend $20 to get 1 chilli and collect chillis to redeem food! Having tried Nando's in Australia and New Zealand, their membership system there was addictive and it really got me to keep going back to Nando's and I'm glad that Singapore's Nando's is trying to implement a similar loyalty program. That could the explanation for the 30 minute queue I had to patiently wait through on a sunday night!1. Chicken Pita $11.90++Served in a lightly toasted pita, stuffed with chicken tenders, crisp veggie salad and creamy whip. This chicken pita is part of a revamp of the Nando's menu which just happened at the end of 2015. The revamp provides a wider option of their chicken items, rather than just having chicken with sides, you can choose to have chicken in burgers, wraps or pita.I love the combination ingredients especially the chicken tenders. You could still taste the slightly charred chicken tender which was so juicy despite having a glaze of creamy whip all around. The vegetables were mixed in well and you got a bit of all the ingredients in every bite. It was kind of a mess trying to eat this with a fork and knife, so just go all out and use your hands!2. 1/4 Chicken Herb and Lemon with Wedges and Mediterranean rice $14.90++Once you have chosen the size of your chicken*Price with no sides (on it's own)-  1/4 $10.90-  1/2 $18.90-  Whole $36.90and you have picked your sides (either on it's own, 1 side or 2 sides)*Each side is priced at $2.90 on it's own- Spicy Rice- Mediterranean Rice- Coleslaw- PERi chips- PERi wedges- Grilled Veggie- Garlic Bread- Three Bean Salad- Corn-on-the-conthen you choose you level of spiciness for your chicken1. Lemon and Herb - Not so Brave!2. Mild - Tickle your taste buds3. Hot - Gets you in the mood4. Extra hot - Sure to raffle your feathersI went with Lemon and Herb and found the chicken to be extremely juicy and succulent with a zesty lemony taste. As each order is flamed grilled to order, you may experience a longer waiting time as compared to other restaurants. But be patient, it's all worth the wait!~ The chicken skin was extremely crispy, underneath the skin you will not be able to find any fats as the chicken had been grilled to perfection such that all the fat had melted away! You can catch the flame grilling action right behind the cashier!The wedges were crispy on the edges and soft and mushy in the center. The Mediterranean rice, despite it's look like it's a simple small plate of white rice was actually very tasty. The rice grains are a lot longer than your typical asian rice grains. They were also slightly harder with some oil mixed into it.3. 1/4 Chicken Herb and Lemon with fries and grilled vegetables $14.90++The PERi fries are addictive and I'm glad that they were generous with it. Not a single french fry was soggy! Woohoo! The grilled vegetables was a real treat and next round, I'm getting 2 sides of grilled vegetables. There's onions, capsicum as well as juicy mushrooms in the mixture. All of which had a nice char grill aroma.I highly recommend getting the 1/4 chicken with the grilled vegetables and PERi fries!4. Rainbow Cake $5.90++I decided to try something not so African and go with a rainbow cake for dessert. It was slightly dry and came on a freezing cold plate. I'm assuming that they had pre cut the cake and left this cake sitting on this plate in the fridge. The cake tasted okay and the butter cream was super creamy, very sinful. Not a bad way to end a grilled dinner. Just wished the cake could've been a little bit more moist.I must say that the ambiance is amazing! Very nice to chill, with the relaxing African cultural music that provides a modern tribal feel. The walls are well illustrated with pop culture. The service is efficient as well! We didn't have to wait for so long for our food to arrive. As I had ordered a coke that was refillable, the wait staff were always attentive to us and was polite everytime they asked if they could help us refill the drinks.

easy weeknight dinner - nando's is always an easy-go-to post-work, both here and in london. I like the standard half chicken, the parents like the espetadas (rather impressive hanging skewer of chicken chunks), and we often get a bit of the garlic bread and hummus to share.I love that they've open so close to me now - and this outlet does a roaring business without crazy lines. good, easy stuff.

Slow service. Need to get attention of waiter three times before order is taken. After 15 minutes not even lay out the table. Drinks no where in sight.Food quality dropped since previous time, like garlic bread was still soft and chicken less tasty. Guess it depends on the griller.

address: 49A Serangoon Garden Way Serangoon Garden Food Market Singapore 555945 Singapore
comment: Great chicken rice with no queue! Had the $4.50 set meal, comes with soup of the day, vegs, chicken & rice. Choose between roasted or white. For the adventurous ones, organs up for sale too! ;)The portion is very generous, good for a hungry tummy. Rice is not oily, chicken is tender & toasted with a layer of sweet sauce. Nothing special about the vegs but its a good balance to the meal. Soup comes with big chunks of old cucumber & red dates, good to flush the food down your throat. Most important of all, the chilli! Its spicy & smooth for dipping or spreading on the rice. Extra garlic by the side too! Look like any other stalls but i heard there is a long history behind them. Will return for more.

address: 1 Maju Ave #02-03/06 myVillage at Serangoon Garden Singapore 556679 Singapore
comment: It's ok. It's convenient and there is usually no crowd, maybe because I've only been here for weekday lunch. The menu is standard japanese fare, with a wide variety.Food is fresh but nothing very mindblowing.Good lunch deal: 50% off second lunch set ordered!

Stumbling upon this place was like finding a prize in the cereal box. We knew good food was in the are,  as we came to visit a local food center, but then we spotted a LONG line of "Grab" drivers picking up food deliveries from here. We decided to come back to visit this place the next day and my taste buds went wild. The chicken tikka taco was delicious, I wish i could take the mango dressing back to NYC with me. The Nutella pata was also divine. It was a delicious mix of sweet and savory when I dipped it in the sauce it came with. On top of all of that, the service was quick and great. If I'm ever back in Singapore, this will be my first stop.

I had a great experience here, perhaps they changed staff from reading the previous reviews. I was greeted and taken care of with great service throughout the night. We ordered a large pepperoni pizza which is deff plenty to split for two people. The pizza was delicious and came out pretty fast. Price is reasonable for Singapore $24 for large pepperoni Ambience is nice, very casual and friendly. They have some outside seating as well. I'll deff come stop back in for another pizza :) Free wife :)

I've been coming here off and on for a couple of years and I really enjoy it. If you are looking for good atmosphere, varied menu, good pizza, and reasonable (For Singapore) prices for large pizzas, this is the place to come.I haven't been to any of their other outlets, but this really has a good atmosphere, it feels like a true New York neighborhood pizzeria with the tile floors built around the large wood fired oven in the middle.They have a large varied menu which contains many great dishes, I've had their pasta and some appetizers in the past, I don't remember specifics,I was pleased and not disappointed. My last visit we did get the house salad, which had good dressing and was large enough for 2-3 people to easily share.The real draw to this restaurant, and the focus of their name is the Pizza. This is really good pizza, it isn't too fancy, it is just good pizza. They have a wide range of toppings and pre-designed types to order from including the traditional Pepperoni, which is always a good measure to judge by. The pizza is a hand tossed, thin crust, wood fired oven pizza; it has just the right amount of char on the bottom. The pizza is greasy on top, if that isn't appealing, take a napkin and sop it up as I have seen many do in other parts of the world. The table comes standard with napkins for this and utensils along with the usual, crushed red pepper and grated cheese to fine tune your slice the way you want.The $50 21" is a great deal to ensure all are satisfied and you will have slices for breakfast the next morning, and if a harmonious consensus on the toppings isn't possible at your table you can always do a half and half style pizza. I advise making reservations as they fill up fast with families, couples, large groups and others looking for a good pizza night out.

Pizza. I lurbe you. Pizza. Its kinda like playing the guitar. You can learn it with just 4 chords but Its pretty dang hard to master it. So with pizza you can't go wrong making it even if you tried, but to make good pizza....aha....Here in pepperoni, they celebrate the different ways of eating and enjoying pizza.I was tempted to do a Cindy Crawford pizza pull. (90s kids you know what I mean??) For Peperoni, its their speciality.  I ordered the pepperoni and seafood half and half 21 inch.Huge pizza, cut in quarters, it was lovely to my stomach and I'm loving all of it.The cheese is lovely but I think its a bit too much as I couldn't love the ingredients along with it.A lone stray hair came baked in the pizza but hey, its alright as the pizza is a pizza.I ordered a pasta - linguine in pesto... Its alright....not bad...little watery no oomph but cmon its a pizza place! So they're an aiight place to hang. A place to indulge in huge pizzas and Instagram it and get lots of likes*Guess how many times i said pizza in this review!.

Bloody awesome place. Good service. Good homely and folksy atmosphere. Good and generous food. The wood fire pizza was fantastic. The squid ink pasta was good too. A tad too watery for my liking but still good. The must try is the funghi portobello con pollo. Just ridiculously good with a crispy and tasty batter. I'll be back.

Don't eat at the restaurant. The service is terrible. After dropping a fork and a knife clumsily behind me, missing my back by a few centimetres, the slim-built waitress did not even have the audacity to apologise. Stick to takeaway if you must have their pizza. What a disappointing dining experience!

Peperoni Pizzeria's claim to fame is their XXL (21-inch!) pizza, and their versatility. If you want two kinds of toppings and can't decide on one - you don't have to! You can have both of them on one pizza. Isn't that neat?The pizza crust is thin, the toppings are fresh, the selection is vast, and put to the taste test, the Pancetta (Cured bacon, sliced tomatoes & egg) is delectable. The egg, still runny, goes perfect with the bursting-with-juice and huge slices of tomato, and the pork isn't like the typical American breakfast variety - still salty, not crispy, and tender. The selection of beers (Belgian!) is impressive as well - you have the leffes, the Satan Gold (oh la la!) and if you catch them at happy hour, you knock $2 off the price. Isn't that neat? Still a little overpriced even at happy hour - but worth it for the money you save on the pizza.Compared to the Greenwood Avenue branch, this has a more cutesy American diner feel, as compared to Greenwood's aged Italian pizzeria feel - but both joints have pizza with the pizzazz!
Great place for pizzas! Have been eating here now and then for the past two years and i have zero regrets because they have one of the best pizzas in town! Their pizzas never disappoint!

One time I was here in 2015, the manager had an attitude. He was more concerned with sitting and entertaining his friends who were seated the next table. Made eye contact and asked for the bill a few times but was openly ignored. This was when there wasn't anyone else in the restaurant at that time during a late noon. The second time this year 2016, I was glad to see that service has improved, and the snooty manager was nowhere to be found. You kept a customer apprehensive to return for an entire year before returning. Good service matters, guys!
Poor service. Manager has an attitude. Made me wait like an idiot while he served customers coming in later.

If you're a true blue pizza lover, this could be your second home. Its an ideal place for big groups as they have that XXL pizza you can order and its great for sharing. Reservations are recommended though as the place can get quite busy especially on weekends.Back to the food, the pizzas are baked in a wood fire oven and its something I really like. I guess it somehow enhances the flavour of the pizza. With the XXL pizzas, you can split them into 2 different flavours. I love the seafood and parma ham options. Their appetizers are pretty good too. It may sound weird but, do give their chicken wings a try. They're seasoned well and are really tasty. However, I'd say give their pastas a miss. I'd rather you spend your money on their pizzas.

If you're a true blue pizza lover, this could be your second home. Its an ideal place for big groups as they have that XXL pizza you can order and its great for sharing. Reservations are recommended though as the place can get quite busy especially on weekends.Back to the food, the pizzas are baked in a wood fire oven and its something I really like. I guess it somehow enhances the flavour of the pizza. With the XXL pizzas, you can split them into 2 different flavours. I love the seafood and parma ham options. Their appetizers are pretty good too. It may sound weird but, do give their chicken wings a try. They're seasoned well and are really tasty. However, I'd say give their pastas a miss. I'd rather you spend your money on their pizzas.

address: 97 Frankel Avenue Frankel Estate Singapore 458222 Singapore
comment: We were hunting for a place to have breakfast and decided on this place after my friend mentioned that he had a positive experience here last time.We found a seat relatively quickly and made our orders. The service was cursory not bad.I ordered the signature rosti set, which came with a big sausage, rosti (of course), a serving of salad and a drink (I chose ice tea. The rosti was quite well done; it was lightly charred with potato, onion and cheese, and I think the rosti here is one of the better ones I've tried so far. The salad was ok but I am not a huge fan of greens in the first place so I can't give an accurate assessment.We rounded off our meal with a chocolate éclair, and we really liked it. The size was big and it was filled with generous amounts of cream. Of course, it was really delicious as well.Overall, this is definitely a great place to have some swiss food and I would highly recommend it.

address: 97 Frankel Avenue Frankel Estate Singapore 458222 Singapore
comment: What a great place for breakfast! The rosti is good, and I had mine with a delicious veal sausage, although you have a choice of chicken, pork or veal. I haven't tried the eggs royale and eggs benedicte yet, but both dishes look very impressive and I'm looking forward to returning and trying those as well. In terms of the baked goods, it's not really the best in the area and I'd generally prefer to head over to Cedele for their vast variety of bread. Nevertheless, this is a good spot for breakfast in the neighbourhood, and the chilled out, casual atmosphere is a huge draw as well.

Fu Lin Tou Fu Yuen (福林豆腐园）is where you go to for the best Yong Tau Foo (酿豆腐） in Singapore, opened since 1994.Their Yong Tau Foo (YTF) is best eaten dry - you can select your own ingredients and I recommend a mix of fried and cooked food. 4 of us ordered this big plate of dry YTF for only $21 - including rice and noodles.I've never liked yong tau foo - only ate if when I was dieting - because it's mostly plain soup and tasteless. But Foo Lin's ytf stands out from the rest as it comes with their secret recipe - minced chicken and mushroom broth that generously cover over the tou fu, veggies, rice and noodles. The fried stuff are placed safely away from the sauce to keep their crispiness intact - 10/10

This is the ampang Yong tau hu (YTH) style. Fried Yong tau hu pieces and you only have 2 types of carbo to choose from, thick Beehoon or rice. Trust me when I say that I've tried to ask if they have anything else. The man looked at me as if I'm an idiot for not understanding that they ONLY have the 2 selections. The deep frying makes everything taste better for my hubby.  He is not a fan of soft and soupy stuff so this type of YTH that makes him excited about dinner. I was tired so hubby offered to go pick and choose the YTH pieces and I regretted as the server brought over this high plate of mainly meat pieces. When questioned, hubby insisted that there were some brinjal pieces buried underneath somewhere. I rolled my eyes. But like I said, deeper fried YTH pieces can't go wrong and it's overall an enjoyable meal. One tip to remember is to eat the deep fried bits relatively quick else they will all turn soggy under the sauce. Else, tell them to not pour the sauce over the plate and give you the sauce in a bowl, on the side. This way, you can choose to dip the pieces in the sauce when you're eating. I would definitely return when I need my deep fried YTH fix!

FuLin YongTauFoo along east coast road isn't like your normal yongtaufoo. They have a wide range of items to choose from, all mainly under $1. Their speciality has to be their home-made prawn ngoh hiang ($2) is full of flavor, soft and succulent on the inside, they only make a limited number each day so be sure to get there early to get your fill. Served with either their meat sauce vermicelli or rice. It's definitely one I'll highly recommend. Well I like to believe that I'm having high class yongtaufoo. So when you're around the area next time, make sure you make a point to try it. #yongtaufoo #lunch #cravings #craving #cravingsatisfied

Although this place has been around for a long time at Siglap, this is actually my first time here. The food was nice although I think I'll skip on the Otaknext time. The yong tau fu is a dry/fried version with a savory sauce poured over it. Pair it with their signature thick bee hoon with the same sauce, it's comfort food at it's best.

Right next to Siglap Center, you will find a Yong Tau Foo stall that serves their dishes in a style that differs from the ones that are commonly sold in hawker centers. Although Yong Tau Foo is a dish that people often eat for health purposes, the one at Fu Lin is definitely not what you should go for if you are seeking a healthy diet. Similar to other Yong Tau Foo stalls, you select a handful of ingredients like tofu, fishballs, ladyfingers, and ngo hiang, but unlike other stalls, Fu Lin deep fries your chosen items and completes the dish with a thick minced meat soy sauce. The items are accompanied by a bowl of thick white noodles doused in flavorsome minced chicken sauce. Even the healthier options like ladyfingers, eggplants and bitter gourds are deep-fried. But who am I to complain; deep fried fare can be wholesomely satisfying if cooked well, like at Fu Lin.

The unique style of Yong Tau Foo here makes this place a must-try for all fans of Yong Tau Foo. Originally part of a coffeeshop along Siglap, it eventually moved out to this store on its own.  After picking your ingredients, everything is deep fried and served to you on a huge plate with either a bowl of thick BeeHoon in a soy based minced meat gravy or a plate of rice served with the same gravy on the side. There are a wide variety of ingredients to choose from that include your regular fried Yong Tau Foo ingredients like fish cakes, fish/meat balls and tofu however there are some of the usual steamed ingredients but whats different about this stall is that eventually, everything is deep fried before its served to you. Its a nice touch and makes it all quite delicious with the gravy. You'll face you usual parking woes during dinner time as there are very few lots to park at along the driveway right outside the restaurant however there are a few lots at the HDB carpark across the road and more available further up the road near the Shell Petrol kiosk near Jalan Tua Kong (about 5 minutes walk away).

This is a yong tau foo stall located in East Coast. I love yong tau foo because I feel that it is really value for money in terms of the amount of ingredients you could get for a relatively affordable sum of money, and you had the freedom to choose what you wanted so you would get a slightly different dining experience each time.Anyway, for the ingredients that I got this time, I ordered the goh hiong, tau pok, to fu and fish cake you tiao. The ingredients were all very fresh and very tasty, so no complaints there. I ordered the thick beehoon, which is a change from my usual preference for kway tiao. Anyway, the sauce that came with the thick bee hoon was heavenly. It's somewhat unlike what I usually have, and the sauce here is very fragrant, slightly sweet and went very well with all the ingredients. Overall, a great place to have some very delicious yong tau foo.

When I eat yong tau foo, it is because I want something soupy and healthy. So when I see a shop called Tou Fu Yuen selling yong tau foo, naturally, I went in expecting the best in healthy food selections. Lo and behold, first of all, you do not get a soup option. The horror, everything is deep fried. The person I was with was not feeling well and we though something soupy would be good for them and all we got was noodles with a meat sauce, similar to the taiwanese / hokkien braised meat rice. It is very difficult to get a seat during lunch time and there's a long wait. Once you place your order you get a number, go back to your seat, and wait. Even perfectly good things that do not need to be deep fried, gets deep fried. It's an absolutely frustrating place. They also sell some other western food like items in addition to the yong tau foo. It's a perplexing place for a first time visitor. I will consider going back but I'll make sure I am craving for deep fried choke to my arteries before I go back again.

Seriously anything fried tastes awesome! I'm sure all of you agree with me. So think about it, fried yong tau foo and then this starchy thick braised gravy with minced meat is poured all over the golden brown babies.. I have arrived at YTH heaven, where fat cells expand and 6 packs abs are non-existent.My favorite items are the ngoh hiang, tau pok (really great for soaking the gravy), toufu and fish cake you tiao! Not the usual yong tau foo fan so i don't have those fish cake filled vege or chili. They do have that though. Seriously i can finish up all the gravy! Say hello to cellulite!!More gravy for the thick beehoon. I love the gravy because it's like the Taiwanese lu rou fan (braised meat rice) sauce. Ate tons of that in Taipei and i only found a comparable stall in Singapore (Full House at Central and Far East Plaza). Anyway, this is a twist to the rice but if you prefer rice they have that as well.Fu Lin is opened daily so you can get it for breakfast, lunch or dinner which is pretty awesome to me. I wouldn't have this in the morning though because this is pretty sinful even for me. Cheap cheap must eat! It's usually about 6 bucks per person inclusive of a drink. :) Do holler if you see me eating there!

There are treats and then there are treats!   When you eat here, you're pretty much in Yong taufu heaven!  Amazing flavors, perfectly cooked noodles to accompany and my favorite part, a delicious gravy to compliment it's tastes!!

address: LTN Food Village 936 East Coast Road Singapore 459129 Singapore
comment: stir-fry version of the kway tiao is available at night. You can have it like the traditional char kway tiao (i.e. with cockles, fish cake,etc), or with sliced beef.The sliced beef version is more like the traditional cockles char kway tiao than beef horfun. Nice and sweet and lots of bean sprouts.Standard day time beef noodles is still available per my earlier review.

address: LTN Food Village 936 East Coast Road Singapore 459129 Singapore
comment: I had this place bookmarked as a must for our Singapore trip and was so excited to come across it when we went to Maxwell Food Centre for dinner.  The owner was sitting at a table in front and when we asked what the popular dish was, he responded with "everything." I wasn't hungry enough for everything, so I chose the beef kway teow soup. We already tried a fried kway teow the prior day, so I was eager to try the soup version! It was only $5 SGD but came packed with noodles and meat. Their homemade chili sauce was super spicy and added so much flavor. It didn't compare to other chili sauces we had from other stalls. It's definitely that homemade touch. I can see why Empress Place has earned so many awards now. It was definitely one of my top meals during my stay in Singapore!

address: LTN Food Village 936 East Coast Road Singapore 459129 Singapore
comment: Don't ever order food from this place. Ordered with food panda, and even payed for extra chili. But they can't seem to remember to put chili on the noodles or even put a packet of it inside. Happened three times already. Called them and they said to call back tomorrow, and they'll send me a packet of chili. Great service right there.

address: LTN Food Village 936 East Coast Road Singapore 459129 Singapore
comment: This version of the popular beef kway teow dish is a Teochew variation of it. Unlike the Hainanese style, which is served with a thick rice noodles and starchy gravy, the Teochew version is  beautiful mix of dry kway teow, excellent beef stock, chilli, sesame oil and soy sauce. It's a simple combination but extremely fragrant. I usually order the beef and beef ball combination and the beef slices always come perfectly cooked. I love how they are tender but don't crumble in your mouth. Another thing I must mention is the stock they use. You won't find any sort of beef soup that tastes like this anywhere else in Singapore, or at least to my knowledge. It really is a beautiful marriage of beef, noodles and soup.

address: LTN Food Village 936 East Coast Road Singapore 459129 Singapore
comment: The stall is run by a very friendly couple who are always happy to answer all your questions while preparing your meal. Dry or wet, the beef Kuay Teow here is taste wonderful. If I'm doing lunch, I usually have mine dry and if its dinner, I have the soup. You'll still get a bowl of soup with your dry noodles so you'll still get to taste it. When ordering, be sure to inform the uncle or aunty about which ingredients you want. I'm not a big fan of intestines so I just go for beef and balls (uncle's terminology).The soup is full of aroma and rich in flavor. The beef is tender and the beef balls are perfect! There is an excellent chilli sauce that complements the experience and I normally dump 2 in the soup for a slightly spicier taste. The chilli is not that spicy for me so use more. The small beef and balls bowl normally costs about $5.50 while the bigger one is $6.50.I'll definitely keep coming back here for my Beef Kuay Teow cravings!

address: LTN Food Village 936 East Coast Road Singapore 459129 Singapore
comment: The dry  version of this beef kuay teow does not have the gooey gravy that other places have. For this place, kuay teow is dry tossed with their signature chilli, which has salty slightly sourish tinge to it. I like it because its very light and delicate, even the dry version. The broth is also very good. Very tasty. One of the best around. I always order the mixed meats as i love the different textures that the different grissly bits offers. The chili sauce, which is the same one mentioned earlier, goes very well with the beef. Beef balls are also great.

After a long hiatus, Tian Kee is back, and they moved to Siglap. The famous rainbow cake is still here and so is the original signboard from the old store. There's a new array of flavored gelato too. Unfortunately, when I visited on September 23, it was only day 2 of business at the new location, It's not full service and there are limited food options. There's no coffee yet, only cakes and gelato for takeout. Let's hope they get the coffee machine up and running!

address: 3 Simei St 6 #B1-16, Eastpoint Mall Singapore 528833 Singapore
comment: I'm always on the hunt for good fishball noodles when I go home so when my mom told me about this new place in the reopened Eastpoint Mall I was eager to try it. Of course I had to wait a few days for them to reopen after CNY. Apparently this is a chain from a pretty famous stall that I haven't tried before. This turned out to be one of the most satisfying meals of my entire trip. These guys can write a book on fishball noodles best practices. Springy meepok, bouncy fishballs, fishcake and fish dumpling, good chili and condiments. Even the sliced chili and soy sauce were good quality (no it's not the same everywhere). The downside is that the portion is a little small.

address: 12 Jalan Pari Burong Picardy Garden Singapore 488678 Singapore
comment: Name brand chicken rice in the east - and it isn't even expensive! I've been here a couple times, and had both the white and the roast chicken. Thankfully, they've been pretty consistent, and the chicken's always smooth, tender and moist.Now one of the highlights of Tian Tian is the rice. I am open with my bias, but any rice with that chicken-y fragrance, and when the grains are so easily separated, you know they've got that good coating of oil... healthy eating isn't really a concern here eh?What makes Tian Tian so special - the highlight of highlights - for me is the gravy. You can pour it over your chicken, or your rice, and this gravy is ridiculously awesome!On my last visit here, I noticed a table with a bowl of macaroni soup. I asked about it, and apparently it costs only 80 cents. Now I've got something to go back for, even if its because my cheapo curious side wants to see what the macaroni is like.

address: 12 Jalan Pari Burong Picardy Garden Singapore 488678 Singapore
comment: I have heard rave reviews for years of this particular chicken rice. I have to say I'm disappointed. The chicken was average and the rice not very tasty. I have had better in a lot of other unassuming places.

address: 12 Jalan Pari Burong Picardy Garden Singapore 488678 Singapore
comment: This Tian Tian Chicken Rice is a franchise of the exact same famous stall at Maxwell Food Center, so the people living in the east are up for a treat! This stall is located along a row of shophouse restaurants near Simpang Bedok. Just like the chicken rice served at Maxwell, the rice was fragrant and flavorsome. The chicken was tender, and covered in a homemade sauce with hints of soya sauce and sesame oil. I tried eating the chicken like I was advised to - with their chili sauce and ginger - and it tasted so much better. The chili sauce made the chicken rice seem more appetizing, and can be possibly the best chili sauce I've tasted with chicken rice. The service was average though, as the staff seemed pretty impersonal. It was as if they were just doing their job of taking orders and serving, and lacked the warmth that the restaurant requires.

address: 12 Jalan Pari Burong Picardy Garden Singapore 488678 Singapore
comment: Came here with a whole bunch of relatives flying in from Hong Kong and they all loved the food. Great place to introduce any visiting friends to some "famous Singaporean chicken rice" without having to wait in line and sweat it out at Tian Tian's Maxwell location.

The serving staff here are warm and friendly, there's a lady who speaks good English. I like the noodles at this place because it's the "kew kew" kind (I like the slightly translucent type that is a bit chewy, not too soft)At $5, you get the Signature Wanton Noodles with a bowl of soup with wanton, and a drink. Not too bad. I had also the Dumpling soup, and Ngoh Hiang that comes with chilli with peanut. The general flavours of the food are not too bad, though nothing outstanding, but it is a restaurant complete with air-conditioning and warm friendly people that draws me (also away from the heat... heh heh!).

It's been a while since I've discovered a place from a pure walk-in that made me go absolutely Wow! I have to confess this is one such place. Wasn't even listed on Yelp yet. Was just going for a random lunch, taking my usual shortcut from hdb car park to another mall, and came across this one. Location isn't great because it is actually on the outskirts of the mall rather than in it. I hope that doesn't  affect business too much, because this is a place I'd frequent. For those who've been to Bali and tried the dirty duck, and those who've tried the sup buntut fried version in Jakarta,  look no further in Singapore. You now know where to go for your fix, until you get to go to Indonesia again, that is. Hard to beat the real stuff lah, but close enough in my humble view. Prices are reasonable. Portions are too. Only disappointment was that the crispy duck feet was sold out, wanted to try it. Oh and, it was cash only. Embarrassingly, my friend had to pay as I had none on me. For that, I give it 4 stars. If not easily could have been 5.

I love the pratas! We got the kosong prata and tissue prata. My brother observed that it was because the prata pan was not flat, and the pratas are basically deep fried. Well, deep fried or not, they are delicious and very worth the dollar for kosong pratas! I'm also glad they have tubs of sugar on the table, because I like my prata with sugar, and not so much the curry. The curries were good though! Unfortunately, the maggi goreng was not as good. It was just a boiled maggi packet with the maggi seasoning. It is not the usual red colored indian maggi goreng. Maggi goreng was $3.50, which is steep. Get the prata instead!

The main Simpang Bedok food spots are all in a row, and buzzing - Spize and the lot of them are all there, and it's just become too much, with the touting and the sitting at specific sections. I feel like not the cool kid in school all over again, and now I have to pick the cool food stall as well?I know you know what I mean (intentional inception and brain/tongue twister all at once).So I step across the road from all the madness, and enjoy a fantastic prata plaster, and a decent cup of teh ais. And now I think I love this place. It's got it's own fans, and they sit along the side of the restaurant, all the way to the back alley. They've got pretty good bee hoon goreng, and indian rojak too. I don't need much else! The best part is... I don't feel half as harassed as I would be if  was sitting at the cool kids table. When will I go back to the madness? I'll think about it, but now that I've tried the magic at Mahmoodiya, don't hold your breath.

I like bad meals. There, I said it. Greasy, fast and fake are all right up my alley but because I worry about orphaning my two dogs via a cardiac arrest, I try to limit them as best as I can. So all the artery clogging meals that I choose to partake in had better be worth my while. Today was a pig out day and it was decreed that being around Bedok Simpang = ice cream, mee pok and prata, in that exact order. Post mee pok, Mahmoodiya it was. Nothing like a good fatty mamak meal to wash down a good fatty cheena meal just moments prior eh? I usually go for all the Maggi gorengs I can find, and while Mahamoodiya's maggi hasn't disappointed me yet through all my 3am cravings, the Disc of Ghee Glory was serenading my name. Ordered up one prata kosong and prata bawang and wow. It's a bit different from the other pratas I've had so far- lighter and fluffier as compared to the flattened crispy slabs that are commonplace. Dual dips of curry and chili sauce provide a good kick of heat. Worth a heart attack? Let's just say I could think of worse ways to pass on. The place is one of those mamak institutions- fat lizards on the wall, peeling signboards, and a nonchalant cat loitering about. Service is non existent until you've ordered, and then servers start asking you if you've ordered or need a drink. Leftover food from other patrons sit next to you for a good half of your meal. The tentative plans of what the eat on the next trip down to Simpang. Suppers (and second lunches for greedy people) are made of these. Why would you have it any other way?

Had Chicken Briyani and it was tasty with usual spices. Not oily but chicken could be more tender.  This is not the 'dum' cooked type. Plenty of rice provided..too much for me.Papadum was tasty. Better than most. Location is remote. Ambience/ cleanliness -shd improve.Will like to try kebabs next with said artery clogging pratas with dips ...will takeaway if tables are still yucky. Maybe the auxillary cleaning crows are not doing their job.
Excellent prata and murtabak at this restaurant, the food is amazing.  This would have had 5 stars if only the service was better.

In comparison to the bustling side of Simpang Bedok where Spize is, is New Mahamoodiya Restaurant just across the street. It is a small corner shop with a coffee shop setting. New Mahamoodiya specializes in Indian Muslim food like Roti Prata, Nasi Goreng, Mutton Soup, and drinks like Teh Tarik. I recall patronizing this stall more than 5 years ago, going there monthly to satisfy my occasional prata craving. But I stopped after realizing that their standard dropped tremendously. Just a few weeks ago, I realized that the same shop was still there so I decided to drop by and try the food again. Our orders arrived really fast and we did not have to wait, because of the lack of customers there. Sadly, the quality of the food had not improved. The Mutton Soup was diluted and tasteless. The Nasi Goreng was average and not fantastic. Even the drink I ordered, Teh Ping, was bland and not sweet. It was an overall disappointing experience.

address: 430 Upper Changi Road #01-67/68, East Village Singapore 487048 Singapore
comment: Very surprised by the low ratings for this place: completely contradicts the packed and bustling atmosphere on any weekday night! My family has "followed" this place through its short-lived run at East Coast Road to Eastwood further at Bedok (where I believe it still is) and finally to 5 minutes from my place. Yay!! It's a simple, no-frills atmosphere, spacious, run by local staff, including the lao ban niang who may seem to have a slower gait but is formidable, helpful, and remembers everything. More of a family or friends place). The noise level is also quite loud. I basically see it as zichar but with air-con haha. They're known for san lao hor fun (hor fun with fish, bean sprouts, gravy), prawn paste chicken, hei zhou (prawn rolls), and I also love love their fish sliced noodles soup. The stock isn't artificially sweetened with overwhelming amounts of milk but light and fragrant. The other dishes are solid zichar quality, but not Best in Singapore types. Portions are incredibly generous for the price. At my last visit, two of us ordered fish sliced noodles soup ($6), sambal fried rice ($6), tie ban tofu and prawn paste chicken ($8), because we are greedy lol. And also because we expected smaller portions, but nope! (Ended up bringing half the food back). The tofu dish had like 8 slices of tofu, prawns, minced meat, and egg. No wonder so many residents around the area like to come here! A 3.5 in all for dependable comfort food, but I'm giving a 4 seeing the other low ratings here!

address: 430 Upper Changi Road #01-67/68, East Village Singapore 487048 Singapore
comment: The interior and exterior may look unassuming, but this place dishes up consistently good Cantonese "zhi char" (煮炒 literally: cook n fry) dishes.It's very hard to fault this place when most dishes are consistently good, with that smoky "wok hei" (镬气) flavor. There are a couple of good dishes that one should order, such as the shrimp paste chicken (har cheong gai), the tofu, the pork ribs, and the rice noodles with fish slices (sam lou hor fun). The shrimp paste chicken is amazingly crispy on the outside and jucy and tender on the inside without that strong shrimp flavor that normally characterizes the dish. The ribs are succulent, well fried and coated in sauce without being soggy.This restaurant was formerly located at Eastwood Centre, but moved to the current location towards the end of 2014. There's another restaurant at Thomson (Novena Gardens) with the same name that is under the same ownership.I assume that the restaurant was originally located at Hong Kong Street, from which the place obtains its name. Hong Kong Street is near Boat Quay. If anyone knows the history of the restaurant, give me a holla.I'm not sure why the previous reviewer gave it a 1 star, knocking the place. Perhaps their head chef is at the helm only on weekends? For the record, I came here on the weekend.Whatever the case, you can't go wrong coming here on the weekend. It's consistently packed to the rafters, so make a reservation before coming by... your wallet and stomach will thank you.

address: 430 Upper Changi Road #01-67/68, East Village Singapore 487048 Singapore
comment: The food is good.  The waitress was friendly.  There are 2 things that put me off about this restaurant.  1. When she came to clear the table, she took all the left of leftovers from the other plates and dumped them into the big serving plate at the table in front of the 9 of us at the table. Then she proceeded to dump to the trash from everyone's plate into the big plate at the table. I had to look away to avoid throwing up. After we settled the bill for the 9-10 dishes which was over a hundred dollar, a guest wanted a cup of warm water.  They insisted on charging us 40 cents for the water.  Seriously?? We were all appalled.  They never come by to top off our water throughout the meal.  Only 3 tables were occupied so they were not busy. We decided that we will never go back to this restaurant.

address: 430 Upper Changi Road #01-67/68, East Village Singapore 487048 Singapore
comment: I had eaten here mostl in the weekends, before they moved to the new location and while the food was not memorable and the ambience lacking, had not thought it necessary to post a review as it was simply unremarkable. However, my expereince last night at their new location, merits a post, sadly, a negative one. the food was sad and dsimal. Their signature fish head beehoon was lacking in flavor and quality ingredients. The fish reminded me of leftover fish bones that the cat wont eat. The hotplate tofu was so bad most of it was left on the plate when we left. The fried rice was tasteless and even the sambal chili they brought on request could not salvage the dish. The one saving grace was the prawn paste chicken that was fried right and crispy on the outside and tasty and succulent inside. I dont know if they have a weekday cook and a weekend cook but if they do, then dont go there in the weekdays.

address: 3 Simei Street 6 #01-12, Eastpoint Mall Singapore 528833 Singapore
comment: My experience here was pleasantly good!  For just under $13SGP, I got the Thai green curry grilled chicken pasta, the soup, and a lemon iced tea.The lady explained to me how you write your order on the pad and pay for food at the register and they'll bring out your food to your table.  The lemon iced tea arrived at my table before I did and it was quite flavorful.  The broccoli soup wasn't what I expected at all.  I thought it would be bland and nasty but it was super garlicky and delicious.Finally, the chicken pasta was amazing.  The chicken was so crispy, tender, and lived a good life before laying down in my bed of pasta.  Portion was perfect for lunch without overindulging.  How can you go wrong at this price?I don't know about this name of this place tho.  Although it was delicious, I only saw 1 cook in the kitchen.  Where was the other 17 people?  Maybe they died of a heart attack already?  I certainly hope not.  Who's gonna cook my food when this one's off?Know what I like about this place?  They have NAPKINS!  Quite rare in SGP at places like this.  But then again did you see the Chili and Ketchup dispenser?  You gotta go milk them!

address: 3 Simei Street 6 #01-12, Eastpoint Mall Singapore 528833 Singapore
comment: Good variations average qualityIt started with a noble idea of helping people who need second chances. I dig it. I was one of the earliest customers. Now it's a chain of many restaurants.It's popular with the youth crowds, namely school teenagers, national serviceman, uni kids. They even hire the same kids. I had a chirpy girl introducing their Chinese New Year menu items which sounds and looks great.Not many social service establishment can attract positive attention and at the same time be profitable. All social businesses should be like that, self sustaining. Food. Not much to say really. The customers here are not very discerning; and if they were it's unlikely they will return and pay for average quality food. Maybe to see their friends maybe they work here, maybe they just want to support the noble idea.The double cheesy fries is not imaginative, the sweet sour chicken is disappointing and the fish & chips needs a makeover.Yeah. Come back to support the kids too. Hopefully they get better menu, better cooks and run it like a proper restaurant. I live around the area and will still bring my kids here when they ask, just like McD. I wish they would make the food better next time round.5 stars for the social aspect. 2 stars for the food. Average 3 stars. I deducted 0.5 stars for making me use plastic forks. $38.40 for 2 pax.

address: 3 Simei Street 6 #01-12, Eastpoint Mall Singapore 528833 Singapore
comment: Decent food slightly pricey.We ordered their steak/chicken/sausage and fried rice platter supposedly good for 4 person - but we had to order addl items to have enough for everyone.  Steak sauce or gravy could have been added in the platter and the sauce in the chicken could be improved or at least put on the side to give the customers choice whether to use or not. Taste can be improved by adding different choices of dips/sauce (ie chilli, graby, mustard, tomato sauce etc).

address: 3 Simei Street 6 #01-12, Eastpoint Mall Singapore 528833 Singapore
comment: It's absolutely not a bad restaurant - just one that I would not go to now. I love their social mission and part of me feels tempted to b much more positive because of that: but I'll be honest. The food here is varied and includes pasta, baked rice, and so on. Prices range from $7-15ish, and it's a casual atmosphere. I've tried the baked rice, tom yam spaghetti, tried some of my friends fried rice and fries too. It's just very o-Kay and average. A friend's baked rice was quite cold. the tom yam spaghetti, which I had high hopes for, was watery and the taste of tom yam was not as strong as the tomato sauce. It's often located in malls and thus is very convenient though! Attracts a lot of students, and I could imagine coming here during those days. For me now, I'd rather eat tasty Singaporean food at a food court for $3-5, or pay slightly more for better western food, than come here.

address: 2 Tampines Central 5, Century Square #B1-01/12/13 Singapore 529509 Singapore
comment: I love going to the restaurants in Century Square basement 1 because it seems to be frequently overlooked by the crowds and I therefore could enjoy a relatively peaceful dinner on most weekday evenings. Soup Restaurant is famous for its Samsui ginger chicken which you eat by wrapping a piece of chicken and a generous amount of ginger into a large lettuce. They also have very wholesome tasting soups and they even have details of how each soup is good for you on their menu. Just remember to not take the frog leg's soup if you are pregnant.The service here is polite and quick - only problem I find is that the tables are placed too close together (a problem with many mid-ranged restaurants in Singapore) and there is a slight lack of personal space.

address: 2 Tampines Central 5, Century Square #B1-01/12/13 Singapore 529509 Singapore
comment: Great value for money. Soups are deliciously healthful and do not leave you thirsty from the MSG. My go-to food are usually:The Samsui Chicken with extra extra ginger sauce (LOVE IT SO MUCH I CAN EAT THE SAUCE BY ITSELF).Sliced San Yu fishHomemade Beggar Tofu topped with minced meat and Black Olive Rice *MUST TRY* (apparently I was told by my friend who came from Guangzhou that Olive Rice aids weight loss and it tastes really great too!)In conclusion the foods are mild, it is good for people who doesn't like spicy food. The prices are reasonable as well.

address: 2 Tampines Central 5, Century Square #B1-01/12/13 Singapore 529509 Singapore
comment: This is a review of a lunch with a colleague at Soup Restaurant in Tampines Mall.tinyurl.com/c5qthqktinyurl.com/blzucnkThe ambiance of Soup is very ornate.  It almost has the ability to transport you to another time and place.  They were certainly not shy in allowing the Chinese influence to shine through.tinyurl.com/c4gzqn4The service was professional and efficient.  It was not what I would call overly warm or friendly but it was polite.  The food came out in a very timely manner.The food was very good.Samsui Ginger Chicken - I do not know if this is their signature dish but it is featured prominently in their menu and it seems that everyone orders it.  The chicken was tender and flavourful  The ginger sauce was out of this world.  I realize I may be speaking heresy and I am allowing my western aesthetic to shine through but I can't help but think this dish would be better if the chicken was served hot instead of cold.  The heat from the chicken would bring out even more flavour and fragrance from the ginger sauce.  My colleague didn't notice it but I kept running into a fish flavour.  It was as if a fish sauce had been used or the chicken was cooked along side fish.  At times this overpowered the delicate flavour of the chicken and clashed with the ginger sauce.tinyurl.com/c2gppe9Double Boiled Ling Zhi w Lean Pork Soup - The first thing I have to say about this soup is the broth was simply amazing.  It was bold, deep, and rich.  I am not sure how long you have to cook a stock to create a broth like that but the time is well spent.  The pork had a very nice rich flavour but the texture was a little dry and coarse.tinyurl.com/boxq93uReceipt (Lunch for 2 - $42.73)tinyurl.com/buek8wkOverall - The food and ambiance are the stars of Soup Restaurant.  The service is only there as a means to take your order and bring your food.  I would not hesitate to return and try some of their other soups and dishes.

address: 2 Tampines Central 5, Century Square #B1-01/12/13 Singapore 529509 Singapore
comment: This was where I had my frist taste of their Samsui Chicken and I;ve never looked back since. I found that it tasted very much like good chicken rice chicken, if you know what I mean.The ginger was not too overpowering as well and I really like how the chicken and ginger goes so well together. The combination had a very delightful natural sweetness to it.Also worth trying are the steamed sun yu and steamed minced pork with salted egg. Perfect with a bowl of rice!

address: 430 Upper Changi Rd #01-05 East Village Singapore 486936 Singapore
comment: This is the real deal, folks. Their pizza is perfect in my opinion.1. The crust: They make their own crust and cook it in a brick oven. It's thin, but not to the point where it's crunchy like a cracker. The flavor of the crust is perfect.2. The rest: Like a real Italian pizza, the cheese and sauce are used sparingly, so the pizzas are not heavy or greasy.The pizzas are only available in 7" and 12". This is an excuse to get a few and have some variety.Pizzas I've had:Parma HamSpinaciMargeritaMushroomAll were delicious, and I'd order them all again.The staff here is very friendly too.

address: 430 Upper Changi Rd #01-05 East Village Singapore 486936 Singapore
comment: Good pizza. The pizza's are made fresh behind the counter and you can watch if you'd like. The dough is good, bubbles up nicely in the fired oven. Bacon is actual pig bacon, none of this turkey bacon and chicken sausage nonsense. The cheeses are also a great taste of home too. This isn't the type of place you'd take someone on a date. Nicely decorated and can be a little chilly with the air con, but you'll be fine once you start eating. There's no music and it lacks that 'restaurant' style service, but if you're looking for good pizza in the east of the island, this place is worth a shot!

address: 430 Upper Changi Rd #01-05 East Village Singapore 486936 Singapore
comment: We ordered delivery from this place and it was one of the worst pizzas we've had. Kids wouldn't even eat more than a few bites. Extremely dry, tasted old and slightly burnt. Find somewhere else.

They have got a bib for me!!! Nice!!! Was this to prevent the spillage whilst the staffs were cooking or for my leaky mouth? I did get a bit of splatter but not that bad la..Overall nice place, and the food pretty good! We ordered their Chicken Galbo and Seafood Pancakes. The cooks were provided and we just sat back, relaxed and chit-chatted. We could smell the Chicken Galbi as it was stirred fried in a big wok in front of us and I was thinking I would smelt like BBQ too but it wasn't that bad. The Chicken Galbi was well marinated and had good portions of vege, meat and rice cakes! It ended with us frying some rice in the same wok and the end results was fantastic kimchi fried rice with nice seaweed taste! The Seafood Pancake also had good servings of prawns and squids and vege and though the had a dipping sauce, I still preferred the original taste! It wasn't too squishy as some other Korean Seafood Pancake tasted and had some slight crisp to it!Yoogane at Bugis is usually crowded most of the time but this outlet I tried at Tampines Mall wasn't. Maybe it's too new? But I am sure the crowd will be drawn to it real soon. Return to eat? A definite yea!!

address: Bedok Shopping Complex Bedok Road Singapore 469444 Singapore
comment: It's always a little confusing why places exist with OTHER places in their names. E.g. Katong laksa in Tiong Bahru, Beach Road prawn mee in East Coast etc. Must be some proud of heritage thing. Similarly, Old Punggol End Seafood is tucked away at the back of Bedok Shopping Complex, and is a gem of a find. Am told that they've relocated from Punggol where their original outlet was pretty popular as well, but that's great for us as this eatery dishes up good, hearty nosh. Some people think the test of a zi char stall is its fried rice, a gauge for the elusive wok hei. Ok, whatever dayongs your sampan, dude. Instead, we went with classic choices of tofu, vegetable, prawn and an alternative carb dish. The tofu is one of their signature dishes, as is the Buddha yam ring (hey, yam counts as a veg dish ok). The tofu is silky, coated with egg and flash fried before being swathed in a coat of gravy and then topped with a mound of minced pork. The prawn dish was one of the more unusual I've encountered so far - battered and then tossed in pumpkin sauce. The serving was generous, I remember devouring about three, much to my guilty recall. We chose to go for mee goreng, which was commented on to be on the spicy side. I thought it was ok, but one of the others I was with has a sensitive tummy and headed for some elimination straight after. This is a great casual hangout for dinner, and I'd definitely recommend this place. Parking can be a bit of a hit or miss though, due to the limited lots, despite Bedok Shopping Centre having them placed all around its perimeter.

Located 218 Bedok North Street 1, is Stone Age, a restaurant in the quiet neighbourhood of Bedok that serves up family style Chinese Cuisine. There's both indoor and outdoor dining areas as well as private rooms, great for family functions.1. Dendrobe, Lingzi, Cordeceps with Chicken  $22/$32/$42Really tender chicken that falls right off the bone, with a strong aroma of all the nutritious Chinese herbs. Definitely one of those super nourishing soups that old folks would enjoy. Great for your body, soul and lots of chicken to go around to feed the hungry tummies.2. Sautéed prawns with wild mushrooms $18Served with 4 types of mushrooms, this was my favourite dish. Lots of crunchy fresh prawns with a slightly sweet flavour together with mushrooms some of which were crunchy, chewy and also juicy. Lots of texture and flavours going on with this dish that compliments well together. The design on the plates are drawn out by the chef using fruit jam. A for effort there, it definitely makes the dish look more appetizing!3. Golden Sand Ribs with Garlic $12/$18A typical favourite at any Chinese family meal is pork ribs but one served up with golden sand and fried with a crispy exterior is definitely to be a big family hit. The flavour was pretty intense and had a distinct sweetness. The meat was slightly tough and it took quite a bit of effort to get the meat off the bone.4. Tendons braised in superior abalone sauce served with sautéed shiitake mushrooms $25Loved the presentation of this dish with a quail egg right in the center. The tendons were also extremely soft and filled with juices from all the flavouful ingredients.5. Beggar chicken $25The waiter will hammer the clay to reveal the chicken and the whole chicken is in tact. The chicken didn't really bring about any fragrance or aroma, similar to that of the Dendrobe, Lingzi, Cordeceps with Chicken. Once I tried to take a serving of this chicken, I realized why, the meat wasn't tender enough to be removed easily, and the flavour of the chicken had yet to set in. I think there needed to be more sauce or essence from the chicken to make this whole chicken more tender. The chicken just tasted tough and bland.Overall : Family friendly restaurant that serves up pretty interesting dishes that taste great and also look pretty. Prices are NETT so it makes all the menu items here pretty affordable as well.

address: 3 Simei Street 6 #04-15, Eastpoint Mall Singapore 528833 Singapore
comment: Located in East Point Mall, Curry Hopper immediately stands out because of its clean, bright look amidst the more homey feel of the rest of the mall. A good crowd can be found on most nights, although it is probably novelty more than anything else that keeps people coming; the East is the perfect place for better, cheaper options of the same cuisine. The menu isn't very extensive, and unlike most Indian restaurants, vegetarian options are not immediately apparent. A quick check with the staff reveals that they often get requests for vegetarian options, which they easily provide. The Mee Goreng with veggies and tofu is a good option; a generous serving of red chilli and lime add that zing to an already tasty dish. Other options like prata and other Indian breads, however, are way too overpriced. I'm not paying $6 for a prata, and I'm certainly not doing it in the East.It might be worth checking out if you're looking for creative, meat-based Indian fusion.
For a restaurant which is primarily a delivery proposition, Dominos come in very short. Majority of the time I have called them they are unable to deliver, even on weekdays before 6 pm!!

address: 51 Changi Business Park Central 2 Lan Kwai Fong Food Mall - Signature Building Basement Singapore 486066 Singapore
comment: This is a review of a solo carryout lunch from Super Kitchen Stall in the Lan Kwai Fong Food Mall found located at the Signature Building in Changi Business Park.  There is a smaller sign that refers to the stall as Super Ayam Penyet Malay Food.tinyurl.com/awgb4uxThe stall area is very clean and neat.  It is well-kept.tinyurl.com/avkjsahThe attendant was very friendly.  The food came out very quickly.  It was neatly packed in a Styrofoam container.The food was very good.  They have bright clear photos of the different dishes.Nasi Goreng Ayam Penyet - This was basically fried chicken with rice.  A little bag of sambal was also included.  I didn't expect much.  But this was quite good.  The chicken was fried pretty much like any grandma from the southern US would fry chicken.  It was crisp on the outside.  It was tender, moist, and flavourful on the inside.  Take that and add the spicy sauce and you get a pretty tasty dish.  I just wish the piece of chicken had been a bit bigger and I would've loved another little bag of sauce.  I have to say the lunch did fill me up.  Well, at the time it did.  But, later in the afternoon, I was hungry again.tinyurl.com/awvb8pzThe cost was just under $6.  I thought that was very reasonable.  The lunch was $5,50 but there was a slight fee for carryout.  I do not have an issue with this.Overall - I really enjoyed this lunch.  Plus, the attendant was very friendly and helpful.  Currently, this was my favourite lunch from a stall in Lan Kwai Fong Food Mall.

address: 1 Tampines Walk #B1-53A/54 Our Tampines Hub Singapore 528523 Singapore
