OVERALL EXPERIENCE: If the hygiene was cleaner / the food had a slightly shorter waiting time, i would have given it a four star without doubt as the food is good. I will return and hopefully it will be a better experience!

"a hungry man is an angry man".  i'm writing this review while waiting for more than 20 minutes for the main course we ordered. me and my friend decided to try this restaurant because the food looks delish. we came in, decided to order calamari for appetizer (not bad), pesto chicken salad (tastes ok), grilled dory fish and grilled chicken. before we decided to order the items above, we WANTED pizza. After taking our order, we waited with so much gusto only to find out (first 20 mins of waiting) that they ran out of pizza sauce! Seriously? Now, into the main course, they have lots lots to choose from (which at times is a disadvantage). You can also choose between having 1 or 2 side dish. But on this particular day, only 3 amongst 10 or 11 choices are available! WOW! Now that I'm full, Id probably give this restaurant a 2nd chance.

Sometimes I just want an old fashioned chicken chop from a western food stall. I don't need it to be posh - I just want a griddle-fried, slightly crispy chicken thigh, liberally slathered with brown sauce, and some coleslaw, and fries. I don't need them designer fries neither. Crinkle cut? I'll take 'em. Shoestring? Even better. It's just so damn nostalgic. This place makes it that way, and it takes me back to the days when I was a kid, and the 'rents would take me to the hawker centre and this would be such a treat.Okay, so these guys who run the store are young-ish, but the make the food in that same way, and I know exactly what I'm getting here. Kudos to these guys keeping up a tradition. Without them, kids would never know what cheap thrills this kind of food brings.

The McCafé at Tampines Mall deserves some honorable mention! It has one of the most relaxing and chill environment a McCafé can get. For this outlet, the McDonald's side and the McCafé is separated, which gives a sense of exclusivity as you enjoy a good cup of coffee. Service wise, it's thumbs up! Even if you order just a simple cup of flat white, the barista will at least bother to do a little latte art for you (this service is not consistently seen at other McCafé outlets). On the downside, this is not a 24 hour outlet and it can be crowded on weekends and Friday evenings. Other than that, thumbs up for the superb service!

I love to frequent McCafe for their MELTS. Chocolate Melts, Cinnamon Melts.. ohhh so sinful. It's not only cheap and affordable, the people here are nice. I love their iced tea and their mango smoothie as well. If you are looking for a good place to cram at McCafe here will be a good place. On the downside for me, this place is sadly a little far...

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #B1-26/27 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: I visited the branch at Changi City Point, a shopping mall i rarely visit since it's out of the way and in the changi business district. Bae decided to grab lunch here.... We ordered:Pho:The broth was too bland for my liking and the rice noodles were a little thicker than the normal. Nope, didn't like the pho here.Tamarind Chicken Wings:Just too salty..Lemongrass Tea:10/10 you can't fuck this up. Young Coconut:The meat was incredibly hard... Verdict: Probably won't be back or will be back to try other dishes and redeem this review!

My go to spot for lunch around the office.  Chicken here is legit and value is amazing.  Half chicken is SGD $10 and the portion is large compared to many of the other chicken joints.I always go for the white chicken since meat is extremely tender and flavorful.  Honestly, I like their white chicken so much that I haven't really tried much of the other stuff at the food centre here.  Would definitely recommend.
The stall is managed by a friendly couple. The Chiken is really nice and juicy, price is also reasonable. It's worth to try!

rest_name: Hock Seng Choon Fishball Kway Teow Mee
address: 16 Bedok South Road Bedok South Market #01-50 Singapore 469275 Singapore
comment: Don't quite get the long lines. Ok, it is a better than average kind of fishball noodles. I would love eating it but not if I need to line up for 30 min.The fishballs are not big, bouncy and yet soft. I had the dry noodle version and the chilli is very spicy. It is not oily though so that is good. Most people ordered the soup version or the kway teow-mee version. Maybe next time.The stall only opens at noon. So don't expect to have fishball noodles for breakfast.

rest_name: Hock Seng Choon Fishball Kway Teow Mee
address: 16 Bedok South Road Bedok South Market #01-50 Singapore 469275 Singapore
comment: This stall, originally from the backlane at Lothian Terrace, has been at this Bedok hawker centre for over 40 years. Lately, it suffers from bad service! The staff made a mistake with the orders and did not apologise. Instead the staff (said he was the owner's son) made rude remarks. Such an attitude! This is the last time I will be patronizing this stall.

rest_name: Hock Seng Choon Fishball Kway Teow Mee
address: 16 Bedok South Road Bedok South Market #01-50 Singapore 469275 Singapore
comment: Very stingy with their red cut chilli. Not only that they stinge on the sauces becomes less tasty as compared to last time.

rest_name: Hock Seng Choon Fishball Kway Teow Mee
address: 16 Bedok South Road Bedok South Market #01-50 Singapore 469275 Singapore
comment: The fishballs are fresh and bouncy. The yellow noodle is very tasty.

Went to Putien for dinner to celebrate a birthday. Had simple dishes that were wellmade. The pork with fried buns was delicious. The peas were fresh and sweet. Wait was short. Be warned, some of the staff only speaks mandarin. For birthday treat they have "peach" buns that were complimentary. It takes 15 minutes to heat up so order in advance. They can do that before or after the meal.

We went with Putien for a family dinner during the 2nd day of Chinese New Year since we were sure they were open. Since it was still Chinese New Year, they didn't have everything on the ala carte menu so we went with the set menu. This meant there was lots of food for a better, if not inexpensive deal. It was a blur of food but as usual, there was the must-have Yu Sheng. If memory serves me right, we had fried chicken (good and moist but nothing special), braised tofu (this was a highlight for me as the sauce was very flavorful), steamed fish (fresh tasting), fried noodles plus others that I can't recall now.Wait staff was pretty friendly although we had to flag them down to help prep the Yu Sheng.

A decent place for Chinese food, some of the dishes that I would recommend include the Homemade Beancurd (fresh and fragrant), Spinach with Salted Egg & Century Egg (very tasty with whole cloves of garlic and served in a rich stock),  the deep fried Eggplant with pork floss (deliciously light the eggplant wasn't oily at all - a real treat), and the fried bee hoon (the bee hoon was alot smoother and thinner than those usually served in other restaurants, and yet maintained a level of chewiness). The restaurant is clean and brightly lit with high ceilings - a very inviting atmosphere.  The staff are also pleasant and efficient, but most of them speak only chinese.
Serving is really small for that kind of pricing, it's really pissing...food quality is relatively good...they should learn how to serve more on the plate to be honest...

Putien is one of the places I go for pretty delicious Chinese food. The menu has quite a good variety and they have different sizes so that it'd be good for sharing. Other than the few dishes that are already mentioned, like the Spinach with Salted Egg & Century Egg, Eggplant with pork floss and the fried bee hoon, I would also recommend the fried rice here. It is fragrant, flavorful and not too oily. Even my little nephews like it a lot. The restaurant is quite clean, creating a very comfortable for dining. The staff are also very attentive and friendly, being patient and giving us recommendations when we still seemed undecided when ordering. They also make good table arrangements for big families and family with little children, which I thought was a very nice and kind gesture.

I been coming here for over 5 years now and this kopitiam always has a wide variety food. Must try's are the ayam penggang (Indonesian) and fish slices beehoon (original sliced fish store). Other food stores such as MALA or dim sum and Malay food are also available here. Not bad for a decent affordable meal.

Kopitiam at Tampines Mall is a popular spot for a quick and affordable meal. There is a good variety of food here, ranging from local favorites to popular overseas cuisines like Japanese food, Indonesian barbeque as well as Taiwanese and Philippines cuisines. This Kopitiam is also quite big, which is able to seat even big groups. But I dislike that this Kopitiam constantly crowded. You may have to wait for at least 10-15 minutes on to get a 4-seat table. Also, the clearing up of the plates is pretty slow. Last but not least, I do not like their beverage store. The coffee tastes bad because it's too bland!

Barley is quite possibly the thing I'm most excited about every time I'm back in Singapore. It just makes me happy to be alive. So I'm inherently biased towards this place. But really, May's Kopi Bar does their barley (5 stars) perfectly - it's rich, flavorful, has just enough barley seeds in it for some bite with each sip, and costs half the price of the one at Ya Kun. They also have a lemon barley option (5 stars). I had the kaya toast as well, and it was also outstanding (5 stars). The bread was thin and crispy, unlike Ya Kun's, and had a generous amount of kaya. The kaya is on the sweet side, but it's not too bad with the bread and your drink to balance it out. They also renovated this corner coffee shop a while back and I love its new look. There's no air-conditioning, but it's open early and late enough to go when it isn't too warm out. And May's Kopi Bar's is near enough to my place for me to swing by when I crave barley or kaya toast! I'm gonna miss this place when I move out.
Been seeing this place but have not try anything until today, this is a place where you can enjoy a good tasting local coffee.

address: 805 Bukit Timah Road #01-02 Sixth Avenue Centre Singapore 279883 Singapore
comment: My favorite place to order Indian food since almost 2 years! I order every once in a while and was absolutely never disappointed. The team is friendly and the free tandoori chicken tasty!Keep in mind that the Order might take sown time. Prices seem not cheap but compared to the big portion absolutely worth it!

address: 805 Bukit Timah Road #01-02 Sixth Avenue Centre Singapore 279883 Singapore
comment: The food he was marvelous I cannot wait to go back another time to enjoy them amazing environment and surroundings and chefs cuisine

address: 805 Bukit Timah Road #01-02 Sixth Avenue Centre Singapore 279883 Singapore
comment: I had chicken tikka masala and my wife had fish tikkas.  I ordered the items to go and the packaging held up over the ten minute walk home.  The food smelled nice and fresh and was still hot.Unfortunately, I neglected to order rice with my dish as I had assumed (perhaps foolishly) that it came with rice.  When I ordered the food, it would have been nice if the employee had asked if I wanted some rice as well, but it wasn't a big deal.  I cooked some rice once I got home.I thought the fish tikkas tasted pretty good, but I'm not sure what kind of fish they used.  Whatever it was, it had a strong fishy taste that made the dish unpopular with my wife.  The chicken tikka masala had a somewhat neutral and bland flavor.  If it contained a wide variety of spices, it was difficult to tell.  I also ordered some garlic naan, but I can't accurately rate it.  By the time I cooked my rice, it had gotten cold and overly spongy.  If you're dying for north Indian cuisine, this place will hit the spot.  We won't be going back though.
Tried their pizzas and burgers and they were both yummy. The desserts are superb as well. Will definitely make this a regular place to visit.

Food is healthy and tasty, but prices are ridiculous, even for Singapore. Service has room for improvement as well.I ordered the Veggie Nori Roll, which was supposed to come with cashew mayo. After eating two pieces and finding them totally dry and uninteresting, I realized the cashew mayo was missing! The server agreed to bring me a side, but then returned telling me that the kitchen claimed to have already put some on. I showed her the remaining rolls, turning one over and showing they very clearly had no mayo. She reluctantly agreed to bring some, and returned with a thimble-sized dish. It definitely improved the flavor, although I had to beg for another thimble to get through the remaining two pieces.Tiramisu was delicious, but a tiny precious serving. The bill ended up coming to over $40 for what could only be considered a snack.Atmosphere makes for a pleasant space to relax, but with the exorbitant prices, stingy portion sizes and miserly service, it's not surprising the place was empty the whole time I was there. I'm giving them an extra star because I'm rooting for the vegan movement to catch on, though their price point creates a counter-productive elitist barrier which ultimately cancels out any positive gains.Secure wifi, credit cards accepted.
I've been twice, and both times the food was bland and tasteless - especially the pistachio salad. Nice atmosphere though.

There is no place for arrogance in the restaurant business. While 3 of the food items we order were very good, the avocado cucumber soup was basically uneatable as it had such contrasting and spicy tastes, neither my wife or I could eat it.  We told the inexperienced, young server about it and she had no reaction, just took it away. When the bill came, they refused to give any restitution for it. That is a bad business practice in the service industry. Shows a lot of arrogance. We certainly won't return again. Way to pricy for the quality of food too!  Guess you can't believe all the reviews all the time.

The cafe was located just in front of the Sixth Avenue MRT. The first level is for dine in while the second level is the shop. The place offered healthy fusion dishes with options for vegans, vegetarians and gluten free.6th AVENUE ROSTI ($18.50++)herbed sweet potato rosti, smoked salmon, asparagus, onion, poached egg, wasabi aioli Although the serving looked small, I was quite full after having it. The rosti looked quite thin and dry but there was a sweetness which came from the sweet potato in it.SKIN SMOOTHIE ($8.50++)banana,orange, raspberry, strawberry, soy lecithinIce blended, the drink was thick, smooth and fruity in taste.Overall food was delicious and the place was quite cozy there was only a couple of tables occupied during sat morning.

As an organic, soy free, gluten free vegan traveling abroad this was a great option! The food was well prepared and came out relatively fast. Pricing is fair for what you receive. I ate here multiple times and preferred the quinoa burger both on a gluten free bun (which was amazing given the often tough texture of gluten free breads in Singapore), as well as on lettuce. It's a quaint place that's not crowded with a good ambiance. Easy music and free wi-if make it a good relaxing spot as well. They offer multiple deserts and food for dinning in or to-go. I haven't tried the sweets because I avoid most sugars but many of their ingredients are listed with coconut sugar or dates - most of which are raw. I am a very picky and health conscious eater but I will definitely come here again whenever I'm in Singapore.

Delicious healthy food. A bit expensive, but worth it once in a while. The vegetarian, vegan, and gluten free options here don't taste like rabbit food (which is sometimes how they taste), but are wholesome, filling, flavorful meals. The servers are incredibly pleasant and efficient. I will absolutely be returning for another meal.

i really want to like this place, given that it is started by Dana Heather, a master nutritionist, i have high expectations on its food. i came here on a sunday after a long morning jog, working up a big appetite, however was left speechless when tasting the food.First we have to wait for quite a bit for the food given the short-staffed situation. And the air conditioning system needs some servicing too as it feels like we are on a fan ventilated room instead. decor is nothing original but passable. location wise it is on a row of shophouses, with construction going on next to it, so it is not a prime hang out location.Onto the food. Never order the cake! we ordered 2 brownies and that must be one of the worst dessert i have had in recent years. and for an indiscriminating chocolate lover, i really find those brownies hard to swallow! freshness is definitely a key issue, i could taste (and smell) distinctly more refrigerator coolant/ refrigerant than chocolate! i wonder if that's their attempt at fat-free brownies (not mentioned anywhere that it is fat-free), or aged brownies. these goodies should have been tossed! the quinoa salad i have fared better in term of freshness, yet the dressing left me in astonishment! i could taste only soy sauce for the dressings!!!being famished after our morning jog, i have hardly the energy to complain then. But the memory of that awful brownies, is enough to kill off any chocolate cravings I have. It's such a pity, i really love the concept, the menu, the staff, sigh~

Feeling like raw, fresh, vegan food? Come here!We came here on a Friday night for dinner, for two. This place doesn't get that crowded, so no reservations were needed when I called to check. We got the veggie brown rice bowl, zucchini pasta with pesto, and mushroom soup to share. We felt sufficiently filled as their portions aren't stingy.I really enjoyed the brown rice bowl, because it was topped with a mix of veggies, chirashi style, and had a choice of two sauces over it. Tasted like a brown rice topped with guacamole ingredients - so yum! Our mushroom soup was filled with the goodness of mushrooms, and because this place is dairy-free, this soup is not the run-of-the-mill cream of mushroom, but rather, a blended, chunky emulsion of mushrooms. Very tasty. I really enjoyed the zucchini pasta, which is spiraled raw zucchini, tossed with a pesto. Carb-free, guilt-free, and raw.We finished it off with a raw chocolate "cheesecake", which had a nut base, and the "cheese" in the cake wasn't very apparent, but it was a pleasant chocolate "custard" of sorts. I really enjoyed my meal here, without feeling that something had to give for the dairy and meat that was missing. I would revisit again with no qualms!

If you're a health concious homo sapien living in Singapore then this will be your holy shrine. Literally the BEST place that I recommend any of my health loving friends to visit in Singapore.First off - the staff are so friendly. I would come here to eat lunch everyday in Singapore if I could. They are just so bright and cheery. The ambience is very chilled and laid back and the food is wonderful. There is no booking so if you're coming for a weekend brunch, I would recommend coming early because the place does fill up very fast.There is a lot on offer to order on the menu and I feel there is something for everyone. If you're vegan then this is heaven on earth but if you're not, you won't think your friend has just brought you into hell either. There are burgers and meats on the menu but I feel The Living Cafe has gone out of its way to offer the best quality food possible for each category. No hidden nasties here.They also have a big fridge filled of yummy raw treats! I remember how excited I was to find The Living Cafe in Singapore after having discovered raw treats in the US and the UK. This place had become Utopia. Upstairs you will find a huge selection of books which make excellent additions to any food lovers library. They also sell bits and bobs that health freaks (me) in Singapore generally have a hard time finding such as Bee Pollen, Coconut Oil, Spiralizer, Vitamix..Even if you're not that 'into' being healthy I would definitely give this place a go to see what its all about. And if you're brave enough, try one of their Wheatgrass shots. Take them instead of Tequila. Same bitterness but the after effect out weighs it, I assure you! ;).

At the heart of TLC menu is RAW Food or RAW-Fusion Food. It uses no red meat, no cow dairy, no white sugar, no preservatives, no additives, no artificial colorings and include gluten free alternatives. So if you are quick to spot the (loop)holes, this place is not entirely vegan, as it serves things like salmon and goat cheese.Starters were the hand-cut Sweet Potato Wedges ($4) that were earthy and good. Lightly baked with olive oil, it did not had the tempting smell of fries from fast food outlets but an alluring scent of coriander seeds. Some might find it rather firm but these were perfect for napping in the home-made mayonnaise (made of cashew nut milk, lemon juice, water, olive oil and salt but no egg yolks.)Follow that up with TLC cheese burger ($15): a dehydrated patty of portobello mushrooms, almonds and sunflower seeds, topped with tomatoes, sprouts and romaine lettuce. I stared in disbelief at the bun-less burger as those burgers from the opposite tables had buns and cheese.Though the mushroom patty had a robust aroma, it was tough and dry, not aided by an unidentified bland orange sauce Wished it was a simple grilled Portobello mushroom with garlicky herbs. But there were good things like the Mexican-inspired Raw Taco Boats ($12). My trepidations of greasy wheat glutens dissipated when the two large sized mock meat turned out to be made of dehydrated walnuts. The light guacamole and mango salsa sauce had a touch of Indian flavors, probably because this dish used similar spices such as cumin.  While the savoury food were wholesome, it was the RAW desserts that blown us away. Each had their own merits and everyone declared our own favourite item. I love the Raw Dark German Chocolate Cake ($8.50) made with Dates, Zucchini, Coconut oil, Cacao Powder, Irish Moss Honey and Macadamia. It was compact and chocolatey, not too sweet despite a toffee-lookalike honey layer on top. The shards of fragrant toasted coconuts were a bonus.As for the Raw Blueberry Cheesecake($8.50)made with coconut oil, agave, cashew and lemon juice, we could not be bothered by the alien-sounding ingredients such as psyllium husk, soy lecithin, Irish moss, as we dived straight into the delicate mousse and crunchy base. A bit of sweet and a bit of summer fruity flavours, we did not miss the sharp tang of cream cheese.Tiramisu (actually we all did)  was made of natural coffee extract and sitted on chalky and fragile almond-flour cake base. This is literally an authentic tiramisu sans the fats from Mascarpone Cheese and Raw Egg Yolks (Yes, tiramiusu is made of raw eggs too). And who says tiramisu must have the alcohol to taste good? Honestly, I left the place feeling more satisfied than I had expected (perhaps it's due to eating "Real Food" ). However, the fact that nearly every dish were full of (grinded) NUTS, drove me nuts a little. Perhaps I would still pick Indian/Chinese style vegetarian food from Raj Restaurant over TLC.  That said, don't leave without trying TLC's desserts which had not been compromised on flavours. Hoping that they can satisfy my sweet tooth while bring less harm to my health, I happily dabao (takeaway) more items home

Surprised with this find! Very healthy food and it tastes pretty damn good too. I'm not a fan of vegetable but consume them for the vitamins and fibre. Had the zucchini pasta, it is made entirely of zucchini and has some alfalfa sprouts as garnish. Looks great and tastes refreshing but since it's cold it can take some getting used to. For those craving something warm, go for the sweet potato wedges! Highly recommended. We had the chocolate ganache tart too but the taste of coconut overpowered any taste of chocolate but presentation was flawless. Will be coming back for more! Service was pretty good especially the female waitress I had. Friendly with a smile! About $48 for 2 zucchini pastas, 1 sweet potato wedges, 1 chocolate ganache tart, 1 flat white coffee with hazelnut milk and 1 puri tea.

Let me start off by first saying that I'm a red-blooded, meat-eating American who was just looking for a healthy change for a weekend brunch. I usually can't get too full from just eating vegetables and had to order a number of items to feel satisfied here.We started with the living cafe roll, which contained an assortment of fresh vegetables, wrapped in daikon sheets and had two splotches of different sauces on the nicely-presented sides of our plate. While clearly fresh and juicy (and the creaminess of the avocado was a good complement to the fresh peppers and lettuce), I feel like the sauces needed to be either thicker or just marinated into the vegetables-- as I needed to dip my pieces several times to get a flavorful bite. And because there's no real binding agent, the pieces also fall apart fairly easily, unless you put a whole piece into your mouth-- which can be a bit challenging.On the other hand, the raw zucchini lasagne was flavorful and fresh, but a bit small in its portion.I also ordered the acai kickstart, which was a very tasty balance of bananas, oats, honey and acai-- until you ate past the top inch and are left a bland layer of with frozen acai filling up the bottom 2/3 of the cup.Because I still wasn't full after the three orders, we also had the poached fresh salmon-- which has pieces as small as you'd find in sushi nigiri and was clean and unsalted-- and the hand-cut sweet potato wedges-- which were huge potato segments (they used both the traditional orange sweet potato, along with a purple variety) that were pretty decently fried, without being oily.The flat white coffee with soy milk is pretty decent (although they had run out of the hazelnut milk that we had initially wanted to try).Overall, I wasn't a huge fan of the place, but I think that it lives up to its concept and will please raw foodists and other healthy living enthusiasts in Singapore.Very nice, casual atmosphere too with very clean, polished setup. The crowd seemed to consist of a lot of Caucasian mothers who took/take prenatal yoga classes.

This place is quite interesting. It's an eatery under a wellness center. They provides fruit and veggie juices with ingredients that are hard to come by in many healthy restaurants I've been to. They have juices with coconut water, goji berries, cilantro, wheatgrass, etc., but they also add supplements to some of their juices like Vitamineral green, lecithin, maca powder, etc. Their smoothies and shakes are vegan, made with nut or rice milk, a refreshing change if you want to cut dairy out of your diet. The food menu, however, is not 100% vegetarian. They have chicken and fish on the menu from what I remember. The night I went, I had the TLC roll and the TLC Cheeseburger, both of which are vegetarian. The roll did have homemade mayo so I'm not sure if its totally vegan, but the quality of the ingredients are definitely very good. The price sort of matches that, reasonable. I paid $40 for a fruit and veggie juice, a roll, the cheeseburger and a vegan/gluten free chocolate cake.This place also sells supplements, tools to make things at home like a nut milk bag, mason jars and the like, as well as ingredients like salt, vanilla extract, palm sugar, etc. Not gunna lie though, those items were expensive and I know that I can get these same items for cheaper back in the states or even in other shops in Singapore.

Delicious healthy food. A bit expensive, but worth it once in a while. The vegetarian, vegan, and gluten free options here don't taste like rabbit food (which is sometimes how they taste), but are wholesome, filling, flavorful meals. The servers are incredibly pleasant and efficient. I will absolutely be returning for another meal.

Somehow, it's really hard to find genuinely healthy food options that aren't salad or the healthy afterthought on a menu. But this place has got it all - raw food, vegan, vegetarian, gluten free, and nut free items. Literally everything here is healthy (perhaps except the desserts, which while made with natural ingredients, are still sweet).The kids menu is healthy too - none of those burgers and fries stuff. Wholewheat bread, brown rice, etc.Good stuff. Your heart will thank you.

The menu is about a half raw and half cooked dishes with lots of vegetarian selection. There's enough on it to keep you coming back to try things even though it's temping to re-live delicious dishes. I'm not a raw foodist but I've certainly been to raw restaurants all over the world and would say this is a good one. Also having it not exclusively raw is nice for feeding diverse groups of people.The service is... well Singaporean... I'm not sure what happened but it went from surprisingly good to quite poor over the period I've been going there. So that's sad but not unexpected.They also sell raw food ingredients, desserts-to-go, juicers and they give raw "cooking" classes. Lots going on here and while it's never packed when I go in, it's certainly never empty either.

My only conclusion as to why this cafe is rated almost 4* on Yelp vs the sub par experience I had on Saturday was this:  the standards for service are low and people are desperate for a semblance of raw/vegetarian food that they will overlook a lot of shortcomings.I live in the area and have driven past the Living Cafe and it looked like a place I should try because I enjoy eating clean and I am willing to pay higher prices for quality (and some serenity even). My better half is also a gluten-free eater. Well I walked in on a Saturday morning and there was one table occupied. No one greeted me and so I figured I'll just sit down and wait for service. 20 minutes later I was still ignored while another party came in, sat at the table at the back of the cafe and was waited on immediately. I also observed the same for the next two tables that walked in. The cynical part of me would say maybe I wasn't the right skin color, but nice let's-give-them-the-benefit-of-doubt side would argue maybe the service just is bad.So I got myself a menu and managed to order my food by getting one waiter's attention. Service was better from there as said waiter was efficient in delivering the food, but that's about it. I ordered the granola crunch bowl, pancakes and vegetarian omelet. When the food came, I got the same surprise I had a few months ago at the other cafe down the street, the LITTLE diner. Yup folks, small portions for not so small prices. And it was not like I was eating anything particularly unique or outstanding. The pancakes were on the rubbery side with a *sprinkle* of blue and strawberries and a sparse drizzle of what tasted like honey. The omelet was tasty and went well with the multi-grain bread but again, I felt kind of ripped off because this was easily something my mum could make, bigger and for cheaper.I guess this places is a convenient snack place after yoga class but I really wouldn't make the effort to eat here otherwise. Onaka, 7 Sensations and even Whole Earth offer much better value considering the creativity that's put into reinterpreting dishes, the portions and the quality of ingredients.

If there's one thing exceptional about my palette, it's the fact that I don't like vegetables. Nadda, not one vegetable. There is no exception, I might eat the occasional veg if I'm too lazy to pick it out of my noodles and its soft, but otherwise, I really don't like vegetables. Something about the texture and taste as a whole.So for me to visit a place that specializes in raw vegan food... definitely an experience.Eating uncooked food is quite an acquired taste - I am Chinese and I like my food hot, thank you very much. There was a raw mushroom soup I attempted - think uncooked mushrooms pureed into soup-like texture akin to Gazpacho with a really strong raw mushroom smell. I only managed one scoop of that. There are also raw pizzas and raw pastas (it's sliced up zucchini!), and even cakes for those who like this sorta thing.Thankfully, there are options for the less refined palettes, I had a cooked pizza with a mysterious "cheesy" sauce, inverted commas and all. While cooked, it was healthier with a whole wheat base that reminded me of digestive biscuits, but overall quite yummy.Raw vegan food does come at a price though - the portions are not very big but the prices are still the pricey bistro sort. Also, make sure you have time because the food is all freshly prepared and takes quite awhile to come.

I LOVE that they have a raw food menu as well as a gluten free menu!  These are two concepts that are ridiculously challenging to find in Singapore, and I commend the Living Cafe for having put in the effort on both fronts.  Having moved to Singapore from Los Angeles where gluten-free and raw food restaurants are aplenty, I must admit that the food at Balanced Living is lacking a bit of creativity.  Their raw pizza is nothing more than a salad atop a flax crust.  The salad menu is much smaller than I would expect from a health food restaurant.  The raw zucchini pesto pasta is quite nice.  Their raw desserts really do hit the mark:  raw cheesecake, raw german chocolate cake, raw chocolate mud pie, raw apple pie, raw chocolates, raw spirulina balls,  etc.   I like that they actually do have meat as an option.  My husband loves coming here because he can still get a "real meal" while I enjoy my raw food!Hopefully more people will go to the Living Cafe and they will be able to both grow and refine the menu a bit!
I've been twice, and both times the food was bland and tasteless - especially the pistachio salad. Nice atmosphere though.

It's my first experience with RAW food andI went in really raw and clueless about what it is all about. Don't worry, they don't expect you to dine a la neanderthal style, bloody meat and all. The raw part comes from the emphasis on raw vegan cuisine, no dairy or meat products, food cooked below 48deg Celsius. It's all quite healthy really and of course the food would preserve more of the vitamins and nutrients when it's not overheated. What I had was a special kiwi menu created by The Living Cafe but that kinda gave us the idea how food is prepared here. A lot of nuts are used, in making dehydrated crackers and tart base. It gives it a crunchy texture which I like. If you have allergies, pray stay away.There are also cooked food available and different cuisines as well. Italian and Thai are among them. It's not that intimidating trying raw food and I think TLC makes it really easy for you to forget its even raw in the first place. Do give it a try. TLC is part of the Balanced Living Asia group located at the same compound. You can find out more about the benefits of RAW food here.

address: 200 Turf Club Rd #03-03 Main Grandstand Singapore 287994 Singapore
comment: I still haven't figured out if this is the same restaurant, or at least kitchen, as Ah Yat. I definitely prefer it, though, to any other crab option on the island.Obviously Turf Club and the racetrack have changed a lot in the last few years. When I first came to Owen's, the racetrack was a dark, deserted green spot. Then the building became mostly a construction site, where even if Ah Yat's access remained obvious, getting to Owen's required a long trek through barely lit corridors of construction planking (naturally with no signs). Today, it's a big shiny comfortable mall which even has clean toilets, what a luxury!Owen's hasn't changed, though. There's still plenty of outdoor seating, although now you can watch night football on the former race track. The wait staff still don't speak much English - in fact going to Owen's does remind me of trips to the PRC, when they scramble to find a waitress who does speak English or at least enough to understand the annoying ang mohs. The prices are still cheap, still officially "discounted" on every tank. The crabs are still huge and the cooking still the same. Uncles will still scream at each other in a warm and friendly Chinese whilst chain smoking at nearby tables. People still eat with their hands and occasionally rinse them at the numerous taps on the side.We usually come as a group, because the best crabs are larger, and because it's impossible to choose. The pepper crab, the chili crab and the salted egg yolk crab are all delicious, all the best of their genre nationally as far as I'm concerned (but then I've only gone to the other big chains like Jumbo). I usually grab a few garlic clams as well, the long knife shaped ones - they are cooked so fresh and ummami in their garlic sauce they are always a hit with guests. Mantou buns are the same as everywhere else, a crispy oily deep fried "factory bread", but that's what goes best with the sweet, chunky chili sauce. Add rice and pitchers of beers, and who would need anything else?

address: 200 Turf Club Rd #03-03 Main Grandstand Singapore 287994 Singapore
comment: The fish was smooth the way it was cooked.  The oysters were enormous and garnished well.  The abalone was also very fresh.  The crab with curry sauce worked well.  Service was efficient with plates with shells being removed quickly and they were on the ready for refills of tea cups.

address: 200 Turf Club Road #01-27 The Grandstand Singapore 287994 Singapore
comment: Excellent if you let the Chef/ owner select the dishes . Good quality food . Had a great time . Have recommended to my work colleagues. Quality produce , service good , a must try again and againThe photo shows fish sperm ( try anything once ) sea urchin rice and bbq at table crab claw

address: 200 Turf Club Road #01-27 The Grandstand Singapore 287994 Singapore
comment: Service could be better. Takes a Long time to get staff's attention. They don't top up hot tea until they get a request and then the tea is room temperature. Hot tea only arrives after we requested for "Hot tea please".Grilled thin sardines - nice, reminds me of crispy cuttlefishEdamameHand rolls - California, Golden salmon - too much rice, Hot plain udon (thin)Deep fried fish - lightly salted - niceEel - niceDeep fried oystersSalad Generally, food was not bad but service definitely needs improvement.

address: 200 Turf Club Road #01-27 The Grandstand Singapore 287994 Singapore
comment: good japanese food at this hideaway in turf city, pretty much fine-dining but in a family-friendly environment. I was quite impressed with the food that arrived at our table - sashimi is cut thick and meaty, sushi is rolled to expert-looking balls of rice below torched toppings, and cooked food do decently too.it's quite a small, quiet restaurant - furnished in black - with booth seats (good for 4) and a long sushi bar. service is friendly, customers are dressed in smart casual - so it's not the sort of joint to be stressed about.their bento sets are immensely good value, especially since they are available during dinner - and even more so because they are usually very filling. you get the regular choice of cooked food options, sushi or sashimi sets, and the accompaniments are usually dictated by the price of the set (duh, right?). I've found their ala carte options to be pretty decent, even if sometimes flawed: chawanmushi is smooth and chock-full of ingredients - mushrooms and chicken, I believe; tempura comes decently golden (even if that greasiness repeats here); and pitan tofu is topped generously with century egg puree and crunchy tobiko; and the tamago was good (only slightly too-small).sashimi was thick, generous slices of a good variety of fresh fish - and we also had a delicious plate of peppered beef cubes - tender, beefy, and chewy without sinew - maybe the best dish of the day.the bentos constitute more carby fillers, like sushi, udon noodles and fried rice - but I was most impressed with my aburi sushi, which came with torched fatty fish melting over well-formed balls of rice. there's quite a lot of sushi, so it's very filling, but it's also incredible quality and quantity (especially for the price).so it's pretty good food, but a little hidden away in turf city - so not nearly as crowded as if it would be in town. the dining here is priced close to akashi at orchard parade hotel, and has the same sort of smart-casual feel. good choice if you're in the area - but for something similar, sushi goshin at heeren or suntec sity work just as well (with more convenient locations).

address: 200 Turf Club Road #01-27 The Grandstand Singapore 287994 Singapore
comment: Kuro Kin is a nice option for Japanese at the Grandstand, which is priced very well, especially with the set meals.  The sushi set was very good, especially the Amberjack and Salmon, and included some nice extras like fried oysters (yum!), chawan mushi, and udon.  We also ordered an udon set which was also similarly a good value, and I liked the lighter broth.  We returned for a round of sashimi, and enjoyed the thicker cuts of fish here.  Service can be a little slow, but otherwise, Kuro Kin provied to be a solid option with some good values!

address: 200 Turf Club Road #01-27 The Grandstand Singapore 287994 Singapore
comment: It's kinda well located near the carpark but off the main air-conditioned areas so you may miss this place .  Service is good and prompt.  Cloth napkins are a very nice touch! Good variety of Bentos for lunch and great value. Tofu appetizer tastes a lot better than it looks. The bara chirashi was about average.  It had tobiko mixed well into the rice (which could use a tad more vinegar) with a tinge of truffle,  which some people may like but spoils the taste for those who don't like truffle. Side rant,  what is it with chefs who put truffle in everything?  Now chirashi!?! Is nothing sacred? They could also have been more generous with the tiny and few fish cubes. The tempura which came with the set was pleasantly light and sweet. The gindara set was much better.  The fish was crispy,  tender and fresh.  The sashimi set had good variety and flavor.  Overall, worth a return visit to try the beef!

address: 200 Turf Club Road #01-27 The Grandstand Singapore 287994 Singapore
comment: Great sushi! Best I've had so far in singapore!
Excellent service and great food. Love all the food we ordered and the tiramisu to end our dinner date night. We will be back!

3rd time back here.  Went straight to the main course as we don't want to over eat this time around.  First came the caprese pizza. Wonderful thin crust with crispy texture on the outside but still a tad of soft dough inside.  It topped with simple toppings as fresh tomatoes and baffalo cheese.  Definitely a good grade pizza as it does not come off making you fill stuffed up.  Fettuccine was equally good.  Pasta done just right but as usual with cream and this one with sausage ain't gonna be good for the hearth healthy people.  The seabream was yet again simply done with sautéed tomatoes and onions.  Can't say was wowed by it but at least the veins won't choke up for this. As for the tiramisu which is the real reason we are back.  For some reason it was done differently this time I.e the usual way served in a ice cream cup which was a little different and tasted different.  We came to a conclusion that believe the partner to this joint who does the cooking is probably off?  Lastly don't get the camomile tea as for $5 bucks they should have provided real tea instead of Lipton as that is good for 15 cents wholesale.Ok just did a bit of research and indeed the original chef have left for greener pasture in Malaysia so confirm we will not be back :).

address: The Grandstand 200 Turf Club Road #01-20/21 Singapore 287994 Singapore
comment: Dancing CrabsThe Grandstand Turf CityHuge premises.Good crab. Fresh.Waitress wasn't helpful with the level of spiciness. Watch out for the signature Cajun "spicy" sauce. It was Super duper spicy.It's okay if you dig crab out and dip into the sauce.It's not okay if you put crab to mouth coz your lips will be numb.I take spicy food but this is way too much for most people.My Friend bought a 50% off voucher from Chope so it's really worth it.Lobster rolls were good.Chowder was terrible. Fried rice so so.Lime soda was terribly weak.

address: The Grandstand 200 Turf Club Road #01-20/21 Singapore 287994 Singapore
comment: Novelty dining experience and pretty fun eating off the table with no plates. Although it's a tad pricey to buy for frozen seafood fare, it was tasty enough to warrant 3 stars for the overall experience

address: The Grandstand 200 Turf Club Road #01-20/21 Singapore 287994 Singapore
comment: The place was pretty empty for a Saturday afternoon. We were showed to a booth table at the far end as it was one of the available pre-covered with disposable cover. There was also tissue paper and spicy hot sauce available on the table. Remember to help yourself to the plain water at the counter. Hand wash area was just next to the kitchen.Combo Bag #02 ($40++)350 grams prawns, 250 grams mussels, 300 grams clams, corn, sausagesserved with Beurre Blanc sauceWhen the food was served, we had the option to serve in the pot or pour everything onto the table. We decided to have everything on the table. The sauce was rich and creamy, went quite well with the seafood. The sausages were a tab spicy. The corn was quite juicy. The seafood was big and juicy.Washed everything down with a glass of Pink Thyme Lemonade ($4++).

address: The Grandstand 200 Turf Club Road #01-20/21 Singapore 287994 Singapore
comment: I was having a birthday celebration with my friends on sunday lunch, the place is fun, the food is pretty good for variety, well singapore signature black pepper and chili crabs are still singaporean type of food, i would say this is good for variety. Love the butter garlic saos crab so muchActually Price wise, they are pretty much at the same level like jumbo or long beach though our total cost per person was about sgd35 after discount from american express credit card maybe because we were having it with many people and we were looking for fun more than full tummy?   well in this kind of places, you better eat with many people so you can try many variety of food with considered manageable cost

address: The Grandstand 200 Turf Club Road #01-20/21 Singapore 287994 Singapore
comment: So wanted to try this place when I saw it that I didn't care that it was a weekday... Asked my colleague who was totally game and another who had to be dragged along. Walking in, you see the mess on the table, people in white plastic aprons and elbows propped up on the table, with both hands holding seafood, sinking their teeth into it... Oh ya, there is also the look of I-don't-care-how-I-look-I'm-enjoying-my-food-so-bugger-off look on most people's faces.So yup! It's my kinda place.Ordered the basic bag ($88) and a side of chicken wings and fries. And that was more than sufficient for the three of us. Fries were average. Chicken wings were great - crispy even when it has been on the table for abit. For the basic bag, we had their signature sauce at spicy (the medium one, not the hottest, but was a tab bit too much for me - colleagues seems perfectly ok with it though). In the bag - one decent size crab, 6 prawns (I think), clams, potato, sausage, carrots and corn. Love the whole experience of picking food off the table and pouring sauce (hot sauce) on the table for dipping :)For drinks, I had the lavender lemonade ($4) which was different but taste was so so. There are other varieties. Colleagues decided to try their bottled beers at $15 each. Ouch.For the full experience, we ordered dessert too - waffles with chocolate ice cream. Ice cream was ok, waffles were not that great. Heard there are other dessert places out there... So many can skip dessert from this place :)Enjoyed the experience very much :) recommended :)

address: The Grandstand 200 Turf Club Road #01-20/21 Singapore 287994 Singapore
comment: So this is my first time trying this messy seafood Creole cuisine which seems to be popping up all over Singapore since Cajun Kings, Crab in da bag and now this Dancing Crab.I've only known about this place as it was popping up quite a few times on my Instagram by a few friends. I also did a quick research on online reviews and basically tried the ones people said were quite good. So anyway this is what me and my party of 4 ordered - 1. Combo Bag #1 (from what I "remembered" it came with a small Sri Lankan Crab, mussels, corn, potatoes and prawns)2. Cold Platter (prawns, mussels, 4oysters, Alaskan crab as seen in picture)3. A bag of clams 4. Calamari5. Lobster Roll (comes in pairs)6. Moonshine Tiger Prawns7. Crab CakesFor no.1, they gave you 3 different types of sauces to choose from. There's the original, in 3 different levels of spiceyness. Then there's the butter herb sauce and lastly the cream sauce. First time trying creole so let's go for the original with spicey level 2. It was pretty hot! So ya watch out! I've heard the mild is way too mild so maybe they need to work things out a little bit there! All in all.. Not too bad. The seafood was definitely fresh and this taste was new and interesting to me, albeit a bit small in size. (I'm used to eating big crabs local style with my black pepper or chilli!) On to the cold platter - again fresh seafood but nothing that wow for the price. Even oysters were super small! Maybe the size just enough to put on my "orh lua".Bag of clams we ordered the cream one, again it didn't really leave a mark to remember for me.Calamari was fresh and well battered and full of taste, not disappointed there!Lobster Roll, well I really like the lobster roll as I was pleasantly suprised how quite generous they were with the filling with the bread being very fluffy and tasty. ( I might just come back just for this!) It comes in pairs with some fries and a bit of salad, just nice for a small meal for one person.Moonshine Tiger Prawns; well if you're a minimalistic prawn lover. This is quite nice. I think it was a bit more fancier than anything else becoz they flambé it infront of you mixing 2 types of wines inside it. I heard it's a mix of both western and Chinese wines. The prawns tasted fresh, sweet with only small hints of the alcohol. It's nice but can be a bit gimmicky! Heh!Crab cakes were also fully loaded! Crispy and nice! Loved them!In conclusion, me being just ME, I can't help but to know what's already out there and already love the way locals cook our seafood. Places like jumbo, red house etc.. and still think that's the BEST way it should be done! But then I would be giving a BIASED 3stars. I DID however, could not say I didn't like any of the dishes and still it was really tasty with a spicy KICK and most importantly with fresh ingredients! Go ahead and try this place, I doubt you'll regret it. But after trying, I probably will be going back to my same old local haunts for my seafood fix! (Okok maybe ill back for the crab cakes and Lobster Rolls!) ;)Oh btw.. The damage for all that was almost exactly 70bucks per pax.

address: The Grandstand 200 Turf Club Road #01-20/21 Singapore 287994 Singapore
comment: I had to wait very long for the black pepper crab (more than 40 minutes) and I was upset.However, the lady waiter that was serving us (so sorry I don't know her name) was very caring, went the extra mile to make us happy. She explained that ours was a new dish and needed more preparation, and they still didn't have enough experience with it. She then made a great effort to satisfy us. I am giving this review to that particular waiter, she was great and made our dinner a good one.By the way, the black pepper crab was really nice, I'll go back for it :)

address: The Grandstand 200 Turf Club Road #01-20/21 Singapore 287994 Singapore
comment: Given Singapore's love affair with Crab, it's not surprising that a place like Dancing Crab has opened up and offers some interesting alternatives to the local chili crab.  Their concept is to offer crabs in a Louisiana/Cajun style, although with some interesting deviations.  Being from Seattle, I will take a Dungeness Crab over a Sri Lanka mud crab any day.  And the Dungeness Crab we went with a zesty garlic preparations.  For the most part, it was quite tasty!  The crab itself was very fresh and the meat was easy to pick off .  The whole thing was also served with a bag which included clams, prawns, sausages, and corn.  The problem, however, was with the zesty garlic sauce which was way too rich.  Also, the price of the Dungeness crab was high - about $12/100 gram, which made me cringe as my usual source in Seattle charge $5 per whole crab...).  Another unexpected bonus was a decent beer/wine list that was not overpriced.  Anyway, it's an interesting concept, and perhaps the next time, we will try the Cajun style, but it may be awhile as dinner was over $300 for 2 people, and for that much, there are other places I would try first.

address: The Grandstand 200 Turf Club Road #01-20/21 Singapore 287994 Singapore
comment: A girlfriend and I decided to come here on a Saturday night for dinner, and we decided on that only on Saturday afternoon. Mistake! After calling them for the third time, someone finally picked up the telephone to tell me that they were fully booked. They do take online reservos but the website says they only take reservos two days in advance. Not that I advocate coming here. I know someone who works at Tung Lok (Dancing Crab's parent company), so we managed to get a booking at 9pm, without having to wait outside. We arrived at 910pm, to see about 6-8 people waiting outside. Jesus.And we come to discuss the food! We ordered a lobster roll (comes in two mini rolls, and with fries, and combo bag 1, in herb butter. The lobster roll was insipid. Chunks of lobster in mayo and not enough flavoring. Let's just say the brioche bun was better than its filling. We chose herb butter for the combo bag, because we didn't feel like spicy food. Boy oh boy, it is a giant puddle of grease. Potatoes, carrots, and sausages do not taste good in a giant bowl of oil. The crab, prawns, and mussels were reasonably fresh. That's one advantage  herb butter has over a spicy sauce - freshness can't be masked that way.I rate the food 3/10 overall. Service was spotty. We waited 5 minutes for our table to be "prepared" despite having a reservation. Before our meal, I had to grab the disposable aprons and paper towels from another table, because we weren't given any. Shameful. We also had to request for crab-eating utensils. I tried, but just couldn't dig flesh from tiny crevices with my already small hands.Bill was 120ish. We didn't get any drinks. Would I come back here? Not even for half price.P.S. 15% off for DBS credit cards.

address: The Grandstand 200 Turf Club Road #01-20/21 Singapore 287994 Singapore
comment: My husband is from Louisiana and I lived there so we knew we had to lower expectations when trying this place, but we didn't lower them enough. Nothing here resembles the special food of Louisiana. The gumbo is tomato, not roux, based and lacks filé and the holy trinity. The signature crab is too saucy and has way too much garlic. The cornbread looks and tastes like muffins made with cake flour and yellow food coloring. The fried oysters, though not really Cajun or Creole, were OK.Lesson learned: In Singapore, stick to pepper crab or chili crab and you'll be happy.

address: The Grandstand 200 Turf Club Road #01-20/21 Singapore 287994 Singapore
comment: Fresh seafood, lovely drinks and side dishes. However the seafood combo signature sauce wasn't really delicious IMO. It overwhelmed the freshness of the seafood and we were struggling to finish the food towards the end. Their chicken wings were awesome though, and service crew very young and enthusiastic -- servers were all smiles and kept coming to play with my kids, but they can be a little clueless when you really need service. Still, I think this is a good place to have big gatherings and get a little rowdy and dirty (fingers), price-wise on the high side (we're talking about seafood here) but with Amex platinum card discounts can be quite substantial. Hope they can improve on kid service in terms of a kid-sized bib, kids meals and maybe a play area.

address: The Grandstand 200 Turf Club Road #01-20/21 Singapore 287994 Singapore
comment: While the food is definitely fresh, fries are coated with a tad too much seasoning and salt...(the poor crabs are over-crowding and cramped in a tank with restricted movement for them)the spicy sauce is really too spicy (not even at the highest level of spiciness) for adults, would appreciate the waiter to caution customers before ordering (good that we are all spice-lover)However, its  distinctive beurre blanc sauce is perfect!the lobster roll/ bread can be easily done by any housewife who knows nothing about culinary (wish that it doesnt come with unhealthy fries and hence the price at S$30 can be further lowered instead)It can be quite costly just on the food alone! (w free water)The kids' fav- drawing wall area could be a haphazard place for service staff dishing out food...the place is pathetic with only two taps for hand-washing!Disliked its rigid reservation system (that doesnt take in any special request) on the website and phone system...

address: The Grandstand 200 Turf Club Road #01-20/21 Singapore 287994 Singapore
comment: While Singapore is known for our chilli crabs, we do have other styles of seafood as well. Recently, seafood boil in Cajun style has been hitting our shores, with restaurants such as Crab in Da Bag, The Cajun Kings and Full of Crab being a few of the pioneers. However, a new kid on the block, Dancing Crab, is emerging as a strong competitor. Dancing Crab, backed by Tung Lok Group, is definitely here to stay and also determined to knock down all competition.The crab cakes were AMAZING. Chunks of succulent crab meat were used to make these crab cakes and deep fried to perfection. Crispy and yet not oily, these were the perfect light snacks to placate our rumbling tummies while waiting for our main courses.While the seafood gumbo did not amaze us like the crab cakes did, we have to commend the use of extremely fresh seafood in this dish. The prawns were firm and sweet while the shellfish were plump and fresh. However, the rice was too soft for my liking and the tomato sauce was just a tinge too thick. Nonetheless, this would be great to fill up the tummy if some carbs were what you were looking for in addition to the seafood.The star of the meal: Combo Bag #01, consisting of a huge Sri Lankan crab, 300g Prawns, 250g Mussels, Potatoes, Corn and Sausages. As mentioned, the seafood was super fresh, with the meat being succulent and sweet. We were told that only live seafood was used in order to maintain the freshness. At Dancing Crab, you also get to choose the type of sauce that you want your seafood to be cooked in. This was served in Dancing Crab Signature sauce (Mild) and I loved it. I also tried the Signature sauce in Spicy and Extra Spicy but preferred Mild out of the 3 as Mild was mostly tomato based. The spiciness, unlike Chilli Crab sauce, tasted like hot sauce (i.e. Tabasco sauce). So be warned, it's not the local type of chilli padi spiciness but Tabasco-like spiciness. So if you like tabasco, you may want to opt for the spicy sauce.So while fried mantous are dipped in the chilli crab gravy, cornbread is used at Dancing Crab instead. These cornbread tasted pretty good on their own as well and can be ordered as an appetiser too!We also had the Alaskan King Crab Legs, this time round in Herb Butter. The Herb Butter was delicious and slightly reminiscent of the spread on garlic bread. Once again, the crab meat was fresh and sweet and we really enjoyed the meat.

I downloaded Yelp just to give this restaurant a review. Food: Excellent. Service: Excellent. Ordered the tikki chicken and chicken saag. Does not taste oily at all. Food might come abit slow but I believe because it's made fresh every order. Mine came out piping hot. Definitely recommend this place as I have enjoyed myself very much here.Oh and their garlic naan? The best.

Their service is just impeccable. I ordered through Food Panda and they called me up to say that the briyani rice was slightly overcooked and that they didn't want to serve it to their customers, offering the cumin rice instead. The entire phone call, he was terribly apologetic and kind. Such a joy to support their business!Fish Tikka Masala - 5 starsTender on the inside with a perfectly grilled crust. This beats any sort of chicken tikka masala hands down (I don't eat chicken, and the ones I've eaten in the past have always been dry).Fish Briyani Rice Set ($11.77 on FoodPanda) - 3 starsThe one dish I'm not impressed by. It comes with only 3 small pieces of fish - fish that's breaded similar to the orange-colored frozen fish filet in a McDonald's burger and some shredded cabbage, carrots, cucumbers and tomatoes. The fish was cooked well - it was tender and not overcooked. But I'd still order rice and dishes like the fish tikka masala separately the next time. Usually rice and 2-3 dishes (spinach, fish, palak paneer) can easily last me 4-5 meals.Spinach ($7.49) - 4.5 starsA bit on the soggy side this time. But there's always ample cooked spinach!

Food is tasty, service is friendly, but food is dammmmmnnnnnnn slow.Ordered what we thought would be the most basic food - plain dosa. Ended up taking what felt like more than half an hour to arrive, by which time our chicken tikka was completely cold. Dosa was ok, but the gravy / Dhal was pretty stingy. If you're in this area, much better off going to Karu's on top of Sime Darby Centre.

Why this place has two N's, we will never know.  Stopped in here for dinner before soccer camp after a little snafu with my ability to read military time.I got the chicken tikka masala and was annoyed that I had to order my carbs separately. The chicken was really juicy but the sauce wasn't as creamy as I'd like. Friendly service and very cold water though!

For the price, this is a very good option for north indian food. Casual setting but very tasty preparations. All the regulars like butter chicken, chicken tikka masala, naan breads are well executed. Service is pleasant too.Would skip the more expensive sixth avenue options to come to this place. Parking is easier too.

Non hygienic and waste of money. Nothing cooked properly just served from hot basket. We tried Briyani , chicken tikka and French fries. All were cold and wasn't cooked properly. And doesn't deserve the money they charge.  Please don't waste your time and money in this.

they used to be along the road facing the second hand car shops.they also used to be non air conditioned.now they are in a spanking new location opposite omakase burger within the retail complex itself.now they are air conditioned with the option for alfresco dining if you so choose.they open at 10.30am just as we arrived.only vegetarian choices available until around 12pm.and that's when we managed to get our hands on their yummy yogurt tender chicken tikka with a tinge of spiciness.before 12pm, you just have to settle for their stir fried cabbage with spices and dried chillies.very sedap!mixed vegetables consisting of cauliflower, chick peas, potatoes, carrots and long beans was a little stodgy.chick pea curry was creamy good.kosong bawang is my favourite prata.plain prata with plentiful sweet onions!their masala thosai was crispy outside with soft potato filling inside.a healthier option when compared to the prata.finish off with their teh halia, not too sweet and not too gingery.

The restaurant is full for lunch during the weekends and although the front-line staff are working hard, the food takes a bit longer and orders can get mixed up.The food is good, place is clean, and pricing is reasonable.Enjoyed the curry and ice-lime juice.
Very good food here. The curry fish head is piping hot and the spiciness is just right. For $25, the curry fish head is definitely great value for money.
Fabulous fish Masala with different spices coming forth. The prata was light and crispy.  The butter chicken and Masala Dosai were also flavorful. Food service is a little slow but worth the wait.

I like Curry Gardenn for it's reasonably priced (average $5 per dish) and delicious North Indian dishes. While it's not as good as some other North Indian restaurants in Singapore, I would still recommend Curry Gardenn because it's really good value for money and it just has a really good vibe. The owner's are nice and friendly and the service is efficient. I've tried the Palak Paneer, Butter Chicken, Mango Lassi and Garlic Naan and enjoyed all of it.Curry Gardenn is also situated in an interesting location. It's really quiet at night, parking is abundant and free. However, I've heard that Turf City has been bought over and is due to be renovated so I'm not sure what will happen to Curry Gardenn. Better go quick!

This place has quite a strange name with two "n's" in its name, but anyway we decided to come here since we were all craving for some good Indian food.We got here at about dinner time and found the place to be pretty much packed with people. We decided to wait around and luckily managed to get a seat not too long after we arrived.We had to wait quite a long while for our food to be served, but I guess that is to be expected given the crowds around here. Anyway, we had the following dishes such as the curry fish head, chicken masala, all kinds of naan and rice. The curry here is absolutely amazing! The curry ws just rich enough and not overpowering, the degree of spiciness was also just right for me.Overall, this is definitely a great place to eat some good Indian food.

A quite authentic feeling Indian restaurant. Seems to be famous for its Prata (fried, flavored paratha), almost all the other guests ordered that with a simple gravy. We ordered that but also the chicken set which is the standard chicken curry, with a veg curry and rice. Tasted nice, not too spicy and good flavors. There's a bunch of Indian restaurants in this area, this is definitely one of the better ones.
Masala thosai ($3.30) - 2.5 starsIt wasn't hot when they served it, only lukewarm. Pretty sure they don't make it on the spot. The filling was lukewarm as well.

Happy to know another Malaysian brand made it to Singapore! I always loved GO Noodle for its clean and flavorful broth and i no longer have to travel across to Johor Bahru whenever i need a fix. The newly opened restaurant is located at Basement 3 of 313@Somerset so that makes it perfect and centrally located in town. If you're new to GO Noodle, go for the signature "bursting" meatballs with your choice of noodles or the Hakka sauce homemade noodles with century egg. Both are really delicious, you can't go wrong with that. Otherwise, if you're feeling adventurous, you can opt for the double bursting fishball (fish roe) in homemade spicy soup with mi xian. I'm a wuss when it comes to spicy food, so i'm happy to just stick to the former.  So whenever you're in town and looking for a bowl of comfort (think hot, soupy noodles made to order), give this restaurant a try. For the price of $10++, you really get the best of everything in one bowl!

address: 181 Orchard Rd #12-02, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: Got lost in Orchard Central (as always) while looking for a restaurant and chanced upon Sumiya. I glanced through the menu quickly, saw a $4.90 beer, grab-as-much-as-you-can edamame and nabe-style porridge. The latter two items jolted my memory of Wong Ah Yoke's review a few months back and I figured this place can't be that bad if he thought it warranted a review in the Sunday Times.Sumiya comes pretty close to replicating the izakaya experience you'd get in Tokyo. They've got high tables with bar stools, sit down tables sectioned off by...plastic shower curtain things (totally cracked us up) and quirky cartoon masks on the walls and waitresses' arms. We loved the weird Japanese vibe and I half expected a robot with a chain saw to pop out. The menu is pretty extensive and varied. The vegetable based dishes, sushi and sashimi are all less than $10 a serving, while the proteins are around $8-20. The great price points mean you can throw down some beers AND try new dishes without blowing a hole in your pocket. We started our meal with a Singapore roll that was simple but fresh, with crunchy cucumber sticks paired with salmon and roe. Then came 2 salads: a pumpkin mash with sultanas that was absolutely delicious and a "sesame fresh veggie" dish that had dou miao and julienned carrots cooked in a mushroom broth, topped with what tasted like yuzu shavings. Both these salads were light but with a very interesting blend of flavors and textures.With 1 round of beer down, we ordered a grilled amberjack head ($9!!), grilled skewer plate, deep fried squid and oysters. The amberjack head was fresh and grilled crisp, so we picked it clean like good Asians should. I don't think Sakuraya even sells grilled fish heads this cheap so this dish made me doubly happy. The deep fried dishes were decent and i liked the spicy sauce paid on the squid, though some of the batter on both dishes got soggy quick. Finally, the skewers were a little disappointing as all of them seemed just under grilled and lacked the charcoal "wok hei" you normally get from a master kushiyaki chef.Overall we had a delicious meal and the Asahi drafts were, get this, bone cold chilled. Think of all the sad insipid beers you've had that withered in Singapore's heat. Yep our beers came in chilled glasses, a good inch + of head and the golden body was ice cold. I almost weeped. The servers at Sumiya were also very quick and attentive, delivering the food the minute each kitchen station put them out, which is critical when you want hot food to go with your beer. Lastly, it feels like everyone was happy to be at Sumiya, which is something I don't see often at restaurants here. Sure the food isn't fancy, but its executed pretty well. We had an unexpectedly great evening here and if you don't take my word for it...half the house was Japanese, so it must be up to their standards at least!

address: 181 Orchard Rd #12-02, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: We were greeted with the drumroll, a welcome chant, and seated near the window with high stools. Note that in the evening, you cannot see the night view because of the glass reflection and the bright internal lights. The food is economical and reflective of the standard. The Wagyu beef skewer is priced at $11 and I wonder if the chef cooked the wrong beef. The Unagi rice was interesting that can be eaten on its own or mixed with soup.

address: 181 Orchard Rd #12-02, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: If memory serves me well, this place was better a couple of years ago, when I last visited. Prices have soared. Beer used to be $4.90 (as it should be at an izakaya!) but it's now $5.80 during happy hour (ends at 7pm), and $8.80 after. The fun "edemame grab" used to be $6 and it's now $18!! Whaaaaat.Food was ok, some items better than others. The grill/skewers are good, as was the beef tongue. The current uni (sea urchin) promotion is disappointing. $24.80 for a little tray, which is fine, but then the uni were really small and not particularly tasty. :(

address: 181 Orchard Rd #12-02, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: Been here a number of times and the food quality is consistently superb. It never disappoints!

address: 181 Orchard Rd #12-02, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: utterly fantastic and amazingly fun izakaya at the top of the stupidly-designed orchard central. today, I bring you a gem. I visited this place for an invited tasting - and the food was great, the atmosphere authentic and incredibly fun - and I know, pffffff. invited-schmited what-had-I-expected.so I sent my parents on to the restaurant the weekend after my visit for a proper litmus test, and they came back full of praise for the place. which makes me really glad - because now I can be utterly effervescent without qualm.I can't quite recall the last time I ever described a place as fun - and I'm not really that sort of bouncy jovial person anyway (I might swing a little too much to the other side of things) - but that's all I thought while there. izakayas are boisterous places - plates of good food and never-empty glasses of beer to lubricate conversations and wind down after a long day, and staff who know how to keep the place cheerful and loud enough for you to do so; this place has all those qualities in spades.as it is, the dishes are both familiar and well-prepared - don't come expecting overtly innovative preparations and poncy arrangements. the food surpasses my favourite conveyor belt place - and while it isn't posh japanese fine-dining, it truly is very good. fresh ingredients simply prepared, an array of comfortingly familiar flavors, and served at a well-met pace.n.b. get the yakitori with the leeks - those were some delicious things. the place is genuinely lovely: a vantage point over town, and a location so exclusive as to be both intimate and cosy - and it truly does remind me of japan. there is proudly-displayed vintage paraphernalia strewn all over - and the place is divided between three historic styles of izakaya dining, onward from the '50s. my memory is a little wonky - so let's call them the low-one (cosy and casual), the tall-one (more glamorous by the floor-to-ceiling-windows) and the outdoor-one (where you barbecue your own meats).the staff were friendly, enthusiastic - and gracious the way only japanese can be. be prepared for a boisterous night - I've been told the asahi is the cheapest here at $4.90 a mug, which might account for it - and if not, it's a welcoming place where you can, like me, clink your water to your friend's beer mugs, and call it a day.and if that all weren't enough, here's the kicker: almost every dish on the menu is priced at less than a tenner. I think that's completely ridiculous (by which I mean stupendously good) pricing, and it certainly made my parents happy when they got the bill. great ambience and good food (and cheap beer, if you're into that) - I certainly will be coming back.

address: 181 Orchard Rd #12-02, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: Great deal! Their mixed bara chirashi set is gratuitous in amount and it's only $18.80! Comes with salad, chawanmushi, miso soup, radish and mochi! The fish quality is good too. Had a few surprise otoroo pieces in my bowl! :)

address: 181 Orchard Rd #12-02, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: Excellent and a breathtaking view over the city on the 11th floor. This is the only place where I can go back again and again for their grilled cod first marinated in a sort of broth of hich I still want to find the recipe. Also very priceworthy: this dish also has 3 types of vegetables, rice, mushi, miso soup (gindara saikou yaki set) at 16.80!

address: 181 Orchard Rd #12-02, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: The beef on menu $20+ was decent, the soup for the oysters was so good. However the umi bamboo steamed rice was quite ddisappointing. Their sushi is quite decent too. The fried prawn (not tempura) has roe!

address: 181 Orchard Rd #12-02, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: Service and atmosphere was good.  Unfortunately the bottom line food just not good.  Trying too hard to be too creative.  Went there after reading a lot of great review including this one as well as hungrygowhere but hugely disappointed.  Wished i have photos and can write more details but it was not much i can remember and won't try :).

address: 181 Orchard Rd #12-02, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: Quite a decent place! I like coming here for dinner. The view at night is amazing! Food here is decently prized and you will get decent quality too. All in all, this has become my regular hang out.

address: 333 Orchard Rd Level 35, Orchard Wing Singapore 238867 Singapore
comment: I've had Szechuan Chinese food multiple times in my young adult life.  I hope the bar hasn't been set too high for places in the states after this dinner.The ambiance is elegant, but not stuffy.  The views from the 35th floor are stunning.  The attentiveness of the staff, at least on that night, was unparalleled.  The cost is crazy low considering what the entire experience entails.Highlights of food/Steamed Sliced Kurobuta Pork with Chilli Oil (Appetizer): An amazing start to the dinner.  Would order againMapo Doufu/Tofu: One of the signature dishes and does not disappoint.  If all tofu could be cooked this way, I'd always order it as a main dish.  A significant amount of spice that does not overpower the rest of the components. Sautéed chicken and chilli pepper: The right combo of crispiness and spice for each piece of chicken.  Glad I tried it, but would order something else next time--not because it wasn't delicious, but there are just so many other things I'd want to try. Chen's original spicy dry noodle:  Some of the best noodles I've had.  They were firm on each bite, took on the flavor of any surrounding oil, sauce, gravy or protein and wish I ordered more.  The entire bill was less than $80 USD, which feels astonishing for a 2 Michelin Star Restaurant in Downtown Singapore on the 35th floor. I've paid more for much less in every aspect of this meal, and hope to return here.

address: 333 Orchard Rd Level 35, Orchard Wing Singapore 238867 Singapore
comment: We were running late from the top of Cloud Forest. We ran down skipping attractions just to get a Grab ASAP to make the reservation. I'm actually quite surprised that I was let in given what I was wearing.The ambience is quite stunning with all of the lights and you're on the 35th floor! We got the stir-fried prawn with chili sauce, mapo doufu, Chef's original spicy dry noodle, and more. This makes for a great place to catch up with friends eating good food. I enjoyed all of the dishes, but honestly, I left with no desire to come back. It was a good experience, but I feel like I can get good Schezuan elsewhere easily.

address: 333 Orchard Rd Level 35, Orchard Wing Singapore 238867 Singapore
comment: Chinese fine dining, at a very affordable price.This is a 2 michelin star outpost serving up fine chinese cuisine with impeccable service and great ambience. Their lunch set menu is a great way to taste their dishes without breaking the bank. Their signature dish is the Mapo Tofu, which is one of the best renditions I've ever tried. Overall though, I'm not sure if it is worthy of 2 stars, I've had equivalent or better food at several one star places, and the only 2 star place I've been to other than this was an order of magnitude better.

address: 333 Orchard Rd Level 35, Orchard Wing Singapore 238867 Singapore
comment: Unforgettable Chinese fine-dining, at incredibly affordable prices with impeccable service.We ordered the weekend brunch menu ($65 sgd pax, incl tea/tax/service), which was a fantastic mix of dishes. The opening dim sum highlight was the crispy prawn. The duck was as good as any I've had in China.The soup was moreish, but not too rich.
