The stir fried prawns were huge and succulent, in a delicious sauce. The Mapo Doufu was to perfection - not too overwhelming, but spicy enough, and was well balanced with the riceThe desserts were not too special, but for $65, we'd already committed daylight robbery. Will be back!

address: 333 Orchard Rd Level 35, Orchard Wing Singapore 238867 Singapore
comment: Excellent food, with 2 Michelin Star quality, served gracefully. The price is actually surprisingly low for the type of location and of food! Probably one of my best meals in Singapore.

address: 333 Orchard Rd Level 35, Orchard Wing Singapore 238867 Singapore
comment: This is a nice restaurant located high above Singapore at 35 storeys of the Emeritus Mandarins. The decorations looks fantastic, with chandeliers and oriental furniture. The service was good - quick to attend to you, but somewhat lacking. For example they did not change your plate but you can get new plates from the buffet area. So far the place is great, the decorations are very nice , the service could be better and the important reason we are here.... The food is so-so. We had the dim sum buffet. The normal run of the mill prawn dumplings, stewed chicken feet, Char siew pow, etc. Unfortunately the steamed pork rib and stewed chicken feet was dry probably over steamed. The fillings of the pau was also dry. I expected better given the class of this restaurant. You get to order a soup each l had the corn Alaskan crab soup, three signature dishes - they were mostly good, and a dessert. You can get more dessert at the buffet area but the ordered dessert was excellent. Appetizers are available at the buffet area. Free flow of dim sum in additional to those ordered items.The ordered dishes were ok not great. The dim sum were so so only. The dessert was excellent.Given that this is a Japanese Chinese cuisine , it just not as good as pure Chinese cuisine.

address: 333 Orchard Rd Level 35, Orchard Wing Singapore 238867 Singapore
comment: I am a HUGE fan! The fact that it never gets crowded even during lunch/dinner time makes it even better (I still book it pre-arrival just to be safe though). I am not from Sichuan but it is definitely one of my most favorite Chinese cuisines, so we have looked almost all over Singapore for authentic Sichuan food at a decent place. That means the food has to be mostly hot as blazes from Sichuan peppers, which are different from chili peppers. It will still wither your mouth but these peppers have a natural chemical that gives a little bit of numbness. I personally don't take extremely hot flavor on a daily basis or in general except for Sichuan food (by the way you can opt for less spicy).My faves:Spicy cold steamed chicken with cashew nuts $20Chen's Mapo Doufu $20 *perfect with Hokkaido riceStewed fish fillet in super-hot Szechwan pepper sauce $26Sautéed chilli pepper and chicken $22I've tried many Sichuan restaurants in China as well as US and this is one of the restaurants that I have found really authentic. I've been going here for more than 10 times in less than a year. The interior is very beautiful and classy. Servers are attentive and the food is consistently high quality. This place is perfect for the atmosphere to impress a date or client especially if you know that they love real Sichuan food so much! Meals are a la carte in medium sizes to share mostly but they have three options for set menu that start from $68 per person. On a la carte section, one dish is typically $12-25 on average which I think is very affordable for the ambiance, location and food quality. If you order one per person and then share it's not hard to have a generous meal with some tasty leftovers to take home.

address: 333 Orchard Rd Level 35, Orchard Wing Singapore 238867 Singapore
comment: Excellent food quality, nice decor n ambience, not so expensive food at all. I had their pipa duck, chicken w chilli n pepper, bbq pork bun, siumai, mapotofu, and kurobuta dumpling which all turned out very yummy. I saw some other table ordering other type of duck dishes as well, which I supposed to be their specialty perhaps ?

address: 333 Orchard Rd Level 35, Orchard Wing Singapore 238867 Singapore
comment: Meh. Bearable if you're looking for somewhat fancy Cantonese food to dine with your Chinese in laws. Nothing special, nothing interesting, nothing creative -- think "braised abalone" and "XO" dishes. There are a couple of Sichuan dishes on the menu that are mediocre imitations of the real thing.If you are forced to go, book a booth next to the skyline windows -- perhaps the only redeeming thing about this place. Otherwise, pass. And certainly don't buy into the hype about the founder and his father -- true or not, certainly doesn't show up in the food. There are far far better Sichuan places in SIngapore ....3 stars, which is very generous.

address: 333 Orchard Rd Level 35, Orchard Wing Singapore 238867 Singapore
comment: Although touted as a purveyor of Japanese-Sichuan cuisine, the fare at Shisen Hanten is very simply, Sichuan fare, made just a little more refined and nuanced by the quintessential Japanese precision.The extensive menu is a tad daunting, and while we loved almost everything we ordered, it wasn't a 100% hit-rate, but a tip is to stick to the traditional stuff for a slamdunk meal.We had:1) Cold Steamed Chicken ($22) - seasoned with sesame and leek oil: incredibly aromatic, and despite subtle kick of the chilli pepper spice, was clear and refreshing. This was like Hainanese chicken, but all shredded up and given a spicy twist. Absolute must try.2) Grilled Wagyu Beef ($30): beautifully burnished and glossed with a delicate garlicky spice blend. Sumptuous, albeit forgettable. The earlier starter really stole the limelight. 3) Hot & Sour Soup ($12): exceptional, punchy and robust, but finished with an exquisite polish 4) Braised Corn Soup with Crabmeat ($12): skip this, it was insipid and clunky.5) Roasted Crispy Chicken ($46 for whole and promotionally half-priced on Thursday lunches): outstanding. For once, I actually only ate the breast meat, which was wonderfully moist and flavoursome6) Sweet & Sour Pork with Black Vinegar ($26): A galfriend thought it was "too porky", but I thought it was acceptably full-bodied. The one thing we all could agree on, was that the heady, sweetish, piquant glaze was absolutely delightful.7) Chen's Mapo Doufu ($22): hearty but restrained. I liked the complex nuance finessed into this.8) Rice Vermicelli with Crabmeat ($28): The noodles were lush with stock, but managed a light elegance; and it was generously piled with scallops, shitmeiji caps, freshly shredded crabmeat and egg white scramble

Probably the most authentic place to get Indoensian soup in Singapore. I've tried everything on the menu and they are all legit!my personal favs are Soto Ayam (chicken soup), Soto Buntut (oxtail soup) and the Siomay bandung (tofu and meatballs in peanut sauce)and always get the sambal.
This is some yummy Indonesian food and price is reasonable for your portion.  Their tempeh is pretty flavourful plus their passion fruit Soda is the bomb!

Decided to eat here for dinner as the rest around were crowded. Order at the cashier and collect at the counter. The staff would knock on the wooden gong. Mie Ayam Jamur Bakso ($7.80) chicken and mushroom noodle with side soup + beef ballThe dish was served dried, topped with a huge cracker. The seasoning looked simple but the noodles was very tasty. The beef ball was lacking of the meat taste, seem to have too much flour in it.Remember to help yourself to the chilli sauce where there was 4 different versions available.Es Cendol ($3.80)Tasted not bad especially for the green jelly strips which did not get frozen, but a tab different to eat with the spoon provided.

Humble street food brought to singapore price standard.  Had the campur which was pretty good.  Let it be known the skill in the cooking is there for sure and most importantly not overly sweet.  Mee soto though nice was way too small for the price and to top if off broth was lukewarm.  Be back again for sure

address: 277 Orchard Road #04-01, Orchard Gateway Downtown Core 238858 Singapore
comment: I had a outback special 8 ounce just today as my blunder (breakfast + lunch +dinner). The food was not what I expected. I am not that satisfied with 50 dollars meal. The French fries were horrible, stakes meat was not professionally cut, and the mashed potatoes were OK.  The waitress was cordial.My rating is 2 star.Taj

address: 277 Orchard Road #04-01, Orchard Gateway Downtown Core 238858 Singapore
comment: This place leaves so much to be desired. I ordered a burger and was asked how I would like it cooked. I said rare. They came back and said I could only have it medium or well done. I asked for medium and got it very well done. The service was lousy. They brought the drinks, but never came back to check on refills. We asked for two takeaway trays and they brought one. Run away! There are too many great places to eat in Singapore. Do not waste your time or money.

address: 277 Orchard Road #04-01, Orchard Gateway Downtown Core 238858 Singapore
comment: This was absolutely the worst experience I've ever had. Usually outbacks have great bloomin onions and average to sub par steaks. This outback managed to ruin both. The blooming onion is cooked like onion rings here, is poorly battered, and just tastes soggy. My steak was rare on one half and well done on the other. Furthermore, the prices are absurd compared to other outbacks. A strip is 50 dollars. You can get a quality strip in New York for 50 rather than the crap they serve here. AVOID AT ALL COST.

address: 277 Orchard Road #04-01, Orchard Gateway Downtown Core 238858 Singapore
comment: This place is awful. The Aussie cheese fries seemed like it was dug out of a garbage can from yesterday. So stale and barely any heat. The wings looked nothing like the menu and seemed like it was deep fried in old oil. I felt a bit sick to eat it. Ribeye was ok , my lady thought it was very disappointing and actually they brought out a medium rather than a medium rare. Staff seems a bit green. The table smells like it was wiped down with a rag that was soaking in old milk overnight.Actually we came here because of the 30 percent off special they had running but seriously not worth it with the discount.

address: 277 Orchard Road #04-01, Orchard Gateway Downtown Core 238858 Singapore
comment: I thought after a week of trying local foods, I would just do a comfort place before flying back to US. But, wow.  This place is in a very expensive "looking" area, but is just awful. I mean seriously. I had fun trying to swap the flies and bugs trying to steal some of my wine, the appetizer had no taste, the food was tremendously undercooked, and on sending back they did cook it more, I was greeted with a hot mess returned. I am actually laughing to myself at how bad this is.  I guess it must be all about the presentation. At least the wine was in a bottle so they could not try to add "value there"?Just wow.

address: 277 Orchard Road #04-01, Orchard Gateway Downtown Core 238858 Singapore
comment: the manager was kind enough to not bill us for the ribeye and the porterhouse.ribeye was cooked well done on one side, the raw on the other. We made a complaint to have the steak changed and the replacement dish we got was a raw ribeye.to make matters worse, my porterhouse had a taste of lamb in which I was allergic to and made me feel nauseated.The floor staff were excellent, but the kitchen is a total nightmare. I don't think the cooks (calling them chefs would be an insult to the profession) know what they were doing at all. it was a mother's day ruined.

address: 277 Orchard Road #04-01, Orchard Gateway Downtown Core 238858 Singapore
comment: American citizen viewpoint: this is NOT what you'd expect from an Outback back in the states. The steak was pretty thin and the baked potato is tiny.  Should have known when there was no queue line on a Friday night that it wasn't worth it.We went here thinking it would be a familiar steakhouse to enjoy that wasn't to expensive versus other Singapore steakhouses. While familiar it is sorely lacking. Don't expect the service or food to be on par with what you are used to in the states.I'm giving it two stars. It wasn't horrible food but for the price even in Singapore you can get a better dinner experience in the restaurant next door to it.

address: 277 Orchard Road #04-01, Orchard Gateway Downtown Core 238858 Singapore
comment: My first time in an Outback that wasn't it's own building, as this is in a mall. But the food and the service too was outstanding, as my food arrived before I finished my first slice of bread. Oh and I had my first ever banana chocolate milkshake. Very pleased I came here, probably will visit one more time before I head back to Boston.

address: 277 Orchard Road #04-01, Orchard Gateway Downtown Core 238858 Singapore
comment: They are going down the hill. We ordered drinks, starter and main, the drinks and starter came and they went ahead to pack our main course. When we told them we didn't ask for to go, they took the food from the pack and plated it for us. We asked for a medium cooked steak, it came rare. The manager conveniently asked me to place the steak onto the side plate where I had the bread. Minutes later, they brought the steak back and it was still rare. Again the steak was send back to the kitchen. This time, it came and was cooked medium rare. Not to mention the pork loin we ordered, was super tough to chew.

address: 277 Orchard Road #04-01, Orchard Gateway Downtown Core 238858 Singapore
comment: Tried Outback Steakhouse even though I'm a tony Tomas frequent patron. I gave a 4star because Outback Steakhouse at orchard central was worth the 5 star rating. They offered really good service, complementary bread just like tony Roma's. But their food and great is great too! As compared to tony Roma's baby ribs, Outback Steakhouse wasn't as nice but their other dishes are just as good! The fillet steak is really juicy and tasted really good amazing. Worth the price as its huge in portion.

address: 277 Orchard Road #04-01, Orchard Gateway Downtown Core 238858 Singapore
comment: I guess for the price, one can't really complain. The bread and butter were terrible. The steak was done the way I liked it, but it's hard to elevate a mediocre piece of meat. Salt does the trick I suppose. There is nothing special about this place, and there is nothing really bad.

address: 277 Orchard Road #04-01, Orchard Gateway Downtown Core 238858 Singapore
comment: The 4 stars if for the food.  We have been visiting this outpost since they opened.  Each time back we notice that it has become less and less of an experience.  A lot has to do with the front of the house floor staffing.  Our last visit was on January 10th.  It amazes me that restaurants in Singapore complain about the cost of everything and then let their front of the house greeters walk customers out the door.  Customers willing to spend dollars with only the slightest of accommodation request.  This was going to be a birthday and business meeting dinner.  We did not want to be jammed into a corner already stuffed with guests when the rest of the dining room sat empty.  Staffing should not become the customers issue to deal with. Sunday January 10th visit. Reason for visiting one of our favourites was for My birthday. We approached the guest services desk at 7:15 pm that Sunday night. The dining room was empty and we asked for a table for 2. We were shown to an area just inside the door. All the dinner guests at that time had been herded and coralled into this small area of booths. We asked for another option and were shown another booth in the same exact area. We have had this happen here twice before with deficient service. Obviously there is a staffing crisis here. No offer was made to seat us at the bar. We chose the best option by walking our dollars out the front door. This story has a happy ending as we found another dining outpost with sufficient staffing and. Had a wonderful birthday dinner. Guess we can cross Outback Orchard Gateway off our list. No equals next.

address: 277 Orchard Road #04-01, Orchard Gateway Downtown Core 238858 Singapore
comment: We'd initially thought of Outback as an Aussie barbie version of Pasta Mania, so it was quite a big surprise that the food here was decent, almost commendable. This isn't Wooloomooloo, but at these price points, it's the cheaper, better Morganfield's.We had:1) Baby Back Ribs & Alice Springs Chicken Combo ($34.90): half a rack of juicy, fork-tender ribs burnished with a tangy bbq sauce that was finger-licking good, and petite chicken breast layered with sauteed mushrooms, crisped bacon and smothered in melted monterey jack and cheddar was flame-grilled to a moist perfection. This was sided by hearty handmashed potatoes, skins and all.  2) Seafood Mix Grill ($29.90): a massive platter of smoky grilled mahi fillet (watch out for bones), seared shrimp and scallops, set atop a piquant mango salsa, and paired with buttered steamed vegetables, and a somewhat middling corn on the cob. Of note was the fat succulent scallops, which were done perfectly

address: 277 Orchard Road #04-01, Orchard Gateway Downtown Core 238858 Singapore
comment: American citizen viewpoint: this is NOT what you'd expect from an Outback back in the states. The steak was pretty thin and the baked potato is tiny.  Should have known when there was no queue line on a Friday night that it wasn't worth it.We went here thinking it would be a familiar steakhouse to enjoy that wasn't to expensive versus other Singapore steakhouses. While familiar it is sorely lacking. Don't expect the service or food to be on par with what you are used to in the states.I'm giving it two stars. It wasn't horrible food but for the price even in Singapore you can get a better dinner experience in the restaurant next door to it.

address: 277 Orchard Road #04-01, Orchard Gateway Downtown Core 238858 Singapore
comment: They are going down the hill. We ordered drinks, starter and main, the drinks and starter came and they went ahead to pack our main course. When we told them we didn't ask for to go, they took the food from the pack and plated it for us. We asked for a medium cooked steak, it came rare. The manager conveniently asked me to place the steak onto the side plate where I had the bread. Minutes later, they brought the steak back and it was still rare. Again the steak was send back to the kitchen. This time, it came and was cooked medium rare. Not to mention the pork loin we ordered, was super tough to chew.

address: 277 Orchard Road #04-01, Orchard Gateway Downtown Core 238858 Singapore
comment: The worst steak expirience so far. I ordered a prime rib eye that was full of fat and overcooked. My friend's steak was raw instead of medium. The service was a bit sluggish considering that the restaurant was half empty when we arrived.

address: 277 Orchard Road #04-01, Orchard Gateway Downtown Core 238858 Singapore
comment: wait for one hour then after checked with one of waiter, only tell us she forgot to put our main courses into order!! this is dinner time and the waitress simply just forgot to enter main courses into system?! sucks big time!!

If you're around Orchard Rd and looking for a decent burger, head to Orchard Central and go up eleven floors to Burger VS Wings + Bar.  It's a burgers and beer spot that's trying REALLY HARD  to be an American chain restaurant/sports bar.  There's seating both indoors and outdoors on a covered patio area.  And just as the name suggests + there is a bar.  Service was quick and friendly.  The decor has a masculine//boxing/food fight theme which is meant to appeal to the Man/Child in us all.  Fries are not included with the burger and offered at an additional charge.  There's a salad/sides/token dessert bar that I believe was included in the price of the burger.The Good: The Burgers and Fries are delicious.The Bad:  The Thai wings were decent, but I don't think I would order them again.  The decor and theming is meh.The Verdict:  A worthy contender in Singapore's epic Burger War (if there were such a thing)Note to Burger VS Wings: The first rule of good signage design is to not misspell the name

Don't get me wrong- this place does have good burgers. Unfortunately the service and ambiance were a bit of a miss.If you come here, you should definitely try the Tyson peanut butter burger. I've never seen or heard of anyone putting peanut butter on a burger, so seeing it on the menu excited me greatly. It tastes exactly as you think it would, but when combined with the juices of the burger, it takes the flavour to another level! Too bad the burgers cost between $15-22 and doesn't even include fries!*In terms of service, I asked for ice water, and the server said they only serve warm. So I ordered warm and then she said, "No, there is no free water, only mineral water." Strange.Miguel ordered a different burger than I did, and when our food was served, our server had absolutely no clue which was which. I have never seen anyone so flustered on the job... I felt a bit bad for her.I was also surprised about the music they were playing. I'm amazed that considering the amount of censorship that goes on in Singapore, F&B and retail establishments can get away with playing music with expletives in them**. And I'm talking repeated use of F bombs. I noticed they were playing the uncensored version of Enrique Iglesias' "Tonight I'm Lovin' You". Yes, that's right- they were blasting "Tonight I'm F***in' You". And children were in the restaurant, too!So yeah, lots of weird stuff going on here... but if you can overlook it and just enjoy the burgers, then you'll be fine.--*This should seriously be considered a sin.**I've experienced this in Forever 21 at 313@Somerset, too. They were blasting Lil' Jon's "What You Gon' Do", F bombs, N words, and sh*t uncensored. And they played the song in it's entirety!

Given this place a couple of tries and service is not great.  At first I was impressed with the concept of wings and burgers plus the nice patio view from the 11th floor,  but got majorly disappointed with the service. After flagging him down and asking for suggestions that he clearly did not want to give or maybe he didn't know the menu, started to have doubts about this restaurant. Ordered a mojito that was decent but it took about 15 minutes to make it. I never mind waiting for a freshly squeezed beverage but it was just meh.Wings are yummy. Not your typical Hooters style wings, spicy with cinnamon and other Asian flavors.  No blue cheese or ranch dressing either, honey mustard is served with them and it does complement the wings quite nicely!  The hubs loved his peanut butter, Thai style burger but my trio of burgers was just average. Food comes as it is made and we got everything staggered, good because everything is hot and fresh but my dish seemed to take forever. Prices are reasonable but I probably won't be back anytime soon.

Coming from the states, I will never get used to paying $20 for a burger. And, oh by the way it doesn't even come with fries. Doh!Nevertheless, B.W.B delivers some wickedly good, But Out Of the Ordinary Burgers. My favorite was the Tyson peanut butter burger. A creamy peanut butter sauce layered on top of the beef patty combined with a sun dried tomato brioche. Peanut Butter, You may ask??? Yes, surprisingly it works really well. It's a little different than the peanut butter you normally have with your PB & J. It's creamier, less brown and let's just say looks a little more classy :DI also tried the classic BWB Classic Heavy weight burger. It's good, but definitely not heavy weight as the name says it to be. It's good, but a little "normal" for my liking. I hear the Wings are pretty good as well, but I can't say I've tried them.BWB is a hip and happening place despite the restaurant being located on the top floor of Orchard Central. Background music is top 40 and the crowd is generally in the twenty to thirty something range.Overall, a classic American burger/wing joint. A little on the pricey side in terms of food, but the restaurant makes up for it in the coolness factor.

This play is ok. Maybe I had high hopes. The burger is bland. I mean real bland even with the toppings inside which did nothing. I had the classic burger. The cheese fries came first actually and it was real nice. I thought well a good indicator but not the case. Also the hot buffalo wings is bad. Maybe it's more asian style but it was soggy, the skin. They also don't offer any kind of water. I usually like to have dessert after so I don't like to sugar up on soda. Positive note, if you are a kid it has a fun feeling as it's super noisy and active. There was 3 birthdays within 10 minutes so I guess it's popular for that. Anyone with an American palette will not be impressed with this place.

This place is the place if you're ever in orchard and need a good burger (or wings). The burgers were juicy and not loaded with sauces and too much seasoning, just the right amount, so one can still taste the beef. And the wings, oh my, the wings were really well marinated and seasoned. Love them. Overall, this place surprised me for a restaurant that has gotten very few write ups, tucked away in the roof of Orchard Central (gotta take the lift up to the 11th floor).I would come back again.
They have closed down, very disappointed for make my way over there when yelp said still exists. Please update the app.

The burger was up to expectations. Tasty and quite large (a little over $20). I also had plain deep fried wings with Thai sauce and mustard.  (6 wings for about $18). The wings were below my expectations. The main issue is that there was hardly any meat at all on the wings.  It was almost all chicken skin and deep fried batter. I am used to much more meaty chicken wings (in the US).Stella beer on draft until 7pm every day for $5.50, a good bargain.
Mediocre burger. Not better than Mc. D IMHO but with 2-3x the price. Truffle Fries was drenched with synthetic truffle oil it looks really unappetizing and unhealthy.
Burger was ok. But no ice water or water!!!  Really the only way to get water is to buy a bottle of water. Won't be back!
food was so-so, but service was terrible. unfriendly waiter who looked like he wished he wasn't there

rest_name: Signs A Taste of Vietnam Pho
comment: At the basement of Midpoint Orchard, we will get to see a humble Vietnam Pho tucked at the corner of corner of the building. Just like many other "hole in the wall" eateries, the stall looks simple with functional furnishing. However behind the stall, its manned by a couple who is deaf. Despite the communication barriers, this couple took up the challenge and set up the F&B business.The menu is pretty straight forward with Pho Noodles, spring rolls, Vietnamese Smoothies and drinks, compact and similar to most pho stall we have here. Diners will need to pen down their orders on the dining chit and pass back to the counter, thereafter once the food ready, it will be served to our table.No doubt Vietnamese Spring Roll is my Must Order in every Viet cuisine, I didnt had the chance to try it as there is no room for them, reason being I'm dining alone, thus I had the simplest bowl of Pho with Sliced Beef Ribeye Pho and extra topping of sliced beef ribeye.The bowl of pho tasted authentic and without any use of MSG. It was light and refreshing with onions, beansprouts and hints of herb taste. Squeezing the juice from the wedge of lime seemingly enliven the taste. Sliced beef were tender and broth was tasty, dabbed these sliced beef into the chilli for some spicy kick.Sliced Beef Ribeye Pho - $6 & Extra Topping of Sliced Beef Ribeye $2The only disadvantage here perhaps maybe the limitation of seating and phone reception. Other than that food is commendable and definitely worth a return.It is a definite dining experience I had here and I can strongly sense their strong passion from the service rendered, trying their best to serve each meal.

I'm honestly a fan of their black pepper wagyu bowl going for $22+ , there's 10% service charge but no GST. Stray by fatcat was initially on entertainer for like Jan 2018 and after which they decided not to be part of the promo. Sad, but oh well! I guess their business is doing too well?Their salted egg softserve is just right for me, savoury, sweet, smooth, swirled into one. Skip their calamansi dessert. $10+ for 3 chocolate shelled balls filled with calamansi juice? It's a palate cleanser that's it. Their charcoal waffle is crisp and holds a light sweet taste with every bite.I like their fusion dishes and though the menu looks small, each item seems to have gone through, thorough thought and care!

First impression waitress was a little irresponsive don't smile so nor exactly welcoming.   So that is a slight minus. Ordered salmon Yusheng, beef bowl and the claypot.  Now the Salmon Yusheng was not impressive as it is nothing usual though it did come in a nice bowl.   The beef bowl got to say the beef was done just right.   just a little too small.   claypot again the meat was done very well. but overall the price points are way off.   Would i be back? hmmmm.....

It's quit surprised by few of their dishes, all of them are really unique and great. I'm a tourist so I can't really judge by their pricing, it's a little bit expensive for me. But overall 4 stars, I would love to return for more dessert

I happened upon this place a few weeks ago while they were still setting up for business. I was pleased to see them open today. I ordered a Nitro Coffee and the Black Pepper Beef Bowl. Both were very nice. The coffee was rich & strong, but super smooth. Delicious. The beef was tender & tasty and the seasonings were just right. The ginger foam gave it an extra something special. It's a soft opening with a limited menu until sometime in February. Also, they will be closed from 27-30 January for CNY

Interesting twist on some traditional dishes. But the menu is too short, the atmosphere too casual (tables set in a corridor of a mall!), and the dishes not good enough for people to go back on return visits. Of the dishes we tried at lunch, only the salmon Yu sheng bowl was good. The rendang carrot cake and the wagyu beef bowl were interesting, but too rich that one must struggle to finish the small serving. Only young people might go hete more than once, and prices nay be too high for many of them.

Portions tend to be tiny, and the menu is not super long, but generally speaking the food is good and unusual. The char siew is fantastic, although it's a bit sweet, so limiting consumption to two pieces per person probably maximises pleasure. The signature truffle duck is delectable. The seabass is quite yummy. Other dishes we had are ok without being wow - the main thing is there was no bad dish. Service is very attentive, albeit a bit awkward throughout the evening. Prices are reasonable, especially with a discount voucher from a variety of suppliers like Entertainer. Overall, a good restaurant, but not good enough to displace the premium Chinese restaurants at hotels in the Orchard Road area, eg. Regent, Four Seasons, Orchard Hotel, Mandarin Orchard. But in my opinion, it beats Goodwood Park, Marriott, and maybe St Regis.

Great HH deal! But 1 get 1 for selected drinks; but these include some really yummy cocktails.. AND you get a free appetizer for the table.. The char siew was delicious - nicely charred and so succulent. The duck spring rolls were really good too; crispy on the outside, not too greasy, and filled with flavorful shredded duck meat in the inside. Best to come in pairs so you get the most out of that 1 free app! :) it's usually pretty quiet; so it's great if you like it private, but not when you want a place to see and be seen.

address: 181 Orchard Road #08-01, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: We went for lunch a couple times.  Come hungry.  The food quality is lacking in my opinion.  For the price, though it is pretty good.  Most things are well stocked.  Salmon sashimi was fairly good, but cut irregularly.  Large quantity, though.  Desserts were halfway decent, ice cream was hit or miss.  One time it was smooth and creamy, another it was icy and crystallized.  Overall for the price you pay for a weekday lunch, not bad.

address: 181 Orchard Road #08-01, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: When you factor in the fact that weekday lunch at Kiseki is just under $20++, it's actually pretty decent fare for what you paid. Word to the wise though, make reservations ahead of time or you'll end up in the walk-in line which can take a while if they can only seat you when there are no-shows. Nice selection of sashimi that is decently fresh. They also had a yu-shang station next to it when I was there after CNY. Decent selection of cooked foods from shrimp tempura to Japanese chicken congee to fried salmon heads and more. Seemed like the only MTO dish that they deliver to your table was the seafood hotpot which was forgettable. Drinks and dessert also included in the buffet. Considering that set-lunches can already set you back over $20, it's a pretty good deal for lunch at Kiseki especially if you like variety.

address: 181 Orchard Road #08-01, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: Got my expectation too high when coming to this restaurant. Food variety is bad. Food quality is bad. Replenishment is an issue. Unagi cheese fried rice is only good on its sound. The real thing is just a regular fried rice, nothing to be desired, but it not the worst part yet. The soba is floury, the soba sauce is lukewarm instead of cold. The taste is bland. The ebi tempura is not a tempura at all. It is a Chinese food deep fried shrimp. I guess the restaurant doesn't think they are different.  Black curry sauce... You'd better avoid. Cawan mushi is alright and they get it right for most part but it will be forever before they replenish it. Sake karagee is good and one of the few good things in this restaurant. Don't make me start on salmon sashimi since I am not sure what kind of salmon or which part of it being used but it is very chewy and doesn't take like usual salmon. Other buffet places are much better than this and even sushi express. Oh and it is the only fish sashimi they have. Awesome. Shrimp and crab legs are OK I guess? The only ones being replenished quite quickly so it is better if they change the concept to Chinese buffet? Dessert variety is abysmal, quality is questionable since it is my first time eating a puke-textured mochi that I fought my gag reflect to the fullest not to spit it. So if you want a Japanese buffet then it is better for you to eat at the one in suntec city since it is Japanese and it is good both in quality and variety. Avoid this place whenever possible how good their ice Coke is.

address: 181 Orchard Road #08-01, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: Dear belly, I am sorry for the abuse you had gone through last night after our meal at Kiseki.... I am sorry for the lousy salmon sashimi that didn't even have the skin layer cleaned off... I know we could have gotten a much better experience by going to Cold Storage, but I though it was Friday and I wanted to give you a treat. After all, we flew more than 20 hours to get here once a year. And of course I know you weren't going to forgive me for the yucky prawns which were tasteless at best and the atrocious scallops which were supposed to be fresh... I know I know you are weeping because I cheated you with the fabulous pictures posted outside Kiseki but the real deal looked nothing like it... or more like a shit storm just torn through the restaurant right before we got there! Importantly, I beg your pardon for the worst cooked buffet selection you had to endure. I am very sorry that I even offered you the undercooked corn, taste buds insulting yaki selection and much more. On a brighter note, I am glad you didn't have to talk to Mr anus right away about the watery diarrhea he had to process like the rest of the family after the meal... actually I am just sorry to even remind you of the horror and traumatic experience last night. I would like to reassure you that this wasn't intentional and yes yes there's so much more in Singapore to try please just don't give up on me just yet.... please. Regards,Bi

address: 181 Orchard Road #08-01, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: Food standard has dropped tremendously. For the lunch buffet, selection is extremely limited. For example, at the sushi station, there was only 3-4 kinds.Fried vegetables were served cold. Japanese curry was cold. In short I'll only pay 15++ for this (per pax was 35++) or would rather go opposite for Shabu Sai.Flabbergasted.

address: 181 Orchard Road #08-01, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: Your average run-of-the-mill Japanese buffet place with sub-standard food. Go for quantity, not quality.It's size and variety is good for large gatherings though, as I came here for a department dinner. I think coming for lunch is definitely more value-for-money than dinner, as dinner was $31.80++.Would not come back again, unless coerced into it.

address: 181 Orchard Road #08-01, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: This is hands down one of the best buffet places I have ever visited. It offers a wide selection of main dishes and delectable desserts. Most of the main dishes are prepared on the spot, ensuring that each dish is piping hot for your consumption.At stations like the teppanyaki grill, one can select from fish, chicken or pork. Each of these choices were cooked to perfection with juices dripping off the chunks. Another one of my favourites was the mini rosti - essentially strips of potatoes pan fried in butter. Slightly crispy on the outside and fluffy on the inside, every bite was pure heaven.Other main stations include sushi, chawanmushi (steamed egg), hot pot and yakitori.Now moving on to the desserts. Like most buffet places, it offers a selection of dainty cakes and even a chocolate fountain with a selection of fruits. But what stood out amongst these already awesome choices was its tofu cheesecake. Imagine this; silky cheesecake of the creamiest and richest texture, and you know for a fact that it is a healthier choice with the tofu compared to your average cheesecake. Need I say more.The store's pomelo sorbet was also a refreshing dessert with its sweet and tart flavours perfect for clearing your palate.Its new location at Orchard Central is also an added bonus for accessibility. With good food, an affordable price and prime location, there's really nothing stopping you from visiting the restaurant. You can be sure that I'll be returning for more soon!

address: 181 Orchard Road #08-01, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: Not worth the money, especially during dinner when it costs about $43 per person for a lousy selection and quality of food. Left much to be desired.

address: 181 Orchard Road #08-01, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: This place is a very good place for gatherings for Big Groups.The Seafood and Sashimi are all very fresh and there is a very wide selection of food. The BBQ is cooked on the spot by the staff and they are cook to perfection and seasoned very nicely, food is also replenished at a fast rate. The staff are friendly and efficient, clearing of plates is fast and so is the serving of food. The place is very big and it is very well ventilated and Air-conditioned, the lighting is also very bright and not gloomy.

address: 181 Orchard Road #08-01, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: The place is really big! It can accommodate a huge group of people if you make reservations in advance. I enjoyed the grilled beef, teppanyaki bean sprouts, and pork shabu shabu hotpot! I also like the sweet potato and ebi tempura. A large variety of hot and cold drinks are available. They also have interesting gelato flavours like wasabi (gasp!) and Yuzu, along with green tea and vanilla. Great gelato texture and good flavours. Service was efficient and there was always someone clearing the plates. Overall a good experience!

address: 181 Orchard Road #08-01, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: This place is as good as it can get! The lunch buffet is the most worth it of all. Please make reservation before heading as there are lots of people! The food varieties is great and quality of food matches the price you paid during lunch.Do expect crowds of people taking food. For sashimi you have to go to the counter and request as they do not place the sashimi out. Dessert is amazing as there are lots o choices! Would recommend this!

address: 181 Orchard Road #08-01, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: Good buffet for the price esp. during weekdays. Come after 12:15pm so that everyone are seated and the line is minimal. Or come before 11:30am instead. Food choice is vast, but you get tired of the taste after you overfeed yourself the first two plates with everything on it. It'll feel like youre gulping a blender concoction of food. Yuck! The trick is to eat just like you do in an a la carte restaurant, one plate one kind of food at a time. Eating all kinds at once will cause your taste buds send multiple sensory signals to the brain and cause it to get nauseated. Like reading magazine while travelling in a car in a city traffic. You'll want to throw up.

address: 181 Orchard Road #08-01, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: Looking for a place that gathers a bunch of good people? I needed a smorgasbord of International foods that could make my  group happy and this 280-seat buffet joint - Kiseki Japanese Buffet looks extremely ultimate with a roomy and well-ventilated environment. It becomes one of my shortlisted.I am not a typical fan of buffet-style meal but I am happy to have it once in a while. And specially when the group is large, I can rest assured that each of them will find something fanciful among the 8 self-help stations. This is achievable, given the mega spread Kiseki is offering. Not sure if its a blessing, but close to 40% of the range are non-Japanese cuisines. While the Japanese dishes still make up the majority, I am one of those weirdo who only eye for that fluffy looking deep pocketed batter cake resting on the iron rack. For all you know, I am dotty about waffles.In my view, a buffet feast equates a marathon. Just as the gun sounded, I find myself derailed and taking shortcuts to the finishing line - dessert station. There, my eyes are fixed at the lady behind the waffle maker, counting the number of waffle wedges she is dishing out and eye balling frantically for condiments for a switch up. Fresh fruit dices -nope. Candy rice - nope nope. Jellied puddings, mochi and Daifuku - nope nope nope. Until I reached the chilling box with 6-8 flavours of gelato - yes; black sesame, green tea & vanilla checked (even though they all turned melty in the chiller?!?). Then that chocolate fondue drizzles - again marked! They are invited to join me at my table. Results of them all? The gelato was nice and creamy but the exterior wasn't  crisp enough, least comparable to Geláre. Sadly, the whole grid cake was soft in nature. Still, I remain faithful to my beloved dough-based cake.After the off-track, I joined the rest on the official route - pacing up and down the counters, examined each food items closely. I picked a few sizable tempura from the Agemono sub-section - ebi, kani stick & yasai (broccoli), all tasted fresh and crunchy of which, I liked the vegetable most. Okay, crowned me a fake-vegan title if you like.Then slightly to the right, there are Teppanyaki & Robatayaki where you find monstrous grilled salmon fish heads, shishamo, baby tender chicken teriyaki sticks and grilled plumply shitake mushrooms. Towards the end of the row, I ordered some wok fry assorted vegetables, mostly bean sprouts with a few stringy choy sum - not bad though I'd prefer marche's. My girlfriend ordered a portion of Teppanyaki pork collar in ginger sauce which I thought was pretty delicious, moist and very tender, not fibrous and the seasoning was just right. The cook done it better than the garlic beef steak which tasted leathery. Oh, please bring along those table-numbered mini file clips found on your table when ordering so that the wait staff could send the food when it's ready.Walk around the bustling see-through kitchen, another row of food items revealed. At the left-hand corner, you could order Italian pasta of 3 choices - Wafu vinaigrette dressing, creamy carbonara or konkase tomato sauce; alternatively, pick up a ready thin-crust pizza with teriyaki chicken, Japanese curry or seafood toppings. Potato-goers could give the Rösti a shot, its shredded surface was pan-roasted to crisp but it lacked that robust buttery flavour I used to know.Stroll along and you get to reach out to more fried items like potato ebi rolls, cheese crab balls, seafood Croquettes, Haru Maki (spring roll) seafood. Next, I flipped open the steamer cover and help myself to the hearty winter dish - Japanese Oden with plentiful of squishy quail eggs, fish cakes with hidden popping fish roe, perfectly stewed daikon, glutenous Konjac (greyish starch corms) and the most delightful Kinchaku pouch - deep fried bean curd wrapped with fish cake. I enjoyed the light soy sauce broth that makes everything taste homely.While I skipped the egg plants and roasted chicken, I took a bite on the Japanese curry udon placed along the next counter. I am glad that the udon didn't taste overly soggy but the curry seasoning was a bit loud, somewhere didn't fare quite right. I heard the pork shabu ramen did better. Well, I was unlucky then.You may want to try out Chawanmushi or Tamagoyaki in the bamboo tray plus a bowl of steaming hot seafood soup. Or simply walk to the adjacent counter for some cold seafood selections - chilled prawns & mussels or clams, salads, soba, sushi and sashimi.With so much to offer, what else could make my people über happy? I don't know.

address: 181 Orchard Road #08-01, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: There are many types of jap food here. but the varieties of each type isnt much.I am hoping that they can serve ramen but they do not have. The sashimi is fresh but too thickly cut. The fried salmon head is bland and tasteless.However, one thing good is that there are people constantly clearing your plates and the food are constantly replenished. Please reserve as there are a very long queue for walk-in on weekends.

address: 181 Orchard Road #08-01, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
comment: A friend's friend recommended this place. We went and paid $65.44 for 2.Both my friend and I had studied in japan. I was there for 5 years and very particular about authentic Japanese food. So far, I think only their Chawanmushi and chicken yakitori were pretty good. The rest just so-so...Sashimi is rather stingy, only squid (ika) , Salmon and may be 2 other kinds. They have fried rice, oden, and some other varieties but not a great deal.Dessert is alittle pathetic,  only 3 kinds of cakes, strawberry, goma (sesame seeds) and yuzi. Another 5, 6 different of kinds of ice-cream, macha (green tea) is not even up to the bar...and it was squeezed in a corner when there's always a line and right beside someone having their meals.It was rather noisy on the Vesak Day...I will continue to try out other Japanese restaurant.

It's nice to have a good korean food option without having to go all the way to Tanjong Pagar rd, aka k-town of Singapore. This place is technically a branch of Supulae anyway which is one of the best korean BBQ in town, but just smaller place.But i don't usually com here for the BBQ. I come here for the good ol' Korean dishes. My favorite is their bibimbap (mixed rice) and the soondooboo (Spicy tofu soup).They start doing all you can eat BBQ lately which could be good value. I haven't tried it though!
Lunch sets suck. Quality is sooo bad. The fish ordered, Burnt on outside so bitter and raw inside.

I went there yesterday for dinner as I'm craving Korean food (which is pretty much every day of the week).  I'm surprised by the taste since I didn't feel too positive after reading reviews about Supulae in Tanjor Pagar. I think this will be one of my frequented Korean restaurants since it's so close to home. We had the Pork Belly Kimchi Stew $28, which is served on the gas burner in a stewing pan. The taste is flavourful without being too salty.  Portion is good, although we added extra Rice Cake $5 and my husband also ordered a rice. The Bachan is above average, although I wish they would serve bean sprouts / spinach to add more veggies. They offered kimchi, cabbage salad, fish cake, daikon/cucumber pickles, seaweed salad, and hard boiled quail eggs last night.I would stay away from the Korean drinks in a pop $4 each due to price, but otherwise, price/quality is pretty good. I'll come back to try the steamed egg $5 and BBQ some other time.

One of my favorite spots in singapore,conveniently right outside the mrt in the 313. One of the best pizzas in singapore, especially the 4 cheese. The pizza with french fries on it is a nice touch. Excellent service and friendly staff.
Close to my hotel and just walk to here. From 2:00 to 7:00, happy hour is to buy 1 and 1.The Otus is strong and special, but taste isbgoo

The pizza appeared to be properly baked but inexplicably it was served on a wooden platform that trapped the moisture so it came out soft and soggy.  Disgusting.  Service was typically awful.   I won't be back.

I had one of their garlic seafood pasta which is the most expensive pasta I ever had. But the taste is super good!! It's just about their price more than 30 SGD but really got a lot great seafood such as prawn, so many clam and Perna viridis! With the little red pepper which is really spicy! Last don't forget order a glass of white wine. You will love it!

When it comes to Italian food i have to admit, this wasn't impressive.  This felt like the Olive garden of the US.  The items on the menu were overprice in my opinion.  But again, everything in Singapore is expensive.  I had a salad with soup which still is cheaper compared to their pasta dishes. The minestrone soup was so so , it did have a lot of fresh ingredients but it was a little salty.  The pasta portions were really small and not worth the price to me.  This place can really loud because it's outside of the station and mall entrance. Overall, i prob would stick to my Hainan chicken over this.

The food at Suju isn't anything fancy. It won't change your life, it won't redefine the way you look at sushi, not define how certain dishes should taste. They do simple, and they do it pretty damn well.Food here isn't cheap, and personally I think one starter, two mains, and a chazuke for SGD $130 is quite frankly, a little on the pricey side. One cannot deny the execution though. The homemade tofu salad is refreshing and a perfect start to the meal. The chawanmushi while a little pricey, is a solid rendition though a little different (think dried scallops instead of the usual chicken and mushroom). As everyone else said, the miso silver cod is pretty good. I'm not a big fan of miso cod in general (save Nobu), but most of my friends speak highly of it. What I do love is their grilled chicken with salt and pepper. Crisp, savoury, oily, it's delicious, and goes very well with most of their carbs. Speaking of carbs, I highly recommend their grilled salmon chazuke. It's simple, but incredibly nourishing. There's a depth and warmth that makes it a great meal on a rainy day... or a on any day really. Overall I think Suju is definitely a keeper. You get a $30 voucher with every $100 spent if you pay by Amex, so factoring that in, I'm quite inclined to go back again and again.

The visit today explains why we have not been back to this restaurant for several years. The menu is relatively short, with no innovation. The food is decent, but quite meh; the sushi is not extremely fresh. The best food item at Suju is the rice!! At $80-90 per pax, I'd rather go to Sushi Tei.

Had a lunch meeting here. We had the lunch special set at SGD25 each. Delicious. Fresh "saba shioyaki" or grilled mackerel and the set came with pickles, a bit of veggies, and "miso" or soybean soup. Very satisfying.

Great Japanese restaurant hidden on the 4th floor of Mandarin Gallery. We had toro don and tenderloin steak lunch sets. Both were excellent. We went back for dinner a few days later. We got oysters, mozuku, and agedashi for appetizers and tenderloin steak as well as the grilled fish for the main dishes. Everything was so good so we went back for our last dinner before leaving Singapore. This time we had Iberico and wagyu steak as our main course. The sauce that came with wagyu steak is divine. The service is also perfect during all three meals.

I came in at 6.03 pm, the waitress sent us to our seat and let us know that we have the table until 7pm, we agreed. But our food didnt come until 6.40 pm and by 7pm she wanted us to move to the counter while it was free since the beginning. Imagine in the middle of having dinner and u must pay for the bill, i lost my appetite and  maybe wont return, what a service.

With all due respect, why on Earth would anyone compare Suju to Sukiyabashi Jiro? lolAt first, I thought Suju would just be another overpriced mediocre Japanese restaurant in Orchard Road that will just serve average food while burning a hole in our pockets. But after my brother recommended it to me, I decided to try it.The highlight in the menu is definitely the miso paste black cod. I have not seen another restaurant, besides Nobu themselves, who does it as well as Suju. The marinate just penetrates the fish without overwhelming it. It perfectly and subtly changes the texture of the black code just like how it's supposed to.Unfortunately, the rest of the dishes were not really that special. It wasn't bad and it was better than expected but it won't make me order anything else other than the black cod when I visit Suju.

As the other reviewers have said, the grilled cod (gindara) here is something special. It's a pretty thick cut that is nonetheless perfectly seasoned and cooked. Slightly sweet, full of umami, skin grilled to an oily, slightly crisped perfection, the fish melts apart in flakes to the touch and dissolves gently on the tongue. Goes well with some of their offered sake!The sashimi is pretty much Singapore standard (ie don't expect much). The home made soft tofu was pretty good, but it's an appetizer. I was underwhelmed by their much-advertised copper-pot rice, which my brother had raved about but even he had to admit that the day we went together was an off-day for the rice, for it was okay but nothing special. Still, the cod makes it a destination worth coming to!

So far the best japanese restaurant in Singapore. Yes i said it.. The food in suju are so simple & feel like home cook food. Am not japanese, however, everytime i had lunch / dinner there i can feel the warmth in their dishes. So simple things like their rice & miso soup is more than enough. If we talked about their cooked dish like chicken nanaban, chicken teriyaki, beef sukiyaki & more. All feel very authentic & cooked with passion. I didnt get anything by writting all above. However just like to say that their food are really cooked with passion. Enjoy.. Eat well & life well.

My husband and I dine at Suju regularly.  We've enjoyed the atmosphere, small dishes, and Japanese whiskey list.  However, after last experience, we are on the look out for our new sushi joint.  We made a reservation for Saturday evening at 9:15.  This did not seem to be a problem.  When we arrived, the restaurant was emptying out.  We ordered a variety of sashimi, and sake.  The sashimi was high quality fish, but looked like it had been cut with a spoon--pieces that were far too thick and unevenly cut.  Our grilled salmon was overcooked.  At 10 pm, while we were still eating, the waitstaff brought us the bill, and waited until I took out my credit card.  After bringing back the receipt, they ushered us out as the staff began to mop.  This restaurant says it is open until 10:30.

Good bijoufu (can't rem) sake, we had gindara (cod fish) , chirashi and Toku (special) sushi sets.  The miso soup is nice and generous. The cod was nice and the miso marinate wasn't overpowering and enjoyed it to the last bite. The sashimi over rice and sushi was one of the better ones I tried for a while.  And comparing to Sukiyabashi Jiro's roppongi branch it is much value for money and yet I enjoyed it very much.   Would definitely go back and try other rice dishes.  Suju is a rice specialty Jap restaurant, no ramen. Of course it is nestled between 2 other jap restaurant which specializes in ramen and jap BBQ if one fancies.

A gift from the gods.  The chilli crab was totally amazing and made my trip to Singapore!  The staff was kind and helpful, patiently showing me how to eat this wonderful stuff.  Can't wait to return!!

Tonite dinner at Tunglok Seafood which located at the 11th floor of @orchardcentral Sake (Norwegian Salmon) Sashimi 挪威三文鱼刺身 (S$22++) Got 1-for-1 if you use Burpple Beyond deal!Deep-Fried Prawn with Wasabi-Mayo Sauce 芥末虾球 (S$28++)White Pepper Dungeness Crab with Leek and Fresh Peppercorn 白胡椒深海螃蟹 (S$9.80++/ 100g)Tung Lok Signature Chilli Crab 同乐招牌辣椒螃蟹 (S$9.80++/ 100g)Served with Deep Fried Mantou.Braised Rice Vermicelli with Seafood 招牌海鲜白米粉 (S$24++) - Don't leave behind the broth! That's the best part, so milky and rich.End with dessert Chilled Mango Cream Pomelo and Sago 杨枝甘露 (S$6++)Chilled Lemongrass Jelly with Lime Sorbet 青柠冰香茅冻 (S$6++)Don't forget to put on the stick on apron before attacking the crabs. Disposable gloves and wet tissue are provided too.

Came here for the chilli crab and it's perfectly cooked. The chilly crab sauce is a tad on the sweet side would prefer it to a tad spicier.We also ordered the Asam steamed fish and spinach with three eggs. The fish is very fresh! The service is very good.I am very impressed with the location of this restaurant as its very closed to where we are staying in orchard Central.

Talk about fine dining on the 11th floor of orchard central. With a view! We were unlucky though. We got seated away from the ceiling-to-floor windows :( We Came here for the ala carte buffet during lunch. It's waaaay cheaper than dinner. Pretty much half off as dinner is apparently $60 a pop. Lunch was a lot less but still more than how much you'd pay normally for lunch haha. so this is like royalty status dining. Anyway, onto the food~ We ordered: Salmon sashimi, fried fish skin with salted egg, fried prawns with oats, chili prawns, tofu with scallop and shrimp, fried eggplant, some soup i forgot the name of. and for dessert: we got these fried rolls with taro paste or pandan paste inside. and those glutinous seasame balls. Now since this was pretty much an AYCE (all you can eat), we obviously got more than one of most dishes.. like 3 plates of salmon sashimi and 2 of the fish skin. We ate until we looked like we had food-babies. It was hard because in our party of 4, half of us can't eat a lot so my cousin and I pretty much tried to eat for two people hahaha. Service was alright. The ladies were very nice in changing our plates, refilling our drinks, and even took a very nice photo of us. I was surprised! Dining here is probably a once in a blue moon type of thing. Otherwise, your wallet will probably cry a thousand river.

decent-for-the-price à la carte buffet atop orchard central. this is pretty alright chinese food dished up as much as you like, whenever you like (while they're serving lunch, of course) - and at this meal we went through the entire menu at least once.nothing really stood out enough for me to recall it to you - but we did have perhaps six or seven servings of the salmon sashimi, which was seafood-fresh and tender - and perhaps the best part of the meal.the chinese food I would liken to better-than-catering, served hot and quickly (admirable considering the crowds they were serving), and good for crowds (and plenty cheap for a gluttonous sunday lunch).

Had chilli crab as was on the must-do list for when we were in Singapore recently & my parents used to eat it all the time in Punngol pt in the 80's.  I can't even really describe in words but if I had to? well here they are...THE BEST CHILLI CRAB EVER. That is all.

address: 391A Orchard Rd Takashimaya Shopping Centre Singapore 238873 Singapore
comment: Ya Kun Kaya makes some of the best kaya that I've had. I always have to stop by and pick up a few jars before leaving Singapore. They make for great gifts, and my friends always ask me to bring some back with me when I visit. This location is within the Food Village in Takashimaya SC.

address: 391A Orchard Rd Takashimaya Shopping Centre Singapore 238873 Singapore
comment: My favorite coffee in Singapore! Coffee is prepared for each individual cup. Great flavor & aroma! They're busy but staff is efficient. Located in the Food Village of Takashimaya SC.

Went to this place on a lark.  I was pining for some solid greasy sweet Indo Martabak.  And this place didn't disappoint.  Their mixed Martabak is what I was used to when I was a kid.  Love this place and I also love the service.  Terima kasih banyak.And I'll be back.

Jtown Café - Indonesian Cafe @ Midpoint Orchard.Ordered and made the necessary payment at the counter.  The Staff will send your order to where you are seated.Decent Indonesian flare if I am craving for their Soup Dumplings and their Beef Ball Soup aka Bakso - especially during the "Rainy" season here in Singapore.The staffs are indeed accommodating and welcoming.  My least favorite item was the Chicken dish drenched in some kind of gravy/sauce - tasted more like soy sauce.Do allocate about 10 to 15 minutes if you intend to order the "Martabak Manis".  Doable "Martabak Manis" aka Sweet Thick Pancakes.  May need to try other flavors in the future.Since this establishment is tiny, during PEAK Lunch hours, it can get cramped and packed to the brim.  Hence plan accordingly.Hmm, if ONLY they offer "Savory" Martabak...  That can change to another level.  Perhaps from there my review might differ.May return when needed.

The martabak! The martabak manis has passed my Indo aunt's test. My aunt happened to be in Singapore when I bought the martabak home and she had a taste of it. I chose the mix which had everything - cheese, chocolate, peanuts, sugar and butter. I could even taste the condensed milk though it was not in the menu description.Her verdict: Very similar to those found in Jakarta as it was very rich unlike Singapore's version (min jiang kueh peanuts sugar or red bean flavor)I have to agree. The martabak brought back memories of my aunt bringing this (and many other goodies) into Singapore whenever she was here for a visit. It is that good. I really hardly see this on the menu in Indonesian restaurants so for the moment, this will be the place to go if I get craving for this. The menu also includes the usual noodles and rice but do not expect much. It is quite simple fare but jazzed up a bit. I tried the black pepper bakmie but I did not really like it. I will be back to try the usual bakmie and bakso though.

JTown Cafe is a small outlet in Midpoint, selling Jakarta street food at reasonable prices, and somemore in orchard area. It is located across from the food court. Although the selection is not a lot, the place is packed during lunch with the office crowd with most having its lunch sets priced at $5.90.Bakmie Ayam ($5.90)It is actually indonesian chicken noodle, served with a cup of iced tea.The iced tea is bland but refreshing to have in such a hot day.The noodle comes with a bowl of soup, filled with 3 pieces of beef meatballs.I like that there is a lot of crispy fried shallots in the noodles. Remember to add the spicy tangy chilli sauce from the counter. The heat from the sauce adds extra kick to the dish.Martabak Campur ($3.90 regular)indonesian pancake with mixed topping of peanuts, chocolate rice and cheeseAs I am too full I decide to take this away which costs another $0.20 more. I like the texture of the melting cheese, the crunchy nutty peanuts and chocolate rice which makes a yummy dessert.Overall the food is not bad. No wonder the place is packed during lunch.

Very good noodles with chicken and beef balls. The item was not as spicy as I thought. The noodles are amazing, they are made by hand, springy and bouncy. The beef balls have amazing soft texture, not rubbery.

Kind of an authentic Indonesian food. The staff members were all friendly. The ambiance is casual. It gets pretty loud inside too. I've been here three times. The first time I came here, I ordered their original bakmi ayam ($5.5), the seasoning was good although it's a bit on the dry side so I needed to ask for more chicken oil, with springy noodles done just the way I like it, martabak ovomaltine which was impressive (apparently it tastes pretty authentic according to my Indonesian friends), siomay (Indonesian siew mai) which was awful because they used too much starch with only little meat used and fried dumplings ($2.5 for 3pcs) which is my favorite aside from their bakmi.Second time I came, I tried their popcorn chicken bakmi ($5.9) and since then it ultimately became my only favorite here, it is so simple, tidy, spare, and absolutely spot on. Tried soup dumplings too but not as nice as the fried version. The meatballs though, it's pretty good. However, neither dish is meant to be complex or overly adorned.Kitchen is really small so expect a slow service but prices are reasonably affordable so can't complaint! Remember to ask for extra chicken oil to your bakmi for better taste. I wish I could give this place more than 3 stars because I LOVE THE BAKMI! But too bad that's the only food  I like here so I guess 3 stars it is. PS: Everything is halal

Comfort food at its best. If you're feeling hungry in Orchard Road and you fancy a more asian palate, J-Town is the place to go. Friends from Jakarta say that its pretty close to what you can get there.The chilli-ed up Mee Goreng or the Black Pepper Bakmie is definitely recommended. Don't forget the sinfully sweet Martabak dessert. Do share with a friend.Lunchtime crowd might delay your food a bit though. Its a small kitchen after all.

I like coming here when I have a bakmi craving. This is the food of my childhood. I like the popcorn chicken bakmi with a side of fried wontons on the side. The portion sizes are generous and I'm always full after eating here. I always come with the intention to try the martabak but never have enough room to try it. Perhaps one day, I'll just come here for the martabak.

I LOVE THEIR MARTABAK MANIS. After consulting with all my Indonesian friends, this is probably one of the few places in SG that sells legit martabak manis. I always get the coklat and keju, not much of a fan of having kacang in it. Sometimes they burn it a little, but most of the time its delicious. I brave the hoards of Orchard shoppers just to get to this place. Given that it is one of the few places that does sell martabak manis, its a bit expensive (esp comparing to how much cheaper it is in Indonesia -__-) but when you have a craving you have to fulfill it ^_^. But its worth it. You'll have to wait about 10 minutes for them to make it since they don't have it just waiting in the corner, which is awesome and well worth the wait for the thousand calorie pleasure. Also had their bakso which was also pretty good. Its quite easy to get to, its right across the street from Somerset or take a bus and get off at Midpoint Orchard.
simple raw set up. Nothing amazing except for street indonesian food. Good Lunch Menus

A Raw-Ing good time Another one of those places that have been opened a while but was skeptical of trying, primarily due to it looking like another upmarket restaurant that tries too hard to be different. While I still think that it's slightly on the pricy side, the food, I have to admit that it was a joy to have! Happy Hour oysters and Martini, shaken not stirred (sorry.. Just had to add that in)We were there before 8 pm (they do sell themselves as a bar so I suppose 8pm does makes sense for happy hour) and decided to give their oysters a try. At $2.00 an oyster with every alcoholic drink bought (at $10.00 for a martini, it worked out to $22.00 for 6 oysters, under $4.00 each), it wasn't too bad. As their name suggests, they do specialize in Raw dishes so the quality of the oysters were definitely there. Don't expect the super rich, high end $7-12 French oysters but still, decently sized and very fresh oysters. The Lychee Martini itself was pretty good too. Unlike most bars who taste like they're serving lychee syrup, you could taste the alcohol in the drink and it was nice that they gave 2 lychees instead of 1.(minor detail I know but for a lychee lover, it's a huge plus point) Ocean RockefellerThis would have made a great starter to any dinner. Served in 3 varieties, the raw salmon, scallops and spicy lobster was well thought through. Serves In a scallop shell, the torched Mozzarella tied the ingredients in nicely and added a touch of saltiness to the dish. The salmon was fresh, the scallops were nice and sweet and the lobster, while spicy to some, was a great way to end the trio. Sunshine Donburi Now this.... This is the kind of rice bowl we dreamt of as a kid (and definitely today too). What could be better than a bowl of rice, served with bacon, luncheon meat, smoked duck breast and an egg! I'm just happy that the luncheon meat and bacon were not fried to death. What could have made this dish better though was if they served it with a poached or Ajitsuke Tamago (the ramen eggs). The yolk would have helped make the dish a little richer and help tie in the ingredients better, making it a complete dish and not just rice with 3 ingredients. Can't wait to be back for their lunch specials, which IS slightly cheaper than their regular Ala Carte Menu. An overall great place to eat and meet up with friends, though definitely on the pricy side. Only draw back? Service wasn't as friendly as it could have been, given the fact that you're paying $15-20 a main.

My go-to lunch spot for a quick meal in the Orchard area. The lunch set ($10) is always a steal and I usually go for the salmon kaisen, soboro beef, or shohei. You can also top up for green tea, miso soup, and a salad. While the portions have gotten smaller in recent years, they've still maintained their quality and the happy hour deals are a plus!

I came here because I heard good things about their beef bowls, but honestly left a bit disappointed. The beef and rice together weren't as flavorful as I wanted. It seems to be quite a popular place though, as there was a bit of queue when I arrived.Food:- Beef Bowl: They're most known for their Truffle Yakiniku Bowl. I'm not a big fan of truffle, so I tried one of their specials, which was a Yakiniku Bowl with a more standard gyudon sauce and an egg. The beef itself and the sauce both weren't as flavorful as I would like, though I did quite enjoy the egg. The portion size is just okay as well. I did try a bit of the Truffle bowl and just note that the flavorful of the truffle is very strong.- Salmon Sashimi: They had a happy hour special where each piece of sashimi was $1 for certain kinds. Note that each piece is very small, much smaller than you would normally expect for sashimi. The taste was not bad though.Service/Wait:- Service was fine. One complaint was that you have to order a drink for the happy hour special, which we didn't realize. I ended up ordering a strawberry cocktail that was reasonable ($10).- Didn't have to wait when I arrived at 6:45pm on a weekday, but the line got quite long within about 15 min afterwards.Price: $$The price is pretty standard for a nice donburi in Singapore. It was about $19 for my beef bowl and $18 for the Truffle one. Most of their bowls are in the $15-30 range, including their sashimi ones, though they do have a few pricier ones too.

Recently the casual Japanese restaurant has reopened at the shopping centre. It is now located at level 4, with a bigger dine in area. Similar to its previous location, it has both indoor and outdoor dine in area.As the restaurant was crowded, I decided to ask for outdoor dine in area, which was still has quite a number of tables as most felt that it was quite hot to dine outdoor. Compared to indoor, I felt outdoor was better as indoor was filled with cooking smell. Sitting in outdoor, one also can enjoy the great view of the busy Orchard Road.While looking through the menu, I was served iced water. A bit disappointed as the water was not refilled. Maybe sitting outdoor was not so good after all, as it was difficult to get the attention of the staffs.Although it was weekend, the restaurant offered lunch menu. Just add $2++ to the main dish to make it a lunch set. I decided to have a Premium Set by topping $5++. The set included miso soup, green salad, and coffee or "Back to work" beverage.Foie Gras Truffle Yakiniku ($19.90++)pan-seared foie gras, US black angus short rib, onsen egg, truffle soy, black garlic brown butter over Tanuki's signature mixed riceThe foie gras was quite buttery and melt in the mouth. The beef was quite tender and moist. The mixed rice was tasty on its own.Miso SoupThe soup was filled with chunky pieces of tofu and seaweed. The soup tasted light and flavourful.Green SaladThe salad was lightly tossed with ginger soyu dressing. Light and crunchy.Shio Smooth (a la carte $5++)fresh shiso, matcha green tea, lemon, blended with iceIt was my choice of "Back to work" beverage. It was light and refreshing in taste. Just the right to have during such a hot day.Overall the food was not bad. But the service needed to be improved as it was quite difficult to get the attraction of the staffs.

I think the food standard has dropped. The first time I was here was for an Yelp Elite Event and everything was of course amazingly good. Subsequently I had returned a few times and the food was still ok but my last visit last week was downright terrible.My favorite item was always the American Roll as I loved the beef with rice. However this was more chewy (due to the thick flour coating the roll) and carbs laden than before. More rice than meat. It was so bad I just removed the outer layer. No longer can I rave about this to my friends now. The Rockstar which my friend ordered was equally average to not so nice like before. Did the chef change? The only thing which had it going was its happy hour promotion of $2 oyster and $10 cocktail. Those were still decent though my friend said her drink was not as potent as before.

Apparently there is always a queue outside no matter what time of day. I had the foie gras yakiniku with onsen egg. Very fast to serve. I thought the rice was a tad soggy as I would have liked less gravy. The caramel matcha smoothie is very yummy.

I have been reading Tanuki Raw somewhere and it kinds of remind me of Donburi with onsen egg. (Their marketing advertisement has been good to give me such good impression). We was looking at Minions Cafe in Orchard Central and it wasn't appealing to us and by chance we decided to dine in Tanuki Raw instead.Tanuki Raw is modernly furnished in an industrial interior tempered by eye-catching furniture.and has 80 seats spread across an outdoor balcony overlooking Orchard Road.It was fun sitting at the bar side observing how the tenders mix and prepare variety of drinks. As for our glasses of Water Melon Yuzu. Fresh watermelon juice were already prepared before hand and kept in the fridge. They just have to mix portion of it with yuzu and served them on the "rocks".Water Melon Yuzu - $10While Tanuki Raw is having a house promotion for happy hour daily from 5-8pm, we get to order Oysters at $2 each, limited to 6 pcs per glass of drink. The fresh raw oysters they served were brought in from Canada, France and Japan.Fresh Oysters - $2 EachBesides having that, we ordered a plate of 5 slices salmon that falls under the happy hour promotion too. It was great having Sashimi again with Wasabi and Soy Sauce!For bites, seeing Sweet Potato Fries excites me. These thick-cut sweet potato fries were deep fried with Tanuki Raw's spice mix, truffle oil and served with truffle aioli in an aluminium tin.Truffle Sweet Potato Fries - $10.90One of the recommended rolls on the Menu is none other than the Golden Kani Maki with deep fried house seasoned soft shell crab, fresh snow crab, cucumber and crispy mozzarella all in a roll. Divided into portion of 4, these delicious rolls were topped with toasted seaweed and drizzled with generous amount of golden salted duck egg hollandaise sauce.Golden Kani Maki - $18.90Well, we just did not have enough of salmon and here comes the seared salmon roll topped with Mentaiko sauce over some crispy mozzarella cheese, seasoned flakes and Tanuki's Oko Sauce! Yums!Superstar Roll - $12.90It was my first time there and would not be my last. Simply love the environment. Best of all, if you are having gathering with friends who are vegetarians, there are food for them too. Hope to be back soon.

This posh Japanese restaurant sits at the top of Orchard Central, offering a quiet, chill atmosphere for diners.I got the Truffle Yakiniku Premium set, which comes with the donburi (rice bowl), miso soup, salad, and your choice of a drink.Overall, not impressed with the food, especially for its high price point ($22 for the bowl). Although the truffle was a nice touch, I wish the beef was slightly more cooked, at least seared, and cut thinner for the flavour to really come through. The whole time I felt like I was spending more time trying to chew than hold up a conversation. The drink (I had the grapefruit tonic), miso soup and salad were not outstanding either.I can see this place as a great happy hour spot. However, I don't think I would be coming back on my own accord.

We arrived at Tanuki at about 7pm and ordered what we want to eat. We waited for half an hour when we realized why the customers that came later have gotten their food already while we have not. We asked one of the server, and she said the food was coming. Then 5 minutes later she mentioned that the order was not put in. We were shocked and ask what happened but your servers were not apologetic. We asked for the manager and they said that there was not manager according to themWe were utterly disappointed because first of our orders were not put in the system and we have wasted our 30 minutes for nothing!!! Then to make things worst, she lied about food coming in when the order was not even coming. Then third and worst of all, was the servers' attitude. They did not look apologetic and DID NOT say sorry. We ended up walking out of the restaurant. We lost a good 1 hour not getting food and compensated. The servers name were GENA & MEL. We do not know whether they lied about their name.Please do something about this as we would never go back to your restaurant from this bad experience. We will also NOT recommend your restaurant to our circle of friends
3.5 stars. Popular Japanese fusion place. I had the chirashi-don. Food was Ok - you get a filling dish for ~30 with a  decent selection of fish. Truffle fries were excellent.
