Too many loopholes.I was really losing my patience since my friends and I were really tired and almost left for the day, the lady in front of me finally finished her orders! I jumped straight to my orders, when the cashier suddenly stopped me and carried out his SOP of telling me what are the items that ran out of orders. Actually I really can already see from my queue FOR THE PAST 20 MINS and have back up plans for orders that ran out, so I thought his explanation was really unnecessary and probably that explains why each order took so long. I snapped, but the cashier handled "this nasty customer" well. He lost a little patience too, but eventually tried his best to cool me down and returned wrong change.Eventually, I settled for a green tea mille crepe and a banana mille feulle for 4 to share. Both tasted really good, and ended my night on a sweet note. I like the creamy fillings of the green tea mille crepe that is generous yet not greasy, and the chunk of banana in the mille feulle (a little too much cream for this though). It's well balanced on the flavors!We finished, pack and go within 20 mins. It's not worth the wait for these mille crepes, and yes I will return only if there is no queue at all, be it take away or dine in.

Came here on a weekday evening to see what the fuss was about.PROS * didn't have to wait (I've seen some pretty horrific lines)* Spacious and pretty interior* good variety of cakes offered CONS* for the price ($16), I could have had a better cake and coffee* the place seems kind of pretentious. People sneaking glances at others and giving off a general cold vibe.* Mille crepe cake was good, but not amazeballsWouldn't come back unless my arm was twisted to. The chocolate Mille crepe cake is more or less the same as the one served at Awfully Chocolate.

The first time my friends and I wanted to eat here, the queue was too long. The 2nd time, I bought a few slices to take home. Not bad, the cakes were delicious. Finally, last weekend, I had a chance to get the full experience.It was Sunday at 8:30 pm. Got in through the ground floor, up through the staircase, saw a staff member (female) who told us to queue outside. On the way out, another staff (male) saw us and said "thank you for coming". He thought we had already finished eating.  Got to the queue and found no one there, waited patiently. In a short while the male staff came to usher us inside. On the way to our table, we bumped into another group coming up the staircase, looking for a table. While the male staff brought us to our table, the female staff took the other group to another table, without asking them to join the queue (there were a couple of people behind us). The table assigned to us was on the side of the staircase. It was difficult to get on the bench, and on the other side were high bar stools. Not easy for my elderly father, so we immediately requested a different table. I called the female staff 's attention, this was just after she had brought the other group to their table. I asked for another table and told her that the other group had cut the queue. She did not seem to realize that. We ordered a banana crepe and a chocolate ganache. Both took more than 15 minutes to arrive. They tasted ok, though I felt cheated because the banana crepe was mostly cream, with a few banana chunks. The chocolate ganache was rich and tasty, not too sweet.Overall, I think this place is just over hyped. The staff are friendly and helpful but the physical structure, with staircase and 2 entrances, do not help them at all. If I were the manager, I would strictly use the ground floor for exit only, to avoid confusion. The cakes are delicious, but not worth $9 for a slice.

Two floors for this shopfront was pretty amazing. But one of my friends who is also an architect said that they could use some of the spaces to expand their seating areas.Came here at 9.20pm and there were queues for both take away and dine in. Looking at the display cases, there was not much choices left. Decided to get Apple Galette as it is specially baked at the Orchard Central branch for take away. Service was extremely slow. Probably because it is closing time and people are trying to take away or get their bills. Even though it is a big space, there is only one person in charged of the cashier, one person in charged of cutting the cakes. While standing and waiting for my order to be served, besides the lack of staffs they have, I noticed that most of the customers were impatient to get their orders. The waiting time was pretty long - 20-25 minutes even though they just had to put my order in a box without any plastic covers like the ones they put on the cakes. Was pretty disappointed at the service as I experienced a much better service at the Marina Square branch.Besides that, people was not in order especially at the take away section. They had to cut off the queue as it was about to close and they only had a few baked goods choices left when customers suddenly poured in. Since this is the first review of this branch, I will give a starting of 4 stars hoping that there is a change in this store in the upcoming future. I definitely love the modern touch for the interior design but would be better if there are more seatings in the store.
We had the Checkers and Lady M Signature Mille Crêpes. Nice.

It was newly opened in Shanghai and the queue line is always 200 meters long. Happy to enjoy Lady M this afternoon without waiting in Singapore. Signature Mille crepes is the best I've ever had. But coffee is a disaster. Maybe I shouldn't have ordered a coffee with such a girly name "Lady M iced coffee".

My favourite millecrepe place! The savory brunch items were decent too until they were sadly discontinued. Get the original and green tea millecrepes. The rest I've tried (including the special earl grey and chestnut flavours) aren't as strongly flavored or delicious. This location can be quite echo-y though. Not recommended for people who have issues with loud noise.Also, you need to share your millecrepe with a friend. Otherwise, it will be too gelat (i.e. you will be too glutted to enjoy it)!

The design of the place is very nice. You can sit at tables overseeing Orchard road.But the cholocate éclair was a big disappointment: super hard chocolate shell, tasteless filling. The chocolate millecrepe was better. But in my opinion, it's a boring dish. I have eaten far better chocolate than that.

I ordered long black and miles crepes chocolate. The coffee was so-so, but the miles crepes was good. Nothing really special but the ambience was great with full view of Orchard road. The service was nice and friendly.
Mille crepes are awesome but it's sad that their coffee are just normal brewed coffee without any specialty beans.

Not a big fan of crepe cake so went Feuille instead.  Taste is ok but nothing that will have me come back for more. We also had the signature crepe cake as well as the citron crepe cake, again it was just ok.  The ambience is good, service is good too.  But the coffee is terrible - luke warm and tasted worse than Starbucks.  Curiosity really killed the cat this time :)

The cake is one of the best in the world. However the place if you seat near the windows, and look outside, you will see the bottom and the frames of the windows are so dirty.  They should clean them up more often.

What's all the hype about?I've heard people talk about Lady M, but never had a chance to go in New York, so I was excited to see a few locations in Singapore. A friend was visiting Singapore, so we met up over dessert at Lady M. The two of us are San Francisco foodies, and I don't think either of us were impressed.Since it was our first time, we opted for slices of the signature Mille Crêpe cakes; one original and one chocolate. The reaction, "meh." The original was a bit too sweet and the chocolate one isn't firm enough to stand up--it fell apart after the first cut.And they don't have decaffeinated coffee or espresso.

I went to orchard branch 2 times. The environment and the cake was nice. But the staff service was pool.  When I came to the front of shop nobody bring us to inside and entertain us. Hope the service can be improve. I really like the cake and the environment there. But the service was disappointed.

My friends and I shared a Green tea Mille cake, Strawberry Shortcake, and Chocolate Arc-en-Ciel. The green tea flavor was lacking in the mille cake while the chocolate cake was rich in flavor. The strawberry shortcake had a nice balance in sweetness and texture. Probably had better cakes for the price but would recommend it if you haven't tried layered crepe-cakes before for the experience.

Worst service ever. We were so thirsty waiting for our drinks we asked for water. We received luke warm water so we asked for ice. The servers blank expression was perplexing but there response was even worse. They said they do not have ice for the water. I explained I just ordered ice coffee and could they not just take that ice and put it in my water? They said no but advised that I could take the ice "out" of my coffee and put it in my water. Fail!
Loved the green tea layer crepe cake! Wish I got the chocolate limited flavor but instead opted for banana which wasn't too great! Overall great!

This new Lady M outlet looks like a giant space ship that has landed on Orchard Road.  The high ceiling is indeed impressive, but beyond that I hardly seem to recognise the sleek and elegant patisserie that I first visited more than 10 years ago in upper east side.  Seating arrangements are funny and I am a bit blinded by all the spotlights and silver railings.  I guess Lady M has evolved into a different kind of creature in Singapore.  At least their cakes are still consistently good.  I also tried their salad this time - I had the salmon and pumpkin salad while my friend had the grilled chicken salad.  Unfortunately both are just ok, way too much dressing, next time I will just stick to cakes.  The green tea crepe cake was good as usual, that saved my evening.

The signature cake is nice and actually is better than other similar layered cakes. They do the layers even thinner with a subtle caramelized top. The banana cake was so so as I felt it was old. The crust and banana seemed aged. Possibly not a high turn around on that one. The espresso actually has potential. Tasted like it was extracted properly. BUT it came out cold. Cold not even luke warm. I guess do to the pre order process of the place. Oh that. We waited 30 minutes for a seat. The venue is charming but it designed not to hold many seats. End result? Line up for a seat. I still think for 8.50-9 for any cake is a pretty good deal based on the quality. Of course bearing you are willing to wait.

Too pricey for the quality. It wasn't amazing or bad, just average. Had the green tea crepe and the flourless chocolate cake which were both pretty alright, nothing special. Though the ambience of the place is great for having long conversations.

Nevermind its long queue and its lousy service, this is how a lady make us lust over her! nevermind about its breakfast and side dishes...its Green Tea Mille Crêpes is so exquisite!! Not any cake shop/cafes that sell cakes can duplicate that for sure! the texture of the mille crepes burnt a memory into my mind and tongue, i love how this lady torture me by burning me!Any budding chef should start doing intern here to perfect their skills!To cure my craving, i m going to buy a whole cake soon!
The cakes were delicious. The service was not that great. There were many vacant tables and several staff members. The staff members were up top talking and enjoying each others company.
The service is so bad, order took forever to serve our cakes. And it took over 15mins to get  our bill
Great spot for watching the world go by. Crepe layers work well to make a wonderful cake. Can get crowded so go on a mid week afternoon if you can.

I brought my mom to celebrate her birthday in Lady M. Not too much ppl when we arrived. Green tea cake is that much sweet and my mom liked very much. We request a small candle and they help to delight it, which is very sweet.

Came in on a Friday afternoon after lunch for coffee and cake. We ordered the green tea Mille, chocolate ganache, and lemon tart. All were great, would come back just for those. We ordered two hot chocolates and a latte, but when the hot chocolates came, we noted that it was not hot! However, after talking to the waiter, he apologized for it and offered to take it off our bill. Service level here is better than expected, would definitely come back!
10 points for the interesting layout, 9 points for the cake (beautiful mille crepes, but it was a little too creamy with too little actual cake for my liking), none for the service.

This is a very well-designed restaurant located in the Hotel Jen Orchard Gateway. It is not that most hotel restaurants are bad it is simply that many of them are not very good. Surprisingly, this restaurant is an exception. Makan is primarily designed around an ever-changing buffet which is located central to the restaurant. The food is prepared by chefs who are right there doing their job in the thick of things. Meaning, the food is very fresh, well-prepared, and well-managed. What this buffet presents changes quite frequently, so you know you are going to get an interesting choice of foods.Personally, I don't like buffets. But, that just me. For those like me, Makan also offer menu-based options from a very complete menu. There is a lot dishes to choose from. Of course, this restaurant also has the obvious choices of soft drinks, coffee, beer, and wine. Though this is large restaurant, it is also a very popular restaurant. Keep that in mind as there may be a wait.Overall, good place to eat if you are staying at the hotel or simply in the neighborhood.

This restaurant is located on the 10th floor of Hotel Jen. It's primarily a buffet style restaurant, from morning to night, but the buffet was closed at 10pm, and I was able to order from the menu. The picture doesn't do it justice because it is primarily brown in color,  but the food was delicious. My plate included fried rice with shrimp, topped with a fried egg. There were skewers, deep fried chicken drumsticks, a tangy pickled cucumber and carrot side dish, and chips.  It makes my mouth water just thinking about it. There were so many different ingredients in my fried rice, I had a lot to savor in each bite.  I wasn't aware I had to travel all the way to Singapore to consume perfect fried rice.

I won a couple of buffet vouchers for this place on a social media contest and decided to head there on a wednesday evening. I made a reservation online and was greeted politely at the entrance. Makan @ Hotel Jen orchard gateway is located on the 10th floor. It has a slightly scenic view but it doesn't face orchard road. The buffet spread started with salads, sushi, salmon sashimi which was reasonably fresh, not the best but okay for me. There were boiled crabs which hardly had any meat in them, but they were bright red and pretty. Skip the mee goreng and try the laksa fried rice instead. I also tried their roasted duck wanton noodles. The noodle soup wasn't too salty and their noodles were abit too hard for my liking, but the duck was juicy and tasty. The meat section of the buffet, included suckling pig with mantou, grilled lamb, beef, sausages, beef bulgogi, grilled prawns that were huge. They were all mediocre at best. The ice kachang machine was idiot proof and I drown my bowl of ice kachang with lots of gula melaka and atap seeds. I loved it.The dessert table looked impressive but all their cakes were so-so. Their ice cream was slightly better.All in all, for about $50++ per pax, it's reasonable, nothing really stood out for me and I prolly won't be heading back there either.

Came for the 3 course buffet and stayed for the serene and relaxing atmosphere. Was very impressed by the variety of Southeast Asian appetizers which included my personal favorite, gado-gado. The dessert bar appeared tantalizing at first glance, but the tarts were dense and mousse slices a little too sweet. The sautéed seafood (my main course) was mediocre. In conclusion, I would say you're paying more for a place to chill and kill time. Protip: call in advance to inquire about the mains available for that day!

I would say this is a 3.5 stars joint. Makan has the cheapest lunch deals in town (Orchard area) for a hotel. Choose a main for just $9.90 (includes free flow coffee/tea/iced tea) and if you want a fuller meal, you can add $5 for either an appetizer or dessert buffet. It will be additional $10 if you want both. It does get crowded after 12pm when you get the office crowd as it is really good deal. The food is average. The choice of mains (about 4 dishes) changes daily and it includes local and western options. I would say it reminds me of the food in the old Hotel Phoenix which is also where Hotel Jen is occupying now. I like the place with its airy high ceiling and floor to ceiling windows. You get to see greenery all around. The appetizer and dessert buffet selection is small but they will fill you up. I like that everything is in small pieces, perfect for a taste. Ice cream is very local with durian and corn flavors, besides the usual chocolate and strawberry. The coffee is great as it is made with a machine and you can have your choice of latte, cappuccino, etc. Same with the tea (choose your tea bag) and iced tea. I saw peach flavored and lemon and green tea. There is even a pitcher with cinnamon flavored water. Getting there is a bit tricky as there are 2 entrances. Get to level 10 from either inside Orchard Gateway or from the main hotel entrance. The restaurant entrance is actually right outside the elevator which also serves Orchard Gateway. I went in by the other door which was nearer the hotel elevator.

Enjoyed the food! Few of variety but all so yummy!!! Ambiance very apetizing too! Staffs friendly! Great experience overall!Trying their seafood buffet tonight. The crabs are gone!!! They usually have those on regular days. Anyways, still good selection of dishes

The restaurant environment is excellent. Very modern looking. This review is for the buffet brunch.Being a weekday, there was not many customers, even so our plates piled up to around 5 plates high before the waiter removed them.As it was a brunch, there was not many selections. They do have sushi, some cold sea food, roasted pork & duck. you can get freshly made eggs to your liking at The egg station.A good variety of drinks including fruid juices and freshly ground coffee latte and cappuccino.Desserts includes fruits, cakes and 8 different types of ice  cream (for breakfast?).

Had Hi Tea buffet here this afternoon - a good spread of western, chinese & japanese.Makan@jen is situated on level 10 of Hotel Jen Orchardgateway. It is a new brand by Shangri-la. After some hustle & bustle down at orchard road, it was good to have escaped to have some quiet moments.As it is new, it was not crowded so it was nice! We had a lot of attention by the attendants and had a great time chatting with them too. Guests are able to go up to level 19 to enjoy the scenary.Hi-tea price is $30++ per pax. Currently if you pay by OCBC card, it will be 3 pax for the price of 2 Worth a try.

address: 181 Orchard Rd #01-16, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['12:00 PM - 12:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Tue', ['Closed']), ('Wed', ['Closed']), ('Thu', ['12:00 PM - 12:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Fri', ['12:00 PM - 1:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Sat', ['Closed']), ('Sun', ['12:00 PM - 1:00 AM (Next day)'])]
comment: Delicious food, tiny place, middle of the mall but has a cozy vibe to it! Must try - Kaisen Salad, Garlic Edamame

address: 181 Orchard Rd #01-16, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['12:00 PM - 12:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Tue', ['Closed']), ('Wed', ['Closed']), ('Thu', ['12:00 PM - 12:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Fri', ['12:00 PM - 1:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Sat', ['Closed']), ('Sun', ['12:00 PM - 1:00 AM (Next day)'])]
comment: A newly opened Japanese restaurant at the level one of the shopping mall, which took over part of the space formerly occupied by Cold Stone Creamery. For 12noon to 3pm daily, the restaurant only offered lunch sets due to the limited kitchen space. The lunch sets were served with Salad, Japanese Appetiser, Asari miso soup and Ice-cream.Kaisen Chirashi ($20++)10 kinds of chef selection of sashimi on En's Pink Sushi RiceThere was Ikura, Amabi, Hotate, Unagi, Anago, Hamachi, Maguro, Aburi Salmon, Salmon, Tamago Yaki topping the sushi rice. The sushi rice was pinkish in colour, with a slightly savoury taste. It was created with a special mix of Japanese condiments. I would prefer the sushi rice in a more traditional way with a sweeter taste. The texture was not bad, easy on the mouth.The salad was greens lightly dressed with soyu dressing, while the appetiser was salmon flakes in mayonnaise. The soup was flavourful with tofu cubes, wakame, and a clam in it. The meal ended with a scoop of rich creamy black sesame ice cream.Overall the food was not bad. Service was smooth. There was bag basket under the table for one to put bag in.

address: 181 Orchard Rd #01-16, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['12:00 PM - 12:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Tue', ['Closed']), ('Wed', ['Closed']), ('Thu', ['12:00 PM - 12:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Fri', ['12:00 PM - 1:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Sat', ['Closed']), ('Sun', ['12:00 PM - 1:00 AM (Next day)'])]
comment: A gem hidden within consumerism mayhem of Orchard Central. En Sakaba was such a pleasant discovery for us during a frustrating shopping spree. Their food--albeit pricey-par-for-the-course-in-SG--is bang on. Highly recommend the wagyu, chili-garlic edamame, tuna tayaki and everything else on the menu. Nothing disappointed, and this can possibly be a top five value-to-experience Japanese restaurant in SG. Just wish it wasn't in a shopping mall...

address: 181 Orchard Rd #01-16, Orchard Central Singapore 238896 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['12:00 PM - 12:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Tue', ['Closed']), ('Wed', ['Closed']), ('Thu', ['12:00 PM - 12:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Fri', ['12:00 PM - 1:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Sat', ['Closed']), ('Sun', ['12:00 PM - 1:00 AM (Next day)'])]
comment: Simply delicious. Servers are the bests to attentive, kind efficient and knowledgeable. My favorite in Singapore

address: 391 Orchard Rd #B1-56 Takashimaya S C Ngee Ann City Singapore 238872 Singapore
comment: Walked by this place by chance and saw this new restaurant at Ngee Ann City. At first thought the name was d'gold cafe, but I'm closer inspection the 'l'  is actually a coffee bean. The place wasn't too crowded, about 60% filled. But noticed a celebrity seated near the bar with his family. On display are many mugs signed with well wishes from other celebrities, so maybe I the cafe is owned by a celebrity?Was given 2 menus by the waiter. 1 is a food menu and the other a drinks menu. This is quite common, but the drinks menu is like 5 times thicker than the food menu. Haa... Although I always order the same old ice tea or ice latte, I decided to check out the drinks menu anyway. The selection of teas is really... Wah...  Also don't know how to describe. You come once a week for the rest of the year, and you probably would not have tried all the teas yet. Anyway, the boring person that I am, I tried the old English iced tea,and it was pretty delicious. Definitely not BOH or lipton brand..  Back to food, I ordered the pork cheek whilst my wife ordered the Crispy salmon. Both were fantastic. Portion abit small but it leaves just enough room in your stomach for dessert. Which is probably the goal because when a pair of girls came and sat beside us, they were already chittering away about the cheesecake. One of them sat down, looked at the cake display and exclaimed "what? Only 2 cakes left? That's it, Im not going to order a main, I'm just eating cake.". She meant it too. They didn't order anything else, just the last 2 slices of cheesecake. I can't say much for the cake, I didn't get to try it. But from where I was sitting it looked pretty good. Nothing fancy about it. Just a classic, tall, moist cheesecake. All in all, full marks from every aspect. The service staff are friendly, prompt and attentive. They don't charge for water. Food is good and served in a timely manner and at the same time. Comfortable and stylish ambience. And perhaps some chance to score a look at some celebrities. To summarise, pretentious food without the hefty price tag.

address: 391 Orchard Rd #B1-56 Takashimaya S C Ngee Ann City Singapore 238872 Singapore
comment: I stumbled here while shopping in Takashimaya and decided to get some coffee.D'Good Cafe knows its coffee, they have real good coffee. Cold brews, nitros, filtered coffee... they've got it all. They also have cakes and hot food too.I had a cappuccino. which was skillfully made- you know the sort that has the leafy pattern on top. I gotta say the cappuccino here is way better than Starbucks. It also comes with a tiny biscotti. The cup that it was served in was rather interesting - there was no handle!!The decor is also very cute- there were British tube signs but the names were replaced with towns in Singapore.When you go to the cashier to pay the check, make sure you look at some of the cute teapots and stuff that they sell!

address: 391 Orchard Rd #B1-56 Takashimaya S C Ngee Ann City Singapore 238872 Singapore
comment: The cafe was opened in Sept by local actor Chew Chor Meng and his wife Deon Tan. It was the second outlet after the first one in Holland Village. The 65-seat café houses a London Tube and an English Garden. A red British postbox is placed outside the new branch for customers who are upset to pen down their feelings. We were showed a table at English Garden area as little JJ was struck with the swing at one of the tables. He was so in love with the swing that he wanted one at home.Spiral Galaxy ($15++)Green tea and grape juice with a spiralling visual treat.The tea change to purplish colour when mixed with the juice. The golden dust gave the drink a shimmering colour. It tasted light and refreshing.Coconut Infused Cold Brew ($9.50++)A multi-sensory experience with coconut-infused coffee.The drink was presented with lots of smoke from the dry ice. The coffee, smelt of roasted coconut, tasted not bad with hints of the coconut aftertaste.Hot Chocolate Surprise ($7.50++)A chocolate sphere, served with hot chocolate. When the hot drink was poured over the sphere, it revealed a marshmallow in it.D'Lobster Roll ($22++)Prepared from live Boston lobster. 100grams of claw and tail flesh, tarragon mayonnaise and chips.The roll was great although I wish for more sauce.LING Cod Fish and Chips ($22++)Cod fish, straight cut fish, tartar sauce and malt vinegarAlthough it sounded quite expensive, the fish was quite meaty and juicy.Pomegranate Citrus Smoked Duck ($13++)Smoked duck, pomegranate, mandarin orange, pear, greens, caramelized walnuts and citrus sauce.The pancake served here was not the usual type but Deutsch Skillet Pancake. It had a eggy texture which tasted more like Nian Gao 年糕.Overall the food was delicious. There was 10% discount for senior citizens. The staff were knowledgeable and spot on for their recommendations.

address: 391 Orchard Rd #B1-56 Takashimaya S C Ngee Ann City Singapore 238872 Singapore
comment: Brunch / lunch place with several outlets in Singapore. Tried their salmon and pancake in a skillet. The salmon is standard - decent quality salmon steak / nothing particularly special though. The pancake in skillet is good as expected - hot cake in hot pan come on. Taste was alright, have had better skillet pancakes elsewhere thoughRestaurant feels a bit cramped

address: 391 Orchard Rd #B1-56 Takashimaya S C Ngee Ann City Singapore 238872 Singapore
comment: Such a cute place and away from the busy crowds. Lots of food options for any mood. I tried the pork cheek and it was so savory and delicious. Also great for tea and coffee. We ended the meal with white chocolate raspberry ice cream- superb!

address: 8 Grange Road #02-11 Cathay Cineleisure Singapore 239695 Singapore
comment: Supposed to be a 2 stars review but.. there was something that was worth adding another star.Came here with a group of friends during lunch hour on a Saturday. It was pretty empty. Even though I tried to avoid dining here, my friends on the other hand decided to try the foods out as the items on the menu looked appetizing.The server came over and sat us at a semi-circle seating area. He then let us take our time to decide on what we wanted and even explained to us the difference between condensed milk and evaporated milk as one of my friend hadn't tried hong kong style milk tea prior to coming here. It was pretty quick decision for me as I decided to give their baked rice with cheese and mushroom a try. For drink, I ordered ice lemon tea (homemade) and requested for less ice.Drinks came pretty quickly and the food was served within 5 minutes (pretty efficient). Took a bite of my cheesy baked rice and my brain suddenly stopped for awhile as the tongue gave a signal that the dish was way too salty. When the waiter walked over to hand over my friend's dish, I asked him whether it is supposed to be overly salty. He took my dish away and probably asked the chef to try and yup.. I was right.. While waiting, he gave me a bowl of homemade soya bean curd. (+1 star here) - pretty smooth, not too sweet and big portion. I even let my friends tried and they gave me the same feedback.The second baked rice arrived. And this time round it was still salty but tolerable. The rice unfortunately wasn't cooked properly as some side of the dish has rice which are softer than the others. And I realized that beneath the top layer of cheese, they placed uneven tomato sauce which might be another reason of why it was too salty. I probably ate only half of the dish.For dessert, my friend ordered a tower of mango shaved ice with mango ice cream, some mango syrup and bits of mangoes. The middle part of the ice was hollow and after a few bites, we realized that it had more ice than other things so we probably only touch a quarter of it.Price wise it was pretty costly.. Spent approximately $25 for the three items (shared the dessert cost). If you joined their $15 per year membership, you can get some freebies (free dish, free milk tea) - which my friends did and that covered some of the costs.Besides the good customer service and the soya bean curd, there isn't much to crave for.

address: 8 Grange Road #02-11 Cathay Cineleisure Singapore 239695 Singapore
comment: There are a number of Hong Kong Cafes in Singapore and Xin Wang Cafe is one of the more popular ones. Even though at times I feel that it's not really worth the money for I can also dish up something similar with my instant noodles.On the other hand, the curry and dim sum at Xin Wang are rather decent and worthy of your money. A good thing about this cafe is its opening hours. It opens till late at night and many people visit the cafe for desserts or late dinner after a movie or so.I like their milk tea with grass jelly and the yuan yang (coffee and tea) drinks. I've heard that the papaya soup is bad, but do try the thick bread toasts.

address: 8 Grange Road #02-11 Cathay Cineleisure Singapore 239695 Singapore
comment: Avoid the XW signature fried rice.   The Flavours found in this dish are confusing at best with the aroma it gives off

address: 8 Grange Road #02-11 Cathay Cineleisure Singapore 239695 Singapore
comment: This one is notable because it's one of the few eateries that's still open after a late night movie at Cineleisure. Food-wise it's so-so, nothing spectacular and you're definitely not here looking for gourmet food - it's good for people who get instant noodle cravings and don't mind shelling out money for other people to cook it for them. I usually decide on the cheese baked dishes which look a lot more like TV dinners than anything else. Decent HK milk tea though, at least they got that covered.It's hard to tell but it's surprisingly large inside. So-so grub all around, good location and situation.

As it crazy as this sounds, I first heard about Tony Roma's when I was a young boy living in Singapore in the early 90s. After moving to the US in 1996, I did not see another Tony Romas for the next 14 years! The closest I ever got to a Tony Romas in my home state of Connecticut was a pre-packaged Tony Romas ribs at my local Costco. These pre-packaged ribs were great... but I still longed for those freshly cooked ribs straight from the restaurant kitchen. Fast forward some 15 years, the restaurant venue has changed from the original Orchard location to now, Orchard Central, but more importantly those Original Baby Back Ribs still taste as good as when I was young boy. The meat just falls off the bone and the original barbecue sauce is just quintessential Tony Romas.., as good as they come. DON'T EVEN BOTHER with the other Rib offerings: St. Louis, Carolina Honey's, etc. Simply put, they just suck! I've some of the best Ribs that my good old US of A has to offer. Rudy's in Texas, The very best of Carolina Dry Rub (my alma mater is Duke University, so I would know a thing or two). I'm not saying that Tony Romas is the best Ribs I've ever tried, but if you are a starved American like me craving for Ribs in the little island of Singapore, you can no better than Tony Romas. Best of all, I can fulfill my Asian cravings by ordering two sides of Rice. You can't say you can do that at every barbecue join back home! :DTo Conclude: ORIGINAL BABY BACK RIBS is all you need to know. Period!

We had our sales lunch treated by boss. Yay!! this is the first time i'm invited to the lunch. Tony Roma!!,Yep Its you...... i heard a bout his place for a very very long time and have yet to try it.  Finally, i get to try you this time round with the expense of my boss (treat).We order the Tony Sampler oh gosh you need to order this cause i fall in love with the spinach artichoke dip its really really nice ..... Oh the ribs .... i order the original baby back ribs its really soft and tender. Seriously, this is my first time didn't really expect it to be this good. The location is not very fantastic as it doesn't appeal to the mass crowd as its not somewhere near the shopping area.

The husband was craving ribs, so he decided to take me to the Tony Roma's location he used to go to as a kid way back in the '90s. Believe it or not, I've never been to a Tony Roma's before in the US, but I used to buy their original BBQ ribs at Costco all the time. I was excited to finally check out a physical Tony Roma's location!Walking in, it felt really familiar and American, although slightly dated. The prices for lunch were a bit steep for me (over $20 for a meal), but when the hubby has a craving, we have to go for it.Since I am very familiar with their original recipe, I wanted to be adventurous and try something different. I opted for the ribs with the bourbon sauce. However, I was informed that they ran out of the bourbon, so I ended up getting the sweet version (I believe it's the "Carolina Honeys".)They have a lot of sides to choose from, so I settled for corn on the cob and coleslaw, which were well portioned. As for the ribs, I liked how they fell off the bone, but they weren't as meaty as the ones back home. Also, the sauce wasn't that great. It was sweet, as advertised, but it was lacking some flavor. It was reminiscent of the "blah" sweet and sour chicken you get at a crappy Chinese buffet.  I think it would've been better if it could've been more smoky. Lesson learned- just stick with the original! Bottom line, I wouldn't jump at the chance of coming back since I find it overpriced, and I have a feeling there are other places in Singapore that serve better ribs (word on the street is that Smokey's meets this challenge!) so onwards to the next BBQ joint!

Tony Roma's is a great western family restaurant, famous for its ribs. With every visit, we always make it a point to order the baby back ribs. The portion is satisfactory, whereby half -rib is usually sufficient for two to share. Each serving also has a sizeable amount of meat that is so extremely  tender. Crispy on the outside drizzled with honey sauce and juicy on the inside, just using your fork is enough to pry the meat away from each bone.Before the main course is served, each table is served a bread basket with their own unique butter mixed with various herbs and spices. Spread on thick fluffy slices of baguette, this is absolutely heavenly. Unfortunately the branches are not exactly consistent on this; the bread was actually stale on two occasions. When we feel like indulging ourselves, the giant cookie with ice cream dessert is ordered. Served in a pan, the cookie is warm and chewy with a scoop of vanilla ice cream melting on it. Together with chocolate sauce drizzled all over, this is a sinful dessert that is perfect to end the meal with.One minus point would be the location of the branch at Orchard Hotel. The place is somewhat inaccessible even when you drive. The branch is situated such that it is outside of the hotel, but the only way you can get to it is to walk through and around the hotel. Pretty unusual for a family restaurant. The location also means that it's the kind of restaurant that is only popular among the regulars. Definitely not the kind that you would go "let's try this!" when walking around, because its simply quite isolated from popular shopping areas. The branch at Suntec City is slightly better, but also difficult to navigate at the basement area of the huge complex. But once you've tried it, there's a high chance that you'll become a regular just like me.

Mmmm RIBS !!! Yes I have to admit sometimes I enjoy getting down & dirty at the Tony Roma's of my choice. Though this is merely reflecting the mess you make when enjoying these wonderful BBQ Bourbon Ribs it's always joy to go back to Tony's.Now: This location is not really ideal except you are on a shopping spree at ION and don't mind walking a little. I would not call it a back alley but parking etc can be a PITA there so better take a cab!It doesn't seem to be a very touristy spot, probably due to the location. Sometimes you even have to Q up because it gets pretty busy esp on Fri/Sat night.Make sure you order the baked & loaded potato with your ribs! And i can't stress this enough : This is a place that I would recommend for ribs only. Often people come with us who might not like ribs and will order chicken or a steak that end up to be disappointing. If you or one of your companions don't like ribs I suggest don't go to a place that has 'ribs' already in it's name (duh).The second location at Suntec is a bit nicer but also pretty busy. I like them both though.Nom Nom-s
Great ribs...other dishes are so so...service ok. Industrial quality bread...nice barbeque sauce...desserts not really great

I have been walking pass Angus House umpteenth times but never has the chance to step in until just this year. It was a celebration meal for a birthday and finally we had the chance to explore Angus House. Angus House is quite easy to locate as she is on the 4th Level of Takashimaya, next to the Toys / Children Department .I quite like this open concept kitchen part of the restaurant whereby we were able to take a click preview of the chef busying in the kitchen.Internally is well lited, under the spacious and romantic lights, environment makes it cozy and relaxing. With attentive servers around, I would say that their service is prompt and smiley.It is perfect place for a first date. Also, it is recommended to make reservation and secure a seat.We were there for steak but to make it a meal with appetizer, soup, salad, bread and dessert, we topped up $15 each and find it quite worthy.Appetizer was a big piece of salmon with flaky bread stick and sweet sauce.Reminds of my Mos Burger Style of Salad and immediately I know they are common as its Japanese! Greens was crunchy with cherry tomato, Japanese cucumber, corn kernels, cabbages and dressed with roasted sesame sauce.We had the escargot as our sides. Well baked with herbs and butter, served sizzling hot. I'm not really a fan of these shells but I think the style of preparation were rather fragrant. Escargot - $18You can still hear the sizzling and bubbling effect of butter together with escargot when they serve to the table.Close up of EscargotEnvironment was quite cold and just right with a warm bowl of calm chowder.Calm ChowderIngredients in Calm ChowderThis is not the usual Western Style Steak I had. In case you are not aware, Angus House is mainly serving Japanese Style Beef Steak as well as pasta and the type of serving may not be what you have on mind if you are thinking along Morton's Style.The 200g Sirloin Steak comes in a sizzling hot plate direct from the kitchen in Medium-Well doneness as requested. A piece of savoury herb butter and slice of lemon was placed on the steak, as the heat rises, the butter melts accordingly. Steak was definitely soft and texture was friendly with the knife.Sirloin Steak 200g - $60While the man had a bigger portion of 300g Steak from the Rib Eye at Medium doneness. Similarly, the steak was juicy and tender just like I had my Sirloin.Rib Eye Steak 300g - $78Desserts have option of Cheese Cake or Tiramisu. Since we are having 2 sets, we opted for both and ended our dinner with sweet endings. Cheese cake came with a very moist biscuit base and was light in taste, not too cloying. I love the Cereal and the dash of raspberry sauce and cream by the side.dCheese CakeTiramisu was light and tasty coupled with honey melon, dragonfruit, mint leaf and strawberry. It was real good and in fact I dont mind having another piece if they do offer.TiramisuAt least I can strike off the To Visit / To Eat from my list after visiting Angus House. The quality of food and service are commendable. I won't hesitate to recommend my friends here if they want to try Japanese Style Beef.

We each ordered a set that came with a starter, bun, main and dessert. On weekdays there is free tea/coffee but not on weekends.Starter: Threadfin fish on a bed of mashed potatoSalad - nice too.Best bun! Soft and warm.Cream of mushroom soup - good, not heavy.Sirloin steak - good, just as I had ordered. Far better than the one at Wooloomooloo.Corn on the cob - Super lousy, tasteless & hard.Guava mousse cake - never had this before but it's nice. Their most popular dessert is tiramisu. The other choice was ice cream.Overall a very good meal.Reasonably priced for the quality.

My family has been coming here for years. Angus House serves Japanese style steaks and pastas. We always get the set since it's a great deal (you'd get an appetizer, soup, salad, dessert to go with your mains), and make a special request for the corn soup and extra sauce for the steaks. If you like Japanese style pastas, you should also check them out. Their sea- urchin and scallop spaghetti makes for great comfort food.

The Food: We got the set for all of these mains (below). The set includes a salad, prawn spring roll & breaded prawns starters (the prawn spring roll came out a little cold though) , soup (lobster chowder - love it!) for an additional $10. 1. Spaghetti salmon row & abalone set $33- A fusion of east & west! The salmon row and abalone was topped off with seaweed strips :) - Overall ok. 2. Chicken grill $38- Loved it! The chicken was so tender and succulent! They grill it and serve it on a hotplate. - A generous portion was given too. 3. Tenderloin steak (medium well) $57- The beef was not over cooked, definitely juicy which was good. I had mine medium well so I was happy they didn't over cook it like most places. - Portion wise it was small. Service: Good. Very efficient (even on a friday night). Ambiance: A colonial yet modern & clean cut setting (very korean drama serial). The servers had to wear a french-maid like outfit (not the sexy kind, mind you) but it was still a bit strange to see the restaurant have its staff wear such uniforms. I can't imagine the servers like it much? I guess it contributes to the overall theme of the restaurant? Though I would stil eat there even without the french-maid uniforms being worn. It's definitely about the food & service. Tip: this place serves THE BEST BREAD! It's freshly baked and each person gets one. The bread is fashioned like a cube with a little top cap. When you pull it off, you can see the steam escaping from within - that's how fresh it is! :) delicious.
This is one of my favorite steak house in singapore. Consistent quality of food and consistent nice service. Good for family and business. Great location.

Steak was ... Good. Sides were quite flavourless (I had the greens site fried with garlic). Service was ... accurate.On the whole, the experience was .... adequate. But for the price, I was expecting something significantly more.

If your from the US, this is not going to be what you expect from the name. Yeah, they have steaks. But they are small and very expensive. And to be honest, not that good. I've been waiting for three weeks to get home so I can cook my own steak on the grill.

Love the Rib-Eye steak set - comes with an appetizer, soup, dinner roll, salad, dessert, in addition to the steak!You can choose whether you want a plain dinner roll or a garlic bread.The juicy steak comes sizzling in a hot plate with the right amount of sauce. We went there a few weeks ago, and the service was top notch, and there were 16 of us!

The ribeye steak was perfect (appx $55SG). The bottle of wine was average. Service staff was polite but not memorable. Seating was okay. View was pretty nice. Love the dinner set. Salad and mushroom soup was also done well (though nothing too special). Overall, worth it =)

Changed a lot for the worse. The last place I'd expect for a very unprofessional way of handling wrongly cooked steak. Instead of grilling a new one, they recooked the steak and overcooked it from a medium rare to a well done, drying up the steak. Was a terrible experience.

Jap style steaks with miso sauce.Tip: Order your steaks with meat temperature lower than you usually do. a medium rare order usually turn out "medium" due to the hotplace that continues to cook the steak.

Kids wanted steaks after a weekend walkabout around Orchard, so decided to head over to Angus. First time for me although have heard alot of this place. Tug away at a quiet corner of Orchard, its a good place to wind down with family. Went for the rib-eye; overall was OK. Meat was done well to my liking i.e. medium rare; and servings were generous. Enjoyed the dinner because of the quiet dining which is a rarity in Singapore these days.

There are quite a few Japanese hotpot places in the red dot, but this is the one I keep returning to. Shabu Sai reminds me of the AYCE hotpot buffets in Japan, although you can never beat the quality you get in Japan but the concept and look-and-feel is the same. They offer you free flow meat (my fave is the beef), served at your table plus quite a few veggie options to satisfy your hunger. Also, there a few options on sushi and other bites, but I typically stay away from them as I want the AYCE meat + veggies is to have a satisfying meal.The broth options are plenty, I always go for the sukiyaki, which is my favorite plus another one, I already tried several but I always find sukiyaki the most tasty in combination with the beef.As a person who likes to drink a lot, I am also happy that they have a soda fountain so you don't need to worry about flagging down the staff when your glass is empty. Although I must agree that there are some other places which offer a better quality, but at this price point this is as good as it gets in my opinion.

The spread is decent for $20 (all in without the free flow soda and ice cream) during lunch time. You get 70 minutes to dine and they will come round with a slip of paper indicating what time you need to end your meal about 30 minutes before that. You get lots of vegetables and a few types of mushrooms and some processed food on the buffet counter. There are also 6 types of sushi (rice is hard and quality is not that great) and 3 types of noodles (glass, ramen and udon) plus rice for your carbs. For the meat, you just tell the server what you wish to have (regular beef, pork and chicken). The quality of the beef was not as good as Shi Li Fang and the cut had plenty of gristle. The pork was totally frozen hard, even after 70 minutes it was still very tough so we left it. The chicken was a surprise. It was sliced thinly which made it quite tasty. The soup we had was good. We chose sukiyaki and yuzu collagen. The sauces and condiments were plenty so have fun concocting your preference. I would say it is a decent hot pot place Japanese style with a wide variety of food but do not expect much for the meat.

The 3* purely goes to the quality and food choices available; plus they have sushi on the side if the steamboat buffet isn't enough to satisfy your hunger.I was contemplating giving this place 2* initially because one particular waitress/cashier kept reminding us about the time limit. We were under the impression that we had 90 mins for the lunch buffet and the guy who seated us didn't mention it either. Halfway through our meal, the cashier came to us and said "please remember you have to leave at 12.40pm" - which was in another 10 mins. To be honest, we were not big eaters and we ate slowly so as to avoid indigestion (is true!). The fact that we were reminded of the time, kinda stressed us out - I mean who likes to be rushed when eating steamboat right? We still had some 10 mins left and my friend decided to take 3 pcs of sushi just to try. The same cashier, upon seeing my friend heading to the sushi bar, was miffed that we were not packing up to leave soon. She came by to our table again and pointed to the time, "you don't have much time left". I mean seriously? I asked if we can at least finish the food that we had in the pot since there is surcharge for food wastage. She simple shrugged and said the system will charge. To which I said, "charge what?". "The system will impose a charge." How vague and nonsensical is that? Moreover, it's not as if there was a line of people waiting to come in, the place was not even half full! We lost all our appetite then and the cashier kept walking past our table with a watchful eye. Actually, this was my first time to Shabu Sai, and I doubt I will ever return.P.s. Not for those who like to eat slowly and enjoy their food.

The selling point of this place has to be the communal feeling, buffet spread of ingredients, and the price. I came with two colleagues for lunch on a weekday, and the place was barely filled. Lunch apparently has a time limit, but nobody checks, and waitstaff are friendly and approachable. The meats are fresh (don't bother with the chicken), just go for the pork and beef. I love the spread of vegetables and accompaniments displayed very nicely in their refrigerated "boxes", as well as the fact that you can make your own dipping sauce just like most Chinese hotpot places. We had the kimchi and chicken broths, and let's just say the kimchi broth wasn't awesome - stick to chicken! For three people at lunch, it was about $20 per person. We had a massive food coma from this. Plus: They accept Amex cards.Minus: At the dipping sauce corner, the cilantro/coriander jar, has very very old (think 10 days) coriander at the bottom of it. I think they should wash it, but otherwise, no other issues with this place.

Visited this new established branch with my colleague yesterday evening for dinner. Overall, I was impressed.I've visited a couple of Shabu Shabu / Steamboat restaurants, and Shabu Sai is of good value.The Queue:When we arrived (around 6:30), there was no queue to get into the restaurant. We were seated immediately and chose our soup base(s).The Food:We went with the Sukiyaki Broth and the Chicken Broth, and chose all three types of meat (beef, chicken, pork). The meat is brought to your table in small trays - thinly sliced and well presented. I was impressed with the cut and quality of the meat - nice and red with marbling and slight fat.The buffet selection (where you go up to get items) primarily consisted of noodles (ramen, soba, udon), vegetables (gailan, radish, lettuce, etc.) and fish items (i.e., fish ball, fish paste, crab meat). They also had a decent selection of sushi available too. All items were put under fridge/freezing temperature cooling to obviously keep the food fresh. The broth ended up being quite salty - so when getting our bowl topped up, we asked that they fill it with water, rather than additional broth - to dilute the saltiness.Overall, the service was OK - they were definitely understaffed (there was also a long Q waiting for tables by 8:30) and several items, such as the sauce station and the soft-serve ice cream machines (yes, you read that right) were perpetually empty. It took a good 5-10 minutes for them to get around to refilling it.I'd return - and I would hope that they have gotten the logistics sorted by then. I think more staff coverage and attending to tables (i.e., clearing empty plates, refilling water/stock, and maintaining upkeep of the buffet items) is something to work on.

Shabu-Sai (vegetables in Japanese!) belongs to the same group that runs Chiso Zanmai, Hifumi, Hamonaya Robata & Maccha House. The restaurant is famous for the all-you-can-eat Shabu Shabu featuring Sliced Beef, Pork & Chicken and a total of 7 different soup bases at any one time. The outlet at Orchard Central also has a limited selection of cooked food which includes Mini Salmon and Ikura Dons and Unagi Dons.With prices starting from $16.90++ for a weekday lunch (add $2++ for free-flow drinks and soft serve) and quality ingredients available, Shabu-Sai does serve up unbeatable value. I've tried 2 different Bi-monthly special soup bases: Asari Clams & Yuzu Collagen and they were both considerably better than many of the staples. Among the other 6, I also like the Sukiyaki, though many have found it too salty. Shabu-Sai has cleverly remedied this by providing a jug of water on each table for diners to dilute the soup bases to a suitable taste themselves.What makes this place especially worthwhile is the meats which are thinly-sliced and with quality that rivals most mid-end Japanese Shabu Restaurants (and they come free-flow!).There are of course also steamboat staples such as Shimeiji and Enoki Mushrooms, Squid and Prawns as well as different types of Noodles.For photos and the full review visit voraciousappetite.wordpr…

Kept walking past the Shijuku Station outlet while I was in Tokyo but failed to try. Only when I came back then I realized that this was the same outlet I saw in Tokyo. Anyway, I tried the butter chicken curry set and felt it was so-so. The butter chicken could do better, what with the meager portion of chicken. The second and third time I dined here, I ordered the 2 soup sets. Favourite soups thus far is the Chicken Soup and the Beef Goulash. Both times I ordered the brown rice which felt very dry, grainy and reminiscent of the time I long for loose, dry rice when I was sick. The brown rice might be a delight to some and a pain to some. Choose your poison wisely.Noticed I gave it four stars? That's because I simply love the portion of soup they dole out - just nice for a lady on diet!

Another newly opened joint and apparently a very popular chain of restaurants in Tokyo. We had the Tokyo Beef Bosch, Chicken with 8 vegetable soup, Pork and tomato stroganoff and Hokkaido crab bisque.The soups itself were very tasty but could have been so much better with a bit more ingredients. Beef in the Bosch was nice and tender and so was the chicken. The Hokkaido Crab bisque was thick and creamy but lacked a certain oomph about it white the Pork Stroganoff lacked ingredients, with a few more chunks of pork. Not too expensive @ $12.90 for 2 small soups and rice. With a bit more ingredients, they could really give the likes of Soup Spoon a run for their money.

I like this place for its cosy vibe, tucked away somewhere in town. This place only seats 8, and I booked my reservation of two for dinner a month in advance on their Facebook page.Food here is lovingly (and busily) crafted by one man, Javier. You get to watch him do his thing as the kitchen and dining area are one. It is really quite admirable for someone his age to strike out on his own and do a one-man-show which clearly isn't easy and requires a lot of him. The food is a fusion of Japanese and French (I think), and incorporates lots of good produce (Japanese scallops, sea urchin, beef, etc) and well-showcased in his cooking.Make sure you bring cash as they don't do digital payments! Would return!

i don't blame you if you have never heard of this place, i never did.not until my sg yelp partner in crime(natalie) decided to treat me to an early birthday dinner here! thanks so much, brutally honest gal!:)i also don't blame you if you do not hang around orchard plaza.it is rather seedy and if you were ever seen loitering around here, gossips will fly, for sure!well, i can see myself back at this hole in the wall/ one man show.just remember to bring the whole village, max 8 pax, and show them a good, gourmet kind of, time here!affordable, tasty and feels like you are eating in someone's kitchen at their home.not great in terms of ambience but i think if you come with that in mind you will enjoy the chatty cosiness.simple dishes, well executed and cooked to order, served immediately, omakase style.he will gladly take dietary preferences and restrictions into account and come up with viable alternatives for you.no birthday cake for me at the end but sliced japanese momo with a candle and a song!it was indeed a memorable first for me and rightfully deserves it's first review on yelp.

Came with a Friend.Not with high hopes but then one never knows until one tries.California maki roll Chewy udon (hot)Ebi (prawn) tempuraRazor clamsChicken wings grilledUna don - eel with rice.Overall, an okay meal but I wouldn't make an effort to come here for a meal.

This review is based strictly on their lunch sets. My husband and I went to Cuppage for Saturday lunch, but found out the hard way that most of the Japanese restaurants are closed during that time. Shinjuku was one of the few F&B establishments operating, and considering we've seen queues for them for dinner, on top of our grumbling tummies, we decided to give them a try for lunch.The good news is that they have a lot of affordable lunch sets to choose from... I'd say at least 10-15 different meals. I went with their #1, which was tempura and sashimi, while Miguel went a la carte and tried their Chirashi.The bad news is that they specialise in yakitori/fried foods, and you can definitely tell from their non-fried foods. The tempura was delicious, but my sashimi was nothing to write home about. It didn't make me sick, but it wasn't the best ever. My husband didn't enjoy his chirashi at all, mainly because it was drenched in some weird sauce. It was so hard for him to eat it, so much that his pain tugged at my heart strings to the point where I let him share some of my lunch set.*Your takeaway from this is that if you choose the lunch sets, try something fried; if you go a la carte, choose something fried! Should be easy to remember, right? :)--*If I don't receive my Wife of the Year award for this outstanding act of kindness, someone's gonna get a hurt reeeeeal bad!
This is one of my favorite Korean resto's in S'pore. Food quality is good and consistent. Try the kimchi pork belly dish, yummy.

Late lunch.. found this place inside the Scott Plaza. Surprisingly, it's almost full house at 3pm+. Ordered a cold brew single origin. It was actually quite good, even slightly better than Starbucks and far better than TCC. And the price is reasonable $5.50. I ordered the all day breakfast, Scandinavian. Salmon wrapped with asparagus, on top of deep fried thin hash brown (I hope I got it right), drizzled with hollandaise dressing. Sadly, I didn't like it. Not at all. Especially I didn't know what to do with the tomatoes. The deep fried "nest" made of hash brown was very tough and oily, I was slightly worry about it flew out of my plate when I cut it with knife. That would be embarrassing. I didn't finish the main, I thus ordered a brownie with vanilla ice cream. Not bad! Good for sharing. Too much for one person. Conclusion, a place good for coffee and dessert.

Who can say no to all day breakfast? Prices here seem a little on the high side but portions are comparatively larger. The food was decent, and I did enjoy my spanish hash, but it didnt wow me. I guess I'm paying more for the ambience, the comfortable seats and the strong AC. Great place for a meetup with friends where food isnt the focus.

Ah, comfort food, comfort place.Wild honey has been a favorite to-go place for brunch in Singapore. But because they're so famous, make sure you have reservation prior or be prepared to wait. There are 2 outlets around Orchard Road vicinity - one at Mandarin Gallery (first outlet) and they accept no reservation, so you'll have to pray hard there is no queue and the second outlet - at Scotts Square has bigger dining area capacity and accepts reservation. My favorite is always their second outlet at Scotts Square as the sitting area is more spread out and the verandah sitting area has the best natural light for you food "pornographers" out there.Their menu has been the same since I visited 2.5 years ago until today. That's pretty unacceptable in Singapore since the dining scene is always fast paced and people always crave for something different from time to time. But it got me thinking, the main reasons that they're maintaining their stellar items in the menu is probably because it still sells like hotcakes? The superstar items like the Tunisian (baked eggs with chorizo in thick tomato sauce) or their perfectly poached eggs benny that we won't get bored eating or the simple-yet-so-delicious French toast that we crave. If one main isn't enough to fill you up (for my case all the time), consider getting "small plates" of chorizo, sautéed mushroom, bacon and the likes. They have a long list of items under this section for you to mix and match to your liking.Looking at the lack of good cafés around Orchard road area, Wild Honey will always be my to go place if I need a good brunch spot knowing that they're always consistent with their quality and portion.
Food is pretty good. Though a bit pricy, the portion is big too. I like the drinks particularly. The milkshake is quite healthy feeling and fast food too

Loved the ambience of the Scotts Square outlet, with an open air patio, located on the 3rd floor. With such an extensive menu, Beck and I couldn't decide so went with our first choices as we could come back again to try the rest. My caramel latte was pretty good

This is a great spot on the 3rd floor of Scott's Square.  They serve breakfast all day. Portions are large and there is plenty for vegetarians.  Prices are reasonable (by Orchard Road standards, anyways), and the staff was attentive when we were there, but this was closer to 2pm on a Monday, so not exactly peak time.I really liked the Santa Fe eggs, though I'm pretty sure they left off the cheddar cheese.  It was tortillas filled with pico de gallo, topped with fried eggs, corn and sour cream.  My boy had the Norwegian, which included perfectly poached eggs with salmon wrapped around them.The coffee was too bitter for my taste, but that seems to be the case with everywhere here.There's free wifi.

I suppose it's my fault for picking this place for dinner (like I've mentioned before I love the ambience). I wanted something savory without eggs, and that was difficult to find. I ended up picking a sandwich with artichoke and cheese. I can't remember what it's called but it was average - 3 stars. The price would put it lower than that though. My friend picked the Portobello Road, again 3 stars. At the end of the day I'm not sure it's quite worth the price!

Best breakfast/brunch restaurant there is!They have all kinds of breakfast: Spanish with chorizo, the classic English breakfast which comprise of bacon eggs and baked beans, Tunisian breakfast, salmon, and so on. The portion is very filling. I went for English breakfast, which was very good. I will definitely go for Spanish next time!

Nice selection of western style breakfast food. I ordered the Santa fe which is two fried eggs sitting on top of two folded tortillas with some pico de gallo and tiny bits of avocado mixed in. (If you are from the south west region of the us or CA you are probably laughing at this type of presentation and mere the idea of eating tortillas with a fork and knife!)My husband ordered the Norwegian which looked very nice too. Ironically, it was served with slices of avocado. (When was the last time you had avocado in Norway?)We also had a raspberry smoothie that was essentially raspberry puree and ice blended together and served in a martini glass. Nice presentation but the flavor was fairly bland.Topped off with hot herbal and black teas served in mini french press pots.I'd go here again, but I'm curious to see other brunch spots as well.

All day breakfast ... This place is amazing, I love it. They have all kinds of breakfasts .. I ordered NY breakfast: it's 2 scramble eggs with small pieces of salmons. With bagel and white chess cream on the side. IT was delicious The place Is quite , with modern look. The the ground and every thing in the restaurant is from wood. It has a little English touch as well. The coffee and sweet was just ok. Highly highly Recommended for breakfast

Definitely on my go to list for weekend brunch. The ambiance here is quite pleasant for weekend gathering and stuff although it is rather noisy (lots of echoes but well it's quite common in dense SG isn't it?). The waiter are welcoming and are not intrusive at all despite the fact the place was crowded, which i really appreciate as I was able to catch up with my friend comfortably without feeling hurried to leave. Onto the main highlight, food. Pricewise, it's rather pricey (bout $30/pax) but portion is quite generous. We ordered the English breakfast and the Boulevard St Michel and it was delicious. I like the fact that jn both of our dishes, they successfully poached the eggs so it has firm whites but runny yolks which I adore. I also liked that they serve our dishes at the same time and are responsive whenever we call them although it was a busy day. Unfortunately, the coffee was a rather let down. We ordered the cold brew coffee but too bad it tasted more like your ordinary cup of joe on ice. I may be a bit of coffee snob but I believe cold brew should be slightly stronger and more aromatic. Nevertheless, my friend, whom is not a coffee drinker, enjoys it. So i guess it depends on your preferences.All in all, i would recommend this place to people who seeks for a good brunch at central location. I would advice you to reserve your seats as it may be hard to get a seat, unless you don't mind sitting at the bar, facing the columns.

This place is pretty unspectacular. I had the Corsican and a friend had the Carribean for dinner.This place hasn't changed its menu for ages. I don't feel there is anything spectacular here. My Corsican was an omelette stuffed with cheese, with some basil and bread on the side. The Carribean waffles were unimpressive, with insufficient mango and banana. I don't think the food here warrants their high prices. Zero innovation, subpar food, high prices. Meh.

Hidden on an upper floor of the Scotts Square shopping centre, Wild Honey is a popular spot for brunch in Singapore. I've been 2x now for breakfast and both times I enjoyed my food and the casual cafe atmosphere. The menu is an eclectic mix of breakfast offerings you'd find in Europe, Australia, and the Americas. This last go I went with the Canadian option which consisted of fluffy pancakes, bacon (the Canadian kind), fruit compote and of course a heavy dousing of syrup.  Healthy, no, but sometimes a bit of a carb heavy decadence is needed to cure jet-lag.Service is prompt/efficient though not especially warm.As a tip, be sure to book ahead or get there early, last time I was there by 845am on a Friday morning and there was already a pre-opening queue!

Food is great depending on what you order, so I can't really generalize and say that everything is good. The food looks great and appetizing though, I saw some plates being served. However, the taste of the food is mediocre. I got Spanish Hash which was a bit too oily. I also got a slice of Apple Crumble, I didn't like it as well. It was too sour for my taste and wasn't warm when I had it. The ambiance though was average. I guess I expected too much because everyone was telling me about how pretty the place is and the food. Although style and taste is relative, you should still give this a shot.

I think this place wins more for the ambience than the food. Everything that we had is just okay. Not good not bad. But the place is beautiful. For the price (average plate is about $25 for a relatively small portion), I think there are much better brunch options out there but maybe in a not as pretty setting.
Food is Alright, quite a big portion and did not have space for desert :(Coffee was not bad
This is a good place to have conversations with friends, and at the same time getting your tastebuds to work!

Downgrading a star. We ventured off our menu go-tos and were very disappointed. We left half of our I Love NY and Mexican burrito dishes on the table. Just wasn't very edible. Stick to the Spanish and the Tunisian.

Visited Wild Honey at Scotts Square. It's actually located right next to the hair salon at Level 3. We had ordered the English breakfast, which I find the portion to be reasonable, not too big a portion but enough for a satisfying breakfast. When we got there, we happily went in and chose our table at the corner of the establishment, but was told by one of the staff that the table was reserved and that we can only sit at the long table in the middle.The seats at the long table was uncomfortable, and the whole place feels gloomy when there's few customers but resembles a fish market when crowded. Although the breakfast was delicious and up to standard, I feel the service could be improved. That said, I will still return to Wild Honey in the near future.

Another great breakfast option in Singapore! I had the Canadian which was 3 perfectly fluffy pancakes, maple syrup, fruit compote and candied bacon. Absolutely delicious and just the right size. My fellow diners (breakfasters?) had the Flinders Street and the Corsican. Both looked excellent and were well received. You definitely need to be book, we were there on a Wednesday at 10:00am and it was pretty full. I also wouldn't recommend it with small children, it's definitely more of an adult breakfast joint!Didn't really enjoy the coffee though but realising that coffee is pretty personal I could make do.

Expensive but worth it. We had an amazing brunch ordering the Portobello Road and the European breakfast. The eggs were poached to perfection and the coffees were perfect. I was actually struggling to finish my meal given it's size. We arrived around 11am on a Sunday and only bar seating was available. This was fine. It is near a hotel so you get many international travellers here having a leisurely breakfast. Fantastic atmosphere and décor. Definitely on the pricey brunch end.

Love the decor of the place. But it would be great if they serve fresh avocadoes instead of old ones. According to the reviews, I expected the perfect poached eggs but it was a shame. Waitress hands over our change from the back over my husband's shoulder; not cool. Personally, I wouldn't come back but for those who would like to just chill out and have good milkshakes, this might be a nice spot to soak in all that posh ambience.

All day breakfast mains here are priced at insanely high prices for the quality. The desserts were way better than the mains. Using the chope voucher, it was worth it, but if you're paying full price for the mains, it's definitely not worth it. Not sure if I will return for the desserts though. Service was really slow too on a Monday.

We wanted a quiet and relaxing place to chill out after dinner and Wild Honey was the perfect place. Their blender was not working when I went there so I couldn't order ice blended drinks but the recommended the Queen Bee iced drink. I had no regrets! We also ordered a Wild Mocha Dulce and it was ok. The Queen Bee trumped all other drinks! :)!Would love to come back and try the food next time!

Delicious. Best breakfast I've had in a loooong time. Great portion sizes. Very popular place, can't linger without a reservation. The European breakfast was amazing. The hubby had the English breakfast and rated it.
This place often stays quiet at meal times when Coffee Academics downstairs is full. Portions are large, but the food is really nothing to write home about.

This place was FANTASTIC!!! We came on Easter Sunday and it was a great atmosphere and it's very reasonable in price. My husband had the European and I had the coconut waffles. Both were excellent. We also ordered sausages and Canadian bacon. Again, simply amazing. We will definitely be back!!

Great for big brunch excursions. Portion sizes are generous and coffee is good quality. Service is a bit slow and the wait staff do tend to forget requests (had to remind them about our pilsner and they brought the bill when we asked for milk). Overall, you're paying for the location and food, which is worth it.

A business cum social meeting was the occassion and Wild Honey was chosen as the venue. I must say from the get-go, its popularity is warranted. Location wise it is the most convenient to get to - minutes away from Orchard MRT station, with bus stops closeby and the Grand Hyatt taxi stand at your disposal next door - it was a breeze getting there.Without the foresight of making a reservation, we were told it would be a half an hour wait at 11.30am on a Sunday, during which we decided to have coffee in the basement below. Their technologically advanced waiting list system was impressive. A few taps on the iPad located at their entrance, I was 7th in line and I received a call on my mobile, informing to choose if I would be there immediately or needed at 10 minute extension. A 'service' I was particularly fond of.Jumpin right in, we were seated outdoors (you can indicate preferences on the iPad), and it being my first time, I took about 5-7 minutes to decide what I wanted whilst we were served water and the orange juice I ordered (Which was fresh, not too sour, good job once again). I decided on the 'Scandinavian', which is grilled salmon fillet on potato rosti, chargrilled asparagus & homemade Hollandaise sauce. It was right on the money,  approximate $25 bucks if I recall correctly. Salmon was grilled to perfection and the rosti was crispy (I am used to it being less crispy, but it clearly said 'crisp rosti' on the menu so I guess it was done right). Do note it takes about 15-20 minutes to prepare, so if you feel like having this, get your order out right as you are seated.  My friend ordered the 'Norwegian' which consisted avocado, grilled asparagus spears, two perfectly poached eggs wrapped with imported Norwegian smoked salmon, homemade Hollandaise & salmon pearls on a whole-wheat brioche. It looked fantastic, and he isn't too expressive about food but just gave me a thumbs up and a sigh of satisfaction when he was done.Definitely coming back here for more. Service was great, a little too crowded for my liking but then again, Singapore is getting that way and perhaps making reservations in advance would save you unnecessary delays. Another great brunch menu checked off my list!
Looking for an American meal while in Singapore, Wild Honey is a must try. The food and service are excellent.
Visited a few times on an extended trip. Coffee is really good and the wait staff is friendly! Try to get a seat on the patio - it's a nice relaxing atmosphere

I believe most people are familiar with the fantastic range of all day breakfasts available at the Wild Honey. But due to the smaller set up in the Mandarin Gallery outlet, seating is limited and it is on a first come first serve on-site queue basis, no reservations allowed.But guess what, at the Scotts Square branch, not only is the restaurant bigger, you can actually make reservations! No need to queue and you are guaranteed a table when you arrive! As this outlet is also larger, you wont have the issue of tables being too close to the next so you have more privacy when dining. Not only that, for those who love the Wild Honey Concept so much, you can actually reserve their terrace for private parties!One thing to note though, due to the mall operating hours, this outlet closes slightly earlier than other regular restaurants not within a mall so do go early to maximise your dining experience.Cant wait to go for my breakfast during dinner time again soon! :)

Located in an upscale mall, bright cheery decor.  Filled with "teenagers and twenty somethings", so noisy. It was an "ok" place to grab a western style lunch. Service was pleasant, albeit slow. Had to hunt down my server more than once. Ordered a 250gm Australian sliced steak platter with a side salad and carrot juice. Very good, but very $$$$. Almost 60SPD! Lots of breakfast/brunch choices served all day.
I ordered a latte.  You would think for $7 they would know not to boil the milk.  Starbucks do better coffee and that's saying something

On a trip with a group of friends all from the US, we specifically sought out Wild Honey while in Singapore. It was completely worth it. A diverse, eclectic breakfast & brunch menu with specialty dishes with US & AsianFlavor. It looks amazing as well. Be prepared to wait though. Next time I'm in Singapore, I will be first in line!
Food was excellent and presentation was of a high quality. Unfortunately, the hostess was being dismissive towards us

Wild Honey has the best Eggs Benedict in Singapore. Two perfectly poached eggs, sauteed mushrooms and prosciutto on toasted homemade brioche and hollandaise sauce. This has to be my favorite dish of all time. I always end up ordering this even though i always say i wanna try something new. Anyway, i think that the Mandarin Gallery branch does it better? Somehow the bread is over toasted and was too crunchy. Pretty dry. :(The Wild Mocha Dolce is my poison. This is intensely sweet but packs in some serious caffeine. I always get super high after drinking this. Friends know not to feed me with too much coffee/tea because i'd be bouncing off the walls. I also love the scones at WH. For tea, i like to have their cranberry scone with a cuppa of hot mocha dolce. This has to be one of the better scones in town. I'd put it in the same category as Foster's (another of my favorite). The exterior is crispy and the middle is dense and moist. I'll gently coat it with a thin layer of butter and sprinkle sea salt flakes on it- my very own version of salted butter (because WH doesn't provide salted ones). Yummy!
