And their fresh compote of berries to go with it. Perfecto.I would be hanging out at the SS branch more often for the following reasons1. Wider desserts selectionAccording to the manager, the kitchen at SS is 3 times bigger than that at MG. Therefore, more space to make pastries! I tried the sour cherry strudel when i was there recently (not fantastic) and they also have more tea cakes and stuff. :) I'll be sure to try more desserts soon.2. More breathing space! I always felt that the MG store was really claustrophobic! In fact, the entire MG feels that way. I feel like i can easily touch the ceiling (ok i exaggerate). Also, because of the small size of the place, i do feel like i can't stay on for too long even though i just wanna chill out with my book sometimes. Scotts is more airy and there's more natural light hence the relaxed ambience. So if you haven't tried WH (quite impossible IMO), do head on down. All day breakfast means that you never have to wake up early! As for me, ADB FTW!

The food here is good, but I don't think it's worth the prices they serve them at. Although the atmosphere and the service was really great. It's a nice "I feel fancy today" kind of a place... But definitely not coming back here anytime soon. Still on the hunt for a regular brunch spot. Mainly breakfast and brunch place that serves brunch cocktails. Decent food and large servings but extremely pricey.

The food was fresh and the portions were good.  If you're not super hungry, you can split an entree to save on the high costs.  My friend and I got two coffees, some bread and split a breakfast entree and it was about 25 SPD each - ouch!  It's a good spot to get a Western breakfast and it's cute inside.  This is definitely a family establishment, but it's a good place to start your day.  Also, they didn't bat an eye when we told them we were splitting an entree, in fact, they split it onto two plates.

Meal ordered: Duck confit hash with eggs and potatoesPros: 1) There was a wait when I arrived on a Saturday morning, and I received a text message when they were ready to seat me. If you don't mind sitting at the bar, you'll be seated quickly. 2) I tried the duck confit hash meal since the chef was testing it out and the waitress recommended it. It was excellent. I hope they put it permanently on their menu. 3) Their customer service was excellent.Cons: 1) It was on the pricey side, but it was an excellent meal so that's not really a con. 2) It might be difficult to get seated right away if you are in a large group. Summary: Whenever I am back in Singapore, I will visit this restaurant again.

I am absolutely smitten with Wild Honey!!!PROS:-Location - quite rare to find nice brunch places in town nowadays -Great service, the waiters were very attentive-A lovely ambience, posh yet cosy (Saw Rebecca Lim dining there!)-Great comfort food! I've had the English Breakfast, Spanish Hash, Norwegian Breakfast, Monte Cubano Sandwich and their brownies, and I LOVE all of them!-Wide choice of foods-There's an iPad at the counter where they have pictures of all their dishes, which is useful when deciding what to order whilst waiting in the queueCONS:-Long queues, all members of your group must be present before they are willing to seat you-Pretty expensive eg. (~22 dollars for sandwiches), but still worth it, I wholeheartedly believe-Certain dishes have quite small portions when compared with others of the same price range on the menu (eg. the Norwegian breakfast is just veggies + two slices of brioche topped with eggs wrapped in salmon, kind of like an eggs benny --- I would rather pay a little more for the HUGE english breakfast)
Great breakfast... no wait at 9:30amCoffee too strong for me!Love the veranda! Not to hot sitting out here.My avocado was perfect

Tried the Spanish Hash for brunch today - pretty good. I love poached eggs and the chorizo in the hash still had a nice snap to the skin. Definitely recommended! The patio seating was very laid back and comfy. I really enjoyed the atmosphere at Wild Honey. Downside: sour bitter tasting expresso, yuck! Bloody Mary was thin and there was no bite to it (had the spiciness but no horse radish). Still searching for the perfect Bloody Mary in Singapore...

My wife and I come from New York. The food at Wild Honey was fantastic. My wife had their Boulevard St. Michel and I had the European. My first choice was Norwegian, but they were "out of it"!  Their Mello Mellon fresh juice was great.  The ambiance is good. The service was satisfactory. They can be a bit more friendly and attentive. After we were seated, no one came along to greet us until I managed to get a waiter's attention.Prices are high - more than it should be. But for the high quality of the food, I don't mind it. I do mind it for unfriendly and unattentive service. For the price they are charging, they should add a smile!
Good eggs Benedict.

brunch as good as the states! lord, let me tell you, me and brunch have a long, intimate history together and our relationship has been a little bit on the rocks since coming to singapore. don't get me wrong, there's brunch places here but a truly good brunch consists of eggs, eggs, meat, carb and eggs and a very good bloody mary. wild honey does not disappoint!tunisian - delicious! a lot of spice, great portion and just love the brioche that comes with it. i would come back for this dish alone.breakfast sandwich - huge! delicious ciabatta placed on top of a mountain of eggs and meat. i got this with a side of pork sausage, all good. the teas here are great too and the decor is beautiful. officially my new go-to brunch joint.

Sad to say, Wild Honey was an over-hyped and over rated restaurant for me. A couple of old friends suggested dinner there to try out their 'must-try' all day brunches, and it was on the list of 'trendy cafes in Singapore' that we've heard so much about. We weren't allowed to make reservations, and despite arriving super early after rushing down from work, I couldn't get seated to ensure 4 of my other friends had seats either, which was quite disappointing service. So there I was waiting alone outside while the restaurant slowly filled up, to the point where by the time all my friends arrived, we had to be seated at a table for 4, with an additional chair squeezed in. The food was greatly talked about, so we went all out and got a banana toffee milkshake that came served in a colour and shape that was honestly that of doo-doo. It tasted cloying and overly artificial, and the drink slowly congealed into a paste towards the end of the meal - not tasty at all! We ordered several different pancakes from their all day brunch menu that they were famous for, and the top choice was the Norwegian pancakes, that came with smoked salmon on scone like breads. This was average at best, with the accompanying sauce a bit too sour for my taste since it just made the eggs taste sour and the salmon taste bad. 2 stars at most for just having a good ambience in the restaurant.

Wild Honey @ Mandarin GalleryWild Honey dared to be different by serving all day breakfasts - even for dinner.  Totally against the grain but it works! With queues even at dinner time, expect to wait 15-30 mins for a table. Service is mediocre, the staff aren't exceptionally cheerful (or efficient) for that matter, but you're really here for the atmosphere - plush cosy chairs in little corners, dim lights and a strong cinnamon-y sweet scent. Love how the dishes are named after different cities / areas - one of my favourites is the 'Belgian', fluffly waffles with grilled mango and blueberries.  An instant hit for my sweet tooth - beware though, it IS sweet and may not go down well as a main for dinner.  Perhaps better to share as a desert :)
Took me ages to get a seat in this popular restaurant. The wait is terrible but once you've tasted the food your anger just melts away.....

This is one of my favourite brunch places for a few reasons: its accessible(for me) smack in town, the service and food quality is consistent, wide range of  menu, cosy ambience, delicious smoothies. The downside is the price (well its in Orchard road, what do you expect), some dishes aren't too fantastic (e.g. Mexican), some of the portions are too small for my liking in relation to the price. Also you can't make a reservation for the mandarin gallery branch, although this is not a problem for the Scott's branch.In conclusion: not perfect but always a reliable place to go for brunch. I'm still waiting for the seats out on the patio!

Late lunch.. found this place inside the Scott Plaza. Surprisingly, it's almost full house at 3pm+. Ordered a cold brew single origin. It was actually quite good, even slightly better than Starbucks and far better than TCC. And the price is reasonable $5.50. I ordered the all day breakfast, Scandinavian. Salmon wrapped with asparagus, on top of deep fried thin hash brown (I hope I got it right), drizzled with hollandaise dressing. Sadly, I didn't like it. Not at all. Especially I didn't know what to do with the tomatoes. The deep fried "nest" made of hash brown was very tough and oily, I was slightly worry about it flew out of my plate when I cut it with knife. That would be embarrassing. I didn't finish the main, I thus ordered a brownie with vanilla ice cream. Not bad! Good for sharing. Too much for one person. Conclusion, a place good for coffee and dessert.

Who can say no to all day breakfast? Prices here seem a little on the high side but portions are comparatively larger. The food was decent, and I did enjoy my spanish hash, but it didnt wow me. I guess I'm paying more for the ambience, the comfortable seats and the strong AC. Great place for a meetup with friends where food isnt the focus.

Ah, comfort food, comfort place.Wild honey has been a favorite to-go place for brunch in Singapore. But because they're so famous, make sure you have reservation prior or be prepared to wait. There are 2 outlets around Orchard Road vicinity - one at Mandarin Gallery (first outlet) and they accept no reservation, so you'll have to pray hard there is no queue and the second outlet - at Scotts Square has bigger dining area capacity and accepts reservation. My favorite is always their second outlet at Scotts Square as the sitting area is more spread out and the verandah sitting area has the best natural light for you food "pornographers" out there.Their menu has been the same since I visited 2.5 years ago until today. That's pretty unacceptable in Singapore since the dining scene is always fast paced and people always crave for something different from time to time. But it got me thinking, the main reasons that they're maintaining their stellar items in the menu is probably because it still sells like hotcakes? The superstar items like the Tunisian (baked eggs with chorizo in thick tomato sauce) or their perfectly poached eggs benny that we won't get bored eating or the simple-yet-so-delicious French toast that we crave. If one main isn't enough to fill you up (for my case all the time), consider getting "small plates" of chorizo, sautéed mushroom, bacon and the likes. They have a long list of items under this section for you to mix and match to your liking.Looking at the lack of good cafés around Orchard road area, Wild Honey will always be my to go place if I need a good brunch spot knowing that they're always consistent with their quality and portion.
Food is pretty good. Though a bit pricy, the portion is big too. I like the drinks particularly. The milkshake is quite healthy feeling and fast food too

Loved the ambience of the Scotts Square outlet, with an open air patio, located on the 3rd floor. With such an extensive menu, Beck and I couldn't decide so went with our first choices as we could come back again to try the rest. My caramel latte was pretty good

This is a great spot on the 3rd floor of Scott's Square.  They serve breakfast all day. Portions are large and there is plenty for vegetarians.  Prices are reasonable (by Orchard Road standards, anyways), and the staff was attentive when we were there, but this was closer to 2pm on a Monday, so not exactly peak time.I really liked the Santa Fe eggs, though I'm pretty sure they left off the cheddar cheese.  It was tortillas filled with pico de gallo, topped with fried eggs, corn and sour cream.  My boy had the Norwegian, which included perfectly poached eggs with salmon wrapped around them.The coffee was too bitter for my taste, but that seems to be the case with everywhere here.There's free wifi.

I suppose it's my fault for picking this place for dinner (like I've mentioned before I love the ambience). I wanted something savory without eggs, and that was difficult to find. I ended up picking a sandwich with artichoke and cheese. I can't remember what it's called but it was average - 3 stars. The price would put it lower than that though. My friend picked the Portobello Road, again 3 stars. At the end of the day I'm not sure it's quite worth the price!

Best breakfast/brunch restaurant there is!They have all kinds of breakfast: Spanish with chorizo, the classic English breakfast which comprise of bacon eggs and baked beans, Tunisian breakfast, salmon, and so on. The portion is very filling. I went for English breakfast, which was very good. I will definitely go for Spanish next time!

Nice selection of western style breakfast food. I ordered the Santa fe which is two fried eggs sitting on top of two folded tortillas with some pico de gallo and tiny bits of avocado mixed in. (If you are from the south west region of the us or CA you are probably laughing at this type of presentation and mere the idea of eating tortillas with a fork and knife!)My husband ordered the Norwegian which looked very nice too. Ironically, it was served with slices of avocado. (When was the last time you had avocado in Norway?)We also had a raspberry smoothie that was essentially raspberry puree and ice blended together and served in a martini glass. Nice presentation but the flavor was fairly bland.Topped off with hot herbal and black teas served in mini french press pots.I'd go here again, but I'm curious to see other brunch spots as well.

All day breakfast ... This place is amazing, I love it. They have all kinds of breakfasts .. I ordered NY breakfast: it's 2 scramble eggs with small pieces of salmons. With bagel and white chess cream on the side. IT was delicious The place Is quite , with modern look. The the ground and every thing in the restaurant is from wood. It has a little English touch as well. The coffee and sweet was just ok. Highly highly Recommended for breakfast

Definitely on my go to list for weekend brunch. The ambiance here is quite pleasant for weekend gathering and stuff although it is rather noisy (lots of echoes but well it's quite common in dense SG isn't it?). The waiter are welcoming and are not intrusive at all despite the fact the place was crowded, which i really appreciate as I was able to catch up with my friend comfortably without feeling hurried to leave. Onto the main highlight, food. Pricewise, it's rather pricey (bout $30/pax) but portion is quite generous. We ordered the English breakfast and the Boulevard St Michel and it was delicious. I like the fact that jn both of our dishes, they successfully poached the eggs so it has firm whites but runny yolks which I adore. I also liked that they serve our dishes at the same time and are responsive whenever we call them although it was a busy day. Unfortunately, the coffee was a rather let down. We ordered the cold brew coffee but too bad it tasted more like your ordinary cup of joe on ice. I may be a bit of coffee snob but I believe cold brew should be slightly stronger and more aromatic. Nevertheless, my friend, whom is not a coffee drinker, enjoys it. So i guess it depends on your preferences.All in all, i would recommend this place to people who seeks for a good brunch at central location. I would advice you to reserve your seats as it may be hard to get a seat, unless you don't mind sitting at the bar, facing the columns.

This place is pretty unspectacular. I had the Corsican and a friend had the Carribean for dinner.This place hasn't changed its menu for ages. I don't feel there is anything spectacular here. My Corsican was an omelette stuffed with cheese, with some basil and bread on the side. The Carribean waffles were unimpressive, with insufficient mango and banana. I don't think the food here warrants their high prices. Zero innovation, subpar food, high prices. Meh.

Hidden on an upper floor of the Scotts Square shopping centre, Wild Honey is a popular spot for brunch in Singapore. I've been 2x now for breakfast and both times I enjoyed my food and the casual cafe atmosphere. The menu is an eclectic mix of breakfast offerings you'd find in Europe, Australia, and the Americas. This last go I went with the Canadian option which consisted of fluffy pancakes, bacon (the Canadian kind), fruit compote and of course a heavy dousing of syrup.  Healthy, no, but sometimes a bit of a carb heavy decadence is needed to cure jet-lag.Service is prompt/efficient though not especially warm.As a tip, be sure to book ahead or get there early, last time I was there by 845am on a Friday morning and there was already a pre-opening queue!

Food is great depending on what you order, so I can't really generalize and say that everything is good. The food looks great and appetizing though, I saw some plates being served. However, the taste of the food is mediocre. I got Spanish Hash which was a bit too oily. I also got a slice of Apple Crumble, I didn't like it as well. It was too sour for my taste and wasn't warm when I had it. The ambiance though was average. I guess I expected too much because everyone was telling me about how pretty the place is and the food. Although style and taste is relative, you should still give this a shot.

I think this place wins more for the ambience than the food. Everything that we had is just okay. Not good not bad. But the place is beautiful. For the price (average plate is about $25 for a relatively small portion), I think there are much better brunch options out there but maybe in a not as pretty setting.
Food is Alright, quite a big portion and did not have space for desert :(Coffee was not bad
This is a good place to have conversations with friends, and at the same time getting your tastebuds to work!

Downgrading a star. We ventured off our menu go-tos and were very disappointed. We left half of our I Love NY and Mexican burrito dishes on the table. Just wasn't very edible. Stick to the Spanish and the Tunisian.

Visited Wild Honey at Scotts Square. It's actually located right next to the hair salon at Level 3. We had ordered the English breakfast, which I find the portion to be reasonable, not too big a portion but enough for a satisfying breakfast. When we got there, we happily went in and chose our table at the corner of the establishment, but was told by one of the staff that the table was reserved and that we can only sit at the long table in the middle.The seats at the long table was uncomfortable, and the whole place feels gloomy when there's few customers but resembles a fish market when crowded. Although the breakfast was delicious and up to standard, I feel the service could be improved. That said, I will still return to Wild Honey in the near future.

Another great breakfast option in Singapore! I had the Canadian which was 3 perfectly fluffy pancakes, maple syrup, fruit compote and candied bacon. Absolutely delicious and just the right size. My fellow diners (breakfasters?) had the Flinders Street and the Corsican. Both looked excellent and were well received. You definitely need to be book, we were there on a Wednesday at 10:00am and it was pretty full. I also wouldn't recommend it with small children, it's definitely more of an adult breakfast joint!Didn't really enjoy the coffee though but realising that coffee is pretty personal I could make do.

Expensive but worth it. We had an amazing brunch ordering the Portobello Road and the European breakfast. The eggs were poached to perfection and the coffees were perfect. I was actually struggling to finish my meal given it's size. We arrived around 11am on a Sunday and only bar seating was available. This was fine. It is near a hotel so you get many international travellers here having a leisurely breakfast. Fantastic atmosphere and décor. Definitely on the pricey brunch end.

Love the decor of the place. But it would be great if they serve fresh avocadoes instead of old ones. According to the reviews, I expected the perfect poached eggs but it was a shame. Waitress hands over our change from the back over my husband's shoulder; not cool. Personally, I wouldn't come back but for those who would like to just chill out and have good milkshakes, this might be a nice spot to soak in all that posh ambience.

All day breakfast mains here are priced at insanely high prices for the quality. The desserts were way better than the mains. Using the chope voucher, it was worth it, but if you're paying full price for the mains, it's definitely not worth it. Not sure if I will return for the desserts though. Service was really slow too on a Monday.

We wanted a quiet and relaxing place to chill out after dinner and Wild Honey was the perfect place. Their blender was not working when I went there so I couldn't order ice blended drinks but the recommended the Queen Bee iced drink. I had no regrets! We also ordered a Wild Mocha Dulce and it was ok. The Queen Bee trumped all other drinks! :)!Would love to come back and try the food next time!

Delicious. Best breakfast I've had in a loooong time. Great portion sizes. Very popular place, can't linger without a reservation. The European breakfast was amazing. The hubby had the English breakfast and rated it.
This place often stays quiet at meal times when Coffee Academics downstairs is full. Portions are large, but the food is really nothing to write home about.

This place was FANTASTIC!!! We came on Easter Sunday and it was a great atmosphere and it's very reasonable in price. My husband had the European and I had the coconut waffles. Both were excellent. We also ordered sausages and Canadian bacon. Again, simply amazing. We will definitely be back!!

Great for big brunch excursions. Portion sizes are generous and coffee is good quality. Service is a bit slow and the wait staff do tend to forget requests (had to remind them about our pilsner and they brought the bill when we asked for milk). Overall, you're paying for the location and food, which is worth it.

A business cum social meeting was the occassion and Wild Honey was chosen as the venue. I must say from the get-go, its popularity is warranted. Location wise it is the most convenient to get to - minutes away from Orchard MRT station, with bus stops closeby and the Grand Hyatt taxi stand at your disposal next door - it was a breeze getting there.Without the foresight of making a reservation, we were told it would be a half an hour wait at 11.30am on a Sunday, during which we decided to have coffee in the basement below. Their technologically advanced waiting list system was impressive. A few taps on the iPad located at their entrance, I was 7th in line and I received a call on my mobile, informing to choose if I would be there immediately or needed at 10 minute extension. A 'service' I was particularly fond of.Jumpin right in, we were seated outdoors (you can indicate preferences on the iPad), and it being my first time, I took about 5-7 minutes to decide what I wanted whilst we were served water and the orange juice I ordered (Which was fresh, not too sour, good job once again). I decided on the 'Scandinavian', which is grilled salmon fillet on potato rosti, chargrilled asparagus & homemade Hollandaise sauce. It was right on the money,  approximate $25 bucks if I recall correctly. Salmon was grilled to perfection and the rosti was crispy (I am used to it being less crispy, but it clearly said 'crisp rosti' on the menu so I guess it was done right). Do note it takes about 15-20 minutes to prepare, so if you feel like having this, get your order out right as you are seated.  My friend ordered the 'Norwegian' which consisted avocado, grilled asparagus spears, two perfectly poached eggs wrapped with imported Norwegian smoked salmon, homemade Hollandaise & salmon pearls on a whole-wheat brioche. It looked fantastic, and he isn't too expressive about food but just gave me a thumbs up and a sigh of satisfaction when he was done.Definitely coming back here for more. Service was great, a little too crowded for my liking but then again, Singapore is getting that way and perhaps making reservations in advance would save you unnecessary delays. Another great brunch menu checked off my list!
Looking for an American meal while in Singapore, Wild Honey is a must try. The food and service are excellent.
Visited a few times on an extended trip. Coffee is really good and the wait staff is friendly! Try to get a seat on the patio - it's a nice relaxing atmosphere

I believe most people are familiar with the fantastic range of all day breakfasts available at the Wild Honey. But due to the smaller set up in the Mandarin Gallery outlet, seating is limited and it is on a first come first serve on-site queue basis, no reservations allowed.But guess what, at the Scotts Square branch, not only is the restaurant bigger, you can actually make reservations! No need to queue and you are guaranteed a table when you arrive! As this outlet is also larger, you wont have the issue of tables being too close to the next so you have more privacy when dining. Not only that, for those who love the Wild Honey Concept so much, you can actually reserve their terrace for private parties!One thing to note though, due to the mall operating hours, this outlet closes slightly earlier than other regular restaurants not within a mall so do go early to maximise your dining experience.Cant wait to go for my breakfast during dinner time again soon! :)

Located in an upscale mall, bright cheery decor.  Filled with "teenagers and twenty somethings", so noisy. It was an "ok" place to grab a western style lunch. Service was pleasant, albeit slow. Had to hunt down my server more than once. Ordered a 250gm Australian sliced steak platter with a side salad and carrot juice. Very good, but very $$$$. Almost 60SPD! Lots of breakfast/brunch choices served all day.
I ordered a latte.  You would think for $7 they would know not to boil the milk.  Starbucks do better coffee and that's saying something

On a trip with a group of friends all from the US, we specifically sought out Wild Honey while in Singapore. It was completely worth it. A diverse, eclectic breakfast & brunch menu with specialty dishes with US & AsianFlavor. It looks amazing as well. Be prepared to wait though. Next time I'm in Singapore, I will be first in line!
Food was excellent and presentation was of a high quality. Unfortunately, the hostess was being dismissive towards us

Wild Honey has the best Eggs Benedict in Singapore. Two perfectly poached eggs, sauteed mushrooms and prosciutto on toasted homemade brioche and hollandaise sauce. This has to be my favorite dish of all time. I always end up ordering this even though i always say i wanna try something new. Anyway, i think that the Mandarin Gallery branch does it better? Somehow the bread is over toasted and was too crunchy. Pretty dry. :(The Wild Mocha Dolce is my poison. This is intensely sweet but packs in some serious caffeine. I always get super high after drinking this. Friends know not to feed me with too much coffee/tea because i'd be bouncing off the walls. I also love the scones at WH. For tea, i like to have their cranberry scone with a cuppa of hot mocha dolce. This has to be one of the better scones in town. I'd put it in the same category as Foster's (another of my favorite). The exterior is crispy and the middle is dense and moist. I'll gently coat it with a thin layer of butter and sprinkle sea salt flakes on it- my very own version of salted butter (because WH doesn't provide salted ones). Yummy! And their fresh compote of berries to go with it. Perfecto.I would be hanging out at the SS branch more often for the following reasons1. Wider desserts selectionAccording to the manager, the kitchen at SS is 3 times bigger than that at MG. Therefore, more space to make pastries! I tried the sour cherry strudel when i was there recently (not fantastic) and they also have more tea cakes and stuff. :) I'll be sure to try more desserts soon.2. More breathing space! I always felt that the MG store was really claustrophobic! In fact, the entire MG feels that way. I feel like i can easily touch the ceiling (ok i exaggerate). Also, because of the small size of the place, i do feel like i can't stay on for too long even though i just wanna chill out with my book sometimes. Scotts is more airy and there's more natural light hence the relaxed ambience. So if you haven't tried WH (quite impossible IMO), do head on down. All day breakfast means that you never have to wake up early! As for me, ADB FTW!

The food here is good, but I don't think it's worth the prices they serve them at. Although the atmosphere and the service was really great. It's a nice "I feel fancy today" kind of a place... But definitely not coming back here anytime soon. Still on the hunt for a regular brunch spot. Mainly breakfast and brunch place that serves brunch cocktails. Decent food and large servings but extremely pricey.

The food was fresh and the portions were good.  If you're not super hungry, you can split an entree to save on the high costs.  My friend and I got two coffees, some bread and split a breakfast entree and it was about 25 SPD each - ouch!  It's a good spot to get a Western breakfast and it's cute inside.  This is definitely a family establishment, but it's a good place to start your day.  Also, they didn't bat an eye when we told them we were splitting an entree, in fact, they split it onto two plates.

Meal ordered: Duck confit hash with eggs and potatoesPros: 1) There was a wait when I arrived on a Saturday morning, and I received a text message when they were ready to seat me. If you don't mind sitting at the bar, you'll be seated quickly. 2) I tried the duck confit hash meal since the chef was testing it out and the waitress recommended it. It was excellent. I hope they put it permanently on their menu. 3) Their customer service was excellent.Cons: 1) It was on the pricey side, but it was an excellent meal so that's not really a con. 2) It might be difficult to get seated right away if you are in a large group. Summary: Whenever I am back in Singapore, I will visit this restaurant again.

The food here is good, but I don't think it's worth the prices they serve them at. Although the atmosphere and the service was really great. It's a nice "I feel fancy today" kind of a place... But definitely not coming back here anytime soon. Still on the hunt for a regular brunch spot. Mainly breakfast and brunch place that serves brunch cocktails. Decent food and large servings but extremely pricey.

Had a really awful experience at Wild Honey where we waited over an hour for our food. When we finally asked about our order, we realized that it never actually went into their system, with the only explanation being a breakdown in their system. When we asked to speak to the manager, the only thing he said was that it must have been a bad day and didn't try to offer anything else to compensate us. When my order finally came, it was incorrect (I asked for sauce on the side and it was piled on top of my order). I used to frequent Wild Honey at Scotts Square, but given this unacceptable experience which is the worst I've had in Singapore, I highly recommend avoiding this place!!

Tried the Spanish Hash for brunch today - pretty good. I love poached eggs and the chorizo in the hash still had a nice snap to the skin. Definitely recommended! The patio seating was very laid back and comfy. I really enjoyed the atmosphere at Wild Honey. Downside: sour bitter tasting expresso, yuck! Bloody Mary was thin and there was no bite to it (had the spiciness but no horse radish). Still searching for the perfect Bloody Mary in Singapore...

Ah, comfort food, comfort place.Wild honey has been a favorite to-go place for brunch in Singapore. But because they're so famous, make sure you have reservation prior or be prepared to wait. There are 2 outlets around Orchard Road vicinity - one at Mandarin Gallery (first outlet) and they accept no reservation, so you'll have to pray hard there is no queue and the second outlet - at Scotts Square has bigger dining area capacity and accepts reservation. My favorite is always their second outlet at Scotts Square as the sitting area is more spread out and the verandah sitting area has the best natural light for you food "pornographers" out there.Their menu has been the same since I visited 2.5 years ago until today. That's pretty unacceptable in Singapore since the dining scene is always fast paced and people always crave for something different from time to time. But it got me thinking, the main reasons that they're maintaining their stellar items in the menu is probably because it still sells like hotcakes? The superstar items like the Tunisian (baked eggs with chorizo in thick tomato sauce) or their perfectly poached eggs benny that we won't get bored eating or the simple-yet-so-delicious French toast that we crave. If one main isn't enough to fill you up (for my case all the time), consider getting "small plates" of chorizo, sautéed mushroom, bacon and the likes. They have a long list of items under this section for you to mix and match to your liking.Looking at the lack of good cafés around Orchard road area, Wild Honey will always be my to go place if I need a good brunch spot knowing that they're always consistent with their quality and portion.

Unimpressive. My wife's French press coffee was light yellow in color, when we asked if they could make it stronger we were told no... And my sandwich came out with the bread soggy. Nice ambience but go somewhere else if you care about the food.

The only good thing about wild honey is the wide variety of food. The service is terrible. My friend made a reservation for her birthday and we were kept waiting for an extremely long time. The hostess was continuously rude and bitter about our requests to be seated. In addition, the chef is incapable of accommodating to simple modifications of a dish. Later, hair was found in a dish and certain items on the menu were unavailable.

The food was fresh and the portions were good.  If you're not super hungry, you can split an entree to save on the high costs.  My friend and I got two coffees, some bread and split a breakfast entree and it was about 25 SPD each - ouch!  It's a good spot to get a Western breakfast and it's cute inside.  This is definitely a family establishment, but it's a good place to start your day.  Also, they didn't bat an eye when we told them we were splitting an entree, in fact, they split it onto two plates.

This place is pretty unspectacular. I had the Corsican and a friend had the Carribean for dinner.This place hasn't changed its menu for ages. I don't feel there is anything spectacular here. My Corsican was an omelette stuffed with cheese, with some basil and bread on the side. The Carribean waffles were unimpressive, with insufficient mango and banana. I don't think the food here warrants their high prices. Zero innovation, subpar food, high prices. Meh.

Hidden on an upper floor of the Scotts Square shopping centre, Wild Honey is a popular spot for brunch in Singapore. I've been 2x now for breakfast and both times I enjoyed my food and the casual cafe atmosphere. The menu is an eclectic mix of breakfast offerings you'd find in Europe, Australia, and the Americas. This last go I went with the Canadian option which consisted of fluffy pancakes, bacon (the Canadian kind), fruit compote and of course a heavy dousing of syrup.  Healthy, no, but sometimes a bit of a carb heavy decadence is needed to cure jet-lag.Service is prompt/efficient though not especially warm.As a tip, be sure to book ahead or get there early, last time I was there by 845am on a Friday morning and there was already a pre-opening queue!

Breakfast done in a odd seating and difficult service routine - not the worst breakfast in Singapore but the facility is more for a family reunion than a breakfast.  Coffee is cold and pricey.  The wait and amount of strollers is disturbing.  Don't the helpers know how to cook an omelet and toast?
Great breakfast - the New Yorker in me could not resist - Ordered I Love NY breakfast - awesome...felt I like was in the Village.

I went to Wild Honey with my SO for a special occasion brunch. It is AMAZING! I got the eggs with smoked fish. They had gluten free bread that was actually so good that I was afraid it wasn't actually gluten free. The hot chocolate was ridiculous with the housemade marshmellow. WH also had the only Bloody Mary that I've had in Singapore so far that was actually good. Overall, I wish my stomach could have fit more in it cause it was all so delicious. My only complaint is it was very pricey. It's definitely not something we could do regularly as it was over $100 for the two of us.
Best breakfast on the island. Rivals places in San Fransisco and Chicago for best breakfast. I had their huevos rancheros called Santa FE...it  rocked.
Nice spot with a good menu, service a little slow but overly enjoyed the experience. Went for the NY breakfast would have again. Cold brew was nice without being great.

Whatever it was before, it isn't anymore  super expensive, felt like they were just piling a bunch of ingredients together to justify the cost.  I am not a fancy chef, but boy the flavor profiles were so off ... like 0/4 dishes $24 SGD plus each.  Sad ... Very Sad.  The bad food might have been somewhat compensated by service staff but sadly again, that was bad too.

We have been coming to Wild Honey since this branch opened and are pretty much regulars on the patio at opening on Sundays.  It helps that one of our friends has a baby but the rest of us are just naturally early risers.  I've tried most of the menu and would say my ideal meal is the European with a side of Brazilian bread and a Queen Bee.  The dishes are all named after a geographic location but are pretty imaginative from there. The European is their take on eggs Benedict: seriously thick brioche with parma ham and poached eggs.  The brazilian bread is this cheesy little roll thing, amazing. And the queen bee is a honey grapefruit mocktail.  Yum.Other highlights of the menu are the Tunisian and the English.  Enjoy breakfast!

A beautiful breakfast parlor in the heart of Orchard road has been the talk of the town since its opening. The beeline at its 1st outlet; Mandarin Gallery, has become a common sight. Due to the limited seats, many find it frustrating to wait. The restaurant did excite me but not the queue. I wouldn't brave myself to Wild Honey until its 2nd outlet at Scott's Square becomes operational; there - I have gotten my most important meal of the day fixed without having to wait, any time of the day.    Serving an array of breakfast dishes; distinguished by country that ranges from English, European, Belgian, Canadian,Tunisian to Japanese et cetra. While many raved about European - eggs Benedict; I heart English instead.The portion has been massive; it can feed 2 ladies with small appetite. Routinely, I would portion the plate unless I declared a NO dessert and could leave the place without any. What have been so enjoyable in the plate are those juicy pork meat cased in its crispy sausage skin. They are perfectly grilled without drying out and loosing their flavour. The toasted brioche is more provocative - rich in taste with a strong buttery note. Slightly fluffy yet crumbly in some parts. While the briny bacons compliment well with the bread, the scrambled eggs add moist and even-out the saltiness in the former. When waffles becomes unavailable, I will make good with a stack of pancake - Canadian. These thick fermented round flapjacks are doubled in size; 3s are somewhat excessive - sharing is more ideal. I am particularly fond of its texture - very light yet with some volume. They are relatively moist but not dampish. For a savory note, nibble on the bacons along with the cake. Otherwise, top it up either with maple syrup or homemade jam - the morning becomes more angelic.

The only good thing about wild honey is the wide variety of food. The service is terrible. My friend made a reservation for her birthday and we were kept waiting for an extremely long time. The hostess was continuously rude and bitter about our requests to be seated. In addition, the chef is incapable of accommodating to simple modifications of a dish. Later, hair was found in a dish and certain items on the menu were unavailable.

Excellent food options with outdoor and indoor seating.  Great for Sunday brunch with a group but make reservations in advance as this is a popular spot in this neighborhood.   Their cocktails are excellent albeit a bit pricey.  Food is served hot but if you sit outside, the overhead fans cool it quick. Deserts are decent as well.

I had a great, albeit somewhat expensive experience here. In between my friend's church wedding and wedding dinner reception next door at the Hyatt, i managed to meet another friend for coffee here (talk about multitasking; gotta keep the schedule going when you're visiting for only 2.5 weeks). I had a delicious, strong serving of French Press coffee- really, it reminded me of Blue Bottle Coffee in SF- strong and luxurious. Also had a serving of the Apple cobbler ala mode. Delish. It's definitely overpriced, but i look forward to checking out their brunch or dinner service when i visit again

Food is ok but marred by terrible top ten music blasted at  very high volume. Couldn't have a conversation at the table. Asked Service staff to reduce volume but nothing happened. They need to decide if they are running a restaurant or cheap disco playing shitty top ten music.
Great food and exceptional service. I can't compare to other brunch/breakfast places in the area as it is my first, but it might also be my last.

Breakfast done in a odd seating and difficult service routine - not the worst breakfast in Singapore but the facility is more for a family reunion than a breakfast.  Coffee is cold and pricey.  The wait and amount of strollers is disturbing.  Don't the helpers know how to cook an omelet and toast?

Empty restaurant in the haze but they refuse to make even minor modifications to menu items. Avoid if you have any dietary restrictions at all. Ordered a pitcher of "extra spicy" bloody maries and they were bland but for being exceedingly salty.

Dining here costs a lot - at least $50 a head. And that's just for breakfast! However, if you're willing to splurge, then there is no problems dining here. The service is excellent and they only use the freshest ingredients. I mainly come here to sample their worldwide breakfast menu, as there are quite a few varieties available rather than the boring standard breakfast. The ambience is really nice and conducive to have breakfast with friends, or even alone.

Tried this breakfast joint recently as it rated highly on Yelp. Not everything is good on the menu as we found out soon enough how dissappointing their waffles (Canadian Bfast) were. I'll stick to the European (Eggs Benedict) or English (Scrambled Eggs and Sausage) for now. S$80 for 2? That's quite abit for breakfast.

Most sets cost around $20. The menu looks interesting with breakfast inspired by all parts of the world. I had the Tunisian breakfast set served in a pan - I loved the seasoning used, and how it looked. You pay at the counter before getting your set. Prepare for a long wait though, as this place is always crowded. More importantly, i liked the cosy cafe setting with nice sofa chairs. What I disliked is the queue!

My wife and I had breakfast here on a Monday morning, and loved it. The service, food and atmosphere were all great. The food is quite expensive, but for a schmancy breakfast spot in downtown Singapore, that's to be expected. One thing I really liked was that both of our entrees came out together. In Singapore it is very common for different people at the same table to be served minutes apart, which is a major faux pas in decent restaurants all over the world. My Bloody Mary could have been spicier and had another splash of vodka, but it was still good, and a great compliment to my eggs bennie and fruit.

Chops for ambience and location but food is rather overpriced for the quality. Had the Santa Fe and the Brittany, both of which were served at room temperature. Would have been nice for the food to have been served warmed. In any case, I suspect we're paying for the rent here. Could be better...

How can breakfasts be so expensive? Singaporeans must really love their breakfasts to pay these prices. I skipped the breakfast items (so cannot comment on them, and therefore, I suppose I shouldn't judge the pricing, as the breakfast items could be really crazy good) and ordered a "chicken salad chop chop" or something with an equally silly name. Possibly "chop chop chicken salad"??Anyway, the salad is NOT like a salad at all. Firstly, there were no greens. Ok, fine, there was some lettuce in the salad. But the lettuce was coated in some brown coloured seasoning (curry powder? no idea). In fact, the entire bowl of "salad" was one single colour - brown! Definitely not appetizing and not the fresh, healthy bowl of salad I was expecting. However, having said that, the salad tasted fine and I grew to like the crunchy crackers in the salad. So much for trying to have a healthy meal. In a bid to keep up with my attempt to have a healthy meal, I ordered the mixed beetroot juice - this was expensive, but not too bad, quite tasty and was freshly squeezed, of course.Service was slow. Our glasses of water were not topped up. I'm not used to paying such sky high prices for breakfast food and won't be coming back. It's not like the food I had was that great, or the service, that good. In fact, everything was pretty average to me, down to the ambience. Only advantage I suppose would be the location, although to me, I'd very much prefer a relaxing, quieter cafe to have my breakfast at.

Expensive......Be prepared to pay S$40 a head easy... for breakfast. Are you kidding me?Went there with my gf whose friend is a fan, she made reservations.Even though we had reservations we still had to wait about 10min.They made the reservations process so troublesome but still had to queu up, really? what was the point?Decor is nice, however crowded.Just be prepared to have a packed restaurant and many many kids, so if you are looking for relaxing look elsewhere.Service was so so. Still had to chase down the server for salt, although pepper was readily available on the table. To management: if you offer pepper then ignore the salt?What ticked me off finally was the hostess came and suggested to us there were people still waiting 10 min after we paid our bill.  I was not aware there was a time limit for brunch,  really? usher your customers out after they just paid  a S$117 bill for 3?Maybe its me but for S$40 i would be expecting a much better experience.

I had lunch there with my daughter-in-law and her friend.  The food was very good, but the service was a bit slow.  We had to wave our waiter down and while the food was prompt after ordering, we had to remind him to bring us water.  But I would go there again.

Had a really awful experience at Wild Honey where we waited over an hour for our food. When we finally asked about our order, we realized that it never actually went into their system, with the only explanation being a breakdown in their system. When we asked to speak to the manager, the only thing he said was that it must have been a bad day and didn't try to offer anything else to compensate us. When my order finally came, it was incorrect (I asked for sauce on the side and it was piled on top of my order). I used to frequent Wild Honey at Scotts Square, but given this unacceptable experience which is the worst I've had in Singapore, I highly recommend avoiding this place!!

Holiday weekend and we walked to Wild Honey to get a change of pace from The Line at Shangri La. The hostess stand had an iPad where we checked in digitally and received texts regarding the status of our table. The wait time was estimated at 45-60 minutes and we waited only 40 minutes. We walked around the mall and did some shopping to pass the time more quickly, which was a nice change of pace to lingering around the entrance. We received a call when our table was ready and were greeted by a friendly gentleman apologizing for how crazy it was, but we weren't concerned at all because it was a holiday weekend. We were seated at the round counter and quickly greeted and put in drink orders - iced coffee. The menu had a lot of variety and offered meals from many regions around the world. I chose the Tunisian, which was chorizo and eggs in a tomato based sauce, with two hearty pieces of toast and a cucumber and tomato salad. It was incredibly tasty but not very filling since my Paleo lifestyle doesn't allow me to consume grains. My hubby tried the special - duck confit potato hash topped with poached eggs and hollandaise. It was also very good. We topped off our meals with the berries, but passed on the yogurt. The service was good. The menu is a little limited if you're paleo, but it's not too hard to make it work. The atmosphere was cozy and inviting, and I was a fan of the music selection, which would fit into the "coffee house" genre. Overall, we were very pleased and will be back.

Unimpressive. My wife's French press coffee was light yellow in color, when we asked if they could make it stronger we were told no... And my sandwich came out with the bread soggy. Nice ambience but go somewhere else if you care about the food.

We normally love this place, but today the three of us left very disappointed and may not go back. We had an 11 am reservation for 3. Two of us arrived 20 minutes early and asked if the table was free for us to go ahead a sit down. We were shown to our table and reminded about the 90 min reservation. We thought that started from our 11:00 reservation time, so no problem. We each ordered a drink, our friend arrived we ordered a second drink and our food. Our second drinks did not come. They came to take our food order and we asked about the drinks. They hadn't made them yet. The food was good as always. At 12:10 they brought the check and asked us to leave for the next reservation who were waiting outside. We said that we had the table until 12:30. She told us that since we came early, the 90 minutes started when we sat down. We did not argue and left. A disappointing experience.

Wild Honey at Scotts Square is a vast improvement on its sister outlet at Mandarin Gallery. For starters, there's a lot more space and a wider variety on its menu, and we can finally make reservations online instead of having to wake up at the crack of dawn on a weekend to queue for a table.Food : The best eggs Benedict I've had in Singapore. We shared the Tunisian, the Scandinavian, the European, the English, the Australian and I Love New York amongst us so that we could all get a taste of the different breakfast sets. The coffees were well made and a couple of us tried this Banoffee drink which was mad yummy! Being a ravenous lot, we also shared a bread basket while waiting for our breakfast sets to arrive. We particularly liked the croissant, evident in the fact we almost came to blows over the sole croissant in the basket. The homemade jams and honey too, were the perfect complement to the bread basket. If we hadn't wanted to save some stomach space for our breakfast sets, we would have ordered one more! The most difficult decision you will face at Wild Honey is deciding which breakfast set to order, but whichever you decide, rest assured they are all equally tasty in their own indigenous way.Ambience : Love the mosaic tiles on the floor and the airy feel of the restaurant. The dark wood works well with the colorful furniture and drapes. Overall, the atmosphere is bustling yet comfortable, and is a great place to people watch on weekends. We like!Service : Can be a bit sketchy if one is sitting outside on the verandah. It is practically impossible to get service after the server takes our initial order, and the wait staff inside the restaurant are too busy to pay us any attention. If you can get their attention however, they are perfectly pleasant.Perfect if they can improve service standards. Prices are a bit steep for brunch but at least the large portions compensate somewhat. Reservations for weekend brunch at prime time absolutely necessary at least a week in advance.

Decent food but way overpriced.  I had the Spanish Hash which was tasty, and my wife had the English breakfast.  She also had a donut and coffee.  She was disappointed that the breakfast came with toasted brioche but no jam or marmalade.  Overall bill was $70...ouch.

address: 8 Grange Rd #01-01/02 Cathay Cineleisure Orchard Singapore 239695 Singapore
comment: Nice cafe near Orchard Road. We had the Egg Benedict while wifey enjoyed her Salmon Spaghetti. Simply delicious and healthy. Good ambiance with new age music. Fast service.
A repeated fave. Since I can't go to Japan, I've found myself coming here more often of late. The queue sometimes deter me but more often than not my cravings will see me wait to get a seat!

14:27hrs ish - Friday December 21st 2018Err, did I get to the correct establishment or NOT??  I went inside this Cold Storage @ Takashimaya and found the SUSHI COUNTER with a few seating available..  What??, I whispered to myself...  Maybe I need to double check, the next time around for further confirmation.Anyways, since I want AKA NEED my Nigiri/Sushi fix..  I always CRAVE for SUSHI PERIOD!  So, when I walk by at this counter, luckily they have 3 empty seats available.  The Staff said I need to pick up some items from the prepackaged sushi tray or nigiri/sushi trays available at the chiller section.After observing, many trays of Nigiri/Sushi I decide to opt one, that has Uni in it.  Who can turned down UNI??  DEFINITELY NOT ME!  Anyways, once I pick my item, I proceed to the payment counter just next to the Dining Stall, get myself the seat and the staff proceed to gave me a Cup of Boiling Hot Green Tea.  The Sushi Tray that I choose was (SG$16.50).While enjoying my meal, I did noticed the Menu posted on my left, but was just too lazy to ask - perhaps next time.  I also observed some other patrons, opt to have some SET BOWL Meal AKA Bento Meal Set of some kind.From the tray I have chosen, The UNI though a little fishy to my liking, I like what I ate.  In between, when my HOT Tea Cup runs empty, I ask the staff to refill the Hot Tea.  She willingly took my cup and refill it with the Boiling Hot Green Tea.Added plus points, its reasonably priced!  SCORE!  Its satisfied my Nigiri/Sushi Craving for a day..  Hehehe..  DEFINITELY returning when needed.Cold Storage Nakajima SuisanTakashimaya Singapore Limited391A Orchard RoadSingapore 238873Tel : 67381111
Still one of the most popular and my favourite grilled fish place in town. Still affordable and great value.
Fresh, tasty and reasonably priced.  Got the saba set and they are still worth it though a hike in price.  There are lots of other grill you can get like oysters, shrimp etc.

Excellent food with the price paid. All fish but value for $ without tax or service charge. Price net with rice, miso soup, salad and free flow hot green tea. It's not top of the range but the food taste pretty good. Recommend to try the Unagi ! For the price of SGD15.50, it's the most affordable yet taste Unagi. Note that guest must go to counter order and pay, a number will be given and guest will have to join a queue behind the sign board. Once table and seat is available, they will call the number and guest would be able to sit down. This system is great because guest don't wait too long for food. If they were to sit down , order and wait for food and pay after finish food (the traditional way), each guest would have to wait much longer to get to eat. So hope all visitor understand the reasons behind their order-pay-getNumber-queue-sitdown-foodserve-enjoymeals, rather than sitdown-order-waitlongforfood-enjoymeals-pay. Recommended visiting days: Weekdays ( weekend tends to be overcrowded)Recommended food: Unagi Kayabaki Set @ SGD15.50

nothing fancy, but an oh-so-satisfying food store at the back of the takashimaya food hall - queues build up long and quick here during mealtimes, so choose to eat at an awkward time, or get ready for a bit of a wait.this isn't a place to linger - even if you were to ignore the death stares dealt to you by the horde of people queueing to take you place, the food is meant to be quick and cheap - and satisfies by fulfilling both those expectations and topping it with tasty, satisfying fare.I started with a chawanmushi, which was a great start to the meal - soft, smooth, custardy steamed egg, that was: (1) surprisingly unsalty, which is a common gripe; and (2) really surprisingly chockful of chicken, fishcake and gingko (my favorite part!). seriously cheap and good (even the fiance, who doesn't usually like chawanmushi, shared this!)and the bentos that arrived quickly after were just as satisfying. first of all, they don't skimp on the rice quality here - it's good, sticky-enough japanese rice, cooked well enough to maintain grain integrity. secondly, the fish comes in a generous portion (I've certainly gotten much smaller for much higher prices elsewhere), sauced adequately and tender.the grilled cod had fatty skin that was blistered and charred enough to bring texture and interest. if you really want to fault it (but what for?), you could gripe that the cod fillet comes with bones (be careful!) and the unagi certainly isn't fatty enough to be melt-in-the-mouth, but I would call you a grouch (which is rich, coming from me).anyway - it's about one step up from food court in ambiance but more than a few steps up for quality, and it's certainly a nice meal to round off a long day.
Fresh, taste gd, no service charge too! Value for money! Do try the Oden too, it's usually sold out by evening.
The Kimeno Dai SaikyoYaki Set is fresh and taste great, though the portion quite small but I like it. There is no service charge and value for money!

Went to eat here a week ago and found it a charming place with wonderful service .The reason for 3 stars is based on the food.It's not amazing but average and that's reflected in the price.  Wine is very reasonable too and very attentive cheerful staff member which makes this place just a great quick Indian.  Love the outdoor seating   Which makes a change from the a/c.Would definitely eat here again for the atmosphere, reasonable food and wine.Don't come here if you want amazing Indian cuisine but it's not bad.

address: 150 Orchard Road #02-25 Orchard Plaza Singapore 238841 Singapore
comment: Prepare to have your preconceptions of large, chain Japanese 'restaurants' with their largely deep fried, stale, generic food wiped from your memory as you step into Ryu.It's a small, dingy (cosy, if it's not a full house), hole-in-a-wall in Orchard Plaza (above the various KTV lounges and Filipino hostesses), with a very much Japanese chef (who behaves like an extremely culinary-talented dad at home), and his Singaporean 'translator'/co-owner of the place who helps speak to the chef and to get orders.Brought my mum here for my birthday dinner-bash (just us two), and boy did we have a great time! My mum was a sucker for fermented soy beans - and the 'chef' was so delighted to hear from the host that she likes those - he whipped out a pre-prepared portion, kicked it up a notch, and my mum was extremely pleased. We were asking for recommendations (after having their tofu, yellowtail, miso dishes, kurobuta pork (YUM!)) and the chef got us a small plate of fresh sashimi (about $58!) which was the best we've ever had out of Japan. The price IS definitely to gawk at, but it was my birthday and my mum was getting it... so...If you're tired of Genki/Sakae/Ichiban Boshi or other places, here's a place you should go to. Be sure to be on time and make a reservation - because they rarely do walk-ins!

I never been to a MOS Cafe so yesterday was a first for me. I have seen a MOS Cafe at Omotesando Hills but never stepped in. Meeting my sister and nephew for lunch, I was not sure where to go but since they were running late and I was shopping in the area, I texted my sis to see if MOS Cafe was alright for them. We just wanted something easy. Upon entering, I noticed MOS Cafe was different from MOS Burger. It seemed like MOS Cafe has some if not most of the menu at MOS Burger, it also has original items like rice bowl and showcased healthier choice of food. Think salad.SERVICE 5/5The staffs taking orders at the counters were all friendly and nice. The staff who delivered my food to our table was very kind too. So even though this was a fast food cafe, service is 5 Stars. AMBIENCE 4/5It was bright and lots of seatings. I like the corner seating. It was a tad noisy but then again this was not exactly a restaurant. The tables were clean though I guess the previous patron left behind some strands of hair on the bench (ugh!!) I hope she realized soon she needs a new shampoo to prevent hair loss. There was no way any staff could have seen and cleaned those hair fast enough for the next patron, so no fault on any staff. FOOD 4/5I ordered a Wagyu Burger Demi-glacé and a hot fruit tea. The hot fruit tea came with real pieces of fruits in a transparent glass tea pot. It was pretty, i meant that fruit tea. I did not add any sugar in my tea. It was not the best tasting tea, but it was good. My Wagyu Burger was good. Again, this was not a gourmet burger and cost less than $5. The beef and lettuce were fresh though. The burger was tasty afterall. Will I go back again? Definitely!! I want to try other items and those parfait which looked really yummy!!

The restaurant was located at the rather ula ula end of the floor, surrounded by empty shop spaces. The dining area was huge but not much customers around. I was attracted by a instagram post showing 1-for-1 skewers promotion which led me to this place. There was only staff serving the customers from cashier to showing customers to table to serving food, so it took quite awhile to get his attention. There was no GST on the bill but got 10% service charge.The promotion was limited to Signature Lamb Skewer 招牌羊肉串 (S$2.20+/ skewer)AUS Grain Fed Beef Skewer 精选牛肉串 (S$2.60+/skewer)Chicken Skewer 鸡肉串 (S$2+/ skewer)It tasted of cajun seasoning. Quite tender and flavourful.Pork Belly Skewer 低调五花肉 (S$2+/ skewer)Limited to 5 skewers per customers.Just 8 minutes on the griller. The meat were easy to remove from the metal skewers. The skewers were flavourful and tender. Dip them with chilli powder and peanut powder.Also tried Grilled Pork Intestine 烤猪肠 (S$1.80++/ skewer)No offending taste.The Caveman Bread 野人烤面包 (S$2+/ skewer)Light and crispy. Spread with butter and sugar, although wish for more butter.Grilled Banana 烤香蕉 (S$2+/ skewer)It looked char black when served. Peeled off the skin, one would find soft and sweet flesh of banana.Wash down with a bottle of Mineral Water 矿泉水 (S$2.50+)

It is a modern style Korean bistro with many tapas .The spicy marinated chicken is quite good . Ginseng chicken terrine is their unique creation using spring chicken , dates , ginseng n garlic n ginseng broth . Taste like the famous ginseng chicken soup but in a moder twist . The Japchae noodle taste good as well but rather lack of ingredients . Another unique dish is the crispy tofu with kimchi sauce , it's like the Japanese Agedashi tofu only with different sauce , pretty interesting they use kimchi as the sauce .

$78nett seafood buffet is hard to beat. At the raw station, there are fresh oysters, Boston lobsters, mussels and fresh prawns, sashimi. Lobster was tough and tasteless though. But the rest were good. In the salad section, lots of different types. Healthy and tasty. Mango salad with shrimp aka Thai salad, roasted vegetables and also quinoa and mushrooms. At the hot section,  tons of other yummy food like roast beef, roast lamb, baked salmon, roast meats and 6 different types of laksa. There is 2 different soups - one Chinese and one western. There is also a bit of Malay and Indian fare if that tickles your fancy. Dessert is mainly western cakes and the trendy cake and dessert in little jars. Also fresh fruits for the health conscious. In a nutshell, there is something for everyone. If there is a birthday, they offer complimentary cupcake tower with candle.

My favorite cousin from my dad's side of the family is 12 years younger than me and just recently finished his BMT (Basic Military Training, Singapore). Knowing that I was on my way out of Singapore, he asked that I join him and the rest of the family for another meal so that he can share his latest - hopefully funny - experiences in Tekong.Yet, I must point out that there one primary difference with this meal: he actually challenged me to a volume-binge at this buffet. Of course, there was no cash involved and just good ol'fun between cousins. (A little background info: he was still a pup when I went through the military...and he still remembers my crazy stories from back then...as well as labelled me as his favorite "crazy but fun" cousin, lol).Soooo...the battle begins!As always, my buffet ritual (in any form of competition) is as follows:1. Enter leopard mode, stalk the whole buffet line, and strategically decide which route is best for tackling all desirable dishes. I usually map out in my mind every dish that I will try before deciding the binge-worthy.2. Enter hummingbird mode, grab a bit of just about everything interesting, fly back to the table, and taste each section.3. Enter squirrel mode, run back and forth to my favorite dishes, stuff my mouth until I look like a raccoon, and work up a larger appetite in the process.4. Enter camel mode, drink enough liquids to rinse out the initial sudden salt intake as well as stretch out the stomach.5. Enter monkey mode, chit-chatter-talk-endlessly-with-others-in-company, and wait as the stretched out stomach transitions all the extra liquid.6. Enter dog mode and say hi to the almighty "wall".7. Enter bear mode and feast on the real favorites until hibernation comes calling.Yep, my cousin lost so bad...it wasn't even funny...lol.USEFUL INFORMATION:The cooked food in the buffet is pathetic at best with only a few that were even worthy of tasting. What made up for this was the cold seafood section with the Boston lobster, salmon and tuna sashimi (yep, I actually ate these fresh but poor knife skill cuts), and crab legs.Sure, it gets boring eating the same thing repeatedly but try this next time at a buffet. Create your own sauces for the cold dishes...such as eating the lobster with chilli crab sauce, soy and wasabe, chilli sauce, or lemon. It kept the boring away and allowed me to hippo away enough to destroy my cousin's total tally by 3 times. =)Yelp 100: 49/100/My-last-3-weeks-in-SG

We checked out the Sunday Champagne Brunch at J65. At $128 nett, it's one of the most affordable champagne brunch serving free flow of Perrier-Jouët champagne, beers, wines, juices and drinks. Well even if not for the food, the champagne alone would be worth the tag. The food selection is quite small, with only 1 live station that does Asian noodles. What I enjoyed was the selection of healthy and tasty salads and greens (great for vegetarians), decent selection of cold seafood, and a variety of meats and cold cuts. Skip desserts and stick with the bubbly as the calories are better spent on the latter. Or if you must, pop over to Jen's Kitchen On-the-Go - the lobby café and snack bar which offers locally roasted coffee and sweet concoctions like this Cake Shake that I had as a birthday cake.
Very good n wide range international buffet. Cols salmon, roasted pork, kuay pai tee, durian pengak, great aroma coffee. Value for money n good quality

I went there for a family function and I liked that the place had a nice, casual feel to it. It was relaxed and thankfully, not too crowded. They serve and Asian International spread, so they had dishes ranging from Crustacean Bisque and Baked Seabass to Chicken Tikka and Sushi. They also have a seafood counter that served the works of crab, mussels, clams, scallops and lobsters.Some of the dishes were appetizing, but some weren't up to scratch. Several dishes also had really unusual names and descriptions. Unfortunately, I'm a more of a "safe" buffet person. At $73 per head, I'm not sure I'll be heading back there anytime soon.

Not what it used to be. Very disappointing to see one of my favorite restaurants for past years go so far down hill. I hadn't eaten at this location for more than a year because of my last experience, but thought I give them another shot. Bad decision. Last time it was service and food, this time service was okay, but food mediocre at best. Although, the service staff seemed to have a problem with English. That's a shocker in Singapore. Biggest compliant is they no longer serve bread with meals. Although, the still have a bread plate. I've never seen a soup and pasta restaurant that didn't have bread on the menu. Soup is still good, but the pasta was dry and way too much garlic. Sorry, CPK, it's Jamie's Kitchen next time.

CPK used to occupy two floors at The Forum, then one, now it has retrenched to an even smaller area at Claymore Connect, with half the seatings in such an open space that passers-by could pick up a chicken wing or spring roll from your plate if they want. Service staff are friendly, although a bit blurred - confusing the extent of various offers (Entertainer, Burple, etc), or asking questions like "do you like one or two toothpicks?" The food is still pretty decent and fairly innovative, and if you have a 1-for-1 promotion, it's good value.

It's been over 2 years since I last went to a CPK in the US, so I had the singapore one on my list as a place to satisfy my craving of the old memories.  sadly..as usual...things are never as good as you seem to remember them. I opted for the Milan thin crust pizza. it was just a thin and with that crisp edge that I love. the toppings had a good serving of cheese and sausage, yet somehow I feel like something was missing.  it was kinda bland. not much flavor. maybe the caramelized onions were not mixed in well. not sure...it just wasn't the same. or maybe the US ingredients are just different. either way, the pizza was decent...the drink was great - cold and refreshing..just what a cooler should be. just think it's slightly over priced...8 bucks for that glass.. I wouldn't say I've scratched CPK off my list....its just not gonna be on my top must go to places. it will be a "if I'm in the area and craving pasta..." place. also..did CPK stop giving bread as a starter? or is that just a USA thing?

There are not as many traditional american fare as one hope in a cosmopolitan city, but cpk comes as good as it come if you like the US menu pallate and portion size. Too bad waiters aren't quite trained and familiar with american condiments i.e., mustard, balsamic vinegar, etcOther than that, good place for those who wants chilis or aplebees alternatives

I ate here with my family again.  The last time we came here I ordered chicken quesadillas.  The so-called "chicken" quesadillas barely contained any chicken at all leading me to complain.  They gave me more virtually chicken-less quesadillas and some coupons so I could return and give them another try.That's what we did today.  We gave them another try.  I had chicken quesadillas again and, once again, the "chicken" quesadillas were practically chicken-free.  I can only conclude that this is how they serve "chicken" quesadillas at California Pizza Kitchen, with almost no chicken in them whatsoever.As God is my witness, I didn't know chickens could get polio.

This is a place that is serving good food minus the pretentions that comes with most of the outlets these days. This is probably the first restaurant that started to serve gourmet pizzas like peking duck, chipotle pizza etc.Nice and if I can say healthier pizzas with lots of fresh vegetables. Servings are good and pricing is as reasonable as they can be. Cheaper than any of the places in any of the quays or dempsey.Will definitely be back and might make this as a regular place for us.

I love salad, so the volume and variety is salads they have is wonderful.  Pizza is average American Pizza, nice.  Pasta is above average - I think overall quite ok.サラダは日本人にとって嬉しいボリューム、味も悪くないです。ピザはアメリカンピザそのもので、いわゆるシカゴ（PAN）ピザとは違います。パスタも特別すごいという訳ではありませんが、美味しく食べられます。家族にはオススメできます。

Went to California Pizza Kitchen for my friend's birthday celebration. We heard that they are good at their skinny pizza.Ambience was good, not too noisy, and they have 2 levels, level 1 and basement. We had a table at the basement and arrange a surprise birthday cake to be served to my friend. We ordered 2 pizza to share with. I love the unqiue sweet taste of the pizza. Something to do with the pizza dough, which i find it really nice.

Definitely not like the CPK in the US, that's for sure.  I needed a quick somewhat healthy salad and had an hour to kill on a Saturday between appointments.  I sat at the bar, and ordered my usual, the Thai crunch 1/2 chicken salad.  No.  The salad was old looking, the chicken looked like it was either frozen, or came out of a bag somewhere, and the dressing was clumpy.  It looked like they at least make their pizzas homemade, but definitely stay away from the salads.
Nice find in Orchard road! Great spring rolls and good pizza plus a good wine selection! Nice cozy place with good service!

To me, pizza is the kind of food that comes to mind when I'm stuck at home feeling hungry and lazy on a rainy Saturday night. This is until I head down to CPK for their popular wood-fired peking duck pizza. If you haven't tried wood-fired pizza before, I assure you this will be one of the best pizzas you've ever tasted.  The crust is slightly thin and crispy and filled with a hint of smoky aroma of the wood-fired oven. Topped with with duck slices, garnishes and crispy crackers, the peking duck pizza is one of the must-try dishes at CPK. The ambience of the restaurant is pretty modern and cosy at the same time --Probably due to use of amber lighting. The staff's service, especially the branch manager's, is extremely good. The branch manager was very helpful and courteous in acceding to my questions and request for an extra serving of deliciously fresh guacamole dips. What I have learnt from my visit: You have not tried real pizza if you've not try wood-fired pizza! (holds true at least for the ones at CPK)Must tries: Peking duck pizza, tortilla spring rolls

Says they're open till 11:30 but they close their kitchen at 10:30. Found this out the hard way. Suck it CPK. Try fixing your hours. If you close your kitchen at 10:30, then state that online and on the storefront and hostess table.

I have always been a huge fan of CPK.  I have been out of the country and returned this week and wanted my BBQ chicken chopped salad fix.  I waited to be seated for quite awhile whilst all sorts of employees milled about. No one attended to me which should have been my first clue but I persisted.  I was finally seated and again there were probably 10 employees circling around looking very busy (talking to each other) but no one bothered coming by for almost 10 minutes whilst people seated at the same time as me had drinks already.  I ordered and when my tiny little $25 half portion salad came out I was shocked.  There were about 4 cubes of chicken and 4 cubes of avocado which I had paid $3 extra for.  At this point, I had still not received any drinks and I could not catch the eye of any of the 10 servers walking around and chatting.  I also wanted to use the salt shaker (I know bad me) and I tried 6 salt shakers before I could find one that hadn't crusted over.  Several staff saw me get up and go to various tables but no one assisted me.  Finally my disappointing meal was over and I couldn't flag anyone down to give me the bill.  That exercise took another 10-15 minutes.  I have always been a fan of this place but the service and quality of the food this time were shockingly bad and I will never return.

An average review for an average tasting pizza. Had the Peking Duck and whilst different, it just wasn't that tasty. Also tried the pepperoni classic thin crust and I believe there wasn't enough meat on it. Great atmosphere for a large group.
Slowest of the slow service, dry pizza and, somehow, $70 for 2 pizzas and 2 drinks.Added a service chare that wasn't advised on the menu.Avoid!

Not up to the expectations based on my experience in their US outlet.I like their cal veggie pizza the most. But very disappointed when took my wife there with a big built-up image. It was very ordinary and found the ingredients not as fresh as their US outlet. Truffle oil was the most disappointing experience. Other local pizza chains offer better pizza options. May be their oriental touch has spoiled their originality. I am not going there anymore.

California Pizza Kitchen was a favorite restaurant of mine back when I was studying in the US. It reminds me of eating at Cheesecake Factory, it's a restaurant that you know serves good food. Not only good food, but good old American comfort food.Here in Singapore, California Pizza Kitchen has smaller servings compared to what they serve in America of course but what remains is the great tasting food and service. I've never ordered anything I didn't end up liking, that includes the Wild Mushroom and the Mushroom Pepperoni Sausage but I usually go for the pastas.California Pizza Kitchen is a great choice for group gatherings as the restaurant is spread over two floors and rather spacious.
I think they took what is already a borderline mediocre chain restaurant in the US and made the portions smaller and the prices higher.
Absolutely horrible. Extremely slow and caustic service, so so food, and hugely overpriced. Playing off "California" trendy wannabes. Avoid at all costs.
