Good food with a lot of variety but just because of its location the food here was quite expensive but still in my opinion it was still worth it.

Had the ramen here a couple of times and the standard is rather consistent. Both times, I had the signature uma uma ramen-the usual ramen topped with black fungus, chasiu and spring onions as well as a bit of spicy miso. The broth was well done-not too thick or cloying and was nicely complemented by the ramen. What stood out was their cha siu ($6) as a side (not the one that comes in the ramen). The distinct barbequed/grilled taste had me at the first bite and will be what I'm returning for! The one bite gyoza ($8), a small plate of 10 mini gyozas are decent but nothing to shout about. Order the chasiu instead-I promise you won't regret it! :))If you're there on a weekday, do order their lunch set which comprises of a ramen and an additional topping, a (half) side and a drink for an additional $4. If you fancy some alcohol, there is also an option to add $8 for asahi superdry on tap (half a pint) or bottled beer

Been here maybe a dozen of times over the last five years.... but, since COVID they decided to get the worst self-ordering app, something called GetzPay. Last time I could not even get the order to check out, this time I could but the payment! How the hell do you have an app for ordering on mobile, which does NOT support ApplePay?!? I guess will find a new ramen place.....

I was really craving ramen and this place was near my hotel so I decided to give it a try.The restaurant is pretty small but I came during non-peak hours so it wasn't a problem. I'm not really a picky eater but the ramen was just passable for me. There was nothing really amazing or stood out. If I had another chance I would have gone somewhere else. The noodles were average and the broth was a bit on the salty side. The service was excellent and they were very nice but the taste of the food just didn't meet my expectation. I ordered the combo meal with the Uma Uma Ramen and I just felt it wasn't it worth it money wise either.The Recommendation:Uma Uma Ramen is your average ramen shop. Nothing amazing here so skip if you have another ramen shop in mind.

The ramen is pretty good, although not at par with the best ramen in town; I personally even prefer the under-rated Bari-Uma located at nearby Tanglin Shopping Centre. The original ramen comes with an unusual lime-flavoured broth. Side dishes are nothing to write home about.

After seeing the 9342390 check-ins by Natalie H and the accompanying photos, there was only one thing in my mind: TO TRY THEIR TRUFFLE RAMEN.And that was exactly what I did, after my Japanese lessons across the road. After spending the whole 3 hours with RAMEN RAMEN RAMEN on my mind, I dashed across the road (okay, actually, I crossed it via the underground link-- not  planning to make it literally to-die-for) and STORMED towards the Forum Shopping Centre. Note: the shop is actually on the outside of the shopping centre, facing Orchard road. Don't make the same mistake as I did, which was to enter the complex immediately, texting Natalie frantically while my stomach growled more and more ferociously with each passing moment.Finally found the shop and dashed in. It's a small, casual joint, probably seating 25 at most. I ordered the Truffle Ramen (my heart ached a bit when I saw that it was $38 before tax), then looked through the rest of their offerings. The rest of the menu was more moderately-priced (about $20 or less for a bowl, with very affordable (~$15) lunch sets).The blessed bowl arrived swiftly. Managed to resist the temptation to wolf it down immediately, and practiced enough restraint to first take a photo (which you can admire at the bottom of this post). Okay, the bowl looks tiny and probably won't fill a grown man up very well and it's a dry ramen with no soup broth to rave about but mygod was it divine or was it DIVINE? Perfectly springy al-dente yellow noodles covered with bits of garlic and loads of white truffle abundantly sprinkled over the bowl. And a nicely-cooked (albeit cold) half-boiled egg which I poked like a barbarian. Mixed the whole lot together and it was heaven. At the end I wiped my tears of gratitude and thanked the Ramen Gods for coming up with such a delicious treat. GOCHISOSAMA DESHITA! ARIGATOU RAMEN GODS (and Natalie-san for the recommendation)!

We ordered 2 Uma Uma ramen, 1 garlic ramen and 1 spicy cha siu ramen. Noodles were thin and firm and the gravy thick. The spicy char siu ramen soup is a bit too sweet for me, but we all like the generous servings of vegetables. My companions enjoyed theirs. Will want to try the others next time.

This place is the real deal. Have been coming here for ages, and have yet to be disappointed. I've tried Japanese ramen all over the world, from Tokyo to London. This place stands with the best of them. The ramen broth is rich, flavourful, and sticky with umami goodness. Noodles offer a consistently springy bite. Shoyu eggs are properly done - firm whites and barely-cooked-creamy soft yolk. Chasiu is soft and delightfully fatty, and rounded off with a tasty char-grill flavour. The bushi tonkotsu ramen deserves special mention. The lovely rich ramen broth is made more fragrant with the addition of white onion. A hit of lime and ginger helps lift the broth and keeps it refreshing. Service is usually friendly and unobtrusive. Have come often enough that the senior staff recognise us. Suffice it to say that I highly recommend this place. Special tip - there's a cocktail bar in the basement! It's called Horse's Mouth. The entrance is right next to the cashier, and the place is pretty spacious. You get the exact same menu, plus some additional Japanese bar food like ei hire (grilled stingray fin). Cocktails are absolutely solid, from seasonal concoctions to old standbys. Bartenders are knowledgeable (a rarity here) and will go the extra mile to whip up something that matches your mood and palate. The selection of Japanese whiskies is also quite decent, and well width checking out.

Had this on my bookmark so I decided to try it out on a Thursday lunch time. Ordered the lunch ramen set special as I have more varieties for a cheaper price. For the ramen, I tried garlic ramen. Yummy! Love the eggs the most :) the soup base doesn't have much seasonings but somehow the chasiu actually added to the taste. Additional topping: everything looks normal besides kikurage (black fungus) so I ordered that. Location: forum shopping mall but the entrance is on the front between coffee bean and California pizza kitchen. Small restaurant but cozy. For the side karaage (chicken) looks appetizing and chasiu, gyoza looks normal. It taste like Japanese popcorn chicken that you can get at boba places in California :) It will be much better if it is warmer.Drink: tropical juice looks appetising but I felt cheated cause it's actually minute maid's tropical mixed fruit drink. Overall, will be back :)

Was looking to try a different Ramen restaurant near my hotel.Already tried another restaurant the other day so decided to try Uma Uma.Location is convenient, but has very limited seating capacity.Food was good, but was rather bland compared to other ramen's I have had.Ordered the Uma Uma which was supposed to be spicy, any spice or heat did not register for me.Also portions (mostly noodles) could have been better, the chasu pork was tender and buttery.Not very impressed and found the food to be rather spending in comparison to what you receive (S$20 for ramen & can of iced tea).Other than the hostess, the rest of the wait staff were not very friendly.

Best ramen I've ever had (although that's not to say I've had a lot).For some reason, this place exudes a very authentic air, I almost felt like I was back in Tokyo. Service is also great, and the staff is friendly and approachable.The menu is a simple one-sheet affair, just the way I like it. Order a ramen, a side if you so desire, a drink, and you're done.There are two types of noodles, depending on which ramen you order: the curly springy type and the thin straight kind. Both are very good.Of course, the star of the show is the chasiu -- equal parts lean and fatty meat that just melts in your mouth. Simply heavenly.The chilli oil in the spicy chasiu ramen is a little too much, though.And there's no way you should come to this place without ordering the Suntory Premium Malt beer. Pairing it with the ramen is a dream!

best time to come is when they open at 11.30am!else you might need to get in the queue.small menu but everything done well.portions are smaller than other ramen joints but still enough to fill you up.al dente noodles in rich, thick stock without being over bearing.tender juicy pork slices leave you wanting more, always.mr. iggys himself was here taking my order as they, like the whole service industry, are unable to hire enough help.i detracted 1 star as they charge $3 for green tea.i simply find that too ex.when i gave my feedback about it, i was told it's because it is free flow.SO? do people really come sit in your ramen shop to drink free flow green tea??how much can one drink???

Small cafe with limited seating. I started with a Chasiu bun, which was lovely. The pork was melt-in-your mouth tender and had just a little bit of kick. From there I moved on to the Uma Uma Ramen, which had an amazing miso broth, perfectly cooked noodles, and a very nice half-boiled egg. Nothing fancy here, but definitely a good stop if you're craving noodles.

Food was so so considering they claimed that its a Fukuoka brand. Service was all-right but not warm, perhaps they were short handed considering that we went on a public holiday. The bite side gyoza was good. All others, ramen and chicken karaage was mediocre. Nothing to shout about.

Price is typical of ramen in Singapore but expensive by Japanese standard (50-100% more). Had the Uma Uma ramen ($13 iirc), the char Siew and soft boil egg were satisfying. Can't say the same for the broth, it just lacked a soul. Granted it's not tonkotsu, but something is missing. The lunch set add on of $4 for a drink and free side is well worth it I guess.Verdict: Ok, but not compelling for me to come back again. Good enough for tourist or hotel guests staying in the area who are too lazy to wander further down orchard road.

Love the chasiu rice. Period. Lovely torched flavor, nicely fat-lined.Ramen is a lot thinner than the usual ramen, and still retains a good bite. The uma uma broth is however, not quite my palate. I still prefer my regular pork bone broth.
The spicy chasiu ramen was delicious but they weren't kidding when they said hot. The meat was delicious and the "black fungus" was even tasty. I had it with a side of edamame for s$21

back with hunger vengeance! tried two more dishes today :)1. tonkatsu ramen. came with cha siu, spring onions and sesame seeds. i added egg as ramen is not complete without egg for me. i.must.have.my.eggie. compared to what i had before, i prefer the uma ramen, e soup base just suited my taste buds better. e noodle is still a winner so despite e soup base, i still walloped up e whole bowl.2. mazesoba. came with bamboo shoots, spring onions, leek and egg. this is a dry noodle dish. e sauce is tasty and e egg that came with it is soft boiled and cracked into e bow, unlike e ones served on ramen.  e soba is not e usual white thick soba one usually has, this one is yellow and chewy. unique but i prefer e white udon.argh! i have yet to try e karaage! i need to come back again.

Came to Uma Uma today, as it was close to the hotel I was staying at.I had the Uma Uma Ramen, while my vegetarian colleague had the Mazesoba. We also split an order of Tamago side/appetizer. A decomposition of the Uma Uma ramen:- Uma Uma's ramen style is Hakata-style ramen (thinner, straighter noodles). I had not tried this style before. While the noodles were good, I think my personal preference is for a curlier, thicker, chewier noodle.- The broth was good, a little higher on the lard, but contributed to a rich broth- The cha-siu was good, slightly fatty, not too muchI couldn't be sold on the noodles - it is just a personal preference. This place is worth trying though.

This place sucked. Simple. I love me some good ramen, and while I mainly eat vegetarian now, I do like to have a treat once in a while (but I still don't eat the pork), so I went to this place because it was near me. Not a good idea. I had the Uma Uma ramen and the broth was bland. It had no depth and hardly any distinct flavor. Usually, ramen will fill me up to the brim, but I actually left there still hungry and down $20 for lunch! Not worth it at all! I gave it 2 stars only because the ramen came out fast and there was no line. I know why now.

I tried Japanese ramen in various places, Japan , New York , China , but this particular restaurant  is the best I've ever tried, comparing to authentic Japanese ramen(which is oily), this one has intensive soup that has a taste of southeastern( spacy，sweet and acetic ），

This could be my new favorite ramen place in Singapore, alongside Santouka. I found out that it was started by the same group that runs Iggy's, supposedly Singapore's best restaurant, so we decided to give it a try.The highlight of the meal is the noodles. They are very thin and springy, just the way I like it.I had the tonkotsu broth and it was creamy milky good. Might be too salty though.The chashu was a huge let down. It was way too dry and needed more fat to it.

It wasn't a good day to have gone into try for the first time, since i wasn't feeling good. BUT HERE'S THE CATCH: In spite of having little appetite, the ramen here did loads for me since I downed my bowl of char siu rice and had a couple bites from the boyfriend's ramen. The egg is phenomenal. Runny and perfectly textured as a soft boiled should be. The ramen stock may be a tad too oily for my liking but the flavour is complex and truly Japanese.The rice option was not at all bad if you're not up for a bowl. I like the simplicity of the menu - just ramen or rice. Go try if you haven't but be warned, it's really packed during dinnertime!
Very so so.  Service was average.  The broth was salty but otherwise reasonably planned. The noodles were undercooked.  I don't think I will be coming back.
Prices were quite high for what you get, but the taste was good enough. Had the spicy ramen with the gyoza as a side dish. Atmosphere is average so not ideal for a romantic date.

Somehow my recent visits haven't been as inspiring. I don't think the standard had dropped, but perhaps my taste has changed. With all the ramen-yas that have opened in recent years, I don't think Uma Uma's in the top bracket anymore.

First time means trying to standard bowl, and the Uma Uma ramen had some really thick broth - a little too goopy for my liking, and the concentration meant it was a little salty for me.But that Chasyu. Oh, my drooling Gods of roast meat... that chasyu rocked my socks. Eat the half portion, then finish it off with a small chasyu rice. Yeah, Chasyu.

On a recent business trip to Singapore, I did an informal tour of area ramen restaurants around Orchard and Scots. This place was the winner for me! The ramen broth was magic elixir and made me want to dive in and drink my way out. The noodles, egg, and meat were near perfection. I think I slurped the whole thing down in about 10 minutes. Service was enough--invisible but helpful. But the ramen is the star. Now I'm back home and wishing I had some as I write this.

Not bad. Mazesoba was different. Otherwise I thought the ramen was "standard" fare. The restaurant charges for drinks - including the tea. This tends to push up the total bill. Service was fair by ramen restaurant standards. Given the hype, I would have expected better but maybe I am a little spoiled for choice!

I first found it a little unusual that they serve only 2 types of ramen in the restaurant, but I've gotten used to the idea.  I've tried both their regular and spicy ramen, and though both are good, I will probably opt for the regular one in future.  Their tamago (hard boiled egg with a runny yolk) is absolutely delicious and good mixed with the ramen, or eaten separately. The karaage chicken was a hit with my kids. This is a family friendly restaurant as well, with high chairs and kids' cutlery. They've even catered for baskets so that you can place your bags on the floor safely by your side as you eat. Also, probably to avoid patrons from taking up seats unnecessarily for their bags. All in all, easily one of my favourite ramen joints.
Disappointed! The soup was bland and the topping portions left much to be desired. For the same style and price, Yoshimaru is better!

I didn't know steamboat means hot pot in Singapore. This location is nice and clean (unlike the ghetto China town in NYC...) lots of veggies, quality meat (Kurobuta is awesome), and noodle. Waitress will help you set up your meal, and you prepare your rest of meal...we have to pay and prepare own meal?! LoL. Food is definitely amazing. Location is right on top of Icon center and overlooking the traffic intersection, the view is awesome. Reservation is a must, and there's a time limit so be sure to pace yourself.

Best steamboat in Singapore, but be prepared to shell out good $$ for the meal!Prices here are definitely on the high side, but the food quality is really good and the experience is excellent! Service is pretty decent, and food is served promptly after ordering.The fried beancurd roll is life changing, and the soup base is excellent.Highly recommended!

The restaurant was under the Imperial Treasure chain, and offered hotpot. It was considered one of the most atas outlet in Singapore to offer hotpot. There was also branch in Great World City. This outlet looked quite grand from the entrance. Reservation of 8 people was made a week ago. The staff called up about an hour before the reservation to confirm. The staff showed us to a private room with a great view of Orchard Road. The table was big with 2 induction stoves and could seat 10 pax comfortably. Most hotpot restaurant had sauce counter, but here the staff brought the tray of sauces which consisted of satay sauce, peanut sauce, sesame sauce, sesame seeds, chilli sauce, garlic chilli sauce, sliced green chilli, sliced red chilli, chopped coriander, deep fried chopped garlic, chopped garlic, chopped spring onion) to the table. Each person was charged $2.50++ for the sauces.For soup base, selected Imperial Drunken Chicken Soup 乾隆醉雞窩 ($28++) which tasted slightly bitter in the beginning but was quite flavourful. It came with a bowl of marinated chicken to add into the soup. The chicken was quite tender.Accompanied with the following :King Tiger Prawn 鳳尾蝦 ($18++/ 4pc) - served peeled, big and juicySliced Eel 白鱔片 ($14++) - quite boneySquid 鮮魷魚 ($10++)USA Sliced "Kurobuta" Pork Belly 美國黑豚豬腩肉片 ($14++)Sliced Lamb Shoulder 鮮羊肩片 ($15++)Four Treasure Ball Platter 鮮四寶丸 ($14++/ 8pc) - Fresh Prawn Ball, Fresh Cuttle Fish Ball, Fresh Canton Dace Fish Ball, Fresh Pork BallFresh Prawn Noodle 唧唧鮮虾麵 ($14++) - The staff pipped out the paste from a bag, very tenderFresh Dace Fish Noodle 唧唧鯪魚麵 ($11++) - The staff pipped out the paste from a bag, very tenderAssorted Vegetable 雜菜籃 ($6.80++)Bamboo Pith 野山竹笙 ($20++) - spongy and softAssorted Mushrooms 雜菇籃 ($8.80++)Deep Fried Fish Skin 酥炸魚皮 ($6.80++)Deep Fried Beancurd Skin 炸三秒 ($6.80++) - Everyone's favourite item, had it without soaking in the hotpot, so that it would be light and crispy. Else soaked for a few seconds in hotpot which soaked up the soup easily.Chilled Beancurd 凍豆腐 ($4++) - It was like a more airy and softer version of the dried bean curd, which was able to soak up the soup.Washed down the meal with Cooling Herbal Tea 清熱凉茶 ($12++/jar) and Sweeten Plum 秘制酸梅湯 ($12++/jar)

I would give this a full 5stars based on food taste and experience alone, but will deduct 1 star just becoz it's pricey.The ingredients are really really REALLY fresh and I can't fault them for putting the prices they do, you do get what you pay for.The prawn balls, sotong balls, and all dumplings are handmade and you will definitely know the difference between other steamboat places the immediate instant you take a bite out of it!The soup bases are already very thick even before you pop any stuff into the steamboat. No msg or artificial flavouring taste can be found inside the soup. The porkbone soup is milky and flavourful, the mala is not oily like what u might find elsewhere! You can be sure I'll be back again soon! But this time, I won't order the set, just go alacarte and go straight for all the handmade meat/seafood balls and dumplings and some of those slices of pork and beef! That's where the money's at!I also loved the dip mix which the waitress helped us concocted! Damn you imperial treasure for setting steamboat standards so high, I might never enjoy steamboat anywhere else again! :(

Ah, Imperial Treasure Steamboat.One of my favourite-est steamboat places in Singapore, the quality is excellent, the soups mouth-watering, the prices (can be) eye-watering. While reservations are generally recommended, you're sometimes able to sneak in without one, but I wouldn't gamble on it if you're already set on having dining here.There's no one item that blows me away, but rather just the sense of indulgence, the delicious food, and the soups that time and time again prove to be so much better than most other places.The price makes it hard to give five stars, but if you're the sort that's price insensitive when it comes to food (cough cough join the club) then this place will easily win your heart. And stomach. And hard earned cash.

Located in the 4th floor of Ion, the restaurant is famous for its steamboatWe arrived at 8pm and the restaurant looks fully booked . better to make a reservation.They have  some set menus but we ordered a la carte :- Prawn Balls & Pork Balls, Dumpling- raw Fish- crab- lamb shoulder- chicken  meat- vegetables- soup : good selection Food :  4/5Seafood Freshness is fantasticMeat is meltingService : 5/5Perfect service. Value : 4Quality = pricy

There are many competitors for this kind of steamboat in Singapore in recent months but this still remain my favorite. Some of my favorite items:1. Beef short ribs2. Pork belly3. Cuttlefish noodles (even has bits of ikura in it)4. Prawn or cuttlefish paste5. Fried fish skin (for a 3 second dip so that it is still crispy)6. Any seafood7. Chives dumplings The above are just some of the items that are less common and yummy here. Some other steamboat places don't do it as tasty.

Not been here since Jul 2014 thought the last round was at the somerset branch.  Protocol still the same best to reserve ahead or else no steaming boat for you.  We ordered the usual the USA beef, drunken chicken, the hand made balls (which is a combo of seafood and meat) and lots of veggies.  Got the chicken healthy soup which is so comforting to sip down.  Really not a cheap place and to dine but really better this than do the all you can eat and get poor quality food.

We are big fans of the ImpTreas group, and like ALL their different brands, no month goes by without us visiting one of their outlets. I must say I am not a big amateur of steamboats especially in the hot Singapore weather, so this was our first visit since the restaurant opened.  You can recognise the Imperial Treasure signature: understated and elegant décor, courteous and professional service. The food? It is high-end alright - lots of soup choices, high-quality ingredients, nice sauces - but it's over-the-top for a steamboat restaurant, which at the end of the day is still a family or close-friend affair. It's too pricey, a bit stiff, and after the meal you can still feel the MSG. At least, Haidilao is more fun. So, we'll stick to ImpTreas Teochew, Peking Duck and Shanghai, or the simple Noodles & Congee.

A great option when you have a steamboat craving! The ingredients here are fresh and they have really yummy soup bases too. Another huge plus for me is that it that they are rarely crowded so if you are in a big-ish group and don't want to queue for dinner in ION then just head here.

They have different kinds of soup stocks for us to choose. And likewise for the food. The soup stock is delicious & ingredients are fresh. The only setback is the pricing - way too expensive. Would love to dine in this restaurant every week or thrice a month if the prices are reasonable. Then, it is worth dining at this restaurant.

This is my favorite toastbox, located at B4 @Ion Orchard near the escalator (turn left when heading down the escalator).My usual will be the kaya toast. When I was still a little child, my mom would make her own kaya. My mom's kaya was so good. Kaya is not something I eat very often, I don't know why. I mean after all where can I get kaya when I am in Atlanta? Recent times a friend of mine who seems to love a good kaya toast from Toastbox got me hooked on this simple breakfast.Sometimes I will order the kaya traditional set which comes with a slice of kaya toast, two soft boiled eggs and a beverage. Other times I just order the toast and a beverage from the al la carte section.I wish the staff would crack the eggs for me like those at Ya Kun, but ok I should not be so lazy. The kaya toast here definitely edged out those at Ya Kun.I like this location not only the toast was made perfectly every time, the staffs are always nice. I usually head over here really early and then stroll around and wait for the stores at Ion or other malls to open. There seems to be a very long line around 9-9.30am. One needs patience ;)

I stopped by for a coffee break and the SG$2 kopi-c hit the spot.  The menu is limited with your Singaporean toast varieties.  Aside from convenience to the shopping , I won't go out of my way to come here.

address: 19 Tanglin Road #B1-01/02, Tanglin Shopping Centre Singapore 247909 Singapore
comment: I got to try this ramen shop with my niece who is a big fan.The tonkotsu broth is viscous and almost overwhelms you with umami. The chashu were like slabs of pork roast properly caramelized and accented with little dabs of chili paste. The noodles. Hand made, firm, slightly coarse. The egg had tender whites and a semi molten yolk. The chicken karaage was crispy outside and most inside.In short it is more about fundamental execution than the additives. And this shop delivers in spades.

address: 19 Tanglin Road #B1-01/02, Tanglin Shopping Centre Singapore 247909 Singapore
comment: Pretty good ramen, a longer-than-average menu, and reasonable prices are the pluses if this joint. In addition, you can order your noodles firm (how I like it), 'original', or soft.  However, it can be inconsistent. Sometimes, the char siew can be too chewy, the broth not piping hot, and worse, they don't greet you with energetic screamings! Have the baritones left Bari-Uma?

address: 19 Tanglin Road #B1-01/02, Tanglin Shopping Centre Singapore 247909 Singapore
comment: I'm not an expert on ramen but I know what I like - food that is served fast, is full of flavor (which normally means "spicy"), and is fairly priced. This restaurant hits the mark. The spicy ramen, with $2 add-on for extra noodles, plus a 2-1 beer deal, was perfect for me. In and out in 45 minutes.

address: 19 Tanglin Road #B1-01/02, Tanglin Shopping Centre Singapore 247909 Singapore
comment: nice set up.good japanese feel to the whole place.menu was typical ramen menu with the addition of yakitori.but i'm here to eat ramen!:)i ordered their nori uma ramen $15.50 and added a tamago $1.50.additionally the aburi chashu $9 was too tempting for me to resist.finally a cuppa hot green tea $1.50 while i wait.the declaration of bariuma spirits is proudly displayed for all to see.even though their numbering of these spirits is questionable!?so did they fulfill their promise?1. we will energetically serve hot ramen.yes, they did!1. we will energetically greet with big & cheerful voice.yes, they did!1. we will energetically provide cheerful service.yes, they did!1. we will energetically provide brisk service.yes, they did!1. we will energetically clean up our restaurant till it shines.yes, they did! and that was why i picked up the medicine i dropped on the floor and popped it into my mouth without hesitation!!!:)the spirits were there but was it enough???the noodles are slightly thicker than normal hakata ones.broth was rich but a little too much shoyu for my liking.tamago was perfect!chashu was nicely aburied.i think they are easily a 3.5 star place but for one small issue i had when i was making my payment.the male chinese staff charged me for edamame which i did not order.the female chinese staff came over and did not know how to correct the error.so they SOS the male japanese staff for help.he just said give cash back.so he calculated and the refund amount is $5.29.so he said give him $5.30 back, which was great.but straight away the female chinese staff say no! only give back $5.25!what? never mind, just give me my change:(so after her rounding down of my refund, i should get back $17.60 in total but she gave me $17.55!??????i walked out and felt weird about the amount and went back in to demand for my $0.05!:)it could well have been a 4 star review.BUT after rounding down, this is now a 3 star review!

address: 19 Tanglin Road #B1-01/02, Tanglin Shopping Centre Singapore 247909 Singapore
comment: Oh Ramen Bari-Uma, I've lost track of the people I've recommended you to.I think the one minus to Bari-Uma is its inconsistency, but when they're on song, the charsiu here is amongst the best in Singapore, fatty, smoky, and delicious. They aburi it before serving so there's that extra smokiness for those who like it.Noodles and soup are solid complements to that rock-star charsiu, and the stock is rich, umami, and worth coming back for.I generally find the yakitori not worth mentioning, and to be honest, everything else on the menu is pretty mediocre. Just go for the ramen. Everything else is edible so if you really want to order gyoza or yakitori, go ahead. Just know that it won't be amazing.

address: 19 Tanglin Road #B1-01/02, Tanglin Shopping Centre Singapore 247909 Singapore
comment: I have since returned uncountable times to Bari Uma for my ramen fix. This is my go-to place period. They made a ramen fan out of me and it is hurting mee because no other place makes noodles that thin & soft or soup that rich, spicy and porky. I had Hida Takayama recently in Vancouver and even with all that collagen and made from scratch food I was like....bleh I miss Bari-Uma. Ditto with Ivan ramen and Ippudo in NYC, Tokyo...I know ramen is very subjective, so here are my reasons why this is a fiver:1) The char shu is so freakin' awesome. Charred, melt in your mouth with just enough fat to keep you eating that extra plate of char shu you knew you had to order. Plus they are super generous with portions.2) The noodles is made on the premises and it is always cooked the Japanese equivalent of "al dente". None of it is clumped together and I love that the noodles isn't too thick.3) The broth. Omg. Just taste it yourself. Get the spicy broth.4) Free tamago promo until 31 Dec '14 was awesome. You didn't need the flyer, just a smile.5) Service is pretty good even when the place gets crowded and the food is consistent. I don't mind paying $15-20 for ramen if it is consistently delicious.6) Free ice water. Yes, that's what the Singapore dining experience comes down to.7) Parking is easy. In and out in an hour isn't a problem.

address: 19 Tanglin Road #B1-01/02, Tanglin Shopping Centre Singapore 247909 Singapore
comment: Finally made my way to try the ramen at Ramen Bari-Uma last week. It is under the Kenko Fish Spa/Foot Reflexology at Tanglin Shopping Center, nearer to Orchard Parade Hotel. Unfortunately it is not linked to the main corridor of the building so you need to enter from the outside. Terrible when it is raining as there is no covered walkway from the main building. The menu is simple, similar to Marutama style or Uma Uma Ramen. It is pure ramen with a small selection of side dishes. The specialty is the thick cut char siu in pork broth. All the ramen except one is with pork broth. The exception is ramen in miso. I had the bestseller (I think) which includes a piece of the thick cut char siu, 1 whole egg (pretty big and they do not cut it in half), bamboo shoots and some chopped spring onions. The soup is very rich and thick and porky, great for those who love pork. The miso based soup is surprisingly saltier than the pork broth. The noodle is quite forgettable though. The good thing is they can do a smaller bowl for $2 less. Overall it is nice but not something I will want to travel all the way to have. I think there are many other options around which serve similar quality ramen.

address: 19 Tanglin Road #B1-01/02, Tanglin Shopping Centre Singapore 247909 Singapore
comment: Nothing impressive.  Noodles are not the typical ramen type of noodles and the char siew is really hard to bite into?  Thats a first for me and ive tried quite a few ramen stores already.  Service is basic.  The smell of the fumes from the kitchen fills up the whole restaurant when i visited and thats a turn off for me bc it stains your clothes.

address: 19 Tanglin Road #B1-01/02, Tanglin Shopping Centre Singapore 247909 Singapore
comment: I'm afraid we didn't even get to eat because everything happened before we could even order.  So this review is just based on service attitude.  Restaurant was less than a fifth full when we went at 1pm on a Sunday . Asked to be seated on the side away from the 2x2s in the center aisle but instead get an incredibly rude comment from the waitress to her colleague that we (roughly translated) "die also must sit there". The head waiter came and explained that we were asking to sit where they normally seat 8 (the tables for 2 are joined together). Don't want this to sound like a long whine but in the end,  this is another restaurant with inflexible seating policies and a bad egg (no pun intended) waitress who (denied she said those words) should be in another line of work. We made our choice,  left to eat at Ippudo instead across the street and were much happier for it.

address: 19 Tanglin Road #B1-01/02, Tanglin Shopping Centre Singapore 247909 Singapore
comment: Decent place for a quick bite near Orchard, if you want to escape the crowd and chaos. We went into the PS Cafe (long line at 2 pm) and California Pizza Kitchen (the place smelled funny) nearby before settling here, and were grateful for this option.I had the ramen in spicy broth on two visits. It was a lot spicier on one visit than the other. They aren't stingy on meat like some other ramen joints in town -- I like the chunky pieces of meat. Broth is quite thick. and on the oily side. If you are on a diet, skip it ;)At 20 bucks (a bowl of ramen and a cup of green tea, no refill), it ain't cheap but it's similar to other ramen restaurants in town.

address: 19 Tanglin Road #B1-01/02, Tanglin Shopping Centre Singapore 247909 Singapore
comment: If you are a fan of ramen this place is worth a try.we had the special which was the char su and pork broth w egg. Taste was good. Broth was soooo tasty, noodle portion was just right, i had to order extra just to keep me full.

address: 19 Tanglin Road #B1-01/02, Tanglin Shopping Centre Singapore 247909 Singapore
comment: Very under-rated ramen joint. Few options but most offerings executed well. My favourite is the spicy ramen, it has a real kick. Great thick charshiu which has been torched for extra crisp on the outside. Heavenly and hits the spot every time!

address: 19 Tanglin Road #B1-01/02, Tanglin Shopping Centre Singapore 247909 Singapore
comment: Yet another ramen joint has sprung up in Singapore - Ramen Bari-Uma, located at the basement of Tanglin Shopping Centre (NOT Tanglin Mall), replacing the Bombay Woodlands restaurant. Apparently it's a chain of ramen joints from Hiroshima.The Travelling Hungryboy gave this place a very good review, stating that it has fast propelled into his top 3 ramen places in Singapore, along with Menya Mushashi and Tonkotsu King. Well, since I loved the latter two, I had to try this place out for myself.I visited at circa 9.30pm on a Sunday night and boy was it empty - the only other diners were 4 Japanese. I ordered the Ajitama ramen (their specialty) to see what the fuss was about. My ramen soon came - and boy it was good! The broth was reminscent of Menya Musashi's - thick, savoury, full of umami, not too salty, and with a bit of that smoky flavour, although not as smoky as Menya's. Good, although I have to say I prefer Tonkotsu King's soup, which is a bit more complex. The pork on the other hand was better than Tonkotsu King's - it was charred nicely and had that char-grilled flavour. Overall a very good Ramen joint in Singapore - top 3 for tonkotsu. (8/10)

address: 19 Tanglin Road #B1-01/02, Tanglin Shopping Centre Singapore 247909 Singapore
comment: I've been here twice and can say that this is my favorite ramen restaurant in Singapore
Pleasant décor, friendly service, prices are high for the location, but food is hit-or-miss, so I wouldn't go back!!

Pano Kato is not a place that's value for money. The high price point is not justified by the quality and taste of food served. We ordered the carbonara, pizzas and chicken skewers. They were average and nothing to shout about. The servers were swift and polite but I would only return with the use of entertainer or deals.

As anticipated, the restaurant is beautiful and has good ambience. It also has a reasonably decent deal for dinner, where you can get a main course and a buffet of starters and desserts for $73+ (the St Regis Connoisseur Dinner). They also come under the AMEX discount scheme which was another reason why my friend and I decided to give it a try last night.However, the problem lies with the service and some of the food. I am not one to nitpick when it comes to service but we were served both our drinks and main course wrongly. It did ruin our dinner a fair bit, especially in light of the considerable waiting time for dishes. To their credit, they did try to make up for it by offering us wine on the house.As for the food, the oven roasted black angus prime rib was arguably average and the pan seared prawns and scallops were so-so as well. We did enjoy the desserts though and the wide range of skewered food for the chocolate fondue fountain is noteworthy. It is unfortunate that this place turned out to be somewhat of a letdown. There is certainly room to improve.

The cafe at the st. Regis which is where the hotel serves buffet breakfast. We tried the place on our staycation here recently. The food is decent though a bit of a hit or miss depending on what you order. Service is very sloppy and on one of the days our breakfast took over an hour to arrive. You can tell that the staff is stretched. But at the st. Regis you expect a higher standard of service which is missing.

Beautiful setting, albeit not very intimate, even if you sit in a semi-private alcove. Lunch is a half buffet, where you choose among 5-or-so main courses. The whole meal (appetisers, mains, and desserts) was good, but no innovative or memorable dishes. But again, st $58++, it's not that expensive either. In the neighbourhood, I much prefer 190 at Four Seasons Hotel - more cozy décor, many more food choices at comparable quality.

Let's talk about the good things first. Place is beautifully set up as one would expect of the St Regis with the mesmerizing decor and general 'luxury' feeling of the place certainly set a great ambiance of something special is about to happen. Plates were cleared, water /wine was topped up, cutlery was replaced without being requested, and complimentary parking tickets were given immediately. Also, I was impressed with one of the lady staff there who's very knowledgeable about wines. She recommended several and we tried 3 different wines to pair our food with including a really good dessert wine. All the wines served were quite good for the price. We even thought that she's a sommelier, I enquired her about it and turned out she's in the middle of becoming one. They don't offer a lot of wines but seems like the ones they have are pretty much curated by the experts and the lady also said that the wine list will be updated in about a week time. The 4 courses which served at the table were such a huge letdown. Sure, they were presented really well but not as delicious as it looked. The entree, crayfish salad wrapped in smoked salmon tasted like what anyone could easily make at home that would be perfect for your lunch box. The salad was basically just thousand island dressing and a little crayfish meat. Next we had the sweet corn velouté with pan seared hokkaido scallop, black truffle purée and crustacean oil. After the entree, to be honest, I tried really hard to lower my expectation and to my surprise the quality of food kept going downhill. The velouté was really disappointing (needed additional spices/salt/pepper to liven it up), watery, couldn't taste the corn (only could taste the black truffle) and at this rate a baby food would taste better than that. The scallop was thick but dry.We had the option to choose between duck breast with foie gras and oven-baked cod fillet for our third meal. I chose cod but my two dining companions chose duck. I was glad that I picked the right choice because the duck was not properly cooked, hence it had a really unpleasant smell that I'm very sensitive of but I guess the foie gras helped to make up for the smell. The cod was a tad dry on the outside but still edible on the inner part, loved the lobster bisque underneath the cod though. Lastly, the dessert part. There were 3 mini chocolate cakes and I think two of them had a touch of 'Valrhona Chocolate Mousse' but when I tasted it, it's nothing Valrhona at all. Omg, it seriously tasted like the mousse was made of cheap cocoa powder, something a 5th grader would use to bake their first cake. So, because of that I barely touched my dessert. I'm usually not this brutal but I couldn't fathom my sorrow for having to waste my time and calories eating those miserable food.Overall, the food served was certainly appetizing to see but nothing really special in terms of taste, is it because it's restaurant week and they have cheap price tag ($58++) so they had to sacrifice a crucial thing like flavor??? I don't know. I'll probably only be back for the drinks. This place definitely has an exceptional ambience and service but food was somewhat disappointing.

All my meal attempts at Brasserie Les Saveurs were pleasant - nothing screwed up - but not utterly out of this world. Believe it or not, this is the only restaurant proved to be a cut above the rest in the 6-star rated  tavern, with Yan Ting being the runner up. But it makes me wonder what infallible strategies the business have employed to make it sustainable in the long run when I see a fading crowd, the dining room barely filled with 15 guests on a Saturday evening. Strong bottom line or just keeping afloat, either way, it should least worry me, as long as they still served me quality food with exceptional service. Yes, their Maître d' is expecting my arrival and receives me cordially.I was here for a round of dinner, a birthday celebration sort with a group. The idea of sitting right in front of the Live band sounds groovy but turned out ill-considered. I will relate why as it goes along.The opening ceremony wasn't at full blast but one that's solemn. Arrived in pairs, the wait staff sent messages from the Chef of Cuisine - Alexandre Lozachmeur, who aims to amuse us and that was why it has been called the "Amuse Bouche". Lovely duck confit, slowed cooked to yield a tender (not meltingly) texture and then meticulously tear into humble strips to feed the guests. Sits atop a bed of lentils evenly dressed in light vinaigrette, the duck meat shines in the dark and becomes a bit more stimulating with chives decor.Well, the messengers have left us quite a while, giving us room to handle the mouth amuser and avoid eavesdropping behind the partition. But I know we were been observed from a distance, that was how they were described as "discreet & attentive"! I hope our laughter didn't radiate the whole dining room and thanks to the Live music, our serious conversation turned into a few moments of chuckle, then ventured into some senseless jokes when we interpret each other wrongly - because we were muffling away as the band plays in the background. So, my end-of-day conclusion was right - I made a poor judgement, I chose the wrong table but it was fun, anyway. We turned silent when we noticed the messengers were back in the hall. Marching towards us, this time, they delivered the Terrine de Foie Gras.Being popular and well-liked, this duck foie gras came to me in a terrine form. I took a few twinkles before slather a part of it on my brioche toast. Undeniably good, very rich and buttery. I am not a fan of this "fat-liver" species, as I find the force-feeding breeding technique disturbing and so I could only consumed a portion of it. I know most people cannot resist its delicate taste and although this is a duck version, it was less gamey and melting, not losing its shine when placed side by side with those goose cousins. The braised figs are not to be missed. They were cushy, naturally sweet with a sharp sourish note fathered by the balsamic vinegar decked within the salad, very refreshing.Then the soup arrived. It seems the chef is getting a little impatient, sending us his new message more quickly by now. Never mind about the pace, I could stop them when appropriate. Watching them drowning the pancetta in my plate with that creamy Chestnut Veloute was so tantalizing. The engagement was rhythmic with chestnut bits, then bacon fragments, followed by the smooth and velvety chestnut creme whirling in my mouth - sensational. I have always loved the veloute here, either the pumpkins or spinach, they were all good. The volume was kept reasonable, hence it wouldn't weigh you down. But some in my group did find it slightly too creamy, so its up to one's tolerance.This braised short rib is prime! Every one agreed that this is the key catalyst to the night's event. Unbelievably dissolved in the mouth. The well-marbled beef cut has been braised in red wine, producing an ultra-tender; barely visible texture that rewards me with mouthful of rich winery flavour. The potato purée smeared in part with tapenade sauce was buttery and smooth, not too complex but very heart-warming. The modern beef cube was truly a refined piece, I was completed sold.At last, the chef has send us his love note. His 2-piece poetry appears romantic and impressive. The Hazenut ice-cream was chocolatey, not overly sweet though I'd prefer some good bitter ones. It's tactical and trying hard to pair up the two, but none was psychoactive. Not entirely weak, at least that slab of milk chocolate mass was worth remembering for its caramel taste highlighted with a hint of salt that average out the otherwise cloying feel. And the lusty segment was gently carpeted by a praline sable which was made sandy and mimics the taste of a shortbread but faint. This masterpiece was striving hard to win me over but I was not attracted by it, sadly. Not complaining but this Chocolat au Lait et Noisettes was anemic among the rest.

As part of the St. Regis Arts Celebration held from 29 Jul to 4 Aug 2013, I was invited to the exclusive preview of The American Kaleidoscope special menu created by Chef Chris Kurth of The US Grant, A Luxury Collection Hotel, San Diego at Brasserie Les Saveurs. The 5-course Dinner is based on Chef Chris' interpretations of iconic American favorites.For $188 per pax, guests can look forward to a degustation dinner paired with boutique American wines during this period. The wine pairing changes every night so go check out the list. I enjoyed the Beringer's Chardonnay very much.The Baked Red Beet Root was absolutely delish. This was certainly my favorite course. I love the mix of flavors and texture in this one. A light sourish Ricotta wrapped in sweet and crisp Feuille Brick Tarragon. An airy and innovative Chive meringue with arugula. Pieces of juicy sweet beetroot and some California dates with sea salt. Truly amazing dish.Second course was the San Diego 'Mock Turtle Soup' which is made from braised US Black Angus Beef and Tongue to replace the actual turtle which was used in the past at the San Diego US Grant hotel. I was told that tongue has a similar texture to turtle (which i have never had). Robust flavors in this fish stock dish.  Next was the Pan seared Albacore Tuna. I'm not a huge fan of tuna but this was palatable enough. The meat was simply done and i could taste the freshness of it. The powdered brown butter was subtle but went very well with the fish. Oregon Pinot noir reduction and pickled strawberries and a purée of cilantro and sweet onion garnished and added interesting flavors to the dish. The Charcoal-Grilled Colorado Lamb Saddle was my other favorite. I've never had lamb that is so simply done and yet tastes this amazing. Chef used a Mediterranean style of pairing with the sweet dried fruit preserves which worked extremely well. We concluded lunch with the Almond Brown Butter cake with a milk confiture and apricot sorbet with caramelized white chocolate ice cream and black cherry beignet. The dessert was on the whole rather sweet except for the tangy sorbet and the lovely beignet which was like a tempura cherry. Nevertheless, great dense and moist texture from the cake and lovely caramel white choc ice cream.To enjoy the celebration in its entirety, you should get a seat at the St. Regis Midnight Supper, the gala dinner held at Brasserie Les Saveurs on 2nd August. This includes the front row seating at The Whiffenpoofs recital and the 5 course degustation menu by Chef Chris, complete with wine pairing. The St. Regis Singapore will be donating S$100 to UNICEF for every seat purchased at $288. Support a good cause anyone?

Our friends recommended us this restaurant located in the Tanglin Mall, and it's delicious. One of the better QUALITY thai dining in Sing, which is hard to find. I dare to say that it was similar in taste and quality to some of the dishes at the actual Blue Elephant royal thai cuisine we tried in Bangkok, Thailand. But this is Singapore, and any of the quality dishes come with a hefty price tag, even if it's thai food. So expect to spend around $100 for a party of two, without any drinks. While we love other thai dishes, we just stuck with our typical favorite:Shrimp Pad thaiChicken Pad SiewPineapple Fried RiceMango Sticky Riceseems like a lot to share between the two, but the portions are tiny and we were scraping the plates for more. Mango sticky rice dessert was just okay- we still haven't found one that parallels the taste we fell in love with in Thailand.  overall, perfect place for a regular date night or couple dates!

The food is very good. There are some unusual dishes rarely found in Thai restaurants overseas, and execution is quite masterful. Service is courteous and competent. What makes this not a top-end restaurant as it aims to be and as reflected in its pricing is the very dated décor, more comfortable than smart.

Food is ok, but not as good as it would be for this kind of price. The starters like spring rolls are better than the main courses like fried fish and curries beefs and chicken.. Overall, quite mediocre.
My favourite Thai restaurant in town- quiet and peaceful. Love the a la carte buffet lunch! Wide variety to choose from and good quality!

Ate here recently with coworkers and the appetizers and food were very good. It is conveniently located in the Tanglin Mall. The service was fine. Enjoyed the food much better than the food at Jim Thompson which is a highly rated Thai restaurant in Singapore. It was better food and a better value.

One of my favorite places to have Thai Cuisine while staying in Singapore.  My favorite Tom Yum Goon soup among many other such as the spicy green curry and pineapple rice.  We were given a taste of some durian flavored dessert.  It was the first time I ever tried durian and it was interesting let's just say I will not try again. . I highly recommend this restaurant located in the Tanglin Shopping Center on Orchard Rd, walking distance from the Hilton & most hotels there On Orchard.

Patara is located on upper level of Tanglin mall,  it is considered upscale Thai but that has to do a lot with the decor and ambience.  The food was good but not out of this world good. Thai green curry, soft shell crabs with mango, spring rolls and Tom yum soup were on the table for me.  Enjoyed it all.

This is a review of a dinner date at Patara Fine Thai Cuisine.It is a beautiful room with numerous ornate appointments.  This is a true Thai fine dining setting.tinyurl.com/bb7lvqstinyurl.com/b3qaxmvThe service was extremely good.  Throughout the meal, they were very attentive and helpful.  The meal proceeded at a nice unrushed pace.The food ranged from good to very good.Goong Thod Saweay (A combination of deep fried prawn in crispy rice vermicelli, chicken and vegetable spring rolls and golden pouches) - Each of these were good. But the golden pouches are the ones that stood out.  Wonderful little pouches hiding away a small succulent prawn.tinyurl.com/bb5xe5pHoy Shell (Seared sea scallops on half shell with chili lime dressing) - These were very perfectly prepared scallops with a touch of spice and citrus.  It was also a beautifully presented dish.tinyurl.com/a8rhvbvTom Yum Goong/Talay (Authentic hot spicy and sour prawns soup with Thai herbs, mushrooms, and sliced of young coconut meat) - This was a good Tom Yum.  My date requested it be mild.  I did not object.  So, it wasn't as super spicy as some versions of this soup.  The ingredients all came together very well.  I particularly enjoyed the mushrooms.  The prawns could have been a touch more tender. But, this is often the case with Tom Yum.  They keep cooking in the soup.  I had hoped it would be served in the traditional way. However, instead, we were simply each brought a bowl.tinyurl.com/bgqfce9See Krong Kae Yang (Pan-seared lemongrass marinated rack of lamb served with papaya salad and crisp sweet rice rolls) - This was a lamb lovers lamb.  It had a strong potent flavour.  The meat was tender.  This was another wonderfully presented dish.  The rice rolls were quite a refreshing balance to the strong flavour of the lamb.tinyurl.com/b5c2pb5Gang Daeng Gai (Thai chicken red curry with coconut heart and baby eggplants) - This was a very good curry.  The chicken was tender.  There was lots of depth of flavour. Every once in awhile, I would run into a pepper.  The heat went so well with the sweetness of the curry.  It was my favourite dish of the evening.tinyurl.com/beym4nsKhao Phad Poo (Fried rice with crabmeat and spring onions) - My date selected their fried rice with crabmeat.  it was pretty good.  It melded well with the other dishes.Thai Coconut - She enjoyed it so much that she had two of them.  As for me, I had 7-Up.tinyurl.com/a2mxgg5Receipt (Dinner for 2) - $204.80tinyurl.com/agxsz9mWith Thai restaurants, there is often an expectation with price.  It is often viewed as a lower priced meal.  However, most Thai restaurants do not provide an experience that works well for a date or special evening.  They tend to be hurried meals with little service.  The food is often amazing but the meal is over in 30 minutes.  The food at Patara is good and, at times, very good.  But it is not better than many hole in the wall Thai restaurants.  The presentation is a step up.  In service and ambiance, Patara delivers beyond most of these and creates a dining experience.  I feel Patara delivers an experience worthy of the premium.Overall - This was a nice evening meal.  The ambiance and service live up to the expectations of fine dining.  The food was consistently well prepared and beautifully presented.

Made 2 visits this month hoping for some good Thai food but since they came under the management of CreativeEats, the standard has really dropped. Their baked seafood glass noodles was too salty to eat and only had prawns. Pineapple rice did not even come in a pineapple and was a tad too sweet ( maybe in my opinion).  We also ordered the Morning Glory at S$19 and that came out very badly stir-fried and too small a portion. Also was very, very salty. The dessert platter was also disappointing with 2 pieces of dragonfruit, some pieces of melon and 2 pieces of Thai rice cakes. Thai fish cakes also tastes like it was from a frozen packet.We knew not to order the Tom Yum Soup which was at best mediocre. Staff were generally friendly, which was the saving grace but service time was too long. Our simple dinner for 2 took 2.5 hours from start to finish. Good quality and experience not worth the prices. Probably my last visit here.

The set meals are pricey but give you a chance to sample several little bits of multiple chef's recommended dishes. The Green curry with beef was spicy and went well with the fragrant jasmine rice. I also loved the creamy coconut chicken and mushroom soup. The Thai tea is a must have - so pretty you can't stop staring at the glass. For dessert give the coconut sticky rice a skip and have the mango cheesecake instead.

fine cuisine but not so fine service. No service to speak of - just left menus on our table , had to alert them to say we were ready to order . After we had finished , they cleared the plates but did not wipe down the table . We were left to chat .... No one came to asked if we might be interested in having some desserts etc ... Even when we asked for the bill it didn't occur to server to ask if we wanted coffee . Overall quite pathetic standard of service ... But then again this is so typical of most local establishments . In the end I asked to see the Manager ... Who looked like she just left school !! I said to minus the 10% service charge from the bill which she obliged. As part of the "service recovery ", we were offers two $50 vouchers ( each for a min $120 spend on next visit ). Won't be back in a hurry ....

A-OK Thai foodPatara was probably one of the first Thai restaurants I visited in Singapore, and for that, I have pretty fond memories of it. The other outlet at City Hall has closed, so this is the only one left at this time.The setting is pretty elegant, in tasteful vibrant gold and dark wood, and the dishes come in gorgeous intricate plates. Expect all the staples that you would normally enjoy, including spicy tom yum soup (be sure to make your chilli tolerance known), and mango sticky rice. The best dishes are probably the wonderful olive fried rice, with bits of kaffir lime leaves in it, grilled jumbo prawns with lemongrass sauce, and roast duck curry - always a treat with hot fragrant rice. The service staff seem genuinely pleasant, a good indication of the quality of the Creative Eateries group (which this restaurant belongs to). Their sister restaurant is the more casual Bangkok Jam chain of diners.

This used to be my favorite place for Thai food in Singapore, but after having been disappointed with their service in more than one recent occasion, I can no longer recommend this place to anyone anymore.

Tucked away innocuously in the predominantly ex-pat Tanglin mall, Patara's charms may not be evident to those who think that the best food is found only in the high rent downtown district.  As is the case with most higher end Singaporean food establishments, the service is friendly and helpful.  The olive fried rice is superb and the spices and curries are complex in their heat and flavours.  We had the prawns as well as the eggplant dishes, all superb.  Do not miss the mango and warm sticky rice.  It's not cheap though, so be warned. Turns out Patara has branches all over the world, but the one in Singapore is well worth the visit.

They've got a good mango salad with soft shell crab, one of their signature dishes. However the other 2 other signature dishes we ordered were rather disappointing and certainly weren't worth the high prices. Water also comes at premium as they serve you glass bottled Evian water.

my favorite thai restaurant in singapore.pricey, but the food is excellent.the prawn cakes are amazing, so is the tom yum soup, and the mee krob, and the pad thai, and the jumbo prawn.for dessert, the sticky rice with durian and vanilla ice cream is a must have, if you love durian. :)don't bother with the red ruby. it's fancy and pretty, but it's not worth the price tag. (ps. i just looked at their menu online...they don't list the durian dessert anymore. oh no.)

Excellent Patara quality that one comes to expect. Whilst the location and interior cannot compare to the London restaurants the food is excellent. In particular the Spicy Tuna Tartar. Strongly recommend it.

this is the best thai food in town. great taste, great chef, great service and great prices. one star less only for the location between the bars and clubs in orchard towers. its not the girls but be prepared to have a late dinner with all the drunken western expats there. this restaurant is my fav, i go often all the way from clementi to eat there. if the owner decides one day to move it to a nice location in east coast, i would even travel the double distance to eat there

Slightly underwhelming as compared to the other thai restaurant on the same floor considering its fame. The crispy omelette was ok but the fried wings did not taste very good. Good ordering system via qr code/web site.

Had dinner here yesterday, the fried pineapple rice with beef was pretty good however the portion of meat could have been more. Tried the raw prawns with spicy seafood chilli too. Delicious but it is definitely not for those who cannot handle spicy food. Would definitely recommend trying the raw prawns if you are there! It opens until 3am which is good for people who frequent orchard towers until late and are looking for good supper.

Had Late lunch here yesterday! On recommendation from a friend... Damn Tastey! tucked away in the back corner of the famous towers... Thai family cooking, really the best thai i have had, the real stuff... green curry is the way it should be. Do try with high recommendation! opens late apparently, but not sure what time, I was there at 4pm

address: #B1-07 Orchard Towers 400 Orchard Rd Singapore 238875 Singapore
comment: I was told to check out Isle Eating House in Orchard Towers for some seriously good local nosh. I must confess I was half skeptical as I have tried the economy rice stuff at Isle Cafe in Tanglin Shopping Centre and Far East Plaza, and both were ok, not something you will salivate or dream about. Isle Eating House has more variety as it encompasses 3 stalls in 1 location. Besides the economy rice section where the dishes look more appetizing, there is a stall selling roast meat with rice and another stall selling cooked noodles (bak chor mee, mee rebus, mee siam, prawn noodles soup etc). In the afternoon, after 230 pm, it will also sell char kway teow and other fried dishes. Basically it has everything local you can think of under one roof. The shop space is just 1 unit, so there are not many tables for dining in. But there is another Isle Cafe a few meters away, just out the food court, where you can probably bring your food there to eat.I ordered the prawn noodles soup to go (I was told the soup version is much better than dry) at the cashier, got a number and waited. It was quite fast and it was packed in a big plastic container. The prawn bee hoon mee soup was absolutely stunning. For just $3.80 (very affordable price in expensive Orchard Road), you get 3 whole prawns, 4 thick slices of meat and some thick slices of fish cake with a very generous serving of yummilicious prawn-y and a bit spicy broth. It was totally worth the walk to Orchard Towers. Other recommended dishes would be the mee rebus and mee siam. Oh, and the prawn noodle soup is only available on Tuesday and Friday.

address: Unit.No. R1 Tasty Food Court B1-17 Tanglin Mall 163 Tanglin Road Singapore 247933 Singapore
comment: Komala's Deli (Komala's Restaurant) is great for a quick take-away Indian vegetarian lunch if you in the Tanglin area.This branch is part of the food court in Tanglin Mall, at the left side of the entrance. You cannot miss it.There are a lot of seats if you want to eat there, but it gets very crowded during lunch. There will be small packets of tissue placed on empty tables. These are how the fauna mark their territory around here. Do not sit at tables marked like this! At around 2pm, the food court magically clears out. MAGIC!!!Service is fast and efficient, stand in line and while waiting for your turn, look at the pictures of food (and prices) and decide what you want.My personal favourites are:Paper Masala Dosai - This is important, when you order, stress the word "PAPER". Or you'd end up with the normal dosai, not as good as the paper version. The paper dosai is a thin and crisp and light and subtle crepe. Made out of fermented rice flour and lentils, the taste is tangy and surprisingly light!! Order the paper dosai and the cook will expertly create a super sized crispy crepe for you, put a large dollop of masala potato in the middle and fold it into a perfect cylinder or cone. Be careful, the dosai is usually bigger than the tray (TRAY) it is served on, so fold the precious cargo inwards before you walk! SGD$4.70Bhattura - A large football sized fried bread, but don't worry, it's just filled with air! It comes with a very good chickpea curry gravy and a wedge of lemon. Be ready for rude children and adults to stare and point at you when you carry it back to your table to eat. (See pic!) SGD$5Vadai - For a snack, grab a couple of vadai. These small doughnut shaped savoury snacks are made of lentils and dhal. Deep fried to perfection, it can keep crispy for hours! Well, at least till tea. (Which will be soon! Yum!) SGD$1.50Everything else is worth trying, the rice sets are good value too.

address: 1 Scotts Rd #04-20/21 Shaw Centre Singapore 228208 Singapore
comment: Surprisingly 8 Korean BBQ originated from the heart of Korea Town in Los Angeles, California, America. Its first outlet in Singapore was opened in The Central. Recently in September, it had opened its second outlet in the recently upgraded Shaw Centre. The second outlet was much smaller compared to its first outlet with only indoor dine in area. The tables here were arranged to seat 4 each, each with 2 stoves, one for grilling, while another for stews. Check its stools, where one could lift up the top, to put bag in.Iced Yucha Tea ($4++) The drink was commonly known as citron tea, was a traditional Korean tea (herbal tea) made from the citrus fruit yuzu. It was light with a slight citrus taste.Passionfruit Makgeolli ($35++)Organic House Brew Makgeolli slushed with Passionfruit It tasted milky with a slight citrus taste.We were served pickled radish, boiled spinach, and boiled potato as Banchan (side dishes). The plain looking potato was peaked up with a sauce made with syrup and soya sauce.Korean Grilled Squid ($18++) It was grilled with butter on the spot, served with a mixture of soyu and mayonnaise. The squid tasted tender and bouncy.8 Colours Set ($98++)8 Flavours of Pork Belly from Mangalitza (Mahn-ga-leet-za) Hog, a rare pig of Hungarian origin.Original/ Wine/ Curry/ Garlic/ Miso/ Herb/ Kalbi/ Red Pepper Paste -- at 8 Korean BBQ Shaw Centre.Interestingly the meat was covered with a sheet to prevent oil spattering. Out of the 8 different flavours, the garlic flavoured one tasted the strongest. The rest seems to be similar in taste. The kimchi and marinated bean sprouts were served on the lower end of the griller, as it soaked up the flavourful oil released out by the fatty pork belly when grilling. This gave the usual vegetables an enhanced flavour. Army Stew ($24++) It was instant noodles served with luncheon meat and sausages. Felt that the version here was a tab plain.Kimcheese Fried Rice ($20++) Tossed with raw egg, cheese, bonito fish flakes, which gave it an umami taste. Everyone's favourite.Seafood Pancake ($20++)Served with soyu, it tasted average.Pork Belly Kimchi Stew ($18++) Looked simple, the pork belly was tender and smooth.Wild Mushroom Set ($18++) I was surprised how good it smelt as the garlic butter melted on the mushrooms. The golden mushrooms soaked the flavour of the butter rather well.Choco Loco ($18++) Nutella strips hidden under a hill of melt-in-your milky shaved ice, topped with chocolate powder, brownie cubes, chocolate sauce, chocolate ice cream, marshmallow, and crunchy chocolate balls.Bibimbap Bingsu ($28++)Served in bibimbap stone pot, the shaved milk ice was topped like a rainbow with rainbow-coloured mini marshmallows, crushed oreo, toasted almond slices, chopped grapes, chopped strawberries, red bean paste, granola, chopped kiwi and peach. It looked so pretty that we did not remember about the sauce for it. Looked great and tasted great!If you are coming with a group of friends, don't forget to order Seoul Train.Grab a spoon and hit the first shot glass lightly to activate the Seoul train!

address: 1 Scotts Rd #04-20/21 Shaw Centre Singapore 228208 Singapore
comment: Unlike the different pork offerings here, the beef (we ordered the Argentine and US ones) are NOT marinated, so they taste a little bland for me. The 'stew' is nice, but not the yummiest kimchi soup we've had. Very dedicated Filipina service staff. Restaurants located on the upper floors of Shaw Centre need a lot of luck to succeed. Quality alone is not sufficient as this is such a low-traffic area. No wonder they're called 8 Korean, Lucky 8, Small Plates (La Taperia), etc.

address: 1 Scotts Rd #04-20/21 Shaw Centre Singapore 228208 Singapore
comment: The best korean bbq in SG. Love the meat and the service is really good. The side dishes was not as many but the star is the pork. The soup is also good with refillable soup base. We always go back here whenever we want to pigout.
